title: Simulation and Experimental Study on the Coupling Characteristics of Shielded Multiconductor Cables Under HEMP Environment
authors: Mingmin Zhao, Zeyuan Mu, Luxing Zhao, Lei Gao, Jiahao Zhu, Peng Zhao, Yang Meng
abstract: This article presents the coupling characteristics of shielded multiconductor cables under high-altitude electromagnetic pulse (HEMP) numerically and experimentally. The numerical analysis is employed to study the coupling characteristics of a representative shielded multiconductor cable under different conditions first. The impacts of cable wiring configurations, cable parameters, and propagation direction of incident electromagnetic waves are given. Then, a horizontally polarized hybrid EMP simulator is constructed, and some radiated tests are conducted to validate the conclusions obtained in numerical analysis. The results show that the open circuit of the shielding layer results in the core wire coupling to the same high voltage as the shielding layer, while grounding the shielding layer significantly reduces the coupling voltage on core wires. In addition, increasing cable height, cable length, elevation angle, and azimuth angle all result in an amplification of the level of coupled current. The experimental outcomes of the radiated tests validate the effectiveness of the simulation and the precision of the numerical analysis results.

title: DOMDRL: A Multi-Objective Meta-DRL Algorithm for Dependency-Aware Video Offloading in Vehicular Edge Networks
authors: Honghai Wu, Bowen Ji, Huahong Ma, Kaikai Deng, Jianping Gao, Ling Xing
abstract: Real-time analytics on video data requires substantial computational resources and high energy consumption, and computational offloading has emerged as a promising solution to support such resource-intensive services. Nevertheless, most of the existing research overlook the resource dependencies induced by object-level correlations in dependent video processing tasks. To address this challenges, we propose a theoretical framework employing a novel scaling factor to model resource dependencies among video tasks, enabling accurate estimation of computation and transmission demands for video blocks with multiple interdependent objects. In contrast to conventional single-objective methods, we formulate the problem as a constrained multi-objective optimization and present a decomposition-based meta-deep reinforcement learning (DOMDRL) framework to balance competing objectives. The proposed approach employs meta-learning to train a meta-model, which is then fine-tuned through limited gradient updates to construct the Pareto front. Simulation results based on real-world datasets demonstrate that DOMDRL reduces average task delay by approximately 9.32%, decreases energy consumption by around 6.26%, and improves video analytics accuracy by about 18.9% compared to state-of-the-art task offloading methods.

title: Compact Wideband Circularly Polarized Magneto-Electric Dipole Antenna Array
authors: Yurong Sun, Quanyuan Feng, Yan Wen, Xiao Gao
abstract: In this paper, a compact wideband circularly polarized (CP) magneto-electric (ME) dipole antenna array is proposed. The CP unit is fed by a microstrip line and coupled to the upper substrate through irregular slots. The radiation patch comprises a pair of L-shaped notched patches and a pair of rectangular patches, forming an electric dipole, while the grounded metal via and ground plane establish a magnetic dipole. By combining the slot and radiating patch design, the electric field vectors of the antenna constitute energies with the same amplitude and a phase difference of 90°, resulting in a circular polarization. Moreover, the CP units are configured in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> sequential rotation array, incorporating a metal cavity constructed with substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) to distribute energy more evenly across each CP unit. This approach preserves the wideband and stable radiation characteristics of the ME dipole unit while enhancing the axial ratio bandwidth (ARBW) and gain. HFSS simulations demonstrate that the antenna array achieves an impedance bandwidth (IBW) of 27 % at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40.3-52.9 \text{GHz}$</tex> and an ARBW of 20.8 % at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$39.3-48.4 \text{GHz}$</tex>, with a stable and flat gain over the entire frequency band and a peak gain of 13.4 dBic. The antenna array exhibits stable radiations in both horizontal and vertical planes, cross-polarization discrimination (XPD) exceeding 17 dB, and low side-lobe levels (SLL). The proposed circularly polarized antenna array can meet the demands of high bandwidth, low interference and high resolution, especially in the high-speed mobile environment, and its directional beam and circularly polarized characteristics can greatly improve the reliability and stability of communication.

title: Fuzzy Ellipsoidal Clustering Incorporating Compactness and Separation of Clusters
authors: Daichi Machida, Katsuhiro Honda, Seiki Ubukata, Akira Notsu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: Although Fuzzy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$c$</tex>-Means (FCM) clustering is effective for identifying compact clusters by minimizing within-cluster variances, it often fails to distinguish adjacent or overlapping clusters due to its sensitivity to random initialization and lack of separation awareness. To address this issue, Fuzzy Compactness and Separation (FCS) was proposed as an extension that incorporates both compactness and inter-cluster separation into the objective function. In this paper, we propose a novel fuzzy clustering algorithm based on ellipsoidal prototypes that explicitly considers both cluster compactness and separation. Extending the conventional Fuzzy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$c$</tex>-Elliptotypes (FCE) model, the proposed method enables flexible modeling of elongated clusters. The objective function is formulated to simultaneously minimize vertical deviations, control dispersion along the principal axis, and maximize the distance between cluster centers. Experimental results using artificial datasets demonstrate that the proposed Fuzzy Ellipsoidal Clustering with Compactness and Separation (FECS) improves initialization robustness and achieves more accurate cluster separation compared to conventional methods.

title: Prediction of Chronic Kidney Disease Based on Machine Learning with Personalized Dietary Suggestions
authors: Raj Papadkar, Taniya Bhattacharjee, Om Patil, Ojas Ingle, Chirag Bedse
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Accurate and prompt disease identification is crucial for efficient treatment of patients' health. However, identifying different diseases, particularly in their early phases, is a bit challenging because of subtle and misleading symptoms. This highlights the fusion of two key medical data sources: image scans and clinical notes of patients. The model uses DenseNet-121 along with image normalization methods to capture complex visual details from medical images. Meanwhile, ClinicalBERT for clinical text data uses tokenization and contextual embeddings to extract important key insights from patient records. A hybrid fusion model, which uses attention mechanisms, merges both medical records, enabling the system to evaluate the complete range of accessible patient data. This classification model predicts by giving results as healthy individuals and patients with diseases, further identifying specific disease types and analyzing the growth of the condition. By using the fusion of medical records and advanced ML methods, this model helps in improving diagnostic accuracy and supporting earlier disease detection.

title:
Bulk-Driven Rail-to-Rail Comparator with V
                    <sub>DD</sub>
                    of 0.25 V in 65 nm CMOS Technology
authors: Lukas Nagy, Adam Hudec, Viera Stopjakova
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper addresses the design and verification of a voltage comparator of novel topology, implemented in a 65 nm general-purpose CMOS technology. The proposed circuit combines a bulk-driven transistor approach with so-called currentmode operation, which enables truely promising ultra-low-voltage performance. Design verification has been carried out using Monte-Carlo simulations across an industrial temperature range from $T=-20^{\circ} C$ to $T=85^{\circ} C$, as well as through simulations across all relevant process-voltage-temperature (PVT) corners. The proposed topology demonstrates the ability to operate correctly with $V_{D D}$ as low as 250 mV with rail-to-rail input voltage range. The comparator can achieve a very low input offset voltage without trimming or digital calibration, at the cost of increased silicon area consumption. However, the presented topology can be easily modified to implement various trimming methods, if required.

title: Utilizing Morpheme-Based Translation Units to Enhance Bidirectional Amharic-Khimtagne Machine Translation with Deep Learning
authors: Adane Kasie Chekole, Tesfahun Nurrie Mengestie, Belayneh Teshome Kebie, Yohannes Ayana Ejigu, Kelemework Kindie Moges, Anteneh Yehalem Tegegne
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: Neural Machine Translation (NMT), a critical application of NLP, automates translation between natural languages without human interaction. This research develops a bidirectional machine translation system for Amharic and Khimtagne, two morphologically rich Ethiopian languages. Building a translation model for this pair improves digital inclusion, information access, and helps preserve indigenous languages. We created a parallel corpus of 17,153 aligned sentence pairs from religious literature, educational resources, news, and official documents. Both word-based and morpheme-based segmentation strategies were used, with Morfessor for unsupervised morphological analysis. The dataset was tested with deep learning models, including LSTM, LSTM with Attention, CNN with Attention, and Transformer, in both directions: Amharic–Khimtagne and Khimtagne–Amharic. The Transformer model based on morphemes performed best, with BLEU scores of 22.99 for Khimtagne-to-Amharic and 23.42 for Amharic-to-Khimtagne. Compared to word-based methods, these results show morpheme-level units handle the intricate morphology of both languages, increasing accuracy. The study acknowledges dataset size and subject diversity limits. Future research will expand the corpus and explore training methods to improve quality. This research advances NMT for under-resourced languages and supports inclusive AI in Ethiopia.

title: Detection of Potentially Malicious Domain Names for Ethiopic Script (Amharic language): A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Hiwot Amare, Solomon Gizaw
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: The Domain Name System (DNS) is a crucial component of the Internet that enables seamless interaction between users and computers. Initially, DNS was designed to support ASCII characters only. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) introduced Internationalized Domain Names (IDNs). IDNs enhanced inclusivity by enabling the use of non-ASCII characters in the DNS. However, vulnerabilities in DNS have also increased with the use of IDNs, due to visually similar characters between different scripts. Various scripts present characteristics that further contribute to DNS vulnerabilities. The Ethiopic script used in several languages within Ethiopia presents unique challenges, which make the DNS open to spoofing attacks. This is due to phonetically redundant characters that are used interchangeably in the Amharic language.This research develops a Machine Learning (ML) model designed to detect domains written in the Ethiopic script, specifically the issue of phonetic redundancy associated with the Amharic language. The model also takes into account homographs and typosquatting. Pairs of benign and malicious domain names were generated using Ethiopic scripts. Eight Machine Learning (ML) models were trained and compared. The Artificial Neural Network (ANN) model achieved the highest overall performance, with an accuracy and an AUC-ROC of, 95.82% and 97% respectively. This paper presents a designed model for detecting malicious domain names in the Ethiopic script, to encourage its adoption and establish a secure domain name environment in Amharic.

title: Improving Object Point Software Effort Estimation Using a Deep Learning Approach
authors: Shimels Tilahun, Seffi Gebeyehu, Abebaw Muche, Yeshiwas Adane, Derejaw Misganaw, Mulatu Yirga, Tesfahun Nurrie Mengestie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: Delivering high-quality software within budget and schedule constraints is a critical responsibility of project managers, and it depends on the accurate early prediction of software development effort. However, previous software projects' effort estimation methods, such as source lines of code and function point size metrics, have limitations in estimating effort at the specification stage. A machine learning-based object point analysis technique for software effort estimation is the earliest technique to predict software project effort at the specification stage. Even object point analysis software and effort estimation techniques using machine learning algorithms can make effort predictions at an earlier stage. Still, they have some accuracy limitations compared to the actual effort. However, deep learning models showed better accuracy in effort estimation near the actual effort at the earliest specification stage. This work advances the state-of-the-art by combining OPA’s simplicity with DNN’s predictive power, offering a practical solution for industry adoption. The study conducted a comparative experimental study on object point effort estimation using a recent deep learning model and three traditional machine learning algorithms (K-Neighbors Regression, Linear Regression, and Support Vector Regression). The experimental results ensured that the Deep learning model achieves superior performance, with minimal prediction errors (lower MAE, RMSE, and MSE) and a higher R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score compared to traditional approaches.

title: Responsive, Resilient, Restored: A Review of the Role of Data Analytics in Healthcare Amidst Disease Outbreaks
authors: Raktim Pal, Elham Torabi, Claudia R. Rosales, Baback Vaziri, Srinivas Talluri
abstract: We synthesize the literature at the intersection of healthcare and data analytics and examine the use of data analytics methods to improve responsiveness, resilience, and restoration capabilities of healthcare systems when dealing with pandemic/epidemic outbreaks. We develop a conceptual framework to help us organize, analyze, and identify gaps in current research. Analysis of the literature helps us conclude that most of the work in the field supports healthcare institutions improve in terms of responsiveness and resilience, but more focus is needed to help systems restore to normalcy. We identify research gaps such as the development of robust disease surveillance tools based on novel technologies like AI, evaluating the benefits of coordinating limited resources within regional healthcare systems, and reducing risk within the complex healthcare supply chain. Moreover, based on our findings and interactions with practitioners we identify the need to channel more efforts on developing research that supports healthcare institutions as they seek to return to normalcy in the post pandemic world. Health systems are now operating with fewer resources while dealing with an increased number of patients who present multiple comorbidities, while dealing with ongoing shortages of critical supplies. These challenging conditions have resulted in significant financial losses for several healthcare systems post-pandemic. We propose future research directions that can provide a research agenda to scholars in our field seeking to enhance the responsiveness, resilience, and restoration of healthcare systems in preparation for future disease outbreaks.

title: Internet of Things: Innovation, Threats, and Consequences
authors: Md Mokhlesur Rahman, Alhassan Abdulhamid, Moemedi Lefoane, Sohag Kabir, Ibrahim Ghafir
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT), a paradigm driven by the integration of artificial intelligence and the convergence of the physical and digital domains, has ushered in a new era of hyperconnectivity and intelligent automation. While its innovations offer vast societal and economic benefits, IoT adoption faces significant challenges, including high deployment costs, integration complexity, and critical threats to security, privacy, and safety. This article critically examines these issues by exploring current advancements, highlighting economic and operational barriers, and analysing the evolving threat landscape. It emphasises the often-overlooked risks of rapid IoT expansion and presents balanced, forward-looking recommendations to support safer, more resilient, and sustainable IoT adoption and governance.

title: First inter-comparison of optical to electrical time delay calibrated photodetectors and calibration setup validation
authors: Peter. P. M. Jansweijer, Nayib. A. D. Boukadida, Kalle. Hanhijärvi, Anders. Wallin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Precision Clock Synchronization for Measurement, Control, and Communication (ISPCS)
abstract: A time transfer link consisting of PTP High Accuracy equipment (PTP-HA, e.g., White Rabbit) can transfer time with sub-nanosecond accuracy. Originally PTP-HA equipment is calibrated as a set of two devices. Progress in calibration makes exchange of individual components, such as pluggable transceivers, possible without the need for expensive in-situ end-to-end calibrations. This is expected to be covered in a future release of the IEEE 1588 standard.To determine the latencies of a pluggable transceiver, a time delay calibrated reference photodetector is essential. Latency values are stored in the transceiver memory, which enables exchange without breaking calibration.This paper describes the results of inter-comparing several calibrated reference photodetectors that were calibrated in different calibration setups. These photodetectors were exchanged between laboratories to cross-verify their stated optical to electrical time delays. The initial cross-verification results lead to further investigation of the calibration setup. The results of this investigation will be reported.

title: Ontologies for Autonomous Agricultural Robots and Implements
authors: Eike Gassen, Dennis Meckel, Olaide Oladimeji, Karsten Berns
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: To automate agricultural field operations, an ontology is essential as a central organizing element that structures agronomic tasks and communicates them to a control framework. This framework manages both tractor and implement, applies intelligent algorithms, processes sensor data, and provides a graphical user interface. The ontology establishes a shared semantic foundation, enabling seamless information exchange between machinery and software components. This facilitates context-aware, precise control and coordination of complex workflows. By mapping agronomic knowledge into machine-readable structures, the ontology enables full automation of field processes. It acts as a bridge between domain expertise and technical execution, supporting efficient, adaptive, and intelligent farming operations through integrated communication and control.

title: Fuzzy Logic-Based Smoothing Control for Grid-Connected PV Systems with Lithium-Ion Battery Storage
authors: Cong-Sheng Huang, Kai-Li Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: With the increasing integration of photovoltaic (PV) power generation into modern power grids, mitigating output fluctuations caused by weather variability has become a critical challenge. These fluctuations not only jeopardize grid stability but also accelerate the degradation of lithium-ion battery energy storage systems (BESS) when used for smoothing purposes. This paper proposes a fuzzy logic-based power smoothing control strategy that dynamically adjusts the smoothing window size based on real-time weather conditions, including cloud coverage, cloud height, and wind speed. By intelligently determining the window size of a sliding window filter, the proposed method effectively balances power fluctuation mitigation and battery health preservation. The performance of the proposed approach was evaluated using actual PV generation data and compared against traditional smoothing techniques, including moving average, double moving average, low-pass filter, Savitzky-Golay filter, and Gaussian filter. Results indicate that in July, the proposed method reduced the battery cycling frequency to 0.19 cycles per day, which is significantly lower than other filters. Furthermore, the required battery capacity was minimized to 2869.58 kWh, representing an 11.36 % to 66.88 % reduction compared to other methods. The life cycle cost analysis reveals that the proposed method achieved a total cost of USD 46,530.52, which is 7.78 % to 58.03 % lower than the conventional methods evaluated. These results confirm the proposed method's capability to enhance smoothing performance while extending battery life and reducing system costs.

title: Plant Disease Recognition Using Deep Learning Technique
authors: Dipak R. Patil, Vaishnavi S. Tambe, Shruti B. Mhaske, Gayatri S. Sonawane
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Study and analysis of crop diseases pose significant threats to agricultural productivity, necessitating timely and accurate identification for effective management. This project develops a deep learning-based system using convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to detect and diagnose diseases in corn, tomato, citrus, and wheat. The system analyzes images of affected leaves, identifying patterns and symptoms characteristic of diseases like tomato powdery mildew, wheat leaf rust, corn gray leaf spot, and citrus greening. Trained on a comprehensive dataset of annotated images, the model's performance is evaluated using accuracy, achieving an overall accuracy of 94.8 %. This technology aims to provide farmers with actionable insights, enabling early intervention and reducing crop losses. By integrating this system into agricultural practices, we aim to optimize pesticide use, improve crop health, and promote sustainable farming.

title: CareerQuest - A Comprehensive Career Guidance Using Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing Techniques
authors: W.P. Rahane, Sarthak Sulakhe, Utkarsha Todkar, Sanskruti Sokande, Rajesh Bharati
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The absence of personalised data-driven support services in career guidance creates difficulties for modern students in making career choices, thus leading to inappropriate job choices and increased student dropout rates. Career counselling practitioners typically implement generic recommendations that fail to consider particular client talents and personality traits. The research paper presents CareerQuest - A Comprehensive Career Guidance, which employs Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing approaches to recommend suitable career paths aligned with students' requirements for proper educational choices. The design of CareerQuest relies on XGBoost and BERT to deliver personalised professional guidance that matches users' professional abilities against their future goals. The system integrates the MBTI (Myers-Briggs Type Indicator) and RIASEC models to assess career compatibility between user skills and industry preferences for informed decisions. The platform delivers personalised recommendations and advice to all users through predictive analytics that use ML features to track career environment changes. Through its development process, CareerQuest provides its users access to make specific career choices in the adaptable career counseling system. The data processing system of CareerQuest builds educational-professional connections to deliver enduring career satisfaction along with professional growth to students on their complete career path.

title: DeepNhKcr: Explainable Deep Learning Framework for the Prediction of Crotonylation Sites of Non-histone Lysine in Plants Based on Pre-trained Protein Language Model
authors: Jinwei Wang, Zhenjie Luo, Aoyun Geng, Junlin Xu, Yajie Meng, Shankai Yan, Leyi Wei, Zilong Zhang, Qingchen Zhang, Quan Zou, Feifei Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Lysine crotonylation (Kcr) is an important protein modification occurring after translation in biology, serving an essential function in a range of biological processes in both plants and animals, including the regulation of gene expression, the maintenance of cellular metabolic balance, and the enhancement of photosynthesis. Exploring the detection of Kcr sites is essential for uncovering their biological functions. Nonetheless, conventional experimental approaches for detection are often time-consuming, expensive, and hindered by various technical constraints, making the precise identification of Kcr sites a significant challenge. This study seeks to develop a computational approach for the rapid and accurate prediction of Kcr sites in plant non-histone proteins. We introduce a novel deep learning framework named DeepNhKcr, which integrates the protein language model (ESM2) with a bidirectional long short-term memory (BiLSTM) network. To address the challenge of data imbalance, the model replaces the conventional cross-entropy loss with the focal loss function. In addition, DeepNhKcr combines advanced deep learning approaches with traditional protein encoding strategies to enable effective feature extraction and integration. This method not only significantly boosts the accuracy of predicting Kcr sites in non-histone proteins of plants. but also provides interpretability, shedding light on the potential links between key sequence characteristics and their biological roles. DeepNhKcr delivers outstanding results, surpassing existing machine learning and deep learning models, and demonstrating excellent performance in both five-fold cross-validation and independent test experiments. Moreover, the model integrates interpretability analysis techniques to investigate the connections between important sequence features and their biological roles. DeepNhKcr acts as a powerful method for detecting Kcr sites in plant non-histone proteins and is anticipated to greatly advance future studies in plant Kcr site prediction. The web server for DeepNhKcr is freely accessible at http://www.bioai-lab.com/DeepNhKcr.

title: Double Resampling Architecture for Distance Measurement in FMCW LiDAR with Degraded Transmitter Systems
authors: Jonghyun Kim, Dohyun Shin, Jinwook Burm
abstract: Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) LiDAR systems require the precise generation of linear chirp signals for high-resolution distance measurements. While previous studies have primarily focused on the intrinsic frequency nonlinearity of laser diode, this work considers the broader impact of the entire transmit (TX) chain on ranging accuracy. The nonlinearity of the TX system is newly classified into a static component and a residual component, each requiring independent optimization strategies. To address this, we introduce a double-resampling approach that combines pre-distortion with a post-processing algorithm. Both stages employ similar Hilbert transform-based structures, minimizing algorithmic complexity while enabling high-precision operation even with low-cost or aged TX hardware, which demonstrates strong commercial potential. Experimental results under free-space conditions show a standard deviation (STD) of 0.18 mm and an error rate (Accuracy) of 0.17% at 1 m, with a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 6.28 mm, indicating the distance resolution.

title: Comparative Life Cycle Assessment of High Voltage Gas Insulated Switchgear
authors: Abdel-Wahab Dirawieh, Maurizio Albano, A. Manu Haddad
abstract: In this paper, the authors articulate the phaseout of sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) in the electrical high voltage (HV) insulated switchgear system. The main focus is on the transition to SF6 alternatives and compilation of existing research on the life cycle assessments (LCAs) of these technologies. Their potential for decarbonization is explored through comparative methodologies, optimal ways to reduce carbon footprints and enhance sustainability. By synthesizing the effects of these technologies on carbon footprints, the study underlines the role that revolutionary answers have in propelling decarbonization attempts in the electrical transmission sectors through innovative solutions which with broader climate change mitigation strategies. Subsequently, it undertakes a detailed comparative LCA evaluation of different aspects, indicators and approaches. Then, this process is followed through with a detailed interpretation of the impacts of the methods and assumptions used in calculating the final assessment results. Consequently, this interpretation emphasizes the most influential and transparent method regarding the product's environmental performance across its entire life cycle stages. The outcomes show that complete standardized LCA is necessary to effectively compare the ecological impact of various HV products and technologies. It allows related stakeholders to conclude the fairest LCA in their decisions and strategy towards decarbonization. There are also proposals and recommendations for future research and decision-making regarding future enhancements and improvements for comparable and accurate environmental assessments.

title: Implementation of Research Findings on Corona Noise Propagation into the Teaching Process at Technically Oriented Universities
authors: Ervin Lumnitzer, Elena Lukac Jurgovska, Miriama Pinosova, Ruzena Kralikova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This article focuses on modern ways of teaching. It mainly concerns the implementation of practical skills, experience, and knowledge into the teaching process. It is a trend that is currently in high demand among students, mainly among the audience of universities with a technical character. These students thus gain not only theoretical skills and knowledge but are also able to apply these skills and knowledge in real practice. The form of teaching presented in this article is focused not only on simple, practical and repetitive applications. Students must study the theory, they have access to practical laboratory measurements of the phenomenon (the coronary noise in our case), which they have to understand thoroughly, and their task will be to apply the theoretical knowledge and the results of research-oriented laboratory measurements to solve real-world problems in practice, in our case, in the urbanised environment of cities and towns. That means generalising theoretical knowledge and the results of laboratory measurements and implementing them into the real problem that occurs in our practice. The issue is deliberately selected because no generalised exact procedures for solving it in practice exist, only general guidelines of how to proceed in such cases. Students must design a methodology and apply that methodology to a real problem. The skills which students thus acquire are priceless for their future practical life.

title: G-UniRouting: A Graph-Based Unified Neural Model for Solving Multi-Attribute Vehicle Routing Problems
authors: Amine Jari, Sohaib Afifi, Rym Nesrine Guibadj, Eric Lefèvre
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Real-world Vehicle Routing Problems (VRPs) involve multiple operational attributes such as capacity limits, time windows, backhauls, open routes, and route duration constraints. Most existing methods are tailored to specific variants, limiting adaptability and reuse. This paper introduces G-UniRouting: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A$</tex> Graph-Based Unified Neural Model for Solving Multi-Attribute Vehicle Routing Problems. Our approach integrates a Graph Neural Network (GNN) encoder that captures spatial and relational structure with a constraint-aware decoder that dynamically enforces feasibility through dynamic masking and distance-aware attention mechanisms. Our proposed model is an end-to-end framework trained using the REINFORCE algorithm with a rollout baseline to minimize routing costs. G-UniRouting is evaluated on 24 distinct VRP variants within a unified framework and employs multi-start inference to enhance solution quality. Experimental results show that our unified model generalizes across diverse constraints and consistently outperforms or rivals specialized baselines, offering a scalable and flexible solution to complex, multi-attribute routing problems.

title: Investigating Hausdorff Window in Antenna Power Weighting: Preliminary Findings and Practical Implications
authors: Hartuti Mistialustina, Muhammad Farhan Maulana, Muhammad Manzil Karama, Achmad Munir
abstract: The use of Hausdorff function in power-weighted array antenna is a novel and intriguing topic in antenna research. This paper presents the initial investigation on implementation of Hausdorff window in antenna power weighting, focusing on preliminary findings and practical implications. The investigation includes a theoretical analysis of characteristics and potential advantages of Hausdorff window compared to other window functions. Technical challenges and practical implications in implementing Hausdorff window in antenna power weighting are also investigated. Through simulations, the radiation pattern performance of Hausdorff linear array (HLA) is evaluated, particularly in sidelobe level (SLL) suppression. Initial findings based on array factor observations indicate that the Hausdorff coefficient set is closely similar to the Kaiser coefficient set. Further comparisons will also be made with the Chebyshev and uniform distribution. The SLL suppressions of Hausdorff, Kaiser, Chebyshev, and uniform linear array antenna demonstrate interesting results. The evidences using array factor observation reveal the SLL suppression values of 35.1 dB for Hausdorff, 34.55 dB for Kaiser, 43.21 dB for Chebyshev, and 13.44 dB for uniform. These provide valuable insights and pave the way for further investigation on the implementation of Hausdorff window in complex array antenna designs.

title: Non-Invasive Exploration of Archaeological Falaj System: L-Band SAR Tomography Insights
authors: L. P. Oliveira, Jarrah Hammadi, T. Prabowo, L. S. Bins, J. R. Moreira Neto, M. Almansoori, F. Vega
abstract: This paper presents the results of a subsurface tomography study at an Aflaj archaeological site in the United Arab Emirates, using drone-borne Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) systems. The survey utilized three helical flight tracks to capture high-resolution imagery across a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.6 \times 0.6 \text{km}^{2}$</tex> area. L-band SAR tomography demonstrated its capability to detect and map intricate underground features, including the Falaj tunnels and associated wells, to depths of up to 20 meters. Advanced post-processing techniques, such as median filtering and polarization analysis, enhanced image clarity, revealing subtle variations in material composition and structural integrity. These results underscore SAR tomography's value as a non-invasive and precise tool for preserving and understanding ancient water management systems, offering new pathways for archaeological research and cultural heritage conservation.

title: Physics Inspired Neural Network for Cortical Electromagnetic Activity of Neonates
authors: A. Jeremic, A. Biran, Aljazi A. AlMaghlouth
abstract: Neonatal convulsions are one of the most common emergency neurological events in the early period after birth with the frequency of 1.5 to 3 in 1000 live births. Consequently, neonatal intensive care units (NICU) continuously monitor electrical activity of preterm infants for both short-term and long-term interventions and/or treatments. These techniques commonly utilize only detection algorithms whose main purpose is to detect events in electroencephalography (EEG) recordings. In addition to those, estimation techniques can potentially provide insight into the brain development and indicate regions of higher convulsion rate. The estimation of electrical activity of the brain in adults has been a subject of considerable research interest in adults. To this purpose in this paper we investigate the possibility of estimating the cortical activity of the neonates using physics informed neural networks. The main idea behind this approach lies in the possibility of significantly reducing the computational intensity of the inverse approach by avoiding the need for inversion using artificial neural networks (ANN).

title: Edge-Aware Federated AI: Scalable LLM Integration for Privacy-Preserving Big Data Networks
authors: Anil Kumar Jonnalagadda, Gokul Narain Natarajan, Satya Manesh Veerapaneni, Srinivas Vikram
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: As demand for AI that preserves privacy in real time grows, traditional centralized architectures face challenges in scalability, latency, and data sovereignty. This paper proposes a novel framework called Edge-Aware Federated AI (EAFAI), designed to integrate Large Language Models (LLMs) into edge networks using federated learning principles. EAFAI dynamically distributes AI workloads across edge devices and cloud nodes, enabling adaptive LLM deployment while preserving data locality. The architecture leverages decentralized training, model compression, and selective parameter sharing to address privacy, bandwidth, and computation constraints. We demonstrate the framework’s applicability in healthcare and smart city data ecosystems, showcasing its performance across three dimensions: latency, privacy preservation, and model accuracy. Our results show that EAFAI reduces communication overhead by up to 47% and maintains competitive LLM inference accuracy, proving its potential for scalable, privacy-aligned big data intelligence at the edge.

title: Enhancing Home Network Security through a Gamified, User-Centric Intrusion Detection System
authors: Andrei Sandu, Ioan Valentin Sita, Vlad Muresan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The potential attack surface for cyber threats has significantly increased due to the quick spread of Internet of Things (IoT) devices and the increasing complexity of residential networks. This paper introduces an independent and resourceefficient Intrusion Detection System (IDS) made especially for home and small office/home office (SOHO) settings in response to these difficulties. The proposed system, which is based on the ESP32 microcontroller, performs basic vulnerability assessments, anomaly detection, and active network monitoring. Through a dual-interface system that consists of a web-based dashboard and a local OLED display, both enhanced with gamification features, it raises user awareness and engagement with security. For important events, the system also allows external notifications through Discord. According to experimental evaluation, the proposed system can effectively identify common network vulnerabilities, detect unauthorized devices, and send out timely alerts-all while working within the limited resources of an inexpensive embedded platform.

title: Detecting and Preventing Data Poisoning Attacks on AI Models
authors: Halima I. Kure, Pradipta Sarkar, Ahmed B. Ndanusa, Augustine O. Nwajana
abstract: This paper investigates the critical issue of data poisoning attacks on AI models, a growing concern in the ever-evolving landscape of artificial intelligence and cybersecurity. As advanced technology systems become increasingly prevalent across various sectors, the need for robust defence mechanisms against adversarial attacks becomes paramount. The study aims to develop and evaluate novel techniques for detecting and preventing data poisoning attacks, focusing on both theoretical frameworks and practical applications. Through a comprehensive literature review, experimental validation using the CIFAR-10 and Insurance Claims datasets, and the development of innovative algorithms, this paper seeks to enhance the resilience of AI models against malicious data manipulation. The study explores various methods, including anomaly detection, robust optimization strategies, and ensemble learning, to identify and mitigate the effects of poisoned data during model training. Experimental results indicate that data poisoning significantly degrades model performance, reducing classification accuracy by up to 27 % in image recognition tasks (CIFAR-10) and 22 % in fraud detection models (Insurance Claims dataset). The proposed defence mechanisms, including statistical anomaly detection and adversarial training, successfully mitigated poisoning effects, improving model robustness and restoring accuracy levels by an average of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15-20 \%$</tex>. The findings further demonstrate that ensemble learning techniques provide an additional layer of resilience, reducing false positives and false negatives caused by adversarial data injections. The findings of this paper contribute to the broader understanding of adversarial machine learning and provide actionable insights for practitioners in industries facing emerging threats to AI-based systems. By addressing the challenges of data poisoning attacks, this study aims to improve the security and reliability of AI models, ultimately fostering greater trust in AI technologies across critical applications.

title: Ml-Powered Python Solution for Detecting Faults in Electrical Drives
authors: Georgi Enchev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper presents a Python-based machine learning solution for fault detection in electrical drives using simulation data. The dataset used in this study was generated through MATLAB simulations of various fault scenarios in motor drives. The system processes the raw simulated sensor data, segments it, performs normalization and label encoding, and then evaluates multiple classifiers with diverse configurations. Performance metrics, including accuracy and F1-score, are recorded and visualized to provide insights into model behavior and efficiency. The implementation supports automation and integration with databases, allowing for streamlined experimentation, reproducibility, and systematic result storage.

title: A Parametric Optimization Algorithm Based on the U-Net for Two-Dimensional Electromagnetic Reconstruction
authors: Hao Ran Yang, Chun Xia Yang, Mei Song Tong
abstract: The electromagnetic inverse scattering problem involves retrieving the shape, location, material composition, and other characteristics of an object based on known electromagnetic wave scattering information. Due to its broad applications, research in this area has been ongoing. However, traditional methods struggle with efficient and accurate electromagnetic reconstruction because of the nonlinear and ill-posed nature of the problem. In recent years, deep learning techniques have rapidly advanced and have been applied to solve the electromagnetic inverse scattering problem, thereby improving reconstruction efficiency. Nevertheless, the lack of a priori information poses significant challenges, leading to poor reconstruction accuracy. This paper introduces a hybrid optimization algorithm that integrates Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) with the U-Net neural network, which excels in image segmentation, to address the electromagnetic reconstruction of regular targets. The most critical step in PSO is to compute the fitness metric, which significantly influences optimization search speed. This metric evaluates each particle's performance and proximity to an optimal solution within the search space. By applying U-Net to accelerate the complex matrix computations required for the fitness value in PSO, the proposed hybrid method not only retains the high accuracy of PSO, but also substantially improves computational speed.

title: Workforce Efficiency in Factories: Computer Vision Approach
authors: Vishal Hegde, K Anirudha, Simhadri M H, Manojkumar M Hegde, Mallikarjuna Gowda C P
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: The recent advancements in AI and deep learning applications across a variety of domains, stressing their revolutionary impact. Organizations can manage high security areas and large events through real time alerts and threat detection using YOLO and YOLOv8m models because these models show high accuracy and recall with their real time performance. Many paper suggests automated attendance systems based on YOLO, FaceNet and Haar Cascade algorithms that can scale face recognition technology precisely to handle organizational needs including remote work functionality. AI systems in construction and manufacturing use real time tracking and computer vision to monitor productivity and safety. The paper presents different AI technologies which make progress possible in multiple industrial and agriculture sectors.

title: Experimental Study of Stationary Processes During Injection of Carbon Dioxide into the Reservoir
authors: Nazarov Serdar Gochakovich
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This study of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> injection into depletedreservoir analogues investigates H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> generation, pressure rise, and the role of iron shavings. Column tests with CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-saturated and unsaturated waters (technical, distilled, artificial seawater <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 5 ~ g} / \mathbf{L ~ N a C l}$</tex>) showed fastest H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> production in technical water and salinity-suppressed kinetics; reactor pressure rose from 24 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$23-25 ~\text{atm}$</tex> with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1-2{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> temperature increase, and gas reached <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 96 \% \mathrm{H}_{2}\left(\text{CO}_{2}<3 \%\right)$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 20.8 ~\text{atm}$</tex> after <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 144 ~\mathrm{h}$</tex>. The apparent water-decomposition rate was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 4 \times 10^{-5} ~\mathrm{g} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \cdot \mathrm{h}^{-1} \cdot ~\mathrm{g}^{-1}$</tex>, while iron activity peaked then declined over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1500 ~\mathrm{h}$</tex> due to corrosion and passivation. Results highlight the need to control fluid mineralization, monitor pressure, and manage iron-related reactivity for safe CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> storage.

title: Real-Time Phase-OTDR Signal Processing on FPGA for Enhanced Fiber Optic Sensing
authors: M. H. Öncüer, R. Ağaoğlu, I. Ölçer, F. Üstüner
abstract: Phase-sensitive Optical Time-Domain Reflectometry (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Phi$</tex>-OTDR) is commonly used for distributed fiber optic sensing (DFOS) applications which monitors phase shifts along fiber optic cables caused by vibration, strain, and temperature changes. Due to these monitoring capabilities, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Phi$</tex>-OTDR can be used for security applications, structural health monitoring (SHM), and environmental sensing. However, real-time data processing for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Phi$</tex>-OTDR continues to be demanding. Software-based approaches often struggle due to the required processing power. This problem limits their effectiveness in real-time use. In this paper, we propose a field programmable gate arrays (FPGA)-based approach to processing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Phi$</tex>-OTDR data in real-time. Our system can process large amounts of data without causing a significant amount of lag so that it can be used for time-critical applications. The system uses a noise suppression technique that effectively reduces noise without distorting the signal, making detecting small changes along the fiber optic cable easier. This paper introduces a real-time FPGA-based <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Phi$</tex>-OTDR signal processing system that integrates adaptive matched filter (AMF) technique to deliver improved performance and scalability for industrial and security applications.

title: DOA Estimation with Uniform Linear Arrays in the Presence of Mutual Coupling via EBG Ladder Shaped Decoupling Structure
authors: Moustafa M. Abdalla, Albatool A. Elmezwghi, Moussa Ali Hamdan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The decline in the capability of estimating the direction of arrival with high resolution due to the mutual coupling effects has been well known. Many methods have been proposed throughout the year to tackle these problems. In this paper, a new method for increasing the isolation between very closely spaced compact omnidirectional MIMO arrays is proposed. The method is based on introducing an Electromagnetic Band Gap (EBG) structure named the ladder-shaped decoupling structure between closely spaced MIMO arrays to modify the mutual coupling matrix. Comprehensive simulations are conducted with CST Microwave Studio software utilizing a simulated Z-parameters. MUSIC algorithm is applied to evaluate how well the new method performs when mutual coupling is applied. The outcomes are compared to conventional MUSIC approach that does not account for mutual coupling compensation. The findings derived from estimating the DOA illustrates the validity and the efficiency of the suggested method.

title: Enhancing Vision Transformer Performance in LowLight Conditions through Object-Focused Pixel Reallocation
authors: Jae-Yong Seong, Hyun-Suk Lee, Tea-Ho Kim, Seong -Geon Bae
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: In low-light environments, the visual information in images becomes limited, which often leads to a significant degradation in image classification performance. This is particularly problematic for transformer-based models such as the Vision Transformer, which relies on global attention learned from image patches and is therefore highly sensitive to input quality. In this study, we propose a preprocessing-based approach to improve the classification performance of Vision Transformer under low-light conditions. Specifically, we apply histogram equalization to input images in order to restore contrast and enhance visual features that are often lost in low-light scenes. This enhancement enables Vision Transformer to learn richer and more meaningful visual representations, resulting in improved classification accuracy. Experiments were conducted using the ExDark dataset, which contains images captured under real-world low-light conditions, and the effectiveness of the proposed preprocessing technique was quantitatively evaluated. The results demonstrate that even without modifying the model architecture, histogram-based preprocessing significantly improves the classification performance of Vision Transformer. This study highlights the importance of preprocessing in low-light image classification and presents an efficient strategy for enhancing the practical utility of transformer-based vision models.

title: Enzyme Classification using Transformer-Based Sequence Embeddings
authors: Jateen Joharapurkar, Sahar Hooshmand
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Enzyme function classification plays a critical role in understanding biological processes, drug discovery, and protein annotation. This paper presents a computational pipeline that leverages ESM2, a transformer-based protein language model to generate contextual embeddings from raw amino acid sequences. We explore strategies to address class imbalance and evaluate the embeddings on two supervised learning architectures: a MLP and a deeper custom neural network. Our observations demonstrate that the MLP model with oversampling achieves the best performance, achieving a test accuracy of 93.5% and macro F1-score of 91% outperforming deeper architectures and class-weighted loss. Our findings suggest that even embeddings generated from a lightweight transformer combined with effective imbalance handling techniques can provide an efficient solution for enzyme function classification.

title: Lightweight Transfer Learning Models for Kerangas Landscape Classification on Edge Devices
authors: Dwi Ahmad Dzulhijjah, Kusrini Kusrini, Afdhal Afdhal, Noor Akhmad Setiawan, Adi Wibowo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Kerangas forests (tropical heath forests) are nutrient-poor, fire-prone ecosystems threatened by deforestation and land-use change. Monitoring these post-disturbance landscapes is crucial for ecological restoration but remains challenging due to field inaccessibility and the high resource demands of conventional deep learning. This study evaluates lightweight CNNs (MobileNetV1/V2) for classifying Kerangas imagery into three ecological succession stages. Using transfer learning and domain-specific data, twelve RGB and grayscale models were assessed by accuracy, latency, RAM, and flash usage for edge deployment. MobileNetV2 with 160×160 RGB and α =0.75 reached 95.8% accuracy, matched by a 96×96 grayscale model with α =0.35—which reduced memory by over 97% and achieved sub-second inference time.

title: Dual-State Reinforcement-Learning-Based Dynamic Ensemble Model for Pork Price Forecasting
authors: Guobao Liu, Xudong Lin, Zhiguo Du, Bin Wen, Zhihui Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Reasonable forecasting of pork prices is of great significance for stabilizing price fluctuations in the pig market and promoting the healthy and sustainable development of the pig industry.The study addresses the high volatility and nonlinear characteristics of pork prices by proposing a composite forecasting framework that integrates a dynamic state transition mechanism with a dual random forest model to predict the monthly average pork prices. The accuracy of price forecasting is significantly enhanced through the introduction of adaptive feature engineering, a reinforcement learning-driven state transition mechanism, and a trend correction module. The core of the algorithm comprises three innovative mechanisms: (i) a volatility state detection system based on dynamic time warping, which accurately categorizes market states through the synergistic analysis of annualized volatility matrices and price momentum;(ii) a parallel architecture of dual random forest models, designed with differentiated parameters for stable and volatile periods;(iii) a reinforcement learning-driven adaptive weight adjustment mechanism that achieves online optimization of model weights by integrating state transition probability matrices and dynamic threshold control. Empirical research using pork price data from China from 2002 to 2024 demonstrates that the proposed hybrid model achieves an MSE of 0.4691, MAE of 0.4892, RMSE of 0.6849, and MAPE of 2.4056%. The research findings offer a novel methodological framework for agricultural product price forecasting and hold practical value for stabilizing the supply chain of the pork market.

title: How Effective are Classical Cryptographic Protocols Against Early Quantum Decryption Attempts?
authors: Zachary Carruthers, Victor Clincy
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The advent of quantum computing poses a significant challenge to classical cryptographic protocols, threatening to undermine the security of widely used security systems like RSA, ECC, and AES. This paper investigates the vulnerabilities of traditional public-key and symmetric cryptographic schemes to quantum decryption techniques, such as Shor’s and Grover’s algorithms, while analyzing the efficacy of post-quantum cryptography (PQC) as a mitigation strategy. Through a review of current literature and simulations of quantum attacks on legacy protocols, this research identifies critical gaps in preparedness and evaluates emergent quantumresistant solutions. The findings highlight the immediate risks of “store now, decrypt later” attacks, emphasizing the importance of transitioning to PQC algorithms. Despite promising advances, challenges related to performance, interoperability, and standardization remain. This study concludes with a call for collaborative efforts in research, policy development, and widespread adoption of quantum-safe practices to ensure the resilience of digital communications in the quantum era.

title: A Review of IoT-Enhanced Battery Management Systems for Electric Vehicles: Trends, Architectures, and Industrial Insights
authors: Prabha Niraula, Muhammad Rashid, Bijay Dhungana
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper reviews Internet of Things (IoT) based Battery Management Systems (BMS) for electric vehicles from 2018 to 2025. The study groups BMS designs into four generations, showing the shift from basic sensing to AI enabled and cloud connected platforms. Common State of Charge (SoC) and State of Health (SoH) estimation methods such as Coulomb counting, Kalman filters, and neural networks are compared for their accuracy and practical use. Examples from industry, including Tesla’s AI BMS, GM’s wireless BMS, and BYD’s Blade Battery, are discussed to connect academic and commercial progress. The review also highlights key challenges such as interoperability, cybersecurity, and hardware limits, and discusses future research directions.

title: Capacity Building for Industrial Decarbonization: An Educational Program on Energy Transition Audits in Greece
authors: Theofilos A. Papadopoulos, Ioanna D. Pasiopoulou, Grigoris K. Papagiannis
abstract: Clean energy transition necessitates the adoption of measures to enhance both competitiveness and sustainability, with a particular emphasis on energy efficiency initiatives. Energy efficiency is critically important for energy-intensive industries. However, its implementation is often impeded by various barriers, including limited awareness of energy efficiency opportunities, insufficient technical expertise, and challenges related to financing measures. To address these issues and promote the benefits of the energy transition, the European-funded EnTRAINER project proposes an innovative framework aimed at fostering a sustainability-oriented culture within energy intensive companies. This framework seeks to enhance the skills of energy auditors and stakeholders through targeted training, develop suitable digital tools, and establish a comprehensive energy transition audit procedure. The scope of this paper is to present the general structure and impact of the EnTRAINER educational and training program delivered in Greece. End-of-course survey results showed very positive feedback from the participants, indicating the success of the program.

title: An Automated Detection System for Aspiration During Sleep Based on Deep Learning
authors: Kentaro Mori, Yutaka Hata, Toshiyuki Sawayama, Yasumitsu Fujii, Yoshiaki Saji, Yoshitada Sakai, Naomi Yagi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Aspiration pneumonia has high incidence and mortality rates among the elderly. Continuous patient monitoring is essential for prevention, but it remains challenging. This study proposes a system to predict aspiration during sleep based on deep learning. The system captures facial images of sleeping subjects using infrared cameras. Time series feature values based on the facial action coding system are computed using the artificial intelligence library MediaPipe. The deep learning model composed by a convolutional neural network and a long short-term memory model detects aspiration during sleep from the feature values. We conducted an experiment on nine healthy subjects to obtain facial image data. We used these images to train the model and evaluate its prediction accuracy. The results presented that the model could predict two types, normal and pained expressions, with high accuracy. This work is expected to improve the safety of elderly people and reduce the workload of health and care professionals.

title: Marine Target Detection in Polarimetric SAR Images Based on Three-Component Decomposition and Generalized Likelihood Ratio Test
authors: Chun Liu, Cong Huang, Ke Shi, Xiaobo Deng
abstract: The challenges of marine target detection in polarimetric synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images include the varied sea state, the secondary sidelobe echoes interference, and similar false alarms on the sea surface. To reduce false alarms that are prone to be detected by the traditional constant false alarm rate (CFAR) and deep learning approaches, a method based on the polarimetric three-component decomposition and the generalized likelihood ratio test (GLRT) is proposed. First, the surface, double-bounce and volume scattering powers of land covers are extracted by the three-component decomposition of reflection symmetry approximation (RSA). Subsequently, using the scattering difference between targets and the sea surface, the GLRT threshold segmentation is carried out on the volume scattering power to extract regions of interest (ROIs) for marine targets. Finally, determining the dynamic range of the double-bounce scattering power of ROIs, ROIs are discriminated by determining whether the average double-bounce scattering power is within the range or not. Experiments are conducted using datasets acquired from RADARSAT-2 and GAOFEN-3 data, respectively. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an overall detection rate of over 95 % with a false alarm rate below 10 %, outperforming traditional polarimetric whitening filter and power-based detection methods.

title: Design of Standing Wave Detection System for High Power Medium-Long Wave Antenna
authors: Xinglong Liu, Yuyu Zhu, Haoran Li, Yonghao Lu, Qilong Yu, Yining Qing, Junfeng Luo
abstract: In high-power RF systems, designing a standing wave detection system is essential for measuring the standing wave ratio (SWR), which reflects the degree of impedance matching between the load antenna and the pre-stage power amplifier. When the signal is in a superior impedance matching state, its transmission will be more efficient, the power loss will be decreased, and the transmission stability will be enhanced, enabling the overall performance of the system to reach the optimum. In practical engineering applications, a standing wave meter is typically utilized to measure the standing wave ratio, forward power, and reverse power. The existing medium and long wave standing wave meters are mainly of several hundred watts, so it is highly meaningful to design and manufacture a high-power, high-precision, small-sized medium and long wave standing wave detection system. The design adopts the centralized parameter bidirectional coupler. Through the reasonable setting of magnetic devices, topology structure, and heat dissipation mode, the system power capacity can reach more than 5 kW, and the working frequency range is set at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150 \text{kHz} \sim 500 \text{kHz}$</tex>. A nonlinear compensation circuit is designed to mitigate the nonlinear distortion in the forward and reverse voltage detector. Aiming at the nonlinear issue of the bidirectional coupler topology itself, a high-order curve fitting model is introduced to correct the detection results, ultimately obtaining a more accurate measurement result with the measurement error controlled within 2 %. The system possesses the characteristics of high power, high precision, small volume, and good stability, which is suitable for military and civilian medium and long wave communication. It can operate stably in a special environment and has significant application value.

title: Designing an Automated Seeding Drone System for Soil-Condition-Based Multi-Crop Farming
authors: Mareme Moshito Petja, Makhulu Relebogile Langa, Michael Nthabiseng Moeti
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This research investigates the feasibility of developing an automated, soil-condition-aware seeding drone system that supports multi-crop planting. Traditional farming and current precision agriculture often overlook the spatial variability of soil conditions, leading to suboptimal crop performance and inefficient resource use. Existing mechanical and Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)-based seeding systems are typically designed for monocrop strategies. This study proposes a system that leverages real-time soil analysis and intelligent seeddispensing mechanisms to address these inefficiencies. The core problem is the absence of an integrated, autonomous drone-based system that can detect and analyze spatial soil variations in real time, intelligently select suitable crop types based on conditions, and execute precise multi-crop planting. The proposed system aims to improve land use efficiency, enhance crop yields, promote soil health, and contribute to sustainable agriculture by enabling a UAV to autonomously analyze soil conditions and dynamically plant the most suitable crops in distinct zones within a single field.
