title: Time-Modulated Wire Media with High-Precision Resolution
authors: M. Khobzei, V. Tkach, A. Mikhailovskaya, S. Haliuk, O. Eliiashiv, A. Samila, M. Parfjonovs, J. Porins, T. Salgals, V. Bobrovs, D. Vovchuk
abstract: Time modulation introduces new possibilities for controlling electromagnetic interactions in structured media. While theoretical predictions suggest unique phenomena arising from rapid changes in material susceptibilities comparable to carrier oscillation periods, experimental progress has been slower. However, gradual and practically achievable parametric changes in effective media offer both fundamental interest and immediate applications. In this study, we investigate modal hierarchies in a deformable Fabry-Perot resonator composed of a wire array embedded in a compressible dielectric. Our investigation includes a set of simulations and experimental measurements. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> wired structure appeared as the best candidate for the compression/decompression due to evenly changing eigenmode with high Q-factor value. Experimental verification met a challenge for a search of appropriate material for the wire media's host with suitable EM and elastic properties. Therefore, wires of the structure were inserted into an elastic foam that allows tunability of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> wired structure over a 3 -fold range that corresponds to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10-30 ~\text{mm}$</tex> of the wire media cross-section, enabling remarkable electromagnetic adaptability. The resonator exhibits extreme sensitivity to mechanical deformation, with a 0.3 mm change in lattice constant (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 0.002 \lambda$</tex>) causing a significant shift of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.7-1.8 \text{GHz}$</tex> in the Fabry-Perot resonance frequency range. This high responsiveness positions deformable electromagnetic metamaterials as adaptive components, facilitating new wireless communication systems where frequency, bandwidth, and signal direction can be dynamically optimized to meet varying environmental and user requirements.

title: Mix Activation Functions Multi-Hidden-Layered LSTM Model for Logistic Vehicle Dispatching
authors: Ywh-Leh Chou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study investigates the impact of diverse activation functions across hidden layers in Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. Activation functions significantly influence performance and convergence, yet each has inherent limitations. To address these constraints, a dual activation function approach is proposed, optimizing combinations for hidden layers to enhance accuracy and computational efficiency. The proposed LSTM model comprises five layers: an input layer, three hidden layers, and an output layer. Activation functions are implemented across the hidden layers, with a particular focus on optimizing configurations for the input and hidden layers. Evaluated on a real-world logistic vehicle dispatching scenario, the model demonstrates a 25% reduction in Mean Squared Error (MSE) and a 15% improvement in other metrics over conventional LSTMs. Significant tests confirm its superior predictive accuracy and error reduction.

title: Study on Universal Approximators for the EFVIE Solution of Inhomogeneous Dielectric Objects
authors: Ji–Yuan Wang, Xin–Yue Lou, Xiao–Min Pan
abstract: In the field of frequency-domain electromagnetism, the electric field volume integral equation (EFVIE) describes the phenomenon of electromagnetic scattering from inhomogeneous dielectric objects. To solve the EFVIE by deep learning (DL), a mapping from real-valued numbers to complex-valued numbers has to be approximated where the electric field is viewed as a function of the spatial coordinates. This work investigated four DL-based solvers, or to say, universal approximators based on different universal approximation theorem. A numerical comparative study is conducted on the EFVIE solution of three-dimensional (3-D) inhomogeneous dielectric objects with respect to different network structures to handle the phase information contained in the complex-valued numbers. The results demonstrate that our proposed hybrid-valued universal approximator has best performance among the investigated network structures.

title: Triple-Band Pass Filter Using Substrate Integrated Waveguides with Open Loop Resonators for Ku/K Band Applications
authors: Pranav Krishnan, Sahithya Kattamuri, A. P. Praveen, Sreedevi K. Menon
abstract: This paper describes the design and analysis of a substrate-integrated waveguide (SIW) triple bandpass filter for applications in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ku} / \mathrm{K}$</tex> bands. This structure is implemented using rectangular open-loop resonators on conducting plates. The substrate has a total thickness of 1.64 mm. The substrate material used is RO4003C (RT-Rogers) with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varepsilon_{r}=3.38$</tex>. For the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ku} / \mathrm{K}$</tex> band, the SIW, designed with a 15 GHz cutoff frequency, is modified to achieve triple passbands at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15.87 \text{GHz}, 17.6 \text{GHz}$</tex>, and 19.39 GHz. This design exhibits miniaturization, which offers several advantages, including reduced material costs, easier integration with other microwave components, lower weight, and improved compatibility with modern compact communication systems. Tapered microstrip-to-SIW transitions are integrated at the ports to ensure proper impedance matching at the input and output. The proposed triple-band SIW filters utilize the Defective Patch Slot (DPS) and Defective Ground Slot (DGS) approaches with open-loop resonators to disrupt the electromagnetic fields within the SIW cavity, thereby creating multiple resonances from a single compact resonator. The dimensions of the filter are obtained using fundamental relations and optimized using ANSYS HFSS. Fabrication is done via photolithography, followed by a chemical etching process. This design achieves high <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Q$</tex>-factors of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$226.7,1706$</tex>, and 484.78 respectively, demonstrating an effective method for producing high-performance, multi-band SIW filters with desired passbands, controlled by the initial SIW dimensions and rectangular open-loop resonator patterns. The application of this study helps in satellite and radar communication systems where miniaturized structures are needed.

title: Calibration of the trapped ion quantum computer
authors: Marek Źyczkowski, Szymon Fiderkiewicz, Grzegorz Czelusta, Bartosz Grygielski, Wawrzyniec Suleja, Marcin Sadowski, Mariusz Semczuk, Grzegorz Kasprowicz, Jakub Mielczarek
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This article provides an overview of the ion trap quantum computer being developed in the MIKOK project. It focuses on the hardware architecture, particularly the optical infrastructure, and outlines the core calibration procedures essential for system computational utility. The insights presented aim to support and inform other research teams working on similar quantum computing technologies.

title: Optimal Operation Strategy of a Multi-Energy Integrated System for Minimizing Renewable Energy Curtailment
authors: Yuhan Shao, Grazia Todeschini
abstract: This paper proposes an integrated energy system that couples electricity, hydrogen, and carbon within a coordinated multi-energy operational framework. To achieve optimal coordination among these subsystems, a mixed-integer programming model is developed with the objective of minimizing renewable energy curtailment and is validated using real-world data from a region in Yorkshire, United Kingdom. Case studies demonstrate curtailment reductions of 97.58% on a typical day and 56.94% over a 2,208-hour test period. These improvements are attributed to the effectiveness of the multi-energy coupling strategy in enhancing internal energy utilization and system self-sufficiency. Furthermore, the integration of a hydrogen carbon methanation pathway increases the flexibility of the system and the overall economic viability. These results confirm the potential of the proposed approach for integrated energy systems that aim to achieve carbon neutrality.

title: Prompt Inject Detection with Generative Explanation as an Investigative Tool
authors: Jonathan Pan, Swee Liang Wong, Yidi Yuan, Xin Wei Chia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are vulnerable to adversarial prompt based injects. These injects could jailbreak or exploit vulnerabilities within these models with explicit prompt requests leading to undesired responses. In the context of investigating prompt injects, the challenge is the sheer volume of input prompts involved that are likely to be largely benign. This investigative challenge is further complicated by the semantics and subjectivity of the input prompts involved in the LLM conversation with its user and the context of the environment to which the conversation is being carried out. Hence, the challenge for AI security investigators would be twofold. The first is to identify adversarial prompt injects and then to assess whether the input prompt is contextually benign or adversarial. For the first step, this could be done using existing AI security solutions like guardrails to detect and protect the LLMs. Guardrails have been developed using a variety of approaches. A popular approach is to use signature based. Another popular approach to develop AI models to classify such prompts include the use of NLP based models like a language model. However, in the context of conducting an AI security investigation of prompt injects, these guardrails lack the ability to aid investigators in triaging or assessing the identified input prompts. In this applied research exploration, we explore the use of a text generation capabilities of LLM to detect prompt injects and generate explanation for its detections to aid AI security investigators in assessing and triaging of such prompt inject detections. The practical benefit of such a tool is to ease the task of conducting investigation into prompt injects.

title: Influence of Superconducting Fault Current Limiter Operation on Power Transformer
authors: Krzysztof Solak, Bartosz Brusilowicz, Waldemar Rebizant
abstract: Superconducting Fault Current Limiters (SFCLs) are devices designed to protect power systems from the detrimental effects of short-circuit currents. In SFCLs, high-temperature superconducting (HTS) tapes of the second generation (2G) are used. These HTS 2G tapes enter a resistive state—a process known as quenching—when the tape's characteristic critical current is exceeded. This transition effectively limits the fault current, and the critical current thus determines the precise activation point of the SFCL. The SFCL can be installed near a power transformer, for example, in a transformer feeder, where it effectively limits short-circuit currents flowing into the transformer. Thanks to this, the ageing of power transformers and other equipment is reduced, which helps to extend the operational lifespan of power system components. The paper presents the research results related to the influence of SFCL operation on power transformers and their protections. Simulation and experimental results reveal certain limitations in power transformer performance and protection when an SFCL is closely installed.

title: Surface Plasmon Resonance Excited by Twisted Fiber for Highly Sensitive Refractive Index Sensing
authors: Lingling Li, Yuheng Zuo, Peizhen Jiang, Fang Liu, Nina Yue, Yan Yang, Ai Zhou
abstract: We have proposed and demonstrated a twisted structure fiber that realizes the concept of surface plasmon resonance (SPR) sensor for high-sensitivity refractive index sensing. The sensor is made of a side single-hole-two-core fiber (SSHTF) inserted into a single-mode fiber (SMF) and a multi-mode fiber (MMF). The SSHTF is rotated when heated to form a twisted structure. The unique design of the twisted structure provides the sensor with a different SPR incident angle compared to that of without twisting. The SPR incident angle is adjustable, regulated by the spacing of the twisted turns of the optical fiber. This adjustability enables the sensor to have different refractive index sensitivities, addressing the limitation of single sensitivity enhancement of sensitive materials. The optimized sensing device exhibits an excellent performance with the maximum sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2621.74 \text{nm} /$</tex> RIU within the refractive index range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.33-1.38$</tex>. This highly sensitive performance confers a significant advantage to the sensor in the field of biosensing.

title: Cost-Effective scheduling and flexibility provision of EV aggregators under departure uncertainty
authors: Khaled Abedrabboh, Luluwah Al-Fagih
abstract: Rapid electrification of transport presents both challenges and opportunities for distribution system operators (DSOs) seeking to balance supply and demand. In particular, the inherent uncertainty in electric vehicle (EV) user behaviour, in particular arrival and departure times, and state-of-charge requirements, complicates day-ahead scheduling and may lead to suboptimal grid utilisation or unmet charging needs. This paper makes two key contributions. First, it formulates a day-ahead robust optimisation model that accounts for early departure uncertainty via a min-max framework, ensuring guaranteed feasibility under worst-case conditions. Second, it proposes a rollinghorizon dynamic optimisation strategy that re-solves convex scheduling problems in real time as EV availability and market prices are revealed. Together, these approaches are compared under identical local energy and flexibility market constructs. The methodology integrates vehicle state-of-charge dynamics, market participation constraints, and flexibility limits into a unified convex optimisation problem. The robust model utilises pessimistic departure times, while the dynamic model updates schedules hourly based on actual EV behaviour. Case studies with a fleet of 50 EVs demonstrate that the proposed methods can achieve cost savings between 18% and 55% for EV owners. Moreover, the dynamic approach yields more efficient outcomes when compared to robust optimisation. These results highlight the impact of real-time adaptability in EV aggregation, providing DSOs and aggregators with actionable insights on scheduling strategies that balance economic performance and reliability in emerging flexibility markets.

title: Heuristic Settings of Virtual Orders of Class Labels for Nominal Classification
authors: Han Liu, Yinghui Pan, Hao Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: In multi-class classification tasks, binary decomposition of the class attribute is necessary for some learning algorithms such as support vector machines. While the class attribute is nominal, the binary decomposition is typically done in an unordered way, which can result in a negative impact on the effectiveness and efficiency of learning binary classifiers in some scenarios. In this paper, we explore whether it is achievable to improve the performance of nominal classification by setting virtual class orders for achieving ordered binary decomposition of the class attribute. Specifically, we propose a framework to search for virtual label orders that are suitable for effectively transforming a nominal classification problem into simpler binary ones, where the framework consists of a heuristic search module for searching local optimal orders and an ensemble module for combining the orders. The experimental results show that our framework leads to an improvement of the classification performance in comparison with arbitrarily assigning a label order or setting the class labels to be unordered. The current work can be regarded as a type of class representation learning. Keywords:

title: The Safe and Smart Use of AI at Comenius University
authors: Katarina Pišútová, Katarína Kánova, Katarína Revayova, Alžbeta Juhásová, Eleonóra Beňová
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Artificial intelligence is rapidly transforming higher education, offering significant opportunities for innovation, as well as introducing new ethical, safety, and security challenges. At Comenius University, systematic efforts have been underway for a few years to address these issues, through the development of institutional guidelines that promote responsible and honest use of AI. Building on this foundation, this paper examines both the advantages and risks of AI adoption in academic environments and focuses on a recent training initiative by the Training Center, a part of the Center for Information Technologies at Comenius University. The initiative focuses on the creation of a comprehensive, interactive, and engaging training course aimed at equipping all university employees and students with the skills necessary for the safe and secure use of AI. This paper introduces the structure and pedagogical design of the course, and outlines the rationale for its development. We believe that this training model successfully balances efficiency, accessibility, and quality, and may serve as a replicable blueprint for other universities seeking to implement large-scale educational interventions. In doing so, it contributes to ongoing international discussions on how higher education institutions can navigate the challenges of AI, while also safeguarding academic integrity, security, and trust.

title: An Enhanced Probabilistic Optimal Power Flow Analysis for Power System using Zhao’s Point Estimation Method with Nataf Transformation
authors: Siripat Somchit, Rongrit Chatthaworn
abstract: This study presents an enhanced Probabilistic Optimal Power Flow (POPF) analysis by integrating Zhao’s Point Estimation Method (Zhao’s PEM) with the Nataf Transformation (NT), aiming to improve computational burden and accuracy when considering power system uncertainties.Traditionally, Monte Carlo Simulation (MCS) is widely utilized for POPF calculations due to its ability to generate a comprehensive set of scenarios that effectively capture uncertainties. However, MCS is computationally intensive, often requiring a large number of scenarios to achieve accurate results, which leads to high computational time. In contrast, Zhao’s PEM with NT can effectively represent uncertainties using fewer scenarios than MCS, thereby reducing overall computational time. Accordingly, Zhao’s PEM with NT is applied as an efficient approach for scenario generation in POPF calculation. The performances of the 3-point, 5-point, and 7-point of Zhao’s PEM with NT are compared with the results obtained from MCS in terms of their mean and standard deviation of the POPF parameters. The IEEE 14-bus system is employed to test and validate the POPF. Simulation results indicate that the 7-point of Zhao’s PEM with NT delivers mean and standard deviation values most closely aligned with those of the MCS, while achieving a 99.8544% reduction in computational time.
