title: A Multiplatform Application for Personalized Educational Materials in Special Needs Education
authors: Miroslav Murin, Lenka Bubeňková, Branislav Zurian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a multi-platform application designed to support teachers in creating and distributing personalized interactive educational materials for students with mental disabilities. Traditional educational materials often fail to effectively address the diverse individual needs of these students, complicating their learning process. The developed application provides an intuitive interface for teachers to create four types of interactive activities: puzzles, quizzes, word jumbles, and connection exercises. The application was implemented using Node.js with TypeScript for the server-side and Flutter for the client-side, ensuring compatibility across various devices. A usability evaluation using the System Usability Scale (SUS) methodology yielded a score of 86.60%, indicating excellent usability. Furthermore, practical testing in a special education environment demonstrated the application’s efficacy in enhancing student engagement and learning outcomes. Compared to existing solutions, the developed application provides enhanced personalization options and a simplified interface specifically designed for children with mental disabilities.

title: Semiconductor Memories for Low-Power and Low-Compute Hardware-Oriented Artificial Intelligence System
authors: Soomin Kim, Yeji Lee, So Won Son, Sungjun Kim, Soo Youn Kim, Myounggon Kang, Seongjae Cho
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: The development of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies for reasoning based on big data is rapidly advancing day by day. Moving beyond large language models (LLMs), recent technological trends show the emergence of large vision models (LVMs), indicating that the application scope of AI is expanding at an accelerated pace. Currently, most AI services are implemented through software technologies. However, from the perspective of energy saving and environmental pollution, it is a crucial turning point where a shift to hardware-oriented AI technology must take place. Hardware-oriented AI aims to move away from the conventional series high-speed operation, towards low-power computing technologies that maximize computational concurrency. In order to achieve this goal, changes in computing architecture are necessary, with semiconductor memory technology playing a central role. Simultaneously, recent research indicates that high-speed, large-scale computation systems naturally lead to increased system temperatures, which can produce gases harmful to human health. Although these goals differ in terms of the original starting points, all these technological objectives share a common aim of low-power and small-number computing. This paper examines next-generation AI computing technologies based on large-capacity memory technologies, specifically dynamic random-access memory (DRAM) and flash memories built on relatively mature Si fabrication processing suitable for chip production, evaluating pattern recognition accuracies.

title: Dense Supervised Contrastive Learning for Few-Shot Remote Sensing Scene Classification
authors: Ge Liu, Xiangzhong Fang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Few-shot remote sensing scene classification (FSRSSC) tackles the challenge of recognizing novel scene categories with only a limited number of labeled examples, which heavily relies on pre-trained transferable deep representations. Recent advances have widely explored contrastive learning to improve global feature representations for this task. However, we argue that global feature representations often fail to capture the fine-grained local features crucial for distinguishing remote sensing scenes, which typically include numerous small-scale, densely distributed objects. To address this limitation, we propose Dense Supervised Contrastive Learning (DSCL), which applies supervised contrastive learning at the patch level to improve local feature discriminability. By optimizing a dense pairwise similarity loss across local patches, DSCL significantly boosts generalization in few-shot scenarios. Experiments on three benchmark datasets (UCM, WHU-RS19, and NWPU-RESISC45) demonstrate that DSCL achieves competitive performance compared to recent state-of-the-art methods in both 5-way 1-shot and 5-shot settings, highlighting the potential of local-level feature learning for FSRSSC.

title: Enhancing Dermatological Diagnosis with Few-Shot Learning
authors: Kaustubh Patil, Dhanashri Patil, Anjana Rajagopal, Rachana Nair, Mohamad Ali Patel
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Automated skin disease classification poses significant challenges due to limited labeled dermatological data and class imbalance. This study proposes a deep learning-based system that leverages Few-Shot Learning (FSL) to enhance multiskin disease detection, focusing on Vitiligo, Seborrheic Keratosis, and Eczema. Utilizing a 3 -way N -shot learning approach, we assess the performance of VGG19, ResNet50, and DenseNet121 under 5 -shot, 7 -shot, and 10 -shot settings. Experimental results indicate that DenseNet121 achieves the highest accuracy of 96.66% and an F1-score of 0.97 in the 10- shot configuration, demonstrating its superior generalization. ResNet50 shows robust performance in the 5 -shot setting (93.33% accuracy, 0.92 F1score) but drops to 83.33% accuracy and 0.85 F1-score in the 10 -shot scenario, suggesting sensitivity to data volume. VGG19 lags behind, with a peak accuracy of 73.66% and an F1-score of 0.75. Incorporating attention mechanisms after each pretrained model further improves classification accuracy and F1-scores, demonstrating the effectiveness of FSL combined with transfer learning in dermatological applications, making it a viable AIassisted diagnostic tool for low-resource clinical settings.

title: Laser Scattering Measurement of AC Electric Field-Induced Dynamic Characteristics of Transformer Oil-Water Interfaces
authors: Tian Yuan, Jianwei Shao, Zhuo Wei, Qi Wang, Gang Wu, Mengyuan Wang, Yin Zhang, Xiaoqin Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: The synergistic effect of AC electric fields and moisture in transformer oil causes insulation degradation, but quantitative methods for dynamic oil-water interfaces remain lacking. This research uses colloid chemistry theory modeling, molecular dynamics simulation, and laser scattering technologies to study the microstructural development of the transformer oil-water interface under an AC electric field. It establishes a quantitative relationship between the grayscale value of the Tyndall Effect, electric field strength, and moisture content, as well as an analysis of the oil expansion phenomenon in high-moisture oil samples caused by high electric fields and the coupling of oil flow fluctuations and localized glow phenomenon. Simulations reveal that an AC electric field can increase the diffusion depth of the water phase and cause uneven thickening of the transition layer. Experimental results reveal that within the range of 0-6 kV, the grayscale value exhibits a linear correlation with the electric field strength. Furthermore, the higher the moisture content, the more electric field-induced scattering occurs. For the first time, the electric field-induced oil swelling lens effect is observed, where localized glow phenomenon migrates with oil flow. The proposed non-intrusive method surpasses traditional techniques, enabling real-time monitoring of interface dynamics for transformer insulation assessment.

title: Quantum Federated Learning: A Comprehensive Survey
authors: Md Raihan Uddin, Shaba Shaon, Ratun Rahman, Dinh C. Nguyen, Octavia Dobre, Dusit Niyato
abstract: Quantum federated learning (QFL) is a combination of distributed quantum computing and federated machine learning, integrating the strengths of both to enable privacy-preserving decentralized learning with quantum-enhanced capabilities. It appears as a promising approach for addressing challenges in efficient and secure model training across distributed quantum systems. This paper presents a comprehensive survey on QFL, exploring its key concepts, fundamentals, applications, and emerging challenges in this rapidly developing field. Specifically, we begin with an introduction to the recent advancements of QFL, followed by discussion on its market opportunity and background knowledge. We then discuss the motivation behind the integration of quantum computing and federated learning, highlighting its working principle. Moreover, we review the fundamentals of QFL and its taxonomy. Particularly, we explore federation architecture, networking topology, communication schemes, optimization techniques, and security mechanisms within QFL frameworks. Furthermore, we investigate applications of QFL across several domains which include vehicular networks, healthcare networks, satellite networks, metaverse, and network security. Additionally, we analyze frameworks and platforms related to QFL, delving into its prototype implementations, and provide a detailed case study. Key insights and lessons learned from this review of QFL are also highlighted. We complete the survey by identifying current challenges and outlining potential avenues for future research in this rapidly advancing field.

title: Shared Switched Capacitor Multi Output Hybrid Converter for High Conversion Ratio Applications
authors: Ratul Das, Hanh-Phuc Le
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Solid-State Circuits Society
abstract: This work presents a shared-switched-capacitor multi-output hybrid (SSC-MoH) converter to support large conversion ratios from a 12V-24V input to three separate outputs of 0.8V-1.8V. The 6-switch converter includes a 3X-step-down switched capacitor (SC) front-end that is fully soft-charged and shared by three output inductors. The output voltages are individually regulated using PWM signals from a power-collaborative control (PCC). The chip was manufactured in a 130nm HV BCD process, achieving a peak efficiency of 87.14%, 30X conversion ratio, and 11.93W peak output power in system evaluation.

title: Chronic Kidney Disease Classification: A Random Forest Approach with Optimized Preprocessing
authors: V Varshini, G. Akila, Rajan Ravichandran, Pradeeba Sridhar, R.Krishna Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a serious medical condition that necessitates early diagnosis to prevent long-term complications and improve patient outcomes. Existing studies often highlight limitations such as inconsistent preprocessing, suboptimal accuracy, and a lack of robustness. This study presents an effective classification approach for CKD detection using the UCI CKD dataset. The raw data set was rigorously preprocessed which involved feature extraction, management of categorical and numerical variables, and appropriate data partitioning. A Random Forest classifier was trained and evaluated using a robust cross-validation strategy, with typical splits involving 80% for training and $20 \%$ for testing. The proposed model achieves a classification accuracy of 99%, demonstrating the efficacy of our preprocessing strategy combined with the Random Forest algorithm. Our method distinguishes itself by focusing on simplicity, reproducibility, and high performance. The results support the suitability of Random Forest with clean, well-prepared data for reliable CKD prediction in clinical environments. Future work will focus on validating this approach with datasets collected from the Indian subcontinent for better understanding CKD prevalence and facilitate early diagnosis, particularly within specific cohorts such as diabetic or hypertensive populations, where early detection can significantly aid in timely treatment.

title: Development of Improved Gyrotron-based System for CVD Diamond Synthesis
authors: S. A. Bogdanov, A. L. Vikharev, A. V. Aktanaev, M. Yu. Glyavin, A. M. Gorbachev, S. A. Goryachev, M. V. Kamenskiy, M. V. Morozkin, A. A. Orlovskiy, M. D. Proyavin, D. I. Sobolev
abstract: The report presents a description of a complex for chemical vapor deposition diamond disks and films production, with using a gyrotron at the main cyclotron resonance and a magnetically shielded solenoid, which allowed for an approximately twofold increase in the microwave radiation power up to 20–25 kW in CW mode and an enlarge in the integral efficiency of the system in comparison with previously implemented ones, operated at second harmonic of gyrofrequency. The complex is equipped with an automated control system to ensure stable long-term (the characteristic process time is about a week) operation.

title: Biomarker-Based Prediction of Parkinson’s Disease Onset Using Machine Learning
authors: Dhanashri Solanki, Anshul B A, Gayathri Jayan, Bandi Nikitha, Hema M S, Roopashree Shailendra
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: Since traditional diagnostic approaches for Parkinson’s Disease (PD) tend to rely on the detection of signs of neurological impairment, they do not find PD until after irreparable damage has been inflicted. In this paper, the capability of several machine learning models in predicting the early onset of PD was analyzed by using biomarker data. KNN, Logistic Regression, SVM , Decision tree and Random Forest, were all implemented on the AMP-PD dataset which consists of clinical and biomarker indicators obtained from 248 unique participants. This dataset was cleaned by removing irrelevant features, followed by normalization, and standardization. Models were trained by using a 80:20 train-test split with 5-fold cross validation to ensure robust performance. They were then evaluated based on accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score measurement, and ROC-AUC value to determine the performance. It was found that the Decision tree model had the highest accuracy of 97% after the post-pruning technique was applied. Random Forests achieved an accuracy of 96% with a high recall for the PD class making it useful in cases where sensitivity is of utmost priority. This study illustrates the value of contrasting different ML models for PD prediction and aims to address the lack of research in investigating biomarker-based diagnostics.

title: A Compact Broadband 10 GHz Quadrature Modulator for Millimeter-Wave Systems
authors: Jacqueline Damas, Abdi T. Abdalla
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The development of a reliable quadrature intermediate frequency (IF) modulator depends significantly on achieving high linearity and a low output noise floor in analog systems. Quadrature modulation is widely employed in digital communication systems, including fifth-generation (5 G) networks. This paper presents a low-cost, miniature, and highly integrated broadband IF quadrature modulator, incorporating an isolated hybrid up-converter IQ mixer and low-noise amplifiers for IF signal modulation. The proposed system is implemented using off-the-shelf components assembled on a printed circuit board (PCB), with a total power consumption of 950 mW. The design utilizes a four-layer PCB, with the top metal layer featuring minimum trace width, trace-to-trace clearance, and via diameter of 0.1 mm. A comprehensive performance analysis is provided, considering bandwidth, modulation gain, isolation, phase noise, and support for various modulation formats. Simulated and measured results show close agreement, validating the modulator’s effectiveness for integration in IF systems where secure bandwidth availability is critical, such as in WiGi applications. The modulator achieves a wide bandwidth of 7 GHz, spanning $6.5 \mathrm{GHz}-13.5 \mathrm{GHz}$, as demonstrated by the reflection coefficients of the in-phase and quadrature inputs. The IQ module exhibits a 2.5 dB noise figure, over the $10-16 \mathrm{GHz}$ RF range, preserving spectral purity. The carrier noise floor at a 1 MHz frequency offset is approximately $-120 \mathrm{dBc} / \mathrm{Hz}$. We verified the IQ module’s functionality by integrating it into a radio over fiber (RoF) system to modulate the signal before transmission.

title: Band-Aid Backdoor: A Dual-Branch Framework for Physical Backdoor Attacks on Face Recognition Systems
authors: Jun-Hong Li, Ying-Qi Zheng, Patrick P. K. Chan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: A physical backdoor attack framework against face recognition systems, using band-aid stickers as visually plausible triggers, is proposed. The proposed method introduces a dual-branch architecture that decouples identity recognition from trigger classification, enabling the model to maintain high recognition accuracy on clean inputs while inducing targeted misclassification when a specific physical trigger is present. To ensure photorealistic integration, the band-aid undergoes a 3D curvature-aware warping and illumination adjustment process before being applied to facial images. Experiments conducted under both digital and real-world conditions demonstrate the effectiveness and specificity of the attack. Compared to a standard single-task model, the dual-branch model achieves significantly higher attack success rates and lower false positive rates, while remaining robust to unseen trigger types. However, results also reveal a performance gap between digital and physical scenarios, emphasizing the importance of visual distinctiveness and domain consistency. This work highlights the practical feasibility of physical backdoor attacks and provides insights into their design and mitigation.

title: Highly-Efficient Near-Field Thermophotovoltaics Based on Nanowire Metamaterials for Low-Grade Heat Recovery
authors: X. Li, S. Zhang, Y. Dang, Y. Li, Y. Jin, Y. Ma
abstract: The challenges associated with designing and developing practical near-field thermophotovoltaic (NFTPV) devices for low-grade heat recovery have predominantly revolved around enhancing the thermoelectric conversion performance. In response to this, we introduce a low-temperature NFTPV device, aimed at achieving both high energy conversion efficiency and substantial electrical output power. The system includes an emitter composed of tungsten nanowire (WNA)-based hyperbolic metamaterial and a TPV cell comprising p-i-n indium antimonide (InSb) nanowires. The WNA emitter demonstrates a hyperbolic dispersion supporting a high density of states, and the photon tunneling through the vacuum gap enhances and regulates the radiative heat flux according to the source temperature. Our innovative NFTPV cell incorporates nanowire structures for the first time, significantly enlarging the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{p}-\mathrm{n}$</tex> junction and allowing for increased excitation of photon-generated carriers to elevate the current intensities. This calculation method can also be applied to other novel structures. Under operating temperatures of 500 K for the emitter and 300 K for the TPV cell with a 50 nm vacuum gap between them, the designed device can achieve an approximate 34% conversion efficiency and approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1363 \text{Wm}^{-2}$</tex> electrical output power, which are approximately 10 times and 5 times improvement than the traditional bulk scheme. This proposed method offers a promising avenue for advancing NFTPV devices in low-grade heat recovery applications, thus holding significant potential for achieving high-efficiency energy conversion and high power density.

title: Multimodal Emotion Recognition Using Speech and Facial Information Based on Late Fusion
authors: Jin-Jing Jiang, Eri Sato-Shimokawara
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Emotion recognition plays a key role in human-computer interaction(HCI) and intelligent systems. This study proposes a multimodal approach that combines facial expressions and speech information to improve classification accuracy. VGG16-based CNN and 1D-CNN are used for facial and speech recognition, respectively. A weighted late fusion strategy integrates both outputs to make the final prediction. Experiments using KDEF and SAVEE datasets demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms unimodal models, particularly for neutral, fear, and disgust emotions, while reducing gender bias. The results highlight the effectiveness of multimodal fusion in enhancing emotion recognition.

title: Challenges of Fault Current Analysis using IEC 60909 and ENA G74 in Grids Dominated by Converter Fed Generation
authors: Stephen Sommerville, Marko Aunedi, Gareth A Taylor
abstract: Fault current analysis is a key part of designing, managing and analysing an electrical network. The traditional IEC 60909 calculation method has been well established in standards for many decades, however it is based on a number of simplified assumptions to make the computational process simple and efficient. A comparison is also included with the ENA G74 short circuit calculation method. The assumptions used in these methods are creating misleading results in large renewable energy generation plants that have a significant portion of Converter Fed Generation (CFG), by overstating the retained voltages and increasing the calculated fault levels. This paper shows how these assumptions break down in generation sites dominated by CFG, and can produce unrealistic results, due to the constant current output of the CFG. The paper also outlines some of the shortfalls in assessment of Grid Forming Inverters fault contribution.

title: Extending Nvidia Omniverse for Industrial Computer Vision Tasks: Direct 3D Mesh Manipulation and Ageing for Enhanced Fault Detection and Packaging Processes
authors: Johannes Metzler, Paul Philipp Seiler, Till Haas, Dirk Reichelt
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Industrial computer vision increasingly uses synthetic image data to train deep learning models for object detection and quality control. NVIDIA Omniverse excels at generating such data via 3D mesh-based environments and domain randomization but cannot alter meshes directly, limiting variability to lighting, object placement, and camera angles. We present an Omniverse extension that procedurally manipulates meshes-adding defects like cracks or deformations-to produce realistic fault scenarios in manufactured components. We also simulate packaging processes (e.g., vacuum sealing) and introduce a cellular-automata-driven surface-aging algorithm to model corrosion and mold growth (demonstrated on rusting rims and decaying apples). By moving beyond purely texture-based defect simulation, our approach enhances dataset realism and generalization, boosting model accuracy in real-world industrial tasks. This scalable, automated extension broadens the applicability of synthetic data for tailored computer vision training pipelines.

title: Exploiting Phase Singularities in Metasurfaces Design
authors: M. Barbuto, A. Monti, S. Vellucci, A. Alù, F. Bilotti, A. Toscano
abstract: This contribution discusses the potential of phase singularities as a distinct design tool to enhance the functionality of metasurfaces. By generating points of undefined phase, metasurfaces can create structured fields like vortices and composite vortex beams and achieve unique electromagnetic responses. The work combines theoretical modeling and simulations to demonstrate how phase singularities facilitate advanced applications such as beam steering and shaping, while also reducing design complexity. Practical aspects, including materials and fabrication for microwave implementations, are considered. The findings highlight the versatility of phase singularities in enabling novel metasurface designs and expanding their application scope.

title: Classification of Monofloral and Polyfloral Honey using Near-Infrared Spectroscopy and Chemometric Techniques
authors: Petya Veleva, Svilen Lazarov, Simeon Uzunov, Tsvetelina Georgieva
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Honey is a widely consumed natural product with substantial commercial importance. The ability to rapidly and reliably differentiate honey types would benefit both producers and consumers. This study examines the application of nearinfrared (NIR) spectroscopy, combined with chemometric analysis, to differentiate between monofloral and polyfloral honey. A total of 102 honey samples (44 monofloral and 58 polyfloral) were collected from various apiaries across Bulgaria, with botanical origins confirmed through melissopalynology analysis. Spectral data were acquired using a NIRQuest 512 scanning spectrometer (Ocean Optics, Inc.) in the 900-1700 nm range, employing a reflection fiber-optic probe. Soft Independent Modeling of Class Analogy (SIMCA) models were created using various preprocessing techniques. The SIMCA model based on autoscaling, smoothing, and first derivative transformation demonstrated the most consistent performance, with calibration and test accuracies of 98.04 % and 96.08 %, respectively. These results emphasize the potential of NIR spectroscopy as a fast, non-destructive screening tool for honey type classification. In addition, such techniques may be incorporated into industrial workflows for honey quality assessment, including the use of portable NIR instruments suitable for on-site applications.

title: Sparse Transformer for Anomaly Detection with Association Discrepancy
authors: Sanjeev Shrestha, Yifan Zhang, Hui Liu, Arjun Silwal
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Multivariate time-series anomaly detection aims to identify deviations from normal behavior in data streams collected simultaneously from multiple sensors and systems. This approach is widely used across diverse industries to support smooth operation, maintenance, and fault prevention. Modeling complex temporal dynamics presents a significant challenge. In recent years, transformer-based models such as Anomaly Transformer have shown remarkable performance due to their ability to model long-range temporal dependencies. However, transformer is burdened by the computational inefficiency of the standard attention mechanism. In this paper, we propose a novel transformer-based model, DozerAnomaly, that can efficiently detect anomalies in multivariate time series. We integrated a sparse attention mechanism, Dozer self-attention, with local and seasonal adaptation that captures the locality and seasonality of data patterns. It addresses the quadratic complexity of the standard self-attention mechanism by focusing only on relevant time steps, thereby reducing computational overhead. We employ the association discrepancy between prior and series associations to distinguish normal and abnormal time series patterns. Experimental results in five real-world datasets show that our model achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of accuracy and efficiency, with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 2 \%}$</tex> reduction in floating-point operations (FLOPs) compared to baselines, significantly improving computational efficiency without compromising accuracy.

title: Crystal structure of the new photonic high-index material Wurtzite GaP
authors: Alexander Shalin, Ilia Komendo, Natalja Muracova, Vjaceslavs Bobrovs, Olga Koval
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: High-refractive-index materials have become increasingly critical for advanced photonic applications. Wurtzitestructured gallium phosphide (WZ-GaP) is particularly promising due to its theoretically predicted high refractive index, making it attractive for nanophotonics. We present a rapid, non-destructive approach for characterizing metastable WZ-GaP using powder Xray diffraction, with phase confirmation provided by complementary Raman spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy. Our single-step refinement method enables reliable identification of this metastable phase and accurate determination of its unit cell parameters, even at low concentrations, significantly simplifying structural analysis for potential optoelectronic applications.

title: Fundamental and Generalized Solutions of Maxwell's Equations at Moving Emitters of Electromagnetic Waves
authors: L. A. Alexeyeva, I. A. Kanymgaziyeva
abstract: In the works [1], [2] the authors constructed transport solutions of Maxwell's equations which describe electromagnetic fields of moving particles and charged bodies and surfaces in the entire range of speeds. Here we consider vibration transport solutions of Maxwell's equations of moving emitters of electromagnetic waves of a fixed frequency, moving in a certain direction at a constant speed. Using the Fourier transform of generalized functions, fundamental and generalized solutions of the equations are constructed at sublight speeds, which are less than the speed of propagation of electromagnetic waves in the medium. The properties of the convolution of the Green's tensor of differential equations are used to construct solutions for emitters, both distributed and concentrated on moving surfaces and spatial curves. The influence of the speed of movement and frequency of the emitter on the characteristics of its electromagnetic field is investigated. The obtained results can be used to study the electromagnetic fields of emitters of light and radio waves located on moving objects.

title: Study on Shielding Effect of Brushless Motor Chassis
authors: Renjun Pan, Xin Cao, Qiang-Ming Cai, Longjian Zhou, Quanfeng Jiang, Junbo Li, Junhao Shi, Liping Wang, Haoran Li, Yuyu Zhu
abstract: In this paper, the shielding effect of different materials and different openings in the shielding case is studied. For engineering applications, the shielding efficiency of carbon steel (Q235B) and other materials, the shielding efficiency under different openings of the shielding chassis, and the shielding status of the chassis against motor radiation when the chassis is applied to a small brushless motor are studied by theoretical calculation and simulation tests. The results show that carbon steel (Q235B) has better shielding efficiency in the frequency band from 0 Hz to 100 KHz when the same chassis is made of different materials, and the circular holes in the chassis are more conducive to shielding. The electromagnetic interference can be effectively reduced when the chassis made of carbon steel with array round holes on the side is applied to small brushless motors.

title: Traque: Streamlining College Bus Operations with Real-Time Tracking and Management
authors: Ramana Reddy B, Lalitha Taruna Vishalakshi Mulugur, Vasita Puppala
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: The current transportation systems of educational institutions often face challenges such as lack of reliable tracking, unpredictable delays, and no proper communication channels between students or faculty. This paper talks about Traque, an efficient college bus tracking application built for both iOS and Android. It involves the usage of WebSockets for the exchange of real-time information like live location of the bus, enabling Administrators, Students, Faculty and Parents to track the bus efficiently. This application also includes additional features such as a dedicated communication channel for each bus, ETA prediction using the HERE Maps API, an announcement channel where the Administrator can share circulars and other information related to the buses, a digital bus pass and an efficient notification system. By providing all of these features on a single platform, Traque aims to streamline college bus operations in an effective way.

title: Ground Penetrating Radar-Assisted Multimodal Robot Odometry Using Subsurface Feature Matrix
authors: Haifeng Li, Jiajun Guo, Xuanxin Fan, Huaichao Wang, Ji Liu, Kairat Koshekov, Dezhen Song
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Localization of robots using subsurface features observed by ground-penetrating radar (GPR) enhances and adds robustness to common sensor modalities, as subsurface features are less affected by weather, seasons, and surface changes. We introduce an innovative multimodal odometry approach using inputs from GPR, an inertial measurement unit (IMU), and a wheel encoder. To efficiently address GPR signal noise, we introduce an advanced feature representation called the subsurface feature matrix (SFM). The SFM leverages frequency domain data and identifies peaks within radar scans. Additionally, we propose a novel feature matching method that estimates GPR displacement by aligning SFMs. The integrations from these three input sources are consolidated using a factor graph approach to achieve multimodal robot odometry. Our method has been developed and evaluated with the CMU-GPR public dataset, demonstrating improvements in accuracy and robustness with real-time performance in robotic odometry tasks.

title: Bootstrapping Heterophily Graph Representation Learning via a Large Language Model-Based Approach
authors: Wenxuan Huang, Fengge Wu, Hang Gao, Junsuo Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) excel in homophilic graphs but struggle with heterophilic graphs where connected nodes exhibit divergent characteristics. Existing methods underutilize semantic information in node attributes, a key factor for interpreting heterophilic interactions. To bridge this gap, we propose LLM-Enhanced Graph Neural Network for Heterophily (LEGNNH), a novel framework that synergizes large language model (LLM) with spectral graph convolutions for node classification in heterophilic graphs. LEGNNH operates in three stages: (1) Task-aware semantic embedding using LLMs with instruction-based prompting to encode raw node text; (2) Multi-channel spectral filtering dynamically aggregating local patterns via adaptive low-pass, high-pass, and identity filters; (3) A hierarchical attention module selectively integrates higher-order neighborhood semantics while suppressing noise propagation from label-discordant connections. Addressing the scarcity of heterophilic benchmarks, we contribute two text-attributed graph datasets (YelpNYC and Amazon-Review) with explicit feature-label heterophily. Extensive experiments on seven benchmarks show LEGNNH achieves state-of-the-art performance (average rank 1.86 across 10 baselines), outperforming the best heterophily-specific model by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 3 1 - 5. 3 3 \%}$</tex> accuracy on key datasets.

title: Research on the Complexity of Epilepsy EEG Signals
authors: Shenghu Xiu, Ling Han
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Epileptic EEG signals exhibit non-stationary and nonlinear characteristics. Studying the complexity of epileptic electroencephalography(EEG) signals can reflect the orderliness and synchronization of brain neural system activity. This study investigated the complexity of epileptic EEG signals from three dimensions: temporal, spatial, and spatiotemporal. Furthermore, the study calculated the differences in EEG signal complexity across different frequency bands. The results of the study revealed a significant decrease in temporal and spatial complexity during epileptic seizures, while spatiotemporal complexity showed a significant increase. The results indicate that the complexity of epileptic EEG can effectively distinguish different stages of epilepsy, providing strong support for future research on epilepsy detection and prediction, with significant research value.

title: Experimental Comparative Analysis of Power Losses and THD in BLDC Drives Using Different Inverter Platforms
authors: Dimitar Tsvetanov, Hristo Milushev, Nikolay Djagarov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper presents an experimental comparative analysis of power losses and total harmonic distortion (THD) in brushless DC (BLDC) motor drives using two different inverter platforms: the Texas Instruments BOOSTXL-DRV8305 (silicon-based) and the BOOSTXL-3PHGANINV (GaN-based). The study investigates the efficiency and power quality implications of employing conventional MOSFET-based drivers versus wide-bandgap GaN devices in BLDC drive systems. Experimental tests were conducted under identical operating conditions, with measurements focused on conduction and switching losses, overall inverter efficiency, and current waveform quality. The results demonstrate that the GaN-based inverter exhibits reduced switching losses and improved current waveform fidelity, leading to lower THD compared to the silicon-based platform. These findings highlight the potential of GaN-based power electronics in enhancing the performance of high-efficiency motor drive applications.

title: FastPoint: Super Lightweight Keypoint Detection, Description and Depth Estimation Framework
authors: Chonghao Zhong, Haitao Meng, Wenwei Lin, Gang Chen, Alois Knoll
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Keypoint detection, description and depth estimation are fundamental parts for many computer vision tasks, like image matching and simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) systems. Early methods are based on human heuristics, extracted handcrafted feature from image pixel, which may lead to unstable and confusable results. Recent years learned-based methods have achieved remarkable results in this field. However, most of these methods cannot ensure real-time application, and the lightweight deployment of network models remains challenging. Additionally, the black-box nature of neural network operations lacks interpretability, which constrains further application expansion. This paper proposed a super lightweight framework, FastPoint, used shallow binary neural network combine with handcrafted differentiable module FastLayer, which outputs key-points location, descriptor and depth estimation simultaneously. Our FastPoint is trained on data synthetically created form KITTI Raw dataset and evaluated on HPatches. The results demonstrate that our method achieves competitive performance compared to existing approaches while significantly reducing computational complexity.

title:
Assessment of of CO
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    Pollution Reduction Through a Photovoltaic System
authors: Todor Stoilov, Krasimira Stoilova, Denis Chikurtev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This study derives analytical relations for assessing the absence of carbon dioxide (CO2) pollution from photovoltaic systems. The latter are representatives of the family of “green energy” sources. The electricity they produce does not emit <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>, which is beneficial for the environment and supports society's will to reduce pollution. The assessment of the absence of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> pollution is related to the equivalent amount of electricity that a conventional power system produces. The amount of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> pollution emitted by the current technological energy production system using fossil energy products was estimated. The current value of the lack of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> from the production of one kWh of electricity by a photovoltaic system is estimated for the Bulgarian region

title: Hyperparameter Tuning of Classification Algorithms with a Hyper-Heuristic Framework - the Nested Markov Hyper-Tuner
authors: Nándor Bándi, Noémi Gaskó
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Hyper-heuristic methods have recently attracted research interest due to their effectiveness in solving optimization problems. Hyperparameter optimization (or tuning) is an essential task in machine learning, having huge importance in increasing the performance of models for specific problem instances. In this paper we present a hyper-heuristic framework, the Nested Markov-Chain Hyper-Tuner (NMHT) for the problem of hyperparameter tuning in classification algorithms. Numerical experiments conducted on six datasets and four classifiers highlight the performance of our approach compared to other state-of-the-art hyperparameter tuning methods.

title: Assessment and Prediction of Carbon Emissions Associated with Grid Electricity
authors: Krasimira Stoilova, Todor Stoilov, Galia Angelova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The study presents an approach for estimating carbon emissions from electricity generation. The assessment is based on the available values of carbon emissions and electricity, excluding those from renewable energy sources. This estimate is made for 11 years and on this basis, the forecasts for the next six years are estimated, applying three linear regression models. Numerical simulations of the models are performed. A comparison of the predicted values from the three models is analyzed and discussed.

title: Super Mario A-Star Agent Reloaded
authors: David Šosvald, Jakub Gemrot
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: For over a decade, the iconic Super Mario Bros. game has been used as a benchmark for research in artificial intelligence (AI) and procedural content generation (PCG). Every PCG technique relies on some sort of level validation to ensure that the generated levels are playable. For this, an artificial agent is used to substitute for a human player. The quality of such an agent directly influences the quality of the work built upon it, as it limits the complexity of levels that can be validated, and its performance affects the size of the generative space that can be explored. In this paper, we present a new Super Mario Bros. agent, which first finds a coarse path over the grid-based abstraction of a game level, and then uses the information to guide an A* search through the simulated states of the game. The proposed agent is the first agent that is able to solve all levels with standard Super Mario Bros. features, while also being the most performant (10x fewer node evaluations needed and 8x faster on the most complex level pack), thus it constitutes a new state-of-the-art for the game and should be used as the new level validation standard. Furthermore, we empirically show that the grid-based search alone can be used for the level validation task with almost the same accuracy as the agent while being faster by two orders of magnitude.

title: A Noval Fault Diagnosis Algorithm Based on Optimal Minimum Entropy Morphological Deconvolution
authors: De Zhu, Chunyu Chen, Dawei Zhao, Qingwei Gao, Dong Sun, Yixiang Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The deconvolution algorithm is effective in eliminating interference components, but it is prone to being influenced by impulse interference, resulting in suboptimal performance in early bearing fault identification. To address this, this paper proposes an optimal minimum entropy-based morphological deconvolution method (OMEMD). Firstly, morphological filtering is enhanced using the morphological mixed-product operator (MMPO) and novel structural element (SE), constructing an optimized adaptive time-varying morphological filter (OATVMF), which enhances filtering performance. Secondly, the OATVMF is incorporated into the optimal minimum entropy deconvolution (OMED), which removes impulse interference components from original samples and enhances the algorithm’s capability to extract periodic fault components under intense impulse interference conditions. Finally, the third-order cumulant diagonal slice spectrum (TODSS) is applied to process the frequency-domain results, enhancing the saliency of faults. This method can effectively eliminate impulse interference and extract weak fault components from incipient fault signals with considerable robustness. The superiority of the proposed method has been verified through multiple sets of experiments.

title:
A Novel Wideband 180
                    <sup>°</sup>
                    Power Divider With High Isolation Network
authors: Zhonghao Kou, Xiaoqing Pei, Wei Ma, Xudong Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This work presents a wideband 180° power divider featuring a balun integrated with a compact broadband isolation network to enhance both isolation and impedance matching. The isolation network, strategically positioned between the balun’s differential output ports, employs an inverting transformer combined with an optimized series resistor and a shunt capacitor. This configuration facilitates efficient single-ended-to-differential signal conversion while minimizing coupling and interference between the balanced ports. Theoretical analysis based on even–odd mode decomposition reveals that the shunt capacitor effectively compensates for the leakage inductance reactance of the transformer, thereby achieving broadband resistive loading for even-mode absorption and ensuring high isolation across a wide frequency range. Implemented in a 45-nm CMOS process and centered at 21 GHz, the proposed 180° power divider achieves a 45 % relative bandwidth with isolation exceeding 20dB and return loss better than 10 dB. The circuit maintains excellent balance performance, with amplitude and phase errors below 0.56 dB and 4.7<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">°</sup>, respectively, in a compact layout occupying only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$300\times {\mathrm {350~\mu \text {m} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>.

title: Task-Oriented Reliability Modeling and Analysis of Federated Learning-Enabled Intelligent Manufacturing Systems
authors: Xiaoluoteng Song, Xiuwen Fu, Liudong Xing, Rui Peng
abstract: Intelligent manufacturing systems progressively advance toward highly collaborative and distributed decision making. Federated learning (FL)-enabled intelligent manufacturing systems facilitate efficient data processing and intelligent decision making by deploying artificial intelligence models at the edge and integrating model aggregation mechanisms. However, anomalies occurring in the local devices on which the local models depend can propagate through the aggregation process, leading to model contamination and performance degradation, thereby compromising the task reliability of the entire system. To address this issue, this article proposes a reliability modeling approach for FL-enabled intelligent manufacturing systems (FL-IMSs). In the proposed model, we characterize the performance degradation process of the local model caused by terminal device failures and its impact on task reliability. This process includes the effect of data quality degradation triggered by device failures on model performance, as well as failure propagation caused by intermodel dependencies. Furthermore, to assess the impact of model performance variations on practical production tasks, a task-oriented reliability metric is introduced. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed modeling approach effectively captures local model performance degradation and task reliability in FL-IMSs under terminal device failure conditions.

title: Optimization of Spectrum Resource Allocation for Vehicle Platoon in V2X Networks Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zhicong Lin, Hengwei Pan, Yonghua Wang
abstract: The 5 G NR-V2X standard explicitly identifies vehicle platoon as a key application scenario and considers it an essential component for achieving advanced autonomous driving. Therefore, this paper focuses on spectrum allocation optimization for vehicle platoons in the Internet of Vehicles (IoV). To minimize the Age of Information (AoI) between the platoon leader and the infrastructure while maximizing the data transmission probability within the platoon, a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning algorithm is proposed. This algorithm integrates random network distillation and gradient entropy minimization to jointly optimize communication pattern switching, channel selection, and power control. Considering the large state observation space caused by the time-varying channel conditions in IoV, a random network distillation module based on an intrinsic reward mechanism is introduced to enhance the state exploration capability of vehicle platoons. Furthermore, to strengthen coordination among platoon members, a gradient entropy minimization-based approach is employed to improve credit assignment, enabling platoons to accurately assess their contribution to global performance and dynamically adjust their strategies. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, demonstrating superior performance in reducing AoI and improving data transmission probability in platoon-based vehicular communications.

title: MESA: Effective Matching Redundancy Reduction by Semantic Area Segmentation
authors: Yesheng Zhang, Shuhan Shen, Xu Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Matching redundancy, which refers to fine-grained feature comparison between irrelevant image areas, is a prevalent limitation in current feature matching approaches. It leads to unnecessary and error-prone computations, ultimately diminishing matching accuracy. To reduce matching redundancy, we propose MESA and DMESA, both leveraging advanced image understanding of Segment Anything Model (SAM) to establish semantic area matches prior to point matching. These informative area matches, then, can undergo effective internal feature comparison, facilitating precise inside-area point matching. Specifically, MESA adopts a sparse matching framework, while DMESA applies a dense one. Both of them first obtain candidate areas from SAM results through a novel Area Graph (AG). In MESA, matching the candidates is formulated as a graph energy minimization and solved by graphical models derived from AG. In contrast, DMESA performs area matching by generating dense matching distributions on the entire image, aiming at enhancing efficiency. The distributions are produced from off-the-shelf patch matching, modeled as the Gaussian Mixture Model, and refined via the Expectation Maximization. With less repetitive computation, DMESA showcases an area matching speed improvement of nearly five times compared to MESA, while maintaining competitive accuracy. Our methods are extensively evaluated on four different tasks across six datasets, encompassing both indoor and outdoor scenes. The results suggest that our method achieves notable accuracy improvements for nine baselines of point matching in most cases. Furthermore, our methods exhibit promise generalization and improved robustness against image resolution. Code is available at github.com/Easonyesheng/A2PM-MESA.

title: Longitudinal study on Higher Education Engineering students: How their competency-evaluations evolve?
authors: Danilo Valdes-Ramirez, Christian Samhir Grijalva Quinonez, Genaro Zavala
publish: IEEE Revista Iberoamericana de Tecnologias del Aprendizaje
abstract: Previous studies on competency-based education (CBE) in Higher Education (HE) have primarily relied on small samples, short time frames, and self-perceived measures of competencies, leaving a gap in understanding how STEM students’ competencies evolve through direct evaluations. This study addresses the challenge of evaluating how students’ competencies evolve throughout CBE programs in HE. We conducted longitudinal analyses of competency evaluation data from a cohort of 4, 044 STEM students enrolled in CBE programs. The study examines the evolution of students’ observed competency ratios across six academic periods and analyzes variations according to four between-subject variables: sex, preparatory school background, geographic region, and knowledge area. Competency data were collected through institutional evaluation processes and transformed for longitudinal analysis. Statistical procedures, including repeated measures ANOVA, post-hoc tests, and linear mixed-effect models, were applied to identify significant changes in competency ratios across time and between groups. Results revealed statistically significant improvements in the observed competency ratios throughout the six academic periods, indicating consistent growth in students’ demonstrated competencies. However, differences across some demographic and institutional factors highlight points where competency development progresses unevenly. These findings provide empirical evidence of how CBE models influence STEM students’ competency acquisition over time. They offer valuable insights for educators, curriculum designers, and policymakers seeking to strengthen CBE implementation. In particular, the study emphasizes the importance of continuous monitoring and targeted instructional support during specific academic stages to ensure that all students achieve the intended competencies by graduation.

title: Voltage Sharing Between MOSFETs in a SiC-Based Two-Switch Flyback
authors: Joni-Markus Hietanen, Kalyan Gokhale, Brian Veik, Tommi J. Kärkkäinen, Pertti Silventoinen
abstract: The two-switch flyback converter is a variant of the widely used single-switch flyback converter with an additional switch and clamping diodes that limit the peak voltage across each switch to the input DC voltage level. Moreover, the total voltage during the OFF state of the converter operation is divided across two switches, allowing for higher DC input voltages or the use of components with lower voltage ratings. However, contrary to the literature, the voltage is not evenly shared between the series-connected switches on a SiC MOSFET-based two-switch flyback. This imbalance is heavily affected by the capacitive characteristics of the pulse transformer, which is often used to achieve floating gate drive. In this work, the effect is thoroughly analyzed using mathematical and simulation models, and the results are verified with a physical converter prototype. The interwinding capacitance of the pulse transformer was found to have a substantial effect on voltage sharing between MOSFETs.

title: Adaptive Large Language Model for Task Orchestration in 6G Space-Air-Ground Integrated Computing Power Networks
authors: Wang Li, Fengxiao Tang, Ming Zhao, Masako Omachi, Nei Kato
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: With the rapid deployment of 5G and the advancement of 6G research, traditional network architectures face challenges in meeting the demands of massive data transmission and low-latency computing. Computing Power Networks (CPN) integrate communication and computation resources to support emerging applications efficiently. Meanwhile, the Space-Air Ground Integrated Networks (SAGIN) provides global coverage and multi-layer coordination as acore 6G architecture. This paper proposes SAGIN-CPN, a heterogeneous network architecture that combines SAGIN and CPN, and introduces TOLLM, an Adaptive Large Language Model (LLM)-Based Task Orchestration (TOLLM) scheme. TOLLM exploits the advantages of LLMs in dynamic environment perception, reasoning, and decision making. By incorporating a multi-objective optimization strategy, it enables intelligent scheduling of heterogeneous nodes in SAGIN-CPN and achieves efficient joint optimization of task latency and energy consumption. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in enhancing Quality of Experience (QoE). This work presents a generalizable and intelligent solution for large-scale task management in future 6G networks.

title: Efficient Intrusion Detection for Edge Network via Multi-Stage Few-Shot Class-Incremental Learning
authors: Zhen Yin, Wei Wang, Yanyu Cheng, Yiliang Liu, Xiaozhen Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: The emerging increasingly sophisticated, intelligent, and stealthy network attacks pose more severe security threats to the edge network. In particular, the emergence of novel intelligent attacks makes it a challenging issue to obtain sufficient attack samples, and thus classical deep learning-driven intrusion detection frameworks (IDSs) become ineffective. To tackle this issue, we introduce a novel intrusion detection framework lever aging few-shot class-incremental learning (FSCIL) capabilities to achieve robust detection of emerging threats with few samples. This approach pre-trains a backbone traffic classification model and employs few-shot training with prototypical networks. To further reduce catastrophic forgetting while improving both accuracy and system robustness, we incrementally fine-tune the classification model with supervised contrastive learning, and also realize rapid adaptation to new attacks. Evaluations on the intrusion detection datasets CIC-IDS2017 and USTC-TF2016 demonstrate that our framework consistently outperforms base line models for emerging attacks detection with few attack samples while preserving effective recognition of known threats

title: The origin of gate degradation under HTRB operation: Buffer engineering to suppress impact ionization in GaN HEMT
authors: Mahmut Can Soydan, Amir Ali Joya, Amir Ghobadi, Ekmel Ozbay
abstract: This study investigates the origin of gate degradation in AlGaN/GaN HEMTs under high-temperature reverse bias (HTRB) conditions and proposes a buffer engineering strategy to mitigate this degradation. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis reveals the presence of a thin oxide layer between the gate and AlGaN contact. It is found that the holes generated through impact ionization (under high electric fields of HTRB operation), are directed toward the gate due to the intense local electric field under the gate and the field plate overhang, and are accumulated under this energetic barrier. Consequently, these trapped holes cause gate degradation and increased gate leakage. To address this issue, impact ionization, as the initial forcing mechanism of the degradation, is suppressed via thinning the channel GaN (C-GaN) layer. This improvement is attributed to the suppression of the local electric field near the gate region in thin C-GaN HEMTs. Additionally, the impact of C-GaN thinning on breakdown characteristics and RF performance is discussed. Overall, the findings provide insights into the root cause of gate degradation and offer a buffer engineering strategy to minimize gate degradation under deep off-state stress. This approach enhances the reliability of future high-power and high-frequency GaN HEMTs, contributing to their long-term performance in demanding applications.

title: Miniatured In-Ear Sensor for Motion Artifact-Free Real-Time Vital Sign Monitoring_supp1-3641229.docx
authors: Jeonghyun Kim
abstract: In this study, we developed a miniature wireless in-ear device for bio signal monitoring. The device is based on a flexible printed circuit board (FPCB), allowing it to be folded or deformed while maintaining stable bio signal measurements. Using a reflected photoplethysmogram (PPG) sensor, the device measures oxygen saturation (SpO₂) and heart rate (HR) and transmits the data wirelessly via Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE). Compression and tensile tests on various silicone showed the high durability and low deformation rate of Ecoflex (1:1), which was used for packaging the in-ear device. This ensures reliable data acquisition and high resistance to motion artifacts, even in daily environments. This research presents a reliable and commercially feasible solution for real-time bio signal monitoring that has its potential to advance wearable healthcare.

title: Collision Risk Minimized Multi-Vehicles Cooperative Path Planning in Open-Pit Mine Unloading Areas
authors: Yunchao Chen, Desheng Zhu, Xiaotian Ke, Kehu Yang, Jianjian Yang, Shirong Ge
abstract: Multi-vehicle collaborative trajectory planning for autonomous vehicles has attracted significant attention, yet research aimed at reducing spatial collision probability remains limited. In open-pit mine unloading areas, with their complex environment, flexible tasks, and inertia-induced motion delays in dump trucks, traditional multi-vehicle planning methods based on spatiotemporal trajectories produce planned results that impose strict timing and tracking requirements. This increases the difficulty of controller execution and substantially preserves the risk of vehicle collisions. To address these challenges and fully exploit the open space of unloading areas, this paper innovatively proposes a spatial avoidance-based cooperative multi-vehicle path planning method to minimize collision risks in unstructured environments such as unloading areas. An improved hybrid A* algorithm is proposed, incorporating dynamic routing potential fields (DRP-Hybrid A*) to iteratively generate coarse solutions for the dispersion of multi-vehicle paths. Furthermore, a collision risk minimization multi-vehicle path optimization (CRM-MVPO) algorithm is proposed, which optimizes the path through smoothness and safety distance, minimizing discontinuities and collision risks. Simulation experiments are conducted under two categories, comprising three typical scenarios to validate the approach’s effectiveness: single-entry-single-exit and multiple-entry-multiple-exit multi-dump-point configurations. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively reduces the probability of path overlap and collision risks, enhancing the safety and flexibility of multi-vehicle cooperative operations, and providing a reliable and efficient solution for autonomous driving in complex mining areas.

title: Subsurface Rough Fractures Detection by Borehole Radar: Numerical Simulation and Analysis
authors: Mingqi Hu, Jianfu Ni, Sixin Liu, Sen Tian, Qi Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Borehole radar, due to its high resolution and extensive radial detection capability, has become an important geophysical tool for detecting complex subsurface fractures. The key to evaluating fracture detectability lies in accurate fracture modeling and numerical simulation. To overcome the limitations of conventional fracture modeling approaches, including geometric oversimplification, inadequate representation of aperture and fracture surface correlation, and incomplete characterization of roughness, we propose a multi-factor three-dimensional (3D) rough fracture modeling method. This method integrates two-dimensional (2D) image reconstruction with the Weierstrass-Mandelbrot (W-M) fractal function, which enables a comprehensive description of fracture geometry, surface roughness, aperture, and correlation between the surfaces of a fracture. Based on the developed models, full-wave electromagnetic simulations of borehole radar are conducted using the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method, and the effects of fracture attitudes on radar responses are systematically investigated. The simulation results indicate that variations in dip angle and dip direction significantly influence the characteristics of the borehole radar signals. Fracture surface roughness is also found to introduce perturbations in echo details. Furthermore, the radar migration imaging results are more conducive to the evaluation of fracture attitude, as systematic simulation analysis demonstrates a high morphological consistency between the radar migration imaging results and the geometric projection of the fracture onto the Borehole-Fracture Coupling Plane (BFCP). This is further confirmed by the centroid offset distance and the Intersection over Union (IoU). In addition, the “dip direction ambiguity” in omnidirectional borehole radar detection is revealed, where fractures symmetric about the BFCP generate highly similar radar responses, thereby increasing the difficulty of interpretation. The presented fracture modeling method and observed response patterns from fractures support the accurate detection of complex fractures using borehole radar.

title: Dual-Inverter Driven Inductive Power Transfer System With Variable Reactance Network for Enhanced Misalignment Tolerance
authors: Adarsh Dubey, Apurv Kumar Yadav
abstract: This article introduces a dual-inverter driven inductive wireless power transfer system designed to accommodate higher coil misalignment in contactless charging applications. The proposed concept integrates two inverters in a parallel configuration with a variable reactance network (VRN) branch, which combines power from both inverters into a single output and feeds the conventional LCC-series compensated inductive power transfer (IPT) system. The VRN consists of series LC tank, designed to provide inductive (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{+jX}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) and capacitive (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{-jX}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) reactance with an inherent filtering capabilities. This VRN branch is interconnected through the inverter legs and symmetrically distributed between the forward and return paths. This symmetrical configuration ensures equal power sharing between the two inverters, significantly reducing circulating current within the system. The proposed article adopts a simple PI-based control mechanism that adjusts the phase shift between the two inverters to regulate the reactance seen at their output. This reactance control enables to achieve variable compensation to coupler misalignment. This article also includes the theoretical analysis to formulate the desired phase shift angle <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\delta}_{\boldsymbol{x}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> at which full compensation for the coupler misalignment is attained. To validate the proposed concept, hardware prototype of 1 kW, 400 V, LCC-S compensated IPT system has been developed. The proposed prototype achieves a peak efficiency of 95.78% at full alignment and can accommodate 50% coupler misalignment with an efficiency of 84.87%.

title: Bayesian-based correction of SAR electronic pointing error for ocean surface radial current velocity retrieval in the open ocean
authors: Yanping Qin, Xiaobin Yin, Yan Li, Qing Xu, Xingwei Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Single-beam synthetic aperture radar (SAR) Doppler frequency observations have been widely used for retrieving ocean surface radial current velocities. However, the Doppler frequency contains multiple components, among which the systematic shift caused by electronic pointing error (EPE) is difficult to accurately model and remove. This issue is particularly prominent in open-ocean regions without land echo references, where it can significantly affect the accuracy of current retrieval. To address this problem, this study proposes a Bayesian framework–based method for radial current velocity retrieval, which innovatively incorporates the systematic Doppler shift b caused by EPE as a key parameter into the state vector, enabling its joint estimation with the ocean surface radial current velocity. Empirical analysis of 1,800 SAR sub-swath images demonstrates high consistency between the estimated Doppler shift b and land-derived true values, with a standard deviation (STD) of 6.45 Hz and a correlation coefficient (R) exceeding 93%. This validates the method’s capability for accurate EPE estimation in remote ocean regions. Performance comparisons against HF radar observations and drifting buoy measurements confirm that the proposed Bayesian retrieval method significantly outperforms conventional direct approaches: it reduces radial current velocity STD by 0.23 m/s and improves R by 35.60%. Additionally, it effectively corrects systematic biases in the ocean model background field, lowering the STD of the retrieved radial velocity relative to the model by 13.33%. Even in complicated dynamic contexts, the approach retains great accuracy and physical consistency, as demonstrated by case studies in unique regions. In conclusion, the suggested Bayesian retrieval method significantly improves the precision, resilience, and usefulness of radial current velocity retrieval while successfully resolving the technical difficulty of EPE correction in SAR data over open oceans.

title: An Incipient Fault Diagnosis Scheme via Multi-stable Stochastic Resonance and Improved VMD
authors: Qingbo Wu, Qingwei Gao, Yixiang Lu, De Zhu, Dawei Zhao
abstract: In fields of fault diagnosis, incipient fault features concealed in the vibration signal gathered from the electro-mechanical equipment are difficult to extract under noise interference. Fault features enhancement and adaptive signal decomposition are effective ways to realize the identification of incipient fault. However, the traditional classical bistable stochastic resonance (CBSR) method has the drawbacks of output saturation and limited resonant efficiency. The variational mode decomposition (VMD) algorithm also has the issue of optimal selection of parameters. In this paper, a novel scheme based on multi-stable stochastic resonance (MSSR) and improved VMD (IVMD) is proposed for the diagnosis of incipient fault. Firstly, the stochastic resonance model is upgraded to a second-order equation to improve the filtering efficiency. Potential function applies a multi-stable structure to promote the motion of Brownian particles between wells. Then, a new comprehensive index called Synthetic Kurtosis is designed to achieve parameters optimization of the VMD algorithm. Finally, characteristic frequencies of the incipient fault can be identified sufficiently by envelope analysis of the decomposed components. Both results of simulated and actual signal experiments indicate that the proposed MSSR-IVMD scheme has superior signal enhancement capability and fault diagnosis effectiveness.

title: Multiple-Constrained Adaptive Relative Pose Human-Machine Shared Control for Manned Spacecraft Cooperative Closed-Range Rendezvous and Docking Missions
authors: Ke Tang, Liang Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This study focuses on the problem of human-in-the-loop relative pose control for manned spacecraft rendezvous and docking missions under output constraints and actuator saturation. The time-varying constraints for relative pose outputs are formulated by some linear inequalities such that the safe docking corridor of spacecraft relative position could be described easily, while the logarithm coordinate transformation is employed to ensure the bounded property of system outputs in the defined regions, then the state space of systems could be explicitly divided into the safe, dangerous and hysteresis subsets under the corresponding triggered constraints in human-in-the-loop control systems. In spite of kinematical couplings between the translational and rotational motions, the relative position and relative attitude controllers are still designed separately so that the number of triggered constraints is decreased to facilitate the machine controller design. Specifically, the anti-windup compensator-based adaptive nonlinear control method is proposed to design the sate-feedback-based machine controllers to tackle the actuator saturation and modeling uncertainties. The human control inputs are arbitrary without mathematical design, and human-machine control authority is transferred based on a smoothly output-constraints-related sharing function. Ultimately uniformly bounded convergence of system states is analyzed based on the Lyapunov stability theory, and simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed control approach.
