title: Effects of Subject's Motion Status, Finger's Measurement Site, and Variation in Light Wavelength on the Dynamics of Photoplethysmogram
authors: Nina Sviridova, Miriya Namba
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Photoplethysmography is a widely used noninvasive technique for cardiovascular assessment. Recent advancements in wearable technology have enabled continuous photoplethysmogram (PPG) monitoring, yet measurement accuracy remains highly dependent on various conditions, including the measurement site, light wavelength, and physical activity state. While previous studies have investigated these factors independently and mostly through linear analysis, a comprehensive analysis integrating nonlinear dynamics properties investigation to assess their effects has been lacking. This study employs nonlinear analysis to systematically evaluate PPG signal characteristics under different measurement conditions, including two measurement locations at the finger, green, red, and near-infrared wavelengths, and three motion status levels. Specifically, phase space reconstruction and the largest Lyapunov exponent, recurrence plot, and recurrence quantification analysis were applied to analyze signal dynamics. Clustering analysis was further conducted to classify signals based on motion conditions. The results indicate that the distal phalanx is the most suitable measurement site for PPG data, and green light provides the most stable signal for distinguishing between different motion states. These findings contribute to optimizing PPG measurement protocols for improved accuracy and reliability in wearable health monitoring applications.

title: Ontology-Guided Hybrid Loss for Fault Classification in Oil & Gas
authors: Gustavo Alexsandro De Lima, Joel Luís Carbonera, João Cesar Netto, Mara Abel
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Accurate classification of rare and undesirable events is crucial to maximizing the safety and efficiency of the oil and gas industry. While deep learning techniques have shown promising results in this domain, they often struggle when training data is scarce, a common issue with rare events. Domain ontologies can formally represent domain knowledge about these events. In this work, we hypothesize that it is possible to use domain knowledge represented in ontologies to improve the performance of neural networks when data is limited. Based on that, we propose a novel method by integrating domain knowledge from an ontology with deep learning through a hybrid loss function. Our hybrid loss function combines crossentropy with cosine distance between the ontological embeddings of the predicted and true classes to enforce semantic accuracy. Experiments conducted on the 3W Dataset, which includes nine rare anomalous events, demonstrate that our approach can improve classification accuracy compared to standard methods on smaller datasets.

title: A Robust Metric for Evaluating the Quality of Synthetic Tabular Data
authors: Mihaela Lechner, Oliver Rose
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Access to high-quality data remains a critical bottleneck in the development of artificial intelligence. One promising solution is the use of synthetic tabular data to augment existing datasets. However, generating and evaluating such data is challenging, given the existence of mixed data types, complex distributions, and intricate feature interdependencies. This paper introduces the Tabular Synthetic Data Score (TSDS), a robust, bounded, and interpretable framework for evaluating synthetic tabular data across three core components: fidelity (distributional similarity), association (preservation of feature relationships), and authenticity (novelty of synthetic samples). TSDS is datatype agnostic, using tailored methods for both categorical and continuous variables. Alongside a comprehensive overall score, it also enables component-wise analysis, providing detailed insights into the specific strengths and weaknesses of synthetic datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that TSDS effectively identifies common quality issues in state-of-the-art generative models, such as mode collapse, noise contamination, and memorization, while offering more discriminative and reliable diagnostics than existing evaluation frameworks. Moreover, the metric proves to be a practical tool for assessing the quality of synthetic data produced by commonly used generative models in applied settings.

title: Dual-Spectrum All-Sky camera Cloud Classifier by means of Computer Vision Models
authors: Paolo Pertino, Simone Lomolino, Leonardo Pavarino, Enrico Miotto, Daniele Rege Cambrin, Paolo Garza, Elena Collino, Maciej Sakwa, Emanuele Ogliari
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper deals with the problem of automatically classifying clouds, comparing the performance of different neural networks using infrared-only images, visible-only images, and visible plus infrared images through constructing a labeled dataset from ground-based all-sky camera images. This work is particularly valuable for researchers in renewable energy forecasting, atmospheric science, and computer vision, as well as for applications in grid management and climate monitoring. In the context of photovoltaics, accurate cloud type classification supports nowcasting in microgrids, enabling more reliable shortterm predictions of solar power generation from photovoltaic plants. The images are pre-processed to remove the geometrical distortion introduced by the fisheye lenses of the cameras and then fed to an EfficientNet-based model; two possible ways of combining the two types of images are explored, combining the feature vectors at two different steps. The performances of the three approaches are then compared. The results show that the models trained on visible plus infrared images, on average, are performing better than those trained on the infrared-only and visible-only ones.

title: Evaluation of Induced Voltages and Currents in 400kV Double Circuit Tunnel Power Cables
authors: Inzamam Ul Haq, David Clark, Manu Haddad, Maurizio Albano, Stephen Robson, Anderson Ricardo Justo de Araujo, Barry Nuttall, Dongsheng Guo, Kerri Hayes
abstract: Routine maintenance activities in multi-circuit cable tunnels often involve work on individual de-energized circuits, while adjacent circuits remain live. Electromagnetic coupling with live circuits results in induced voltages and currents on the de-energized cables. These may present a significant safety hazard to maintenance personnel if not properly identified and mitigated. In this paper we model a double circuit cable tunnel using ATP-EMTP to compute the induced voltages and currents in a de-energised circuit due to steady state operation of the adjacent live circuit. The cable length is 18 km, jointed at approximately 1km intervals. The simulations are performed considering the different load and fault conditions, including nominal load, 10% imbalance load, 3-phase faults, single-phase faults and phase-phase faults. Two different earthing scenarios of the de-energised cable circuit are considered. Results show that induced voltages and currents in the de-energized circuit depend greatly on the earthing configuration of cable sheaths and conductors. The designed model of the tunnel cable system and the study can be used as a reference document to identify the safe working methods for maintenance on tunnel power cables.

title: Integration of renewable energies in community buildings: a solution to the energy needs of "El Mirador"
authors: Yaqueline Garzón-Rodríguez, Clara Inés Buriticá-Arboleda, Elisa Peñalvo-Lopez, Iván Valencia-Salazar, Luis Antonio Noguera-Vega
abstract: The decarbonization of buildings is an important strategy for the fight against climate change. In this paper the analysis and design of a photovoltaic system applied to a community building in Ciudad Bolívar in Bogotá, Colombia, is presented. The building provides different social services to the inhabitants of the "El Mirador" neighborhood. In the design stage, in addition to the energy, economic, environmental, and regulatory variables, relevance is given to the social benefits provided by the photovoltaic system. The evaluation of the different options is carried out with an Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), in which the criteria of investment and social welfare are fundamental. As a final result, the modular installation of a photovoltaic system with storage, isolated from the grid, is proposed.

title: Virtual Drive with a BLDC Motor
authors: Igor Bélai, Igor Belai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: The control of brushless DC (BLDC) motors is one of the topics taught at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology at the Slovak Technical University in Bratislava. To verify the properties of BLDC motors, identify their parameters, and implement a current control loop, simulation models were created in MATLAB using Simscape Electrical. These models represent virtual BLDC motor drives and allow users to carry out virtual experiments in an intuitive and user-friendly environment. The procedure reflects the sequence of operations performed on an equivalent real-world system.

title: The Influence of Environmental Parameters on Optical Signal Attenuation in Underwater Wireless Communication Systems
authors: Himaja Madamanchi, M. Baskaran
abstract: Underwater Wireless Optical Communication (UWOC) systems are increasingly recognized for their potential to provide high-bandwidth data transfer in marine environments. However, the efficiency and reliability of these systems are significantly influenced by the attenuation of optical signals as they propagate through seawater. Experiment presents a comparative analysis for underwater optical signals, examining a line-of-sight (LoS) scenario across different sea waters using advanced numerical simulations. The focus is on understanding how environmental factors, such as salinity, temperature, turbidity, and biological content, affect the attenuation of optical signals at varying wavelengths in coastal, open ocean, and estuarine waters. Experiment is conducted to model light propagation in both clear and turbid waters, assessing the impact of scattering and absorption mechanisms in LoS conditions. Fulvic acid, like other dissolved organic materials, plays a significant role in the attenuation of light in water, particularly in the ultraviolet (UV) and blue light regions of the spectrum. The attenuation of light due to fulvic acid and other Dissolved Organic Matter is driven by both absorption and scattering mechanisms. The process is carried out by keeping optical Wireless channel length at 100 meters and keeping Differential Phase Shift Keying (DPSK) modulation on the transmitter side for better efficiency and bit error rate. Results reveal significant differences in attenuation behavior, with line-of-sight conditions showing greater sensitivity to scattering from suspended particles and dissolved organic matter, while line-of-sight transmission is more influenced by absorption due to water composition. Results show bit error rate for pure sea water is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.17 \times 10^{-4}$</tex>, clear ocean water <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.76 \times 10^{-4}$</tex>, coastal water <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.84 \times 10^{-4}$</tex>, turbid harbor water-I <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.95 \times 10^{-4}$</tex>, turbid harbor water-II <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.73 \times 10^{-4}$</tex>. The bit error rate in pure sea water is lower compared to all other water types. This System provides valuable insights into the challenges and potential of UWOC in real-world underwater environments, highlighting the importance of considering LoS conditions for optimizing system design and performance in varying marine settings. These findings have critical implications for the development of robust and efficient UWOC systems for underwater communication, navigation, and remote sensing.

title: Improving 5G/B5G Network Performance with RFID-Enabled Resource Management Systems
authors: Stella N. Arinze, Halima I. Kure, Augustine O. Nwajana
abstract: In the rapidly evolving landscape of 5G and B5G (beyond 5G) networks, efficient resource optimization is critical to addressing the escalating demands for high-speed, low-latency, and energy-efficient communication. This study explores the integration of Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology as a novel approach to enhance resource management in 5G/B5G networks. The motivation behind this research lies in overcoming persistent challenges such as spectrum congestion, high latency, and inefficient load balancing, which impede the performance of traditional resource allocation methods. To achieve this, RFID tags were embedded in critical network components, including user devices, base stations, and Internet of Things (IoT) nodes, enabling the collection of real-time data on device status, location, and resource utilization. RFID readers strategically placed across the network continuously captured this data, which was processed by a centralized controller using a custom-designed optimization algorithm. This algorithm dynamically managed key network resources, including spectrum allocation, load balancing, and energy consumption, ensuring efficient operation under varying network conditions. Simulations were conducted to evaluate the performance of the RFID-based model against traditional 4G dynamic resource allocation techniques. The results demonstrated substantial improvements in key performance metrics. The proposed system achieved a 25 % increase in spectrum utilization, a 30 % reduction in average latency, a 15 % boost in network throughput, and a 20 % decrease in overall energy consumption. These gains highlight the effectiveness of the RFID-based optimization model in meeting the stringent performance requirements of 5 G networks, particularly in high-density deployments. This study provides a scalable, cost-effective solution for optimizing resource management in 5G/B5G and lays the groundwork for future advancements in 6G networks. By leveraging real-time data and intelligent resource allocation, the proposed model addresses critical challenges in modern communication systems, ensuring enhanced network efficiency, reliability, and sustainability.

title: BERT-GRU: A Deep Learning Framework for High-Accuracy Antimicrobial Peptide Recognition
authors: Songbin Zheng, Yi Shi, Guishan Zhang, Chuliang Wei
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: The emergence of antimicrobial resistance necessitates alternatives to conventional antibiotics. Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs), exhibiting broad-spectrum activity against pathogens through membrane disruption mechanisms, have emerged as prime candidates. However, experimental AMP screening faces prohibitive costs and low throughput, while existing computational tools show limited accuracy in distinguishing AMPs from non-AMP sequences. This study proposes a BERT-GRU framework that integrates the BERT pretrained model with a multi-scale convolutional and bidirectional gated recurrent network for antimicrobial peptide (AMP) identification. Experimental results demonstrate that BERT-GRU significantly outperforms existing models in AMP recognition, achieving leading performance across evaluation metrics including accuracy, F1-score, Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), and Area Under the Curve (AUC). We propose that the BERT-GRU framework can serve as a valuable tool for more efficient AMP identification.

title: A Comparative Study of Different Magnetic Gap Modeling Methods Based on PEEC
authors: Qiwen Yan, Xiaoping Li, Xu Wang, Qiusen He, Yin Sun, Jun Fan, Shufang Li, Qiang-Ming Cai
abstract: In the design of electromagnetic equipment such as transformers and sensors, magnetic air gap is a key factor affecting equipment efficiency, stability, thermal management, response speed, and electromagnetic compatibility. It has an important impact on magnetic flux distribution, energy loss, and overall equipment efficiency. In order to accurately analyze and optimize the impact of magnetic air gaps, it is usually necessary to establish an accurate magnetic air gap model. The partial element equivalent circuit (PEEC) method converts electromagnetic field problems into equivalent circuit models, avoiding discretization of the inactive domain (e.g., the air), especially suitable for scenarios with small air gap sizes. This article summarizes and compares three main methods for modeling magnetic air gaps. The first method discretizes the entire region and accurately captures the distribution of magnetic fields in complex geometric structures, which is a common practice in the finite element method (FEM). The second method uses the static magnetic volume integration method (VIM) for the thin air gap model [5]–[7], treating the air gap as a surface area with a given thickness, avoiding the integration difficulties of not gridding the air gap or gridding the air gap into a volume area. The third method, based on the unique boundary processing advantages of PEEC [8], converts the electromagnetic field of the air gap into an equivalent circuit form, simplifying the calculation process. Following a comprehensive comparison of the advantages, disadvantages, and applicability of the three methods, this article presents recommendations for selecting the most appropriate method for different application scenarios. These recommendations provide valuable theoretical and practical guidance for the engineering solution of magnetic air gap modeling problems.

title: MedESM: Improving Clinical Note Readability with a Lightweight Structured Summarization Language Model
authors: Eduardo Dias, André Pilastri, Artur Ferreira, Bruno Lemos, Paulo Cortez
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: The digitization of clinical data via electronic health records (EHRs) shows great promise for data-based decisionmaking, particularly through the analysis of unstructured clinical notes. While large language models (LLMs) offer tools for interpreting these narratives, their vast size and general-purpose design can pose difficulties in real-world healthcare settings. More specialized LLMs, tailored to healthcare contexts, are an alternative solution, although their integration into resourceconstrained environments is often problematic due to their dimensions. In this work, we present MedESM, a lightweight 1B parameter medical LLM specifically fine-tuned for structured summarization of clinical notes across twelve clinically relevant categories. Within our knowledge, MedESM is the only model at the 1B parameter scale capable of performing this task. Trained on over 40,000 real and synthetic clinical notes from the MIMIC-IV-NOTE and Asclepius datasets, MedESM leverages targeted instruction-based summarization and careful prompt design to ensure stable performance on long and complex inputs. Results show that MedESM achieves competitive quality with significantly reduced computational demands, offering a practical solution for structured documentation support in clinical settings.

title: Advancing TDR Technique for Oil Leakage Detection
authors: Hao-Ruei Jhan, Farizal Hakiki, Chih-Ping Lin
abstract: Oil leakage from underground storage tanks and pipelines poses serious risks to both the environment and the economy. This research proposes a time domain reflectometry (TDR)based system for the detection of oil leaks in underground infrastructures. The system has been implemented in two distinct scenarios: embedded within newly installed facilities and remotely monitored through a well for existing structures. Tailored sensing configurations and novel probes have been developed in-house and successfully validated through field tests in Taiwan, supported by comprehensive analysis.

title: SCALAR: Self-Calibrating Adaptive Latent Attention Representation Learning
authors: Farwa Abbas, Hussain Ahmad, Claudia Szabo
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: High-dimensional, heterogeneous data with complex feature interactions pose significant challenges for traditional predictive modeling approaches. While Projection to Latent Structures (PLS) remains a popular technique, it struggles to model complex non-linear relationships, especially in multivariate systems with high-dimensional correlation structures. This challenge is further compounded by simultaneous interactions across multiple scales, where local processing fails to capture crossgroup dependencies. Additionally, static feature weighting limits adaptability to contextual variations, as it ignores sample-specific relevance. To address these limitations, we propose a novel method that enhances predictive performance through novel architectural innovations. Our architecture introduces an adaptive kernel-based attention mechanism that processes distinct feature groups separately before integration, enabling capture of local patterns while preserving global relationships. Experimental results show substantial improvements in performance metrics, compared to the state-of-the-art methods across diverse datasets.

title: GLAD-CSC: Global-Local Attention with Dynamic Confusion Management for Chinese Spelling Correction
authors: Shuo Wang, Nannan Sun, Lei Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Chinese spelling correction (CSC) faces unique challenges from phonetic and visual character confusions. Existing methods suffer from three critical limitations: (1) static confusion sets failing to capture evolving error patterns, (2) inadequate multi-scale contextual modeling, and (3) insufficient exploitation of Chinese phonetic features. We propose GLAD-CSC, a novel framework integrating Global-Local Attention with Dynamic confusion management. Our key innovations include: First, a global-local hybrid attention mechanism that adaptively balances semantic understanding with local context modeling through error-probability-driven window adjustment. Second, a multi-modal fusion strategy integrating textual, phonetic (Pinyin), and confusion features via dynamic weighting, with enhanced phonetic representation (40 % allocation) for handling phonetic errors. Third, a dynamic confusion management system that automatically discovers and validates character confusion patterns during training. Extensive experiments on SIGHAN benchmarks demonstrate state-of-the-art performance: 91.9% character-level correction F1-score on SIGHAN 2015 (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+3.8 \%$</tex> improvement) and 90.6 % sentence-level detection F1-score (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+8.5 \%$</tex> improvement). Our framework excels at phonetic confusion errors, achieving 96.8 % precision and 92.1% recall. Ablation studies confirm significant contributions: enhanced phonetic features (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+4.7 \%$</tex> F1), multi-scale attention (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+4.0 \%$</tex> F1), and dynamic confusion management (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+3.3 \% \text{F1}$</tex>).

title: Multivariable Optimization of Voltage Transformer Design Using Evolutionary Techniques
authors: Steve Juárez, Antonio Venegas, Rolando Demes, Mitzi Baños, Noe Colorado
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Resource optimization is a central objective in most branches of engineering. Reducing production costs and obtaining more efficient and smaller products that consume less material and are increasingly profitable. This work presents the development of a methodology that seeks the optimization of the elementary characteristics of the design of voltage transformers. Evolutionary algorithms are utilized within an integrated computational system, wherein the fitness function is employed in the theoretical model to ascertain ratio correction factor and angle errors. From the transformer equivalent circuit model and the BH magnetization curve, the ratio correction factor and phase angle errors are obtained. Subsequently, a genetic algorithm is developed in MATLAB, including elitism, diversity preservation and adaptive exploration, to optimize critical design variables such as effective core area, winding configuration, conductor gauges and number of turns. The objective function seeks to minimize the square of the ratio correction factor and angular displacement under no-load conditions. An error parallelogram visualization has been implemented to tack his evolution. The results show that the algorithm can identify optimized configurations that significantly reduce measurement errors, while ensuring manufacturability and adherence to standard design practices.

title: Secure Communications and Computations based on Quantum Technologies
authors: Armando Nolasco Pinto
abstract: This work investigates recent advances in implementing secure communication and computing services using quantum technologies, namely Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) systems. The approach is centered around the concept of oblivious keys, a fundamental cryptographic primitive where a transmitter knows a complete key while the receiver knows only half, with the transmitter being unaware of which half the receiver possesses [1]. We demonstrate that oblivious keys can be derived from the raw key material of standard discrete-variable (DV-QKD) and continuous-variable (CV-QKD) systems [2]–[5]. We also presented a hybrid framework that uses QKD with post-quantum cryptographic (PQC) algorithms, creating a dual-layer security model to bolster defenses against the threat of quantum computers. The practical applications of this framework are illustrated through its implementation in two critical domains: genomic medicine, where robust safeguards are essential for protecting sensitive genetic data, and the defense sector, which can profit from secure collaboration with minimal information disclosure.

title: Short-Term Prognostication of Energy Yield from Wind Power Plants
authors: Petya Tsvetkova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The report provides a brief summary of the most commonly used methods for short-term forecasting of electrical loads. A methodology is presented, using the method of autoregressive integrated moving averages, the model with artificial neural networks, and the hybrid combination of the two above-mentioned models for making a day-ahead prognosis of energy production from wind farms, connected to a common node of the electricity grid. Calculations have been made using the three proposed methods for the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 4}$</tex>-hour load schedule of a distribution network with three wind farms included in a common connection node. The obtained results are compared and useful conclusions are drawn about choosing a method for short-term forecasting of energy yield from wind farms.

title: Unraveling Co-Heritability of Antibiotic Resistance in Tuberculosis Evolution
authors: Natasha Prabhu, Nikhil Prabhu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Tuberculosis (TB), caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, remains a global health threat, especially due to the rise of antibiotic-resistant strains. Despite the existence of effective treatments, the emergence and spread of multidrugresistant (MDR) forms of TB significantly u ndermine global eradication efforts. This study analyzes the genetic co-heritability of Rifampicin and Isoniazid resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis using k-mer analysis and genomic similarity modeling. The goal of this study was to find <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$t$</tex> he <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m$</tex> ost <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p$</tex> redictive <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex> mers for multi-drug resistance in M. tuberculosis, and how coheritability plays into resistance. FASTQ, FASTA, and XML data was taken from the ENA and NCBI to ensure broad and diverse genomic representation. One of the key parts of this study was gathering multi-omic data. This includes genotypic data, SNP analyses, and antibiotic resistance profiles. T he heritability of resistance traits and their genetic correlation was estimated by creating a Genetic Relatedness Matrix and using machine learning. The model had an accuracy of 85.68% and was trained on 2,200 samples. Nonresistant strains were predicted correctly 87% of the time, and resistant strains were predicted correctly 82% of the time. These findings <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r$</tex> eveal the potential to predict drug resistance phenotypes from genomic data alone, offering an alternative to traditional culture-based diagnostics. The results indicate a high correlation between resistance to both drugs, which suggests common genetic factors. Fifteen highfrequency k -mers were identified w ithin t he r poB a nd katG genes, which are known to be associated with Rifampicin and Isoniazid resistance, respectively. Potential errors in sequencing and sample size limitations may impact these estimates. Despite these challenges, this research highlights the nature of antibiotic resistance, reinforcing the importance of genomic surveillance in handling multidrug-resistant TB. Understanding these genetic relationships can aid in early detection and predictive modeling, which would help in the creation of more effective treatment strategies.

title: A Framework for Hybrid Set-Theoretic and Numerical Problem Solving
authors: Daniel Crowley, Daniel Le Berre, Olivier Roussel, Yakoub Salhi
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: In formal methods, checking the validity of some proof obligations results in reasoning about sets, and particularly their interrelations and their cardinalities. Motivated by this interest, we investigate hybrid problems that combine constraints from both aspects. In this context, we consider two approaches: one purely qualitative and one explicitly representing membership. We propose SAT-based encodings for solving these problems. First we encode qualitative constraints on relations between sets and their cardinalities. Afterwards, we deal with richer constraints on set elements and with numerical constraints on both cardinalities and integer variables, assuming a fixed domain. In this setting, we identify a domain size bound for the version with explicit membership, beyond which increasing the domain cannot affect satisfiability. We evaluate the proposed encodings on real-world B language specifications. The proposed approaches allow the validation of proofs not yet decided by several existing approaches, and so could be used in addition to the others in order to automate the validation of even more proofs.

title: Strengthening Organizational Cybersecurity Using Gamification in the Employees’ Learning and Development
authors: Milan Kubina, Barbora Blahová, Martin Mičiak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: The article focuses on setting cybersecurity learning and development processes to increase employees’ awareness in this field and their ability to respond to cyber threats. The study uses primary and secondary data to identify employees’ needs and preferences and put them in the broader context of cybersecurity trends. Primary data were obtained via an electronic questionnaire among employees of a selected IT organization (n=96). They were analyzed using statistical methods and visualization. Secondary data came from scientific databases and relevant statistical portals. The results show that employees prefer practical and interactive forms of training, such as simulations, workshops, and penetration tests, while traditional methods, such as documents and conferences, are seen as less effective. Based on the findings, recommendations were formulated for an effective setting of organizational learning and development that combines practical experience with a motivating and entertaining approach. These recommendations provide a concrete framework, including a serious game for increasing cybersecurity knowledge in the organization. The goal is also to actively engage employees and strengthen cybersecurity awareness in the organization in the long term.

title: Attribute-Guided Zero-Shot Activity Recognition in Wearable Health Systems
authors: Naila Tabassum, Asad Masood Khattak, Ashraf Khali, Wajahat Ali Khan, Muhammad Zubair Asghar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper presents an attribute-guided zero-shot learning (ZSL) framework for wearable health monitoring that enables recognition of previously unseen activities without taskspecific supervision. The proposed model combines a multibranch CNN encoder and a semantic attribute predictor to project multimodal physiological signals into an interpretable attribute space. Using cosine similarity, unseen health activities are classified by matching predicted attributes with predefined prototypes. Evaluated on WESAD and PAMAP2 datasets, the framework achieves 92.1% accuracy on unseen classessurpassing supervised baselines-while maintaining low-latency inference suitable for embedded deployment. The results demonstrate strong generalization, semantic interpretability, and computational efficiency, highlighting the framework’s potential for scalable, real-time health monitoring. Limitations related to manual prototype definition and signal variability are discussed, with future directions including automatic attribute generation and continual adaptation.

title: Video Traffic Classification in the 5G Open RAN Network
authors: Tianhua Chen, Roberts Benkis, Nikolajs Bogdanovs, Mihails Stetjuha, Jānis Klūga, Viktors Jeralovičs, Dmitrijs Rjazanovs, Elans Grabs, Aleksandrs Ipatovs
abstract: 5G slicing technology enables the creation of multiple virtualized, isolated networks (slices) over a shared physical infrastructure, extending across the entire 5G network, from the RAN (Radio Access Network) to DU/CU (Distributed Unit/Centralized Unit). It supports three main slice types: Enhanced Mobile Broadband (eMBB), Ultra Reliable Low Latency Communications (URLLC), and Massive Machine Type Communications (mMTC). Each slice has specific resource allocations and Quality of Service (QoS) characteristics, such as resource type, priority level, packet delay budget, packet error rate, and Quality Class Identifier (QCI). Deploying custom network slices in Open RAN allows for dynamic RAN resource adjustment to meet the demands of different slices. This Open RAN architecture enables more flexibility and fine-grained control, which can be challenging for traditional ISPs to achieve. Multimedia applications on mobile devices consume significant network resources, often utilizing the eMBB slice in 5G, which is designed for high data rates and enhanced connectivity. eMBB supports scenarios like 4K/8K Ultra HD video streaming, Virtual Reality (VR), and Augmented Reality (AR). However, the similarity among these application traffic patterns makes fine-grained traffic monitoring and management challenging. To address this issue, this paper proposes using machine learning algorithms to analyze traffic characteristics and enable accurate, fine-grained classification of video network traffic.

title: Microwave Photonics-Based Reflectometry for PCB Defect Detection
authors: Yiling Guo, Menglin L. N. Chen, Wei Lin
abstract: In this study, a microwave photonic-based step frequency reflectometry (MPSR) system is proposed to perform PCB defect detection, which incorporates photonic techniques on wideband step frequency (SF) signal generation to reflectometry implementation. An optical recirculating frequency shift loop (OFSL) is utilized to expand the spectral bandwidth of the input signal transmitted to the device under test (DUT). Coherent mixing process of the DUT's response signal with the incident signal enables the accurate extraction of the DUT's frequency response. Subsequently, the location information of defects, which usually manifested as impedance discontinuity within the DUT, can be extracted from this frequency response under inverse Fourier transform. Simulations of electronic and photonic systems are used to analyze the performance of the proposed concept. The simulation results are in well agreement with the Advanced Design system (ADS) simulation, demonstrating the feasibility of the proposed system in determining PCB defects.

title: Guiding Evolutionary Molecular Design: Adding Reinforcement Learning for Mutation Selection
authors: Gaëlle Milon-Harnois, Chaïmaâ Touhami, Nicolas Gutowski, Benoit Da Mota, Thomas Cauchy
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: The efficient exploration of chemical space remains a central challenge, as many generative models still produce unstable or non-synthesizable compounds. To address these limitations, we present EvoMol-RL, a significant extension of the EvoMol evolutionary algorithm that integrates reinforcement learning to guide molecular mutations based on local structural context. By leveraging Extended Connectivity Fingerprints (ECFPs), EvoMol-RL learns context-aware mutation policies that prioritize chemically plausible transformations. This approach significantly improves the generation of valid and realistic molecules, reducing the frequency of structural artifacts and enhancing optimization performance. The results demonstrate that EvoMol-RL consistently outperforms its baseline in molecular pre-filtering realism. These results emphasize the effectiveness of combining reinforcement learning with molecular fingerprints to generate chemically relevant molecular structures.

title: Real-Time Detection of Malicious IP Addresses using Graph Neural Networks: A Cross-Protocol Machine Learning Approach
authors: Jude Osamor, Pius Owoh, Moses Ashawa, Chigozie Kingsley Ejeofobiri, Funminiyi Olajide
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Modern cybersecurity faces an escalating crisis where sophisticated threat actors exploit malicious IP addresses as pivotal attack infrastructure, with traditional reactive detection methods failing to identify threats until significant damage occurs. Current approaches suffer from protocol isolation, limited contextual understanding, and inherent time delays that enable successful cyberattacks. This paper presents a revolutionary multi-dimensional cybersecurity framework that integrates Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) with cross-protocol behavioral analysis to model complex relationships between network entities. Our approach combines semi-supervised graph-based learning with real-time feature extraction across HTTP, DNS, SMTP, and network flow protocols, enabling high-accuracy detection with minimal labeled data requirements. Experimental evaluation demonstrates unprecedented 98.2% detection accuracy with 96.8% F1-score while maintaining sub-$\mathbf{5 0 m s}$ response latency at $\mathbf{5 0, 0 0 0}$ assessments per second. Most significantly, we achieve proactive threat detection capability, identifying malicious IPs an average of 18.7 hours before conventional blocklist appearance. This early warning capability transforms cyber defense from reactive to anticipatory, providing critical response time for implementing protective measures and representing a paradigm shift toward intelligent, anticipatory cybersecurity.

title: Auction-Based Approach for Pickup and Delivery Problem with Time Windows
authors: Mohamed Nasr Ali, Flavien Lucas, Guillaume Lozenguez, Arnaud Doniec
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: The widespread use of digital technology enables the development of practical solutions to real-life problems. One such challenge is the Pickup and Delivery Problem with Time Windows (PDPTW), an extension of the Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP), in which vehicles transport goods from pickup locations to delivery locations within specific time windows. This research proposes a decentralized approach based on Agent Modeling and an auction-based mechanism to solve the PDPTW. In this model, each courier independently determines its own trajectory, and can keep it as a private information. The main objective is to minimize the number of vehicles used, while each vehicle seeks to reduce its travel distance and serve as many requests as possible. Finally, the results of this approach are compared with those presented in the existing literature, with empirical evidence of the impact of flexibility on fleet size and travel distance compared to centralized methods.

title: High-Performance CMOS OTA Design for Sub-6 GHz RF Applications: Optimizing Efficiency-Linear Trade-Offs in 65 NM Technology
authors: T. Haykir Ergin, Y. S. Saglam, İ. Sisman
abstract: This paper presents the design and optimization of a CMOS-based operational transconductance amplifier (OTA) for RF front-end applications, implemented using 65 nm CMOS technology. The proposed OTA is designed to operate efficiently within the sub- 6 GHz frequency range, specifically targeting the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.5-5 \text{GHz}$</tex> band. It addresses critical challenges such as low power consumption (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<5 ~\text{mW}$</tex>), high linearity, and wide bandwidth (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>15 \text{GHz}$</tex>). CMOS technology offers costeffective integration with digital and mixed-signal components, making it an attractive choice for modern wireless communication systems. However, at RF frequencies, achieving high transconductance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(>10 \text{mS})$</tex>, minimizing noise, and maintaining linearity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{IP}_{3}>+10 \text{dBm}$</tex>) become significant design constraints due to device parasitics and process limitations in scaled technologies. The proposed OTA employs a differential input stage and a folded-cascode architecture to enhance gain (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>50 ~\text{dB}$</tex>) and improve output impedance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geq 500 \mathrm{k} \Omega$</tex>) while minimizing power consumption. Transistor sizing and biasing strategies are carefully optimized to achieve a balance between noise performance (Noise Figure <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<3 ~\text{dB}$</tex>) and linearity. Additionally, current mirror loads are utilized to provide a high gain-bandwidth product, suitable for RF front-end applications such as mixers, filters, and low-noise amplifiers. The design achieves a transconductance-to-power ratio of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5 \text{mS} / \text{mW}$</tex>, meeting the stringent demands of low-power RF systems. Simulation results using industry-standard tools confirm the OTA's performance, demonstrating a gain exceeding 52 dB, a 3 dB bandwidth of 2 GHz, and an intermodulation distortion (IMD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{3}$</tex>) below -50 dBc. The proposed OTA also exhibits excellent phase margin (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>60^{\circ}$</tex>) and stability, ensuring robust operation across process, voltage, and temperature (PVT) variations. This work contributes to the development of compact, high-performance RF components and demonstrates the potential of CMOS OTAs as critical building blocks in next-generation communication systems.

title: GNS3aaS: Networking lab in OpenStack
authors: Martin Kontsek, Pavel Segec, Marek Moravcik, Jana Uramova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper explores the potential of GNS3 as a cloud-based solution for academic institutions. It describes how GNS3aaS has been implemented and its key features. Firstly, a brief explanation is provided on how users can create their own GNS3 server and what data they should provide. Secondly, a detailed description of how the instance is provisioned is provided. A step-by-step tour of the installation and configuration process. Next, the reader will find two more features that were tested/implemented because the faculty wanted to know if it was worth implementing. These 2 features are image sharing and authentication. The next part of the paper describes the new version of the GNS3 server, which has undergone an architectural change. Also introduced some useful features, such as user management, but on the other hand, due to backend changes, broke the image sharing process that was possible in older versions.

title: Harmonising Safety Paradigms: Energy-Aware Control of Active Response and Passive Compliance for Safety-Critical Robotic Tasks_supp1-3643285.mp4
authors: Xinyuan Zhao
abstract: Ensuring safety in robotic manipulation is increasingly critical as robots become integrated into human-shared environments for complex physical interaction tasks. This paper presents an energy-aware control framework that combines active responses with passive compliance for safety-critical robotic manipulation. Specifically, Control Barrier Functions (CBFs) are employed for active collision avoidance with detected obstacles, which are then integrated with fallback safety actions to resolve potential violation of CBF constraints. Complementing this active safety paradigm, a passive safety paradigm is implemented to mitigate post-collision impacts by monitoring energy variance and limiting power exchanges. Furthermore, an energy tank is incorporated to enforce passivity of the robot, which is crucial to address potential instability issues in variable impedance control. To make the tank adaptive to varying energy requirements arising from dynamic environments and unpredictable events, we propose a novel, task-agnostic tank recharging condition without compromising the system's passivity guarantee. The effectiveness of the proposed control framework is validated through experiments on a KUKA iiwa 14 robot.

title: Robust Design for RIS-Aided Integrated Wireless Sensing and Power Transfer System
authors: Fei Wang, Zheng Li, Zhengyu Zhu, Gangcan Sun, Bo Ai, Inkyu Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: By integrating the Internet of Things and sensing technologies, transportation systems can achieve higher management accuracy and efficiency. This paper explores a Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS) assisted integrated wireless sensing and power transfer (IWSPT) system in traffic scenarios with channel estimation errors and obstacles. Specifically, a transmitter deployed within transportation infrastructure optimizes the beamforming vector and RIS phase shifts cooperatively. The objective is to maximize the energy received by multiple energy harvesting devices (EHDs) under the constraint of beampattern thresholds for sensing in multiple directions. The coupled optimization variables in the proposed problem yield a non-convex result, so we propose a semi-infinite relaxation-based method for solving this optimization problem. We then introduce a low-complexity optimization algorithm to address the high computational complexity of the semi-infinite relaxation approach. The proposed algorithm significantly reduces the computational burden by leveraging Taylor expansion and successive convex approximation (SCA) techniques. Simulation results validate the effectiveness and robustness of the algorithm, highlighting its practical applicability in intelligent transportation systems.

title: Adaptive Fault-Tolerant Perimeter Control for Two-Region Networks With Actuator Faults
authors: Xinfeng Ru, Ting Bai, Weiguo Xia, Karl Henrik Johansson
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Recent research has shown that the Macroscopic Fundamental Diagram (MFD) is an effective way to manage traffic flow and mitigate congestion, which regulates bidirectional transfer flows at regional boundaries via perimeter control. In practice, perimeter control may fail to achieve desired control targets due to adverse conditions such as inclement weather or accidents, which may result in loss of actuator effectiveness faults. To address this challenge, this paper proposes two adaptive fault-tolerant perimeter control schemes to handle both time-invariant and time-varying actuator faults. To cope with time-invariant actuator faults, a data-driven fault-tolerant perimeter control approach is presented, which employs adaptive dynamic programming to approximate the solution of the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation. For dealing with time-varying faults, an adaptive fault-tolerant perimeter controller is designed by linearizing the MFD function and ensuring tracking of a given reference model. Theoretical analysis proves that the tracking error converges to zero asymptotically. Finally, simulation studies validate the effectiveness of the proposed schemes in improving traffic management under actuator fault conditions.

title: Interdisciplinary Dialogues on Surgical Data Science: Revising its Benefits for Surgical Stakeholders and Patients
authors: Marco Bombieri, Arnaud Huaulmé, Kevin Cleary, Stamatia Giannarou, Gernot Kronreif, Franziska Mathis-Ullrich, Evangelos Mazomenos, Krystel Nyangoh-Timoh, Micha Pfeiffer, Marco A. Zenati, Paolo Fiorini, Pierre Jannin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: Recent advancements in data science and robotic surgery have introduced significant opportunities and challenges in the field of healthcare. To assess their implications, a multidisciplinary panel of experts in medicine and computer science convened to evaluate the potential benefits, risks, and ethical considerations associated with these technologies. The discussion addressed critical topics, including the role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in enhancing surgical decision-making, the integration of robotics to improve procedural precision, and the broader socioeconomic and psychological impacts on patients and their families. Particular attention was given to the perspectives of key surgical stakeholders, including healthcare professionals and institutions, as well as the implications for equity and accessibility in surgical care. This paper presents a synthesis of the key outcomes from the deliberations. By identifying research gaps and proposing strategic directions, the findings aim to serve as a foundational resource for future investigations and innovations in data-driven and robotic-assisted surgery.

title: CoDeepCL-Based Oscillation-Adaptive and Label-Free Instability Detection Approach for DC Power Electronic Systems
authors: Xueqi Liu, Xin Zhang, Xiaoqi Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: The increasing integration of converters brings instability challenges to DC power electronic systems (PESs). Instability detection based on data-driven analysis provides a promising noninvasive solution for “black-box” DC PESs, enabling reliable indirectly from DC bus voltage signals without requiring internal system information. However, data-driven instability detection approaches still face two major challenges: limited adaptability to oscillation frequency variations and the scarcity of labeled instability data. To solve these challenges, a contrastive learning with deep embedded clustering framework (CoDeepCL)-based instability detection approach is proposed for DC PESs by this paper. Specifically, CoDeepCL employs temporal-noise augmented contrastive learning with a convolutional neural network with long short-term memory (CNN-LSTM) to capture oscillations’ common characteristic and learn discriminative difference between oscillation and non-oscillation features, enabling oscillation-adaptive function. In addition, intrinsic unstable-voltage feature guided contrastive learning with deep embedded clustering is integrated to achieve more accurate label-free instability detection. As a result, the proposed CoDeepCL can detect instability reliably even under varying oscillation conditions without requiring any labeled data. Experiments verified the proposed approach achieves accurately instability detection across diverse working conditions in DC PES.

title: Decision-Making-Based Multiobjective Direct Speed Predictive Control Without Weighting Factors
authors: Emrah Zerdali, Sid Ahmed El Mehdi Ardjoun, Marco Rivera, Jacopo Riccio, Patrick Wheeler
abstract: A novel decision-making (DM) based direct speed predictive control (DSPC) strategy for an induction machine (IM) is presented in this article, eliminating the requirement for weighting factors (WFs). The proposed technique applies the Euclidean norm-based DM approach to DSPC, tackling the challenges observed in conventional WF-based model predictive control strategies. In addition, an extended Kalman filter (EKF) is considered to estimate the rotor flux and load torque, improving the robustness of the system and decreasing complexity by avoiding multiple estimators. The DM-based DSPC technique is validated by simulation and experimental results under different operating conditions. This article also demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed technique by establishing a comparison with a conventional DSPC technique that uses WFs and the same EKF observer. Our results confirm that the DM-based DSPC scheme improves the control performance and robustness of the system, being a promising alternative for high-performance drive applications.

title: A Soft Switched Multimode Domestic Charger for Plug-in and Wireless EVs
authors: Ashutosh Rai, Abhishek Singhal, Narsa Reddy Tummuru, Venkata Ratnam Vakacharla
abstract: Both conductive and wireless charging have advantages over one another in several aspects; therefore, a unified system is essential to provide a flexible and adaptable charging infrastructure for diverse EV types. This article proposes a modified multimode offboard charging system that supports charging for micromobility vehicles (E-scooters and E-rickshaws) and wireless passenger EVs by reusing existing offboard converter hardware originally developed for wireless charging at the domestic level. The architecture utilizes a shared offboard front-end converter and high frequency inverter as a common power interface for both charging channels, enabling compact design and high-power density. The architecture supports multiple modes such as grid to vehicle (G2V), vehicle to grid (V2G), vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V), and simultaneous dual channel charging, enhancing the overall operational versatility. To mitigate electromagnetic interference (EMI) and enhance efficiency, soft switching of the converters is essential. Therefore, zero voltage switching (ZVS) conditions are formulated for all modes of operation, from full load to light load. Finally, a laboratory prototype for proposed system capable of 2.8 kW wireless and 0.8 kW conductive charging has been developed. Experimental results validate various operating modes, ensuring ZVS for all switches in every mode. Both channels achieve a maximum dc–dc efficiency of 94% at their respective full load conditions.

title: Adaptive Scale Fusion via Uncertainty Estimation for Visual Grounding in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Zhipeng Zhang, Yang Zou, Ji Wang, Peng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Visual grounding in remote sensing (RSVG) aims to locate specific objects in remote sensing images based on referring expressions. While recent methods have achieved promising results by enhancing cross-modal fusion between vision and language, a key challenge remains: significant variation in object scales within a single RS image. Large-scale objects often dominate the representation space, leading to smaller ones being underrepresented or overlooked. To better understand and validate this issue, we analyze typical failure cases and then collect a challenging evaluation set, RSVG-MS, which specifically reflects multi-scale discrepancies. Motivated by these insights, we propose ASF-UE, an Adaptive Scale Fusion framework guided by Uncertainty Estimation. ASF-UE introduces a Scale-Sensitive Attention (SSA) module to extract scale-aware visual features across encoder layers under textual guidance. Additionally, a lightweight T-block is designed for spatial alignment, and a spatial uncertainty estimation (SUE) mechanism is integrated to adaptively score and fuse multi-scale features. Extensive experiments on two standard benchmarks, OPT-RSVG and DIOR-RSVG, demonstrate the effectiveness of our method. More importantly, ASF-UE achieves significant improvements on the challenging RSVG-MS dataset, highlighting its strength in handling scale variation in remote sensing visual grounding.

title: Safety-Oriented Evaluation of Embedded C Coding Methodologies for Automotive Software Using MISRA C and ISO 26262 Standards
authors: Rachid Latif, Moussa Bellaou, Lahoucaine Amenzouy, Abdessamade Elboudani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: The growing complexity of automotive systems has led to an increased reliance on embedded software, emphasizing the need for safe, reliable, and maintainable coding practises. This paper presents a comparative evaluation of manual and model-based C code development approaches for automotive systems, focusing on MISRA C and ISO 26262 compliance. The analysis covers two automotive use cases—a Battery Management System and a Wiper Controller—evaluated across safety, maintainability, and traceability metrics. Results demonstrate that standards-compliant manual coding achieved 92.4% ASIL-B coverage with only 3 MISRA violations and 63.6% smaller memory footprint (28.7KB vs 78.9KB) compared to model-based approaches, while maintaining competitive fault detection rates (89.2% vs 95.8%). Although model-based methods reached slightly higher coverage (97.1% ASIL-B), they required 3.2× more code (1,742 vs 548 LOC). These findings establish standards-compliant manual coding as a practical alternative to commercial model-based tools while providing a comparative evaluation methodology for safety-critical automotive software development.

title: Design Guidelines for an LRS-Enabled Electronic Voting System Using Cryptowallet Identities
authors: Silviu-Dumitru Paval, Adina-Andreea Nedelcu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Linkable Ring Signatures (LRS) combine strong voter anonymity with public duplicate-ballot detection, making them an attractive foundation for privacy-preserving online elections. This paper distills a comprehensive set of guidelines for integrating an LRS voting protocol into a modern web application backed by off-the-shelf cryptowallets such as MetaMask. In our design, each voter’s wallet keypair doubles as a persistent digital identity anchor, providing authenticated public keys and secure private-key storage without additional hardware or PKI. We detail the architectural components, protocol flows, and security safeguards required to achieve end-to-end anonymity, linkability, and verifiability while re-using the wallet’s existing public-key infrastructure and user-experience primitives. Our goal is to enable rapid prototyping of small- to medium-scale elections without introducing bespoke cryptographic tooling.

title: Enhancing ATM Security Via Deep Transfer Learning-Based Face Recognition
authors: Tsega Asresa Mengistu, Adomeas Asfaw Tafere, Melaku Bayih Demessie, Tekle Dargaso Degu, Desta Dana Data
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: Computer vision, a critical branch of artificial intelligence (AI), has transformative applications in information security, biometric authentication, banking, and beyond. Despite the widespread adoption of Automated Teller Machines (ATMs) for 24/7 financial transactions, security vulnerabilities persist, necessitating robust authentication mechanisms. This study proposes a deep transfer learning-based face recognition system to enhance ATM security by accurately verifying legitimate users. Leveraging on facial biometrics—a highly distinctive and tamper-resistant identifier, we benchmark state-of-the-art Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), including, VGG16, ResNet50, InceptionV3, and MobileNet, against various train-test splits (70/30, 80/20, and 90/10). Empirical results show that InceptionV3 outperforms the best with 98.7% training accuracy and 97.8% validation accuracy, outcompeting comparative models. Our methodology involves qualitative and quantitative analysis, where RGB facial images (128×128×3 pixels) and binary class labels. The research offers an efficient, scalable solution for the prevention of ATM fraud, in accordance with the latest trends in AI-driven financial security.

title: Adaptive EEG Artifact Space Reconstruction Based on the Support Vector Estimation in Dynamic Motion Conditions
authors: Shao-Ying Lee, Po-Han Lin, Chih-Wei Lu, Congying He, Li-Wei Ko
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: Motion artifacts in EEG signals present a major challenge for Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications, particularly in real-world scenarios where users are in motion. Traditional artifact removal methods struggle to adapt to highly dynamic conditions, limiting their effectiveness in mobile and wearable EEG systems. This study proposed a novel Support Vector Estimation Adaptive Artifact Subspace Reconstruction (SVE-AASR), which is a machine learning-driven approach that can dynamically adjust the cutoff threshold based on the posterior probability extracted by the SVM model to optimize the artifact removal across varying motion artifact conditions. SVE-AASR was evaluated in several naturalistic movement scenarios, including walking, running, and jumping, where it consistently outperformed conventional Adaptive Artifact Subspace Reconstruction (AASR). Notably, during high-intensity movements, SVE-AASR achieved statistically significant improvements (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<0.05$</tex>) in artifact suppression while preserving critical neural components. Additionally, benchmark dataset tests demonstrated superior noise removal and signal retention, further validating its robustness for real-world applications. By enhancing EEG signal quality in dynamic environments, SVE-AASR expands the applicability of mobile EEG-based neurotechnologies, enabling more reliable BCI performance in wearable systems, mobile brain/body imaging (MoBI), neurorehabilitation, and real-time cognitive monitoring.

title: Video Enhancement Using a Hybrid Deep Learning and Reinforcement Learning Approach
authors: Shoaib Shaikh, Nikhil Ravariya, Chandana Shastri, Nivedh Anakakkil, Hemangi Dharav, Arundhati Das
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Video enhancement plays a vital role in improving the visual quality of degraded video content. It involves a range of techniques aimed at enhancing brightness, resolution, contrast, and overall clarity, making it essential for applications in surveillance, media restoration, video streaming, and low-light scenarios. This paper presents a hybrid deep learning and reinforcement learning approach that integrates multiple advanced models to enhance various aspects of video quality. The proposed system employs UGANnet for low-light video enhancement, SRGAN for resolution upscaling, and AMTENnet for artifact analysis and deepfake detection. Additionally, reinforcement learning-based GANs are utilized to adaptively enhance video content based on quality feedback. A frame interpolation module is also integrated to ensure temporal smoothness in videos. The entire pipeline is built into a web-based application that allows users to upload videos or images, apply enhancement techniques, and download the processed output. Experiments conducted on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the hybrid model in improving brightness, clarity, temporal smoothness, and overall video quality across diverse scenarios.

title: A Spatiotemporal and User-Centric Assessment of 5G Enhanced Mobile Broadband Service in Addis Ababa
authors: Mubarik Ahmed Beshir, Beneyam Berehanu Haile
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: The telecom industry is globally moving toward 5G network to address high bandwidth, low latency, and massive connectivity requirements of innovative digital services. The deployment of 5G technology in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia is expected to address the speed and quality requirements of mobile broadband services in the business districts and selected residential areas of the city. However, practically achieved spatial and temporal end-user quality of service and experience from this 5G network has not been studied. This paper presents a spatiotemporal and user-centric assessment of quality of service and quality of experience for 5G enhanced mobile broadband service in Addis Ababa using objective and subjective methods. Measurement tools including a crowdsourcing mobile application (Ookla SpeedTest), a network management system (Huawei iMaster performance reporting system), and a drive test tool (probe handset unit) were applied alongside subjective surveys. The results reveal that, despite the significant disparity in its coverage, Addis Ababa’s 5G network performs above global and ITU IMT-2020 benchmarks for both download and upload throughput, with notable variances based on device type and spatiotemporal factors. Findings of this research work provide stakeholders with early-stage performance benchmarks to guide future enhancements and optimizations.

title: Performance of Transformer-Based Models in Dholuo-Swahili Translation for Low-Resourced Language
authors: Peter Kimanga, Benson Kituku, Juliet Moso, Patrick Gikunda
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: This study evaluates the performance of three transformer-based models: OpenNMT-py, BERT, and LLaMA 3.2 3B in translating Dholuo to Swahili, with a focus on the challenges faced in low-resource language translation. Although Swahili is widely supported in translation systems, Dholuo remains largely underrepresented. Using parallel corpora from KenCorpus and THiNK, we applied data augmentation techniques to enrich the dataset before training the models. Evaluation using BLEU, METEOR, ChrF++, and COMET metrics showed that OpenNMT-py achieved the highest performance, with a BLEU score of 41.77%, METEOR of 48.71%, ChrF++ of 64.46%, and COMET of 75.24%. In contrast, BERT and LLaMA 3.2 3B yielded significantly lower scores across all metrics. These results highlight the effectiveness of task-specific models in low-resource machine translation. Future work will explore the use of additional parallel corpora, and multilingual transfer learning to further improve performance and support wider coverage of low-resourced African languages.

title: Acceleration of Optical Link Recovery for Optical-Switched Data Center Networks via Clock and Protocol Co-Optimization
authors: Changsheng Yang, Xuwei Xue, Bingli Guo, Zihan Qiu, Shikui Shen, Yakun Hu, Wenzhe Li, Xianchen Wu, Guojun Yuan, Buzheng Wei, Xiao Li, Shanguo Huang
abstract: Optical switching offers significant potential for scalable and energy-efficient data center networks (DCNs) by enabling dynamic reconfiguration of high-bandwidth paths. However, fast and reliable optical link reconfiguration is fundamentally limited by synchronization delays introduced at both the physical layers and data link layers. Specifically, link switching disrupts clock and data recovery (CDR), equalization, and Physical Coding Sublayer (PCS) block synchronization at the receiver, while also delaying data link layer reinitialization due to prolonged uncertainty in link status. Excessive link recovery latency leads to packet loss, increased data packet transmission time, and degraded network utilization, especially under fine-grained switching intervals in DCNs. To decrease the link recovery time in optical-switched DCNs, we propose a co-optimized optical link recovery framework that integrates transmitter clock dynamic adjustment, protection sequence insertion, and a lightweight Ethernet-optical packet adapter. These mechanisms collectively reduce the uncertainty of link recovery time during switching, and accelerate fast protocol locking at the receiver. We implement the full system on FPGA hardware with a SOA-based optical switch and experimentally demonstrate nanosecond link recovery under aggressive switching conditions. The proposed mechanism reduces the optical link recovery time from 2.736 μs to 440.32 ns and maintains a packet loss rate as low as 4.24E-10 with a time-slot length of 256 μs, whereas conventional designs require more than 1 ms to reach comparable performance. This enables low-error operation under microsecond-scale switching intervals, facilitating dynamic and low-latency optical interconnects in practical data center environments.

title: Dynamics of Collective Group Affect: Group-level Annotations and the Multimodal Modeling of Convergence and Divergence_supp1-3643752.pdf
authors: Navin Raj Prabhu
abstract: Collaborating in a purposive group, whether face-to-face or virtually, involves continuously expressing emotions and interpreting those of other group members. As such, understanding group affect is essential to comprehending how groups interact and succeed in collaborative efforts. In this study, we move beyond individual-level affect and investigate group-level affect—a collective phenomenon that reflects the shared mood or emotions among group members at a particular moment. As the first in the literature, we gather annotations for group-level affective expressions in purposive group interactions using a fine-grained temporal approach (15 second windows) that also captures the inherent dynamics of this collective construct. To this end, we extensively train annotators and develop an annotation procedure specifically tuned to capture the entire scope of the group interaction from one interaction moment to the next. In addition, we model the ebb and flow of group affect by accounting for the underlying convergence (driven by emotional contagion) and divergence (resulting from emotional reactivity) of affective expressions among group members. To capture these interpersonal dynamics, we employ two approaches: (i) extracting synchrony-based handcrafted features from both audio and visual modalities, and (ii) introducing a novel, data-driven graph neural network to model interpersonal dynamics among group members. Our results highlight the advantages of the graph network over the handcrafted features in modeling group affect, while also emphasizing the importance of temporal modeling and incorporating multimodal cues. Additionally, our analysis of affective convergence and divergence reveals that groups tend to diverge in their social signals during neutral collective affect, while exhibiting convergence during more emotionally intense moments. These insights are drawn from comparative results across both modeling techniques.

title: Coordinated Decision Making for High-Speed Railway Train Timetable Rescheduling and Trajectory Control: Architecture, Algorithms, Simulation, and Applications
authors: Rongsheng Wang, Lingbin Ning, Shichao Ge, Shuxin Ding, Zhiming Yuan
abstract: During emergency response in high-speed railway operations, dispatchers and drivers currently rely on individual experience for decision making, lacking effective coordination between train timetable rescheduling and trajectory control. This results in a train timetable with insufficient precision, failing to provide a global train trajectory, and ultimately making it difficult to handle train delays caused by emergencies promptly. To address this practical problem, this article constructs a novel architecture and proposes a real-time algorithm for coordinated decision making for train timetable rescheduling and trajectory control (CDM-TTRTC). The simulation and application experiments show that compared to the noncoordinated method using manual experience, the proposed CDM-TTRTC algorithm can reduce the total train delay by 17.18% and total energy consumption by 5.82%. In addition, it can generate a train timetable and multitrain trajectory within 3.49 s, providing dispatchers and drivers with more reasonable and efficient decision support.

title: Performance Analysis and Optimization of Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access Enabled Hybrid Satellite-Terrestrial Relay Networks
authors: Jithin James, A. V. Babu, Akhil P. T.
abstract: This paper investigates outage and throughput performance of non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA)-enabled Hybrid Satellite Terrestrial Relay Networks (NOMA-HSTRNs) comprising of a satellite communicating with two terrestrial users (TUs) adopting the NOMA scheme with the help of a terrestrial relay that is selected from a cluster of multiple relays based on partial relay selection (PRS) scheme. We derive analytical expressions for the outage probabilities experienced by the TUs considering co-channel interference (CCI), residual hardware impairments (RHI) at the transceivers and imperfect successive interference cancellation conditions. To provide more insights on the outage performance, we obtain expressions for the asymptotic outage probabilities of the TUs in the high transmit power region. Next, we derive analytical expressions for the optimal power allocation factors (OPAFs) at both the satellite and the selected terrestrial relay that independently minimize the system outage probability. Further, we determine the jointly optimal power allocation factors (JOPAFs) that minimize the system outage probability. We also evaluate the sensitivity of the OPAFs against various system related parameters. We provide extensive analytical and simulations results to show that the proposed OPAFs significantly improve the system throughput and reduce both the system outage probability as well as the outage probabilities experienced by the TUs compared to equal/random power allocation schemes.
