title: AI-Powered System Cybersecurity Operations and Incident Response
authors: Pranita Chaudhary, Varad Sawant, Anurag Karpe, Lokesh Kad, Pratham Kubetkar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The intensity of cyber security hazards is increasing, smart, integrated solutions require which can immediately identify, classify and respond immediately. This paper presents a comprehensive AI-powered cyber security system that integrates modules for simplified monitoring and a centralized dashboard for coordination, detection of malware, network infiltration and email classification. To increase the accuracy of detecting danger and reducing false positivity, the system appoints machine machine learning and intensive learning methods. The email classification system uses supervised learning and natural language processing (NLP) to effectively identify spam and fishing email. The malware detection system appoints nerve network classifier with stable and dynamic analysis methods to identify malicious programs. Network infiltration detection system (NIDS) examines the network traffic behavior through models detecting discrepancy to identify suspicious activities. The dashboard compiles insight from each module, providing real -time analytics, alert management and user response tools to increase the system flexibility. Experimental findings encourage classification accuracy in various modules, in which email classifier reaches more than 90 % of accuracy. Even though delay and throwput assessment was not done, modular and scalable design guarantees flexibility of the system in various network settings. This study highlights the ability of AI-operated cyber security systems to identify the active danger in the corporate environment and improve the event management.

title: Integrating AI in Management Education: Applications & Challenges
authors: Abhijit Vhatkar, Saikat Gochhait
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: This research highlights the integration of Artificial Intelligence technology in the management education sector. It also focuses on various opportunities and challenges associated with AI in management education. AI has made a significant impact on various industries and it has the potential to revolutionize management education. The research has identified the current stage of AI adoption in management education, difficulties faced by management institutes and potential benefits of AI in management education. Management institutes can leverage AI to transform the teaching-learning process and effectively train students for the future.

title: Enhancement in Performance of Embedded Linux Through Study of Memory Management Algorithms of Swapping
authors: Manasi Natu, Supriya Rajankar, Madan Mali, Omprakash Rajankar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Improvements to memory management methods is considered in this paper, with a particular emphasis on swapping, in embedded Linux-based Debian systems. The goal of these enhancements is to increase embedded devices' speed and performance, which is essential for satisfying soft real-time requirements. This study assesses how well these improvements work with the Embedded Linux operating system. Because embedded systems are required to function under tight or moderate real-time constraints, the operating systems on embedded devices must minimize latency. Some applications require the smooth execution of multiple concurrent processes at the same time. This objective may be mostly accomplished effectively by making sure that memory management is done well.

title: Data-Driven Carbon Footprint Estimation in Software Systems Using AI and Deep Learning
authors: Iffat Khan, Pranjali Dharmadhikari, Mikhiel Benji, Rushikesh Edne, S. A. Jakhete
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The software industry contributes significantly to global carbon emissions, driven by the energy-intensive operations of cloud computing, data centers, and AI-driven workloads. This study systematically examines the environmental footprint of software throughout its life cycle, from hardware manufacturing to operational energy consumption. We analyze carbon emissions resulting from software execution, with a particular focus on computationally intensive tasks such as deep learning and large-scale data processing. In addition, we review existing methodologies for measuring and mitigating software-induced carbon emissions, including energy-efficient coding practices, workload optimization strategies, and integration of renewable energy sources. To advance this effort, we introduce an open source tool that quantifies <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> emissions in real time, specifically targeting deep learning models with high computational demands. Using frameworks such as Green Algorithms, our approach provides a standardized method for assessing and reducing carbon footprints in software operations. This paper aims to bridge the gap between sustainable computing practices and industry adoption, offering insights into future pathways for reducing the environmental impact of software technologies while aligning with global sustainability goals.

title: DFUGCN: Image Classifying Technique for Localizing of Diabetic Foot Ulcers
authors: Manaswi Shekokar, Ashutosh Shinde, Atharva S Kore, Anuradha Yenkikar, Nilesh Sable, Sandeep Kore
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) represent a serious and common complication of diabetes, occurring in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 - 2 5 \%}$</tex> of the world's diabetic population and resulting in high morbidity, amputations, and healthcare expense through delayed diagnosis. The current study responds to the need for immediate automated diagnostic systems that are accurate and cost-effective to facilitate early treatment and alleviate healthcare burdens. We introduce DFUGCN (Diabetic Foot Ulcer Graph Convolutional Network), a deep learning approach that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with a three-layer Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) to encode local features and spatial interactions usually not captured by classical CNNs. DFUGCN utilizes super pixel segmentation and region adjacency graphs to improve interpretability and robustness across different imaging modalities and clinically relevant patterns, enhancing the accuracy and trustworthiness of DFU detection. Experimental tests show the model's excellent performance, such as test image predictions with evidence from visual images. Expansion of the dataset and clinical deployment in future work will continue to enhance diagnostic accuracy.

title: Multimodal Sentiment Analysis Using Deep Learning and Attentive Mechanism
authors: Rahul Gaikwad, Monika Satpute, Swejal Phapale, Harshada Patil, Bharati Phapale
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: In today's digital era, interpreting human emotions from online content has become vital in sectors like marketing, customer support, healthcare, and social media analytics. This paper presents a robust multimodal sentiment analysis framework that combines textual and visual data to gain deeper emotional understanding. The approach employs Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to grasp contextual and sequential patterns in text, while EfficientNet, a cutting-edge convolutional neural network, is used to extract high-level features from images, including facial expressions and relevant visual cues. By merging the outputs from both modalities, the model accurately classifies emotions into five categories: very positive, positive, neutral, negative, and very negative. This dual-modality setup addresses the shortcomings of single-source sentiment analysis-such as the vagueness in text or the lack of depth in standalone images. Experimental results reveal that this integrated model delivers significantly higher accuracy and precision compared to traditional unimodal systems. Designed with real-time applications in mind, the system is well-suited for scenarios like monitoring social media trends, analyzing customer opinions, and improving virtual assistant interactions. The model's performance has been thoroughly validated using standard multimodal datasets, ensuring its adaptability and reliability. Ultimately, this research highlights the effectiveness of deep learning-based multimodal systems in decoding complex human emotions across a wide range of real-world applications.

title: Harmonizing Hindi Horizons: Assessing Transformer Variants for News Translation and Abstraction
authors: Sumit Khade, Omkar Biramane, Om Bothara, Vedprakash Bhagade, Rutuja Patil, Grishma Bobhate, Gagandeep Kaur
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of transformer-based models for Hindi-to-English news translation and summarization utilizing a custom dataset gathered from the IITB Hindi-English Corpus and 80 web-scraped articles from BBC Hindi, Amar Ujala, and Dainik Bhaskar. This study evaluated MarianMT against Google Translate for translation and compared BERT and T5 for extractive and abstractive summarization, respectively. The methodology encompasses data acquisition, preprocessing, model fine-tuning, and performance evaluation using metrics such as BLEU, ROUGE, and qualitative assessments. The analysis highlights the strengths and limitations of each model under resource-constrained conditions, offering insights into its applicability to multilingual news processing in India. This study contributes to the understanding of model efficacy on a tailored dataset, paving the way for optimized NLP solutions for India's linguistically diverse population.

title: Robust Federated Video-based Remote Physiological Measurement for Heterogeneous Multi-source Data
authors: Wenan Wang, Qinwei Xu, Xinkun Xu, Shaoxin Li, Feiyue Huang, Yefeng Zheng, Lifeng Zhu, Zhian Bai, Yuchen Xu, Weiguo Hu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) is a technology that uses facial video to capture physiological signals, namely photoplethysmography (PPG) signals, enabling convenient and low-cost non-contact physiolog ical measurement. Although current rPPG methods have achieved remarkable performance through extensive data training, they often ignore the transmission cost and privacy concerns of rPPG data. Federated learning (FL) pro vides a promising solution to these issues. However, effective federated training remains challenging due to the cross-domain heterogeneity that arises when using multi source rPPG data. To address these challenges, we characterize the heterogeneity of multi-source rPPG data from both the input and output domain perspectives. Motivated by this analysis, we introduce pseudo-labeling techniques and propose a novel FL framework, FedGRC. Specifically, we incorporate automatic gradient regularization calibration to mitigate the impact of input domain discrepancies on model performance. Furthermore, we leverage pseudo labels generated by handcrafted rPPG methods to align the output domain and reduce label inconsistencies across datasets. Our approach is validated across six publicly available datasets, demonstrating significant advantages over other approaches and effectively addressing the challenges of privacy protection and heterogeneity of multisource data.

title: TinyML vs LLMs: A Survey of Extreme Scales in Machine Learning
authors: Ismail Lamaakal, Chaymae Yahyati, Khalid El Makkaoui, Yassine Maleh, Ibrahim Ouahbi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: ML now works with an unmatched range of computational scales, from microcontrollers with models that are only a few kilobytes big to cloud infrastructures with Large Language Models (LLMs) that have trillions of parameters. These extremes show how AI has made progress in different ways: Tiny Machine Learning (TinyML) is great for green apps that don’t have a lot of resources because it focuses on real-time, ultra-low-power inference on edge devices. LLMs, on the other hand, are the best at understanding, reasoning, and generating language, but they often use a lot of energy and hurt the environment. This research provides a comprehensive analysis of TinyML and LLMs, highlighting their importance in the context of green and sustainable technology. We offer a systematic taxonomy that evaluates both paradigms based on critical factors such as model size, latency, energy consumption, memory footprint, training methodologies, privacy considerations, and deployment architecture. There are talks about how to use TinyML in smart agriculture, IoT, and wearable health monitoring, and how to use LLMs in cloud-based text generation, code synthesis, and decision support. We carefully consider the pros and cons of centralization and decentralization, scalability and sustainability, and performance and efficiency. Finally, we talk about what might happen in the future, like quantized TinyLLMs, federated learning for privacy-aware sustainability, and hybrid edge-cloud systems where TinyML acts as a green intelligence filter for LLM backends. The purpose of this poll is to get people to share their ideas on how to make AI systems that are both helpful and good for the environment.

title: Comparative Analysis of High-Resolution Phase Measurement Principles for Picosecond Clock Synchronization
authors: Roland Höller, Nikolaus Kerö, Sani Sarcevic
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Precision Clock Synchronization for Measurement, Control, and Communication (ISPCS)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of three high-resolution digital phase measurement methods for sub-nanosecond synchronization over Ethernet networks. Implemented in modern FPGAs, the Digital Dual Mixer Time Difference (DDMTD), Time-to-Digital Converter (TDC), and PLL-based Counter (PLLCTR) circuits are evaluated in terms of accuracy, resolution, and implementation complexity. The measurements were validated using a calibrated 12 GHz oscilloscope. Results show that all three methods achieve sub-100 ps residual error, with the DDMTD offering the highest precision and the TDC providing flexibility for non-periodic signals. The PLLCTR delivers compact, fast measurements with moderate resolution. The findings support the DDMTD’s suitability for applications like White Rabbit, while the TDC and the PLLCTR offer broader applicability for highly accurate, FPGA-based clock synchronization systems.

title: Emerging Trends in Artificial Intelligence for Digital Accessibility: A Topic Modeling Analysis
authors: Fitsum Gizachew Deriba, Amos Oyelere Sunday
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: In past decades, extracting key themes from vast amounts of unstructured data has facilitated the identification of meaningful categories, called topics, from the coding of textual content. While studies have examined the intersection of artificial intelligence and different domains, there is limited research focusing on understanding trends of AI for digital accessibility. This study aims to examine and identify domain areas, themes, and the interconnectivity of AI in accessibility by analyzing 1,479 papers. Using a structured topic modeling approach, the study analyzes emerging themes and topics. A network analysis method with the Fruchterman-Reingold algorithm was also used to understand the interaction and interconnectedness of these topics. The findings revealed 23 relevant topics and their corresponding keywords in the field of AI for digital accessibility, organized into four network communities and the connections between them. The findings highlight an imbalance in research priorities, indicating that current work heavily addresses sensory disabilities (particularly visual impairment), while critical areas such as AI for cognitive disabilities and the ethical challenges of AI in accessibility receive considerably less attention. The human-centered topic cluster were shown to be central to the research network.

title: Towards an Event-Level Analysis in Hadronic Physics Using Generative AI-Based Surrogates
authors: Tareq Alghamdi, Jitao Xu, Nesar Ramachandra, Nobuo Sato, Yaohang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: The field of hadronic physics is poised for significant advancements, driven by upcoming experimental programs at Jefferson Lab's 12 GeV facility and the future Electron-Ion Collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory. These experiments will produce vast amounts of data, necessitating sophisticated analytical methods to bridge experimental observations and the underlying theoretical frameworks of quantum chromodynamics (QCD). This paper introduces a generative AI-based surrogate modeling framework to address the computational and analytical challenges of traditional theory-driven approaches in event-level analysis. Specifically, we evaluate and compare the effectiveness of generative AI models, including Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and Diffusion Models (DMs), as surrogates for event generation. By replacing complex quantum correlation function (QCF) models with generative AI-based surrogates, our proposed framework enables efficient generation of synthetic events directly from QCF parameters. Moreover, this approach facilitates simulation-based parameter inference by learning the mappings between QCF parameters and observables, bypassing the gradient calculation challenges when directly incorporating the QCF model into solving the QCD inverse problems. Through a proof-of-concept QCF study, we demonstrate the capability of generative AI-based surrogates as an important tool to accurately replicate theoretical QCF models, which can be easily incorporated into simulation-based inference to reconstruct QCF parameters from observables.

title: Masked Autoencoders for Ultrasound Signals: Robust Representation Learning for Downstream Applications
authors: Immanuel Roßteutscher, Klaus S. Drese, Thorsten Uphues
abstract: We investigated the adaptation and performance of Masked Autoencoders (MAEs) with Vision Transformer (ViT) architectures for self-supervised representation learning on one-dimensional (1D) ultrasound signals. Although MAEs have demonstrated significant success in computer vision and other domains, their use for 1D signal analysis, especially for raw ultrasound data, remains largely unexplored. Ultrasound signals are vital in industrial applications such as nondestructive testing (NDT) and structural health monitoring (SHM), where labeled data are often scarce and signal processing is highly task-specific. We propose an approach that leverages MAE to pre-train on unlabeled synthetic ultrasound signals, enabling the model to learn robust representations that enhance performance in downstream tasks, such as time-of-flight (ToF) classification. This study systematically investigated the impact of model size, patch size, and masking ratio on pre-training efficiency and downstream accuracy. Our results show that pre-trained models significantly outperform models trained from scratch and strong convolutional neural network (CNN) baselines optimized for the downstream task. Additionally, pre-training on synthetic data demonstrates superior transferability to real-world measured signals compared with training solely on limited real datasets. This study underscores the potential of MAEs for advancing ultrasound signal analysis through scalable, self-supervised learning.

title: Class $\Phi$ Resonant Gate Driver with Waveform Shaping for SiC-based VHF Power Conversion
authors: Prateek Wagle, Ioannis Nikiforidis, Paul D. Mitcheson
abstract: Driving Silicon Carbide (SiC) MOSFETs at high frequencies presents significant challenges due to their high input gate capacitance and required voltage swing. In this paper we propose a design method for a Class $\Phi$ resonant gate driver topology, implemented on a SiC device in a $\mathbf {6.78}\,\mathbf {MHz}$ Class E inverter power stage. The topology is modelled using state-space analysis for performance optimisation and gate voltage profile shaping. Experimental results demonstrate significant advantages compared to conventional hard-switched half-bridge gate drivers, including lower gate driver power consumption and higher power device drain efficiency. Further optimisation of the magnetic components of the gate driver resulted in a further reduction both in size and power consumption, achieving an 8.6-fold reduction in gate driving power compared to the conventional half-bridge gate driver. Additionally, the experimental setup shows improved efficiency of the power stage which correlates to a 8.8 W (25.9%) reduction in loss in the power device when driven by the resonant gate driver.

title: Multi-Task Surrogate-Assisted Search With Bayesian Competitive Knowledge Transfer for Expensive Optimization
authors: Yi Lu, Kai Zhang, Xiaoming Xue, Liming Zhang, Guodong Chen, Chenming Cao, Piyang Liu, Kay Chen Tan
abstract: Expensive optimization problems (EOPs) present significant challenges for traditional evolutionary optimization due to their limited evaluation calls. Although surrogate-assisted search (SAS) has become a popular paradigm for addressing EOPs, it still suffers from the cold-start issue. In response to this challenge, knowledge transfer has been gaining popularity for its ability to leverage search experience from potentially related instances, ultimately facilitating head-start optimization for more efficient decision-making. However, the curse of negative transfer persists when applying knowledge transfer to EOPs, primarily due to the inherent limitations of existing methods in assessing knowledge transferability. On the one hand, a priori transferability assessment criteria are intrinsically inaccurate due to their imprecise understandings. On the other hand, a posteriori methods often necessitate sufficient observations to make correct inferences, rendering them inefficient when applied to EOPs. Considering the above, this paper introduces a Bayesian competitive knowledge transfer (BCKT) method developed to improve multi-task SAS (MSAS) when addressing multiple EOPs simultaneously. Specifically, the transferability of knowledge is estimated from a Bayesian perspective that accommodates both prior beliefs and empirical evidence, enabling accurate competition between inner-task and inter-task solutions, ultimately leading to the adaptive use of promising solutions while effectively suppressing inferior ones. The effectiveness of our method in boosting various SAS algorithms for both multi-task and many-task problems is empirically validated, complemented by comparative studies that demonstrate its superiority over peer algorithms and its applicability to real-world scenarios. The source code is available at https://github.com/XmingHsueh/MSAS-BCKT.

title: IF-TEM based Detection for Spike Communications with RLL Encoding
authors: Pialy Biswas, Meik Dörpinghaus, Gerhard Fettweis
abstract: We study spike-based sensor node communication using runlength-limited (RLL) coding to encode information in the temporal distances of the spikes. For such systems integrate-and-fire time encoding machines (IF-TEMs) are considered as an energy-efficient alternative to uniform sampling analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) at the receiver. In this regard, we present a spike detector that employs an IF-TEM with periodic reset followed by a demapper calculating log-likelihood ratios of the transmitted RLL symbols. We assess the communication performance based on the achievable rate between the RLL encoder input and the RLL decoder output. A comparison to the use of 1-bit ADCs shows that the proposed spike detection enables communication at significantly lower energy per bit to noise power spectral density ratio Eb/N0.

title: An Intelligent Mobile Sink-based Fault Detection and Data Collection Scheme for Consumer IoT-enabled Sensor Networks
authors: Anand Prakash Rawal, Vaibhav Agarwal, Om Jee Pandey, Prasenjit Chanak
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are essential for various consumer Internet of Things (IoT) applications such as Industry 4.0, intelligent transportation systems, and home automation. In these consumer IoT systems, different types of sensors are embedded within the IoT devices, which form a WSN for data collection. Sensor nodes in consumer-focused smart environments are vulnerable to faults due to harsh conditions such as extreme temperatures, high humidity, corrosion, and intense radiation. Faulty nodes reduce the functionality and lifetime of the consumer IoT network. It also significantly increases data routing delays. Existing state-of-the-art fault detection approaches consume a lot of energy to identify faulty sensor nodes within the network. This leads to premature network failure. Existing approaches also suffer from low detection accuracy and high data routing delay due to the unavailability of proper data routing paths. To address these issues, this paper proposes an intelligent fault detection and data collection mechanism for consumer IoT-enabled WSNs. It effectively diagnoses faulty nodes within the network and improves the overall network performance. A Mobile Sink (MS)-based optimal data collection scheme is proposed to collect data in the faulty network. It reduces data routing delay and prevents premature death of the network. Furthermore, an MS-based hard fault detection mechanism is proposed to reduce energy consumption and improve the network lifetime. A hyper-parameter tuning-based soft fault detection mechanism is also proposed to identify software faults within the deployed sensor nodes. It significantly increases the Fault Detection Accuracy (FDA). Extensive simulations and testbed results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed scheme. The simulation and testbed results are evaluated against state-of-the-art algorithms based on True Positive Rate (TPR), Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), F1-Score, FDA, network lifetime, data collection delay, and data collection rate.

title: High-Gain Circularly Polarized Foldable Reflectarray for 3U CubeSat
authors: K. H. Ali, O. S. Hassan, M. A. Abou-Khousa
abstract: CubeSat, a class of nanosatellites, have gained considerable interest as cost-effective alternatives to traditional satellites for space missions. Their affordability and the ability to utilize commercially available components make them attractive for various applications. CubeSat can establish communication links both in orbit and with ground stations for missions targeting destinations such as the Moon, Mars, asteroids, and other planetary bodies, where high data rates are essential. Achieving these high data rates requires antennas with high gain to counteract significant free-space path loss. However, the compact size and weight constraints of CubeSat pose challenges in designing antennas that meet mission requirements. This paper presents a single-layer, high-gain, circularly polarized (CP) foldable reflectarray (FRA) designed specifically for 3U CubeSat applications. The reflectarray comprises 400 unit cells, each featuring copper circular patches with four quasi-spiral phase delay lines printed on a 3.15 mm Rogers RT5880 substrate. The proposed unit cell offers low loss, complete 360° phase coverage, and supports both right-hand and left-hand circular polarization, ensuring the entire FRA is circularly polarized. The proposed FRA consists of three panels, each measuring <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30 \text{cm} \times 10 \text{cm}$</tex>, with a circularly polarized helical antenna serving as the feed. The FRA is designed and simulated using CST Studio Suite to operate at 10 GHz. The simulation results demonstrate a peak gain of 27.71 dBic, along with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28.5 \% 3-\text{dB}$</tex> gain bandwidth and 30% axial ratio bandwidth. These performance characteristics significantly reduce polarization mismatch, enhancing the reliability and consistency of communication links crucial for CubeSat operations.

title: A Novel Technique to Rank-Order Occupational Injury Claims for Return-to-Work Prediction
authors: Gonzalo A. Vivian, Chelsea M. Zuvieta, Taghi M. Khoshgoftaar
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Accurately forecasting the length of an employee's absence following workplace injuries remains a critical yet ongoing challenge. Such incidents place a significant strain on businesses through potential costs such as lost wages and productivity. Organizations may lack reliable tools to predict and prioritize the injury-related absences with the most lost workdays. This study leverages two machine learning models, CatBoost and a decision tree, to predict the number of days from injury to return-to-work date using a comprehensive dataset of workers' compensation claims that consists of employee demographics and injury-related features, such as injury severity, nature, and cause. Instead of regression performance alone, we focus on the models' ability to prioritize cases at risk of extended injury leave. We evaluate this using a rank-ordering framework to examine how well each model identifies cases with the longest absence durations. Our rank-based evaluation shows that both models are able to flag a substantial portion of high-risk cases. This paper proposes a novel predictive framework to support return-to-work planning and resource management. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to predict absence length after a workplace injury and assess regression model performance using ranking analysis in occupational health and safety.

title: Decentralized Approach to 4G Identity Management Using Self-Sovereign Identity and Blockchain
authors: Boda Serge Etiennovitch, Songo-Kette Mogambo Freddy Oscar, Ndassimba Edgard, Ouya Samuel
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Identity management in 4G networks is traditionally based on centralized architectures, which are vulnerable to fraud, identity theft, and privacy breaches. Centralization also limits users’ ability to control their personal data. This paper explores an alternative approach by integrating blockchain technology and the Self-Sovereign Identity model to enable decentralized and secure identity management within a 4 G environment. The prototype network relies on srsRAN and ZeroMQ Virtual Radio, combined with a blockchain infrastructure built using Ganache and Truffle. Authentication is handled through a User Self-Sovereign Identity application, allowing each user to manage their credentials via smart contracts. An experimental platform was developed to evaluate the system’s feasibility and performance. Results show that this approach enhances security, promotes user autonomy, and improves network resilience against threats. By eliminating the need for a central authority, the solution ensures the integrity, traceability, and efficiency of authentication processes, while mitigating the risk of unauthorized access. This work contributes to rethinking digital identity management in mobile networks through the use of decentralized and reliable technologies.

title: High-Resolution Recommender System for Metamaterial Synthesis
authors: Ismail A. Shittu, Mohamed Abou-Khousa, Ibrahim Abe M. Elfadel
abstract: The synthesis of metamaterials using the inverse design approach has revolutionized the field of metamaterials. It allows for efficient exploration of the vast design space and has the potential to accelerate the development of metamaterials for various applications. Machine learning methodologies within the inverse design framework present a viable strategy for metamaterial synthesis. One option in the machine-learning realm involves modeling the relationship between metamaterial layouts and performance parameters as complex nonlinear functions, which can be well approximated with deep generative models. However, deep generative models require enormous computational resources, careful hyperparameter tuning, and extensive training episodes for optimal performance. In addition, the residual training errors inhibit specific metamaterial reconstructions. Relying on the vast amount of data within a specified design space, this study transforms metamaterial synthesis into a retrieval process using a recommender system that outperforms deep generative models without enormous computations, meticulous hyperparameter optimization, and prolonged training sessions. The recommendation system, which uses a modified item-based filtering algorithm, operates on the premise that the metamaterial whose performance parameters most accurately correspond to a given query serves as a reliable approximation. This approach paves the way for a faster and more efficient metamaterial synthesis. The validity of this idea is further substantiated by the significant enhancements in reconstruction quality seen in experiments conducted on the corpus of stealth metamaterial designs, demonstrating the recommender system's ability to capture intricate low-level details. Compared to deep generative models, the algorithm significantly reduces computational time due to the absence of training while maintaining superior reconstruction accuracy, as there are no residual training errors.

title: AI Image and Text Generation for Students in Higher Education
authors: Vasil Kozov, Serkan Sadulov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: A general problem with access to image generation tools with sufficient capabilities by students has been identified. Students need to access the university resources for the purpose of image generation freely. The research problem is to solve the access barrier and to characterize how the pilot solution is used by students and staff. A short literature review on the current text-to-image technological advancements and applications was conducted. In order to solve the problem, an applied research methodology has been adopted and followed. A software architecture model MVC of a solution has been adopted. A software prototype has been developed using C\#. Net, along with a deployed instance of Stable Diffusion 3.5 API on computers with RTX 4090, the authentication integrates the existing university Active Directory for account management. A limited two-week pilot test has been conducted. A total of 814 images were generated, 22% of them by students, 78% by staff. The most frequently generated objects were “person” and “car”. The results have been analyzed, and conclusions on the positive impact of the proposed solution have been made. The feasibility of the solution was demonstrated, creating the groundwork for future research and larger studies. The possible expansion of the proposed solution and future research have been discussed.

title: Automated Answer Paper Evaluation (AAPE)
authors: C K Roopa, D Ashwin, B Adithya, C Ajith, J Chandan
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: To ensure accuracy and fairness in education, grading is crucial. However, conventional techniques for assessing answer sheets can be laborious and frequently influenced by bias. By updating the entire procedure, the Automated Answer Paper Evaluation (AAPE) system solves these problems. Using optical character recognition (OCR), it first scans and reads handwritten responses before comparing them to model responses. Our system uses Natural Language Processing (NLP), which includes cosine metrics to measure similarity and WordNet to expand synonyms, to increase the accuracy of this comparison. Our system additionally integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) to enhance comprehension of the content. Additionally, it does not ignore visual information; to guarantee that answers are graded fairly, diagrams are examined using YOLO-based object detection.Altogether, this smart approach speeds up grading, reduces bias, and gives students more meaningful feedback.

title: Remote Monitoring of Pasture Biomass and Vegetation Health in Free-Range Cattle Systems Using Block-Based RGB Drone Imagery Classification and the Excess Green Index
authors: Iliyan Damyanov, Durhan Saliev, Kalin Dimitrov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper investigates how remote sensing techniques can be used to estimate pasture biomass and assess vegetation health in free-range cattle systems. It introduces a lightweight, reproducible image processing method that relies solely on RGB images captured by autonomous drones. The technique uses a block-based spatial classification with the Excess Green (ExG) index to differentiate between green grass, dry vegetation, and bare soil. Each high-resolution image (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1600 \times 1600$</tex> pixels) is divided into uniform blocks, and the average ExG value within each block is used for classification. The generated vegetation condition maps and statistical summaries support efficient forage management and promote data-driven decisions in livestock production. This approach does not require multispectral sensors or field calibration, making it practical and scalable for low-cost biomass monitoring in grazing environments.

title: Enhancing Parkinson’s Diagnosis with Deep Learning and Speech Features
authors: Sayesha Malhotra, Sujai Kartik Saravanarajan
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: Parkinson’s disease (PD) grows progressively worse in the nervous system while requiring prompt and precise detection methods to handle the condition effectively. A framework based on machine learning methods was developed for PD diagnosis enhancement purposes in this research. The research examines three feature frameworks by implementing Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) and AdaBoost models which perform testing on the entire dataset together with TQWT + MFCC and TQWT + Wavelet features. The voice recordings get processed to get meaningful patterns which serve as input for classification purposes. The evaluation of both models takes place through testing with different feature sets using accuracy and precision and recall and F1-score performance metrics. The ANN model attains superior results to AdaBoost while working with all feature combinations by reaching a maximum accuracy of 97.35% using TQWT + Wavelet features. Deep learning models demonstrate superior PD classification outcomes when combined with optimal feature sets according to the obtained results. The research demonstrates the effectiveness of learning-based techniques to detect Parkinson's disease through noninvasive methods by creating opportunities for automated medical testing advances.

title: Identification of Equipment Failure Behavior Through Comparative Analysis of Statistical and Theoretical Methods
authors: Doru Cosofret, Octavian-Narcis Volintiru, Marius Cucu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Reliability is a key factor in ensuring the continuous and efficient operation of equipment. The failure rate is a parameter used to quantify the reliability performance of equipment and to identify wear and degradation patterns of its components. This article aims to analyze the continuous distribution of data concerning the time intervals between consecutive failures of a piece of equipment, by comparing statistical methods (histogram analysis and the Likelihood Ratio test) for failure time evaluation with theoretical distribution models (exponential and Weibull). The main objective is to determine the behavior of the equipment's failure rate, thereby providing valuable insights for optimizing preventive maintenance strategies to ensure and maintain a high level of reliability. To validate the proposed analytical model, a case study was conducted on the bilge pump system of a ship. The application of the Weibull distribution yielded a shape parameter value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\beta} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{1. 6 9 0 7}$</tex>, indicating an increasing failure rate (wear-out failures). The Likelihood Ratio Test confirmed the superiority of the Weibull model over the Exponential one, obtaining an LR statistic of 4.6 and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p$</tex>-value <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<0.05(p=0.032)$</tex>.

title: OEMLLM: Ophthalmology Expert MLLM for Various Fundus Disease Assisted Diagnosis
authors: Junfeng Sun, Yunchao Gu, Xinliang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: While Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have demonstrated remarkable performance in general-domain tasks, their application in specialized medical fields, such as the assisted diagnosis of fundus diseases, remains limited due to the lack of domain-specific knowledge. To bridge this gap, we introduce the FUNDUS-BENCH dataset, a multi-task benchmark tailored for fundus images. Based on the FUNDUSBENCH dataset, a multimodal medical auxiliary diagnosis system, Ophthalmology Expert MLLM (OEMLLM) is designed, which is an innovative system that leverages a hierarchical feature extraction method based on Vision Transformer to fully utilize both low-level lesion features and high-level semantic features from fundus images. OEMLLM further integrates with a Large Language Model (LLM) to perform multi-task learning for comprehensive fundus disease diagnosis. Extensive experiments show that OEMLLM outperforms state-of-the-art MLLMs with comparable parameter scales (approximately 2B parameters) and maintains competitive performance against larger-scale models. The dataset and code associated with this system will be open-sourced shortly, aiming to facilitate research and development of practical AI-assisted diagnostic tools in medical applications.

title: Design and Verification of Programmable UART with AXI in Application-Specific Integrated Circuits
authors: Jagadeesh Basavaiah, Poornima H S, Audre Arlene Anthony, Naveen Kumar H N, Mahadevaswamy Mahadevaswamy, Chandrashekar Mohan Patil
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: Modern embedded systems demand high-speed, reliable communication between IP cores, necessitating the integration of robust bus protocols and interfaces. To meet this need, our work focuses on designing reusable, synthesizable modules that ensure performance and verification completeness. This study presents the design and verification of a programmable UART, and an AXI interface tailored for ASIC-based embedded systems. The UART module supports serial data transmission, while AXI provides high-speed bus communication for SoCs. Functional simulation and waveform analysis validate the successful data transmission of UART, and AXI’s performance is confirmed using write/read transactions with proper handshaking. The verification is conducted using Universal Verification Methodology (UVM), achieving 90% functional coverage and confirming protocol compliance. The proposed work ensures reliable, low-latency communication, suitable for high-performance embedded applications.

title: Integrating Vision-Language Models and Multimodal Retrieval for Real-Time Emergency Response in Healthcare
authors: Adil Zhiyenbayev, Rakhat Abdrakhmanov, Huseyin Atakan Varol, Adnan Yazici
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Injuries and sudden health crises at home demand rapid medical response. We present a lightweight framework that integrates the PrismerZ vision-language model with a key-frame selection algorithm and a multimodal retrieval system to recognize emergencies from video data. The approach combines image captioning and visual question answering with efficient storage and search of embeddings to support healthcare professionals. Evaluated on the Kinetics benchmark (86.5 % image captioning accuracy, 92.5 % visual question answering accuracy) and on a self-collected dataset of emergency scenarios (85.8 % image captioning accuracy, 87.5 % visual question answering accuracy), the system operated within seconds on an embedded edge device. By uniting anomaly detection and multimedia retrieval, the framework extends human activity recognition toward actionable emergency detection in home environments.

title: Root Nodule Estimation Using a Non-Destructive Machine Learning Approach
authors: Murat Kaya, Abdurrahman Yılmaz, Leonardo Guevara, Grzegorz Cielniak, Ravi Valluru
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The root nodule formation in legumes such as faba bean is a key indicator of biological nitrogen fixation and sustainable agriculture. While image-based and deep learning methods have recently enabled automated nodule detection with high accuracy, these approaches rely on destructive root extraction, controlled imaging, and labour-intensive annotation, which hinder their scalability and practical field application. To address these limitations, this study proposes a non-destructive, and cost-effective machine learning framework for early prediction of root nodule counts in faba bean, using only easily measurable morphological traits. The developed dataaugmented model, trained exclusively on field-accessible, nondestructive features, achieved a test <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> of up to 0.95 and maintained low error rates (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R M S E} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0. 0 3 8 4}$</tex>; MAE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0. 0 2 8 2}$</tex>) even with limited data. Data augmentation further improved both prediction accuracy and model robustness. Overall, this approach offers a scalable solution for high-throughput, fieldready nodule phenotyping, overcoming significant barriers associated with image-based techniques and enabling practical automation in legume symbiosis research.

title: Universal Laboratory Model: Prognosis of Abnormal Clinical Outcomes based on Routine Tests
authors: Pavel Karpov, Ilya Petrenkov, Ruslan Raiman
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Clinical laboratory results are ubiquitous in any diagnosis making. Predicting abnormal values of not prescribed tests based on the results of performed tests looks intriguing, as it would be possible to make early diagnosis available to everyone. The special place is taken by the Common Blood Count (CBC) test, as it is the most widely used clinical procedure. Combining routine biochemical panels with CBC presents a set of test-value pairs that varies from patient to patient, or, in common settings, a table with missing values. Here we formulate a tabular modeling problem as a set translation problem where the source set comprises pairs of GPT-like label column embedding and its corresponding value while the target set consists of the same type embeddings only. The proposed approach can effectively deal with missing values without implicitly estimating them and bridges the world of LLM with the tabular domain. Applying this method to clinical laboratory data, we achieve an improvement up to 4% AUC for joint predictions of high uric acid, glucose, cholesterol, and low ferritin levels.

title: Multipole Analysis of Metasurfaces Exhibiting Toroidal Resonances
authors: Jhon James Hernández-Sárria, Jéssica Abranches Pinto Ribeiro, Luciano Leonel Mendes, J. R. Mejía-Salazar
abstract: Recent advances in analytical methodologies have greatly enhanced our understanding of metasurfaces, particularly in the visible and infrared regimes, through multipole-resonance-coupling-based design. However, in the terahertz (THz) and microwave regimes, metasurface design still relies heavily on trial-and- error approaches, emphasizing the need for systematic, physics-driven strategies. In this work, we employ multipole analysis to investigate the transmission and reflection properties of metasurfaces supporting dipole toroidal resonances. The proposed metasurface is based on a Tai-Chi-inspired unit cell geometry, designed to support toroidal dipole resonances while exhibiting polarization dependence due to its intrinsic chirality. The unit cells are modeled using copper, which behaves as a perfect electric conductor (PEC) in the microwave regime. By optimizing the unit cell's geometric parameters, we amplify the toroidal response, achieving enhanced control over the electromagnetic behavior of the metasurface. To validate our approach, we analyze a recently reported experimental structure, demonstrating excellent qualitative agreement with existing results. This qualitative agreement arises because substrate-associated boundary conditions cannot be fully captured in the multipole expansion method. To address this limitation, we incorporate an effective medium approach to account for substrate effects on the system's electromagnetic properties. Our methodology uniquely enables the decomposition of transmission and reflection spectra into individual multipole contributions, providing deep insights into the electromagnetic behavior of the metasurface. Specifically, we use a Cartesian multipole expansion to quantify the contributions of each electric toroidal moment and electric dipole moment to the spectra. This analysis identifies the role of each multipole in the observed resonances, offering a robust framework for tailoring metasurface properties. Additionally, we present calculations of linear dichroism and its decomposition into distinct multipole components, which are critical for developing polarization-dependent devices that control transmission and reflection properties. Finally, comparative calculations using volumetric and surface approaches highlight skin-depth effects in both the microwave and THz regimes, elucidating their impact on the observed electromagnetic features.

title: Energy-Efficient Smart Irrigation Using Edge AI and Forecast-Driven Scheduling
authors: Christopher G. Harris
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper presents an edge-based smart irrigation system that integrates IoT sensing, machine learning, and explainable AI to optimize water use in agriculture. Unlike cloud-dependent solutions, our framework deploys LSTM and XGBoost models directly on low-power edge devices, enabling real-time, forecast-driven irrigation scheduling in connectivity-constrained environments. The system incorporates SHAP-based interpretability to enhance transparency and farmer trust. We validate the approach through multi-season simulations using real-world datasets from FAO, NASA POWER, and OpenET, evaluating performance across water savings, prediction accuracy, and irrigation efficiency. Results show that the proposed system reduces water use by over 20 % compared to traditional methods while maintaining yield potential and operating within the constraints of embedded hardware. This work demonstrates the feasibility of deploying interpretable, data-driven irrigation control at the field level, offering a scalable solution for sustainable agriculture.

title: Towards Design of Questionnaire to Study the Role of LCA Tool to Foster the Eco-Innovations in Agrifood Sector
authors: Pavel Vitliemov, Juliana Popova, Igor Sheludko
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The agri-food sector is a cornerstone of the global economy, connecting agricultural production to food consumption through a complex system of processes and stakeholders. This sector encompasses every stage of the food journey, from cultivation and harvesting to processing, packaging, transportation, distribution, trade, purchase, preparation, consumption, and disposal. The agri-food sector involves every stage of the food supply chain. It is primarily composed of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which form the backbone of the industry. The environmental challenges posed by the agri-food sector extend beyond GHG emissions and climate change. The goal of this paper is to design a questionnaire that is focused to survey the opinions of SME managers related to the role of LCA tools to foster ecoinnovations in the agri-food sector and to investigate the opinions of managers of SMEs from five ES countries.

title: Pelican Optimization Algorithm Performances for Harmonic Parameters Estimation of a Synthetic Power Signal
authors: Mehmet Akif Senol, Mustafa Saka, Haluk Gozde, M. Cengiz Taplamacioglu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Harmonic estimation of signal parameters is important problem for power system. In this paper, Pelican Optimization Algorithm (POA) performances have been examined for solving harmonic estimation problem. For this purpose, a test signal which is including sub and interharmonics conditions has been chosen. Amplitude and phase angle parameters of a signal has been determined via Pelican Optimization Algorithm. Analyzes have been performed for two different cases: non-noisy signal parameters estimation and noisy signal (for 25db signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) level) parameters estimation. Non-noisy results compared with Bacterial Foraging Optimization (BFO) in the literature. It can be clearly seen from the obtained results that POA is capable and successful method for harmonic parameters estimation of both non-noisy and noisy power system signals.

title: A Multiband Circularly Polarized SIW-Horn Antenna for Sub-Theraherz Frequencies
authors: David Pouhè, Ümit Ucar
abstract: This work proposed a circular polarized dielectric loaded substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$H$</tex>-plane sectoral horn antenna. The antenna is a laminated planar waveguide consisting of two metal structures mounted on the top and bottom of a dielectric substrate with an array of metallic vias embedded in the substrate to emulate the vertical walls of a traditional waveguide. A dielectric slab identical to that of the horn and acting as a lens is used at the horn opening to increase the gain. Printed transitions are etched on that slab for matching purposes and to improve the antenna's bandwidth. Circular polarization is obtained by etching a dipole after the transition elements, whereby one arm of the dipole is on the top layer while the other is on the bottom layer. The simulated results are displayed as obtained. They show that the antenna is a multiband antenna with wideband and circular polarization characteristics. The antenna is of high gain and has a high degree of polarization purity. These characteristics make it a good candidate for the 6th generation of mobile communication systems (6 G).

title: Quantum Machine Learning for EV Mobile Charging Prediction
authors: Alexander Mutiso Mutua, Ruairí de Fréin
abstract: The widespread adoption of Electric Vehicles (EV) is hindered by range anxiety and the limited flexibility of Fixed Charging Points (FCP). There is a pressing need for intelligent, adaptive solutions that ensure timely EV charging while minimising infrastructure costs and grid stress. To address this challenge, we propose to integrate Mobile Charging as a Service (MCaaS) with Machine Learning (ML). We develop asimulation environment modelling 50 EVs operating within an urban area, where GEECharge Mobile Charging Units (MCU) are dynamically dispatched to charge EVs with low-battery charge events. We use a Variational Quantum Neural Network (VQNN) and a LSTM to predict EVs likely to have low-battery charge events. Our VQNN model achieves an accuracy of 88%, outperforming the LSTM baseline at 84%. The VQNN demonstrates a superior performance in detecting critical low-battery charge events, achieving a recall of 50% compared to 0% for the LSTM. MCaaS successfully prevents 81.8% of potential vehicle strandings, with 0 actual strandings recorded on highways during the simulation. The integration of VQNN enhances the proactive nature of MCaaS, thus transforming reactive charging into preventive maintenance. MCaaS has the potential to supply EVs with charge wherever they are and help eliminate the cost of constructing an FCP that requires extensive electrical infrastructure and grid connection, enhancing the green transition and promoting sustainability.

title: Improving Stool Segmentation in Abdominal X-Rays using Gas Mask Guidance with U-Net
authors: Naoya Takashima, Tsuyoshi Sanuki, Yoshikazu Kinoshita, Syoji Kobashi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Segmenting targets with ambiguous features in medical images poses a persistent challenge for quantitative analysis. This is particularly true for stool segmentation in abdominal X-rays—vital for the Stool Volume Score (SVS) in constipation management—where conventional single-channel deep learning methods often struggle. This study investigates if incorporating expert-annotated intestinal gas masks as an explicit, additional input channel to a U-Net model enhances stool segmentation accuracy and SVS reliability. An ablation study compared a dual-channel U-Net (X-ray + gas mask) against an identical single-channel baseline (X-ray only), using the same architectures and training protocols. Performance was assessed using the Dice coefficient, Precision, Recall, and SVS analysis (Pearson correlation, Bland-Altman agreement). The dual-channel model showed an improved Dice coefficient (0.726 vs. 0.710) and Recall (0.706 vs. 0.675) compared to the single-channel baseline, while Precision was slightly higher for the baseline (0.748 vs. 0.747). Crucially, the enhanced segmentation by the dual-channel model yielded a stronger correlation between predicted and ground-truth SVS (Pearson r=0.852 vs. 0.818) and excellent SVS agreement (Bland-Altman bias: 0.01, limits of agreement: -0.06 to 0.07). Explicit gas mask guidance thus improves overall stool segmentation, primarily by achieving a more comprehensive capture of stool regions, which in turn enables more reliable SVS quantification. This dual-channel strategy offers a promising approach for objective fecal load assessment in clinical practice.

title: Design and Development of a High Performance Two-Element MIMO Antenna for 5.9 GHz Vehicular Communication
authors: Bhavya Babu, S. Aiswarya, Nair S. Bhuvana
abstract: A novel two-element MIMO antenna for vehicular communication operating at 5.9 GHz is proposed. The antenna is designed on a FR4 epoxy substrate, having a height of 1.6 mm and a dielectric permittivity of 4.4 using ANSYS Electronics Desktop 2024. The design process begins with a circular patch antenna fed by a quarter-wave transformer. Performance at the operating frequency is significantly enhanced by integrating overlapping circular patches. Each antenna element achieves resonance at 5.91 GHz with a reflection coefficient of 30.5 dB, providing a bandwidth of 682 MHz and a gain of 5.2 dB. To ensure effective MIMO performance, the inter-element distance is optimised to enhance isolation between the antennas. The resulting two-element MIMO antenna exhibits an isolation greater than -24.2 dB which minimises mutual coupling and ensures reliable performance in vehicular communication environments. This design approach, combining the circular patch geometry, and inter-element spacing, provides a compact, high-performance solution suitable for modern vehicular communication applications. The proposed MIMO antenna not only meets the bandwidth and isolation requirements but also achieves enhanced gain, making it a promising candidate for 5.9 GHz vehicular communication systems.

title: New Resonant Converter Design for Low Coupling Wireless Power Transfer Applications
authors: Iman Okasili, Ahmad Elkhateb, Timothy Littler
abstract: This paper presents a new resonant converter design for low coupling wireless power transfer applications. The new design is based on a combination of the class E2 and CUK converters. The goal of this combination is to achieve a flexible system that can operate in a low coupling region whilst maintaining ZVS/ZDS and a controllable output. This paper begins by detailing the key aspects for desired operation and outlines the foundations of the design method. The focus for this paper will be on operation as a boost converter. The design is verified through simulation using PLECS and the results are compared with that of a 15W low power experimental set up. This paper aims to critically evaluate the outcomes of this new design method, the discussion and conclusion serve to highlight the strengths and future enhancements of this system.

title: A Fast Transient Response LDO with Dynamic Adjustment Circult for Slew Rate
authors: Zhong Jie Tang, Zhi Chong Wan, Mei Song Tong
abstract: This article proposes a fast transient response low dropout regulator (LDO) with a dynamic adjustment circuit to control the swing rate. With the increasing demand for power stability and response speed in electronic devices, traditional LDOs are unable to meet the transient performance requirements when facing rapid load current changes. This design introduces a dynamic adjustment circuit that can monitor real-time changes in load current and dynamically adjust the internal parameters of LDO based on the current change rate, effectively improving the conversion rate and significantly enhancing the transient response performance of LDO. The experimental results show that compared with traditional LDO, the proposed LDO significantly reduces the overshoot and undershoot of the output voltage and shortens the recovery time when the load current suddenly changes. It achieves efficient voltage regulation while maintaining low power consumption, providing a feasible solution for high-performance power management systems.

title: Investigation of Quantitative and Qualitative Methods for Risk Assessment in Agricultural Management
authors: Kristina Pavlova, Stanislav Dimitrov, Kamelia Ivanova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Agricultural activity is among the sectors that are most sensitive to various risks arising from different factors. These risks significantly impact the stability, productivity, and sustainable development of agricultural holdings, necessitating in-depth analysis and effective management of uncertainty in the sector. The study provides an overview of the basic principles of risk management in agriculture. Special attention is paid to the main techniques and applications of modern methods for qualitative and quantitative risk analysis. A comparative analysis is carried out to identify the advantages and limitations of qualitative and quantitative methods. Based on the literature review and comparisons, recommendations are made for the integration of combined approaches that combine the benefits of both types of methods. The aim is to achieve greater accuracy, flexibility, and efficiency in risk management processes in agricultural holdings. The results of the study contribute to the improvement of the theoretical and practical foundations of risk management in the agricultural sector. They can serve as a basis for developing integrated models and strategies that support sustainable development and informed management decisions in dynamic and uncertain environments.

title: PyDivDyn: A High-Performance Python Toolkit for Machine Learning Analyses of Macro-Evolutionary
authors: Yiwu Zhu, Changhan Chen, Weixin Liu, Xuejie Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: To overcome the computational limitations that impede large-scale palaeobiological research, we engineered PyDivDyn, a high-performance Python package. We architected PyDivDyn with a fully vectorized computational core based on NumPy and pandas. This core design reduces wall-time by up to 65 % and memory consumption by an order of magnitude on large datasets. To ensure interoperability, we designed a modular, scikit-learn-compatible API and integrated Apache Arrow support for HPC and machine learning pipelines. While achieving these performance gains, we rigorously validated PyDivDyn to ensure it maintains bit-for-bit numerical parity and full functional equivalence with the established <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}$</tex> package divDyn. Our work delivers a computationally efficient and extensible tool that combines statistical rigor with a modern, high-performance design, thereby enabling more advanced, machine-learning-driven analyses of Earth's biodiversity history.

title: Anomaly Detection in Electric Vehicle Charging Stations Using Federated Learning
authors: K C Bishal, Amr Hilal, Pawan Thapa
publish: 2025 IEEE Global Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things (GCAIoT)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is a decentralized training framework widely used in IoT ecosystems that preserves privacy by keeping raw data local, making it ideal for IoT-enabled cyber-physical systems with sensing and communication like Smart Grids (SGs), Connected and Automated Vehicles (CAV), and Electric Vehicle Charging Stations (EVCS). With the rapid expansion of electric vehicle infrastructure, securing these IoTbased charging stations against cyber threats has become critical. Centralized Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) raise privacy concerns due to sensitive network and user data, making FL a promising alternative. However, current FL-based IDS evaluations overlook practical challenges such as system heterogeneity and non-IID data. To address these challenges, we conducted experiments to evaluate the performance of federated learning for anomaly detection in EV charging stations under system and data heterogeneity. We used FedAvg and FedAvgM, widely studied optimization approaches, to analyze their effectiveness in anomaly detection. Under IID settings, FedAvg achieves superior performance to centralized models using the same neural network. However, performance degrades with non-IID data and system heterogeneity. FedAvgM consistently outperforms FedAvg in heterogeneous settings, showing better convergence and higher anomaly detection accuracy. Our results demonstrate that FL can handle heterogeneity in IoT-based EVCS without significant performance loss, with FedAvgM as a promising solution for robust, privacy-preserving EVCS security.

title: Proactive TSCA Detection via Real-Time Thermal Signature Modeling on Low-Power IoT Devices
authors: Amrou Zyad Benelhaouare, Michel Saydé, Idir Mellal, Maroua Oumlaz, Gabriela Nicolescu, Ahmed Lakhssassi
publish: 2025 IEEE Global Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things (GCAIoT)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce a real-time thermal signature modeling approach for embedded IoT systems as a proactive countermeasure against Thermal Side-Channel Attacks (TSCA). Rather than designing new sensing hardware, we exploit the ESP32-S3’s native on-die temperature sensor an 8 bit sigmadelta ADC with factory trimmed DAC that delivers $\simeq \mathbf{0. 2}{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{LSB}$ resolution and $\pm 5{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ absolute accuracy across its $-40{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $+125{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ range to capture core junction temperature directly. Using a three stepper motor control case study, we record the chip’s thermal evolution under four operational loads (idle, one, two, and three motor scenarios) and log the data in structured CSV files. These profiles form a comprehensive dataset of normal operation signatures, laying the groundwork for lightweight, ondevice anomaly detection and future deployment of machine learning-based digital twin models. Our results demonstrate how existing, low cost thermal sensors can be harnessed for thermal profiling, integrating core level signature awareness into resource constrained IoT devices without external components or high overhead methods.

title: Digital Industrial Solutions for Enhancing Student Motivation and Prepare Them for Industry 4.0
authors: Georgi Hristov, Diyana Kinaneva, Plamen Zahariev, Georgi Georgiev, Ivan Beloev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The contemporary digital industry is faced with the serious challenge of finding experts who can respond to dynamically evolving technologies, have multidisciplinary skills, and have the ability to adapt in a rapidly changing environment. This is a prerequisite for rethinking traditional learning approaches and implementing innovation, interactivity, and digitalization in modern learning methods. In this context, the paper explores the integration of digital industrial solutions into engineering curricula with the goal to increase student engagement and motivation and to prepare them for Industry 4.0 demands. The digitalization of industrial processes is a key moment for the successful development, optimization, and productivity of modern industry. This paper presents an interdisciplinary educational approach that integrates digital industrial solutions-such as robotic manufacturing, 3D modeling, and virtual process simulation-into the engineering curriculum to enhance student motivation and preparedness for Industry 4.0. The study discusses the implementation of this approach at the University of Ruse “Angel Kanchev,” highlighting its impact on student engagement, teamwork, and acquisition of Industry <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 0}$</tex> competencies. A case study based on the Shell Eco-marathon project demonstrates how collaborative learning and digital technologies foster practical skills, innovation, and deeper understanding of real-world industrial processes. The results suggest that the integration of digital industrial tools into education bridges the gap between theory and practice and motivates students to pursue engineering careers.
