title: Explaining Time Series Classification Predictions via Causal Attributions
authors: Juan Miguel Lopez Alcaraz, Nils Strodthoff
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Despite the excelling performance of machine learning models, understanding their decisions remains a long-standing goal. Although commonly used attribution methods from explainable AI attempt to address this issue, they typically rely on associational rather than causal relationships. In this study, within the context of time series classification, we introduce a novel model-agnostic attribution method to assess the causal effect of concepts i.e., predefined segments within a time series, on classification outcomes. Our approach compares these causal attributions with closely related associational attributions, both theoretically and empirically. To estimate counterfactual outcomes, we use state-of-the-art diffusion models backed by state space models. We demonstrate the insights gained by our approach for a diverse set of qualitatively different time series classification tasks. Although causal and associational attributions might often share some similarities, in all cases they differ in important details, underscoring the risks associated with drawing causal conclusions from associational data alone. We believe that the proposed approach is also widely applicable in other domains to shed some light on the limits of associational attributions.

title: Automated Bus Scheduling and Route Management
authors: Ritik Maurya, Zabiullah Khan, Jitesh Bharti, Jyoti Deone
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Instead of using ordinary CSV scheduling methods this research develops a structured MySQL database system to handle scheduling work. Every day the system finds best bus and crew placements by using genetic algorithms and follows important bus depot guidelines plus vehicle availability with peak hour trip patterns. Through dynamic procedures the system both assigns buses and crew while tracking available buses along with adjusting bus frequencies during operation. By using artificial intelligence methods, the system achieves optimal resource utilization because it finds all cases where several job assignments lead to unnecessary duplicate work. The scheduling system makes work plans that give employees equal work opportunities while following depot requirements. The schedule needs to keep driver shifts under 12 hours with resting breaks every 40 minutes plus restricts both driver and crew to only 8-hour time periods according to our regular schedule rules. The scheduling system uses route and frequency requirements to design schedules that change as needed when things change. Google Map API is also integrated with the system to assist drivers in planning of journeys.

title: Towards High-Performance Quantum-Based LEDs: Optoelectronic Modulation of 2D Silicon Carbide for Tunable and Efficient White Light Emission
authors: Md. Mahfuzul Haque, Sajid Muhaimin Choudhury
abstract: Two-dimensional silicon carbide (2D SiC) has attracted considerable interest in lighting technologies owing to its remarkable stability, elevated exciton binding energy, and broad bandgap. This work investigates the impacts of biaxial strain, point defects, and point doping in modifying the optoelectronic characteristics of 2D SiC for high-performance lighting applications. We examine the modification of the band structure of 2D SiC using first-principles calculations by adding point doping, point defects, and biaxial strain engineering, which facilitates bandgap tuning, allows for spectrum tunability, and improves light emission efficiency. Our findings indicate that biaxial strain engineering, point doping, and point defects may markedly enhance the electrical, and optical characteristics of the 2D SiC, providing a novel approach for the development of highperformance, energy-efficient lighting systems. Through point doping in 2D SiC, the material used in the active layer of our proposed single quantum-based LED, we exhibit substantial improvements in light emission efficiency and spectrum tunability, which facilitates the emission of red, green, and blue wavelengths from the LED. Moreover, by the integration of these wavelengths, we proposed the production of single quantum-based white light LEDs. The development of tunable LEDs with high efficiency over the visible spectrum is essential for display technologies and advanced lighting solutions. Our research indicates that 2D SiC provides advanced lighting technology, such as environmentally friendly photonic systems, flexible displays, and efficient LEDs. This study promotes novel ideas in lighting systems, merging enhanced performance with decreased energy use.

title: Software managed 5G service centric for Time-Sensitive Networking
authors: Jose Costa-Requena, Nguyen Ngoc
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: G networks architecture can be distributed to support services with different requirements such as Best Effort consumer data or Time Sensitive Networks (TSN). 6G is proposed for industrial environments where reliability and low latency processing are required for factory automation. This paper presents the design and implementation of TSN controller and interaction with $\mathbf{5 G}$ network to support TSN. First performance results of the controller delivering reliable deterministic communications across wired and wireless networks are included. The paper also presents a prototype of TSN capable 5 G network with the network functions i.e. network TSN translator (NW-TT) and DS-TT to provide time synchronization for TSN mobile devices over the 5G network. A first set of measurements showing the accuracy for time synchronization over 5 G network are presented.

title: Data-driven real-time assessment of the hosting capacity for distribution networks under large-scale electric vehicle penetration
authors: Hongyu Long, Yang Xu, Xm Chen, Xiaorui Hu, Shun Li, Yi Long
abstract: The growing integration of electric vehicles (EVs) into urban distribution networks has introduced challenges such as voltage quality degradation and insufficient line transmission capacity due to increased charging loads. The current assessment of the hosting capacity of distribution networks is usually based on probabilistic power flow calculations. Due to the large amount of computation, it is difficult to effectively guarantee real-time performance in practical applications. This paper proposes a data-driven and full-process application method for rapidly assessing EV hosting capacity of distribution networks under large-scale EV penetration. A fully connected neural network model is developed to rapidly forecast short-term charging loads, capturing the spatiotemporal two-dimensional uncertainty of EV behavior. This model is combined with data-driven power flow calculations and a comprehensive evaluation framework to construct an efficient hosting capacity assessment tool. A case study on the IEEE 69-node system demonstrates that the proposed data-driven model achieves high accuracy with an average prediction error after inverse normalization of below 0.5. Furthermore, it significantly reduces computation time to 7.02 seconds for 1000 samples, while the traditional evaluation methods based on probabilistic power flow calculation take 135.46 seconds. This approach provides effective operational insights for distribution network operators, enabling real-time and accurate EV hosting capacity assessment of distribution networks.

title: An Improved Module of Bidirectional Feature Pyramid Network Based on YOLOv11 for Underwater Object Detection
authors: Ziyi Yuan, Shujia Yan, Chunyu Yao, Chenggang Dai, Mei Song Tong, Fei Wu
abstract: In underwater target detection tasks, YOLOv3 and YOLOv5 suffer from inadequate multi-scale feature fusion and background suppression. This paper proposes the YOLOv11-BiFPN model, integrating a bidirectional feature pyramid network and employing data augmentation techniques like color correction and noise suppression to further enhance generalization capabilities. Experimental results show that YOLOv11-BiFPN achieves mAP of 86.6 % and 80.9 % on the ROUD and URPC2020 data-sets respectively, outperforming YOLOv11 and other versions, especially excelling in small targets and complex backgrounds with superior accuracy and efficiency.

title: Teaching Thinking in the Course Mathematics for Computer Science
authors: Katarína Bachratá, Hynek Bachratý
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: In this article, we present our approach to teaching mathematics at the bachelor’s level of study in Computer science programs. The content and form of teaching are inspired by the method of genetic constructivism, which is known at lower levels of schools as "Teaching oriented to building schemes" or also the "Hejny’s method". The fundamental emphasis in teaching is based on the work of students and on changing attitudes towards mathematics as a supportive and useful course for computer science. In addition to teaching methods and experiences with them, the article also includes examples of tasks that students solve, and we document how problem-solving connects both subjects. A significant task today is the use of technology for the development of broader understanding of logical thinking of students, but also to cope with the impact and interference caused by artificial intelligence in teaching.

title: Mechanical Strain Monitoring Using Filter-Based Fiber Bragg Grating Interrogator
authors: Andis Supe, Ugis Senkans, Deniss Zurikovs, Nauris Silkans, Janis Braunfelds
abstract: Optical fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors have attracted huge industry interest due to their high sensitivity, small size, and immunity to electromagnetic interference. Additionally, these sensors can withstand high temperatures and are suitable for integration into different constructions and materials. FBG manufacturing costs have also been reduced significantly. However, the relatively high costs of FBG sensor interrogator units have an impact on the applicability of these sensors. In this research, we propose a relatively simple, experimental optical filter-based FBG interrogator. The key components are microcontroller and optical transceiver. We test the impact of optical transceiver's sensitivity on mechanical strain measurements with two different range transceivers. Industry-standard spectrometer-type FBG interrogator is used as a reference. Results show that higher receiver sensitivity increases the measurement range and reduces noisiness. However, even a short-range optical transceiver has the potential for continuous monitoring applications.

title: Design and numerical modelling of a pivoting tensioned offshore wave energy converter with a mechanical motion rectifier (MMR)
authors: Domenico P. Coiro, Giancarlo Troise
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: A novel wave energy conversion (WEC) system is presented in this work, which continues the main objective of a previous study. The proposed configuration comprises two floating bodies linked through a pivoting hinge: the active body, named buoy, oscillates under the action of the incoming waves and transfer the wave induced oscillations to a PTO (Power take-off) device through the hinge axis. The PTO device is installed on a different floating body, named platform, which is intend to be as stable as possible and is linked to the seabed through a tension leg mooring system. The PTO system is equipped with a mechanical motion rectifier (MMR), aimed to transform the alternating rotational motion induced by the waves into a one-way rotational motion suitable to actuate a standard rotation electric generator. This article presents a description of the model developed to simulate the PTO system behavior, presenting some results related to the search of the optimal values of the main PTO device parameters. The developed model will also be used in a planned test campaign on a dry test bench for the emulation of the PTO response, with the aim to validate the numerical model itself and to fine tune system parameters.

title: AI-Powered Accessible 3D Tactile Graphics Generation System with Voice Interaction
authors: Bor-Jiunn Hwang, Yi-Wen Wu, Chiao-Wen Kao, Hui-Hui Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: This study develops an automated system to produce tactile graphics for individuals with low vision, addressing Braille's limitations in conveying shapes, spatial relationships, and artistic composition. This project not only aims to enhance spatial cognition but also to unlock new avenues for aesthetic and art education. The system is an operational assistive platform that integrates image description, voice-based human-computer interaction, and 3D tactile model generation. It transforms personal photographs and digital art into printable tactile models through a unique, voice-guided, end-to-end workflow, thereby enhancing user autonomy and enabling creative expression. User feedback strongly endorses the system's core features, including its intuitive voice interaction, quality audio descriptions, and flexible multilingual interface. Surveys further confirm its superior performance in tactile design, specifically regarding line thickness, comfort, and size. Beyond its functional benefits, initial findings suggest the system successfully facilitates the tactile appreciation of visual art, allowing users to perceive composition, texture, and form in a new way. Future work will refine model-generation algorithms to better preserve artistic detail and broaden application scenarios to more comprehensively support aesthetic and art education for people with visual impairments.

title: Impact of AlGaN Superlattices on the Thermal Stability of Al-Rich AlGaN Channel HEMTs_supp1-3640586.pdf
authors: Okhyun Nam
abstract: This work presents a comprehensive study on the temperature-dependent and high-field electrical performance of Al ${}_{{0}.{60}}$ Ga ${}_{{0}.{40}}$ N channel high-electron-mobility transistors (HEMTs) incorporating AlN/Al ${}_{{0}.{70}}$ Ga ${}_{{0}.{30}}$ N superlattices (SLs) with total thicknesses of 150 and 300 nm, grown on AlN/4H–SiC substrates with an Al ${}_{{0}.{95}}$ Ga ${}_{\text {0. 0. 05}}$ N barrier. The SLs are engineered to modulate strain relaxation and reduce dislocation density in the AlGaN channel. Devices were characterized between $25~^{\circ }$ C and $200~^{\circ }$ C using capacitance–voltage (CV) and dc measurements to analyze interface trap dynamics, threshold-voltage stability, and thermal reliability. The SLs-150 nm device exhibits superior thermal and electrical stability, with minimal CV hysteresis and negligible threshold-voltage shift ( $\Delta \textit{V}_{\text {th}} \approx ~0.1$ V) up to $200~^{\circ }$ C, achieving the lowest on-resistance ( $\sim 650~\Omega \cdot $ mm) and sharpest subthreshold swing (SS) (~225 mV/dec). The off-state breakdown measurements show that the SLs-300 nm device sustains electric fields exceeding 2.6 kV at ${L}_{\text {gd}} =25$ $\mu $ m—among the highest reported for Al-rich AlGaN-channel HEMTs without field plates and passivation. These results demonstrate that optimized SLs engineering simultaneously enhances thermal stability and breakdown strength, highlighting Al-rich AlGaN-channel HEMTs as promising candidates for next-generation power and RF electronics in extreme environments.

title: An MLS-AK-MCS Framework for Reliability-Based Design Optimization of Rolling Contact Connector
authors: Nianhuan Li, Haihong Wu, Junye Li, Zili Liu, Jianhe Liu, Xin Du
abstract: Rolling contact connector (RCC) is widely used in aerospace and industrial fields, with reliability analysis and optimization being critical for their structural design. This study proposes a reliability analysis and optimization framework for RCC utilizing a multi-level sparse adaptive Monte Carlo simulation (MLS-AK-MCS) combined with Kriging models. The approach enhances computational efficiency and accurately identifies high-risk regions by applying a global Kriging model for overall trend description and local models for detailed risk analysis. The method reduces unnecessary conservatism and optimizes the structural design of RCC, ensuring optimal performance while maintaining reliability. An application of this framework to a flexible ring design, under a failure probability threshold of $\boldsymbol{\eta } = \mathbf{0}{\bf .03}$, demonstrated a maximum compressive stress of 202 MPa and a contact resistance of 40.54 μΩ, with negligible deviations from theoretical predictions (0.26 MPa and 1.30 μΩ). The MLS-AK-MCS method not only improves reliability assessments but also optimizes material usage and performance margins, laying the groundwork for next-generation structural designs. While the current study focuses on the RCC case, the proposed framework is extendable to other structural reliability problems with similar modeling challenges.

title: Intelligent Accident Detection and Prevention with Geofencing Alerts
authors: Aarti S. Pawar, Suvarna P. Kadam, Vivek Bhand, Rohit Baviskar, Sanket Bhere
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: In today's rapidly growing world of electric vehicles, people riding in them are more prone to fatalities due to delayed emergency response, and they are also misused, especially in remote areas. Current systems handle alcohol detection, accident alerts, and geofencing separately. This instance shows how important it is to have a combined solution. The proposed research paper presents an integrated safety system that combines real-time accident detection, alcoholbased ignition control, and geofencing features to bridge this gap. An MQ3 alcohol sensor in the developed prototype can identify alcohol in the driver's breath: the SW420 crash sensor and ADXL345 accelerometer work in tandem to detect collisions. The ESP32 microcontroller is used to process the sensor data. The Neo-7M Global Positioning System (GPS) module is used for location tracking, while the SIM900A Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) contacts a predefined emergency contact in any emergency case. The Neo-7M GPS module logs vehicle data onto an SD card. Most of the current methods in this area only deal with alcohol detection or accident detection. The proposed system combines several safety features into a single platform, which solves several problems related to road safety.

title: Two-Time Scale Based Sliding Mode Controller for Active Suspension Systems to Improve Ride Comfort
authors: Patil M B, Kokate R D, Shendge P D
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Two-time scale (TTS) based on sliding mode control (SMC) strategy is reported to improvise the ride comfort for active suspension system (ASS). By improving the sprung mass's acceleration, the suggested approach enhanced ride comfort as compared to conventional SMC. The rattle space limiting condition is considered in the proposed article. The control law is derived for the quarter car model. The proposed TTSSMC method estimates the effects of spring and damper coefficients which are uncertain and nonlinear along with load variation and unknown road disturbances. In this research, the controller uses only the states of sprung mass rather than the states of sprung as well as unsprung mass. This reduces the need for measurement of unsprung mass states. The controller stability is proved with the Lyapunov candidate function. The proposed method is validated on three different types of road surfaces.

title: A Study on a Wireless Power Transmission Method for Downhole Sensors in Oilfields
authors: Yang Qiu, Haoran Li, Yuyu Zhu, Huanfa Yi, Qianjiang Zhang
abstract: This paper proposes a method for wireless power transfer in oilfield downhole environments, capable of penetrating oil pipes, using magnetic resonance coupling-based wireless power transfer technology. Due to the confined space limitations and the skin effect of electromagnetic waves in downhole environments, the system employs extremely low-frequency electromagnetic waves for power transmission, allowing sensors outside the metal pipe to receive energy more effectively. The system is divided into two parts: the power transmission section inside the pipe and the power reception section outside the pipe. The transmission section mainly consists of a full-bridge inverter, a compensation network, and a Transmitting coil, while the reception section includes a Receiving coil, a compensation network, a rectifier and filter circuit, and a load. At extremely low frequencies, electromagnetic waves can effectively penetrate the metal pipe walls, and the equivalent series resistance of the coils is significantly reduced, which enhances system power output. The system uses a large number of compensation capacitors for parameter matching to address the issue of insufficient inductance in the resonant network. This enables the system to operate in a resonant state, thereby improving energy transfer efficiency, increasing transmission distance, and reducing the power demand on the transmission side. Test results show that when the system connects a 10Ω load (simulating a sensor load) on the reception side outside the pipe, provides a 48 V DC input to the transmission side inside the pipe, and generates an electromagnetic field using a Transmitting coil at an extremely low frequency of 25 Hz from the inverter's output AC voltage, the voltage across the load is approximately 4 V. This corresponds to a power output of about 1.6 W, which is sufficient to meet the operational requirements of sensors.

title: Optimization of Graphical User Interface Rendering on Microcontrollers
authors: Matúš Nečas, Juraj Duďák, Dominik Čambál
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper addresses the optimization of the rendering of the graphical user interface on microprocessors, which typically have limited computational and memory resources. In this paper, a two-stage optimization technique is presented to reduce computational complexity and memory complexity in the processing of graphical data. The first step, Init-Update Time Optimization, splits graphical components into static (rendered only at screen initialization) and dynamic (periodically updated), minimizing repeated rendering. The second step, Low-Color Buffered Sprites Memory Optimization, uses a local memory buffer for the dynamic portions of the screen in which all rendering operations, including erasing, are performed. The resulting image is transferred to the display all at once, eliminating flickering and increasing frame rate. The method also recommends reducing the color bit depth for buffering sprites to further save memory. As a result, the rendering efficiency of the graphical user interface is significantly improved in a microprocessor environment, which is particularly suitable for simpler and moderately complex applications with limited resources.

title: Advancing Contextual Understanding: Evaluating Polysemy Detection in Modern Natural Language Processing
authors: Neha Nair, Mukta Joshi, Ramakrishna M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Understanding the nuances of language is fundamental to natural language processing (NLP) applications. The challenge of polysemy- where a single word can carry multiple meanings depending on the context, continues to hinder progress in areas such as machine translation, sentiment analysis and questionanswering. Despite it being a necessity to gain further advancement in these applications, minimal research has been conducted on how different models approach this problem. Finding the best fit for the polysemy involves taking into account the computational and practical qualifications of the models as well. In this paper, we implemented five models –BERT, RoBERTa, AutoSense, Sense2Vec and ELMo to gauge their performance and determine the best-suited model. Our results demonstrate that context-aware models like BERT and RoBERTa outperform static-embedding-based models like AutoSense and Sense2Vec. This research not only fills a critical void in the literature but also sets the stage for future innovations in semantic understanding, making polysemy detection a central focus for advancing NLP.

title: A Machine Learning-Based Framework for Optimizing Emission Factors in Supply Chain Management within Management Information Systems
authors: Urmi Haldar, Md Mohibur Rahman, Md Alamgir Miah, Mukther Uddin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: As a component of a Management Information Systems (MIS), the current study proposes a machine learning-based solution for supply chain management emission factor optimization. Using advanced regression and clustering algorithms, the framework would be able to anticipate and categorize greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, allowing firms to decrease their environmental impact and enhance operational performance. With an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.914307 and a low Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.145762, Random Forest Regression, in particular, beat Linear Regression in terms of accuracy when used to predict emission components. Industries were categorized according to their emission patterns using the K-Means and DBSCAN clustering algorithms; DBSCAN performed better (Silhouette Score = 0.857191). By incorporating these models into the MIS, supply chain emissions may be optimized via data-driven, real-time decision-making. Although these findings are impressive, incorporating feature engineering and other clustering approaches could further enhance the framework. The approach holds a great deal of promise for future advancements in the fields of multi-objective optimization and real-time data analysis because it sets the groundwork for a long-term, data-based solution to the global emissions challenge.

title: Study, analysis and comparison of power inverters
authors: F. D. Trujillo-Aguilera, E. B. Blázquez-Parra, M. Torres-Fernández
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Today, electricity is used in two different ways: using direct current or alternating current. On the one hand, Direct Current, DC, is the type of electrical energy in which the voltage remains constant. This electrical voltage or potential difference is the work per unit charge that an electric field needs to exert to move a charged particle between two points. Whereas, on the other hand, Alternating Current, AC, as its name indicates, the charges will not move from point A to point B, but will oscillate from one to another, causing the potential difference to vary. Normally, the alternating current used is the sinusoidal form as it is the most optimized, as is the case for most of the electricity transport in the electrical network. In this article, the transformation from DC to AC is studied by means of one of the most useful devices in the field of Power Electronics, the inverter. Nowadays, these devices are constantly used both on a small and large scale. Some of the most useful applications will be presented together with the different types of inverters that have been designed. Through a theoretical study and simulations, the different inverters will be analyzed and a series of efficiency/complexity conclusions will be drawn.

title: Adaptive Fuzzy Prescribed-Time Tracking Control for Underactuated Surface Vessels
authors: Dehao Kong, Song Gao, Bingbing Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: This paper investigates the adaptive fuzzy prescribed-time tracking control problem for underactuated surface vessels in the presence of external disturbances. To address the underactuation issue of the original system, a coordinate transformation is employed. An adaptive law is utilized to estimate the upper bound of unknown complex disturbances. Subsequently, a prescribed-time tracking control scheme is designed, ensuring that the tracking errors converge to the predetermined precision within the predefined settling time. Rigorous theoretical analysis confirms that all signals in the closed-loop system remain bounded. Compared to existing research, the proposed control scheme achieves faster convergence speed and better tracking accuracy. The validity of the designed control strategy is verified through simulation studies.

title: A Hybrid Model For Integrated Soil Sensor Location Allocation Optimization In Agriculture
authors: Egas José Armando, Damien Hanyurwimfura, Omar Gatera, Athanase Nduwumuremyi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Optimizing soil sensor deployment is essential for precision agriculture, especially in resource-limited settings. This paper introduces a hybrid framework that combines geostatistical analysis with a Genetic Algorithm (GA) for optimizing the allocation of integrated soil sensors in terms of number and location. To this end, a wireless sensor node (WSN) was developed and deployed at 144 points for data collection. The WSN comprised a seven-in-one sensor that measured soil temperature, moisture, electrical conductivity (EC), pH, nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). The data were collected in a regular grid of $25 \times 25 \mathrm{~m}$, covering a total area of $350 \times 200 \mathrm{~m}, 7$ ha of cassava field. For data analysis, ordinary kriging was used to model the spatial variability, and GA for sensor placement optimization. Variogram analysis revealed strong spatial dependence for most parameters, with nugget-to-sill ratios of less than $25 \%$ and coverage radius extending up to 139 m. Leave-oneout cross-validation yielded RMSE values ranging from 0.13 to 70.03 and $\mathrm{R}^{2}$ values of up to 0.66. Moran’s I analysis ($\mathrm{p} \lt 0.05$) confirmed significant spatial autocorrelation. The optimization indicated that 3 to 5 strategically placed sensors could effectively monitor the field, with each sensor covering approximately 2.3 hectares of the field. The proposed method provides a scalable, data-driven approach for efficient soil monitoring and precision agriculture using IoT.

title: Design of W-Band Sub-Gigawatt Power Level Relativistic Gyrotron for High-Gradient Accelerator Applications
authors: V. Yu. Zaslavsky, N. Yu. Peskov, K. A. Leshcheva, V. N. Manuilov, A. V. Arzhannikov, D. A. Nikiforov, A. E. Levichev, S. L. Sinitsky
abstract: Project of W-band sub-gigawatt power level relativistic gyrotron for high-gradient accelerator applications has been proposed. The gyrotron is driven by a large diameter of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 10 \text{mm}$</tex> polyhelical electron beam with a high-current of 1 kA at an electron energy of 800 keV and a pitch-factor of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1$</tex>. To form such a beam, a non-adiabatic electron-optical system has been developed. The necessity oscillation velocity of the magnetically-guided relativistic electron beam is achieved as result of initial pumping this velocity by an electric field at a cathode lens-diaphragm and then by usage of the adiabatic increase in the induction of the guide magnetic field. Studies of the gyrotron operating at a fundamental cyclotron harmonic for the case of a magnetic field of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 9 \mathrm{T}$</tex> have been conducted. PIC simulations show the possibility of achieving output power of more than 100 MW at a frequency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 100 \text{GHz}$</tex>.

title: Real-Time Hand Gesture Recognition Using CNN-LSTM for Gesture-to-Voice and Device Control
authors: Mukta Jamage, Sanskruti Rane, Janhavi Raktate, Nisha Chavan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Recognition of hand gestures is an essential HCI technology that enables touch-free, intuitive communication with digital systems. Its applications cross several domains, such as accessibility, virtual reality, automotive systems, and smart environments. New developments utilize computer vision-based deep learning methods, sensor-based techniques, and hybrid methods to improve accuracy. It has applications in sign language translation and gesture-controlled systems in healthcare and automation. Despite the improvements, environmental sensitivity, gesture complexity, and computational complexity remain. Complex AI-ML models such as CNNs, RNNs, 3D CNNs, and transformer models are still working on gesture recognition to make it practical for everyday use. The paper, suggest an ML-based framework for hand gesture detection and its conversion to voice data. The suggested framework is based on the Kaggle dataset ‘Hand Gesture Recognition,’ which includes about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> images.

title: Argubuddy - Personalized AI Debater
authors: Mrinmayee Deshpande, Dipali Gangarde, Aniket Dhage, Anuradha Yenkikar, Pranjal Pandit, Suprabha D Kulkarni
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Common AI-driven debate platforms tend to miss out on essential characteristics like personalization, contextual awareness, and real-time applicability. These omissions, in turn, impede their capacity to properly assist users-particularly competitive examination aspirants and job seekers-to enhance their reasoning, articulation, and counterarguments skills. This paper presents a Context-Aware Personalized AI Debater to tackle these problems by employing Natural Language Processing (NLP), Generative AI, and live knowledge retrieval. The system monitors users' history, debate trends, and individual preferences to come up with custom arguments and counterarguments. Web scraping is utilized to make the content fact-oriented and current. Complementing both text and voice interaction, the debater learns to fit individual users, increasing engagement and making debates more interactive. A feedback loop offers personalized feedback on strengths and weaknesses, and debate transcripts can be downloaded for review. This work shows the feasibility of using AI to develop intelligent, adaptive learning tools. The system presented is efficient in educational, professional, and policy-oriented environments. Future developments consist of multimodal support, state-of-the-art speech recognition, and collaborative debate schemes.

title: Implementing AI techniques for efficient searching in document databases
authors: Sylvia Maťašová, Martin Chovanec, Eva Chovancová, Dušan Čatloch
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This article details the design and implementation of a system for efficient PDF document search and management. It was built using modern technologies like Django, React, PostgreSQL, and Qdrant. The primary goal was to create a powerful tool. This tool uses vector search and embedding technology with the BGE-M3 model. Users can upload and search documents with key phrases, getting relevant results. The article covers the AI techniques used, the system's architecture, implementation, and the final results. We show that integrating vector search with the right model is essential. This integration helps achieve high accuracy and efficiency when working with large document databases.

title: Model-Driven Development as a Theory–Practice Bridge in Theoretical Computer Science Education
authors: Samuel Novotný, Monika Kohútová, William Steingartner, Ján Perháč
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper investigates the integration of the Model-Driven Software Development approach into the teaching of theoretical computer science courses. The aim is to emphasize the practical applicability of theoretical concepts and to bridge the well-known theory–practice gap. The proposed integration was also tested in the Formal Languages course, specifically in lab sessions where students applied the Model-Driven approach to solve practical tasks related to theoretical concepts. The results of this work provide recommendations for integrating a Model-Driven approach into teaching and for effectively connecting theoretical knowledge with practical applications.

title: Acoustic Leaky-Wave Antenna Based on Phononic Crystals
authors: Keqiang Lyu, Ying Wu
abstract: Acoustic leaky wave antennas (ALWAs) are passive, dispersive waveguides capable of achieving frequency-dependent directional radiation scanning. Traditional ALWAs rely on periodic side tubes and elastic membranes in waveguides, but they commonly encounter challenges such as complex assembly, difficulties in membrane tension control, low efficiency, significant side lobe radiation. In this work, we propose a design of ALWA incorporating a phononic crystal featuring double-zero refractive index, which is resulted from the accidental degeneracy of monopole and dipole modes near Brillouin zone center. The antenna possesses a constant leakage factor for length-independent radiation and matches the Bloch impedance of air. With proper aperture geometry design, the leaky mode of the antenna unit achieves finite and comparable quality factors, resulting in a leaky wave antenna with up to 95% radiation efficiency and high directivity. Moreover, an acoustic source replaces port excitation to enable the symmetric and asymmetric control of dualbeam radiation. At the same time, this ALWA can be extended into 2D space. The proposed antenna structure has promising applications in acoustic navigation and imaging requiring low-power operation, as well as in high-precision acoustic source localization.

title: Predicting Anthropometric Dimensions Using Machine Learning for Biomedical Anthropometric Wearable Devices
authors: Duraiarasu E, Madhav Rao, Ananthanarayanan B, Aswin S, Akash B, Abilash R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: Precise anthropometric data are essential for designing personalized biomedical wearable devices. Conventional methods rely on manual measurements or image-based computer vision, both requiring extensive reference data and computational resources. We propose a novel approach using structured biological inputs and machine learning to predict key anthropometric dimensions without image data. Various models, including Decision Tree, SVR, Random Forest, XGBoost, KNN, MLP, TabNet, and CatBoost, were benchmarked, with CatBoost achieving superior accuracy and generalizability. Our model utilizes common inputs such as gender, weight, height, and BMI to predict knee and leg measurements efficiently, reducing computational overhead and enabling scalable, contactless design of wearable systems.

title: Modeling Light-Tissue Interactions in Finger Phantom Using Near Infrared and Mid Infrared Spectroscopy Based on Non-Invasive Glucose Monitoring
authors: Sai Kalyan Rebba Yagna, L. Meenu, S. Aiswarya, Vinodini Ramesh Maneesha
abstract: As the diabetes mellitus is increasing day by day, a replacement for the conventional standard painful finger pricking technique is necessary. One of the main challenges for the accurate and precise non-invasive glucose monitoring is modeling the propagation effects when waves interact with the human tissues. As per literature, the infrared signals have the capability to detect glucose molecules more effectively than other signals in the electromagnetic spectrum. In this work, a phantom of the finger is created in ‘COMSOL — Multiphysics Simulator’ and the light tissue interactions in different spectroscopic ranges like near infrared (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$700-2500 \text{nm}$</tex>) and mid infrared (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2500-25,000 \text{nm}$</tex>) are analyzed. The modeling of the finger is carried out by defining the different layers of finger which are stratum corneum, epidermis, papillary dermis, upper blood net dermis, reticular dermis, deep blood net dermis, fat, muscle and bone. The material properties like thickness, absorption coefficient, scattering coefficient and refractive index for each layer are analyzed separately. In both the mid-infrared and near-infrared ranges, the most glucose absorption was obviously noted in the upper blood net dermis. The second highest glucose absorption was observed in the deep blood net dermis followed by the papillary dermis. Interestingly, the stratum corneum had the largest scattering in the near-infrared and mid-infrared spectral ranges, followed by the papillary dermis. After completing the single layer analysis, the finger phantom as a whole, combining all the individual layers are analyzed. The results of absorption spectra and reflection spectra for both near infrared and mid infrared for the finger phantom are reported. Based on the modeling and results, it can be inferred that mid-infrared may exhibit the highest absorption.

title: Next-Generation Programmable Holographic Metasurface Antenna
authors: Abdul Jabbar, Mostafa Elsayed, Masood Ur-Rehman, Muhammad Ali Imran, Hadi Larijani, Qammer Abbasi, Muhammad Usman
abstract: Dynamic metasurface antennas and holographic surfaces have opened new frontiers in fields of next generation reconfigurable wireless communications, meta-sensing, computational imaging, and computational optics. A critical component of these advanced systems lies in the engineering of meta-elements that efficiently manipulate electromagnetic waves. This paper presents the design of a complementary electric inductive-capacitive (CELC) meta-element based aperture to address limitations in traditional metasurfaces and phased array antennas, which often suffer from restricted phase modulation, significant power consumption, and limited control over beam steering and beam synthesis. Our design leverages an innovative integration of CELC meta-elements, optimizing the tunability and dynamic response of the metasurface antenna. The CELC meta-element can be readily integrated with either a PIN diode (for digital beamforming) or a varactor diode (for continuous beam tuning). Consequently, we demonstrate a metasurface capable of dynamic wavefront control, with both spatially and temporally tunable capabilities. This architecture outperforms traditional setups in terms of power consumption and response time, enabling agile beam steering, beam synthesis, and adaptive holography with minimal power requirements. Furthermore, we validated the CELC meta-element through both full-wave simulations and mmWave experimental setups, illustrating its effectiveness in achieving desired phase profiles and amplitude modulations for fixed-frequency beam steering at 60 GHz, as well as multibeam generation from a single aperture through a software-controlled paradigm. The design is scalable in frequency and can be utilized at lower frequency as well as for optical holograms at high frequency bands following similar design methodology. The proposed CELC meta-element marks a substantial advancement for dynamic metasurfaces, particularly for applications in next-generation metasurface antennas and reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) enabled software wireless paradigm. This work provides a practical pathway to high-performance, energy-efficient solutions in next-generation wireless communication, sensing and imaging, advancing the scope and impact of dynamic metasurface technology for rapidly evolving high-frequency 6G wireless applications.

title: Automating Software Test Case Generation with Pre-trained Large Language Models
authors: Moughit Imane, Hafidi Imad, Mouhassine Najib
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: the rise of Large Language Models (LLMs) has significantly impacted software engineering based on their capability to comprehend and create natural language. Traditional test-case automation techniques, whether they depend only on textual descriptions or exclusively on focal methods often fail to express expected behavior, capture edge conditions, and expose faults. Such limitations make them illsuited for Test-Driven Development (TDD). To overcome these challenges, we present an approach that combines text and methods for test case generation. Using prompt engineering techniques, we evaluate two LLMs: Meta-LLaMA-3-8B (base) and Mistral-7B-Instruct on a dataset of $\mathbf{1 3 6, 0 6 0}$ entries, resulting in the generation of 7,606- unit test cases from opensource projects to assess whether instruction tuning or an increase in parameter count has a greater impact on test case generation quality. Results show that instruction tuning outperforms a larger base model, especially in zero-shot settings, while few-shot prompting reduces syntax errors by $\boldsymbol{\sim} \mathbf{9 0 \%}$ for both.

title: Use of Augmented Reality Concept for UAV Simulation
authors: Ján Vaščák, Patrik Mikčo, Peter Papcun, Ľubomír Urblík, Iveta Zolotová
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Augmented reality (AR) is one of the innovative technologies in the field of human-machine interaction, combining the physical world with virtual elements. Unlike virtual reality, which is completely separated from the physical world, AR provides full depiction and interaction of physical and virtual objects, allowing the user to maintain full contact with the physical world, which is a very important element in applications requiring operational safety. One such application is a UAV or drone simulator for operators, who can safely learn to control UAVs. This paper analyses selected software development platforms with AR support. Based on this analysis, the platform Unity was selected for the design of a UAV simulator, which was tested and the results of the experiments were used to set its parameters. The experiments also confirmed the benefits of this approach for the effective training of UAV operators.

title: Federated Learning for Large-Scale Cloud Robotic Manipulation: Opportunities and Challenges
authors: Obaidullah Zaland, Chanh Nguyen, Florian T. Pokorny, Monowar Bhuyan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is an emerging distributed machine learning paradigm, where the collaborative training of a model involves dynamic participation of devices to achieve broad objectives. In contrast, classical machine learning (ML) typically requires data to be located on-premises for training, whereas FL leverages numerous user devices to train a shared global model without the need to share private data. Current robotic manipulation tasks are constrained by the individual capabilities and speed of robots due to limited low-latency computing resources. Consequently, the concept of cloud robotics has emerged, allowing robotic applications to harness the flexibility and reliability of computing resources, effectively alleviating their computational demands across the cloud-edge continuum. Undoubtedly, within this distributed computing context, as exemplified in cloud robotic manipulation scenarios, FL offers manifold advantages while also presenting several challenges and opportunities. In this paper, we present fundamental concepts of FL and their connection to cloud robotic manipulation. Additionally, we envision the opportunities and challenges associated with realizing efficient and reliable cloud robotic manipulation at scale through FL, where researchers adapt to design and verify FL models in either centralized or decentralized settings.

title: Label-Free Imaging of Cancer Cells - Laden 3D Hydrogel Scaffold Using Spectral Domain Optical Coherence Tomography
authors: P. John, G. Janarthanan, S. Alexander, S. Vijayavenkataraman, A. Zam
abstract: This study explores the capability of investigating the surgical margins between healthy and cancerous regions in cancer cells-laden 3D hydrogel scaffold using a non-invasive, highresolution, label-free, spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) system. The SDOCT system (GAN611C1, Ganymede, Thorlabs) utilizes a superluminescent light emitting diode (SLED) source of center wavelength 930 nm, full-width at half maximum (FWHM) of 102 nm, axial resolution of 3.8 µm (in tissue), lateral resolution of 8 µm (obtained using the objective lens, LSM03 BB, Thorlabs Inc., NJ, with a working distance of 25 mm), operating at a speed of 248,000 A-scans/s. The maximum imaging depth of this system is ~ 2.2 mm in tissue. The primary cancer cells tend to metastasize and invade other parts of the tissues, vasculature, and organs from their region of origin. This leads to the formation of new metastatic tumors, resulting in the increased mortality rates of people suffering from cancer. Breast cancer is one of the most prevalent types of cancer, having the highest incidence and mortality rates in females. MDA-MB-231 cell lines used in this study are highly invasive breast cancer cells. The potential of different hydrogel bioinks, such as gelatin methacrylate (GelMA) and carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), was analyzed by optical characterization. To overcome the confounding scattering effects of photo-initiators present in GelMA, CMC-based biocompatible hydrogels were prepared using the acyl-hydrazone reaction without the need for photo-initiators, toxic chemical crosslinkers or UV light. MDA-MB-231 cells were cultured and embedded in 3D CMC-based hydrogel scaffolds in this study. A mold was fabricated using a fused deposition modeling (FDM) 3D printer. To construct the 3D hydrogel scaffolds, a fused deposition modeling (FDM) 3D printer was used to fabricate a mold with a ~ 5 mm diameter slot, enabling better insertion and removal of the hydrogel. The mold was filled with 10 µl of MDA-MB231 cells suspended in an oxidized CMC and CMC di-hydrazide solutions, which then crosslinked to form the hydrogel. The developed 3D hydrogel sample was imaged using the SD-OCT system before and after the excision of the cell-laden hydrogel with a clear delineation. This approach not only has the potential for high-resolution label-free structural and volumetric imaging but can be further extended towards the dynamic analysis of cancer cells embedded in 3D hydrogels to formulate the optical and mechanical relationship based on the activity of the cancer cells in various bio-inks of different tunable stiffnesses to study the disease progression.

title: Enhancing the OpenAPI Ontology with Asynchronous Service Interaction Descriptions
authors: Emmanouil-Georgios Ieronymakis, Chrisa Tsinaraki, Nikolaos Mainas, Euripides G.M. Petrakis
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: This work advances existing research on converting OpenAPI descriptions into ontology-based semantic descriptions by implementing an improved ontology and translation method. This updated approach efficiently maps complex Schema objects and newly introduced asynchronous features proposed in the most recent OpenAPI version like Webhooks and Callbacks. The ontology has been evaluated through a dual assessment approach: a qualitative analysis ensuring structural and semantic integrity, and a quantitative test validating real-time efficiency in ontology mapping and query searches on a triple-store repository of approximately 10,000 OpenAPI descriptions sourced from the Swagger (API) Hub.

title: Novel Nanoantennas for Gas Sensing Applications
authors: Mohamed A. Swillam, AbdelRahman M. Ghanim
abstract: In this work, we present chip-integrated optical nanoantenna designs for greenhouse gas sensing, leveraging advanced plasmonic configurations — such as bowtie, nanowire, and fanshaped antennas — on a silicon dioxide layer. By incorporating various absorbing materials like polymers, we assessed gas-specific performance. Additionally, we explored silicon nanowires coated with graphene for mid-infrared (MIR) sensing, demonstrating enhanced sensitivity and selectivity due to graphene's adsorption properties and strong light-matter interactions. Our hybrid approach covers visible to MIR spectral ranges, with verified experimental results confirming high detection precision across diverse gases. These findings underline the potential of nanoantenna-based and nanowire-hybrid systems for compact, efficient environmental monitoring solutions.

title: A Game-Based Approach to Improve Digital Skills Fundamental to Future Computer Engineers
authors: Aneliya Ivanova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: In the context of the digital transformation of education, learners' motivation not only retains its key role in the educational process but also gains even greater importance. Several psychological theories discuss this topic, but the ones that seem to correspond most with the educational process, mutually build on each other, and deeply study the problems of intrinsic and extrinsic motivation, as well as their derived attitudes towards learning, are the developments of Ryan, Deci, and Holzcamp, supplemented by the taxonomy proposed by Malone and Lepper. Gamification is undoubtedly an approach that provokes motivation and engagement, and games of the “Escape Room” and “Mystery Room” type, in which players must autonomously, without guidance from the tutor, solve puzzles, competing with other participants, have the potential to fuel intrinsic motivation, and, as a consequence, expansive learning. This work explores the utility of these game genres from the perspective of the aforementioned psychological theories. It discusses the concept and design of a serious game that combines concepts of the game genres mentioned above and some typical board game mechanics, and covers practical digital skills related to arithmetic fundamentals of the computer and the processor's structure and functioning.

title: Elucidation of Pathophysiological Factors of Cardiovascular Diseases
authors: Naoki Kobayashi, Kento Morita, Nice Ren, Shogo Watanabe, Syoji Kobashi, Kinta Hatakeyama, Koji Iihara, Tetsushi Wakabayashi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases are the second leading cause of death in Japan, underscoring the need for improved prevention and treatment. Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is a surgical procedure to remove plaque that has accumulated in the intima of the carotid artery, and is expected to reduce the risk of stroke. However, the long-term prognosis and complications after CEA surgery are not fully understood. In this study, we investigate pathological factors associated with the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score, based on features extracted from pathological images of plaques removed by CEA and clinical data.We extract features from pathological images using an autoencoder (AE) and analyze them with Lasso regression to investigate their association with the mRS score. The obtained R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score was 0.8427, suggesting that the features obtained by AE retained sufficient information related to the mRS score. It should be noted that this analysis was conducted on the training set; therefore, its generalization performance needs to be evaluated in the future. We also visualized the regions associated with the mRS score in pathological images using the trained regression model.

title: A copula-based framework for joint hydro-wind-solar scenario generation
authors: Anderson Mitterhofer Iung, Fernando Luiz Cyrino Oliveira, Guilherme Armando de Almeida Pereira, André Luís Marques Marcato
abstract: The increasing global share of variable renewable energy (VRE) in power systems has intensified the need for advanced scenario generation methods that can capture both the stochastic behavior of each source and their spatial-temporal interdependencies. This paper presents a copula-based framework for generating monthly correlated scenarios of hydro, wind, and solar resources in the Brazilian power system, with a particular focus on sensitivity analyses. The core contribution lies in evaluating the robustness of this framework to changes in the central variable used in the C-vine structure—specifically, the role of hydrological inflows from different Energy Equivalent Reservoirs (EERs) and variations in scenario horizon lengths. Results demonstrate that the proposed method preserves key statistical properties and dependency structures even under significantly different conditioning inputs, providing strong evidence of its adaptability. While applied to the Brazilian context, the methodology can be extended to other electricity markets with historical records of hydropower inflows. This capability is particularly valuable for long-term operation planning, energy market analysis, and hybrid renewable integration under uncertainty.

title: Attention Enhanced Speaker Representation with Contrastive Learning
authors: Arundhati Das, Varsha Patil, Jasmin Hirani, Atharva Kaskar, Yash Varma, Shubham Patil
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Conventional neural text-to-speech (TTS) systems frequently employ recurrent neural network (RNN)-based encoders, such as Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) or Gated Recurrent Units (GRU), to extract speaker embeddings from reference speech. While effective, these sequential models inherently limit parallel computation and exhibit challenges in capturing long-range dependencies. In this paper, we present a novel speaker encoder architecture grounded in the Transformer model. By leveraging the self-attention mechanism, the proposed design enables improved modeling of temporal dependencies across speech sequences, resulting in more robust and generalizable speaker representations. The Transformer-based speaker encoder is trained using a speaker verification objective, specifically utilizing the Generalized End-to-End (GE2E) loss function. These embeddings are integrated within a Tacotron 2-based synthesis framework to support zero-shot speaker adaptation. Performance evaluations, benchmarked against an LSTM-based baseline, demonstrate significant improvements across multiple indicators, including speaker similarity, equal error rate (EER), model complexity, and inference latency. This architectural refinement not only enhances synthesis quality and system efficiency but also simplifies the end-to-end pipeline by eliminating recurrent components. Additionally, the Transformer's capability for parallelized computation significantly accelerates both training and inference. The experimental outcomes confirm the potential of attention-based architectures in speaker encoding, especially in data-constrained and zero-shot learning environments. This work establishes the Transformer-based approach as a viable and efficient alternative to conventional RNN models in modern TTS systems.

title: Enhancing Crowd Counting in Varying Light Conditions with Deep Learning-Based Density Estimation
authors: Sarika Deokate, Mahima Nair, Anjali S More, Disha Parale, Priyanka Nalla, Asmita Mahamuni
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Accurate crowd density estimation in public spaces is crucial for effective crowd management and safety. Traditional methods struggle in challenging lighting conditions, leading to inaccurate predictions. This research presents a deep learning-based approach using the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model CSRNet to estimate crowd density under varying illumination. The model is trained on the UCF-QNRF dataset, incorporating advanced image preprocessing techniques such as histogram equalization to enhance visibility in low-light environments. Performance evaluation using metrics like MAE, MSE, Accuracy and Precision demonstrates significant improvements over previous models, achieving high accuracy in crowd estimation. The results validate CSRNet's effectiveness in handling real-world challenges like occlusion, lighting variations, and high-density crowd scenes.

title: Speech-Based Dementia Detection Using Egemaps Features for Accurate and Explainable Diagnosis
authors: Madhura Pednekar, Jagannath Nirmal, Pramod H. Kachare, Sandeep B. Sangle
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Dementia is a global health issue that majorly affects the cognitive abilities of the elderly population. Conventional detection methods are expensive, and automatic methods based on text processing are restrictive. This paper investigates speechbased features for automatic dementia detection using different machine learning (ML) algorithms. The spoken utterances by dementia patients are processed using the OpenSMILE toolkit to extract 88 acoustic features, a combination of low-level descriptors, and statistical functions. The extracted features are input into six ML algorithms for healthy and dementia classification. These combinations of features and algorithms are evaluated using the Alzheimer's Dementia Recognition through Spontaneous Speech Only 2021 dataset, comprising utterances from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 9}$</tex> healthy and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 5}$</tex> dementia subjects. Comparative analysis showed that all algorithms performed well, with accuracies above 74 %. The gradient boosting model achieved the highest detection with 88.89% accuracy and 93.02% F1-score, followed by the random forest. The investigation of the gradient boosting model showed that loudness, alpha ratio, shimmer, and mel-frequency cepstral coefficients are the most important for automatic dementia classification.

title: Strategies for Enhancing Photovoltaic System Efficiency Under Partial Shading Conditions
authors: Sajjad Choudhry, Walid Issa, Muhammad Akmal, Faris Al-Naemi
abstract: Partial shading in photovoltaic (PV) systems, caused by factors like clouds, trees, buildings, or dirt, can significantly diminish power output and overall system efficiency. Traditional PV setups face challenges such as mismatch losses and the limitations of bypass diodes, particularly under uneven irradiance. This paper investigates the mitigating effects and advanced methods to counteract the negative impacts of partial shading. Key strategies include optimizing through maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms, employing system design techniques such as Series Parallel (SP) reconfiguration. This paper presents work explores a combination of optimized array configurations to mitigate shading impacts by using the simulation results of MATLAB/SIMULINK. The investigation underscores the importance of hybrid configuration solutions to enhance solar energy harvesting in sub-optimal environmental conditions. Optimal PV array interconnections by using the combination of (SP), when rows, columns, corners and diagonally partially shaded simulation results demonstrate the performance when these strategies are implemented.

title: Mitigation of the induced effects on double-circuit hybrid power network with T-pylons in the UK
authors: Anderson R. J. de Araujo, Maurizio Albano, David Clark, Stephen Robson, Muhammad Shaban, Dongshen Guo, Manu Haddad
abstract: This paper examines the induced electromagnetic effects on T-pylon transmission line caused by circuit coupling in a newly implemented 400 kV double-circuit power network in the United Kingdom. This system comprises interconnected segments of T-pylons, lattice towers, and underground cables. The study further evaluates the effectiveness of Drain Earth Shorting Scheme (DrESS) conductors in mitigating these effects by analyzing induced currents on earth wires, phase-to-ground induced voltages, and tower footing currents. The induced effects in the hybrid power network are investigated using ATP-EMTP assuming the pi-transmission line model, considering a soil resistivity of 100 Ω.m, and tower footing resistance of 3 Ω. The results indicate that induced currents on the ground wires of the energized side are consistently higher due to strong magnetic coupling. However, after the installation of DrESS conductors, a significant reduction is observed in the ground wire current on the non-energized side. Regarding induced voltages, a V-shaped distribution is identified along the T-pylon line, with peak magnitudes occurring at the endpoints. The application of DrESS significantly reduces the peak induced voltages while altering the overall voltage profile. Additionally, tower footing currents exhibit a U-shaped distribution, with peak values near transition points between T-pylons and lattice towers, as well as at underground cable junctions. The highest current is recorded at the final T-pylon, while the lowest values appear at segment midpoints. The installation of DrESS conductors effectively reduces tower footing currents at the initial T-pylons. These findings demonstrate that DrESS installation significantly mitigates induced voltages and currents on the non-energized circuit, enhancing safety for maintenance personnel working on T-pylons.

title: Design and Validation of a Teleoperated Oleophilic Belt Skimmer for Intelligent Marine Oil Spill Recovery
authors: Hans Jesús Guerrero Diburga, Cristhofer Gian Pieer Medina Olano, Luis Albero Sampen Alquizar, Jose Alberto Carrizales Navarro, Ayrton Krickst Nieves Acosta, Miguel Alfonso Lara Quispe
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This work presents the design, construction, and experimental validation of a teleoperated oleophilic belt skimmer intended for the efficient recovery of marine oil spills. The proposed system integrates a rotating inclined belt lined with hydrophobic and oleophilic polypropylene tabs, which enhance selective hydrocarbon adhesion while minimizing water intake. Collected oil is mechanically scraped and transferred to an onboard containment tray. Under theoretical conditions -belt speed of 25 RPM and an oil film thickness of 0.5 mm - the estimated recovery rate reaches up to 380 liters per hour, while field tests showed practical recovery rates of around 250 liters per hour, outperforming traditional drum skimmers. The system’s low - speed operation increases adhesion efficiency by extending contact time between oil and belt surface. Future integrations with an intelligent teleoperation module, PID speed control, remote monitoring, and an HMI panel aims to enable real-time parameter adjustments according to changing environmental conditions. The prototype demonstrates a scalable, energy - efficient, and environmentally responsible solution for oil spill mitigation in coastal and shallow waters. The results contribute to the development of smart, remotely operated systems for marine environmental protection.

title: Enhancing Automated Building Plan Analysis: The ELINA Dataset for Unknown Symbol Detection
authors: Daniel Schulz, Tobias Jonas, Sebastian P. Bayerl
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The growing demand for housing has increased the need for intelligent systems in building planning to improve underlying processes and reduce the workload of professionals. A central aspect of creating such systems is the detection of symbols in building plans, which is essential for creating a bill of materials (BOM). This necessitates symbol data that reflects the wide variety of symbols used in practice. However, public datasets are not available, which led to an increased focus on methods for generating synthetic data. To address these issues, this study presents a novel dataset comprising 2,000 distinct ELectrical INstallation symbols from Architectural plans (ELINA), which is provided for research. Based on ELINA, we present an end-to-end system capable of detecting unknown symbols at the pixel-level by learning general representations of symbols with synthetic data. Our system reaches a mean Average Precision (mAP) (0.50-0.95) score of 0.454 for instance segmentation and a score of 0.959 for bounding box detection, cross-validated in a study using 400 unseen test symbols. We further present and analyze a feature clustering method to differentiate detected symbols, enabling the creation of BOMs. In contrast to other work, our method does not require a separate training process. A key finding is that using a supplementary feature extractor enables a two- to threefold improvement in clustering performance, reaching Adjusted Rand Index (ARI) scores up to 0.63.

title: An Efficient Optimization Method for Light-Guiding Microstructure Design Based on Deep Learning
authors: Jun Jie Yuan, Ya Ming Xie, Guo Chun Wan, Mei Song Tong
abstract: The light guide is a structural component that guides light to the location where it needs to emit light, with excellent light guiding performance, and is widely used in optical equipment. However, the complex design process is a significant obstacle to its development. At present, the design of light guides is still in the stage of trial and error, mainly focusing on adjusting the design parameters of light-guiding microstructure. Based on this, this article combines deep learning algorithm with the design. On the basis of the existing dataset, establish the dataset through extensive experiments. The dataset includes six structural parameters and one performance parameter that determine the optical properties of light-guiding microstructure. Select the GAN algorithm, build a seven input seven output GAN model, and record its output data. Verify the output of the algorithm using design software CATIA and simulation software SPEOS. The results show that the optical performance of the optical microstructure designed using output parameters is excellent, proving that the combination of deep learning and light-guiding microstructure design can improve the efficiency and intelligence of the design.

title: Development of a Cell-based Planning and Control System Using PID Control for ROV Navigation in Regularly Shaped Pools
authors: Andreé Renán Santa María Araujo, Luis Alberto Canchari Vargas, José Luis Becerra Felipe, Joel Jesús Figueroa Vilcarromero, Julio Román Ronceros Rivas, Nain Maximo Ramos Alvarez
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This document proposes the novel planning and implementation of an autonomous navigation and trajectory system for a Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV), specifically designed for controlled, shallow water environments. Our unique solution combines an innovative cell mapping and dedicated motion planner with PID control within a highly modular architecture, enabling the seamless and cost-effective integration of various sensors and Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs). This distinct approach demonstrates a significant step towards accessible, high-performance underwater robotics. This integration results in semi-autonomous robot capable of generating motion paths and mapping aquatic environments. The results obtained from the simulations demonstrate effective spatial coverage of the environment, reaching at least 95% of the areas visited. Intelligent behavior was observed in the system by prioritizing cells with high scores (close to 0.85), especially those near the center of the map, which evidences an active exploration strategy. This analysis validates the effectiveness of the score- and proximity-based planning approach, demonstrating the system’s capability to navigate and map efficiently.

title: Gain Performance Analysis of Rare-Earth-Doped Fiber Amplifier for Optical Networks
authors: Dmitrijs Prigunovs, Patriks Morevs, Ints Murans, Inese Parfjonova, Aleksandrs Olins, Ricards Kudojars, Toms Salgals, Vjaceslavs Bobrovs
abstract: This paper presents an innovative design and comprehensive performance analysis of rare-earth-doped fiber amplifiers (REDFAs) optimized for the Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) system. This study focuses on the development and evaluation of REDFAs tailored for 8 -channel wavelength division multiplexing (WDM) transmission systems, emphasizing configurations that support at least <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \text{Gbit} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> transmission rates per <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex>. Both co-propagation and counterpropagation pumping at 980 nm and 1480 nm wavelengths are analyzed to identify optimal configurations that maximize amplification efficiency while minimizing noise. The findings provide critical insights into designing high-performance REDFAs for WDM networks, supporting stable and highquality signal transmission. This research contributes to the development of scalable, high-capacity optical networks capable of meeting the increasing demand for data-intensive applications. An experimental model is tested in different conditions using an up to 8-channel non-return-to-zero (NRZ) modulated 100 GHz spaced transmission system. The gain curve of the designed REDFA is characterized by a WDM system operating in C-band. Results demonstrate that carefully designed REDFAs not only enhance WDM system performance by increasing signal-to-noise ratios (SNR) but also maintain signal fidelity across high-capacity channels. The study's findings underscore the potential of REDFAs as scalable and reliable solutions for WDM networks, offering practical insights into achieving high amplification efficiency in demanding high-speed environments. This work lays the groundwork for advanced amplifier designs in optical communications, providing a roadmap for implementing robust amplification solutions in high-capacity, long-distance optical systems.
