title: Multi-Label Based Plant Disease Identification and Treatment Recommendations Using Transfer Learning and Attention Mechanism
authors: Temesgen Tadesse Tilahun, Tekle Dargaso Degu, Temesgen Tamirat Ashango, Melaku Bayih Demessie, Habtamu Fanta Alambo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: Agriculture remains the primary contributor to the economy and the foundation for food security in Ethiopia, where small farmers grow crops such as enset, tomato, and pepper. However, plant diseases are one of the most pressing concerns for farmers, particularly in the Wolaita Zone, resulting in a reduction in crop production levels and the feasibility of their treatment. To mitigate this problem, previous studies have conducted research on plant disease classification. However, there is a lack of studies conducted to classify plant diseases and provide treatment recommendations. Thus, the proposed study employed a design science research design with both qualitative and quantitative approaches. To achieve our objective and fill the research gap, we developed a lightweight multilabel classification model for crop disease detection and treatment recommendation using transfer learning with pretrained convolutional neural networks, including YOLOv8, VGGNet, DenseNet201, and MobileNetV2 integrated with an attention mechanism that extracts features used for model training. A combined 12,490 images dataset was prepared from healthy and infected enset, tomato, and pepper leaves, as well as the CSV file containing the disease types and their treatment recommendations. Experiments for the proposed models are carried out, and the results of the DenseNet201 algorithm fused with the Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) attention mechanism resulted in a Hamming Loss of 0.0197, Validation Accuracy of 0.992, and mAP of 0.9554 over the entire class. MobileNetv2 demonstrated the best performance in terms of computational complexity, making it ideal for device-level execution.

title: An Ultra-Wideband Electromagnetic Protection Antenna
authors: Quanjie Xiong, Junyi Yang, Qi Chen, Jinqi Dong, Shuyun Lin
abstract: In this paper, an ultra-wideband electromagnetic protection antenna (UWB-EPA) is proposed to integrate the functions of a common ultra-wideband antenna and high-power microwave (HPM) protection. The UWB-EPA is designed based on the planar monopole antenna. By loading a PIN diode and a E-shaped topology, the antenna's resonance can be suppressed when HPM is incident, causing it to lose the ability to receive signals and thereby achieve HPM protection. The results shows that when the PIN diode is in the OFF state, the proposed antenna exhibits a wide impedance bandwidth of 51.9%, spanning from 3.11 GHz to 5.29 GHz, with a return loss of −10 dB. When the PIN diode is in the ON state, the antenna enters the protective mode, the reflection coefficient is more than −3 dB in the frequency range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \text{GHz}-6 \text{GHz}$</tex>, offering a protection level of more than 11 dB and a received power attenuation of 15.8 dB.

title: Optimization of Decision Making and Enhancement of Manufacturing Process Performance through the Application of Business Intelligence
authors: Augustín Stareček, Nikola Bachanová, Martin Lišaník, Zdenka Gyurák Babeľová
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper focuses on the digital transformation in industry sector, with emphasis on the use of Business Intelligence (BI) tools. It addresses the challenge of manual processing and visualization of production data, a task that is both time-consuming and prone to inaccuracies. The primary aim of the study is to present the outcomes of optimizing the visualization of a key production indicator through the application of the Microsoft Power BI Business Intelligence system. The purpose of the application of the Microsoft Power BI Business Intelligence system was streamlining workflows and supporting decision-making in industrial practice. The process of visualizing the key indicator of unplanned downtime was examined in a case study carried out within a manufacturing enterprise producing automotive components. The research employed qualitative methods, such as Gemba Walks and employee interviews, alongside quantitative approaches, including descriptive analysis of data processed in Microsoft Excel and Power BI. The findings confirmed that the implementation of an automated dashboard in Microsoft Power BI led to a substantial reduction in reporting time (a saving of 67 minutes per working day), thereby enabling employees to focus on activities with higher added value. The case study further demonstrated that Business Intelligence systems not only streamline processes and reduce errors but also enhance the transparency of reporting.

title: Towards a Greener Future: Teaching Sustainability in Electrical Engineering
authors: Mohammed Alqarni
abstract: As climate change intensifies and natural resources continue to decline, the need for sustainable solutions within electrical engineering has become more pressing than ever. This paper emphasizes the critical role of engineering education in addressing these challenges and explores why sustainability must be more deeply embedded into electrical engineering programs. It identifies current curriculum gaps, including the absence of sustainability-focused content in core subjects and limited opportunities for practical, real-world application. To address these shortcomings, the paper proposes strategies such as course redesign to foster sustainability thinking, interdisciplinary collaboration, and project-based learning models. These recommendations aim to equip future engineers with both the technical skills and the environmental awareness needed to contribute meaningfully to global sustainability objectives, including clean energy access, responsible resource use, and climate action.

title: Multi-Megawatt KA-Band Relativistic Gyrotron with a Longitudinally Slotted Cavity and a TM-Type Operating Mode
authors: Yu. Yu. Danilov, E. V. Ilyakov, I. S. Kulagin, A. N. Leontyev, R. M. Rozental
abstract: The paper is devoted to the development and investigation of a Ka-band relativistic gyrotron with a TM-type operating mode. To suppress parasitic TE-modes that prevent efficient generation at the operating frequency, a longitudinal slot resonator is used, which ensures selection by the type of operating oscillations. The results of 3D PIC modeling of the interaction of the electron beam with the resonator field are presented. The possibility of obtaining an output power of more than 3 MW is shown, which corresponds to an efficiency of about 25 %. The issues of generation stability in the operating mode and the electrical strength of the structure are discussed.

title: Intelligent Detection of Primary Signals using CNN, SVM and MLP Models
authors: Addessalam El Bandoudi, Mohamed Boulouird
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: As we move towards 6 G communications systems, the increasing number of connected devices is exacerbating spectrum scarcity. Cognitive radio (CR), based on spectrum sensing (SS), can dynamically identify and exploit underutilized frequency bands to optimize their use. Deep neural networks (DNNs) have emerged as powerful tools for improving the performance of spectrum sensing, addressing the key challenges of model accuracy and robustness. In this context, identifying primary users and allowing secondary users access to unoccupied bands is essential for more efficient and equitable spectrum management. Although traditional approaches, such as energy detection and cyclostationary detection, have been widely studied, they have limitations in highly noisy environments. This work examines and compares three detection models-support vector machines (SVM), multilayer perceptrons (MLPs), and convolutional neural networks (CNNs), as well as one classical method, the energy detector. Performance assessment is conducted using the probability of detection, the probability of false alarm, the total error rate, and the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve across various signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) levels. The results show that the CNN model offers slightly better performance than the other models.

title: The Design of Ku-Band Anti-UAV Radar Array Antenna
authors: Tong Su, Yan Chen, Longjian Zhou, Qiang-Ming Cai, Xin Cao, Chao Zou, Tongli Yuan, Haoran Li, Zhen-Yong Du, Yixiang Li, Yuyu Zhu, Jun Fan
abstract: In order to meet the performance requirements of the anti-UAV radar, a millimeterwave microstrip antenna array operates in Ku band is proposed in this paper. This antenna is used for anti-UAV radar system, and should meet the requirements such as high gain and low sidelobe level. A rectangular patch antenna is adopted as the array unit. The antenna unit is fed by microstrip line, which inserts into the patch at the middle of the wide edge of the patch. Series feed network and coaxial feed are combined to realize a low loss feed network and to achieve nonuniform excitation. Through the feed network, all patch antenna units are excited in phase but with different amplitude of Taylor distribution to achieve a low sidelobe level. Finally, the antenna array and network are combined together, and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 16$</tex> microstrip antenna array is realized. The antenna operates between 16.8 GHz and 17.2 GHz. Simulation results show that high efficiency and low sidelobe level is achieved. The beamwidth in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E$</tex>-plane and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$H$</tex>-plane are 12° and 8°, respectively. The gain is about 28 dB while the sidelobe level is lower than −22 dB, which can well realize the characteristics of high gain/low sidelobe.

title: Estimation of the Meteorological Data Time Steps Influence on the Sizing of Hybrid PV Systems Without Energy Injection to the Grid - a Case Study
authors: Ludmil Stoyanov, Ivan Bachev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The paper presents a study of the influence of the meteorological data time steps on the installed powers and capacities in a hybrid photovoltaic system, which does not inject energy to the grid. For this purpose, four different time steps with relatively high resolution are considered. First, the generated deviance of the meteorological data is estimated. Then the meteorological data with different steps are used for annual simulation of the operation of different system configurations. Each simulation results in determination of characteristic parameters, which allow for estimation of the system performance and sizing procedure duration. The comparison of those parameters shows that the time steps of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0}$</tex> minutes can be recommended due to their good precision and relatively fast simulation.

title: AI-Based Framework for Financial Data Mapping and Analysis Using RAG and Transformer Models
authors: Sumaiya Jannat Anne, Sudath R. Heiyanthuduwage, Md Habibur Rahman Nakib, Abir Mahmud, Sabab Bin Habib, Samiha Fairooz
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Use of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) for data analysis has gained popularity in recent years. This research aims to develop a robust, AI-assisted open-source framework for mapping and analyzing structured financial data, powered by RAG and fine-tuned transformer models. The system eliminates the need for manually pulling data, running queries, summarizing, and visualizing primary financial metrics such as revenue, net income, return on investment (ROI), and shareholder equity. Using Sentence Transformer Models (STM) and Facebook AI Similarity Search (FAISS), each financial record is encoded into dense vectors for semantic retrieval. When a user asks a natural language question, the system pulls up related records and creates summaries with a Meta AI, Bidirectional and Auto-Regressive Transformers (BART) model. The proposed solution is designed as a modular architecture combining data ingestion, preprocessing, embedding, RAG-based querying, BART summarization, and interactive visualization components (via Plotly and Streamlit). A prototype was developed based on Jupyter Notebook and tested over real financial data acquired from Fintags Pty Limited. It solves problems such as manual data management, inconsistent data and the lag in decision making with a scalable, precise, and easy-to-use tool. It allows business and financial analysts to get contextually relevant insights from large datasets without needing to know how to code. Experimental results show significant gains in analytical efficiency, model interpretability, and business decision support conventional financial analysis techniques. The proposed system demonstrates how AI-powered semantic summarization can replace conventional manual workflows in financial analysis, improving speed, accessibility, and decision-making quality.

title: Modeling and Predicting Machine Learning Performance
authors: Julio Corona, Rafael Teixeira, Mário Antunes, Rui L. Aguiar
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Modern Machine Learning (ML) models pose challenges such as long development cycles, high costs, and difficult model selection. Understanding how dataset properties influence performance in a model-agnostic and interpretable way remains limited. This work analyzes the relationship between dataset characteristics and model behavior across diverse algorithms, introducing symbolic regression models that transparently estimate accuracy from dataset features and simple model identifiers. Results show that features such as noisiness, redundancy, and class distribution consistently affect performance. A symbolic model using only dataset features achieved modest accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}=0.361$</tex>), while including model identification improved predictions (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}=0.534$</tex>). These findings provide interpretable insights into the data-model relationship, supporting preprocessing decisions (e.g., feature selection, class balancing) and informing meta-learning strategies for algorithm recommendation.

title: Securing the Internet of Things: The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Agricultural Cyber Defense
authors: Dora Konstantinou, Teodora Stoyanova, Stoyan Stoyanov, Radostin Rafailov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper aims to examine the developing landscape of Internet of Things (IoT) technology from a practical perspective. Exploring IoT's implications in various domains including agriculture, the paper focuses on the security challenges that arise from its fast adoption and growth both in domestic and industrial domains. Furthermore, identifying and preventing these critical security vulnerabilities is highly essential. The increased number of attacks on IoT systems, especially the last two years (2023-2024), led us to explore the potential of automated security systems utilizing AI, apart from the conventional ways of security. In response to this, this particular study aims to explore the role of artificial intelligence (AI) in enhancing IoT systems' security with an emphasis on agriculture. The study specifically explores and presents the way AI can be applied to minimize security risks along with a comprehensive review of current AI-driven platforms and solutions designed to strengthen IoT security frameworks in the particular domain.

title: Quantum navigation system considering the fuel consumption due to elevation difference
authors: Tsubasa Suzuki, Takao Tomono
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: In this study, experiments were conducted to mitigate traffic congestion by applying quantum annealing that takes road elevation changes into account, with the aim of reducing carbon dioxide emissions from automobiles. While similar studies have been widely conducted in the past, few have considered the significant impact of road gradients on carbon dioxide emissions. This study was validated in San Francisco, a city with a diverse elevation distribution and well-developed road networks. The effect of elevation changes was incorporated into the results by converting them into equivalent distances using a correction formula. Driving routes were determined using candidate route extraction based on Dijkstra’s algorithm and a quantum annealing simulator. The validation results showed that this method could reduce carbon dioxide emissions by up to 27% compared to previous methods. Furthermore, when the effects of traffic congestion were included in the carbon dioxide emissions, it was confirmed that the carbon dioxide emissions were minimized when the number of candidate routes extracted by Dijkstra’s algorithm was set to 20. This result indicates that the conditions of Dijkstra’s algorithm are also an important factor. For future work, efforts will focus on improving practicality by optimizing the cost functions and other computation conditions in quantum annealing, as well as expanding the computational model to account for factors such as vehicle weight.

title: Study of Power Supplies Used in Telecommunication Systems
authors: Ivelyn Stoykov, Grigor Mihaylov, Teodora Hristova, Ivaylo Stoyanov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Electronic devices require electrical energy. A very small percentage of them are powered directly from a standard AC network (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 1 0 - 2 2 0 ~ V}, \mathbf{5 0 ~ H z}$</tex>). Portable low-power consumers are powered by batteries, accumulators or other primary sources of electrical energy. To power more powerful consumers, which in most cases are stationary, energy from the standard AC network is used, usually converted using electronic converters. The conversion is necessary because different consumers have requirements for different types and values of the supply voltage. In most cases, they require a constant voltage with certain parameters. The paper proposes a system for switching between different energy sources according to the energy regulations of the country to ensure an uninterrupted power supply. The successful operation of the control devices and the achievement of fuel and energy savings are demonstrated. This proves that modern hybrid systems can be successfully used in the telecommunications as well as other manufacturing sectors for lower the carbon footprint.

title: Probabilistic Resource Adequacy Assessment Using an In-House Tool for India’s 2025-26 Power System
authors: Aman Gautam, Himanshu Kumar, Rahul Shukla, Suhas Dambhare, Vamshi Ballikonda, S Usha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Ensuring generation resource adequacy is critical for power system reliability, particularly in India’s evolving grid with increasing penetration of variable renewable energy (VRE). This paper presents the application of an in-house developed probabilistic generation stacking tool to conduct a national-level short-term resource adequacy assessment for India for the fiscal year 2025-26. This analysis was carried out as part of the ShortTerm National Resource Adequacy Plan (ST-NRAP). Using a scenario-based Monte Carlo approach, 1,000 stochastic simulations were performed to capture uncertainties in demand, wind, solar generation, and outages of conventional generating units. The stacking tool evaluates system adequacy using two key reliability metrics: Loss of Load Probability (LOLP) and Normalized Energy Not Served (NENS). A major innovation in this study is the dynamic modeling of storage systems. Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) and Pumped Storage Plants (PSPs) are simulated to charge during surplus generation periods and discharge automatically during shortages, thereby reflecting real-time system flexibility. The results reveal a heightened risk of supply shortfall during non-solar hours, especially from April to September 2025. In the best-case scenario, LOLP and NENS were estimated at $4.8 \%$ and $0.12 \%$, respectively, while the median scenario showed values of $12.1 \%$ and $0.37 \%$. This study highlights the critical role of scenario-based probabilistic tools for early identification of supply shortfall risks and emphasizes the importance of flexible resources, strategic outage planning, and integrated storage operation to ensure grid reliability in a highVRE environment.

title: Domain-Randomized Pointcloud Simulation and Label Filtering for Industrial 3D Object Detection
authors: Christof Schützenhöfer, Sebastian Reicher, Thomas Ulz, Christian Steger
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Recent advances in the generation of synthetic data for artificial intelligence have led to the development of simulators and the integration of physically accurate sensor behavior. Typically, machine learning models require large amounts of data, which are costly and time-consuming in collecting and labeling data. Thus, data aggregation is a challenging part of artificial intelligence. Most open-source simulators focus on autonomous driving, which limits their applicability for other use-cases. This work provides a new approach for an alternative simulator that is highly flexible, usable in any domain and, therefore, solves the problem described before. This simulator is based on the Isaac Sim framework and uses a new method to filter the bounding boxes using a clustering algorithm. A study on object detection for pallets and containers within a warehouse environment for autonomous robots shows that synthetic data is challenging realworld data by outperforming the baseline model by +7.24 in Average Precision utilizing the PointPillar architecture. Further, fine-tuning the weights with a small set of real-world data significantly improves the model, increasing its Average Precision by +24.79 relative to the baseline.

title: Credit Risk Prediction Based on SC-CTGAN for Imbalanced Datasets
authors: Yujia Zhang, Yunjun Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: In recent years, the big data era has provided consumer financial institutions with multi-source personal data, creating a vast pool of credit information. How to effectively utilize and integrate these resources for comprehensive personal credit risk prediction is a key challenge. Credit risk prediction is usually an imbalanced classification task, with default samples far fewer than normal repayment ones, posing challenges for traditional machine learning methods. In this paper, a novel data augmentation method called SC-CTGAN, which combines spectral clustering with conditional tabular generative adversarial network (CTGAN), is proposed to augment the original data with a sufficient number of synthetic default transactions. This integration successfully tackles the issue of an uneven distribution of minority-class samples that often arises when oversampling is performed using CTGAN. Then we propose a credit risk prediction approach grounded in an adaptive weighted ensemble learning model, aiming to enhance the model's generalization capability. By integrating the strengths of diverse learning algorithms, this method effectively leverages the underlying patterns within the data to improve prediction accuracy. The results of the experiment indicate that our proposed ensemble model based on SC-CTGAN outperforms other state-of-the-art machine learning models in AUC score.

title: Cross-Domain and Multilingual Analysis of Retrieval Augmented Generation on Ontologies
authors: Ramona Kühn, Jelena Mitrović, Lorenz Wendlinger, Michael Granitzer
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) extends LLMs with external knowledge, typically from continuous text sources. In this work, we explore the application of RAG to ontologies to support ontology engineers and users in querying structured knowledge. To demonstrate the generalizability of our approach, we evaluate RAG on three ontologies from the domains of video games, IoT infrastructure, and rhetorical figures. Two of the ontologies are in English, while one is in German. Our study compares chunking strategies, chunk sizes, and the use of rerankers. We observe that advanced chunking techniques offer limited performance gains due to the inherently modular structure of ontologies. Additionally, we compare RAG on ontological document structure with the same information in a continuous format and reveal that the performance of RAG is not negatively affected by the ontological document structure. An advantage of using ontologies is that they can be evaluated against their competency questions that are typically developed alongside and define the intended use. With the Ragas evaluation framework, we achieve promising results across domains and languages. To address challenges regarding verbose LLM outputs that decrease performance, we propose a new metric Answer Average Match (AAM), which is specifically designed for the evaluation of RAG on ontologies. Our findings highlight the viability of ontology-aware RAG and offer practical insights for its optimization and evaluation.

title: Operational Studies of a Machine-Tractor Unit for Spring Pre-Seeding Soil Tillage
authors: Petar Dimitrov, Hristo Beloev, Kaloyan Stoyanov, Atanas Atanasov, Todor Delikostov, Evgeni Enchev, Vladimir Donev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Pre-sowing soil treatments for spring crops typically include early spring harrowing and combined cultivation, which may be performed with or without additional harrowing. In Bulgaria, combined cultivation is carried out using cultivators of the KPS or KPG type, or combination cultivators (RAU type), equipped with spring-tine and active rotary working elements that ensure a levelled, fine-grained structure of the arable layer. For the implementation of this technological operation, the “Lemken Korund 8.900” presowing cultivator has been introduced and utilized in Bulgaria over the past three years. This machine is coupled with tractors possessing a nominal traction force of 50 kN, such as the John Deere 8R280. Operational tests were conducted to evaluate the reliability and performance of this machine-tractor unit. The operational indicators studied serve as a basis for assessing the quality of work and provide quantitative characteristics of the aggregate's functional properties. This study presents the results of these evaluations, demonstrating that the newly integrated machine-tractor unit for spring pre-sowing soil preparation operates reliably and ensures timely completion of the required technological tasks. The unit achieved an average operational productivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$60.70 \text{da}^{-1}$</tex> at a working speed of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.0 \text{km}. \mathrm{h}^{-1}$</tex>. The technological and technical reliability coefficients ranged between 1.00 and 0.99, while the fuel consumption was recorded at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.790 \text{kg}^{-1} \text{da}^{-1}$</tex>. The trials were conducted on arable lands under conditions of carbonate chernozem soil, typical for the region.

title: Environmentally Sustainable Entrepreneurship in the Context of Intergenerational Business: Attitudes and Barriers
authors: Aneta Deneva, Daniel Pavlov, Aleksandar Lichev, Silvia Puiu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This study aims to present young people's attitudes towards the development of environmentally sustainable intergenerational businesses. In the context of growing global challenges and the accompanying difficulties, barriers, and transformations, a current vision of the place and role of modern entrepreneurs in society is taking shape. The emphasis is on understanding the need for the transfer of knowledge, values and responsibilities between generations to ensure the development of sustainable and environmentally friendly learning practices in agriculture. The authors present an international comparative study of students' intentions about family businesses in Bulgaria and Romania; the respondents (727 in 2021 and 993 in 2023) answered the questionnaire during their classes or by Messenger. The point of view is - the respondents have the desire and attitude to develop intergenerational business, according to the INTERGEN concept, thus contributing to the development of environmentally sustainable entrepreneurship in individual regions. The two main hypotheses are: (1) Respondents want to develop intergenerational business and (2) Respondents want to develop businesses in specific areas. Thanks to the survey it is possible to discuss these ideas.

title: LLMMutation: Mutation Testing for Large Language Models
authors: Zhiwei Liu, Xinhong Duan, Zhanqi Cui, Zheng Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: The performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) heavily depends on the quality of their training data, while their capabilities are primarily evaluated through taskspecific test datasets. This evaluation approach makes the quality of test datasets a critical factor in ensuring LLM reliability. Even high-accuracy LLMs may exhibit weak generalizability and insufficient robustness when they are evaluated using flawed test sets with insufficient sample sizes or limited diversity. In traditional software testing, mutation testing is a well-established technique for assessing test suite effectiveness by measuring the ability to detect artificially injected faults. However, fundamental differences exist between traditional software and Transformerbased LLMs, preventing the direct application of classical mutation testing techniques. To address this, we propose LLMMutation, a dedicated test dataset quality evaluation method for LLMs, which applies multi-level mutation operators to introduce perturbations into the model. Experimental results demonstrate that models perturbed by different mutation operators exhibit significant accuracy degradation, which validate LLMMutation's effectiveness in fault injection. In addition, different test datasets exhibit distinct mutation score distributions under LLMMutation perturbations, which is positively correlated with the quality of the datasets. This confirms that the mutation score can effectively distinguish the quality of datasets used for the same task.

title: Map Generation From Overlapping Microscopy Images Using Stitching Methods
authors: Gabriel-Sebastian Buță, Ciprian-Mihai Ceaușescu, Bogdan Alexe
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: High-resolution microscopy images play an important role in histopathology and biomedical research. Their limited field of view necessitates stitching multiple overlapping image tiles to form larger, coherent image maps. In this work, we propose and evaluate a suite of image stitching methods, ranging from classical feature-based approaches such as SIFT and KAZE to modern deep learning-based techniques like SuperPoint and LightGlue, for generating high-quality composite microscopy images. We introduce optimizations for stitching order and patch matching to improve alignment robustness and computational efficiency. The proposed methods are benchmarked on two microscopy datasets, including one with ground-truth labels, using both traditional and learned similarity metrics. Experimental results demonstrate that deep learning-based pipelines, particularly those integrating LightGlue, consistently outperform classical alternatives in both visual quality and robustness, while maintaining practical execution times.

title: Deep Learning Based Detection of Islanding Using Scalogram Images and Histogram of Oriented Gradient
authors: Appurva Rajendra Kapil, Kumaresh Pal, Anshuman Bhuyan, Pawan Arun Gawade, Rumit Tiwary, Subhadip Goswami
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: A major challenge driven on by the increasing integration of dispersed power sources is islanding. Islanding may cause harm to consumers as well as their equipment. Since, IEEE 1547 DG connectivity standards state that the DG must be shut down if islanding is detected within two seconds. This paper offers a novel method for image pattern recognition for islanding identification using a deep learning (DL) classification algorithm. The Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) classification algorithm is used in the proposed method. To identify both non-islanding and islanding events, images are used to extract the histogram of oriented gradient (HOG) characteristics. The time series signal obtained from the point of common coupling (PCC) is used to create the scalogram images. HOG features are extracted from the images and then used as feature vector inputs for LSTM classifier training and testing. The rate of change of voltage parameter is used to create scalogram images. The LSTM classifier's effectiveness is assessed through k-fold cross-validations. The classification findings indicates that islanding detection utilising a LSTM classifier and HOG feature for image pattern recognition obtained outstanding performance with 98.62% accuracy and a detection time of 109 milliseconds.

title: Targeted Weed Control: AI-Driven Spot Spraying System with Environmental Adaptation
authors: Muhammet Emre Sanci, Rohit Narwal, Liujun Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This work presents an AI-driven modularized low-cost spot spraying system that uses threshold-based decision-making to dynamically adjust herbicide application in real-time. The system integrates OAK-D for weed detection, Jetson Orin Nano for plant classification, and Arduino Mega for spray control. Simulations demonstrate that this approach significantly reduces herbicide consumption, improves spray precision, and effectively adapts to varying environmental conditions, making it a scalable solution for precision agriculture.

title: A Novel Preprocessing-Driven Approach to Remaining Useful Life (RUL) Prediction Using Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCN)
authors: Florent Imbert, Tosin Adewumi, Hui Han
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Accurate prediction of Remaining Useful Life (RUL) in aero-engines is vital for predictive maintenance, improved operational reliability, and reduced lifecycle costs. While deep learning approaches have demonstrated strong potential in this area, most existing methods focus primarily on model architecture design and treat input features uniformly, often neglecting the influence of data preprocessing. In this work, we propose a novel preprocessing pipeline that enhances RUL prediction by improving data quality and temporal representation before model training. Our approach leverages complete temporal sequences and generates RUL estimates at each timestep, enabling the model to capture finegrained degradation dynamics and deliver continuous prognostic insights throughout the engine's operational life. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed pipeline, we conduct experiments on the NASA C-MAPSS dataset. Comparative evaluations against a suite of state-of-the-art neural models including CNN, RNN, LSTM, DCNN, TCN, BiGRUTSAM, AGCNN, and ATCN, demonstrate that our approach consistently achieves superior accuracy and robustness in aeroengine RUL prediction. These results highlight the critical role of preprocessing in maximizing the effectiveness of neural prognostic models.

title: An Empirical Study on Improving SimCLR's Nonlinear Projection Head Using Pretrained Autoencoder Embeddings
authors: Andreas Schliebitz, Heiko Tapken, Martin Atzmueller
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: This paper focuses on improving the effectiveness of the standard 2-layer MLP projection head featured in the SimCLR framework through the use of pretrained autoencoder embeddings. Given a contrastive learning task with a largely unlabeled image classification dataset, we first train a shallow autoencoder architecture and extract its compressed representations contained in the encoder's embedding layer. After freezing the weights within this pretrained layer, we use it as a drop-in replacement for the input layer of SimCLR's default projector. Additionally, we also apply further architectural changes to the projector by decreasing its width and changing its activation function. The different projection heads are then used to contrastively train and evaluate a feature extractor following the SimCLR protocol. Our experiments indicate that using a pretrained autoencoder embedding in the projector can not only increase classification accuracy by up to 2.9 % or 1.7 % on average, but can also significantly decrease the dimensionality of the projection space. Our results also suggest, that using the sigmoid and tanh activation functions within the projector can outperform ReLU in terms of peak and average classification accuracy. All experiments involving our pretrained projectors are conducted with frozen embeddings, since our test results indicate an advantage compared to using their non-frozen counterparts.

title: Multifactorial Study of Transverse Static Stability of an Agricultural Robot
authors: Georgi Ivanov, Vladimir Kotev, Georgi Komitov, Ivan Ivanov, Evgeni Kehayov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: An agricultural robot is an automated machine or system that uses sensors, artificial intelligence, and mechanized devices to carry out agricultural activities with minimal or no human intervention. The main goal of agricultural robots is to increase efficiency, reduce costs, and be environmentally friendly, while reducing dependence on human labor. The critical angle of lateral stability is a very important parameter for agricultural robots because it determines the maximum slope of the terrain at which the robot can operate safely without tipping over sideways. It defines the boundary between stable and unstable operation of the robot and is key to its safety, reliability and efficiency. This angle of stability is important because it gives the robot safety against damage in case of rollover, efficiency of work by planning the maximum slopes of the terrain to be overcome, allows for better coping with a variety of conditions, it depends on the parameters of the structure, allows for autonomous operation based on predetermined critical angles. Through regression analysis, experimental transverse stability data is turned into an equation or model through which we can predict and improve the stability of the robot. In this article, a regression analysis of the factors influencing the transverse stability of agricultural robots is made. The levels of variation and the levels of their influence on the model are determined with the multiple correlation coefficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R=0.944$</tex>, the total variance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R 2=0.891$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F(2.6) =24.425$</tex> at a significance level of the factors <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}=0.0013$</tex>. Graphical dependencies of this influence are deduced using specialized software. A variance analysis of the factors is also made.

title: Privacy-Aware Deep RL for Sequential Coalition Formation Decisions Under Uncertainty
authors: Gerasimos Koresis, Stergios Plataniotis, Leonidas Bakopoulos, Charilaos Akasiadis, Georgios Chalkiadakis
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Task execution in multiagent settings often calls for the formation of coalitions, since agents may possess complementary skills and/or resources that have to be pulled together for a task. Naturally, the formation process and its efficiency is affected by strategic agent choices, as well as by the uncertainty inherent in practically all real-world settings; thus, in principle it can be facilitated by reinforcement learning (RL). The practicality of employing RL for each individual to learn aspects of the coalition formation problem in large open settings is questionable, however, due to the scarcity of interactions among specific agents and also due to privacy concerns. As such, we propose a novel framework that effectively intertwines sequential decision making during coalition formation under uncertainty with deep RL (DRL) techniques designed to fit the needs of such challenging environments and overcome the aforementioned issues. This is facilitated by the assumption of capability-related agent types; and by allowing the joint RL training of agents in ways that do not jeopardize their privacy. We put forward two DRL algorithms that guarantee privacy preservation by design, as is also verified by a theoretical proof that we provide. Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, and its potential for transfer learning, as already trained models can be successfully employed in environments with different reward functions. To the best of our knowledge, ours is the first approach to allow autonomous agents to employ deep RL for sequentially optimal decisions in large open coalitional task allocation settings, while addressing uncertainty and privacy concerns.

title: High-Gradient Sub-Thz Accelerating Structures Powered by Cherenkov Superradiance Pulses
authors: A. A. Vikharev, I. V. Zotova, A. E. Fedotov, M. I. Yalandin
abstract: Based on numerical simulations, we analyze the possibility of high-gradient accelerations of electrons using high-power sub- THz pulses of Cherenkov superradiance (SR). Due to the ultra-short (nanosecond and subnanosecond) duration, such pulses can power metal structures without developing breakdowns. In order to accelerate photoinjector-formed electron bunches with a sufficiently high energy of about 3 MeV, it is proposed to use a sequence of resonant accelerating cells with lateral power supply perpendicular to the electron beam motion. Simulations take into account the reached parameters of D- and W-band SR pulses, as well as the breakdown field threshold determined in previous acceleration experiments with 38 GHz SR pulses. It is demonstrated that the multi- MeV electron energy gain can be provided in compact systems with high accelerating gradients which significantly exceed the maximum value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \text{MW} / \mathrm{m}$</tex> achievable on the basis of conventional long-wave klystrons.

title: AFP Sensor Based on Ferrocene and AFP (Ab)-Modified Electrode: Synthesis and Performance Evaluation
authors: Yi Liu, Fuliang Wang
abstract: Two highly sensitive amperometric immunosensors for alpha-fetoprotein antigen (AFPAg) detection were fabricated through electrode modification strategies. Typically, during AFPAg detection, electron transfer is mediated by substances such as ferrocene or gold. However, in the case of the prepared zinc oxide electrodes, direct electron transfer was observed between the electrode surface and horseradish peroxidase (HRP). Specifically, by modifying a zinc electrode, pre-heated to 500°C, with AFP antibody (AFPAb) and ferrocene via chitosan, we developed two types of amperometric immunosensors for AFPAg quantification. Under optimized conditions, cyclic voltammetry revealed specific responses of the immunosensors to AFP within two distinct concentration ranges: 1.56 to 12.5 ng/mL and 25.0 to 100.0 ng/mL. The limits of detection were determined to be 0.02 ng/mL and 0.05ng/mL, respectively, at a signal-to-noise ratio of 3. The results demonstrated that electrodes modified with chitosan and AFPAb exhibited high sensitivity, indicating effective immobilization of AFPAb on the electrode surface and facilitating direct electron transfer between the electrode and HRP. Furthermore, when the electrode was additionally modified with ferrocene, a good sensitivity was achieved, suggesting that ferrocene also participated in electron transfer and contributed to signal amplification. We conducted a comprehensive investigation into the factors influencing the performance of the proposed immunosensors. The developed immunosensors exhibited excellent specificity, good reproducibility, repeatability, and long-term stability, making them promising candidates for clinical AFPAg detection.

title: Study on the Output Characteristics of the Trans-former-Rectifier HTS Flux Pump Based on Dynamic Resistance
authors: Jiaqi Li, Anpeng Shu, Wei Pi, Yan Li, Yikai Zhang, Chenyang Han, Zhouxun Li, Yuanlong Din, Yinshun Wang
abstract: The high-temperature superconducting (HTS) flux pump is a charging device that can achieve contactless excitation and provide stable current compensation for superconducting magnets without increasing the refrigeration burden of the system. Compared with the traditional excitation method through current leads, the HTS flux pump has the advantages of high safety performance, high excitation efficiency, and high stability, making it an effective solution for the stable operation of super conducting magnets. Among them, the transformer-rectifier HTS flux pump based on dynamic resistance has the advantages of low loss and low system complexity, and thus holds greater application potential. This paper provides a detailed analysis of the working principle of the transformer-rectifier HTS flux pump based on dynamic resistance, focusing on its core component, the superconducting bridge. Then, a finite element simulation model of the superconducting bridge is established and a formula for the dynamic resistance of the superconducting bridge is obtained. In order to verify the accuracy of the model, a measurement system for the dynamic resistance of a single superconducting tape under a composite magnetic field is also constructed. Subsequently, a circuit model of the transformer-rectifier HTS flux pump is built in MATLAB Simulink and the output characteristics of the flux pump are analyzed. The results indicate that the excitation speed of the load magnet and the final saturation current are mainly affected by the amplitude, frequency, phase difference of the composite magnetic field, and the magnitude of the charging current, but are independent of the frequency of the charging current. The thesis proposes specific methods to optimize the output characteristics of the flux pump by adjusting the amplitude, frequency, and phase difference of the applied magnetic field. For example, the study shows that the output efficiency of the flux pump peaks with a 60° phase lead of the parallel field component over the perpendicular field, which provides theoretical support for optimizing the performance of the flux pump.

title: Multimodal 3D Target Reconstruction from SAR and Optical Imagery via Differentiable Rendering
authors: Chenxing Mao, Weiwei Guo, Zenghui Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal on Miniaturization for Air and Space Systems
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) reconstruction of ground targets from multimodal remote sensing data is vital for miniaturized air systems, enabling applications such as autonomous navigation, surveillance, and environmental monitoring. This paper presents a new multimodal fusion framework for 3D target reconstruction by jointly exploiting multi-view synthetic aperture radar (SAR) and optical images. The proposed framework incorporates an integrated differentiable render for both SAR and optical images in the forward process, enabling efficient generation of simulated SAR and optical images under diverse imaging geometries. In the backward process, a new gradient-based optimization strategy is introduced to iteratively refine the 3D target model by minimizing the discrepancy between the simulated images and the observed SAR and optical images. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed framework, highlighting its potential for accurate 3D reconstruction in complex multimodal remote sensing scenarios.

title: Autonomous Slip-Prevention Grip Force Control and Its Potential in Shared Control of Robotic Prosthetic Hands
authors: Joseph Berman, Varun Nalam, Jie Yin, He Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: This study aimed to develop and validate a novel autonomous slip-prevention grip force controller for a robotic prosthetic hand. The controller utilized an optical flow sensor to detect object slippage events, which triggered increases in the desired gripping force within a closed-loop force control system. We first validated the slip-prevention functionality on a bench test platform. Subsequently, the controller was integrated into a simple shared control framework to demonstrate its feasibility in enhancing the grasping function for prosthesis users. In this shared control framework, myoelectric position control (i.e., user control) was employed when the hand was not engaged in a grasp, while the intelligent autonomous grip force control was activated during contact with an object. The feasibility of the shared control was tested with human participants performing tasks involving the grasping, transferring, and releasing of various objects while using and wearing the prosthetic hand. Additionally, we compared the shared control to a myoelectric-only controller (without the autonomous grip force control) in the object manipulation task combined with a secondary cognitive task. The results demonstrated that the proposed automatic grip force controller effectively prevented slips and improved grasping stability under various perturbations. Compared to myoelectric-only control, the shared control reduced the user’s cognitive effort required for object manipulation and lead to increased task success. While our designed slip-prevention grip force controller shows significant potential to assist the prosthesis users in improving grasping functionality, further exploration of other shared control paradigms is necessary to maximize user performance and acceptance in the future.

title: Synchronous Enhancement of Sensitivity and Frequency of Piezoelectric Micromachined Ultrasonic Transducers Operating in the Second-Order Flexural Mode_supp1-3636207.docx
authors: Lufeng Che
abstract: Piezoelectric Micromachined Ultrasonic Transducers (PMUTs) are widely used in sensing applications, where high-order modes of PMUT can be used to enhance sensing accuracy. However, in existing works, when PMUTs work at a high-order resonance mode, their weak amplitude of flexural vibration and sound pressure cancellation from opposite membrane motions result in low sensitivity. Here, we demonstrate a novel PMUT with double-turn slots at the edge of the membrane, transforming the fully-clamped membrane into a suspended structure, thus modifying the mode shape. When the PMUT operates in the second-order mode, the structure alleviates sound pressure cancellation, and enables large vibration amplitude, thus enhancing both sensitivity and frequency. AlN-based PMUT prototypes are fabricated on a 4-inch wafer with CMOS compatible processes for validation. Compared to fully-clamped PMUTs operating in the fundamental resonance mode, the central displacements of the two devices with different slot angles are increased by 153% and 84%, their frequencies are improved by 59% and 189%, respectively, and the round-trip sensitivity is enhanced by 5.47 dB. As demonstration examples, pulse-echo-based ranging and imaging are explored using a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3\times 5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> PMUT array. The ranging accuracy is 0.65 mm with a maximum distance of 50 mm, and the imaging deviation is 0.6 mm at a distance of 2 cm. These results demonstrate great application potential of this innovative design.

title: Wide Angle Azimuthal Null Frequency Scanning Antenna under Multimode Resonance
authors: Xin-Yao Li, Wen-Jun Lu, Xiao-Hui Mao, Wei Zhou, Lei Zhu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: Design approach to wide angle azimuthal null frequency scanning antennas (ANFSAs) under triple-mode resonance is proposed. A 1.75-wavelength asymmetric prototype magnetic dipole is mapped into an asymmetric circular sector patch antenna under the principal, fifth-order mode resonance. As a result, the null scanning range can be significantly extended owing to the dominant fifth-order resonance, such that the azimuth null scanning range can be enhanced by 30% compared to the traditional one under third-order resonance. A prototype antenna with central angle of α = 300° is designed, fabricated, and measured to validate the design approach. On the one hand, it is demonstrated that prototype antenna exhibits a single null scanning range from ϕ = 266° to 84°, which nearly covers half of the horizontal plane, within an available band ranging from 2.23 to 2.91GHz for null depth smaller than -10dB. On the other hand, the proposed antenna bears a simple, relatively compact size without incorporating external parasitic elements owing to the asymmetric structure.

title: Enhancing Drug Discovery Through Transformer-Based Classification and Regression Models for Bioactivity Estimation
authors: Yasmine E. Mahmoud, Ehab E. Hassanein, Farid Ali, Yassin M. Nissan, Ayman El-Kilany
abstract: The drug discovery process is a complex and resource-demanding enterprise, marked by extended durations and substantial financial investment. Typically, a novel medicinal chemical requires six to twelve years to advance from original idea to market release, highlighting the urgent necessity for innovative techniques to accelerate this process.This study presents a transformer-based dual-stage predictive framework that combines an initial bioactivity categorization module with a subsequent regression model to improve molecular activity prediction. The methodology was assessed on two structurally varied CHEMBL-derived datasets and shown enhanced stability and prediction accuracy relative to conventional autoencoder and Chemprop benchmarks. The framework adeptly encapsulates both discrete and continuous structure-activity correlations, providing a scalable and computationally efficient solution for contemporary drug development processes. The integration of deep learning techniques into the drug discovery process has demonstrated significant potential in overcoming these obstacles. Utilizing the capacity of deep learning models to examine extensive and complex datasets, researchers can augment the prediction and assessment of molecular bioactivities, improve compound optimization, and enhance lead finding methods. This paper presents an innovative deep learning architecture intended to aid chemists in accurately evaluating the biological activity of chemical compounds, with the goal of substantially improving the drug discovery process while ensuring precision and dependability in predicting results. The proposed framework utilizes a Transformer Classifier to categorize the compounds data, then developing a customized Transformer Regression model to accurately estimate the bioactivity of the compounds. The proposed framework attained a classification accuracy of 82.5% and a mean absolute error (MAE) of 2.13 in predicting compound bioactivity utilizing a transformer regression model.

title: Digital Twins as Predictive Models for Real-Time Probabilistic Risk Assessment of Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Kalpit Vadnerkar, Pierluigi Pisu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Autonomous vehicle deployment demands real-time risk assessment systems capable of detecting sensor faults without extensive labeled fault datasets. While physics-based models lack adaptability and data-driven approaches require rare fault data, nominal driving data is abundant. We present a digital twin framework that learns exclusively from fault-free operation to detect anomalies through prediction-observation residuals. Our Spatio-Temporal Graph Attention Network (ST-GAT) fuses multimodal sensor data with HD map topology, explicitly quantifying both epistemic and aleatoric uncertainties through deep ensembles. The framework compares real-time observations against predicted nominal behavior using three residual types (Raw, KL Divergence, CUSUM), achieving 93.7% fault detection accuracy with 1.13ms processing time across Camera, IMU, and LiDAR faults. Principal component analysis reduces the 540-dimensional residual space to 8 components while preserving 95% variance, enabling Random Forest classification with 200 trees. Feature importance analysis reveals Traffic Light Status Flag (29.7%) and CUSUM residuals as most discriminative, validating our hypothesis that sensor faults manifest as persistent accumulated deviations. Unlike existing approaches requiring fault-labeled data or perfect sensors, our sensor-agnostic framework provides interpretable, real-time fault detection generalizable across operational domains, advancing practical autonomous vehicle safety systems.

title: SSM-Det: State Space Model-Based Object Detector for Intelligent Transportation System
authors: Jiaqi Wang, Chunmian Lin, Kan Guo, Jiangang Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The State Space Model (SSM) has been a growth of interest in computer vision due to its long-term dependency modeling with linear complexity. Despite massive endeavor, it has not been extensively explored in intelligent transportation system (ITS) yet. In this paper, we propose State Space Model-based object Detector (SSM-Det), that is meticulously curated with Direction-aware Visual State Space Encoder (D-VSSE). Specifically, it customizes multi-path pixel exchange and patch re-arrangement via four-direction scanning mechanism, promoting for information communication. To bridge the information bottleneck across high-low level, we further design Split-Fusion (SF) and Skip-Connection (SC) modules for contextual feature propagation before decoding: SF performs multi-channel semantic separation and re-weighting in global-local scope, while SC is responsible for cross-layer feature interaction in a cascaded manner. Empirical studies is conducted on both VisDrone2019-DET and SEU_PML benchmarks, and our proposed SSM-Det reports the state-of-the-art performance against all counterparts by a substantial margin, while maintaining the real-time inference speed. We hope this work contributes to the in-depth investigation of SSM-based detector for intelligent transportation applications. The code is available at https://buaawjq.github.io/SSM-Det/.

title: Silent Data Corruption– Optimal Mitigation Strategies for Datacenter Computing
authors: Nirmal Saxena, Saurabh Hukerikar, Siva Hari
abstract: Given current datacenter compute scales, extended job durations, and existing detection mechanisms, the risk of silent data corruption (SDC) exposure is substantial. Leveraging existing detection coverage and SDC characteristics, we propose optimized SDC mitigation strategies that balance availability and reliability. These optimization strategies strive to achieve Shannon’s like bounds on the overhead required for reliable (meaning SDC mitigation) compute channels. While error-correcting codes effectively address transient faults in memory, storage, and high-speed links, residual SDC risks persist. We advocate for algorithm-based error detection (ABED) to bridge this gap and stress the need for ongoing ABED research to adapt to evolving compute patterns. Low-level fault simulation for SDC assessment in long-running jobs is impractical; instead, near-real-time evaluation is essential. Although our approach partially addresses systematic faults, robust design verification and manufacturing tests remain critical for comprehensive fault management. This work highlights the urgency of scalable, efficient SDC detection in large-scale systems.

title: Sample-Efficient LOS/NLOS Identification in Wi-Fi 6 with COTS Devices
authors: Jian Wang, Lixing Wang, Haotian Zhang, Qingxu Deng, Wei Fang, Daqing Chen, Chao Shi, Jingyu Dong
abstract: Accurate LOS/NLOS identification is essential for robust Wi-Fi localization and sensing, yet existing COTS-based methods suffer from high data requirements (e.g., 100-500 packets) and AGC-induced amplitude distortion. To overcome these limitations, we propose two AGC-robust features: CIR Decay, capturing post-peak energy decay in the time-domain channel impulse response, and SEoAR (Sample Entropy of Amplitude Ratios), quantifying frequency-domain signal complexity using CSI amplitude ratios that inherently cancel AGC effects. Evaluated on Wi-Fi 6 COTS devices, our approach achieves 94% weighted accuracy with only 10 CSI packets, reducing data needs by over 90% compared to PhaseU and LiFi. This ultra-low sample dependency enables real-time, lightweight LOS/NLOS identification on resource-constrained edge platforms.

title: TerraSAP: Spatially-Aware Prompt-Based Framework for Few-Shot Class-Incremental Learning in Remote Sensing Image Classification
authors: Jiaxing Zeng, Yifeng Tan, Lina Yang, Siwei Zhang, Lianhui Liang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The core challenge of Few-Shot Class-Incremental Learning (FSCIL) lies in continuously learning new categories with extremely few samples without forgetting old knowledge. However, the performance of general FSCIL solutions is often limited when directly applied to the remote sensing domain. This limitation stems from two unique challenges of remote sensing images, namely complex and explicit spatial structural relationships and significant intra-class heterogeneity. Most existing methods fail to adequately model these characteristics. To address this issue, this paper proposes an efficient framework designed specifically for remote sensing scenarios, called TerraSAP. To tackle the aforementioned challenges, the framework systematically addresses the unique problems of remote sensing FSCIL through two core designs. First, to overcome the limitation of lacking spatial priors, we propose a Spatially-Aware Prompt Module. It explicitly injects the inherent spatial topological structure priors of remote sensing images into deep features through deterministic position encoding and attention mechanisms. Second, to overcome the learning difficulties caused by complex visual characteristics, we design a synergistic mechanism for new-class learning and knowledge retention. This mechanism includes two core parts. First, it enhances the learning efficiency for sparse new classes through an NCAC-based prototype initialization strategy. Second, it achieves a fine balance between retaining old knowledge and learning new knowledge with an innovative Dual-Path Exponential Moving Average (EMA) mechanism. Experimental results show that TerraSAP achieves an average accuracy of 84.52% on the NWPU-RESISC45 dataset, with a significant improvement in new-class learning ability. It also achieves efficient parameter utilization with a 47.10% reduction in total parameters, a 93.20% reduction in trainable parameters, and a 27.80% increase in inference speed.

title: Radiation Tolerant Multi-Loop VCO Structures in 28-nm FDSOI Technology
authors: Jaime Cardenas Chavez, Ming Yan, Adriana Noguera Cundar, Xiaotong Lu, Tejinder Sandhu, Kamal El-Sankary, Li Chen
abstract: This manuscript investigates the use of different multi-loop voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) structures to mitigate single event effects (SEE). The first approach is a three-stage fully differential cross-coupled ring oscillator, designed with current regulation biasing to enhance supply noise rejection. The second is a fully differential current-mode logic (CML) multi-path ring oscillator with coarse/fine control. Both structures were fabricated in 28-nm FDSOI technology. The cross-coupled ring VCO exhibits enhanced performance when using the high-current configuration, showing a phase noise of -80.1 dBc/Hz at 1 MHz offset from the center frequency of 1.49 GHz and a figure of merit (FoM) of 140. Moreover, the CML multi-path VCO stands out as a high-performance structure with -93.4 dBc/Hz phase noise measured at 1 MHz offset from the 1.42 GHz carrier frequency and a FoM of 151. Single event effects (SEE) and total ionizing dose (TID) responses were evaluated using a 105 MeV proton beam and <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">60</sup>Co radiation, respectively. Experimental results demonstrated significant single event transient (SET) mitigation with both solutions, with the CML multi-path VCO exhibiting superior radiation tolerance with a maximum single event frequency transient (SEFT) of 4.2% and a maximum recovery time of 1.3 ns. Both designs showed high TID tolerance up to 300 krads.

title: Interpretable Machine Learning Models for Vitamin A Deficiency Screening in School-Aged Children
authors: Jayroop Ramesh, Stalin Sabu Thomas, Amar Hassan Khamis, Assim Sagahyroon, Fadi Aloul, Adel Rushood
abstract: Vitamin A deficiency (VAD) is one of the leading causes of visual impairment globally. While blood tests are common approaches in developed countries, socioeconomic and public perspectives render this a challenge in developing countries. In Africa and Southeast Asia, the alarming rise of preventable childhood blindness and delayed growth rates has been classified as an "epidemic". With the proliferation of machine learning in clinical support systems and the relative availability of electronic health records, there is a potential promise of early detection to curb ocular complication progression. In this work, the aim is to observe the feasibility of detecting Vitamin A deficiency in children by utilizing existing records using machine learning techniques instead of requiring retinol serum tests. For this purpose, a heterogeneous tabular dataset consisting of 18,423 unique patient records across 25 features belonging to the non-invasive ocular symptomatology and ophthalmological diagnoses was acquired from a children’s hospital in Maradi, Nigeria. Extensive empirical comparisons between traditional machine learning and deep learning methods are provided with their corresponding interpretability through attributions and shapley values. The achieved results indicate that in the case of sparse datasets, after rectification for class imbalances using SMOTE-NC, Random Forest, Light Gradient Boosting Model achieved the highest balanced scores of accuracy: 86.0%, sensitivity: 81.8%, specificity: 86.4% and F1-score: 72.7% respectively. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this is one of the first studies exploring the utility of routine eye examination records to screen for Vitamin A deficient individuals in a school-aged population. We conclude that machine learning can aid in identifying possible candidates for prioritized testing, dietary supplementation and treatment.

title: Adaptive Subarray Segmentation: A New Paradigm of Spatial Non-Stationary Near-Field Channel Estimation for XL-MIMO Systems
authors: Shuhang Yang, Puguang An, Peng Yang, Xianbin Cao, Dapeng Oliver Wu, Tony Q. S. Quek
abstract: To address the complexities of spatial non-stationary (SnS) effects and spherical wave propagation in near-field channel estimation (CE) for extremely large-scale multiple-input multiple-output (XL-MIMO) systems, this paper proposes an SnS-aware CE framework based on adaptive subarray partitioning. We first investigate spherical wave propagation and various SnS characteristics and construct an SnS near-field channel model for XL-MIMO systems. Due to the limitations of uniform subarray patterns in capturing SnS, we analyze the adverse effects of the non-ideal array segmentation (over- and under-segmentation) on CE accuracy. To counter these issues, we develop a dynamic hybrid beamforming-assisted power-based subarray segmentation paradigm (DHBF-PSSP), which integrates power measurements with a dynamic hybrid beamforming structure to enable joint subarray partitioning and decoupling. A power-adaptive subarray segmentation (PASS) algorithm leverages the statistical properties of power profiles, while subarray decoupling is achieved via a subarray segmentation-based sampling method (SS-SM) under radio frequency (RF) chain constraints. For subarray CE, we propose a subarray segmentation-based assorted block sparse Bayesian learning algorithm under the multiple measurement vectors framework (SS-ABSBL-MMV). This algorithm exploits angular-domain block sparsity under a discrete Fourier transform (DFT) codebook and inter-subcarrier structured sparsity. Simulation results confirm that the proposed framework outperforms existing methods in CE performance.

title: Stable Trajectory Tracking of Magnetic Swarms Under Uncertain Viscosity: An Adaptive Robust Lyapunov Redesign
authors: Qigao Fan, Xu Han, Yueyue Liu, Xinzhe Tang, Xinyu Liu, Xiaoli Luan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Magnetic microrobotic swarms are increasingly studied for their potential in precise motion control under complex and uncertain environments. One of the core challenges in swarm-level control lies in achieving accurate trajectory tracking in the presence of time-varying dynamic parameters, such as fluid resistance. To address such problem, we incorporate error integration into the swarms control framework and derive a kinematic model through model transformation. Based on this model, a Lyapunov-based adaptive robust control strategy is developed to ensure closed-loop stability and compensate for environmental uncertainties. The proposed controller dynamically adapts to unknown environmental variations, and rigorous theoretical analysis establishes the asymptotic stability of the system. A series of experiments are conducted on an electromagnetic actuation platform using silicone oil environments with different viscosities (5 cSt, 10 cSt, and 15 cSt) as well as under a rapidly varying viscosity generated by syringe pump to validate the method. Experimental results confirm that the proposed strategy enables the microrobotic swarm to achieve stable and precise trajectory tracking under varying resistance conditions, demonstrating its robustness and adaptability.

title: FLEX: Flexible Linked EXecution for Real-Time Embedded Hotpatching
authors: Heeseung Son, BeomSeok Kim, Ben Lee, Jinsung Cho
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: With the rapid advancement in information technology, embedded systems have become integral to a wide range of critical applications. These systems often require continuous operation and cannot tolerate the downtime associated with traditional software updates, which typically necessitate a system reboot. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel hotpatching technique called Flexible Linked EXecution (FLEX) designed specifically for real-time embedded environments. FLEX enables seamless, dynamic firmware updates by redirecting all function calls and global variable accesses through a compile time generated Control Flow Table (CFT). In contrast to existing hotpatching approaches that depend on specialized hardware or impose strict limits on the number of patches and their size, FLEX is entirely hardware independent and supports scalable patching capacity bounded only by available flash memory and RAM. FLEX offers several unique features, including a relaxed consistency state synchronization mechanism to allow for gradual migration of program state, resolving all symbols at compile time into CFT indirections, applying updates via a double-buffered pointer swap to a new CFT, and a XIP compatible process that guarantees only a short, bounded pause time regardless of patch complexity. Experimental results show that FLEX maintains system stability and performance with an average execution overhead of about 11% and a predictable increase in flash memory usage of roughly 17%. These findings suggest that FLEX offers a robust and flexible solution for dynamically updating the software of embedded systems to ensure high availability and security without sacrificing performance.

title: Improving Emotion and Intent Understanding in Multimodal Conversations with Progressive Interaction
authors: Li Zheng, Tengyue Song, Yuzhe Ding, Xiaorui Wu, Fei Li, Dongdong Xie, Jinbo Li, Chong Teng, Donghong Ji
abstract: Emotion and intent joint understanding in multimodal conversations (MC-EIU) aims to model the semantic dependencies among multimodal conversations while inferring emotion and intent information. Despite making progress, existing methods overlook the differential contributions of modalities and rely on single-round interactions for emotion and intent recognition, resulting in suboptimal model understanding performance. To overcome these limitations, we propose MEIPro, a novel progressive interaction and adaptive weight fusion based multimodal joint understanding of emotion and intent framework. We first design a hierarchical denoising module to effectively remove noise and redundant information from multimodal data. Then, we propose an adaptive weight fusion mechanism that dynamically fuses multimodal features by taking the true classification probabilities of each modality as their respective contributions, thus enhancing the fusion process. Additionally, we present a progressive dual task interaction module to capture the deep seated interactions between emotion and intent through a step-by-step multi-round iteration. Experiments on the benchmark MC-EIU bilingual dataset demonstrate that our MEI-Pro framework significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in both emotion and intent tasks. Specifically, on the English dataset, the F1-scores of the multimodal emotion and intent understanding tasks have increased by 6.12% and 7.25% respectively.

title: Comparative Analysis of Classification Algorithms for Mango Leaves Disease Detection
authors: Lea P. Ymalay, Felicisimo V. Wenceslao, Patrick D. Cerna
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This study is directed towards a Comparative Analysis of Classification Algorithms for Mango Leaves Disease Detection in the province of Guimaras, Philippines. Traditionally, disease detection in mango leaves relies on manual inspections by experts in different mango farms in the province of Guimaras, which is time-consuming, laborintensive, and prone to human error. Three machine learning and classification algorithms, namely Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and the Otsu algorithm, were used to compare the effectiveness in classifying mango diseases. The comparative analysis found that among the three classification algorithms, the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model achieved the highest accuracy (90%), F1score (90 %), recall (90 %), and precision (90 %). It was followed by the SVM with an accuracy of 85.80 %, F1-score of 85.70 %, recall of 85.80 %, and precision of 85.90 %, and the Otsu algorithm with an accuracy of 59.90 %, F1-score of 59.50 %, recall of 59.90 %, and precision of 60 %. The results of the study will serve as a basis for developing a prediction system to detect mango diseases using leaf samples.
