title: Study on the Bioimpedance and fNIRS Bimodal Method for Frontal Brain Investigation
authors: Zhihong He, Qiang Du, Yunfeng Bai, Li Ke
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: When brain function occurs, it is usually accompanied by changes in cerebral blood flow (CBF) and oxygen consumption metabolism <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{CMRO}_{2}\right)$</tex>. In order to explore the effects of brain functional activities on frontal cerebral blood flow and oxygen consumption metabolism under working memory load and the coupling relationship between the two, this paper combined bioimpedance detection technology and functional near-infrared detection technology(fNIRS), and proposed a bimodal hemodynamic response synchronous detection and analysis method. Based on the characteristics of impedance area and hemoglobin concentration, the calculation model of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CMRO}_{2}$</tex> is established, and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CBF}/\text{CMRO}_{2}$</tex> coupling coefficient is proposed. The method was verified and evaluated by working memory experiments. The results showed that although the response mode of frontal lobe blood flow and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CMRO}_{2}$</tex> related to working memory was similar, the response amplitude and speed of CBF were higher than that of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CMRO}_{2}$</tex>. In addition, the CBF/CMRO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> coupling coefficient under low memory load is higher than that under high memory load, which may reflect the difference in the brain's regulation mode of blood flow and metabolism in the face of different workloads, by providing sufficient blood supply to cope with low load demand, and by improving energy utilization efficiency to ensure high load demand.

title: Partial Multivariate Transformer as a Tool for Cryptocurrencies Time Series Prediction
authors: Andrzej Tokajuk, Jarosław A. Chudziak
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Forecasting cryptocurrency prices is hindered by extreme volatility and a methodological dilemma between information-scarce univariate models and noise-prone full-multivariate models. This paper investigates a partialmultivariate approach to balance this trade-off, hypothesizing that a strategic subset of features offers superior predictive power. We apply the Partial-Multivariate Transformer (PMformer) to forecast daily returns for BTCUSDT and ETHUSDT, benchmarking it against eleven classical and deep learning models. Our empirical results yield two primary contributions. First, we demonstrate that the partial-multivariate strategy achieves significant statistical accuracy, effectively balancing informative signals with noise. Second, we experiment and discuss an observable disconnect between this statistical performance and practical trading utility; lower prediction error did not consistently translate to higher financial returns in simulations. This finding challenges the reliance on traditional error metrics and highlights the need to develop evaluation criteria more aligned with realworld financial objectives.

title: Compositional Neural Distance Field with Latent Code Embedding for Dynamic Objects
authors: Xiang Gao, Zhisheng Zheng, Alois Knoll
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: In recent years, implicit neural representation of 3D scenes has evolved significantly and has been rapidly extended to multiple application scenarios. However, using this type of approach for highly dynamic urban scenes remains a challenging problem. Typical images of objects captured by cameras on board autonomous vehicles from one trajectory contains limited number of views, leading unsatisfactory reconstruction quality. To address this problem, we propose a novel hybrid network structure that decomposes the urban scene into a static background and multiple dynamic objects. The background model outputs a signed distance field with its accuracy enhanced by surface constraints. To deal with the issues of insufficient camera view we use a pre-training strategy to leverage shape and appearance prior to the object model from external datasets. We design an autoencoder architecture to encode a category of objects and employ an attention-based fusion module to better extract features from multiple object images. Furthermore, we introduce a “symmetric completion” approach to leverage the inherent symmetry property of normal cars. During experiments with data from Carla Platform, we find that our model can reconstruct scenes with high-fidelity, generate novel-view successfully and edit 3D scene freely.

title: A Lightweight Hybrid Compressed Convolutional Neural Network for Sleep Apnea Detection
authors: Jiaying Li, Yifan Xu, Hao Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and electrocardiogram (ECG) have become hot topics in the field of sleep apnea diagnosis, as they are easier to operate, more affordable and comfortable compared to traditional polysomnography. However, due to the necessity of substantial memory and computation requirements, the deployment of CNN models in wearable devices poses significant challenges. To address this issue, this paper proposes a lightweight hybrid compressed convolutional neural network model based on improved multi-stage channel pruning and quantization-aware training (QAT). For the problem of sleep apnea detection on the Apnea-ECG dataset, the proposed method reduces model parameters by 24% while maintaining the same level of detection accuracy as the state-of-the-art (SOTA) method. This enhancement improves the balance between accuracy and hardware resources, providing a more efficient solution for deploying convolutional neural networks for sleep apnea detection on wearable devices.

title: Influence of Thermophoresis on the Deposition of Limestone Dust Particles on Solar Panel Surfaces
authors: Momchil Vassilev, Borislav Stankov, Penka Zlateva, Ivan Dimchev, Marzhan Karimoldanova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: In areas located near major dust sources such as cement plants and limestone quarries, surface soiling due to particle accumulation can significantly diminish the energy output of solar panels. This study investigates the potential of thermophoresis to mitigate the deposition of airborne limestone dust on photovoltaic (PV) surfaces. A full factorial experiment comprising <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> simulations was conducted to assess the influence of particle diameter, wind speed, and ambient and surface temperatures on dust settling behavior. The analysis is based on a mathematical model that evaluates the thermophoretic and gravitational forces acting on a single particle carried by a parallel forced convection flow over an isothermal horizontal plate. Results indicate that thermophoresis effectively counteracts deposition for particles smaller than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> in diameter, with a dominant effect observed below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.55 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> even under low wind speeds and modest thermal gradients. These findings underscore the importance of incorporating thermophoretic effects into predictive models for solar panel soiling. These results are significant for the optimization of PV systems, especially in regions with high dust concentrations, and may contribute to the development of surface coatings with enhanced anti-soiling properties.

title: Exploring Common Core Targets of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Ulcerative Colitis and Causal Relationship with Intestinal Flora Through Bioinformatics Analysis
authors: Qian Yu, Tao Han, Zuojing Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and ulcerative colitis (UC) may share overlapping pathogenic mechanisms, potentially mediated by gut microbiota (GM). In this study, differential gene expression data from the GEO database were analyzed to identify core targets and pathways using Cytoscape and GSEA. Genome-wide association study (GWAS) datasets for T2DM (ebi-a-GCST006867) and UC (ukb-a-104) were used for two-sample Mendelian randomization (MR) to explore causal associations between microbial taxa and disease. The inverse variance weighting (IVW) method served as the primary MR approach, supported by MR-Egger, weighted median, and MRPRESSO to test for robustness. Four core genes and pathways were identified, and several gut microbes were found to have potential causal effects on both T2DM and UC. These findings highlight shared molecular mechanisms and provide insights into potential microbiota-targeted therapeutic strategies.

title: Inheritance of Family Companies as an Element of Intergenerational Businesses in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Poland, Romania and Uzbekistan
authors: Daniel Pavlov, Denitsa Zagorcheva, Margarita Bakracheva, Hamza Smajić, Laura Raisa Milo, Anna Wójcik-Karpacz, Šejma Aydin, Suzana Demyen, Joanna Rudawska, Aslitdin Nizamov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The inheritance of family businesses is a problem that many entrepreneurs face at the end of their successful activity. The goal of this article is to analyze some preconditions for the successful inheritance of family companies from one generation to another on the basis of two factors: the positive intra-family attitude towards the inheritance of family businesses and the existence of national regulatory frameworks to regulate the inheritance. The objectives are: (1) to present basic legal documents from Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Poland, Romania and Uzbekistan regulating the inheritance of family businesses, and (2) to present a comparative study on student responses from these countries as regards their intentions of having joint businesses with their relatives. The data has been collected by each co-author for the related country within the international academic network of INTERGEN in 2021 and 2023. The target groups were students and alumni from universities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Poland, Romania and Uzbekistan; the number of respondents is 2496.

title: Aggregated Dataset vs. Ensemble Learning for Spatial Transferability in Water Demand Forecasting
authors: Claudia Maussner, Erich Teppan
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Accurate water demand forecasting is crucial for sustainable resource management. State-of-the-art prediction methods building on machine- and deep learning perform well in capturing complex consumption patterns in time series data and provide accurate predictions. However, a major challenge for fresh water suppliers that has remained widely unaddressed so long, is how to transfer prediction models of different geographic regions to another area for which there is no specific knowledge or data available. We call this concept spatial transferability. Based on a real-world data set of ten regions in North-East Italy, we propose and compare different approaches to enable spatial transferability of prediction models. Our approaches build on the one hand on the aggregation of the available data sets, i.e. the combination of the different training inputs, and on the other hand on ensemble techniques, i.e. the combination of the different models' outputs. The underlying basic model types range from rather simple linear models to more complex ones, like long short term memory. Results show that by applying our proposed techniques, the induced transfer error can be kept below one percent on average.

title: Numerically Controlled Optomechatronic System for Capture of Solar Energy
authors: Daniel Besnea, Iolanda Constanţa Panait, Edgar Moraru, Victor Constantin, Vlad-Andrei Stănescu, Laurenţiu-Adrian Cartal, Ionela-Mihaela Popescu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The paper presents an optomechatronic solar energy capture system composed of an orientation system on two numerically controlled axes that allows the precise positioning of a solar energy capture system consisting of a reflective panel with easily configurable mirrors that take the sun's rays and directs them through a condenser consisting of an optical glass lens (a plane converging lens) that receives and condenses the sun's rays to a fixed point where a temperature sensor is placed. The calculation and design of the optical system components is carried out in the Delphi programming environment and the command of the mechatronic orientation system on the three axes is carried out with the help of a development board with a microcontroller.

title: Predicting the Performance of an Internal Combustion Engine Using Linear Models
authors: Simeon P. Iliev, Georgi Krastev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The aim of this study is to predict the power characteristics of internal combustion engines using linear models. For the purpose of the study, experimental data from a single-cylinder gasoline engine were used. The main goal was to examine how blending n-butanol with gasoline affects the power performance of a port fuel injection (PFI) engine. The following additives were studied additions of n-butanol (5%, 10% and 15% by volume) to net gasoline and were investigated and the their effect on brake power.

title: TR-MGI: a temporal reasoning support for multiple instantiations of guidelines
authors: Paolo Terenziani, Antonella Andolina, Andrea Terenziani
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Clinical guidelines represent the “best” clinical procedures to manage patients affected by a specific disease, and are widely used to promote evidence-based medicine to standardize, improve and optimize clinical practice. In the Artificial Intelligence literature, many approaches to computerized clinical guidelines (CIGs) have been devised to provide physicians with decision support in the application of clinical guidelines to patients. Temporal constraints between actions (e.g., the duration of actions, the delay between them) are an essential part of many clinical guidelines, and a lot of attention has been devoted to their representation in CIGs systems. On the other hand, only few CIG systems have faced the related temporal reasoning issues, and none of them has faced them in a “realworld” context in which multiple instantiations of CIGs, on different patients, must be considered (e.g., to schedule the activities in a ward of an hospital). In this paper, we overcome such a limitation, proposing a temporal support (representation + reasoning) to deal with multiple CIG instantiations, which may be temporally related (e.g., to support the scheduling of shared resources). We take Asbru, one of the most widely used approaches in the CIG literature, as reference CIG formalism.

title: Efficient ASIC Implementation of ALE-NLMS and ANN-LMS Filters for Biomedical Signal Enhancement Across Scaled CMOS Technologies
authors: Jayanthi Chittipothala, K Sathesh
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: This paper investigates the ASIC implementation and comparative analysis of ALE-NLMS and ANN-LMS adaptive filters across 180nm, 90nm, and 45nm CMOS technologies for biomedical signal enhancement. The ALE-NLMS architecture achieves a remarkable 92% area reduction (307.50mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 24.71mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) and 76% net power reduction (5.405mW to 1.264mW) when scaled from 180nm to 45nm. Similarly, ANN-LMS shows an 86% area improvement (375.21mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 52.82mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) with 81% lower net power consumption (217.979mW to 41.522mW). Architectural complexity scales appropriately, with ALE-NLMS gate counts increasing from 8340 to 11346 logic gates. The 45nm implementations provide optimal performance-power-area trade-offs, making them particularly suitable for wearable medical devices requiring real-time processing of physiological signals. These findings offer critical insights for designing next-generation biomedical ASICs, highlighting the advantages of deep submicron CMOS technologies for implementing energy-efficient adaptive signal processing solutions in healthcare applications.

title: Design and evaluation of a concave blade to minimize damage to cocoa beans using a rotary roller system using ANSYS Static Structural and Explicit Dinamic
authors: Jorge Aguilar Sanchez, Jesus Fernando Huaman Fernandez, Joel Figueroa Vilcarromero
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: In Perú, the manual process of cracking the cocoa pod is carried out with machetes or wooden mallets. This causes significant damage to the beans. Therefore, this study aimed to design, simulate and implement a cocoa pod cracking machine with counter-rotating rollers and concave blades at an appropriate inclination angle, in order to reduce mechanical damage and improve the efficiency of bean extraction. To achieve this goal, structural and dynamic simulations were performed at ANSYS to evaluate the behavior of the blades at different angles. The angle that performed best was 60° because it produced the lowest maximum stress, reaching a safety factor of 4.2 in the dynamic simulation. Subsequently, experiments were carried out varying the size of the cocoa pod, the speed of the roller and the storage time. From these experiments, an average bean damage of 0.577% and an extraction efficiency of more than 96% was achieved. In addition, the overall test processed 192.2 kg of cobs, resulting in minimal grain damage of 0.333% and extraction efficiency of 96.71%. Therefore, our design proved to be efficient, low-impact, scalable, and suitable for industrial applications, with potential future improvements focused on fruit size sorting for further optimization

title: Digital Financial Literacy Implementation Through a Personal Finance Mobile App among Migrant Workers
authors: Setyo Ferry Wibowo, Dwi Kismayanti Respati, Ayatulloh Michael Musyaffi, Andi Muhammad Sadat, Unggul Purwohedi, Dian Dwi Hapsoro, Kristina Priurity, Maulana Amirul Adha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study aims to evaluate the impact of mobile application-based financial literacy training on changes in financial attitudes of migrant workers. A total of $\mathbf{5 0}$ participants participated in a financial literacy training program that utilized a mobile-based personal finance application. The research method used was a pre-test and post-test design, with paired t-test analysis to test differences in attitudes before and after training. The results showed that there was a significant increase in participants’ positive attitudes towards the use of financial applications after training ($\mathbf{p}\lt0.05$). This finding suggests that the use of digital technology in financial literacy training is effective in increasing acceptance and confidence in personal financial management. The discussion of the research results strengthens previous findings that digital financial literacy can improve financial management behavior, especially among vulnerable populations. The practical implications of this study are the importance of integrating digital technology into financial literacy programs to expand access and effectiveness of training. This study also underlines the need to develop application-based programs that are adaptive to the specific needs of migrant workers. Further research is recommended to evaluate the longterm impact of training on changes in actual financial behavior and expand the scope of respondents.

title: Inverted Split-Ring Resonator with Varactor Tuning for Controlling the Photon-Magnon Coupling in Quantum Magnonic Systems
authors: A. A. Girich, S. V. Nedukh, S. Yu. Polevoy, B. Rami, A. S. Vakula, K. Yu. Sova, S. I. Tarapov
abstract: Using numerical methods, we studied the strength of the photon-magnon (P-M) coupling in the hybrid system based on Inverted Split-Ring Resonator (ISRR) tuned with a varactor diode. Our results demonstrate that with for a varactor capacitance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C_{v}=0.01 \text{pF}$</tex>, the magnitude of the coupling strength between photons and microwave magnons reaches the highest value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$g / 2 \pi=663 \text{MHz}$</tex>. The strength of the P-M coupling normalized by the spin number (single spin-photon coupling) was found to be as high as 3.4101 Hz.

title: Solar Power Generation Prediction Using Advanced Deep Learning Approach for EV Applications
authors: S. Harish Kirthi, D. Dinesh Kumar, N. Manikandan, K. Vijayakumar, T. Dinesh, N. Janaki
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: Accurate solar power prediction plays a pivotal role in the effective management of Electric Vehicle (EV) charging systems, especially in smart energy networks. This paper presents an advanced Deep Learning (DL) based approach for solar power generation forecasting. Historical and real-time solar power generation datasets are collected and undergo comprehensive preprocessing, including data cleaning and normalization, to ensure quality and consistency. The preprocessed dataset is then split into training and testing sets to develop a reliable predictive model. A hybrid DL architecture combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Gated Recurrent Units (GRU), and an attention mechanism is utilized to extract spatial-temporal features and focus on critical input parameters, thereby improving forecasting accuracy. Furthermore, model optimization is carried out using the Chimp Optimization Algorithm (ChOA), which efficiently tunes models hyperparameter by simulating intelligent search behavior. The proposed work implemented using Python and demonstrates strong forecasting capability, achieves MAE of 0.03 and RMSE of 0.09.

title: Theoretical study of design aspects of inductive partial discharge sensors with focus on the novel flux concentrator concept
authors: Bastian Zimmer, Carlos Fernando Hermosilla Morales, Frank Jenau
abstract: Online condition monitoring of medium-voltage cables is effectively performed through partial discharge (PD) detection. High-frequency current transformers (HFCT’s) have proven particularly suitable for this purpose. A previous study introduced a novel sensor concept using a flux concentrator, which enables highly sensitive PD measurements even when the sensor is positioned around a current-carrying medium-voltage cable, without driving the core into magnetic saturation. This flux concentrator combines the sensitivity of conventional HFCT’s with the high dynamic range of sensors such as Rogowski coils. This publication presents a theoretical study of the winding characteristics and core design aspects of inductive sensors. The winding characteristics are discussed based on modelling the parasitic elements in an equivalent circuit diagram. The analysis of the core is based on finite element method (FEM) simulations, focusing on a systematic variation of parameters that are difficult to adjust experimentally. The results obtained from the study provide a comparative evaluation of the flux concentrator design and traditional HFCT designs that feature either non-existent or small air gaps. The aim of this work is to highlight specific design considerations and optimization strategies for inductive sensors used in PD measurement applications within medium-voltage systems.

title: Square-Shape Slope Index-Assisted NSGA-II Optimisation of a PV–Battery–Hydrogen Microgrid for Cost-Carbon Trade-Offs: A Formentera Community Case Study
authors: Bilal Hussein Al-Majali, Abdelaziz Abualshawareb
abstract: Remote islands and weak-grid communities are turning into microgrids that must cut carbon sharply while remaining financially sustainable. Most sizing studies, however, still optimize life cycle cost alone and treat climate performance as an after-thought. This work proposes a two-stage optimization framework that treats net-present cost (NPC) and life-cycle CO₂ emissions as co-equal objectives. Stage 1 employs an enhanced Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) to produce a well-spread Pareto front of photovoltaic, battery-storage and hydrogen configurations under hourly dispatch. The resulting frontier spans €0.85–1.25 million NPC and 68–85 g CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> kWh<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">⁻¹</sup> for a Mediterranean island case study (Formentera, Spain). Stage 2 ranks the nondominated solutions with the Square-Shape Slope Index (SSSI), a posteriori method that converts stakeholder cost-versuscarbon preferences into weights without rerunning the optimization. Using a carbon-aware weight, SSSI recommends a compromise design that raises NPC by only 4 % while lowering emissions by 5 % relative to the cost-optimal case. The workflow therefore delivers an intuitive, transparent and replicable benchmark for community-scale microgrid planning where economic and environmental priorities must be balanced explicitly.

title: Soil Moisture Distribution During Drip Irrigation of Tomatoes
authors: Vesela Petrova-Branicheva, Antoaneta Gigova, Emil Dimitrov, Roumen Gadjev, Yuriy Enakiev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The distribution of irrigation water in the soil, in clay soil, is an important aspect for the effective irrigation of agricultural crops. Clay soils have particularities that must be considered in irrigation management, as these soils have a high-water retention capacity, but also slow drainage. When irrigation is carried out unevenly or too quickly, clay soil can absorb water only in their upper layers, which leads to excessive moisture accumulation. This can cause reduced water absorption in the root zone of plants and lead to moisture deficit for plants in deeper layers. In the present study, an experimental study was conducted to evaluate the moisture distribution process under the surface of irrigation wings under drip irrigation and perpendicular irrigation 24 hours after irrigation, using both soil and irrigation system parameters. The experiments were conducted on leached Cinnamon soil at an emitter flow rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \mathrm{l} / \mathrm{h}$</tex> at four depths of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0,0.20,0.40$</tex> and 0.60 m, where the active root system is located. The results showed a relatively uniform distribution of moisture in the mass harvest in the layer <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-0.60 \mathrm{m}$</tex> in depth and in a radius of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.30-0.50 \mathrm{m}$</tex>, where the active root system is located at 100% irrigation rate. When the irrigation rate is reduced by 50%, a decrease in soil moisture below 80% of the FC at a depth of 0.20 m occurs, which leads to a decrease in production.

title: Dynamic Ransomware Threat Detection in MySQL Using Behavioural Profiling and Query Analytics
authors: Inchara K P, Harish K, Madhumala R B, Taha Kathiria, Ridha Mohammadi, Aakifa Aimen
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: The increasing complexity of database ransomware attacks calls for novel detection systems that can adjust to threats in real time. This study introduces Dynamic Vulnerability Profiling (DVP), a machine learning-based method for detecting ransomware query patterns by continuously modeling MySQL system vulnerabilities. By combining adaptive threat modeling, system behaviors, and real-time query sequence analysis, DVP attains 97.8% detection accuracy with less than 5% performance overhead. Resistant to sophisticated evasion strategies, such as polymorphic query obfuscation and multi-session attack distribution, are empirical evaluations. The framework's modular architecture allows for easy integration with current MySQL architectures while providing proactive defenses without interfering with business as usual. By filling important holes in signature-based detection and offering a scalable remedy for running so ware threats that are always changing, this study improves database security.

title: Green Energy Transition Along the Belt and Road: Opportunities and Challenges
authors: Georgi Chankov, Nikolay Hinov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is the world's largest infrastructure program, with energy projects forming its backbone. While traditionally dominated by fossil fuel investments, recent years have seen a gradual shift toward renewable energy, smart grids, and sustainable practices. This paper explores the integration of renewable energy projects into the BRI framework and discusses their role in the global green transition. Methodologically, the study combines literature review, case study analysis, and comparative perspectives between fossil-based and renewable BRI projects. Beyond synthesizing existing evidence, the paper provides a novel comparative framework linking energy technology choices with geopolitical strategies and highlights digitalization and AI integration as emerging drivers of the Green BRI. Results indicate a growing portfolio of solar, wind, hydro, and nuclear projects, though challenges remain in financing, host-country readiness, and environmental governance. The paper concludes with policy recommendations for enhancing the “Green BRI” and aligning it with global climate goals.

title: Atmospheric Influence on Quantum Key Distribution on the Earth-Space Channel in the Subterahertz Frequency Range
authors: I. V. Lesnov, V. F. Vdovin, M. V. Efimova
abstract: In recent decades researches of quantum cryptography has become one of the most promising area in the field of information security. Quantum key distribution (QKD) provides reliable methods for exchanging keys using the principles of quantum mechanics, ensuring a high level of security in data transmission. Of particular interest is the application of QKD in space communications, where communication channels can cover significant distances - from Earth to satellites. The most promising waveband for quantum communications and cryptography now is subterahertz (sub-THz) frequency range from 100 GHz to 1 THz. The influence of the atmosphere on the efficiency of quantum key distribution is essential for this waveband. The report provides an overview of the influence of the atmosphere on quantum key distribution within sub- THz frequency range. The advantages and disadvantages are analyzed, as well as solutions for increasing the efficiency of quantum key distribution.

title: Impact of Thruster-Induced Power Disturbances on LED Lighting in Shipboard Power Systems
authors: Dimitar Tsvetanov, Nikolai Djagarov, Georgi Enchev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Thruster start-up operations on ships can create severe power quality disturbances that directly affect onboard LED lighting. This paper presents a case study on a cargo vessel, where electrical and optical measurements were recorded in the engine control room. A voltage sag of approximately 6% during thruster engagement caused a 23% reduction in illuminance and pronounced flicker, with 18-20% modulation depth and a Flicker Index of about 0.19. The corresponding chromaticity shift (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta u^{\prime} v^{\prime} \approx 0.0048$</tex>) was near the CIE just noticeable difference threshold, indicating borderline perceptibility for many observers. Although the voltage and frequency deviations remained within classification and IEC/IEEE limits, the lighting fluctuations were clearly visible to the crew. These findings demonstrate that transient power disturbances from large propulsion loads can produce perceptible flicker and colour instability, underscoring the need for flicker-resistant shipboard lighting and improved transient mitigation strategies.

title: A Study of Bioimpedance-Based Functional Cerebral Blood Perfusion Detection Methods
authors: Shuxin Wang, Qiang Du, Yunfeng Bai, Li Ke
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Impedance testing can be used to obtain dynamic information on cerebral blood flow by monitoring changes in cerebral impedance caused by changes in local blood flow perfusion triggered by cerebral neural activity. In this paper, based on the study of cerebral impedance, we propose a blood perfusion calculation method based on the area of cerebral blood flow impedance to quantitatively characterize the blood perfusion in different brain regions, and analyze the changes of blood perfusion in bilateral frontal-parietal lobe brain regions under different brain functional activity states. The results showed that the blood perfusion in the frontal lobe was significantly larger than that in the parietal lobe, the blood perfusion in the left frontal lobe was larger than that in the right frontal lobe, and the recovery of blood perfusion in the frontal lobe was slower than that in the parietal lobe. The results show that the method proposed in this paper can realize the effective quantification of blood perfusion in different brain regions and reflect the differences in blood perfusion under different brain functional activity states, and is sensitive to the changes in blood perfusion in different populations and under different brain functional states. It realizes the assessment of brain blood supply status and correlation analysis with brain functional activity characteristics.

title: NP-Hardness and Approximation Algorithms for Constrained Entropy Maximization
authors: Roberto Bruno, Ugo Vaccaro
abstract: Given a random variable X that takes values in a finite set X = {x1, . . . , xn}, and a positive number R, we consider the problem of finding a deterministic function f : X → Y that maximizes the entropy H(f(X)), while satisfying the constraint H(f(X)) ≤ R. This problem occurs in several contexts, including lossy compression with logarithmic loss and the well-known Deterministic Information Bottleneck problem. We prove the NP-hardness of finding the optimal solution to the above maximization problem. On the positive side, we design approximation algorithms that achieve improved approximation factors compared to existing methods in the literature.

title: Single-Exposure Material Decomposition in Chest Tomosynthesis with a CdTe Photon-Counting Detector
authors: Soohyun Lee, Younghwan Lim, Sungmin Park, Okkyun Lee, Bo Kyung Cha, Hyosung Cho
abstract: Dual-energy material decomposition enables differentiation of soft tissue and bone in X-ray imaging; however, conventional methods require two sequential exposures, increasing radiation dose, acquisition time, and the risk of misregistration. This study presents a single-exposure material decomposition method using a cadmium telluride (CdTe)-based photon-counting detector (PCD) integrated with digital tomosynthesis (DTS). The proposed framework consists of three key steps: 1) simultaneous acquisition of low- and high-energy projections with dual thresholds (25 and 65 keV), 2) calibration-based decomposition using a PMMA–Al wedge phantom, and 3) projection-domain material separation followed by DTS reconstruction. Validation through both simulation and experimental studies demonstrated accurate separation of soft-tissue and bone components, high projection-level decomposition precision (RMSE: 0.052 for PMMA; 0.012 for Al), and improved perceptual image quality (SSIM: 0.979 and 0.974; PSNR: 37.6 and 38.6 dB). Compared with conventional energy-integrating detector (EID)-based dual-energy methods, the proposed PCD-based approach achieved superior structural preservation, contrast uniformity, and image interpretability. Beyond chest imaging, this single-exposure PCD framework is also applicable to non-medical X-ray applications, such as industrial nondestructive testing, security screening, and material characterization.

title: Twin Pipeline: AI Sibling of CI/CD
authors: Yash Salvi, Isha Kanade
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: CI/CD pipelines have become an integral part of today's software development processes, where they help in rapid integration and deployment of code changes. Despite that, they are associated with long execution times, flaky tests and high resource consumption which lead them to become less efficient. Even with state of the art AI driven optimizations, developers frequently need to rerun pipelines to diagnose and correct problems, which results in time being wasted while waiting for pipeline execution to finish and unnecessary resource consumptions. These inefficiencies slow down the development cycle and increase the cost of infrastructure, making CI/CD less effective at scale. This paper introduces the AI Twin Pipeline, a predictive system that simulates CI/CD execution outcomes before running the actual pipeline. By analyzing past pipeline executions and applying predictive modeling, it identifies potential failure points, offers corrective insights to address detected issues, and estimates the execution time of the actual CI/CD pipeline. Developers can debug and resolve issues upfront, reducing unnecessary pipeline runs and improving development efficiency. Unlike existing AI-optimized CI/CD solutions that focus on optimizations after the pipeline is triggered, the AI Twin Pipeline proactively identifies failures before triggering CI/CD thus, minimizing redundant submissions and optimizing resource utilization. This novel approach empowers developers with faster feedback, ensuring more reliable code submissions while significantly improving CI/CD pipeline performance.

title: AyurMi: A Synergistic Approach to Mental Wellness through AI and Ayurvedic Mindfulness
authors: Bhargavi Chauhan, Tanishka Badnaware, Sriya Maharana, Sneha Patil, Prema Kadam
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: In today's highly connected and rapidly changing world, mental health is often available and even undermined from our lifestyle to stresses, and a lack of personal practices of self-care. This paper presents AyurMi, an AI-powered journaling and wellness platform that fully combines ancient Ayurvedic principles with modern-day technologies like natural language processing (NLP), sentiment analysis, and chatbot technology. AyurMi offers users an emotionally intelligent journaling system, sentiment analysis feedback, dosha-based diagnostics and wellness advice recommendations based on the user input. Built with the Streamlit framework and powered by Dialogflow ES for conversational support, AyurMi offers users a personal journey of reflection, mindfulness, and consideration of Ayurvedic tips. This paper discusses AyurMi's motivation, system architecture, implementation approach, and implications in practice by proposing it as a comprehensive approach to digital wellness.

title: Predictive Analysis of Stock Market Data Using Optimal SVM-BAT Algorithm
authors: Rakshanda S. Jumbad, Anuradha Thakare
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Financial markets are volatile and non- linear, making it extremely difficult to predict stock market movements. This research proposes a new approach i.e. an Optimal SVM-BAT Algorithm which offers a revolutionary method of stock market prediction using real-time stock market data from Yahoo Finance (YFinance). The Bat Algorithm is used to optimize the hyper parameters and the power of SVM for regression to achieve an objective to forecast stock values for the upcoming 365 days. SVM is a powerful Machine Learning method, used to simulate how past stock data, including volume, high, low, opening, and closing prices relates to future price changes. The Bat Algorithm, a bio-inspired optimization method, is used to fine-tune the SVM model's hyper parameters, enhancing prediction accuracy. The model's performance is evaluated by predicting stock prices for a one-year horizon (365 days). The results are visualized using time-series graphs to compare predicted vs. actual values. This hybrid method showcases the potential of combining Machine Learning techniques with optimization algorithms for time-series forecasting, providing a powerful tool for investors and traders in anticipating stock market trends and making informed decisions.

title: Multiagent Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient Approach for Voltage Control of Distribution System
authors: Hafiz Mehboob Riaz, Malik Intisar Ali Sajjad, Muhammad Akmal
abstract: Modern power distribution systems face significant challenges, including voltage violations and active power losses, due to the high penetration of renewable energy sources (RESs). Conventional voltage regulation devices are slow and constrained by operational limitations while existing Volt/VAR Control (VVC) techniques for reactive power compensation primarily rely on model-based optimization approaches. In contrast, model-free deep reinforcement learning (DRL) methods, such as Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG), can adapt to changing grid conditions. However, DDPG suffers from Q-value overestimation and unstable learning issues, leading to suboptimal control policies. To address these challenges, a Multi-Agent Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (MA-TD3) technique is proposed in this paper to optimize the setpoints of modern voltage control devices. By leveraging twin critics with delayed policy updates, MA-TD3 enhances learning stability and mitigates overestimation bias. The distribution network is partitioned into sub-areas, with each sub-area formulated as a Markov game and solved cooperatively using MA-TD3. The proposed approach is validated on a modified IEEE 33-bus system, demonstrating superior performance over existing DRL methods in minimizing voltage violations and active power losses.

title: Exploring FEC Code Performance in Super-PON Systems: A Comparative Analysis of RS and LDPC Codes with PAM-4 Modulation
authors: Ricards Kudojars, Dmitrijs Prigunovs, Patriks Morevs, Toms Salgals, Oleksiy Borysenko, Svitlana Matsenko, Vjaceslavs Bobrovs
abstract: This paper investigates the application of forward error correction (FEC) codes, specifically Reed-Solomon (RS) and Low-Density Parity-Check (LDPC) codes in Super Passive Optical Network (Super-PON) systems with spectrally efficient four-level pulse amplitude modulation (PAM4). As demand for high-speed data transmission intensifies, Super-PON networks with extended reach and high capacity have become essential for cost-effective, long-distance optical access networks. In this study, we evaluate the performance of RS and LDPC codes under varying modulation schemes, focusing on PAM-4 across transmission rates of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$56 \text{Gbit} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> per <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex>. This paper aims to experimentally evaluate and compare the performance of RS and LDPC linear block codes within an 8 -channel wavelength division multiplexed passive optical network (WDM-PON) system. Specifically, the study explores the application of RS <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(255,239)$</tex> and LDPC 3/4 FEC codes to assess their impact on system reliability. Using a Bit Error Ratio (BER)-KP4 FEC threshold of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.26 \times 10^{-4}$</tex>, the investigation incorporates PAM-4 modulation at data rates of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$56 \text{Gbit} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> per <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex> to optimize Quality of Service (QoS). Results demonstrate the advantages and limitations of RS and LDPC coding in maintaining signal integrity under both modulations. The analysis reveals optimal configurations for each FEC code, offering guidance for designing robust Super-PON systems. This comparative study underscores the importance of selecting appropriate FEC schemes to enhance Super-PON performance, paving the way for future improvements in large-scale, high-speed optical access networks.

title: Development and Implementation of an Online Master’s Program in Electric Drive Engineering: Meeting Industry 5.0 Educational Needs
authors: Galina Demidova, Nikolai Poliakov, Dmitry Lukichev, Sergei Lovlin, Madina Tsvetkova, Alecksey Anuchin
abstract: This paper presents the development and implementation of an online master’s program in Electric Drive Engineering, designed for engineers specializing in electrical, power engineering, and robotics. The study contributes to the ongoing discussions on digital transformation and the role of education in the Industry 5.0 era by demonstrating how online engineering programs can effectively address the evolving needs of professionals in a rapidly advancing technological landscape. The focus of this paper is on both the theoretical and practical aspects of designing and implementing the program in a real educational setting. The structure of the program and the content of its courses are detailed, with particular attention given to how remote education can be effectively delivered to engineers. Additionally, the paper analyzes the target audience—engineers seeking advanced knowledge in drive systems engineering—and explores the challenges and opportunities of providing high-quality online engineering education. Intermediate learning outcomes showcase the program’s success in enhancing students' theoretical understanding and practical skills. Student feedback, gathered through surveys and course evaluations, highlights positive aspects such as flexibility, accessibility, and the comprehensive nature of the course content.

title: Convolutional-Recurrent Neural Networks for Visual Speech Recognition: An End-To-End Lip-Reading System
authors: Niraj Patil, Ganesh Patil, Aryan Tatiwar, Ojas Hedau, Bhakti Sonawane
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: An automated lip-reading system that uses deep learning to decipher speech from visual lip movements is presented in this research, improving accessibility for those who are hard of hearing. Using our method we combine recurrent layers for temporal analysis and convolutional layers for spatial feature analysis. A preprocessing pipeline uses video segmentation and normalization to guarantee high-quality input. The model is assessed using metrics for word and sentence correctness after being trained on benchmark datasets. The results show that visual signals may effectively recognize speech, highlighting potential in healthcare, education, and assistive technology. This approach improves accessibility to communication and automated lip reading.

title: Wifa: a Weighted Initialization Approach to Federated Learning for Medical Diagnosis
authors: Sharad Adsure, Manoj Devare
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: In the healthcare sector, federated learning (FL) presents a promising framework for building collaborative machine learning models without the need to exchange sensitive patient data. Despite its potential, conventional aggregation methods like Federated Averaging (FedAvg) often fall short when dealing with data disparities across participating institutions. This study proposes a modified aggregation algorithm, Weighted Initial Federated Averaging (WIFA), designed to overcome these limitations. WIFA introduces a weighting approach that considers both the similarity of local models to the global model and the relative size of each institution's dataset. This method ensures more balanced contributions during aggregation, even in the presence of data imbalance and diversity. The approach is evaluated using dental radiographic datasets to assess its performance in detecting various oral health conditions. Results indicate that WIFA outperforms standard FedAvg by producing models with improved generalization, accuracy, and resilience to non-uniform data distributions. Furthermore, WIFA adheres to privacy standards, making it suitable for real-world applications in medical diagnostics. WIFA advances the applicability of decentralized machine learning in clinical and research settings.

title: The Intelligent Power Nap System for Restoring Behavioral Capabilities in Sleepy Drivers
authors: Shao-Yang Cheng, Xun-Meie Kuo, Chih Hsiang Tsai, Shih-Wei Chang, Tsung-Hao Hsieh, Yu-Kai Wang, Sheng-Fu Liang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: Drowsiness significantly increases the risk of accidents and degrades the driver's performance by reducing attention and concentration. Various fatigue driving detection studies and technologies have been proposed, but few of them have thoroughly assessed the efficacy of sleep-based recovery techniques. This study investigates whether a controlled Power Nap may successfully improve fatigue-related driving performance. A total of 10 participants responded to lane deviation events throughout three sessions of driving in a driving simulator, which are regular driving, fatigue driving brought on by extended cognitive demands and post-rest driving conducted after finishing both the fatigue driving session and a controlled Power Nap. Lane deviation events were simulated by controlled steering wheel perturbation. Subjects' reaction time to lane deviation events were used as an indicator of fatigue level. We minimized sleep inertia by monitoring sleep stages and ensuring naps stayed in non-deep sleep phases using an EEG-based Powernap mobile application. Statistical analysis revealed a significant increase in reaction time after fatigue induction <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{t}(9)=10.99, \mathrm{p}<0.001)$</tex>, and a significant reduction following the Power Nap <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{t}(9)=8.26, \mathrm{p}<0.001)$</tex>. The results show that the suggested mobile nap system successfully lowered reaction times to nearly normal levels. These results support the idea that short, controlled naps that follow the Intelligent Rest Strategies can speed up recuperation from sleep-related exhaustion and improve road safety.

title: Integration of Solar Energy System and Mobile Power Rental Station
authors: Meng-Yun Chung, Cheng-Chuan Chen, Xin-Ning Zhang, Heng-Jui Chuang, Pao-Hsuan Weng, Si-Xian Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: Modern people rely heavily on their cell phones in their daily lives and often feel anxious when the battery level falls below 20%. To solve this problem, mobile power has become a common solution. With the advancement of solar energy technology, especially the system with automatic sunlight tracking, the application of green energy has become more mature and facilitates the sustainable development of solar photovoltaic (PV) power generation. Compared with the general conventional solar panels, the solar tracking system will increase the power generation efficiency by at least 30-40 % of its power generation efficiency will of course be adjusted according to the day's weather, this research also adds RFID identification devices for use to make the user identification more convenient to enhance the convenience of operation and energy management efficiency, this research project will utilize a variety of components and technologies, including solar energy, photovoltaic energy, solar energy, solar energy, solar energy, solar energy, solar energy, solar energy, solar energy, solar energy, solar energy, solar energy, solar energy, and solar energy management. This research project will utilize a variety of components and technologies, including solar panels, SG90 servo motors, cell phone charging modules, BH1750 optical sensors, LCD1602 displays, ESP32 modules, Arduino UNO R3, servers, RFID read/write devices, databases, mobile power supplies, wireless charging modules, and transformers, in order to achieve innovative and environmentally friendly solutions. We are committed to realizing innovative and environmentally friendly solutions.

title: Optimal Fuzzy Adaptive Control for a Class of Heterodimensional Second-Order Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Yongqing Fan, Chen He, Liang Luo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: This paper presents an optimal formation adaptive control methodology for a class of heterogeneous, heterodimensional second-order nonlinear multi-agent systems (MASs). Firstly, each agent, despite having nonidentical dimensions, is modeled using a second-order dynamic with its position and velocity. A novel concept of a similar combination for heterogeneous MASs with different dimensions is defined. This defines similarity vectors or matrices between the leader and followers, derived from the structural similarities within the system. Through a predefined mapping transformation based on these similarity vectors or matrices, the followers' states can be transformed to align with the leader's dimension, enabling coherent control design. Secondly, the conventional fuzzy logic system (FLS) is enhanced by incorporating a non-zero adaptive parameter, improving its approximation flexibility. The unknown nonlinear continuous functions in the system dynamics are expressed as a combination of homogeneous functions, each of which is approximated using the proposed modified FLS structure. This approach allows the approximation accuracies of the FLSs to be adjusted in real time via the designed adaptive laws, significantly enhancing the controller's performance in the presence of uncertainties. Finally, the simulation example demonstrates that the agents achieve the desired time-varying formation under the influence of the developed optimal adaptive control scheme, even in the presence of nonidentical dimensions.

title: UAV Autonomous Target Localization by Using Image-Based Visual Servoing
authors: Chong-Kai Wu, Wan-Chen Hu, Guei-Sin Ma, Cheng-Ta Chuang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: This study presents an autonomous UAV control framework that integrates YOLO-based object detection, a Kalman Filter, and Image-Based Visual Servoing (IBVS) into a closed-loop system for precise litter localization. The YOLOv5 model achieved an average precision (AP) above 0.975 for each of the three object classes, with an overall mAP@0.5 of 0.983, demonstrating highly reliable detection performance. The Kalman Filter enhances positional stability by smoothing YOLO outputs and reducing detection noise, while IBVS enables the UAV to autonomously align with the target center within approximately 10 seconds. Simulation results in Gazebo show that the proposed system maintains stable flight trajectories, reduces oscillations, and successfully achieves autonomous hovering directly above the litter target.

title: A Hybrid Genetic and Cat-Salp Swarm Optimization Approach for Energy-Efficient Clustering and Multi-hop Routing in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Wondimu Bantihun Demlew, Kelemwork Abebe Gebreegziabiher, Ermias Kassahun Azage, Eskeziyaw Alemneh Mekonen, Habtamu Maru Yaried
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: a wireless sensor network (WSN) is a network of several interconnected sensor nodes designed to monitor environmental conditions such as temperature, humidity, and pressure. However, one of their most critical challenges is energy limitation. Since sensor nodes are often deployed in inaccessible environments and typically operate on limited battery power, recharging or replacing them is not feasible. To overcome this challenge, we propose a hybrid Genetic Algorithm (GA) and Cat-Salp Swarm (CSSA) algorithm, referred to as GAC-SSA for energy-efficient clustering and multi-hop routing approach in WSN. In this approach, we used GA for clustering, while CSSA is used for efficient multi-hop routing. Through the use of GA’s strong global exploration proficiency in conjunction with the effective local exploitation potential of the CSSA, the proposed approach reduces energy consumption and enhances network lifetime more effectively. Simulation outcomes conducted in MATLAB demonstrate that our proposed method GAC-SSA significantly outperforms existing techniques, including independent GECR and a hybrid methods such as LEACH-GA, LEACH-CSSA, and GA-PSO. In particular, our approach achieves longer network lifetime, lower energy consumption, higher residual energy, and improved throughput, making it a promising solution for energy-constrained WSNs.

title: Study of Magnetoelectric Elements Characteristics for Magnetoelectric Synchronous Generator
authors: V. A. Misilin, V. A. Kiselev, A. R. Petrova, A. A. Rak, E. V. Kuzmin, R. V. Petrov
abstract: The paper is devoted to the study of magnetoelectric elements characteristics for magnetoelectric synchronous generator. Magnetoelectrics are a class of multiferroic substances in which electric polarization occurs under the action of an alternating magnetic field or, conversely, magnetization changes under the action of an alternating electric field. The paper presents models of a generator with magnetoelectric elements operating in resonant and non-resonant modes.

title: Quantum Algorithm for Handling Large-Scale Image Data in Quantum Random Access Memory
authors: Montasir Qasymeh, Ahmed M. Eisa, Mohammed Zidan, Mahmoud A. Ismail Shoman, Hichem Eleuch
abstract: The use of quantum computers to transport and process large-scale, high-resolution, real-time captured images highlights the need for efficient quantum storage methods, particularly in fields such as satellite imaging and astronomy. This paper presents a novel algorithm for integrating real-time captured quantum images that are captured using multi-imaging sources and storing these images to Quantum Random Access Memory (QRAM), utilizing an efficient fixed architecture QRAM in time cost <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O(1)$</tex>. Then, the proposed algorithm reads these images from QRAM in time cost <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O(1)$</tex> to integrate these images and reconstruct a single image from these images. This algorithm is realized experimentally using IMB's Aer simulator with two different image types and quantum representations. The first experiment is conducted on a one-channel (grayscale) image with pixel intensity values encoded as probability amplitudes. The second experiment is executed on a three-channel (RGB) image with pixel intensity values encoded in basis states. The results showcased the robustness and compatibility of the proposed algorithm with different quantum image formats.

title: Efficient Analysis of Near-Field EM Scattering from Complex Targets Coated with Anisotropic Media
authors: Xiaoyi Wang, Zhengqiu Tian, Zhihao Cai, Siyuan He
abstract: This paper presents an approach for predicting the near-field electromagnetic (EM) scattering of complex targets coated with anisotropic media, utilizing the physical optics (PO) method. In this method, the PO near-field integral representation is derived by using the Green's function for localized expansions, which allows for a more efficient and accurate representation of the scattering problem. The Green's function formulation is critical in solving the EM field interactions at the surface of the target, where the anisotropic coating significantly alters the behavior of the incident and scattered waves. To calculate the reflection coefficient of the anisotropic media-coated targets, the spectral domain approach is employed, in combination with boundary conditions, along with the PO near-field integral representation. This hybrid method enables an effective analysis of the near-field EM scattering phenomena for targets covered with anisotropic coatings. The use of spectral domain techniques allows for the decomposition of the scattered field into manageable components, simplifying the complex interactions between the incident field and the anisotropic material. Compared to traditional numerical methods, the results show that the proposed approach is both computationally efficient and accurate, reducing the computational resources and time required for the analysis. Furthermore, the proposed method can easily be extended to analyze electrically large and complex objects, especially in scenarios involving anisotropic coatings. This makes the approach particularly valuable for real-world applications in areas such as radar cross-section (RCS) analysis, where complex target geometries and material properties need to be considered. Overall, the method provides a reliable and scalable solution for near-field EM scattering analysis in complex coated structures.

title: Edge Computing for AI-Driven Acoustic Detection of Birds Pest in Senegalese Rice Paddies
authors: Moustapha Thiam, Madiop Diouf, Ibra Dioum, Stefano Rinaldi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: In Senegal, rice cultivation plays a key role in food self-sufficiency and rural development. However, several obstacles stand in their way: pests, four-legged animals and, above all, harmful birds (quelea quelea). These birds are responsible for colossal yield losses. Farmers use archaic methods to deter them, which are often ineffective or costly, and do not provide constant protection. Faced with this endemic problem, an innovative technological solution is proposed, combining the Internet of Things (IoT), Artificial Intelligence and Edge computing. The system is based on a network of microphones capable of capturing sound anywhere in the rice paddy, and above all, continuously. Bird songs can be specifically identified thanks to real-time analysis of the recorded sounds made possible by on-board AI models. This solution allows for very low latency and fast, autonomous detection without requiring a constant internet connection. The system assists in bird deterrence by quickly and accurately identifying their presence. This intelligent system helps to reduce crop losses, sustainably improve agricultural productivity and enhance precision farming.

title: Project of Multigigawatt Power W-Band Free Electron Maser with 3D Distributed Feedback Driven by Large-Size Sheet Electron Beam
authors: N. Yu. Peskov, E. D. Egorova, V. Yu. Zaslavsky, K. A. Leshcheva, A. A. Vikharev, A. S. Sergeev, N. S. Ginzburg, A. V. Arzhannikov, E. S. Sandalov, D. A. Samtsov, S. L. Sinitsky
abstract: The project of an ultra-high power free electron maser (FEM) of planar geometry operating in the W-band is being developed based on the U-2 accelerator complex (BINP RAS). This generator is planned to be driven by a relativistic electron beam <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \text{MeV} / 70-90 \text{kA} / 7 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex> having a sheet configuration with a cross section of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 ~\text{cm} \times 90 ~\text{cm}$</tex>. The paper is devoted to the design and modeling the key components of this FEM-oscillator. To pump the operating transverse oscillations of the beam electrons, electron-optical system was elaborated, including a pulsed planar wiggler. To ensure the selective excitation of the operating mode in the generator under conditions of substantial oversize along both transverse coordinates, it is proposed to use a three-dimensional distributed feedback mechanism, which is implemented in the electrodynamic system by means of “three-dimensional” Bragg structures. For effective radiation output, a profiled planar horn has been constructed, which provides the formation of a wave-beam with a high Gaussian content. According to the simulations, stable narrow-band generation in the developed FEM can be achieved with a record output power level of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 10-15 \text{GW}$</tex> under the conditions of the planned experiments.

title: Time Synchronization Performance of Single-Pair Ethernet (SPE) Solutions
authors: András Wiesner, Tamás Kovácsházy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Precision Clock Synchronization for Measurement, Control, and Communication (ISPCS)
abstract: Single Pair Ethernet (SPE) standard implementations offer simplified cabling requirements tailored to specific application domains. Currently, 100BASE-T1, 10BASE-T1L, and 10BASE-T1S are the SPE standards that have gained some acceptance. Unfortunately, the time synchronization performance of SPE is in question, especially for the 10 Mb/s variants, as the Physical Layer (PHY) uses low signaling rate, complex coding, and digital signal processing; furthermore, 10BASE-T1S also offers multidrop, half-duplex communication services. Our paper introduces a modular hardware solution for SPE performance evaluation utilizing Microcontrollers (MCU) and the flexPTP MCU Precision Time Protocol (PTP) implementation. We investigate the standard 100BASE-TX Ethernet and compare it to the automotive 100BASE-T1, 10BASE-T1S, and the long-range industrial 10BASE-T1L Ethernet with a PI and a Kalman filter servo algorithm. Our investigation shows that 100BASE-T1 offers significantly better accuracy and precision than the others; 100BASE-TX follows it in performance, and the 10BASE-T1L and 10BASE-T1 offer the worst timing performance.

title: PEM Fuel Cell Parameter Estimation Using a Modified Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Muhammad Ali Mughal, Maliha Khan, Tahir Ejaz
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: The simulation, control and analysis of the systems based on Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFC) demand a precise model with accurately defined parameters. This study introduces a modified swarm intelligence optimization approach, the Modified Particle Swarm Optimization (MPSO) algorithm, to estimate the parameters of the fuel cell model. The MPSO algorithm is an enhanced version of the standard particle swarm optimization (SPSO) technique, designed to improve performance by incorporating stagnation and aggressive mutation strategies, supplementing in avoiding premature convergence and amplifying the exploitation. In this method, a mathematical framework is established to guide the parameter optimization process. An objective function, based on the sum of squared errors (SSE) between the experimental and estimated voltage values, is constructed to facilitate optimal parameter estimation. The MPSO algorithm is then employed to determine the parameters for Nedstack PS6 fuel cell stack. The results are compared with several well-known optimization algorithms from the literature and the standard PSO. The comparative analysis demonstrates that the proposed MPSO algorithm outperforms others in terms of accuracy, search efficiency, and convergence speed. The MPSO has achieved an SSE of 2.0655 with a lower standard deviation of 0.6137 for the thirty runs, comparatively.

title: New Intelligent Control Method for Two-Link Robot Implementation
authors: Ayoub Belkheir, El Mehdi Mellouli, Elhanafi Arjdal, Mustapha Elyaqouti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: It is evident that, with the advancement of contemporary computational capabilities, various methodologies have been developed to enhance the efficiency and performance of autonomous systems. Among these, neural network techniques have shown particular promise in addressing complex control challenges. Nevertheless, this study does not aim to cover every aspect of advanced control. Instead, this study proposes a novel control strategy for a two-link robotic manipulator, designed to enhance tracking performance and effectively compensate for lumped disturbances and system uncertainties. First, the dynamic motion of the two-link robot is simulated using a differential equation. Next, the control design methodology is presented, beginning with the integration of a radial basis function neural network to approximate the lumped dynamic functions of the system. A stability analysis is then carried out using a proposed barrier Lyapunov function. Finally, simulation results validate the effectiveness and reliability of the proposed control approach.

title: Prediction of Bifacial Photovoltaic Module Performance Under Irradiance Using a Novel SPICE-Based Diode Model
authors: Gabriela Mantescu, Eugen Stefan Lakatos
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper presents a research study focused on predicting the electrical behaviour of a bifacial photovoltaic (PV) module under distinct levels of solar irradiance, based on known performance at a specific irradiation level. A new SPICE simulation model is proposed for evaluation with the particularity that the photovoltaic module is represented by an equivalent diode obtained by summing the constituent photovoltaic cells. For the applications in the paper, the serial resistance of a photovoltaic cell in the module has a value of $5 \mathrm{~m} \Omega$ and the parallel resistance is considered to have a value of $100 \Omega$. The simulation approach enables accurate estimation of the current-voltage (I-V) and power-voltage ($\mathbf{P}-\mathbf{V}$) characteristics of a $\mathbf{1 2 0}$-cell bifacial monocrystalline silicon PV module. Results are analysed under Standard Test Conditions (STC), with distinct scenarios considering front-side illumination, rear-side illumination, and simultaneous bifacial exposure. The proposed SPICE model offers a reliable and flexible tool for evaluating bifacial PV module performance in diverse irradiation environments.

title: Research on Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor Control Based on Improved Genetic Optimization Fuzzy PI Algorithm
authors: Gaohua Xiong, Yuyu Zhu, Haoran Li, Huanfa Yi, Yangli Liu, Yue Pan
abstract: The permanent magnet synchronous motor is widely used in industrial control, transportation, medical equipment, etc. due to its high power density, high efficiency, and small size. In the vector control of the three-phase permanent magnet synchronous motor, the traditional PI control has fixed parameters and cannot be adjusted in real-time in dynamic systems, which may cause large overshoots and slower response speed, etc. Fuzzy PI control can effectively improve the disadvantages of traditional PI control, such as poor anti-interference ability. However, the initial control parameters and fuzzy control rules of fuzzy PI control are too dependent on experience, so this paper proposes a fuzzy PI controller optimized by an improved genetic algorithm. The simulation was carried out using MATLAB/Simulink software, and the images of speed regulation, electromagnetic torque, and three-phase current were compared and analyzed before and after optimization. Finally, it was found that the fuzzy PI controller optimized by the improved genetic algorithm has good simulation effects compared to the traditional PI controller, which meets the requirements of high control precision, fast response speed, small overshoot, and strong anti-interference ability for the three-phase permanent magnet synchronous motor.

title: Masked Advantage-Weighted Consistency Training in Online Reinforcement Learning
authors: Feng Zhang, Hak-Keung Lam, Shun-Hung Tsai, Ting-Yu Ho
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: Diffusion models have gained traction in offline RL owing to their multi-modal inference and generalisation. To improve time efficiency for broader RL settings, consistency models (CMs) have been adopted as one-step policies. However, most CM-based policies include the vanilla consistency loss in the actor objective and weight all replay transitions equally, which can silently induce distribution drift by updating on historical out-of-distribution (OOD) data. We propose MAW-CT, a masked advantage-weighted consistency training method that preserves the stabilising role of consistency while suppressing OOD updates. Inspired by group relative policy optimisation (GRPO) and leveraging the batch-sampling capability of CMs, MAW-CT assigns relative advantage-based weights by comparing peer actions within a batch and applies a reconstruction-ratio mask to filter drifted replay actions. On three standard MuJoCo locomotion tasks (Hopper-v3, HalfCheetah-v3, Humanoid-v3), MAW-CT consistently outperforms TD3 and CM-TD3; it is competitive with Diffusion-TD3 while exhibiting lower training variance and reduced computational requirements. These results indicate improved sample efficiency and robustness for CM-based online RL.

title: Fast Swing-Up Control of Inertia Wheel Pendulum Systems Based on Motion Planning
authors: Yi-Gao Ning, Xuan Zhao, Man-Man Li, Jian-Lu Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: This paper presents a fast swing-up control method for inertia wheel pendulum systems based on motion planning. Firstly, perform a state transformation using the system property of differential flatness, and transform the motion planning problem between the initial point and the target point in the state space into a curve interpolation of the differential flatness output with relevant boundary conditions satisfied. Then, a polynomial interpolation approach is adopted to derive the optimization problem for minimum-time motion planning, which is solved based on the bisection method and particle swarm optimization algorithm to obtain the minimum-time motion trajectory. On that basis, the system’s dynamic characteristics and non-minimum phase property are thoroughly analyzed to design an effective trajectory tracking controller for tracking the reference optimal trajectory, thus the fast swing-up control of the inertia wheel pendulum system can be achieved. Finally, the proposed method is verified with simulation test and compared with a direct swing-up controller without motion planning. The test results demonstrate the feasibility and superiority of the proposed method, and the swing-up time under related system constraints can be decreased significantly.

title: Smart Tuning of Wireless Power Transfer Systems with Neural Networks
authors: Lorenzo Sabino, Davide Milillo, Fabio Crescimbini, Francesco Riganti Fulginei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study presents a novel approach utilizing Neural Networks (NN) to estimate the distance between coils in a Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) system while implementing an automatic impedance matching mechanism. The methodology is validated using experimental data and simulation of the experimental setup to cover a wider range of configurations, achieving low predictive error rates. The NN is trained on impedance measurements and scattering parameters collected from the transmitter coil, enabling accurate distance estimation between the two coils. Furthermore, this framework facilitates the identification of optimal capacitance values to enhance circuit performance and achieve ideal impedance matching. The results indicate significant improvements in WPT efficiency, underscoring the potential of NN applications in optimizing wireless energy transfer systems.

title: Review of Non-Isolated Inductive DC-DC Step-Up Voltage Converters for Full On-chip Integration
authors: Róbert Ondica, Adam Hudec, David Maljar, Viera Stopjaková
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper presents a summary of the commonly used inductive DC-DC voltage converters (VCs) for step-up (boost) voltage conversion with their key characteristics. Many of these topologies are based on conventional Buck and Boost converters with different alterations and/or additional components.
