The analysis includes current conduction modes, input source and output capacitor current stresses, and the conversion ratio under Continuous Conduction Mode (CCM) operation. The selection of VCs considered in this study was guided by the feasibility of future full on-chip integration, leading to the exclusion of topologies exhibiting excessive complexity, requiring more than two inductors or need of transformers. This overview summarizes the key characteristics of the selected circuits and provides a guide for the further design of inductive voltage converters.

title: Multi-Beam Training for Movable Antenna Enhanced Wireless Communications
authors: Dukai Xiang, Songjie Yang, Xinyang Li, Hua Chen
abstract: This letter investigates the effect of movable antennas on improving spectral efficiency in multi-subarray beam training of hybrid beamforming systems, forming movable subarrays (MSAs). During beam training, a joint search for both position and beam is conducted, but this increases the codebook dimension and search complexity. To solve this, we propose two low-complexity algorithms. First, an iterative one-sided search (IOSS) is developed to jointly optimize the configuration for each subarray, achieving rapid convergence. To further reduce training overhead, we also introduce a hierarchical angle-position search (HAPS), which offers performance comparable to IOSS with even lower complexity. Numerical results demonstrate that MSAs achieve gains of 39% over traditional fixed subarrays (FSAs) with exhaustive search. Our proposed IOSS algorithm secures a 42% gain, while HAPS achieves a comparable gain of 33%. These findings highlight the significant potential of MSAs.

title: All-in-One: Smartphone-based Intelligent Photonic mHealth System for Plantar and Cardiorespiratory Monitoring
authors: Yingshuo Bao, Zhuo Wang, Qian Zhang, Kun Xiao, Daniele Tosi, Carlo Massaroni, Xiaoli Li, Rui Min
abstract: In elderly remote healthcare, accurate measurement of plantar and cardiorespiratory functions is essential for early detection of mobility decline and chronic disease management, but traditional electrical wearable sensors typically cannot support integrated multimodal monitoring that such care requires. In this work, an all-in-one photonic solution is developed by embedding flexible polydimethylsiloxane polymer optical fiber (PDMS-POF) channels into an insole and chest belt, which are integrated with a smartphone via a custom 3D-printed connector to simultaneously capture gait, respiration, and heart rate. This system employs a series of signal processing techniques to automatically remove motion artifacts and optical noise, achieving clinical grade accuracy (≤ 0.6% error in stance/swing detection; ≤ 5% error in heart and respiratory rates during static activities). Building on this foundation, we introduce TodyNet-Pro, a temporal dynamic graph neural network designed to fuse multiple physiological signals and learn activity labels end to end using sparsity constraints and temporal weighting. In trials involving ten volunteers and validated against clinical standards, TodyNet-Pro achieved 95.5% accuracy in identifying seven static and dynamic activities, and over 80% accuracy in detecting four abnormal gait patterns, outperforming both standard deep learning models and recent studies on elderly activity recognition.

title: GBDE: Granular-Ball Textual Adversarial Attacks With Differential Evolution
authors: Zeli Wang, Tianhao Pu, Shuyin Xia, Longlong Lin, Linpin Liu, Guoyin Wang
abstract: Neural network models in natural language processing have demonstrated remarkable proficiency, but they are still vulnerable to adversarial attacks, where minute and indistinguishable alterations can profoundly disturb their performance. Existing methods struggle to define synonyms accurately and rely on greedy traversal or gradient computation, making them difficult to deploy. Inspired by these, this paper proposes a novel text adversarial attack method, which constructs rich candidate adversarial examples by non-trivially combining the <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">G</u>ranular-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">B</u>all computing and <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</u>ifferential <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">E</u>volution, termed GBDE. Through iterative optimization guided by a meticulously crafted loss function, GBDE iteratively optimizes to generate effective and high-quality adversarial examples. Specifically, GBDE realizes a multi-granularity granular-ball clustering method following the data features, to establish robust synonym sets. It then performs synonym substitutions on target samples to create candidate adversarial samples and further diversifies these samples through a customized differential evolution process. Additionally, the loss function incorporates a reward and punishment mechanism to steer the optimization of attacks. Empirical results showcase GBDE's superiority when contrasted with cutting-edge models. Notably, GBDE produces high-quality adversarial texts with a larger success rate. Besides, ablation studies confirm the contributions of granular-ball clustering and differential evolution in text attacks, and the rationality of the loss function design.

title: PLPO-KF: A Unified Pose-Only Kalman Filter with Point-Line Features for Visual-Inertial Odometry
authors: Liqiang Wang, Hailiang Tang, Yan Wang, Guan Wang, Tisheng Zhang, Xiaoji Niu
abstract: The pose-only Kalman filter (PO-KF) for visual-inertial odometry (VIO) has demonstrated comparable localization accuracy to optimization-based systems while retaining the computational efficiency of filter-based approaches. However, the performance of point-based PO-KF degrades in textureless environments due to the scarcity of point features, while line features can serve as valuable supplements. To exploit the benefits of pose-only line-feature representation, we extend PO-KF with a pose-only line-feature measurement model and propose PLPO-KF, a unified pose-only representation-based Kalman filter for point-line-based VIO. Specifically, to eliminate reliance on 3D line reconstruction and enable immediate line updates, we develop a trifocal tensor-based pose-only line-feature measurement model with a concise and clear measurement equation. In addition, we introduce an INS-enhanced line optical-flow tracking method to ensure robust and accurate line feature association across multiple frames. Extensive experimental results on both public and private datasets demonstrate that PLPO-KF consistently outperforms state-of-the-art point-based and point-line-based VIO systems. Ablation studies further exhibit the effectiveness of both the proposed line pose-only measurement model and the INS-enhanced line tracking method.

title: A Hybrid Multimodal Deep Learning Framework for Robust Diagnosis of Parkinson’s Disease Using Hand Tremor Analysis
authors: Gauri Chandra, Tapan K. Gandhi, Bhim Singh
abstract: Parkinson’s Disease (PD) is a long-term degenerative disorder that affects the nervous system over time predominantly marked by motor dysfunction, with hand tremors being among the earliest and most diagnostically significant symptoms. Conventional PD diagnosis relies heavily on subjective clinical evaluations, which often lack precision and consistency. This research proposes a novel advanced fusion-based deep learning framework that integrates multimodal hand tremor data specifically, kinematic signals from accelerometers and gyroscopes, spiral drawing images, and video-based hand motion recordings to enhance robust and generalizable PD diagnosis with significant potential for early-stage detection. Specialized neural subnetworks are employed to analyze each modality: stacked LSTM layers for temporal sensor data, 2D CNNs for spatial characteristics from spiral drawings, and 3D CNNs for spatio-temporal video evaluation. The extracted feature representations are unified in a cohesive architecture and trained end-to-end using a Hybrid GRU-LSTNet model enhanced with a Bottleneck Attention Module (BAM). Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model significantly outperforms both unimodal deep learning approaches and traditional machine learning benchmarks, accomplishing an accuracy of 94.0%, precision of 93.8%, recall of 94.2%, and F1-score of 94.0%. This work highlights the potency of integrating multiple data modalities for accurately identifying complex motor dysfunction patterns attributed with PD, providing a scalable and highly accurate diagnostic solution.

title: A Robust Continual Domain Adaptation Framework for Gas Path Fault Diagnosis of Aero-Engine under Dynamic Operating Conditions
authors: Chaochao Guo, Youchao Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Achieving reliable fault diagnosis of aero-engine gas path systems under dynamic operating conditions remains a critical challenge due to domain shifts across varying working states. To address this issue, we propose a Robust Continual Domain Adaptation Framework (RCDAF) that enables stable knowledge retention and adaptive transfer across a sequence of target domains. The framework initially leverages joint cross entropy and supervised contrastive loss to enhance intra-class compactness and inter-class separability. A memory buffer is then built to preserve logits, labels, and raw inputs from the source domain, facilitating the replay of knowledge. To mitigate feature distribution shifts during continual adaptation, we introduce a Controllable Batch Normalization (CBN) mechanism. Furthermore, a restraining past loss and dual-knowledge distillation loss are proposed to constrain representation drift while maintaining output consistency and discriminative capability. To address feature uncertainty, conditional entropy minimization is applied, and a pseudo-supervised contrastive (PSC) loss is designed to enable robust class-wise alignment, especially under label imbalance and pseudo-label noise. Lastly, a dynamic buffer update strategy ensures the continual evolution of stored knowledge. Comprehensive experiments on multi-domain aero-engine datasets validate the robustness and adaptability of RCDAF in complex, non-stationary diagnostic scenarios.

title: 2-D Precisely Controllable Smart Jamming Against SAR Based on Dual-Template Joint Modulation
authors: Longyuan Wang, Huijin Yang, Gaofeng Shu, Ning Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: In the field of electronic countermeasures (ECM), the design of barrage jamming techniques with controllable jamming coverage and deceptive jamming techniques with high degrees of freedom for Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) systems is of significant research importance. However, achieving 2-D precisely controllable jamming within regions of interest (ROIs) remains a critical challenge in current jamming technologies. To address this, a 2-D precisely controllable SAR smart jamming method based on dual-template joint modulation (PC-DTJM) is proposed in this paper. By introducing a dual-template joint modulation mechanism, the PC-DTJM method enables the precise control of jamming amplitude, quantity, position, and coverage, delivering versatile jamming effects. This method can generate both barrage jamming and deceptive jamming effects. Specifically, the method utilizes prior information about the ROIs to predefine an amplitude modulation template and a coverage modulation template. Through the definition of range-position modulation factors and azimuth-position modulation factors, precise control over jamming positions is achieved. Furthermore, an amplitude modulation factor is defined based on the amplitude modulation template, enabling high controllability of jamming amplitude and quantity. Finally, a 2-D coverage factor is defined based on the coverage modulation template, allowing flexible control over the jamming coverage area. Additionally, the characteristics of the jamming, including amplitude, quantity, position, and coverage, are analyzed in detail. The impact of system parameter errors on jamming performance is also investigated, confirming the robustness and stability of the PC-DTJM method. Extensive simulations and comparative experiments validate that the proposed method achieves precise control over jamming amplitude, quantity, position, and coverage, thereby demonstrating the effectiveness and superiority of the PC-DTJM method.

title: Outage Analysis of Space-Air-Ground Integrated Networks Powered by Battery-Aided SWIPT
authors: Anuradha Verma, Pankaj K. Sharma, Judhistir Mahapatro
publish: IEEE Journal on Miniaturization for Air and Space Systems
abstract: The integration of overlay technology with Simultaneous Wireless Information and Power Transfer (SWIPT) presents a promising solution to enhance and extend space-air-ground communications for next-generation wireless networks. This article explores an overlay-based Space-Air-Ground Integrated Network (SAGIN) architecture, encompassing a ground-to-satellite (G2S) network and an aerial network constrained by both energy and spectrum. Through this integration, overlay technology enables efficient spectrum utilization by allowing the aerial network to opportunistically access licensed spectrum without interfering with G2S operations. The aerial transmitter (ATx) leverages SWIPT-based battery-assisted non-linear energy harvesting, where it collects energy from incoming signals from the ground node and utilizes the harvested energy to relay signals to the satellite and the aerial receiver (ARx). By addressing the relevant stochastic positioning of the ground nodes, ARx, and satellite, we evaluate the performance of both the G2S and air-to-air (A2A) networks. Our analysis incorporates Shadowed-Rician fading for the satellite link, Nakagami-m fading for the ground link, and Rician fading for the aerial link. We derive analytical expressions for the outage probability and throughput, offering insights into key design parameters that promote energy-efficient and spectrum-efficient network configurations. Finally, Monte Carlo simulations verify the theoretical findings and lay practical guidelines for the development of future SAGINs.

title: Miniature Compliance Controllable Sensor for Tissue Stiffness Sensing and Palpation
authors: Duncan G. Raitt, Shervanthi Homer-Vanniasinkam, Prokar Dasgupta, Sara-Adela Abad, Helge A. Wurdemann
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: Tissue stiffness can provide key details about the health and type of tissues. This paper presents the creation of a miniaturised soft tissue stiffness sensor with dimensions that make it suitable for palpation in minimally invasive surgery. We introduce the stiffness sensor design and experimentally test its force sensing, elasticity measurement, and dynamic palpation performance. The sensor can measure normal forces with an adjustable range. Angled forces were measured with their magnitude and angles, θY and θX, root-mean-square errors (RMSE) of 8.37%, 6.68%, and 13.92% of their respective ranges. Furthermore, samples with an elasticity between 4.20 kPa and 177.62 kPa, which were not in the training set, were measured with an RMSE of 7.79% of the tested range. During palpation, the boundary between the 13.4 kPa elastomer and the 2 mm embedded 29.3 kPa elastomer was located with a signal-noise ratio (SNR) of 77.04:1 and a mean offset of 0.706 mm. This investigation provides new insights into sensing devices capable of fitting trocars while measuring tissue elasticity and force during minimally invasive procedures.

title: Development and Control of a Macro-Micro Multi-Arm Robotic System for Open Spina Bifida Treatment
authors: Xiaohang Zhang, Di Wu, Matthias Tummers, Yuyu Cai, Yao Zhang, Tom Vandebroek, Gianni Borghesan, Jan Deprest, Emmanuel Vander Poorten
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: Open spina bifida (OSB), a congenital anomaly caused by incomplete spinal column closure, leads to progressive nerve damage. While multi-port minimally invasive procedures are being optimized clinically, single-port access (SPA) surgery presents a promising, less invasive alternative. Beyond reducing scarring, SPA may also decrease the risk of iatrogenic preterm premature rupture of membranes and enhance maternal recovery, as suggested by outcomes in other minimally invasive interventions. However, technical challenges persist in SPA implementations, particularly in instrument miniaturization and control precision. To facilitate this approach, a macro-micro multi-arm robotic system is under development. The system features an 11-mm-diameter insertion port to deploy four instrument arms. The arm design incorporates a hybrid backbone structure. A macro proximal section of concentric tubes provides stable deployment, while a micro distal flexible segment enables the dexterous manipulation. This paper presents dedicated modeling and control strategies to address actuator and transmission nonlinearities arising from stringent miniaturization requirements. A hybrid framework combining joint-level feedback with deep-learning-based feedforward compensation mitigates limitations imposed by pneumatic artificial muscles and tendon transmissions. The system is validated through trajectory-following experiments, each conducted over 10 trials. Preliminary results show an average root-mean-squared error of 0.28 mm, an average maximum absolute error of 0.85 mm, and an average standard deviation of 0.18 mm across both trajectories. These results demonstrate consistent sub-millimeter precision, satisfying the requirement for OSB repair. The feasibility of the system was then verified through a phantom study.

title: YOLO-VML: An Improved Object Detection Model for Blastomeres and Pronuclei Localization in IoMT
authors: Aiyun Shen, Chang Li, Jingwei Yang, Guoning Huang, Xiaodong Zhang
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Engineering in Medicine and Biology
abstract: Goal: Blastomeres and pronuclei detection plays a crucial role in advancing research on embryo development and assisted reproductive technologies. However, due to the frequent overlapping of blastomeres and the pronuclei's small size, background similarity, and unclear boundaries, their localization proves to be extremely difficult. Methods: To address these challenges, we propose YOLO-VML, an improved detection model based on the YOLOv10 framework. The model integrates the visual state space (VSS) module of VMamba into the backbone network to enhance the global receptive field and enable broader feature capture. A multi-branch weighted feature pyramid network (MBFPN) is introduced as the neck structure to improve the preservation and fusion of features, especially those related to small targets. Additionally, a lightweight shared convolutional detection head (LSCD) is employed to reduce parameters and computational overhead while maintaining detection accuracy. Results: The proposed YOLO-VML model demonstrates excellent performance in detecting both blastomeres and pronuclei. It achieves a mean average precision (mAP@0.5) of 93.2% for pronuclei detection and 92.3% for blastomere detection beyond the 4-cell stage. Conclusions: YOLO-VML effectively addresses the difficulties in blastomere and pronucleus localization by enhancing feature representation and detection efficiency. Its high accuracy and efficiency make it a valuable tool for advancing embryo research and assisted reproductive technology applications.

title: Radio Map Assisted Routing and Predictive Resource Allocation over Dynamic Low Altitude Networks
authors: Bowen Li, Junting Chen
abstract: Dynamic low altitude networks offer significant potential for efficient and reliable data transport via unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) relays which usually operate with pre-determined trajectories. However, it is challenging to optimize the data routing and resource allocation due to the time-varying topology and the need to control interference with terrestrial systems. Traditional schemes rely on time-expanded graphs with uniform and fine time subdivisions, making them impractical for interference-aware applications. This paper develops a dynamic space-time graph model with a cross-layer optimization framework that converts a joint routing and predictive resource allocation problem into a joint bottleneck path planning and resource allocation problem. We develop explicit deterministic bounds to handle the channel uncertainty and prove a monotonicity property in the problem structure that enables us to efficiently reach the globally optimal solution to the predictive resource allocation subproblem. Then, this approach is extended to multi-commodity transmission tasks through time-frequency allocation, and a bisection search algorithm is developed to find the optimum solution by leveraging the monotonicity of the feasible set family. Simulations verify that the single commodity algorithm approaches global optimality with more than 30 dB performance gain over the classical graph-based methods for delay-sensitive and large data transportation. At the same time, the multi-commodity method achieves 100X improvements in dense service scenarios and enables an additional 20 dB performance gain by data segmenting.

title: Piezoresistive Pressure Sensor With Temperature Compensation Circuit For High-Temperature Applications
authors: Cheng Lei, Xi Wei, Xu Zhang, Zhiqiang Li, Qi Li, Lei Fan, Xiangyang Ren, Qiulin Tan, Ting Liang
abstract: A piezoresistive pressure sensor for use in high-temperature applications is described in this paper. The sensor consists primarily of a temperature compensation circuit, a piezoresistive pressure-sensitive chip, and an encapsulating structure that can withstand high temperatures. The chip was made using MEMS technology and Silicon-On-Insulator (SOI) material. Using passive resistor network compensation technology, the temperature compensation circuit is constructed using PCB boards and low-temperature coefficient (TCR) resistors. The encapsulation eliminates the need for gold bond wires, offering a leadless packaging structure. The experimental findings demonstrate that the temperature compensation circuit successfully lowers the sensor’s thermal zero drift, which drops from 0.1018%FS/°C to 0.0781%FS/°C in the 25°C to 235°C temperature range. Additionally, the sensor’s thermal sensitivity drift is decreased, going from 0.1035% FS/°C to 0.0717% FS/°C.

title: A Planar Sheet-Type Composite Electric and Magnetic Near-Field Probe
authors: Tengfei Gao, Zhaowen Yan, Kunkun Hu, Fuyu Zhao, Xinyu Zhao, Jianhao Ge
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this letter, a planar sheet-type composite electromagnetic near-field probe is proposed for acquiring electromagnetic field intensity in the operating environment of chips. Designed for measuring the normal electric field and tangential magnetic field components, this probe comprises an electric field probe and a magnetic field probe, with an operating frequency range of 100 kHz to 3 GHz and an overall dimensions of 14.5 mm × 10 mm × 1.3 mm. The electric field probe sensing part incorporates a circular monopole, while the magnetic field probe sensing part incorporates two G-shaped loops. Through the analysis of its equivalent circuit model, the primary factors influencing the probe output are determined. Simulations and measurements were conducted on the transmission coefficient, calibration factor, isolation coefficient, and spatial resolution of the probe. Finally, a shielding cavity experiment verifies its detection performance, confirming utility in near-field measurements.

title: Learning-Based User Admission Control for Large-Scale Cell-Free Massive MIMO
authors: Yijie Gao, Peng Cheng, Zhuo Chen, Khoa Tran Phan, Wei Xiang, Yi-Ping Phoebe Chen
abstract: Cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF-mMIMO) is a promising architecture for 6G wireless networks through distributed access point (AP) cooperation. In large-scale deployments where user demand exceeds system capacity, effective user admission control (UAC) is essential to select users while meeting quality-of-service (QoS) requirements. The UAC problem in CF-mMIMO is inherently challenging, involving both discrete user selection and continuous power allocation variables. To address this challenge, we propose a Graphormer-enhanced Monte Carlo Tree Search (GE-MCTS) framework that integrates a Graphormer-based neural network (NN) with Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS). This framework leverages the Graphormer’s capability to model the graph-structured AP–user topology and MCTS’s planning proficiency to efficiently explore the vast decision space. Furthermore, to accommodate users initially unadmitted due to system constraints, we introduce a complementary AP deployment problem. By adapting the GE-MCTS framework, we optimize the placement of additional APs to achieve full user admission with the minimal number of new APs required. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed framework. For UAC, with low computational complexity, GE-MCTS consistently admits 26.3–41.7% more users compared to baseline methods across various network scales. For AP deployment, our framework requires 45–73% fewer additional APs to achieve full user admission, highlighting its efficiency and scalability.

title: Ultrafast Switching of Series-Connected MOSFETs for High-Voltage Nanosecond Pulsed Applications
authors: S. M. Mortazavi, T. Huiskamp
abstract: High-voltage solid-state nanosecond pulse generators are gaining attraction for industrial applications that require fast, high-frequency, repetitive, and fully controllable pulses. However, the limited voltage rating of individual solid-state switches remains a key challenge. For ultrafast switching, series-connecting metal–oxide–semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs) address this but can introduce complexity in gate driving, voltage sharing, cost, size, losses, and switching speed. To address these challenges, this article presents a compact, ultrafast-switching, gate-boosted, series-connected MOSFET topology for use in high-voltage nanosecond pulsed applications. A novel gate-drive approach is proposed, where only the first MOSFET is driven directly, and the rest are triggered via capacitive coupling, enhanced with a gate-boosting technique for faster switching. This improves pulse rise time and reduces switching losses. To enhance the performance of the proposed topology, three versions of the gate-boosted driver and high-voltage switch layout were comparatively evaluated. Based on this comparison, a compact layout was optimized for the high-voltage switch and its gate-boosted driver, achieving the fastest rise times with improved output pulse quality. Simulation and experimental results verify the effectiveness of the optimized layout and gate-driving approach, enabling ultrafast and reliable operation for pulse durations of 20 ns and higher. At 10 kV and a load current of 45.5 A, rise times of 2.8 ns (3.57 kV/ns) for voltage and 2.5 ns for current were achieved, demonstrating excellent ultrafast switching performance. Furthermore, by introducing a two-stage gate-boosting method for high-current applications, current rise rates of up to 60.3 kA/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>s at 187 A were obtained.

title: AIME–PSO: Constraint-Aware Counterfactual Explanations via Approximate Inverse–Guided Particle Swarm
authors: Takafumi Nakanishi, Ponlawat Chophuk, Krisana Chinnasarn
abstract: Counterfactual explanations should transform the decision of a model with minimal and feasible changes under real-world constraints. We present AIME–PSO, combining approximate inverse model explanations (AIME) with particle swarm optimization (PSO). From input–output pairs (X, f (X)), we estimate an approximate inverse operator A†, and for a given instance x0 with prediction y0 = f (x0) we derive instance-specific weights w = |A†y0|. These weights define an anisotropic distance and seed the swarm near the representative preimage A†y0. Each iteration applies a fixed one-hot → clip → to evaluate order and enforces discreteness, invariance, and monotonicity through penalties, enabling a robust search in nonconvex, nonsmooth mixed spaces. We compared AIME–PSO with CEILS, MCCE, DiCE, CFNOW, NICE, and C-CHVAE on four datasets (Synthetic-1, Synthetic-2, Sangiovese, and Adult) in terms of validity, standardized distance, dependency consistency (CES/DPS), immutable violations (IM1), plausibility, and runtime. AIME–PSO achieved validity and plausibility of 1.000 for both the Sangiovese and Synthetic-2 datasets, with moderate distances (0.601 for Sangiovese and 0.389 for Synthetic-2). In Synthetic-1, strong variable dependencies reduced validity (0.675). In Adult, numerous categorical groups increased the distance and time per CF (33.36 s), although order fixing and grouped updates mitigated discrete violations. The UMAP overlays indicate that our counterfactuals remain in the high-density regions of the training distribution. Overall, AIME–PSO delivers robust, constraint-aware counterfactuals in continuous or lowcategorical tasks while avoiding excessive movement, highlighting actionable implementation choices for categorical data.

title: 6G Air-to-Ground Connectivity: A Codebook-Based Framework for Interference Management
authors: Sara Sualiheen, Attiq Ur Rehman, KyungHi Chang
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Air-to-Ground (A2G) integration offers a more promising solution than satellite links, due to lower latency and higher throughput. However, this integration faces significant challenges, particularly co-channel interference, which necessitates the development of advanced interference mitigation strategies. This paper investigates the coexistence of aerial uplink (UL) and ground downlink (DL) communications in dynamic Time-Division Duplexing (D-TDD) systems, where UL transmissions from aerial users introduce severe interference to the DL transmissions of TN users. To address the issue of user-to-user interference (UL-DL) in A2G system, this work proposes a novel Codebook-Based Interference Mitigation (CBIM) framework that incorporates a sliding codebook approach for radio frame configuration (RFC) selection and a dynamic subframe swapping mechanism to resolve subframe misalignments and reduce interference. By optimizing subframe arrangements, the framework effectively minimizes interference while improving resource utilization. Simulation results demonstrate the framework’s effectiveness, achieving a 20.37% reduction in interference and a 28.21% increase in throughput, establishing CBIM as a robust and efficient solution for the future TN-NTN integration in next-generation communication systems.

title: Dual-Channel Disentangled Contrastive Learning with Adaptive Spatio-Temporal Encoding for POI Recommendation
authors: Yongxuan Feng, Binlu Yan, Zhanquan Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: In point-of-interest (POI) recommendation, users' behaviors evolve across contexts, making it hard for static models to capture heterogeneous patterns. Additionally, group conformity introduces popularity bias, causing systems to over-recommend frequent POIs while overlooking long-tail interests. To address these issues, we propose DCDST, a novel framework that combines dual-channel disentangled contrastive learning with adaptive spatio-temporal encoding. Specifically, we introduce a spatio-temporal bias-aware self-attention mechanism that dynamically models contextual dependencies within user trajectories. Simultaneously, a dual-channel contrastive learning module generates adversarial views through group-level augmentation and individual-specific perturbation. A conformity-aware loss function is employed to disentangle shared group behaviors from personalized preferences, enabling better long-tail interest modeling and mitigating popularity bias. Experiments on three real-world datasets demonstrate that DCDST consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both accuracy and recommendation diversity. Our code is available at https://github.com/yx-Feng/DCDST.

title: HHGFD: Graph Fraud Detection Through Heterogeneity and Heterophily Characterization
authors: Ping Hu, Yudong Qin, Junhang Wu, Zhou Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: With the rapid growth of the internet and digital economy, fraudulent activities have grown more sophisticated, leading to substantial social and financial costs. Graph-based fraud detection provides an effective framework by modeling entities as nodes and interactions as edges. However, the prevalent heterophily (target nodes exhibit distinct labels from neighbors) and heterogeneity (multi-typed nodes/edges) in fraud graphs cause traditional graph neural networks to lose critical anomaly signals during message passing. Existing methods handle heterophily and heterogeneity in isolation: heterophily mitigation relies on static grouping strategies, while heterogeneity handling predominantly adopts adaptive weighting mechanisms. Yet neither systematically models their synergistic effects, limiting hierarchical pattern capturing capabilities. This paper proposes HHGFD, a synergistic framework integrating reinforcement learning-driven dynamic grouping with hierarchical attention aggregation. We formulate grouping decisions as a Markov process through reinforcement learning, optimizing grouping boundaries via real-time feedback. Additionally, we introduce a hierarchical attention aggregation framework: node-level self-attention learns cross-type feature importance weights to emphasize fraud-relevant attributes, while relation-level attention dynamically allocates semantic weights for heterogeneous edges. Extensive experiments on four datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method.

title: Composite-Scaled Efficientnet for Enhanced Malaysian Traffic Sign Recognition
authors: Xie Han Lim, Weng Kin Lai, Mei Kuan Lim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Accurate traffic sign recognition (TSR) is critical for autonomous vehicles, especially in diverse driving environments. While datasets such as the German Traffic Sign Recognition Benchmark (GTSRB) have been extensively studied, limited attention has been paid to specific regional challenges, especially in Malaysia. This study explores traffic sign recognition in Malaysia using a composite-scale convolutional neural network (EfficientNet). The Malaysian Traffic Sign (MTS) dataset contains signs with cultural uniqueness, language, and design differences, which are underexplored compared to global datasets. EfficientNet-B5 was selected for its balance between accuracy and efficiency. Enhancements including image resizing, architecture depth expansion, and data augmentation were applied. Results show that EfficientNet-B5 achieves significant improvements, especially on the MTS dataset, demonstrating the potential for scalable, real-time TSR for autonomous driving systems in Malaysia.

title: Industrial IoT Architecture for the Digitalization of a Production Process and Real-Time Monitoring of Overall Equipment Effectiveness
authors: Carlos Calderon-Cordova, Freddy Avendaño, José Raùl Castro
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Low operational efficiency, high maintenance costs, and limited availability of real-time information represent persistent challenges in industrial sectors that have not yet adopted process digitalization. In response to this issue, the present study aims to design and implement a technological system focused on the digitalization of an industrial process to automatically determine the Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE) indicator. The developed architecture integrates elements of industrial automation and Industry 4.0 technologies. Siemens LOGO! and Mitsubishi FX5U programmable logic controllers (PLCs) were used to capture process variables, along with a Lowcost IoT Gateway and Node-RED for data extraction from the PLCs. Additionally, InfluxDB and Grafana were used for realtime data storage and visualization of performance indicators. The system was validated through the implementation of the IIoT architecture, which operated with a virtual production line representing the dosing and weighing process, where $\mathbf{2, 9 3 2}$ products were generated. The key performance indicators (KPIs) obtained included $\mathbf{8 9. 4 \%}$ Availability, $\mathbf{9 7. 7 \%}$ Performance, $\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$ Quality, and an OEE of 87.4%. These results demonstrate the system’s capability to acquire and process reliable real-time information, reduce downtime, optimize resource usage, and improve decision-making accuracy. The proposed solution contributes significantly to the digital transformation of the industrial sector, promoting more efficient, sustainable, and datadriven production environments.

title: A Study on the Application of Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks for Renewable Energy Forecasting
authors: Juan Yan, Yuhao Gao, Wenping Cao, Cungang Hu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: With the widespread adoption of clean energy technologies, accurate forecasting of renewable energy outputs has become increasingly critical. This study explores the application of Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks (KAN) in the domain of renewable energy prediction. KAN, inspired by the Kolmogorov–Arnold representation theorem, replace traditional linear weights in multilayer perceptrons (MLPs) with spline functions, enhancing model interpretability. Unlike conventional black-box models, KAN offer significant explanatory capabilities. We conducted experiments using real-world wind and photovoltaic power output data from Shandong Province, China. The results demonstrate that KAN outperform benchmark models, including MLPs and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, in most scenarios, while also providing superior interpretability. These findings suggest that KAN hold substantial potential for practical applications in renewable energy forecasting.

title: STEM teaching focused on mathematics
authors: Patrik Voštinár, Iveta Kelemecová
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: STEM education offers innovative pedagogical approaches that can increase motivation and interest in mathematics, connect theory with practice, and cultivate transferable skills. Through problem-based tasks, project-based learning, and interdisciplinary activities, STEM not only deepens understanding of mathematical concepts but also promotes their application in real-world contexts and professional life. This paper deals with STEM teaching focused on mathematics in elementary school. We focus on teaching mathematics using educational robotic aids and the educational game Minecraft Education. As part of our research, we focused on determining whether the use of such aids improves mathematical skills and increases interest in mathematics. The challenges identified during implementation provide valuable insights for further improvement of the educational process.

title: Ensemble Forecasting for Basin Extreme Precipitation
authors: Xue-Zhen Li, Kun-Fei Lu, Hao-Jia Chen, Zi-Yu Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Basin extreme precipitation plays a critical role in regulating reservoir operations and water allocation strategies. Machine learning methods provide new opportunities for precipitation prediction. However, due to complex factors, forecasting extreme precipitation in the basin remains a formidable challenge. In this paper, based on the extensive feature engineering, an ensemble learning framework is proposed for forecasting extreme precipitation in basins. In particular, a meta-learned method based on stacked generalization is adopted for ensemble forecasting by constructing a two-layer prediction model and feeding the prediction results of the basic classifiers (layer 0 models) into a layer 1 model. The results of forecast experiments on Dongjiang river basin show that our method is more effective then traditional time series methods, single machine learning models, and even deep learning time series model.

title: Field and Phase Analysis in Printed Passive RFID Tag for Sensor Application
authors: S. Aiswarya, L. Meenu, K. A. Unnikrishna Menon, Sreedevi K. Menon
abstract: Planar RFIDs have found diverse object detection and tracking applications in various fields from object detection to life detection. The RFID system consists of a reader as the transmitter and several tags as receivers. The reader will be continuously sending the interrogating pulses and the tags will respond to the signals from the reader by backscattering the inputted wave. The distance of retransmission will depend on the properties of the resonator like, the depth of scattering parameters and the Quality factor of the RFID resonators. In certain cases duplication of the resonators could double the transmission range compromising the increased size of the tag. The operation of planar RFID tags is closely related to the resonant frequency of the resonators within the tag. Resonance occurs when the electrical length of the antenna is an integer multiple of the wavelength associated with the operating frequency. The electric field characteristics of the tag has a direct impact on the read range of the RFID tag. By optimizing the design of the tag and based on the wavelength of the tag, the read range could be improved. Passive RFID tags working on backscattering principles do not have an internal power source and they utilize the energy from the electromagnetic field generated from the reader to power up and communicate. The sensing capability of these sensors is due to the high electric field when excited at the resonant frequency and is one of the important parameters that determines the range of the passive RFID tag. The electric field analysis of a printed planar 4 bit RFID tag for sensing application is discussed in the paper. The tags are excited at the respective resonant frequencies and the field variation of the excited resonator is identified. The resonators are capable of generating high electric fields thus are capable of long range communication depending upon the reader.

title:
Enabling Sub-
                    <sub>μ</sub>
                    W RF Energy Harvesting by Co-Design of Impedance Matching and Rectifier: A Review
authors: Rongxuan Xing
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The rising trend of Internet of Things (IoT) devices requires the creation of sustainable means for their power supply. One of the most viable means of addressing this is the radio frequency (RF) energy harvesting process, whereby ambient electromagnetic waves are captured and harnessed into usable direct current (DC) electricity. The method has great prospects for powering small, self-sustaining sensors and identification systems. However, conventional RF harvesters face several constraining impediments. The devices often exhibit efficiencies at very low levels of power (less than $-\mathbf{3 5 ~ d B m}$) and are prone to leakage currents for multi-stage rectifiers, besides facing significant losses from adaptive control circuitries. Such drawbacks can substantially degrade the total power conversion efficiency (PCE). The review herein presents an extensive analysis of possible means for mitigating these drawbacks through the concurrent design of the impedance matching circuitries and the rectifiers. The review considers several approaches, including low-power reflectionmatched matching circuitries, sensitive Dickson-type rectifiers, novel cross-coupled differential driver designs, and hybrid system topologies. Using analytical discourse, the paper presents pertinent insight for the design of new-generation RF energy harvesters with the possibility of achieving high levels of sensitivity and efficiency. The improvements are of particular importance for far-field IoT and bio-medical applications, whereby devices are usually expected to operate on only several microwatts of power.

title: Optimal Control for the Transient Stability with Grid-Forming Inverters under High-Penetration EVs-Integration
authors: Hongyu Long, Zhenguang Jiang, Tingting Xu, Yi Long, Xiaorui Hu, Xin Chen
abstract: With the widespread use of electric vehicles (EVs), power systems face challenges of reduced inertia and declining transient stability. This paper proposes an enhanced droop control strategy for LCL-type grid-forming inverters, incorporating a novel power angle compensation controller to dynamically regulate power angle dynamics. The proposed a power angle compensation controller (PACC) significantly improves post-fault recovery speed and transient stability by real-time adjustment of the inverter output voltage phase angle. The PACC adjusts the inverter output voltage phase angle in real time. It quickly balances the power angle difference with synchronous generators and effectively suppresses oscillations. Simulation results show the strategy significantly shortens recovery times for power angle difference, frequency, and power. It also reduces rotor speed deviations. The approach provides an efficient and robust solution for power systems with high power electronics penetration. It enhances grid resilience.

title: Tunable Acoustic Superscattering
authors: Long Sun, Ying Wu
abstract: Superscattering refers to the scattering cross section of a scatterer significantly surpassing the single-channel limit. It has attracted great attention due to its potential for real applications, such as sensing, bioimaging and light trapping. For acoustic waves, Helmholtz resonator, coiling-up space, and hyperbolic structure are among the structures for superscattering. However, these designs are typically static in scale and shape, limiting the frequency range over which superscattering can occur and reducing flexibility for practical applications. In this work, we report a novel design of reconfigurable structure in two dimensions, which can dynamically tune the frequency of superscattering. This superscatter comprises a circular core located at the center of a larger shell with a layer of air separating them. The core and the shell have different refractive indices. We show both analytically and numerically that such structure leads to superscattering and the frequency occurs at frequencies that are sensitive to the geometry of the inner core, offering a flexible and responsive approach to superscattering design principles.

title: Conditional Equivalent Length of Complex Piping Systems for Fluid Transport
authors: Gencho Popov, Kliment Klimentov, Boris Kostov, Kaloyan Totev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The paper presents a methodology for determining the equivalent length <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{e}}$</tex> of the most commonly encountered complex pipe systems. This methodology has been developed based on an original method for the hydraulic calculation of pipelines using criterial equations that are generally valid for different flow regimes of fluids in pipes. A key advantage of the proposed methodology for determining <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{e}$</tex> is that it eliminates the need for iterative methods to calculate friction losses. Its application requires only the geometric parameters of the pipeline sections (diameter, length, and equivalent roughness), as well as the coefficients of local resistances included in them. This makes the methodology universally applicable to all fully developed turbulent flow regimes of fluids in piping systems. The derived relationships can be used to solve a wide range of practical problems, such as determining the operating regimes of pumping and fan systems for fluid transportation, performing energy analyses of characteristic flow-rate control methods for such systems, optimizing pipeline networks, and others. In studies of the energy efficiency of such systems, the impact of variations in the hydraulic resistances of individual branches of the pipeline network on the overall resistance characteristic of the system can be evaluated relatively easily and with sufficient accuracy by means of the equivalent length parameter.

title: Evaluation of Quality at University as Challenge in Education
authors: Daniela Yordanova, Ivanichka Serbezova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The quality of education is a global challenge, related directly with quality of workforce and competitiveness of economics in every country. If there is a relationship between the quality of life and level of technologies applied in industry than the quality of higher education is one of the main prerequisites for attractiveness of country as place for investments and living. Bulgarian legislation sets the main framework for quality standards in university education. Provision of funding for state higher schools is related with many criteria, referring to professional realization of students. Accreditation procedures which provide permission of every high school are related also high quality of educational process. One of main aspects of evaluation is correspondence of the educational product with employers' requirements. The paper discusses one possible approach for evaluation of employers' opinion about the quality of the educational product at higher education which is a main precondition for constantly updating and adapting the educational process to the needs of the labour market. We propose a structure of questionnaire that can be extended and modified for the needs of every professional field. The example is applied at University of Ruse. The higher share of specialists with higher education hired by employers <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-71.51 \%$</tex> graduated Technical Sciences, followed by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 4. 9 5 \%}$</tex> from Social, Economic, and Legal Sciences and 9.68 % from Pedagogical Sciences. 91.3 % of employers are satisfied from graduates' theoretical knowledge, 87 % from practical skills and 82.6 % from ability to combine theory with practice. 95,7% of employers state that software skills as important for work at their organisation. Other important competences include teamwork - for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$95,7 \%$</tex> of respondents, multitasking - 95,7%, time management <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-95,6 \%$</tex>, organization and execution <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-93,4 \%$</tex>, decision-making <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-\mathbf{9 1, 3 \%}$</tex>, and problem-solving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-\mathbf{9 1, 3 \%. 8 8. 6 \%}$</tex> of employers are willing to hire University of Ruse's graduates. The labour market forecast shows that <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 0, 6 \%}$</tex> of employers plan to employ specialists graduates Technical Sciences field. Higher interest was declared for graduates in Social, Economic and Legal Sciences from 33 % of employers, in Natural Sciences, Mathematics and Informatics - <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex> and Health and Sports 15 %.

title: Emerging Paradigms for Securing Federated Learning Systems
authors: Amr Akmal Abouelmagd, Amr Hilal
publish: 2025 IEEE Global Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things (GCAIoT)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) facilitates collaborative model training while keeping raw data decentralized, making it a conduit for leveraging the power of IoT devices while maintaining privacy of the locally collected data. However, existing privacypreserving techniques present notable hurdles. Methods such as Multi-Party Computation (MPC), Homomorphic Encryption (HE), and Differential Privacy (DP) often incur high computational costs and suffer from limited scalability. This survey examines emerging approaches that hold promise for enhancing both privacy and efficiency in FL, including Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs), Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs), Quantum Computing (QC), Chaos-Based Encryption (CBE), Neuromorphic Computing (NC), and Swarm Intelligence (SI). For each paradigm, we assess its relevance to the FL pipeline, outlining its strengths, limitations, and practical considerations. We conclude by highlighting open challenges and prospective research avenues, offering a detailed roadmap for advancing secure and scalable FL systems.

title: CNC-TP: Classifier Nominal Concept Based on Top-Pertinent Attributes
authors: Yasmine Souissi, Fabrice Boissier, Nida Meddouri
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Knowledge Discovery in Databases (KDD) aims to exploit the vast amounts of data generated daily across various domains of computer applications. Its objective is to extract hidden and meaningful knowledge from datasets through a structured process comprising several key steps: data selection, preprocessing, transformation, data mining, and visualization. Among the core data mining techniques are classification and clustering. Classification involves predicting the class of new instances using a classifier trained on labeled data. Several approaches have been proposed in the literature, including Decision Tree Induction, Bayesian classifiers, Nearest Neighbor search, Neural Networks, Support Vector Machines and Formal Concept Analysis (FCA). The last one is recognized as an effective approach for interpretable and explainable learning. It is grounded in the mathematical structure of the concept lattice, which enables the generation of formal concepts and the discovery of hidden relationships among them. In this paper, we present a state-of-the-art review of FCA-based classifiers. We explore various methods for computing closure operators from nominal data and introduce a novel approach for constructing a partial concept lattice that focuses on the most relevant concepts. Experimental results are provided to demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed method.

title: Empowering Conversational Systems Through AI Agents Specialized in Reusable APIs Across Software Ecosystems
authors: Rayfran Rocha Lima, Irineu Evangelista Cruz de Brito, Jardel da Cunha Nascimento, Elias Nascimento Nogueira
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Software reuse is a key strategy in modern engineering practices, yet it remains underexploited in enterprise environments due to technical barriers and limited accessibility to existing functionalities. This paper presents a novel architecture that integrates LLMs with AI agents to enhance conversational systems, enabling intelligent reuse of enterprise APIs through natural language commands. To test the feasibility of this solution, a multi-agent system with three roles was designed - LLM interpreter, recommender agent, and executor agent - deployed in a real-world setting. The solution evaluation combined automated accuracy tests, a TAM-based user satisfaction survey, and focus groups with developers. The bge-m3 embedding model achieved the highest top-5 recommendation accuracy. Users reported increased perceived usefulness and ease of use. Developers valued the modularity of the architecture, but expressed concerns about operational risks. The proposed architecture effectively connects user intent to actionable enterprise APIs, enhancing reuse, accessibility, and adaptability while pointing to future improvements in security, learning, and transparency.

title: Less is more? an ablation study on AutoAttack for adversarial robustness evaluation
authors: Luca Melis, Luca Scionis, Fabio Brau, Maura Pintor, Battista Biggio
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: AutoAttack is widely recognized as a standard adversarial robustness evaluation framework, yet the individual contributions of its components and mechanisms remain insufficiently explored. In this work, we present a comprehensive ablation study on the standard AutoAttack version, isolating the singular contribution of each component, focusing on the attack ensemble, random initialization, and Expectation over Transformation (EoT) optimization across four different state-of-the-art robust models. Our analysis reveals that simplified attack sequences often achieve results comparable to the complete AutoAttack sequence while requiring significantly fewer computational resources. Furthermore, our findings show that EoT generally provides modest improvements in attack success rate, while the benefits of random initialization may vary depending on the model architecture. By identifying which among the AutoAttack components has the most significant influence on the robustness evaluation, our work offers practical recommendations for designing efficient evaluation frameworks that balance thoroughness with computational cost considerations.

title: A Hybrid Kalman Filter and Machine Learning Framework for Data-Driven SoH Estimation of Lithium-Ion Batteries
authors: Diaa-Eldin A. Mansour, Ahmed S. Abdellah, Youssef Elassal, Alaa M. Salman, Tamer F. Megahed, Xiangning Lin
abstract: Accurate estimation of a battery's State of Health (SoH) is essential for optimizing battery management systems (BMS) and enhancing the lifespan and reliability of battery-operated devices. This paper introduces a novel approach that integrates various machine learning algorithms, including decision tree methods, linear regression, Gaussian Support Vector Machines (SVM), neural networks, and kernel methods, to predict SoH based on real-time data from voltage, current, and temperature sensors. By employing performance metrics such as root mean square error (RMSE) and R-squared (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>), the study evaluates the effectiveness of these models in providing reliable SoH assessments. The findings emphasize the significance of advanced predictive modeling in battery management, enabling proactive maintenance and optimizing charge/discharge cycles. This work highlights the potential of machine learning to enhance battery management practices, particularly in applications such as electric vehicles and renewable energy storage.

title: Symplectic integrator approach to propagation of ultrashort light pulses in dispersive media
authors: Tokuei Sako
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: A simple numerical method is developed for propagating light pulses in dispersive media relying on the symplectic integrator formalism to the time-dependent Maxwell equations. The effect of dispersion, namely, frequency- or wavelengthdependent group velocities of light pulses, is taken into account in terms of exponential-type translation operators both for the standard time-propagation and for the space-propagation, the latter being used for chirped pulses. These propagators are evaluated in either of the wave number k space or frequency f space. The simplicity of this method allows us not only intuitive insights into dispersion properties but also easy coding avoiding involved mathematical and programming techniques. The proposed method is applied to two typical examples of pulse broadening and compression.

title: Impacts of distributed energy resources on the feasibility of AI-based OPF surrogates
authors: Ahmad Opeyemi Zubair, Merkebu Zenebe Degefa, Kristian Thorsen, Chiara Bordin
abstract: This paper investigates the impact of distributed energy resource (DER) penetration levels on the feasibility of AI-based surrogate models for solving the optimal power flow (OPF) problem. Using a realistic distribution network with photovoltaic and wind-based DERs, a surrogate model is trained on OPF solutions optimized for loss minimization and evaluated across a range of penetration levels, from 5% to 60% of peak load. The results reveal that while the surrogate achieves high feasibility (>96%) at low penetration levels (5-30%), performance deteriorates at higher levels, reaching approximately 88% at 60% penetration. Constraint violations are strongly tied to DER characteristics: voltage magnitude violations occur at buses hosting large-capacity DERs, while apparent power violations are concentrated at small DER units with tight inverter margins. These findings highlight the sensitivity of OPF surrogate models to DER-induced operational constraints and underscore the challenges of deploying them reliably in high-penetration distribution networks.

title: Effect of Directional Emissivity on Radiative Heat Transfer with Obstacles
authors: Yufei Yan, Kirollos Ernest Matta, Armande Herve, Tarik Bourouina, Elyes Nefzaoui
abstract: Directional emissivity (DE) characterizes how a material's emissivity varies with the emission direction above its surface, enabling not only enhanced radiative cooling but also directional radiative heat exchange for diverse applications, including targeted directional heating. Directional selective thermal emission is especially advantageous for optimizing cooling efficiency in environments where nearby structures might otherwise hinder cooling, as well as for achieving precise heating in applications such as efficient indoor heating. In this work, we numerically investigate the energy exchange between surfaces and surrounding obstacles. We evaluate the thermal behavior of directionally selective materials and discuss the cases of isotropic and anisotropic emissivity under varying view factors and temperature conditions. We also consider the particular use case of an urban environment where a thermal emitter can be surrounded by buildings. Isotropic materials, with their uniform emissivity, exhibit the highest cooling power under low view factor conditions. However, as the view factor increases, anisotropic materials, particularly those with near-zenith high emissivity, outperform isotropic materials. Metamaterials with near-horizon high emissivity show strong targeted heating properties. Additionally, we find that materials with strongly selective emissivity, characterized by a single peak in their DE profile, behave similarly to low-emissivity materials in terms of cooling performance. These results highlight that angle-selective materials can enhance cooling efficiency by leveraging directional thermal emission, with potential application for energy savings in building cooling systems and urban heat island mitigation.

title: Quantum Architecture Search Via Iterative Elimination
authors: Jiacong Zuo, Hongxiang Chen, Zhengjie Zeng, Zhengjiang Li, Zhimin He, Haozhen Situ
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Variational Quantum Algorithms (VQAs) are central to the utility of Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices, but their performance is critically dependent on the design of the parameterized quantum circuit (PQC) ansatz. Manual design of these circuits is a complex, non-trivial task requiring significant expertise. To address this, Quantum Architecture Search (QAS) has emerged to automate the discovery of optimal circuit structures. However, many QAS methods incur substantial computational costs by requiring full training of candidate circuits. In this paper, we introduce QAS via iterative elimination, a novel framework that efficiently identifies high-performing circuits. Our method begins with a large, randomly generated population of circuits and iteratively prunes this set based on a composite score that evaluates both immediate performance and trainability. We introduce a dynamic weighting scheme that initially prioritizes trainability to avoid barren plateaus and gradually shifts focus to performance as the search progresses. We validate our approach on Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) tasks for the 6-qubit Transverse Field Ising Model and the 5-qubit Heisenberg model. Experimental results show that our method, particularly with the dynamic weighting, discovers circuits that are competitive with those found by state-of-the-art training-free QAS methods, demonstrating a powerful balance between search efficiency and solution quality.

title: A Modular, Distributed Systems Approach for a Low-Cost Parallel Robotic Platform
authors: Jan-Hendrik Meusener, Kevin Kollek, Jan-Christoph Krabbe, Adrian Bauer, Anton Kummert
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper presents design decisions regarding the hard- and firmware for a new, affordable and highly modifiable robot pursuing the goal to increase accessibility to robotics. The objective of this work is to create a platform that facilitates rapid prototyping and experimentation in robotics as this may lead to robust understanding of the difficulties, innovative approaches and standards that are tested and developed by many users and use cases in robotic systems integration. Key parameters for this design include modular hardware and a highly configurable behavior. These features ensure that users can adapt the robot to various applications, from educational to industrial settings. The main contributions of this work include the description and validation of a framework that supports seamless interaction between low-cost subsystems, resulting in a unique platform that offers flexibility, affordability, and distributed control. The work presented in this paper may play a part in facilitating domestic, educational and industrial use of low-cost stationary robots, hopefully promoting greater engagement and innovation in the field of robotics and its integration into different environments.

title: Detection System for the Stiff-Peak Stage in Egg Whites Based on Surface-Tension Variation
authors: Jhon Meza, Huber Alejo, Ayrton Nieves, José Carrizales, Mirko Klusmann, Luis Sampen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: In the food industry, accurately determining the stiff peak phase in egg whites is crucial for products such as meringues and soufflés. Currently, this point is identified by subjective methods such as visual assessment (beater “peak” test) or tactile assessment (inverted bowl test) [1], [2]. These approaches present low reproducibility between operators and slow down production lines. Although instrumental alternatives such as rheometry or spectroscopy exist [3], [4], their high cost and complexity make them unfeasible for large-scale industrial applications. This study presents an objective and economical method to detect the stiff peak by monitoring the electric current in a mixer at constant voltage. The central hypothesis is that changes in the mechanical strength of the foam during beating are directly reflected in variations in energy consumption [3]. The experiments showed a characteristic pattern in the current-time curve. First, a rapid increase from 0.000 A to 0.011 A, corresponding to the low viscosity of the liquid egg white. Then, progressively increasing up to 0.036 A, marking the stiff peak where the foam reaches its maximum structural strength [4], [5]. Our analysis of 15 independent tests showed that the electrical method correctly identified the stiff peak point in $\mathbf{8 6. 6 \%}$ of cases $\boldsymbol{(} \boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{2. 1 \%}$ error, $87 \%$ confidence interval) when compared to the assessment of three certified experts. The current showed a standard deviation of 0.004 A at the point of maximum resistance $(0.038 \pm 0.004 \mathrm{~A})$, confirming the reproducibility of the method.

title: Evaluating Mobile Phone Microphone Recordings for Metal Processing Sound Analysis
authors: Nikolay Yordanov, Marin Zhilevski, Mikho Mikhov, Oleg Krol, Vladimir Sokolov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper focuses on the use of mobile phone audio recordings in various mechanical operations for a class of machine tools. The aim is to create a general approach applicable to diverse types of machines and the electrical drives that make them up by using cost-effective ways to capture acoustic data. It evaluates how variations in microphone distance and placement affect the acoustic characteristics of the recordings, and they are analyzed to assess the impact of these variables. The audio recordings are converted into visual representations using the Symmetrized Point Model (SDP) method, which converts sound into image-based data for processing by machine learning. This methodology offers a costeffective, scalable solution for real-time monitoring and fault detection in industrial environments and predictive maintenance.

title: Modelling of the Noise Emissions of Centrifugal Fan with Different Impellers Geometry
authors: Vesela Mihova, Nikolay Kovachev, Ivaylo Nikolaev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Noise represents a significant hygienic, diagnostic, and technical parameter influencing the safety of human-machine systems, as well as the quality of life and occupational environments. This study presents a statistical analysis of the noise generated by a hydraulic system equipped with a centrifugal fan. Four impellers with different geometric configurations were investigated. The dependence of the noise, in individual octave bands, on impeller type and fan flow rate was modelled. A comparative analysis of different models was made. The obtained models help to find a closer relationship between impeller constructive parameters, operating mode and emitted noise. The results of the present work could be used for optimizing the operating mode of fan-assisted systems and the emitted noise.

title: CoWeT: Weakly Supervised Collaborative Learning for CT Image Disease Grading and Localization
authors: Shouhong Wan, Jiahao Li, Hongwu Liu, Bingbing Zou, Wanqin Wang, Peiquan Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Accurate disease grading (assessing lesion severity) and localization (pinpointing lesions) in CT images are critical for clinical diagnosis. While vision-language models typically require pixel-level annotations, medical CT annotation is timeconsuming, labor-intensive, and inconsistent due to differences in experience and annotation styles among experts. Consequently, most datasets provide only image-level category labels, posing significant challenges for current vision-language models under weak supervision, such as difficulty in accurately identifying ambiguous lesion features, susceptibility to confirmation bias, and the risk of error accumulation during training. To address these challenges, we propose CoWeT, a dual-branch collaborative weakly supervised text-guided visual-language model for disease grading and localization. Our model employs a dual-branch collaborative learning strategy, introducing mutual supervision between branches to refine features collaboratively and mitigate confirmation bias, alongside a novel Text Prompt Box (TPB) module that leverages pathology reports as textual prompts to intelligently filter pseudo-labels for robust lesion localization and grading under weak supervision. Evaluations on RTDP and LND datasets show that CoWeT outperforms state-of-the-art methods on accuracy and average precision.

title: Theoretical Determination of the Radius of a Ring Die in Granulation Machines Operating by the Pressing Method
authors: Yuriy Enakiev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Theoretical aspects for determining the radius of the ring die of granulation machines operating by the pressing method have been developed. The obtained formula theoretically defines the size of the granulating die radius and relates the geometric parameters of the die to the physical and mechanical characteristics of the granulated material. The angle of material capture by the pressing roller has been determined depending on the angle of friction of the material on the surface of the ring die of granulation machines operating by the pressing method
