title: Optimization of the Parameters of a Device for Grading Apples in Order to Obtain Maximum Separation Accuracy
authors: Ivan Mortev, Elena Dimitrova, Kiril Stefanov, Yuriy Enakiev, Dmitry Domuschi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: A device for passive sorting of fruits and vegetables has been developed, intended for small farms of up to 10 ha. The device has a simple design, is easy to operate, and has low production costs. Maximal value of the optimization parameter, correct of grading - 83 % are achieved by minimal value of the angle of inclined grid. In this case too many apples are getting hold between the sticks of grid. This problem can be solved by hand helping of mowing the fruits. Grading apples with inclined grid is possible only with hand separation of fruits which are damaged, infection of fungi or insects and any others which cannot be removed with inclined grid.

title: Physics-Informed Deep Learning for Wind Downscaling over Oslo
authors: Jivitesh Sharma, Islen Vallejo, Rune Åvar Ødegård, Thanh Le, Amir Taherkordi, Frank Eliassen
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Running a numerical weather model such as WRF at kilometre or sub-kilometre grid spacing over a regional domain is computationally expensive. We present physics-informed deeplearning models that ingest a single 9km WRF wind field and simultaneously predict two finer-scale wind fields at 3 km and 1 km resolution via dual decoder heads. Four representative architectures are benchmarked-Deep Residual U-Net (DeepRU), DEVINE, a bespoke 3-D Transformer, and a Fourier Neural Operator (FNO)-each trained with divergence-free, vorticity, and Navier-Stokes residual constraints plus Charbonnier and gradient perceptual losses. We train and validate our models on the city of Oslo for the year 2018. DeepRU achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}=0.94$</tex> (RMSE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.050$</tex>) at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 k m}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}=0.89(\mathbf{R M S E}=0.065)$</tex> at 1 km. DEVINE, Transformer 3-D, and FNO yield 3 km scores of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.91-0.93$</tex>, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1} \mathbf{ k m}$</tex> scores lower by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.02-0.08$</tex>, illustrating the increased difficulty of finer-scale reconstruction. Physicsinformed losses improve all models compared to MSE-only baselines, and the residual architecture (DeepRU) remains most effective for this dual-scale task.

title: An Evaluation of Machine Learning Models for Analyzing User Sentiments on the Livin' by Mandiri Application
authors: Rama Ashari, Arief Setyanto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: This study presents a sentiment analysis of user reviews on the Livin' by Mandiri mobile banking application, using a dataset of Indonesian-language reviews collected from the Google Play Store. Reviews were labeled based on their star ratings, with 5-star reviews classified as positive and 1-star reviews as negative. The data underwent extensive preprocessing, including tokenization, stopword removal, stemming, and lemmatization. A Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) approach was used to transform the text into feature vectors. Six machine learning algorithms Decision Tree (DT), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Logistic Regression (LR), Random Forest (RF), Naïve Bayes (NB), and Support Vector Machine (SVM) were evaluated. Among these, the SVM achieved the best performance, with an accuracy of 93.4%, precision of 94.7%, recall of 91.6%, and an F1-score of 93.1%. Although ensemble models were also tested, they provided minimal performance gains. The results demonstrate that SVM offers a reliable and efficient solution for sentiment classification of Indonesian-language mobile app reviews, with strong potential for real-world financial technology applications.

title: Automatic Medication Dispenser for Seniors
authors: Katarína Dudová, Norbert Ferenčík, Teodor Tóth, Bibiána Ondrejová, Miriam Čurillová, Radovan Hudak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This project presents the design and development of an automatic medication dispenser intended to assist elderly individuals in managing their daily medication schedules more effectively and independently. The system is built around the Arduino Uno microcontroller, selected for its reliability, affordability, and compatibility with various peripheral components. Key hardware elements include an MG996R servo motor for precise dose dispensing, a KY-004 button module for user input, a 0.91-inch OLED display for real-time monitoring, and a DS1302 real-time clock module to ensure accurate medication timing.The device is enclosed in a custom 3D-printed housing designed to provide both functionality and user-friendliness while protecting the internal components. Through the integration of hardware and software, the system automates the medication dispensing process, minimizes human error, and enhances treatment adherence among elderly patients.This solution is cost-effective, scalable, and customizable, making it suitable for home-based healthcare applications. By reducing dependence on caregivers and preventing missed or incorrect doses, the proposed device contributes to better health outcomes and supports independent living for seniors. Furthermore, its modular design allows for potential future enhancements, including wireless connectivity, mobile application integration, and advanced monitoring features, making it a promising step toward smart healthcare solutions.

title: Redundancy Mitigation: Towards Accurate and Efficient Image-Text Retrieval_supp1-3643601.pdf
authors: Yupeng Hu
abstract: Image-text retrieval (ITR) is a pivotal task in cross-modal research. However, existing methods often suffer from a fundamental yet overlooked challenge: redundancy. This issue manifests as both semantic redundancy within unimodal representations and relationship redundancy in cross-modal alignments. This not only inflates computational costs but also degrades retrieval accuracy by masking salient features and reinforcing spurious correlations. In this work, we are the first to explicitly analyze and address the ITR problem from a redundancy perspective by proposing the iMage-text rEtrieval rEdundancy miTigation (MEET) framework. MEET employs a cascaded, two-stage process to systematically mitigate both forms of redundancy. First, for Semantic Redundancy Mitigation, it repurposes deep hashing and quantization as synergistic tools, producing compact yet highly discriminative representations. Second, for Relationship Redundancy Mitigation, it progressively refines the cross-modal alignment space by filtering misleading negative samples and adaptively reweighting informative pairs. The structural integration of these modules under a unified optimization objective provides a clear and interpretable pathway to retrieval. Extensive experiments on multiple benchmarks demonstrate that MEET consistently surpasses state-of-the-art methods, validating its effectiveness and generalizability.

title: Multi-LiDAR Registration: A Joint Sensor-Centric Optimization Approach
authors: Jin Wu, Chengxi Zhang
abstract: MultiLiDAR fusion is widely used to increase scene coverage and improve 3D reconstruction quality, but jointly registering point sets from scanners with different resolutions, scales, fields of view, and noise characteristics remains difficult and directly impacts sensing accuracy. This letter presents a sensorcentric multiLiDAR joint registration framework that (i) lifts ICP to a highdimensional formulation to jointly align multiple scans with blockstructured rotation couplings, (ii) introduces datadriven weighting and a twostage outlier diagnostics procedure tailored to crosssensor inconsistencies, and (iii) performs uncertaintyaware regularization using closedform covariances for both rotation and translation. The method preserves simple SVDbased updates while explicitly addressing heterogeneous sensor characteristics. Validation on two hardware platforms—a dual 2D spinning setup (SICK TIM520, Hokuyo UST10LX) and a dual Ouster OS1128 suite—demonstrates sensorsystem–level accuracy gains, reducing accumulated pose error (APE) by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$26.9\sim 40.8\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> relative to representative ICP variants, with run times <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\approx 3 \times$</tex-math></inline-formula> faster than p2pICP and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\approx 38 \times$</tex-math></inline-formula> faster than GoICP (slightly slower than ESICP). These results substantiate a direct contribution to sensor systems by improving multiLiDAR integration robustness, accuracy, and deployment practicality.

title: Fine-Grained Image Captioning by Ranking Diffusion Transformer
authors: Jun Wan, Min Gan, Lefei Zhang, Jie Zhou, Jun Liu, Bo Du, C. L. Philip Chen
abstract: The CLIP visual feature-based image captioning models have developed rapidly and achieved remarkable results. However, existing models still struggle to produce descriptive and discriminative captions because they insufficiently exploit fine-grained visual cues and fail to model complex vision–language alignment. To address these limitations, we propose a Ranking Diffusion Transformer (RDT), which integrates a Ranking Visual Encoder (RVE) and a Ranking Loss (RL) for fine-grained image captioning. The RVE introduces a novel ranking attention mechanism that effectively mines diverse and discriminative visual information from CLIP features. Meanwhile, the RL leverages the ranking of generated caption quality as a global semantic supervisory signal, thereby enhancing the diffusion process and strengthening vision–language semantic alignment. We show that by collaborating RVE and RL via the novel RDT—and by gradually adding and removing noise in the diffusion process—more discriminative visual features are learned and precisely aligned with the language features. Experimental results on popular benchmark datasets demonstrate that our proposed RDT surpasses existing state-of-the-art image captioning models in the literature. The code is publicly available at: https://github.com/junwan2014/RDT.

title:
A Self-Adaptive Decomposition and Dimensionality Reduction Scheme Using C/N
                    <sub>0</sub>
                    -Only for Enhanced Detection of Pseudolite Interference
authors: Xiaotao Han, Qing Wang, Jiujing Xu, Haonan Cui, Zhenyu Yang
abstract: Machine learning algorithms demonstrate strong efficacy in detecting interference signals in indoor pseudolite systems. Nonetheless, their dependence on multiple signal parameters limits practical applicability, as some devices may lack the capability to acquire all required parameters. To address this issue, this study proposes a self-adaptive decomposition and dimensionality reduction (SDDR) scheme that relies solely on the carrier-to-noise ratio (C/N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub>) parameter. The proposed scheme consists of two modules. In the first module, a dung beetle optimization (DBO) algorithm improved in population diversity and exploration capability is integrated with variational mode decomposition (VMD) to adaptively extract C/N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> signal features and construct a multidimensional dataset. In the second module, a principal component analysis strategy (PCA) based on maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) is introduced to assess the intrinsic dimensionality of the multidimensional dataset and dimensionality reduction, thereby suppressing redundant components and enhancing model generalization. Validation on two pseudolite datasets demonstrates that C/N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> signals processed by the SDDR method are more suitable for machine learning-based detection. Specifically, the average detection accuracy of support vector machines and long short-term memory networks improves by 8.4% and 6.1% on the entire dataset, while their average detection accuracy for line-of-sight (LOS) signals increases by 13.0% and 13.2%, respectively.

title: Reconstruct Multi-Scale Features for Lightweight Small Object Detection in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Yuancheng Huang, Renwei Qin, Guoliang Zhao, Hong Ji, Xiangtao Zheng, Yanfei Zhong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Most small objects are missed when object detection algorithms are transferred from natural images to remote sensing images. Constructing multi-scale features has been proven to be an effective approach for detecting small objects. However, existing methods for multi-scale features have two limitations: insufficient discriminative capability and sparse semantic-spatial information, which fail to fully leverage the potential of multi-scale features. To overcome these limitations, we propose the Multiscale Feature Reconstruction Network (MRN), which introduces three novel modules during feature extraction, fusion, and enhancement: the Composite Multi-scale Feature Extraction Module (CEM), Interlayer Feature Joint Module (IJM), and Spatial-Semantic Information Cross Module (SSM). First, CEM utilizes a multi-branch structure to aggregate scale information. Dilated convolution and asymmetric convolution are extensively used in the branches, which expand the receptive field and capture information of rectangular instances, respectively. Second, the IJM leverages a gating mechanism to achieve pixel-level feature enhancement for feature maps at different hierarchical depths. Finally, the SSM alleviates high-level semantic feature information imbalance through dual-branch information interaction. Furthermore, to utilize the limited computational resources, we propose a lightweight version called MRN_Lite. We evaluate MRN and MRN_Lite on three existing public datasets: AI-TOD, VEDAI, and VisDrone2019. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our method. In comparison experiments, both versions of the model outperform the state of the art (SOTA). And MRN_Lite has less than 50% of the FLOPs and parameters of MRN, which has comparable performance to the original version.

title: Joint Power and Admission Control for Fluid Antenna System-Aided Interference Channels
authors: Shu Cai, Yikai Chen, Jun Zhang, Qi Zhang, Zi-Qiong Lian, Ya-Feng Liu
abstract: Joint power and admission control (JPAC) is crucial for interference management in wireless networks, but its mixed-integer nature renders the problem NP-hard. This letter pioneers JPAC optimization for fluid antenna system (FAS)-aided interference channels, where users leverage dynamic port selection to enhance spatial diversity. We formulate the FAS-JPAC problem for a K-link single-input single-output (SISO) interference channel as a unified sparse ℓ0-minimization problem. The introduction of port selection variables induces novel integer constraints and bilinear SINR constraints, challenges absent in prior JPAC formulations. To address these challenges, we propose a generalized ℓq-minimization deflation (GLQMD) framework. Our solution features: (1) An alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM)-based algorithm with semi-closed-form updates for efficient resolution of the nonconvex sparse ℓq-minimization subproblem; and (2) Port-aware pre/postprocessing that accelerates deflation and narrow the ℓq-ℓ0 approximation gap, respectively. Simulations show that FAS-JPAC yields substantial gains in both admitted links and power efficiency over conventional JPAC baselines while maintaining runtimes on the same order as LQMD.

title: Edge-Enabled Deep Learning Architecture for Traffic Sign Recognition and Driver Behavior Analysis
authors: Nishad Ajay Harsulkar, Sarika N. Patil, Saurabh Autade, Sarika B. Patil, Sujal Koli
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: A real-time traffic sign identification and recognition system that combines deep learning with edge computing technology is presented in this study. The system leverages a custom-trained YOLOv8n model, achieving 90% accuracy on a traffic sign dataset collected from the Pune region, including classes such as 'speed_limit', 'traffic_signal', 'stop_sign', and 'cross_walk'. By deploying the model on edge devices, the system ensures low-latency processing, making it suitable for real-world scenarios like in-vehicle assistance and smart traffic monitoring. The recognized traffic signs are further analyzed in comparison with real-time speed data to generate actionable outputs, such as alerts or logs, enhancing driver awareness and promoting road safety. This approach not only aids in accident prevention and detection of harsh driving behaviour but also opens pathways for broader applications in Smart City initiatives, ADAS support systems, and intelligent fleet management. The study demonstrates that integrating computer vision and edge AI can significantly improve traffic flow, safety, and urban mobility infrastructure.

title: Aspect Based Sentiment Analysis by Leveraging Machine Learning for Mulitlingual Sentiment Data
authors: Gaurav Singh, Nandana Prabhu, Deepti Patole
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: There has been notable increase in wanting to know the consumer's opinions on specific aspects of products and services, particularly by customer-focused industries. Aspect Based Sentiment Analysis assists in uncovering detailed feedback by associating sentiments with attributes, instead of treating the entire text as an isolated opinion. Most ABSA systems in use have been designed for English or other singlelanguage contexts, however there is a growing need for tools that handle opinions expressed in multiple languages. This work addresses that gap by developing a machine learning-based ABSA system tailored for multilingual hotel reviews, specifically in English and Italian. The system uses transformer-based language models to identify aspects and assign corresponding sentiment values. To support this, a custom dataset was created by expanding the TripAdvisor Multilingual ABSA dataset (Trip-MAML) with public review data and synthetically generated samples that include informal expressions, emojis, and ambiguous language constructs. This made the compound dataset better reflect the real-world linguistic diversities being dealt with. Models- Multilingual BERT (mBERT) and XLMRoBERTa (XLM-R)- were trained and tested for sentiment and aspect classification. XLM-R demonstrated a stronger performance, achieving a F1-Score of 0.9319 compared to 0.5802 achieved by mBERT. These statistics suggest that XLM<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}$</tex> proved more effective at capturing nuanced sentiment patterns across languages. The findings offer practical insights for building scalable and accurate multilingual ABSA systems in both commercial and research environments.

title: Smart Email for the Visually Impaired: A Voice-Enabled Approach to Digital Inclusion
authors: Nahush Thuse, Dhiraj Wadile, Pushkar Pattiwar, Vaishnavi Sawant, Jyoti Jadhav
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Visually impaired individuals encounter significant difficulties when navigating conventional email platforms, which primarily rely on visual interaction and manual inputs, restricting their ability to communicate independently. To overcome these challenges, this research introduces an advanced desktop-based, voice-enabled email system that integrates cutting-edge Speech-to-Text (S-T-T) and Text-to-Speech (T-T-S) technologies with an intuitive Voice Command Interface. This system enables users to compose, send, and access emails entirely through voice commands, eliminating the dependency on visual elements. Furthermore, it facilitates seamless inbox navigation and attachment management, empowering users to efficiently handle emailrelated tasks. By dismantling visual barriers, this innovation enhances accessibility, fosters self-sufficiency, and serves as a practical tool for both personal and professional communication. Ultimately, this solution contributes to digital inclusion, improves the quality of life for visually impaired people, and sets a new standard for voice-driven accessibility solutions, paving the way for broader advancements in assistive technology.

title: CryptoMap AI :- An AI Powered Solution for Mapping Cryptocurrency Transactions to Their Final Destinations
authors: Vaibhav Suryawanshi, Sagar Shinde, Yash Desai, Pavan Bhavsar, Meherdeep Patane, Darshan Tipale
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The widespread adoption of cryptocurrencies has significantly impacted the financial landscape, offering both innovation and new avenues for criminal exploitation, particularly in drug trafficking. This paper proposes CryptoMapAI, an AI-powered system designed to trace and analyze cryptocurrency transactions associated with illicit activities. The objective is to assist law enforcement agencies in following the transaction trail across major blockchain networks, including Bitcoin, Ethereum, and privacy-focused blockchains like Monero. By leveraging AI and cross-chain data aggregation, CryptoMapAI enhances the ability to identify the final destinations of suspicious funds. Experimental results demonstrate improved accuracy and efficiency in flagging high-risk transactions compared to traditional methods, thereby contributing to the fight against crypto-enabled crime.

title: Joint Estimation and Detection for Massive Access in Low-Altitude IoT Networks
authors: Ting Liu, Xi Yang, Xiaoming Wang, Ji Wang, Xingwang Li
abstract: This paper investigates the estimation of sparse channel state information (CSI) and the detection of active information in a massive machine-type communication (mMTC) system utilizing an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) base station (BS). Both rotary-wing and fixed-wing UAVs are considered in the context of large-scale connectivity. In the first scenario, the rotary-wing UAV is equipped with a small-scale multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) system. A single measurement vector approach is employed to estimate CSI across the time, frequency, and spatial domains, referred to as 3D-domain estimation. In the second scenario, the study focuses on angular-domain-based CSI estimation and active information detection for an mMTC system utilizing a fixed-wing UAV BS with massive MIMO. The multiple measurement vector Bayesian posteriori minimum mean square error method is implemented to enhance performance. To support these estimations, non-orthogonal discrete Fourier transform sequences are designed for the codebook matrix and transmitted via orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing sub-carriers. Additionally, during each iteration, channel parameter learning facilitates the transfer of extrinsic expectation and extrinsic variance, ensuring convergence to the final results. Numerical simulations demonstrate the proposed approach’s superior estimation and detection performance compared to existing methods, such as approximate message-passing algorithms and the orthogonal matching pursuit method, in terms of normalized mean square error, error detection probability, and bit error rate.

title: Memes as Multifunctional Communicative Artifacts: Humor, Social Learning, and Critical Reflection in Doctoral Education Across Mexico and Estonia
authors: Maricarmen Rodríguez-Guillen, Gabriel Valerio-Ureña
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Although often dismissed as trivial entertainment, internet memes have become a central feature of contemporary digital culture. Their capacity to condense complex ideas into humorous, ironic, or critical visual-textual forms positions them as powerful communicative artifacts. Yet within higher education research, and particularly at the doctoral level, memes remain underexplored. This study addresses that gap by examining how doctoral students in Mexico and Estonia engage with memes as tools for humor, social learning, and critical reflection. Drawing on mass communication theory, social learning theory, and critical thinking frameworks, the study investigates how global meme cultures are locally appropriated to negotiate academic pressures and identity formation. Methodologically, the research employed a qualitative design with semi-structured interviews to capture participants’ interpretations of memes in academic and personal contexts. This approach enabled the analysis of communicative intentions, socio-emotional functions, and cross-cultural differences in meme practices. Findings reveal both convergences and divergences. Across both contexts, memes functioned to elicit humor, foster peer connection, and stimulate reflection on academic struggles. In Mexico, they circulated as collective performances that built solidarity and voiced resistance, while in Estonia they operated more as reflective prompts that supported autonomy and self-regulation. These dynamics illustrate how memes extend the ecology of informal learning, democratizing participation and validating the emotional dimensions of doctoral education. The study demonstrates that memes are not trivial byproducts of digital culture but multifunctional tools that reshape communicative practices in higher education and enrich cross-cultural understandings of academic life, highlighting implications for digital pedagogy and doctoral supervision.

title: An Efficient Water Quality Assessment Method Based on Multi-Sensor Fusion System
authors: Qingmiao Tang, Shujia Yan, Chenggang Dai, Xinbo Liu, Mei Song Tong, Qiang Chen
abstract: This paper designs a water quality assessment system. The working principle of this system is as follows: sensors transmit the collected data to the main system, and the assessment model embedded in the main system uses these data to conduct water quality assessment. The assessment results are then transmitted to the display terminal. By using this system, accurate real-time water quality assessment can be carried out. Coupled with some control devices later, it can help users better manage water quality. After numerous tests, this system can operate stably. Its water quality assessment results are highly consistent with those of the national water quality assessment standards, demonstrating strong robustness.

title: The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Enhancing Tax Compliance: A Study of Indonesian SMEs
authors: Surya Anugrah, Sabo Hermawan, Eka Septariana Puspa, Windy Permata Suyono, Dwi Handarini
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study investigates the role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in enhancing tax compliance among Indonesian Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs). Using a survey of 125 SMEs and grounded in the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) and Institutional Theory, we examine factors influencing the intention to adopt AI-based tax systems. Results show that Perceived Usefulness is the strongest predictor of adoption, followed by Perceived Ease of Use and Trust in AI Systems. Interestingly, Institutional Pressure does not significantly influence behavioral intention, suggesting that regulatory mandates alone are insufficient. The findings highlight that for AI tax systems to be adopted, they must deliver visible benefits, be user-friendly, and foster trust. This research provides insights for policymakers and developers aiming to increase AI adoption in taxation by focusing on system functionality, ease of access, and data security factors that are especially crucial in resourceconstrained SME environments.

title: A Survey on TinyML Applications in Education
authors: Chaymae Yahyati, Ismail Lamaakal, Khalid El Makkaoui, Yassine Maleh, Ibrahim Ouahbi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: Tiny Machine Learning (TinyML) is a new discipline that makes it possible to use machine learning models on embedded systems with limited memory and power. TinyML opens up new ways to make educational tools that are dynamic, affordable, and smart in the area. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of recent TinyML applications in the education sector, highlighting key innovations such as emotion-aware analytics, AI-assisted attendance systems, and inquiry-based learning environments powered by edge AI. We analyze the technological frameworks, implementation challenges, and educational goals of each solution to identify significant research deficiencies, such as limited scalability, a lack of comprehensive datasets, and insufficient integration with widely-used educational platforms.

title: Simulation to Analyzing Vibrations of Human on Full Model 3-D in Finite Element Method
authors: Le Duy Long, Nguyen Thanh Quang, Tran Duc Binh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study explores the vibration characteristics of car seats and the human body using finite element (FE) modeling and numerical simulation to improve passenger comfort during vehicular motion. The finite element method (FEM) effectively handles the complexities of modeling human and seat parameters, accurately simulating biodynamic responses, such as stress distributions along the spine. With Matlab Simulink, a seven-degrees-of-freedom (7-DOF) model analyzes seat and human oscillations due to vertical displacements from vehicle-floor vibrations. Ansys Workbench software further enables detailed FE analysis, using Linear and Parabolic Tetra elements to capture dynamic responses of the car-seat-human system. Human vibration frequencies typically range from 3 to 30 Hz, with an absorption range extending to 80 Hz. Comfort levels are evaluated by root mean square (RMS) acceleration values, below $0.315 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ (ISO 2631-1:1997 standards). The model uses a 3D mesh for the car, seat, and human body, and applies forces and boundary conditions based on ISO 8608 to simulate road-induced vibrations. Free vibration analysis explores 200 natural modes, revealing specific frequencies and bending patterns within the human body. Forced vibration analysis, using fast Fourier transforms (FFT), creates frequency-amplitude relationships across body parts, showing that higher seat cushion stiffness results in greater vibration amplitudes in regions like the head and torso. Simulation results align with ISO standards, demonstrating that optimized seat cushioning can improve comfort. Recommendations include using energy-absorbing materials in cushions to reduce vibration effects on the human body. These simulations provide a practical foundation for designing seating systems that enhance comfort and reduce health risks from prolonged vibration exposure.

title: $8 \times 8$ Element Circularly Polarized Array Antenna in the $300-\text{GHz}$ Band
authors: Seiji Nishi, Kazuhiko Tamesue, Toshio Sato, Takuro Sato, Tetsuya Kawanishi
abstract: We have developed an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8$</tex> element 2 -port right circularly polarized array antenna for communication systems in the 300 GHz band. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8$</tex>-element 2-port right circularly polarized array antenna consists of an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8$</tex>-element 4 -port antenna on a dielectric substrate and a waveguide circuit consisting of two pairs of waveguides that are phase-controlled for sequential connection from the two ports on the dielectric substrate and combine the waves for connection to a standard waveguide flange. From the evaluation of the antenna characteristics, it was confirmed that the loss of the waveguide circuit is about 0.5 dB and that the sequential connection improves the circular polarization characteristics. 21 dBic in antenna gain was obtained for the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8$</tex> element 2 -port array antenna, and an axial ratio below 3 dB was obtained with a frequency bandwidth as wide as 50 GHz. Antenna gain is 3 dB higher, 24 dBic, if the waves from the two ports are merged. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8$</tex> element 2 -port array antenna with phase control on two ports and beam steering of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 7.5^{\circ}$</tex> was confirmed by calculation.

title: Accelerating the Computation of Multilayered Media Green's Functions for RFIC Electromagnetic Simulation Using Deep Complex Networks
authors: Hao Zhou, Peng Zhao, Gaofeng Wang, Yuanao Zhong
abstract: The multilayered media Green's function (MLGF) plays a crucial role in solving electromagnetic problems of layered medium structures, e.g., radio frequency integrated circuit (RFIC). The calculation of MLGF often involves Sommerfeld integrals, which are highly oscillatory and slowly attenuating. This affects computational efficiency of electromagnetic simulation. In this presentation, we propose a novel method leveraging deep complex networks (DCN) to accelerate the computation of MLGF. The method exploits the strengths of complex neural networks by jointly training the real and imaginary parts of MLGF, thereby improving the robustness. To further enhance the computational efficiency of RFIC simulation, the integral equation solver is accelerated by multi-level fast multipole algorithm (MLFMA). Compared to the direct calculation of Sommerfeld integrals and direct solvers, the proposed method significantly improves computational efficiency without compromising accuracy.

title: Multilingual Clickbait News Detection and Classification in Social Media Using Multilingual T5: A Focus on Afaan Oromo and Amharic
authors: Abebe Waldesanbet Gina, Fitsum Gizachew Deriba, Mekuanint Yitayew Tariku
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: With the growth of the internet, the peoples interaction and the way how they interact and access information are changed due social media platform. As individuals rely on digital platforms for real-time updates, traditional news sources have become less prominent. This shift has not only changed news consumption but has also provided an open space for people to express their opinions and feedback on various issues. However, this accessibility introduces challenges; for instance in reliability of information reliability in Amharic and Afaan Oromo Languages. This research proposes a deep learning model, specifically a transformer-based model, to detect clickbait news in these languages. We extracted datasets from Facebook and X using Octoparse, Facepagers, and manual methods, applying preprocessing and rule-based language identification. XLM-R was used for feature extraction to capture semantic meaning, while Multilingual T5 (mT5) was employed for cross-lingual text classification. For prototype development and support the information reliability, we used Python Flask API with Spyder IDE. The results of the analysis indicate that the combined mT5 with XLM-R achieved an accuracy of 91.3%, demonstrating strong performance. The findings revealed the effectiveness of multilingual models in combating clickbait in low-resourced languages, suggesting a scalable solution for content moderation and promoting a more trustworthy digital information environment.

title: Analysis of Annual Changes in Electricity Prices and their Influence on the Value Return of 12.6 kW Peak Photovoltaic System
authors: Ventsislav Keseev, Boris Evstatiev, Dimitar Trifonov, Nikolay Valov, Nicolay Mihailov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The photovoltaic (PV) systems are one of the key renewable solutions for the green transition and currently many new capacities are being installed. The problem is that too many PV powers generate too much unneeded power during daytime in an unpredictable manner, which influences the prices on the electricity exchanges and lowers the PV plant value return. The Bulgarian energy mix for the years 2023 and 2024 is analyzed together with the changing trend of electricity prices and their dependence on the increasing PV energy share. The changing electricity prices are matched to the generated energy of an example 12.6 kW peak PV system and conclusions are drawn. The PV plant and energy shares have risen considerably in 2024, in comparison to 2023, and currently many new PV projects are being developed. The current free market energy prices are enough to cover the costs of the built PV plants, but they exclude the lacking energy storage costs, needed for stable power grids. With the rising PV share, the energy prices fall, especially when the PV systems produce the most, which makes them less competitive. The problems with the power grid stability and with the falling PV energy prices could be overcome with battery energy storage capacities, but their technologies are not developed enough, they cost much and are expected to make the PV plants uncompetitive. The investigated 12.6 kW peak PV system produced 0.8 % less energy in 2024 with 0.38 % lower value in comparison to 2023, calculated monthly.

title: Analysis of the Impact of Wartime Subsistence Support on the Digestive System
authors: Chenggong Zhai, Ping Wang, Jianxiang Li, Xiande Fei, Shan Chen, Ye Tian
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: The impact of wartime subsistence support on the digestive system is an important research area, as the dietary environment and food supply under wartime conditions differ greatly from those in peacetime. During wartime, food security has a significant impact on the digestive system of soldiers. Insufficient nutrition, unsafe food, unhygienic eating environment, and psychological stress experienced by soldiers can all have adverse effects on the digestive system. This paper mainly analyzes the impact of wartime subsistence support on the digestive system from the aspects of possible malnutrition, digestive system diseases, soldiers carrying equipment and supplies for a long time, and increasing the burden on the digestive system. It explores how to reduce the risk of digestive system disorders and improve soldiers' combat effectiveness through reasonable subsistence support in wartime environments. This article suggests that in wartime subsistence support, attention should be paid to balanced nutrition to ensure that soldiers can obtain sufficient nutrients. At the same time, food preservation and handling should be strengthened to reduce the risk of food poisoning and intestinal infections. In addition, attention should be paid to the psychological state of soldiers, providing psychological counseling and support to alleviate the impact of psychological pressure on the digestive system.

title: Deep Learning Meets qPCR: Detecting Fungal Plant Diseases
authors: Panagiotis Christakakis, Eleni Kalogeropoulou, Dimitrios Kapetas, Eleftheria Maria Pechlivani
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Fungal pathogens pose a major threat to global food production, causing substantial yield losses and increasing the dependency on chemical controls. Advanced digital tools, incorporating Artificial Intelligence (AI) driven multi-spectral imaging, support phytopathologists in improving early disease diagnostics through rapid, scalable, and non-destructive methods. This study evaluates a dual AI-based diagnostic framework combining multi-spectral image segmentation with molecular validation to detect B. cinerea during early, asymptomatic stages. A Deep Learning (DL) segmentation model, derived from U-Net++ integrating a lightweight MobileViTV2-1.25 encoder and an augmentation technique for minority classes, was deployed on a newly captured dataset of 80 detached cucumber leaves, obtained from B. cinerea infected as well as control plants. The leaves were imaged at five discrete wavelengths and also subjected to quantitative PCR (qPCR) to measure fungal biomass as a biological ground truth. The model classified leaf regions into healthy, invisible and visible classes. The capability of the approach to detect grey mould was assessed by comparing the DL segmentation outputs with qPCR-based quantification of fungal colonization. Results confirmed the ability of the model to detect infection in tissues where symptoms were either minimal or invisible to the naked eye, achieving an overall segmentation accuracy of 91.9% and a mean IoU of 0.816. This integration of AI-based tools with molecular qPCR benchmarking and confirmation offers a robust methodology that complements phytopathological diagnostics, enabling more informed, early intervention and supporting sustainable crop protection strategies.

title: Polarization Orbital Angular Momentum of Vector Beams
authors: Vladislav D. Zaitsev, Sergey S. Stafeev, Aleksey A. Kovalev, Victor V. Kotlyar
abstract: In this paper, possible definitions of polarisation orbital angular momentum are proposed. One orbital angular momentum is proportional to the azimuthal rate of change of the linear polarisation vector direction, and the second is proportional to the azimuthal rate of change of the degree of ellipticity of the polarisation ellipse. For example, the normalized polarisation orbital angular momentum is equal to the order of the cylindrical vector beam. Two most important characteristics of scalar optical vortices are the topological charge (TC) and the orbital angular momentum (OAM). These characteristics are well studied. However, there are known polarisation optical vortices with the polarisation state changing with the azimuthal angle. These vortices have polarisation singularity points, which are described by indices similar to the TC; however, polarisation OAM for polarisation vortices has not yet been investigated.

title: Integrated Perspectives on Sludge and Biogas Management in Municipal Wastewater Management: A Case Study of the Bacau WWTP
authors: Eduard Popescu, Valentin Nedeff, Florin-Marian Nedeff, Narcis Barsan, Andrei Zaharia, Dana Chitimus
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The management of sludge generated in municipal wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) represents one of the most challenging and cost-intensive aspects of environmental engineering, with significant implications for energy efficiency and sustainability. This study presents an indepth assessment of sludge treatment and biogas management at the Bacău WWTP, Romania, with emphasis on process performance, biogas quality, and potential for technological improvement. Results indicate a relatively stable methane concentration (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 63 \%$</tex>), consistent with proper fermentation, but lower than natural gas standards <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\sim 85 \%)$</tex>, limiting its optimal use in cogeneration. Hydrogen sulfide concentrations presented variability, contributing to equipment corrosion, operational inefficiencies, and increased flaring. While the system demonstrates energy management and surplus generation, significant fractions of biogas are wasted through flaring, highlighting the need for advanced purification, compression, and storage technologies. Recommended measures include the application of activated carbon filters, wet scrubbers, airtight digesters, and tri-generation systems to improve energy recovery, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and ensure operational sustainability. Overall, the research show that modernization of sludge and biogas management systems at Bacău WWTP is critical for enhancing energy efficiency, reducing environmental impacts, and aligning with circular economy principles.

title: Can Deep Learning Models Predict Compositional Outputs Without Log-Ratio Transformations?
authors: Luciano Garim Garcia, Gabriel de Oliveira Ramos, Gabriel Tomasi de Melo, Elaine Dias Pires, Milene Freitas Figueiredo, Joselito Cabral Vazquez, Ariane Santos da Silveira
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Compositional data consist of components expressed as proportions of a whole and carry only relative information. In statistical and machine learning contexts, these data require specialized handling due to their constant-sum constraint and non-Euclidean geometry. A common approach is the application of log-ratio transformations-such as the centered log-ratio (CLR)-to project compositional vectors into Euclidean space. While using CLR for inputs is well established, applying this transformation to compositional outputs remains underexplored. This study evaluates the predictive impact of using CLR on target variables in supervised learning, with a geochemical dataset containing lithogeochemical targets and physical-log predictors. Three deep learning architectures are assessed: CNNBiLSTM, SAIDNN, and MHA-BiRNN, each trained on raw and CLR-transformed outputs. Results consistently show that models trained directly on raw compositions outperform their CLR-transformed counterparts. We identify two causes: (i) the inverse CLR transformation redistributes prediction errors across components, reducing local precision, and (ii) zeros in compositional data introduce artifacts when preprocessed for log-ratio transformations. Furthermore, the models demonstrate good generalization on blind tests, especially when trained on raw data. These findings suggest that modern deep learning models can effectively learn from compositional outputs in their native form, avoiding distortions from transformation pipelines.

title: LLM Powered DeepSeek and BiLSTM Pipeline Used in Aspect Based Sentiment Analysis
authors: Moemen Said, Nadia Smairi, Houda Abadlia
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: A hybrid approach for aspect-based sentiment analysis, which integrates a large language model driven aspect extractor with a bidirectional deep learning classifier, is presented in this paper. The proposed pipeline employs the DeepSeek Transformer to automatically identify relevant aspect terms from input sentences using prompt-based generation. These extracted aspects are, then, embedded into reformulated sentence-aspect pairs and fed into a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory Network to obtain fine-grained sentiment classification. Unlike the traditional pipelines that rely on manual annotations or fixed aspect lists, the introduced method dynamically adapts to diverse sentence structures and domains. The experimental results demonstrate that the system achieved F1-scores of 88.87%, 83.47% and 86.32% when applied on three benchmark datasets (Laptop, Restaurant and a merged corpus), respectively. They also show that better and more accurate aspect-aware sentiment classification can be provided by combining generative aspect extraction with contextual sequence modeling.

title: Blockchain for Decentralized Energy Routing in Eenergy Internet (EI)
authors: Manish Gudhe, Irfan Siddavatam, Ashwini Dalvi, Sunayana Jadhav
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Energy routing protocols are critical to the operation of the Energy Internet (EI), a decentralized and dynamic infrastructure designed to manage real-time power distribution between distributed energy resources (DERs) and consumers. These protocols must address key challenges, including subscriber matching (SM), energy-efficient path (EEP) selection, and real-time transmission scheduling (TS) in a demand-driven environment. Additionally, irreversible energy losses, congestion, and variable DER availability increase the complexity of routing decisions. This paper reviews core design considerations for energy routing in the EI and introduces blockchain as a transformative enabler for secure, transparent, and autonomous peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading. Blockchain technology provides decentralized control, tamper-proof transaction records, and smart contract automation, improving trust, traceability, and real-time responsiveness. The proposed approach enhances energy security, transaction integrity, and interoperability in future decentralized smart grid networks.

title: Contextual Filler Word Detection Using BERT and Prosodic Features for Real-Time Speech Fluency Enhancement
authors: Aditya Wagh, Yugal Salunke, Saroj Phalke, Indrayani Gaidhane, Grishma Bobhate, Yogesh Deshpande
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: In both personal and professional contexts, filler words like “um,” “uh,” “like,” and “you know” frequently impair speech fluency, clarity, and perceived confidence. In order to improve speech fluency without sacrificing meaning, this paper suggests a novel, context-aware framework for real-time filler word detection and replacement. Three model architectures are evaluated. The first uses XGBoost to achieve an F1-score of 93.3% by combining prosodic features pitch, energy, and duration extracted using Librosa with word embeddings based on BERT. In order to capture long-range contextual dependencies, the second model introduces a custom Transformer-based model that integrates self-attention and BERT. Using a Random Forest classifier for disfluency prediction, the third model combines textual and acoustic features in a multimodal manner. According to experimental results, the accuracy of filler word detection is greatly increased by combining prosodic cues with deep contextual embeddings. For real-time applications like public speaking, virtual meetings, and interviews, this framework exhibits great promise. In order to provide real-time fluency assistance, future work will involve expanding multilingual support and implementing the system on wearable and mobile platforms.

title: Optimised Cooling Mechanism for Small-Scale Crypto Mining Rigs: An IoT-based Approach
authors: Abbaraju Sree Tharun Raju, Nikhil Chandran, Jayant Sasikumar, Vighnesh S R, Sabitha S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Cryptocurrency mining has gained popularity over the years, yet many miners still lack efficient mining practices. This paper presents a novel and integrated IoT-based framework for cost-effective and energy-efficient cryptocurrency mining, specifically tailored for small-scale operations. Our approach uniquely combines a Raspberry Pi 4 with a DHT11 sensor for dynamic thermal management, creating an accessible and replicable system. By integrating real-time temperature and humidity monitoring with automated cooling and user alerts, precise thermal regulation is achieved, which is critical for maintaining hardware efficiency and extending its lifespan. The mining process involves solving complex cryptographic puzzles to validate and add transactions to the blockchain, a task that requires significant computational power and generates significant heat. This work helps both researchers and miners understand more cost-effective mining practices in a simpler and more accessible manner. Experimental results demonstrate that our setup maintains optimal operating temperatures and enhances the overall efficiency and reliability of the mining process. This makes it a budget-friendly and accessible framework, contributing to the development of a reliable IoT-based cryptomining setup for small-scale miners and newcomers to the field.

title: Layered Minimums and Virtual Labs in the Service of Industrial Transferability
authors: Edina Popof, Zoltán Gömböcz, Zoltán Illés, Gergely Bencsik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: We present an AI-assisted simulated laboratory environment where the Python and C# ecosystem and entry-level ESP32/Arduino edge devices bridge the gap between educational practice and industrial expectations. The virtual lab provides a cost-effective, safe setting for students to model industrial processes and to practice fault diagnosis and remediation, while lowering the maintenance overhead of physical labs. The system is built on realistic Programmable logic controller (PLC) and process simulations, with measurable Definition-of-Done (DoD) gates and telemetry and observability indicators such as Time-to-First-Success (TTFS), Time-to-Diagnosis (ToD) and a /health endpoint. An LLM-based coach delivers adaptive, personalized feedback and dynamically tunes the training content to learners’ behavioral and cognitive patterns, thereby supporting differentiated instruction. Our result is a reference architecture and methodology optimized for metrics and industrial applicability, which enables rapid prototyping and standardizable quality assurance in an educational environment. The study contributes to the future of educational practice, where the coordinated application of simulation, IoT devices, and artificial intelligence creates a bridge between school and industry, promoting the development of digital competences and labor market integration.

title: VoIP as a Service: Asterisk in OpenStack platform
authors: Martin Kontsek, Pavel Segec, Marek Moravcik, Ivana Bridova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This article explores the integration of Asterisk as a VoIP service within the OpenStack cloud platform. It highlights the advantages of cloud services, particularly for end users and IT departments. The implementation process of Asterisk, including installation, configuration, and the development of automation scripts, is detailed. The significance of Network Address Translation (NAT) functionality is emphasized, along with the development of user-friendly configuration scripts. Lastly, the article discusses challenges encountered with the ManageIQ integration, suggesting potential improvements for future deployments.

title: Slovak Teachers’ Experiences with Educational Robotics and the Development of Computational Thinking
authors: Zuzana Kubincová, Karolína Miková
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This study examines the profiles and experiences of Slovak teachers working with educational robotics (ER), with a strong focus on informatics and computational thinking (CT) in formal education. Survey data from 29 teachers—mostly with backgrounds in informatics and mathematics—revealed a growing interest in using ER as a tool to develop algorithmic thinking, problem-solving skills, and student engagement. Sixteen experienced teachers participated in follow-up interviews, identifying key challenges and implications related to teaching with educational robotics. Blended learning and the interdisciplinary integration of educational robotics into projects were also among the topics that teachers commented on. Teachers emphasized the need for structured training in ER pedagogy, practical resources aligned with national curricula, and more collaboration across schools. The findings suggest that while Slovak teachers demonstrate high motivation to implement ER and foster CT, sustainable adoption requires systemic changes in infrastructure, training, and policy to fully leverage its educational potential.

title: Detail-Enhancement Dual-Domain Fusion Network for Optical-DSM Image Segmentation
authors: Zhenshuai Chen, Wei Xiang, Zhiyuan Lin, Kaixuan Yang, Yunpeng Liu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Optical-DSM segmentation leverages auxiliary Digital Surface Model (DSM) data to enhance optical image segmentation, but faces challenges in effectively extracting unimodal features and multimodal fusion. To address this, we propose the Detail-enhancement Dual-domain Fusion Network (D <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> FNet). First, D <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> FNet employs a double backbone strategy to fully extract unimodal semantic features: a powerful DINOv2-s extracts rich semantic features from optical imagery, while a lightweight ResNet18 efficiently captures essential height-related information from DSM. Second, D <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> FNet introduces a cascaded multimodal fusion framework, comprising the Dual-domain Fusion Block (DFB) and the Detail Enhancement Fusion Block (DEFB). Within the DFB, we employ the proposed Feature Interaction Fusion Block (FIFB) to perform initial multimodal feature alignment and fusion in both the spatial and frequency domains, enhancing the model's understanding of the macroscopic object structures. Recognizing the importance of local details for dense segmentation tasks, DEFB employs novel Variable Receptive Field Convolution (VRFC) modules to enhance the detail representation of both the initial fusion features and the DSM features. These detail-enhanced features are fed into the FIFB module to achieve further multimodal alignment and fusion. Extensive experiments on the ISPRS Potsdam and Vaihingen datasets demonstrate that our method achieves mIoU of 86.99% and 84.29%, respectively. It not only outperforms comparative approaches in segmentation performance but also reduces model parameters by 79.6% and computational cost by 85.6%, thereby validating the effectiveness of the proposed network.

title: A Chipless RFID Sensor Based on U-Shaped Resonator with Resistive Switch for Strain Detection
authors: Xiao Shuai Li, Mei Song Tong
abstract: RFID technology is rapidly developing and is now divided into two forms: chipless and chip based. Among them, chipless RFID technology still has the problem of low information carrying capacity per unit area. To solve this problem, a K-order U-shaped resonator has been proposed, which can effectively increase the amount of information. The main problem with this structure is that it is difficult to unify manufacturing and information cannot be changed. In this paper, a non-volatile switch is added to the structure to further increase the transmission rate while solving the above problems. The effectiveness of the new structure is verified through experiments.

title: Power Quality Assessment of Lighting Systems in Intelligent Buildings: A Measurement Study
authors: Pavol Belany, Zuzana Florkova, Peter Hrabovsky, Nikola Cajova Kantova, Marek Roch
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper examines power quality issues in lighting systems in intelligent buildings. In the current context of advanced lighting technologies, especially those using LED systems and digital dimming controllers, these systems are increasingly relied upon. However, the nonlinear characteristics of these technologies cause significant power quality disturbances, including harmonic distortion, poor power factor, and voltage fluctuations. The study evaluates power quality parameters in three operating modes - standby, dimming, and full power within a intelligent building. The study findings showed that the dimming mode posed the most significant challenge, which can be attributed to the increased total harmonic distortion. On the other hand, the full power mode showed increased efficiency and improve waveform quality. Based on these findings, mitigation techniques such as passive harmonic filtering are proposed to improve power quality. This work highlights the importance of monitoring and optimizing power quality in intelligent building environments to facilitate sustainable and reliable operation.

title: MTSCH: MILP-Based Mobility-Aware TSCH Networks for IIoT
authors: Adugna Necho Mulatu, Marco Zennaro, Fikreselam Gared, T V Prabhakar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: The industrial Internet of Things(IIoT) introduced robots, drones, and autonomous vehicles to facilitate real-time data collection and monitoring in industrial applications. The IEEE802.4.15e Time Slotted Channel Hopping(TSCH) protocol is proposed for industrial applications to address the strict requirements, such as reliability and deterministic communication. Although TSCH offers reliable and deterministic communication for such environments, its lack of adaptability to dynamic environments and mobility of entities motivates to address these issues. To address these gaps, a Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP)-based mobility-aware TSCH networks for IIoT (MTSCH) is introduced by employing an MILP model to optimize the strategic placement of static nodes at the boundary of the network deployment area and coverage area and mobility trajectories. The evaluation of the experiment’s results indicates that MTSCH achieves better results relative to the results of baseline approaches like TSCH and Forte across different performance metrics. MTSCH achieves an 84% connectivity, an improved coverage of 87%, and a jointime reduction by 1 s. It also scores the lowest delay of 91.1 s with consistence confidence interval. As per the results, MTSCH can be suggested for industrial use cases that employ mobile nodes in a TSCH network for IIoT.

title: Disordered Speech Recognition (Misarticulation) Using Similarity Algorithms
authors: Anushri Pratik Ghadge, S. P. Mahajan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Articulatory Disorder affect speech clarity and intelligibility, necessitating precise assessment for effective intercession. Traditional evaluation methods which include manual tests are often subjective and time consuming, which in terms generates the need for automated solutions. This paper presents AI-based framework for the assessment of articulatory disorder using similarity algorithms. The proposed system includes automatic speech recognition (ASR), feature extraction and speech similarity measures to compare distorted (misarticulated) speech with reference models of typical articulation. Various similarity algorithms such as Levenshtein's Distance (LD), Dynamic Time Warping (DTW), Jaro Winkler Distance (JW), Cosine Similarity (CS) are applied to quantify the differences in phoneme production. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of framework in identifying articulatory impairments with high precision. This approach offers a reliable, automated and accessible tool for clinicians and speech therapists, facilitating early diagnosis and personalized treatment plans.

title: A Fuzzy Logic-Based Local Path Correction System for Autonomous Mobile Robots
authors: Cheng-Yu Hsiao, Hsien-Ting Chang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: This paper proposes a fuzzy inference-based local path correction system for autonomous mobile robots (AMRs), aiming to improve obstacle avoidance in dynamic environments. The system utilizes a two-stage fuzzification process to extract directional obstacle information from binary occupancy maps representing the current and predicted surroundings. A rulebased inference engine evaluates directional memberships from both steps to generate a correction vector, which is then converted into crisp outputs using a zero-order Sugeno model. To ensure smooth and goal-consistent motion, the final output blends the correction with the global path and prior movement. Experimental results on real 2D LiDAR maps demonstrate that the proposed method enhances safety margins, smooths trajectories, and improves robustness against unknown obstacles.

title: Slice Extraction and Tilt Correction Forsynthesis of Panoramic X-Rays from CT Image
authors: Ichi Hasegawa, Kento Morita, Junya Hirota, Daisuke Takeda, Takumi Hasegawa, Masaya Akashi, Tetsushi Wakabayashi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Panoramic X-ray imaging is a standard diagnostic modality in dentistry, offering a comprehensive view of dental structures. Building AI models for dental diagnostics requires diverse datasets, which are challenging to obtain due to high imaging costs and the need for patient privacy protection. To address this challenge, we propose a method for synthesizing panoramic X-ray images from CT images using an elliptical dental arch and a dynamic rotation center. The method also introduces slice extraction and tilt correction relative to the axial reference plane, which have not been considered in previous approaches. Experiments using CT images from 321 individuals showed that the proposed method achieved a mean Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) of 0.644, outperforming conventional techniques. These results suggest that our method can generate panoramic X-rays similar to actual images and support data augmentation in machine learning.

title: Synergizing Human-AI Cooperation in Automated Software Testing: A Balance for Enhanced Efficiency, Reliability, and Trust
authors: Micheal Tuape, Jussi Kasurinen, Maria T Najjemba, Aminul D Islam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Achieving reliable and trustworthy automated software testing requires a synergistic approach that leverages both human expertise and AI capabilities. This position paper argues that active human oversight is crucial for addressing key challenges such as the test oracle problem and training data bias. By fostering human-AI cooperation, potential biases and inaccuracies can be mitigated, leading to more efficient, reliable, and trustworthy automated testing. This approach also aligns with principles from the EU AI Act, which emphasizes the need for effective human control over AI systems. The paper concludes by outlining a future research agenda focused on developing frameworks to foster seamless human-AI collaboration and presenting several open research questions vital for advancing the field.

title: Performance Analysis of Switchable Linear-to-Circular Polarizer in Finite Array and Conformal Configurations
authors: Dwi Andi Nurmantris, Radial Anwar, Zulfi, Achmad Munir
abstract: One important polarization conversion mode in polarizers is the linear-to-circular (LTC) polarization conversion. Although extensive work has been conducted to enhance the functionality and performance of Reflective Electromagnetic Surfaces (RES) as polarizers, research on the performance of polarizers in finite array and conformal configurations remains relatively small. This paper presents a performance investigation and analysis of switchable LTC polarizers in finite array and conformal configurations. The polarizers are designed to operate at the center frequency of 6.775 GHz, converting a linearly polarized incident wave to a circularly polarized reflected wave in the Off-State condition, while disabling the polarizer functionality in the On-State condition. Studies on the flat surface configuration indicate that using finite arrays of either <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> elements or <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 6$</tex> elements has no compromise the functionality of switchable LTC polarizer in either the Off-State or On-State conditions. However, significant degradation occurs in the On-State condition, where the cross-polarization reflection coefficient value increases by 5 dB to 10 dB in both <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> elements and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 6$</tex> elements. For the conformal configuration, the analysis shows that the curvature radius significantly impacts the performance degradation of switchable LTC polarizer, particularly in the On-State conditions. While in the Off-State conditions, the performance degradation is more pronounced in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 6$</tex> elements compared to the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> elements. Conversely, in the On-State condition, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> elements exhibit greater performance degradation. In addition, smaller curvature radius remarkably degrades the performance of switchable LTC polarizer in the Off-State conditions.

title: Smart Prosthetics Through Deep Learning: A Comparative Study of Neural Architectures for Real-Time Activity Recognition
authors: Johnny Hazboun, Andres Torres, Ahmed Soliman, Aidan Villegas, Mo Rastgaar, Nina Mahmoudian
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Activity classification using wearable sensors has significant applications in healthcare, sports, rehabilitation, and smart prosthetics, the latter being the focus of this paper. Smart prosthetics have the potential to improve mobility and quality of life by dynamically adapting motor configurations and settings based on the user’s activity. We explore deep learning models for activity classification using time-series data from two 9axis Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs) placed on the foot and the shank. We developed and compared three architectures to classify walking, ascending stairs, and descending stairs. The models are Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long ShortTerm Memory Networks (LSTM), and Transformers. The dataset consists of labeled IMU readings from 10 human subjects, processed using different sliding-window techniques: fixed-size window predictions and averaged window predictions. The models were evaluated on the basis of their ability to accurately classify activities under realistic, outside-of-lab environments. Initial results indicate that CNNs and LSTMs excel in capturing sequential dependencies, making them well suited for real-time prosthetic adjustments. Our best-performing model achieved $100 \%$ accuracy for walking, $86 \%$ for stair descent, and $90 \%$ for stair ascent, demonstrating strong potential for practical deployment. This research highlights the feasibility of integrating deep learning models with wearable sensors to enhance the adaptability of smart prosthetics, contributing to the field of assistive technologies and personalized mobility solutions.

title: Energy-Based Confidence Gap Expansion YoLOOD for Multi-Label OOD Detection
authors: Meng Li, Eric C.C. Tsang, Weihua Xu, Qiang He
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: There are abundant multi-label data in Real-world scenarios, and practical applications frequently face challenges from out-of-distribution (OOD) data that deviate from the training distribution. To address this, we propose a multi-label OOD detection algorithm (Energy-Gap-YoLOOD) based on YoLOOD and energy functions. First, during model training, we propose an energy-based confidence gap expansion function specifically designed to amplify the separation between in-distribution (ID) and OOD characteristics in the feature space. Then for inference phase, we introduce a confidence enhancement mechanism that: selectively amplifies high-confidence predictions and adaptively suppresses low-confidence outputs. Finally, we experimentally validate the effectiveness and robustness of our method.

title: Advanced Control and Data-Driven Strategies for Voltage Regulation in Power Systems
authors: Boniswa Malothane, Bongumsa Mendu, Bessie Baakanyang Monchusi, Mbuyu Sumbwanyambe
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Renewable energy sources are inherently unpredictable, necessitating the implementation of mechanisms to ensure voltage regulation within a power system. This highlights FACTS devices like STATCOM, which enhance system reliability. The objective of STATCOM research is to enhance and incorporate FACTS devices into power systems to prevent inadequate voltage stability, which can result in voltage collapse, outages, and potentially a complete system shutdown. This paper employs the SCOPUS database to do a systematic literature review on journals published over a five-year span from 2019 to 2024. Given the extensive nature of the SCOPUS database, it is imperative to design keywords pertaining to the topic and filter the research parameters to the field of Engineering, so as to omit other scientific disciplines and restrict the search exclusively to journals, while removing book chapters and conference reviews. The research repeatedly emphasizes the essential function of STATCOM and other FACTS devices in enhancing voltage regulation, alleviating dynamic voltage instabilities, and facilitating renewable energy integration under diverse grid settings. Notwithstanding significant advancements, there persists a compelling necessity for more rigorous, data-driven evaluations of historical grid performance in relation to temperature, load, and fault fluctuations, particularly correlating STATCOM efficacy with grid stability metrics across various circumstances. This research seeks to elucidate the integration of STATCOM in power systems, the technologies employed alongside STATCOM devices, and the significance of voltage regulation.

title: Performance Evaluation of Micro-Expression Recognition with Various Network Design Variations in Deep Learning
authors: Kotmi Hata, Tomoaki Hirose, Hironobu Takano
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Human emotions are conveyed not only through verbal elements but also through non-verbal cues such as facial expressions, posture, and tone of voice. Among these cues, micro-expressions serve as important indicators of genuine emotions, as they can appear unconsciously even when a person tries to suppress their feelings. This study investigates the effectiveness of deep learning models for estimating internal emotional states based on micro-expressions.The experiment was conducted by comparing five conditions: (1) facial region (full face vs. ROI), (2) number of input frames (apex frame vs. three-frame sequence), (3) presence or absence of fine-tuning using a facial expression dataset, (4) use of the Attention Branch Network (ABN), and (5) use of the ArcFace. The results showed that the use of ROIs and the implementation of ABN improved recognition accuracy, suggesting the importance of capturing local features and emphasizing attention regions in micro-expression recognition. In contrast, no significant improvement was observed from the number of input frames, fine-tuning, or the use of ArcFace. These findings indicate that the choice of input region and the use of attention mechanisms are key factors in enhancing the accuracy of emotion recognition based on micro-expressions.

title: Modelling and development of smart glasses for the blind
authors: Bc. Libor Klein, Ing. Norbert Ferenčík, Ing. Mária Danko, Ing. Katarína Dudová, Ing. Tomáš Balint, Ing. Radovan Hudák
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper deals with the development and optimization of smart glasses designed for blind users. The aim was to create a wearable assistive device that promotes independence and enhances the quality of life of people with visual impairments. The research was based on an initial prototype that was analyzed in terms of ergonomics, weight, design and technical solution. Based on the identified shortcomings, a comprehensive optimization of both hardware and mechanical components was implemented. The new prototype integrates all the electronic components directly into the frame of the glasses, thus achieving a uniform design and respecting the parameters commonly used in optics. At the same time, the weight of the device has been reduced by more than 30%. Testing of the prototype's electronics has confirmed the functionality of all the implemented components implemented as part of the optimization. Comparative testing of the design solutions of the original and the new prototype was carried out on a sample of eleven respondents. The testing showed improvements in handling, comfort and user friendliness in use. The device has also been extended to prepare for battery status monitoring, with software functionality to be added in the next phase of development.
