authors: Max Pröpper, Marc-André Tucholke, Dominik Hanisch, Christoph Schmid, Paul Julius Ritter, Marius Neumann, Edward Goldobin, Dieter Koelle, Reinhold Kleiner, Meinhard Schilling, Benedikt Hampel
abstract: Fabrication of YBa<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>Cu<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7-x</sub> Josephson junctions (JJs) using a direct-write helium-focused ion beam (He-FIB) technique has great potential for various applications due to tunable JJ parameters and arbitrary positioning. This technique allows placing multiple JJs in series to create JJ arrays. They could be used as a voltage standard that is operated at higher temperatures and driving frequencies than the currently used niobium-based JJ arrays. Small YBa<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>Cu<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7-x</sub> He-FIB JJ arrays with superposed Shapiro steps for up to three JJs have already been demonstrated. The number of JJs in the array was limited by the parameter spread of the individual JJs. This study presents WRspice simulations of JJ arrays, which indicate that the normal state resistance <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$R$</tex-math></inline-formula><sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sub>is the most crucial parameter to achieve flat Shapiro steps in JJ arrays. The idea of adding a shunt resistor to the JJ array to deal with the spread in <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$R$</tex-math></inline-formula><sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sub>values is investigated. A new design for GHz frequencies is presented, and the fabrication process is described. The properties of the shunt resistor are evaluated by van der Pauw measurements. Comparison of measurements with and without shunt resistor show the desired effect of changing the total resistance of the JJ array while maintaining the critical current value. Finally, measurements of JJ arrays demonstrating superposed Shapiro steps at 20K at GHz frequencies are presented.

title: Thermal-Robust Mechanical Fault Diagnosis via Hybrid Convolutional Neural Network and Multisensor Fusion with a Novel Temperature Compensation Algorithm_supp1-3639499.docx
authors: Naserodin Sepehry
abstract: Bolt loosening is a significant concern in structural health monitoring (SHM), and the nonlinear wave modulation (NWM) technique shows promise for its detection. However, temperature variations affect piezoelectric sensors, complicating detection. This study examines thermal stress effects on NWM-based damage detection by simulating a beam with boundary loosening under thermal stress. A temperature compensation method was developed to mitigate these effects. A multibolt structure was also analyzed using a hybrid deep learning model combining convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and Dezert-Smarandache Theory (DSmT) for multisensor data fusion. Results show that thermal stress significantly reduces classification accuracy. At 60 °C, the Damage Index dropped to zero, and CNN classification accuracy fell from 87.5% (at 25 °C) to 27.08%. Applying the compensation algorithm restored CNN accuracy to 87.27%. Statistical tests confirmed the compensated results at 60 °C were comparable to those at 25 °C. The DSmT-based fusion model achieved 98.92% accuracy on average, and even at 60 °C, maintained 98.80% accuracy with compensation for a multibolted plate. It combines the probabilistic outputs of multiple CNNs using the PCR6 rule, which redistributes conflicting evidence to improve decision reliability. This fusion strategy effectively handles uncertainty across sensors and significantly enhances classification robustness under temperature variations. In conclusion, thermal stress adversely impacts SHM damage detection, but the proposed compensation method effectively restores performance. Moreover, integrating multisensor fusion with DSmT greatly enhances accuracy, offering a robust solution for SHM in varying thermal environments.

title: Application of the Mathematical Theory of Reliability in Near Redundancy of Protective Devices in the Electric Power Grind
authors: Hristo Ilchev, Petya Tsvetkova, Diyan Ivanov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The paper justifies the need for redundancy of protective devices in electric power systems. Near redundancy of facilities is described in detail. A possibility to assess the reliability of a protective device system, consisting of a main and a backup element, is presented. Conclusions are drawn, useful for the operation of near redundancy systems in power grids.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Optimization of Quantum Dot Bioconjugates for Biomedical Applications
authors: Pangbo Wu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Quantum dots (QDs) have gained significant attention in biomedicine due to their unique optical properties. This study explores the interaction between quantum dots-specifically Cadmium Selenide (CdSe), Zinc Sulfide (ZnS), and Cadmium Telluride (CdTe)-and biomolecules, focusing on their geometric structure optimization and spectral analysis using Ultraviolet-Visible Spectroscopy (UV-VIS). By leveraging machine learning techniques, particularly XGBoost, a predictive model was developed to analyze the optical properties of QD bioconjugates. Feature importance analysis identified key factors such as oscillator strength, ligand attributes, and cadmium presence as critical determinants of spectral behavior. The optimized model significantly improved prediction accuracy, achieving an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> value of 0. 82. These findings provide a foundation for advancing QD bioconjugates in biomedical applications, including imaging and drug delivery.

title: Necessity and Potential Applications of Artificial Intelligence in Higher Agricultural Education: A Case Study of the University of Ruse
authors: Kalin Hristov, Boris Evstatiev, Atanas Atanasov, Chavdar Vezirov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This study highlights the necessity and potential of integrating artificial intelligence (AI) into agricultural higher education, with a specific focus on the University of Ruse. A comprehensive literature review confirms AI's transformative influence on both educational practices and agricultural production systems. The proposed Master of Science program in Artificial Intelligence in Agriculture aims to bridge the gap between traditional agricultural curricula and contemporary industry needs by developing competencies in machine learning, computer vision, predictive analytics, and agricultural data management. The University of Ruse possesses the institutional infrastructure and interdisciplinary expertise required to support such an initiative, including specialized modules and research facilities. However, effective implementation depends on addressing challenges related to faculty qualification, digital infrastructure, and stakeholder collaboration, particularly with farmers and agribusiness partners. The research contributes to the broader discourse on digital transformation in higher agricultural education and outlines a scalable model for developing AI-driven competencies. The outcomes are expected to strengthen employability, innovation capacity, and the transition toward data-informed, sustainable agricultural practices.

title: A Parameter-free Quadratic Programming Feature Selection Algorithm Based on Minimizing Redundancy and Fixing Relevance*
authors: Jianhua Xu, Jun Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Feature selection for classification aims to find an optimal subset of original features through minimizing featurefeature redundancy and maximizing feature-class relevance. After estimating redundancy matrix and relevance vector, constructing a constrained optimization problem has become one of the main-stream approaches recently. However, existing methods either involve some tunable parameters or utilize a complicated optimization procedure. In this paper, we propose a parameterfree quadratic programming feature selection model which minimizes redundancy and fixes relevance, where the former is formulated as a minimum of quadratic term associated with redundancy matrix and the latter as a linear equality constraint with relevance vector, plus a non-negative limit. Further, we apply a first-order Frank-Wolfe optimization method with a sub-linear convergence rate to solve our model, where at each iteration there exist an analytical solution for linear programming problem, an analytical step size and three recursive formulae for objective function, solution vector and gradient vector, which dramatically speeds up our optimization procedure. Our solution technique has an empirical time complexity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O\left(D^{2}\right)$</tex>, where <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$D$</tex> is the number of features. When Hilbert-Schmidt independence criterion (HSIC) is to estimate redundancy matrix and relevance vector, our comprehensive experiments on four extremely highdimensional biological data sets show that the proposed method is superior to seven existing main-stream techniques, including mRMR, InfFS, FoANOCCO, FoHSIC, QPFS, HSICLasso and GRM.

title: A Wrapper-Based Method for EEG Microstates Template Extraction
authors: Chunyu Feng, Yupan Shi
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: In the realm of Electroencephalography (EEG) microstates template extraction, factors such as high noise and non-representative data often interfere with the accuracy and classification performance of the templates. To address this issue, this paper proposes a wrapper-based method for EEG microstates template extraction. This method dynamically selects data that substantially contribute to classification performance based on feedback from machine learning algorithms, thereby constructing optimized microstates templates. In experiments classifying Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients and healthy individuals, the iteratively generated microstates templates using this strategy improved classification accuracy from an initial 74.2% to 86.4%. The results demonstrate that the wrapper-based template extraction method effectively reduces the impact of high noise and non-representative data, significantly enhancing the classification performance of EEG microstates templates and providing a new technical approach for EEG microstates analysis and related applications.

title: MambaPan3D: Mamba-Transformer for 3D LiDAR Panoptic Segmentation with Adaptive Coordinate Fusion
authors: RuiShen Zhou, K. L. Eddie Law
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: With the advent of autonomous intelligent systems, such as humanoid robots, environmental perception should require rapid and accurate real-time 3D scene interpretation. LiDAR sensors are core and accurate distance measuring components, but it is complicated to process the unstructured, sparse, and unevenly distributed nature of LiDAR point cloud data while meeting the real-time object classification needs. To address the limitations of current 3D LiDAR-based panoptic segmentation methods, we propose a MambaPan3D design. It is a hybrid architecture that integrates Mamba and Transformer models for efficient and accurate 3D point cloud understanding. Our framework solves two key challenges: 1) geometric ambiguity caused by sparse and irregular LiDAR point cloud distributions, and 2) inefficient long-range dependency modeling in largescale scenes. Specifically, CartPolar-KAN embedding, a novel positional encoding strategy, is introduced to interpret between Cartesian and polar coordinates by adding a Kolmogorov-Arnold network (KAN) with learnable B-spline basis functions. The module dynamically fuses multi-coordinate features to overcome the limitations of fixed Bird's-Eye View (BEV) quantization. Additionally, our Mamba-Transformer Decoder combines the global attention capabilities of the Transformer and the linear computational efficiency of the Mamba state-space model to achieve real-time inference while maintaining the global receptive field. Extensive experiments on SemanticKITTI dataset demonstrated state-of-the-art performance. The panoptic quality (PQ) could reach 63.3 % in complex urban scenes, i.e., 1.3 % higher than the current optimal baseline method. The proposed framework provides a powerful solution for real-time situational awareness in autonomous driving systems, balancing accuracy, efficiency, and scalability. Our MambaPan3D model offers a robust solution for real-time situational awareness in autonomous systems through balancing accuracy, efficiency, and scalability.

title: Method for Obtaining NDVI from a Single Photo for Very Small Areas
authors: Asparuh Atanasov, Svilen Stoyanov, Aleksandrina Bankova, Stefan Tenev, Desislava Mihaylova, Ivelin Ivanov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Obtaining the NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) reflectance vegetation index from a single photo is of key importance when studying very small areas and is important for the needs of the selection process. The possibility of using a created Python program code for its generation was considered. The obtained result was compared with a MAPIR program product, which is a specialized product for obtaining vegetation indices. A similar spatial map was obtained from both methods. Analysis of the results shows a correlation between the two methods, for Multiple R 83.5% and R Square are 69.5%, which proves the applicability of the method. The approach is suitable for studying small areas and type of plot of land.

title: Collaborative Learning Grouping Under Skill Redundancy-Aware Motivation Evolution
authors: Yanting Cao, Yifeng Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: In project-oriented collaborative learning scenarios, learners are expected to work with heterogeneous group members and make contributions based on their individual skill sets. However, when learners have low expectations about the impact of their skill-based contributions on group outcomes, their motivation tends to decrease, which contributes to common issues in collaborative groups, such as social loafing and freeriding. To solve the problem, this paper introduces a motivation evolution model of learners considering the redundancy of learners' skills within their groups. Based on this model, we define the Collaborative Learning Grouping Problem with Skill Redundancy-Aware Motivation Evolution (CLGP-SR), an NPhard combinatorial problem characterised by a highly structured search space. Given the skill coverage constraints and monotonicity of marginal utility with respect to learner assignments, we propose a backtracking algorithm to exhaustively explore the solution space for small-scale instances with constraint-based and bounding-based pruning strategies. For large-scale instances where exact methods become intractable, we further design a heuristic algorithm in which learners iteratively select suitable groups based on overlap penalty fitness scores. Experimental results on a real-world learner dataset demonstrate that the proposed methods efficiently find optimal solutions for smallscale scenarios and achieve a trade-off between grouping quality and runtime in large-scale scenarios.

title: Analysis of Energy Consumption of Poultry Farm with a Cyclical Farming Method
authors: Seher Kadirova, Tsvetozar Georgiev, Tsvetelina Stefanova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This study analyzes electricity consumption in a poultry farm using hourly measurements aggregated into seasonal and annual profiles. We develop sinusoidal models to capture the diurnal cyclical behavior and quantify model performance via the coefficient of determination (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex>). The results show strong seasonal dependence in both daily energy use and hourly load shapes, with summer exhibiting the highest demand (cooling and ventilation) and spring the lowest. The fitted sinusoidal models provide an accurate representation of the cyclic pattern across seasons and the annual profile, enabling improved forecasting and operational planning.

title: Federated Learning for Video Violence Detection: Complementary Roles of Lightweight CNNs and Vision-Language Models for Energy-Efficient Use
authors: Sébastien Thuau, Siba Haidar, Rachid Chelouah
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Deep learning-based video surveillance increasingly demands privacy-preserving architectures with low computational and environmental overhead. Federated learning preserves privacy but deploying large Vision-Language Models (VLMs) introduces major energy and sustainability challenges. We compare three strategies for federated violence detection under realistic non-IID splits on RWF-2000 and RLVS datasets: zero-shot pretrained VLM inference, LoRA-based fine-tuning of LLaVA-NeXT-Video-7B, and personalized federated learning of a 65.8 M parameter 3D CNN. All methods exceed 90% accuracy in binary violence detection. The 3D CNN achieves superior calibration (ROC AUC 92.59%) at roughly half the energy cost (240 Wh vs. 570 Wh) of federated LoRA, while VLMs provide richer multimodal reasoning. Hierarchical category grouping—based on semantic similarity and class exclusion—boosts VLM multiclass accuracy from 65.31% to 81% on the UCF-Crime dataset. To our knowledge, this is the first comparative simulation study of LoRA-tuned VLMs and personalized CNNs for federated violence detection, with explicit energy and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>e quantification. Our results inform hybrid deployment strategies that default to efficient CNNs for routine inference and selectively engage VLMs for complex contextual reasoning.

title: Innodiversification Approach to Assessing the Sustainability and Effectiveness of Organizations
authors: Mikhail Chernyakov, Maria Chernyakova, Vladislav Chernyakov, Olga Chistyakova, Victor Chechulin, Shakir Suleymanov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The article is devoted to the study of the sustainability and efficiency of consumer cooperation based on the innodiversification approach. The authors cluster the correlation coefficients of indicators for the period 2014-2023, identifying linear and nonlinear dependencies. The paper presents mathematical models constructed using linear and nonlinear regression, which make it possible to predict the dynamics of sustainability and efficiency indicators. The results of the study confirm the hypothesis of a significant influence of the time factor on the activities of consumer cooperatives. Quantitative analysis revealed that 54.7 % of all inter-indicator correlations and 61.3 % of indicator-time correlations were high or very high (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R} \geq \mathbf{0. 7}$</tex>). The constructed models, with an average approximation error not exceeding 5%, demonstrate high predictive accuracy.

title: Hands-on Evaluation of Visual Transformers for Object Recognition and Detection
authors: Dimitrios N. Vlachogiannis, Dimitrios A. Koutsomitropoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for computer vision sometimes struggle with understanding images in a global context, as they mainly focus on local patterns. On the other hand, Vision Transformers (ViTs), inspired by models originally created for language processing, use self-attention mechanisms, which allow them to understand relationships across the entire image. In this paper, we compare different types of ViTs (pure, hierarchical, and hybrid) against traditional CNN models across various tasks, including object recognition, detection, and medical image classification. We conduct thorough tests on standard datasets like ImageNet for image classification and COCO for object detection. Additionally, we apply these models to medical imaging using the ChestX-ray14 dataset. We find that hybrid and hierarchical transformers, especially Swin and CvT, offer a strong balance between accuracy and computational resources. Furthermore, by experimenting with data augmentation techniques on medical images, we discover significant performance improvements, particularly with the Swin Transformer model. Overall, our results indicate that Vision Transformers are competitive and, in many cases, outperform traditional CNNs, especially in scenarios requiring the understanding of global visual contexts like medical imaging.

title: From Black-Box Tuning to Guided Optimization via Hyperparameters Interaction Analysis
authors: Moncef Garouani, Ayah Barhrhouj
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Hyperparameters tuning is a fundamental, yet computationally expensive, step in optimizing machine learning models. Beyond optimization, understanding the relative importance and interaction of hyperparameters is critical to efficient model development. In this paper, we introduce MetaSHAP, a scalable semi-automated eXplainable AI (XAI) method, that uses meta-learning and Shapley values analysis to provide actionable and datasetaware tuning insights. MetaSHAP operates over a vast benchmark of over 09 millions evaluated machine learning pipelines, allowing it to produce interpretable importance scores and actionable tuning insights that reveal how much each hyperparameter matters, how it interacts with others and in which value ranges its influence is concentrated. For a given algorithm and dataset, MetaSHAP learns a surrogate performance model from historical configurations, computes hyperparameters interactions using SHAP-based analysis, and derives interpretable tuning ranges from the most influential hyperparameters. This allows practitioners not only to prioritize which hyperparameters to tune, but also to understand their directionality and interactions. We empirically validate MetaSHAP on a diverse benchmark of 164 classification datasets and 14 classifiers, demonstrating that it produces reliable importance rankings and competitive performance when used to guide Bayesian optimization.

title: DPD: A Dual Prompt Distillation Method for Vision-Language Model
authors: Di Wang, Yiyu Wang, Jungang Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Prompt learning has demonstrated remarkable performance in tuning Vision-Language Models (VLMs) for various downstream tasks. Recent studies have shown the effectiveness of prompt distillation in transferring distribution knowledge between VLM teachers and students. However, existing prompt knowledge distillation methods are limited in diversity, focusing solely on positive probabilities. In this paper, we propose a dual prompt distillation (DPD) method, which teaches the student from both positive and negative aspects. Specifically, during the first phase of teacher training, the positive and negative prompts are both optimized by constructing complementary probability distribution signals. In the second distillation phase, the teacher guides the student with dual prompts - positive prompts to select the correct category and negative prompts to exclude incorrect ones. Extensive experimental results across 11 datasets demonstrate that the proposed DPD method either surpasses or matches the performance of existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods in both few-shot learning and domain generalization tasks while maintaining competitive computational efficiency. The corresponding code is available at https://github.com/wdinancy/DPD.

title: A Conceptual Model for a Photovoltaic Energy Monitoring and Forecasting System
authors: Irena Valova, Tsvetelina Kaneva, Gabriel Kanev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The integration of photovoltaic (PV) systems in smart cities requires intelligent solutions for monitoring, forecasting, and management. This paper proposes a conceptual architecture for an information system tailored to small PV parks and household installations. The system integrates IoTbased data acquisition, real-time monitoring, predictive analytics, and alerting mechanisms. Literature review highlights the effectiveness of machine learning for improving forecasting accuracy and system reliability. The proposed multilayer architecture ensures efficient data handling, proactive management, and financial optimization, contributing to sustainability and the effective integration of renewable energy in smart grids.

title: Automating the process of creating and evolving an ontological description of corporate knowledge
authors: Ekaterina Mashina
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Article is dedicated to the topic of developing automated systems for the ontological design of contemporary companies. The paper examines the features of the stages in the automated ontological description of corporate knowledge and analyzes possible ways to implement this process. As a result of the analysis, the author comes to the conclusion that the main advantages of a uniform structured presentation of corporate knowledge can be realized only if they fully cover the company’s information environment. This can be achieved by developing a specialized Semantic Resource Manager information environment that allows employees of the enterprise, within the framework of a unified user interface, to carry out actions on ontological design and practical use of ontological descriptions at their workplaces. The materials of the work apply to the development of practical ways and methods of structured description and effective use of corporate knowledge in the information systems of companies.

title: Implementing DNA-Based Cryptography Using Residue Number System in Microsoft Excel: An Educational Tool for Telecommunication Security
authors: Adriana Borodzhieva
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: In today's data-saturated world, safeguarding information is crucial for enabling fast and secure digital communication. Unauthorized parties must be kept from accessing sensitive data, while ensuring it reaches the intended recipient with preserved confidentiality, integrity, authenticity, and availability. Recent advances use DNA's molecular computing traits for cryptography and steganography, utilizing DNA strands as covert carriers. This paper proposes a hybrid scheme combining cryptography and steganography through a residue number system (RNS) and DNA-based encoding. First, plaintext is converted into residues using the moduli set <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\{2n -, 2 n, 2 n+1\}$</tex>. These residues are then translated into a DNA sequence. To conceal the encrypted DNA, two distinct, randomly-generated reference DNA sequences serve as steganographic masks. The result is a dual-form ciphertextencrypted residues and encoded DNA - that requires less computational overhead and remains inconspicuous to potential attackers. This hybrid scheme has been implemented in Microsoft Excel and will be integrated into the educational process for bachelor students in the Telecommunication Security course during the seventh semester at the University of Ruse.

title: Sizing and Analysis of an Off-Grid Photovoltaic Power Supply for an Irrigation System
authors: Reni Kabakchieva, Atanas Kabakchiev, Katerina Gabrovska-Evstatieva
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The integration of decentralized energy systems opens many new possibilities, one of which is in the agricultural sector. This study demonstrates a practical approach for optimized sizing of PV-hybrid installations used for powering irrigation systems. It provides practical guidelines for determining the approximate power of the PV modules, the inverter, and the battery storage. Next, simulations have been performed in the PVSyst ver. 8 software to demonstrate the operability of these guidelines. The obtained results showed that the available peak PV power should be oversized by at least 80 % if the consumer operates 5 hours per day. Furthermore, the battery storage should be oversized depending on the required autonomy of the system. Future studies should concentrate on further optimization of PV-hybrid systems in the agricultural sector by integrating different agricultural processes. This would allow utilizing the available PV power in all seasons and would increase the rate at which the investment is returned.

title: GenPTA: Enhancing De Novo and Scaffold-Based Molecular Generation with Attention Refinement Mechanism and Adaptive Positional Encoding
authors: Miao Han, Bo Li, Xiaoqiong Li, Han Zhang, Boyang Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Drug design is conventionally constrained by the limited chemical diversity present in existing databases. Deep learning-based molecular generation models, such as Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) and Transformers, show great promise for both de novo and scaffold-based drug design. However, these widely adopted architectures face challenges in fully leveraging their encoding space due to the loss of key molecular features during pooling. Furthermore, modeling long-range dependencies is difficult because of inherent limitations in absolute positional encoding. Here, we present GenPTA, a model that enhances both de novo and scaffold-based molecular generation through an attention refinement mechanism, adaptive positional encoding, and an innovative Memory-cat module. The attention refinement mechanism dynamically extracts the most critical molecular features, improving latent variable expressiveness and ensuring generated molecules possess the desired properties. Meanwhile, the adaptive positional encoding captures complex spatial relationships and global features. Additionally, the Memory-cat module enables spatial sampling near the encoding space of a given molecule, further diversifying generated structures and optimizing design efficiency. Experimental results show that GenPTA achieves the lowest Fréchet ChemNet Distance (FCD) values of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0631 \pm$</tex> 0.0461 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.4799 \pm 0.0023$</tex> on classic and scaffold-based reference sets, respectively, indicating strong alignment with reference distributions. It also attains the highest Nearest Neighbor Similarity (SNN) scores of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.6278 \pm 0.0323$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.5891 \pm 0.0007$</tex>, reflecting high chemical plausibility. Comparison of GenPTA-generated molecules with the native ligand of Cytochrome P450 1B1 (CYP1B1) reveals additional interactions that stabilize the molecular-protein binding, demonstrating the model's potential to enhance affinity. GenPTA's performance in de novo and scaffold-based generation provides an efficient approach for hit discovery and lead optimization, accelerating drug development.

title: Training Generative Judge with Hard Negative Mining: A Metric Learning Perspective
authors: Changxin Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Prior SFT-based LLM-as-a-Judge suffers from a distributional mismatch between GPT-4 and the smaller opensource language models (SLMs), often leading to overfitting. On-policy methods, such as Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), attempt to address this limitation by training models using their own outputs. However, conventional GRPO typically rely on randomly sampled data, often selecting negative samples with low model-assigned probabilities-samples that provide weak gradient signals and thus limit learning efficacy. To overcome this, we first establish a theoretical connection by proving that GRPO is equivalent to the margin ranking loss commonly used in metric learning. Building on this, we introduce the first approach to optimize GRPO through hard negative mining, a well-established technique in metric learning. We define hard negatives within the context of LLM-as-a-Judge and propose a simple yet effective strategy for identifying them. We evaluate our method on three out-of-domain datasets and one in-domain dataset. Compared to SFT-based methods, our approach demonstrates superior scalability, which is becoming increasingly important for training on modern, largescale datasets. Specifically, while SFT-based methods struggle to improve performance when scaling from 10 % to 100 % of the training data, our method exhibits consistent improvements across this range. This suggests that current SFT methods may not be well-suited for training generative judges. Furthermore, empirical results show that our approach consistently outperforms larger open-source baselines.

title: ComSFI: A Community-Aware Approach to Early Rumor Propagation Prediction
authors: Yuhang Wang, Wei Zhou, Ziang Hu, Jizhong Han, Tao Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Information propagation prediction in social networks remains challenging due to the complex interactions between community structures. Existing models typically overlook multi-peaked cascade patterns that emerge from community-specific dynamics, especially during critical early propagation stages. To address these limitations, we propose ComSFI (Community-aware Susceptible-Forwarding-Immune), a dynamic prediction framework that captures both intra- and inter-community information diffusion. ComSFI makes three key contributions: (1) community-specific diffusion modeling through individualized SFI modules, (2) cross-community propagation modeling with a learnable threshold mechanism that identifies cascade initiation timing, and (3) integration of user interest profiles to estimate propagation willingness across community boundaries. Experiments on Weibo, Douban, and Memetracker datasets demonstrate that ComSFI outperforms state-of-the-art baselines by 3%-12% in cascade size prediction and temporal pattern accuracy, with particular effectiveness in early-stage rumor propagation prediction—a critical application for timely intervention. Our results establish ComSFI as a versatile framework for analyzing and predicting complex information diffusion patterns in real-world networks.

title: Silverbullet or Mystery Box – LLM-based Soft Skill Classification in Volunteering
authors: Johannes Schönböck, Christoph Gassner, Ulrich Bodenhofer, Werner Retschitzegger, Wieland Schwinger, Elisabeth Kapsammer, Birgit Pröll, Marianne Lechner, Christoph Angster
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Volunteering is a vital pillar of critical infrastructures (CIs) and sustainable development goals (SDGs), fostering, e.g, civil protection or rescue/health/social services. Whether supporting CIs or SDGs, skill-based volunteering is key. Standardized knowledge about skills viable or necessary for certain volunteering opportunities is beneficial in the pre-engagement phase to enable effective skill use as well as in the post-engagement phase to leverage skill gain. It is unclear, however, in how far existing skill classification approaches - currently solely focusing on job postings on the labor market - can handle the nuanced, taskdriven, and prose-like descriptions of predominantly soft skills typical in volunteering opportunities. This paper addresses this gap by presenting a comparison of existing skill classification approaches, initially developed for labor market job postings, in the context of volunteering opportunities. Based on that, we propose using cache- and retrieval-augmented generation techniques for soft skill classification in volunteering, avoiding the high costs of LLM fine-tuning common in current methods. The effectiveness of these lightweight techniques is evaluated both quantitatively and qualitatively using a novel soft skill dataset with expert-labeled volunteering opportunities from a global volunteering platform.

title: Three-arm Series Capacitor Buck Converter using DSP-controlled Voltage Feedback
authors: Chin Hsia, Chen-Tung Hsiao, Chien Chen Pan, Chung-Yi Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: This paper presents the three-arm series capacitor buck converter (SCBC) employing the digital voltage feedback control scheme to mitigate current mismatch among three arms, while achieving low overshoot and fast recovery in output voltage regulation. Conventional control strategies often suffer from an imbalance in the current of the inductor when the duty cycle exceeds 50%. To address this issue, a novel control method is proposed in which one arm operates at a fixed 50% duty cycle, while the other two arms dynamically adjust their duty cycles proportionally to maintain overall current balance among three arms. A digital state-space based voltage feedback controller is implemented to regulate the output voltage. A 36 V–to–10 V, 40 W three-arm SCBC prototype is developed, delivering over 3 A of total output current, achieving less than 8% current mismatch. The experimental results demonstrate a maximum efficiency of 90.2% at a switching frequency of 200 kHz. For a 0.5 A load step, the system exhibits a settling time of approximately 5 msec, with undershoot and overshoot limited to 405 mV and 337 mV, respectively.

title: Optimal Energy Management of a Solar-Battery Powered Fixed-Wing Unmanned Aerial Vehicle
authors: Duy An Pham, Pham Nam Kien Nguyen, Tuan Viet Do, Najib Essounbouli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: In this paper, a hybrid power system comprising photovoltaic and lithium-ion battery will be studied for supplying power to a fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicle. Due to the continuous movement of the unmanned aerial vehicle, a fuzzy logic MPPT controller is designed to extract maximum power from the solar cells positioned along the UAV's path. The advantages of the fuzzy logic MPPT controller include high accuracy and a fast response speed, particularly when weather conditions change continuously. A PI controller and a bidirectional DC/DC converter are designed to maintain a constant voltage on the DC bus. To prevent overcharging of the battery, a fuzzy logic supervisor is designed. The simulation results in the MATLAB/Simulink software indicate that the designed controllers are adequate and suitable for the electrical of the unmanned aerial vehicle.

title: Angular Spectrum Decomposition, Localized Approximation and Finite Series Methods in Evaluating the Beam Shape Coefficients of Structured Beams: A Comparison
authors: Jianqi Shen, Siqi Tang
abstract: In studying the interaction between a structured light beam and a spherical particle, the electromagnetic field is expanded into the series of the vector spherical wave functions (VSWFs), weighted by the beam shape coefficients (BSCs). The work presents a comparison of the angular spectrum decomposition (ASD), the localized approximation (LA) and the finite series (FS) methods for evaluating the BSCs of both the scalar potential function and the electromagnetic field of the on-axis located Gaussian beams, in which we detail how the angular spectrum representation (ASR) of the BSCs can be approximated, under the paraxial conditions, to the expressions which are deduced by using the other two methods.

title: The Digital Impression Management Strategies of Festival Film Bahari’s Instagram Account: A Content Analysis Research
authors: Shadia Imanuella Pradsmadji, Ephraim Ryan Pranata, Mochamad Agung Daniswara, Ekky Imanjaya, Rosidah, Dag Yngvesson, Tri Adi Sumbogo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study investigates the digital impression management strategies employed by Festival Film Bahari, an environmentally-focused film festival based in Cirebon, Indonesia, through its Instagram account. Utilizing content analysis on 375 selected Instagram posts from the festival’s sixth and seventh seasons (2023 and 2024), this research explores how the festival strategically presents itself digitally to project sustainability values and reinforce its environmental identity. The analysis identifies four primary impression management strategies, that consist of self-promotion, ingratiation, exemplification, and supplication. The self-promotion being most frequently used (71.4%). Additionally, a word cloud analysis highlights the festival’s emphasis on key themes such as sustainability, marine conservation, and community involvement. The findings suggest that Festival Film Bahari effectively utilizes digital platforms not only for promotional purposes but also as a medium for cultural activism and education, enhancing its credibility and public engagement in sustainability issues.

title: An Efficient Acquisition Method of Multiple Led Colors Based on Fiber-Optic Spectrometer
authors: Zhi Chong Wan, Guo Chun Wan, Mei Song Tong
abstract: This paper proposes a multiplexed RGB-LED color acquisition method based on fiber-optic spectrometer and time-division multiplexing technology, which realizes the light-color parameter acquisition of eight LED light beads through a bundle of eight optical fibers. The method consists of two parts: spectral acquisition and light color calculation. The cosine corrector is used to collect the radiant light within the 180° stereo angle, and the radiant intensity of each sub-fiber is sequentially collected at 5 ms intervals. By calibrating with a standard light source, the XYZ tri-stimulus values and luminous flux of the LEDs are calculated, and the color coordinates and lumen values are determined in the CIE color space. The color coordinate error is less than 0.005 when compared with a high-precision integrating sphere system, confirming the high accuracy and feasibility of the method. This method significantly reduces the equipment size and improves the collection efficiency, providing a new idea for LED light color collection.

title: Mitigating Imprecise Timing in Spiking Neural Networks through Offset-Aware Training
authors: Taylor Kergan, Rui-Jie Zhu, Ahmad Byagowi, Jason Eshraghian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Precision Clock Synchronization for Measurement, Control, and Communication (ISPCS)
abstract: Neuromorphic accelerators, whether asynchronous meshes or globally-asynchronous, locally synchronous (GALS) fabrics, usually devote die area to barrier synchronizers, finely tuned clock trees, and metastability filters to keep spikes in lock-step. How much of that circuitry is truly indispensable? We quantify the intrinsic jitter tolerance of spiking neural networks (SNNs) and show how to push this tolerance further. We introduce a clock offset injector, a single GPU tensor op that time-shifts each core’s spikes by an arbitrary delay, and allows any PyTorch SNN to be stress-tested or hardened without code changes. Vision (N-MNIST) and audio (Spiking Heidelberg Digits) models, trained with and without our proposed offset-aware augmentation, are evaluated across nine skew levels (0-50% of the sample window) and up to eight cores. Baseline N-MNIST stays within ±1 percentage points (pp) until skew reaches 18 ms (6.1%). By accounting for temporally misaligned spikes during training time, we extend survival to 46 ms. Timing-critical SHD collapses beyond 23 ms (9%) but regains 6-9 pp after augmentation. These numbers map out safe envelopes for clock simplification: vision-only workloads can tolerate ≈ 3 ms per hop, while mixed vision-audio workloads must hold skew below 2 ms, or depend on timing-offset aware training. This ultimately shows how to enable lower-effort clocking and using software-level mitigation when needed.

title: Energy Management of a Green Hydrogen Production Autonomous System
authors: Rafika Louli, Abderrezak Badji, Stefan Giurgea, Issam Salhi, Salah Laghrouche, Abdesslem Djerdir
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: This study presents the control and energy management of an off-grid green hydrogen production system powered by photovoltaic energy. In isolated systems, the most basic configuration often relies on photovoltaic panels and batteries, but this setup faces limitations, especially for long-term or seasonal storage needs. To overcome this, the proposed system incorporates hydrogen storage through a proton exchange membrane electrolyzer, allowing excess solar energy to be converted into storable hydrogen for later use. A comprehensive energy management strategy is developed to coordinate the interactions between the photovoltaic source, the electrolyzer, battery storage, and auxiliary components. The system prioritizes hydrogen production when solar energy is available, while the battery compensates during solar deficits. To protect battery longevity, operation of the electrolyzer is suspended during low state-of-charge conditions until the charge recovers to a predefined limit. Simulation results under various operating scenarios demonstrate the system’s ability to operate autonomously off-grid, maintain energy balance, ensure reliability, and maximize the use of renewable resources.

title: Dual-Band Plasmonic Band-Pass Filters Based on Metal-Insulator-Metal Waveguide Square Ring Resonators for Sub-Wavelength Wireless Networks
authors: Kola Thirupathaiah, Montasir Qasymeh
abstract: This article investigates the dual-band characteristics of square ring resonators (SRRs) integrated with metal-insulator-metal (MIM) waveguides. The transmission behavior of various SRRs is analyzed using plasmonic MIM waveguides. A dual-band plasmonic filter and its transmission properties are proposed and numerically demonstrated through the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method. Three different devices are designed, simulated, and analyzed, revealing that the losses increase as the number of slits or gaps in the square ring resonator rises. All devices exhibit dual-band behavior in optical frequency ranges, with the first and second resonant peaks operating simultaneously at 1300 nm and 1600 nm, respectively. These devices exhibit band-pass filter characteristics, and the designs offer the potential for minimizing filter dimensions and enhancing optical applications in photonic integrated circuits (PICs).

title: Towards a Real-Time Driver Distraction Detection framework: A Novel Ensemble CNN Approach
authors: Berrouk Sara, Cherti Ilias
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: One of the main causes of road accidents is driver behavior, accounting for 78–90% of crashes worldwide. Activities such as mobile phone use, eating, or talking to passengers significantly impair reaction times and increase accident risk. While Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have shown promise in detecting driver distraction from images, existing solutions face key challenges: high computational demands, difficulty in deployment on resource-limited edge devices, inter-class similarity between visually similar behaviors, and data leakage from improper dataset splits.This paper proposes a novel ensemble CNN architecture combining MobileNetV2, ResNet50, and a modified VGG-16, designed to balance efficiency, accuracy, and robustness for real-time edge deployment. The approach integrates techniques to reduce inter-class confusion and applies a driver-exclusive data split to eliminate leakage and improve generalization. Using the StateFarm Distracted Driver Detection dataset, the proposed method achieved high accuracy, strong generalization to unseen drivers, and low computational overhead, demonstrating its suitability for real-world, in-vehicle distraction detection systems.

title: A Hybrid XGBoost Framework for Wildfire Risk Prediction: A Case study in North-Central Morocco
authors: Zineb Akhouad, Haytam Zidani, Houda Chakiri, Nasser Assem
publish: 2025 IEEE Global Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things (GCAIoT)
abstract: This study addresses the challenge of developing a robust $\mathbf{5}$-class classifier for wildfire risk prediction using a small ($\mathbf{n} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{5 7 1}$) and highly imbalanced dataset from north-central Morocco. We present an AI and Internet of Things (AIoT) framework that integrates satellite remote sensing data (IoT) with machine learning (AI) to enhance regional resilience. Through a comparative analysis of two modeling pipelines a Systematic Evaluation Pipeline and a Heuristic Tuning Pipeline we identify a hybrid methodology as the optimal approach. The primary finding is that model performance was fundamentally constrained by the initial feature set; an Enriched Dataset incorporating physically relevant predictors (Soil Moisture, NDWI, and binned Wind Direction) was the single most critical factor in achieving a high-performance model. The final hybrid model, combining a simple, default XGBoost architecture with manually refined class weights, achieved a Macro F1 score of 0.6143. This work contributes a reproducible, generalizable framework for tackling high-complexity, low-sample classification tasks, with direct applications to environmental monitoring and the achievement of UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 11, 13, and 15.

title: Realization of Biomedical Colorimetric Sensing Signal Detection and Processing and Visualization System Based on Smartphone
authors: Weihe Zhan, Qingfubo Geng, Baole Wang, Yian Liu, Zhaoxin Geng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: A biomedical colorimetric sensing and signal processing system based on smartphones is presented to solve the challenges of traditional colorimetric detection methods in portability and efficiency. Image preprocessing techniques and the Hough transform-assisted grayscale distribution method are employed to achieve automated localization of multiple target signal regions. The localization accuracy reaches 99.80 %, with an average deviation of 8.735 pixels. A conversion model is developed to translate signal intensity into representative pixel values, and concentration curve fitting is used to quantify the concentrations of target substances, including tumor biomarkers. The system fully integrates into a smartphone application, enabling efficient data processing and visualized output. A cost-effective and portable solution is thereby provided for Point-of-care testing.

title: Optimization of Electric Field Distribution in 4H-SiC Multi-Level Trench JBS Diodes Using P-Well Structure
authors: Jiteng Yang, Quanyuan Feng, Yan Wen
abstract: The device performance is improved by introducing a P-type well based on a multilevel trench structure. Although the traditional multi-level trench JBS diode can moderately enhance the breakdown voltage, it has certain drawbacks. For instance, the electric field concentration at the trench edge restricts the breakdown voltage improvement., and there is room for optimization in the forward conduction characteristics. By introducing the P-Well structure at the bottom of the multi-level trench, the electric field concentration effect is effectively alleviated, and the breakdown voltage and forward conduction characteristics of the device are significantly improved. Experimental findings demonstrate that incorporating a P -well has enhanced the breakdown voltage, increasing it from 1326 V to 1967 V. The breakdown voltage is increased by about 640 V.

title: Stacked Negative Correlation Learning: A Framework for Specialisation in Deep Ensembles
authors: Shiva Kumar Bhuram, Srinivas R. Gottimukkala
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Ensemble learning enhances predictive performance and uncertainty estimation by combining outputs from multiple models. However, standard deep ensemble methods often lead to redundancy due to a lack of model specialisation. This thesis proposes Stacked Negative Correlation Learning (SNCL), a novel framework that combines negative correlation learning with stacked generalisation in a concurrent training scheme. SNCL promotes diversity by encouraging ensemble members to specialise in distinguishing between different class subsets, leading to better generalisation and reduced in-domain uncertainty. Experiments on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, using a consistent CNN architecture differing only in the final layer's output (10 vs. 100 classes), validate SNCL's superiority. The architecture includes three convolutional blocks with ReLU, dropout, and maxpooling layers, followed by fully connected layers. SNCL outperforms traditional methods in classification accuracy, calibration, and out-of-distribution detection, making it a promising solution for scalable, efficient ensemble learning in high-dimensional and safety-critical applications.

title: Integrating Large Language Models with Formal Planning to Automate the Design and Validation of Biosignal Processing Pipelines
authors: João Areias Saraiva, Martin Dyrba, Thomas Kirste
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Robust analysis of biosignals hinges on well-crafted processing pipelines, yet assembling them is still a slow, errorprone exercise, requiring both domain expertise and programming skills. While Large Language Models (LLMs) offer promising assistance, they fundamentally lack the combinatorial reasoning capabilities needed for designing reliable and reproducible processing pipelines. We present an innovative hybrid system that harnesses LLMs' natural language understanding while leveraging classical AI planning for logical reasoning and validation. A retrieval-augmented model parses natural language pipeline descriptions into implementation-independent atomic biosignal processing operations, which follow to a Hierarchical Task Network (HTN) domain that can plan and validate processing workflows, as well as flag violations of biosignal processing best practices. Evaluation on a preliminary corpus of scenarios demonstrates <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 9 - 0. 9 8}$</tex> precision in mapping natural language to processing blocks and 0.97-0.98 F1-score in generating valid 2-15 step pipelines using SHOP3 planner. A drag-and-drop pipeline design interface allows users to build and formally validate their pipeline ideas from scratch, showing potential to democratize and expedite biosignal analysis for scientists of different backgrounds.

title: Experimental Study of Technical, Economic and Environmental Characteristics of a Micro-Flare Frontal Device of a Heat Generator
authors: Aigerim Nurzhanovna Sapargaliyeva, Abay Mukhamediyarovich Dostiyarov, Iliya Krastev Iliev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The article presents the results of an experimental study of a microtorch front device with an air nozzle stabilizer (ANS) intended for use in heat-generating units. The influence of flow swirl, combustion front shape and perforation on the indicators of combustion completeness, heat release and pollutant emissions is considered. The obtained data indicate high efficiency of microtorch combustion from the point of view of both energy consumption and environmental safety. Graphs and diagrams illustrating the nature of the identified dependencies are presented. This study conducted an experimental analysis of the impact of the design parameters of a microtorch device on its efficiency. The influence of the airflow swirl angle, combustion front geometry, and the presence of perforations on such parameters as thermal efficiency, nitrogen oxide (NOx) and carbon monoxide (CO) emissions, and combustion efficiency was investigated. To determine the key parameters of a microtorch front device with the air nozzle stabilizer (ANS) heat generator, experimental tests were conducted under operating conditions on a specialized rig.

title: Cfd Analysis of the Non-Premixed Combustion of Methane-Air Enriched by Hydrogen
authors: Masoud Sahami, George Pitchurov, Momchil Vasilev, Angel Terziev, Martin Ivanov, Petrini Marinov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The increasing demand for cleaner energy sources has positioned hydrogen as a promising alternative fuel to conventional hydrocarbons. However, its unique combustion properties, such as low ignition energy and high flame speed, pose operational challenges like premature ignition and flashback. Therefore, this study addresses these issues by investigating the combustion characteristics of a hydrogenmethane (CH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>/ H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) blend, which offers a practical solution for leveraging hydrogen benefits while mitigating its drawbacks. Using Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) with the commercial software ANSYS Fluent, a numerical simulation of non-premixed turbulent combustion in a 2D chamber is performed. The model employed the standard k-<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varepsilon$</tex> turbulence model coupled with the Probability Density Function (PDF) non-premixed combustion model. The analysis focuses on the effects of lean hydrogen enrichment and varying air mass flow rates on key combustion parameters, including temperature, velocity fields, and emission profiles. The findings aim to establish viability thresholds for using CH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>/ H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> blends in applications such as steam boiler combustors, contributing to the development of sustainable energy systems with reduced emissions and improved efficiency.

title: Blockchain as an “Energy Accumulator”: Tokenized Storage, Price Arbitrage, and State-of-Charge Governance
authors: Nikolay Hinov, Plamen Stanchev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Volatile electricity prices enable arbitrage by charging storage when prices are low and discharging when prices are high. We propose a blockchain-backed “energy accumulator” for communities and microgrids that aggregates heterogeneous storage assets, tokenizes their time-coupled capacity (kWh•slot), and executes charge/discharge schedules via smart contracts connected to price and telemetry oracles. Off-chain forecasting and optimization generate dispatch plans; on-chain contracts provide transparent settlement, constraint enforcement (SoC, cycle limits), and profit sharing. The concept targets low transaction latency (minutes) and negligible onchain overhead relative to arbitrage margin. We outline a simulation framework using historical price series, storage models with degradation costs, and compare three governance modes: centralized operator, permissioned blockchain (PBFT/PoA), and public L2 rollup. Key metrics include arbitrage profit, peak reduction, SoC violations, gas/fees, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> impact. Results (to be developed) will quantify where blockchain brings net value beyond centralized coordination.

title: Real-Time Patient Monitoring System with Predictive Analytics for Improved Healthcare
authors: Mani Sankar G, Jeniton S, Veera Boopathy E, Ashok Kumar R, Manojkumar B, Gowri M
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: As a recent addition to the technology that facilitates healthcare, wearable patient monitoring systems have been developed as a measure to prevent medical emergencies, particularly in eldercare. In this paper, a system to monitor vital health metrics like heart rate, ECG, temperature, blood pressure, and blood glucose is presented that uses the Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense microcontroller. By combining BLE or Wi-Fi connectivity to transmit real-time data to a mobile application, along with ML algorithms for pattern recognition, the system provides the foundation for identifying health risks. SMS, email, or in-app notifications are sent to both healthcare providers and caregivers to enable timely responses. The system’s cloud architecture is integrated as a safe place to store data and also provides access to data from the other side of the globe for healthcare professionals. The reduction of latency in data processing during emergency responses is critical. It lets IoT, real-time analytics, and predictive models form the basis of decision-making, reducing emergency response time and enhancing healthcare outcomes. Predictive analytics allows for more proactive rather than purely reactive health management.

title: Human-AI Collaborative Design of ReActNet-XGBoost Hardware Accelerator for Personalized Wearable ECG Monitoring
authors: Ching-Han Chen, Ke-Shan Lin, Ju-Shan Hsiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: The rapid expansion of personalized healthcare has positioned wearable electrocardiogram (ECG) monitoring systems as a pivotal solution for continuous cardiac assessment. However, achieving real-time signal classification under strict power and resource constraints remains a core challenge for edge-based deployment. While convolutional neural networks (CNNs) offer excellent feature extraction capabilities, their intensive computational and memory demands impede efficient implementation on lightweight hardware platforms. To overcome these limitations, we propose a hybrid hardware accelerator integrating a binarized ReActNet backbone for low-overhead feature extraction with an XGBoost decision tree classifier that provides interpretable and hardware-efficient inference. The ReActNet module leverages binary convolution operations to reduce arithmetic complexity, while the XGBoost component replaces dense layers, enhancing model transparency and reducing logic resource usage. To further streamline deployment, we introduce a generative hardware synthesis methodology based on large language models (LLMs), enabling automatic translation of trained XGBoost models into synthesizable VHDL code from their JSON representation. This LLM-assisted workflow significantly reduces development time, eliminates manual RTL coding, and promotes modular, reusable classifier generation adaptable to evolving clinical models. The proposed system is evaluated through RTL-level simulation and synthesis targeting low-power, resource-constrained FPGA platforms, demonstrating its architectural feasibility for real-time ECG classification at the edge. These findings highlight a unified and scalable framework that fuses binary neural networks, interpretable classifiers, and generative AI techniques to accelerate hardware-software co-design and broaden the deployment of edge AI in wearable health applications.

title: IoT-Enabled VR Simulation Platform for Cobot Motion Visualization and Remote Control
authors: Tarinee Tonggoed, Panu Leelanuch, Suttiphong Sridokbuab, Sarut Panjan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a virtual reality (VR)-based system for the simulation and control of the UR3 collaborative robot, integrated with Internet of Things (IoT) communication protocols. The system employs the PICO 4 VR headset to create an immersive virtual environment wherein the robot’s motion is simulated. The simulated motion data is transmitted to the physical UR3 robot, enabling it to execute corresponding movements. Conversely, joint position data from the actual robot is relayed back and visualized within the VR interface, allowing users to monitor the robot’s behavior. The developed VR-based control system for the UR3 collaborative robot demonstrated efficient performance in both simulation and real-time data transmission. The average latency of 416 milliseconds for single transmissions and $\mathbf{1, 4 6 5}$ milliseconds for batch transmissions indicates acceptable responsiveness for remote applications. The system also achieved high precision in inverse kinematics calculations, with average joint angle errors within $\mathbf{\pm 0. 1 - 0. 3}$ degrees. User feedback further confirmed the system’s usability, with a high satisfaction score averaging 4.57 out of 5.00. These results highlight the system’s reliability, accuracy, and strong potential for real-world deployment in remote robotic control tasks.

title: Laboratory Tests on the Sowing Qualities of Cotton Seeds of the Variety Helius, After Their Pre-Sowing Electromagnetic Treatment
authors: Kiril Sirakov, Minka Koleva
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Using an optimal composite design of type <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$B_{3}$</tex>, three-step pre-sowing electromagnetic treatments were performed on cotton seeds of the variety 'Helius'. The experimental factors selected were the treatment voltage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{U}, \mathbf{k V}$</tex> between the electrodes of the chamber, the duration of electromagnetic exposure <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\tau}(\mathbf{s})$</tex> and the storage period <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T$</tex> (days) from treatment to sowing. The experimental factors were applied at three levels: high, low, and medium. A specific feature of the treatments was that, with each subsequent exposure of the seeds, the voltage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$U$</tex> was periodically reduced, while the duration <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\tau$</tex> of the treatment was increased. The observed responses were the germination vigor (g.v.) and germination percentage (g.). The coefficients of the regression model were calculated, the necessary statistical tests were carried out, and the response curves were plotted for each pair of responses. When seeds were treated with experimental factors set at their low levels (variant 8), an inhibitory effect was recorded. Treatment of the seeds using the high levels of the experimental factors, with the values at the first step being <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$U=8 \text{kV}, \tau=15 ~\mathrm{s}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T=21$</tex> days ((variant 1), had a stimulating effect, with the observed responses exceeding those of the control seeds as follows: germination vigor <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-122.2 \% / \mathrm{C}$</tex>, germination percentage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 5. 0 \% / C}$</tex>. In variant 2, where the treatment voltage was applied at its low level <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{U}=6 \text{kV}$</tex>, while the other experimental factors were at their high levels <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\tau=15 ~\mathrm{s}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{T}=21$</tex> days, the treatment also had a stimulating effect, with the observed responses exceeding those of the control seeds as follows: germination vigor - <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$166.7 \% / \mathrm{C}$</tex>, germination percentage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-133.3 \% / \mathrm{C}$</tex>.

title: Enabling Residential Electric Car-Sharing Models Through Optimum Local Energy System Integration: A Concept
authors: Brian Dietermann, Philipp Rosner, Nico Nachtigall, Markus Lienkamp
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Residential car-sharing with electrified fleets could reduce private car ownership, lowering space demand for underutilized parked vehicles as well as mobility-related costs and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions. However, the increase in site energy demand caused by the electrified sharing fleet possibly necessitates retrofitting of the electrical infrastructure. Integrating smart and bidirectional fleet charging during this process may offer the opportunity to significantly reduce costs. This paper introduces a method to evaluate the cost reduction potential of varying integration levels of residential electric car-sharing fleets, based on realworld data from a nine month case study in Munich, Germany. It incorporates linear programming to optimize both investments and operational energy management of a local system and therefore enables a techno-economic assessment of different fleet integration scenarios for the investigated real-world location.

title: High-Harmonic THz Gyrotron Based on Excitation of a Surface Plasmon Polariton Wave
authors: V. V. Gerasimov, V. D. Kukotenko, E. M. Novak, A. V. Savilov
abstract: Experiments and theoretical estimates demonstrate the existence of surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) in the terahertz (THz) frequency range with a field localized near the surface of the conductor and propagating along the surface with relatively low losses. This fact opens up a possibility of generating SPPs by organizing their “direct” excitation near the metal surface, for example, due to stimulated cyclotron emission from electron beams. This can be a way for realization of THz gyrotrons based on selective excitation of SPPs at high cyclotron harmonics inside special open cavities. In this work, a possible scheme of a plasmonic gyrotron is proposed, the simplest theory of electronic cyclotron excitation of a SPP wave in an open cavity is described, and estimates for the starting currents of possible plasmonic gyrotrons are given.

title: Mobility Model based Performance evaluation of Routing protocols in mobile Ad Hoc network
authors: Kavyashree M K, Megha K M, Chandana S, Priyanka R, Shylaja K C
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: MANETs have no fixed structure and their network topology changes often, finding the best way to send data is very challenging. The mobile nodes mobility patterns have an impact on routing protocol performance in the mobile networks. This work compares Dynamic Source Routing (DSR) and Destination-Sequenced Distance Vector (DSDV) to understand how well they function in different situations where nodes move. Making use of MATLAB, the simulation helps model and analyze all aspects of the communication protocols. Three particular types of movement models are analyzed: the Random Waypoint Model, the Gauss-Markov Model and the Random Direction Model. They mirror everyday examples of movement and support an analysis of how mobility shapes protocol performance. The main factors to assess how responsive and reliable a protocol is are its Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR) and Throughput. The results of the simulations show that protocol performance varies a lot depending on the kind of mobility model used. DSR handles dynamism better than DSDV, but DSDV performs steadier as the nodes move less within a network. Such insights guide the choice of routing strategy for different MANET applications. The study helps increase understanding of mobility-aware protocol design and selection, leading to better and more dependable mobile wireless communication network.

title: Investigation of the Thermal Deformations of a CNC Lathe
authors: Svetlana Koleva
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Accuracy management requires that technical and organizational measures related to thermal deformation errors be identified at the technological design stage. All components of the processing system are subjected to heating and, accordingly, generate thermal deformation errors. The publication provides data from a study conducted in real conditions on the resulting thermal deformation error. These conditions are determined by the actual parameters of the process and the processing system, taking into account the impact of all thermal factors, including their mutual influence. As a result, the probable maximum limit error created by the thermal deformations of the machine tool assemblies and the change in their intensity in each machining cycle was determined.

title: Dielectric Properties Measurement of Cellulose-Containing Materials Using the Resonator Method
authors: T. O. Krapivnitckaia, V. V. Parshin, E. A. Serov, A. B. Alyeva, S. A. Ananicheva, A. A. Vikharev, N. Yu. Peskov, M. Yu. Glyavin
abstract: Based on an open high-Q Fabry-Perot resonator, measurements of the dielectric parameters (dielectric loss tangent and permittivity) of organic materials were carried out in the frequency range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \div 200 \text{GHz}$</tex>: cellulose, lignin, high-moor and low-moor peat. A comparative analysis of the absorption capacity of organic materials at a temperature of 298 K is presented. In order to identify the influence of humidity on the absorption properties of high-moor peat, a comparative assessment of the dielectric parameters of peat with different mass fractions of moisture is carried out. It was found that undrained peat with a moisture content of 21% absorbs microwave radiation better in the studied frequency range. Frequency dependences of the real <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\varepsilon^{\prime})$</tex> and imaginary <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\varepsilon^{\prime \prime})$</tex> parts of the permittivity were obtained, and materials with the highest absorption capacity were determined.

title: A Python-PowerFactory Co-Simulation Framework for Harmonic Load Flow and Dynamic Analysis of an Integrated Distribution Network
authors: Georgios A. Barzegkar-Ntovom, Theofilos A. Papadopoulos, Eleftherios O. Kontis, Grigoris K. Papagiannis
abstract: As power systems experience higher integration of distributed generation units, it becomes essential to model the network in detail across all voltage levels. Consequently, detailed simulation models are required not only for the transmission network but also for the medium voltage and low voltage distribution network (DN) sub-grids. Additionally, the growing complexity of modern power systems often necessitates integrated co-simulation across multiple platforms, automating analysis and input updates to examine a wide range of scenarios without manual intervention. In this context, this paper implements a Python - DIgSILENT PowerFactory co-simulation on an integrated DN model. Results from two indicative case studies—harmonic load flow analysis and dynamic equivalence modeling—are presented. The detailed DN model, developed in DIgSILENT PowerFactory, along with the Python source code used for handling key functionalities in the co-simulation, has been made publicly accessible.
