title: Omnidirectionally Matched Cloak for Unpolarized Waves
authors: Yuqi Wang, Xiaojun Hu, Yuan Gao, Dexin Ye
abstract: Transformation optics (TO) provide a powerful tool to design invisibility cloaks, which can render objects invisible. However, the inhomogeneous and anisotropic constitutive parameters derived from coordinate transformation are difficult to realize. Hence, the invisibility cloaks realized so far are often implemented in a reduced manner at the expense of degrading the cloaking performance. For example, the realized cloaks can only operate under single polarization, hindering the physical implementation of invisibility cloaks. Here, based on Fabry-Pérot (FP) resonance, we propose a general design strategy to realize an omnidirectionally matched and polarization-independent anisotropic metamaterial. Such metamaterial, constructed by perfect electric conductor (PEC) and natural materials, has an anisotropic spatially permittivity tensor. By employing appropriate transformations and combinations of such anisotropic material, we design an omnidirectional cloak with polarization constraints being totally lifted. The numerical simulation results validate that the designed invisibility cloak exhibits excellent invisible performance for unpolarized waves under arbitrary incidence angles. The design strategy paves the way to realize other unpolarized TO devices.

title: Research on Cross Layer Signal Line Interference Suppression in High Speed PCB Boards
authors: Yujie Song, Jiasheng Chen, Bin Xie, Qiang-Ming Cai, Xin Cao, Longjian Zhou, Haoran Li, Yuyu Zhu, Jun Fan
abstract: A design of interlaced periodically loaded transmission lines(PLTL) structure suitable for a wide frequency range is proposed to address the far-end crosstalk (FEXT) problem existing in high-speed circuits on current printed circuit boards (PCBs). By interlacing the open stubs of a pair of PLTL and inserting U-shaped metal structures with opposite opening directions in sequence, this design can increase the mutual capacitance between microstrip lines and slightly increase the self-inductance. Simulation tests were conducted on microstrip lines with different spacings, and the comparison results show that the far-end crosstalk of the microstrip lines is greatly suppressed in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1-20 \text{GHz}$</tex> range, while the near-end crosstalk is increased to a certain extent. The conclusion is applicable to the routing between devices on conventional PCBs. The overall structure does not involve the design of vias and substrate materials, and has the advantages of low processing difficulty and cost compared with common ground guard lines and film structures.

title: Dual-Band $\pi$-Shaped Printed Monopole Antenna with Isolating Stub for 3G and 5G Applications
authors: Mohamed S. Soliman
abstract: In this paper, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pi$</tex>-shaped dual band monopole antenna is presented. The monopole antenna is procuring the conventional characteristic of omnidirectional pattern at frequencies of 2170 MHz and 3500 MHz. As lower frequency region is crowded so isolating the two bands is quite challenging, thus an isolating stub is deployed which eventually forms the shape of antenna as mathematical symbol “<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pi$</tex>”. The incorporation of stub enhances the return loss and bandwidth at the operating bands. Whilst, the efficiency attains by antenna which is modeled on Rogers 5880 is more than 90% in 3G and Sub-6 GHz band of 5G Application.

title: Ultra-Thin Angularly Stable Polarization Conversion Metasurface for Millimeter-Wave Applications
authors: Hisham Khalil, Umair Rafique, Hijab Zahra, Shobit Agarwal, Syed Muzahir Abbas
abstract: This work presents the design of an ultra-thin and wideband polarization conversion metasurface (PCM) for millimeter-wave (mm-wave) applications. The PCM structure is composed of a modified ring patch resonator designed on a low-loss dielectric substrate. From the simulations, it is observed that the designed PCM operates from 26 to 31 GHz and provides impedance bandwidth and fractional bandwidth (FBW) of 5 GHz and 17.54 %, respectively, which well cover the 28 GHz mm -wave frequency spectrum. In addition, a polarization conversion ratio (PCR) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 100 \%$</tex> is observed in the operating bandwidth. Moreover, the performance of the proposed PCM is assessed for different oblique incidences, and a stable response has been observed up to a 50° angle of incidence with PCR to be greater than 90 %.

title: Mobile Application for Fuzzy Logic-based Wood Fungi Classification
authors: Alžbeta Michalíková, Patrik Rusnák, Svetlana Gáperová, Ján Gáper, Adam Dudáš
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Species determination is a fundamental task in biology and environmental studies, yet biologists and students often lack portable and user-friendly tools for fieldwork. When focusing on fungi species classification, the previous work utilizes fuzzy inference system capable of classifying six species of Ganoderma wood fungi based on their morphological features. However, the reliance on desktop software solutions limited its practicality, which motivated the presented work. In this study, we focus on the translation of the fungi classification application to mobile devices, thereby enhancing accessibility and usability in real-world scenarios and field exercises of mycology courses.

title: The Role of Room Impulse Response in Educational Applications
authors: Jakub Urbánek, Peter Kasák, Roman Jarina
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Room acoustics significantly influence learning outcomes in both traditional (in-person) and distance education environments. Artefacts such as background noise and reverberation can negatively affect students' attention, memory, and comprehension. With the growth of distance learning and immersive technologies such as virtual and augmented reality, the importance of high-quality audio becomes even more critical. A possible way to address acoustic interference is through denoising and speech separation. A central component in addressing reverberations is room impulse response. It contains information about sound reflections and material properties making it an essential asset in classroom design, speech transmission improvement, and immersive simulations. This paper reviews applications and research works in various educational contexts, from acoustic treatment of classrooms to speech quality in distance learning and usage in diverse virtual reality simulations. Furthermore, this work reviews different methods for obtaining RIR, ranging from classical measurement techniques to modern machine learning approaches. Finally, the paper outlines opportunities for integrating acoustic modelling into educational practices to improve their effectiveness, quality, and accessibility.

title: A Non-Conventional Loss-of-Field Protection Scheme
authors: Vassilis C. Nikolaidis
abstract: This paper proposes a non-conventional LOF protection scheme which is based on monitoring the response of the air-gap flux linkage, the reactive power, and the rotor angle of the synchronous machine in real time. The proposed scheme is extensively tested on a realistic test power system model operating under different generator loading conditions. Simulation shows that the proposed scheme reliably detects total and partial LOF conditions. Comparison of the proposed LOF scheme with other promising LOF protection methods, as well as with the conventional offset mho protection relay, shows that the proposed scheme detects LOF failures faster than the other methods, whereas it does not maloperate for external system faults.

title: Tsmixing:Multiscale Mixing With Allogenous And Autogenous Variables For Time Series Forcasting
authors: Huixiang Li, Ming Zhang, Guoping Wang, Ke Zuo, Chen Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Society, Information Science and Risk Management (ICDIR)
abstract: Deep models have demonstrated outstanding performance in time series prediction. However, due to the existence of some observational characteristics in real-world application scenarios, focusing only on the target variables (the named autogenous variables) is usually insufficient to ensure the accuracy of the prediction. It is worth noting that a system is often recorded by multiple variables, among which allogenous variables could offer important external information for autogenous variables. Therefore, unlike the mature multivariate or univariate prediction paradigms that treat all variables at the same extent or ignore allogenous information, we are going to focuses on a more detailed setting: time series prediction with allogenous variables, which allogenous variables is the main focus. We propose a novel method, Tsmixing, which enables the standard Transformer to coordinate autogenous and allogenous information through ingeniously designed embedding layers, while simultaneously applying fragment-level self-attention and variable-level cross-attention mechanisms. Furthermore, by learning global autogenous markers, this method effectively Bridges the implicit causal information of allogenous sequences to autogenous time segments.

title: Ultra-High-Frequency Cryptocurrency Price Dynamics: A Deep LSTM Approach for High-Precision Predictions
authors: Ramachandran S, P Vasuki
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: This research presents a rapid method for forecasting cryptocurrency prices using market data collected every five minutes, employing Deep Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural networks. The approach analyzes trading details from the BTC/USDT pair on a prominent cryptocurrency exchange. By examining price history from the previous two hours, it estimates the price for the next 5-minute interval. Testing reveals that these forecasts are highly accurate, with average errors remaining below 0.50%. In multiple experiments, error rates ranged from 0.098% to 0.307%, demonstrating the method’s reliability. This work supports algorithmic trading by providing a dependable strategy for short-term cryptocurrency price forecasting, with potential applications in other financial prediction tasks.

title: Analysis of the Influence of Inverter Parameters and the Related PV System Configuration on the Performance of PV Plants
authors: Ventsislav Keseev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The photovoltaic (PV) systems have comparatively low conversion efficiencies and investment return ratios, and must be optimized. The influence of the inverter parameters and system configuration on the performance of PV systems are studied through simulation with System Advisory Model (SAM). Many different PV system configurations are created and their results compared. The main conclusions are that the main selection criteria of an inverter are the reliability, the required functionalities, depending on the requirements of the project, the price, and secondary the efficiency. Generally, the PV string maximum DC voltages at standard testing conditions (STC) must be either close to the upper inverter maximum power point taking (MPPT) voltage limit or higher, if it supports certain level of oversizing. More precisely, the optimal design of a PV system requires the maximum power point voltage of each PV string at STC to be equal or higher than the recommended nominal MPPT voltage of the selected inverter, if such value is presented by the producer.

title: Daily Land Surface Temperature Reconstruction in Landsat Cross-Track Areas Using Deep Ensemble Learning With Uncertainty Quantification
authors: Shengjie Liu, Siqin Wang, Lu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Many real-world applications rely on land surface temperature (LST) data at high spatiotemporal resolution. In complex urban areas, LST exhibits significant variations, fluctuating dramatically within and across city blocks. Landsat provides high spatial resolution data at 100 meters but is limited by long revisit time, with cloud cover further disrupting data collection. Here, we propose DELAG, a deep ensemble learning method that integrates annual temperature cycles and Gaussian processes, to reconstruct Landsat LST in complex urban areas. Leveraging the cross-track characteristics and dual-satellite operation of Landsat since 2021, we further enhance data availability to 4 scenes every 16 days. We select New York City, London and Hong Kong from three different continents as study areas. Experiments show that DELAG successfully reconstructed LST in the three cities under clear-sky (RMSE = 0.73-0.96 K) and heavily-cloudy (RMSE = 0.84-1.62 K) situations, superior to existing methods. Additionally, DELAG can quantify uncertainty that enhances LST reconstruction reliability. We further tested the reconstructed LST to estimate near-surface air temperature, achieving results (RMSE = 1.48-2.11 K) comparable to those derived from clear-sky LST (RMSE = 1.63-2.02 K). The results demonstrate the successful reconstruction through DELAG and highlight the broader applications of LST reconstruction for estimating accurate air temperature. Our study thus provides a novel and practical method for Landsat LST reconstruction, particularly suited for complex urban areas within Landsat cross-track areas, taking one step toward addressing complex climate events at high spatiotemporal resolution. Code and data will be available at skrisliu.com/delag.

title: Design and Performance Analysis of NOMA-OFDM with Time-Domain Interleaving
authors: Tasneem Assaf, Welelaw Lakew, Shihab Jimaa, Arafat Al-Dweik
abstract: This letter presents an improved non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) design using time-domain interleaving (TDI). The frequency diversity inherent in TDI is leveraged to improve the bit error rate (BER) of NOMA by mitigating the detrimental effects of channel frequency selectivity. The instantaneous signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) of the proposed system is derived and used to evaluate the BER using minimum-mean-square-error (MMSE) equalization semi-analytically with spatial diversity over frequency-selective fading channels for an arbitrary number of users. Moreover, a tight analytic lower-bound (LB) is derived to enable efficient BER evaluation. The obtained analytical results, corroborated by Monte Carlo simulation, demonstrate that TDI can provide significant BER improvement to NOMA by resolving the performance degradation caused by severe fading and multi-user interference. The synergy of receiver spatial diversity and TDI enabled the low-complexity zero-forcing (ZF) equalizer to offer BER that is comparable to MMSE, which is drastically different from the single-input single-output (SISO) case.

title: High Performance Bloch Surface Wave Sensing: Optimized Photonic Bandgap Structure for Low Detection Limit
authors: Huitong Jiang, Weijing Kong, Junsen Wang, Xuanxin Chang, Yu Lu, Xiaochang Ni
abstract: Bloch Surface Waves have emerged as a promising alternative to Surface Plasmon Resonance for high-sensitivity sensing applications, owing to their low optical losses, sharp resonance dips, and tunable polarization properties. This paper explores a high-performance Bloch surface wave sensor based on an optimized one-dimensional photonic crystal structure for ultra-sensitive refractive index detection. The sensor architecture consists of a periodic stack of TiO₂ and SiO₂ layers with a TiO₂ cap layer, designed using the transfer matrix method to operate in aqueous environments. Through numerical simulations and theoretical analyses, we systematically engineer the photonic bandgap structure to achieve enhanced field localization and low transmission loss. A Kretschmann-Raether prism coupling setup with precision angular control is employed to experimentally validate the device's exceptional performance. The narrow resonance feature (FWHM = 0.036°) and high quality factor (Q > 1480) confirm excellent sensing capabilities, demonstrating high sensing sensitivity and an intensity-based detection resolution of 4.51 × 10⁻⁷ RIU. This work establishes BSW sensors as a next-generation platform for label-free biochemical sensing with low detection limit in the near-infrared regime.

title: From Facial Expressions to User Experience (UX): How Emotions Shape the Design of Intelligent Systems
authors: Antonio Di Tecco
abstract: Emotions are a key determinant of User Experience (UX). This work investigates the relationship between facial emotions and UX, presenting ALPHA, a predictive system that estimates User Satisfaction based on valence–arousal (VA) signals. The Dataset DT22, a database of 112 participants, is used to evaluate models on the external test set. An identity-free processing pipeline that uses only VA features achieves ∼77% accuracy/weighted F1-score. When context information is also available—Movie Clip ID and perceived User Quality—the context-aware pipeline increases performance to ∼85–92% in ablation analyses, by using ensembles with majority voting decision rule. This indicates that contextual features provide complementary information to VA. To assess system robustness, Leave-One-Participant-Out (LOPO) and Leave-One-Movieclip-Out (LOMO) protocol schemes, as well as emotion-anchored evaluations (first- and last-emotion), are investigated. The approach is modular and adheres to privacy-by-design principles by operating on identity-free descriptors rather than storing facial frames. Overall, the findings suggest that emotion signals can support adaptive UX and enable dynamic content personalization in applications such as video streaming, customer-experience management, and e-learning. This research presents a practical study on integrating emotion-aware intelligence while respecting user privacy.

title: Reliability Optimization of Ultra-Large-Capacity and High-Speed DFIGMs with Non-Overlapping Winding
authors: Lu Sun, Qiange Wang, Lei Huang, Jin Wang, Xianzhuo Zhang, Haoyu Kang, Zequan Li, Libing Zhou
abstract: The outer diameter linear velocity of the rotor of the ultra-large capacity doubly-fed induction generator motors (DFIGMs) used in variable-speed pumped storage projects can reach 180 m/s. Rotor reliability during super-synchronous operation and forward/reverse switching is the main constraint of DFIGMs. This paper presents a novel non-overlapping winding (NW) hanging tooth structure for rotor. This structure significantly reduces the winding overhang length, simplifies the fixing structure, and effectively addresses the rotor reliability challenge. Based on the magnetic field distribution of the novel NW structure, a multi-constraint and multi-level topology optimization method is proposed with the objectives of low leakage and high winding utilization. Furthermore, stator-rotor winding matching is designed leveraging winding filtering characters. Finally, a prototype of the novel NW structure is developed and experimentally validated to verify its effectiveness.

title: Decentralized Coded Caching under Heterogeneous Cache Sizes and Arbitrary Popularity Distribution
authors: Xiaoxia Wang, Chunpeng Chen, Xiaoran Wang, Jinbei Zhang, Kechao Cai
abstract: Coded caching has emerged as an effective technique to alleviate network congestion. While the individual impact of user cache sizes or file popularity has been investigated independently, their joint impact on coded caching remains unclear. In this paper, we first characterize two information-theoretic lower bounds on the expected transmission rate. The first bound introduces a novel cut-set method that allows users to repeatedly request files at different frequencies, accounting for the heterogeneity of user cache sizes and file popularity. The second bound is derived from the traditional cut-set bound, assuming each file is requested at most once. Then a group-based multi-round decentralized coded caching scheme is introduced. We show that the expected transmission rate for this scheme is at most an O(log K) factor away from the second lower bound, applicable to any cache and popularity distributions, where K is the number of users. Additionally, by combining with the first lower bound, a tighter O(log K mK/m1) gap between the upper and lower bounds is derived for power function and Zipf cache distributions, where m1 and mK represent the minimum and maximum cache sizes, respectively. Simulation results show the superior performance of our proposed scheme.

title: CompleMatch: Boosting Time-Series Semi-Supervised Classification With Temporal-Frequency Complementarity
authors: Zhen Liu, Kun Zeng, Qianli Ma, James T. Kwok
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Time series Semi-Supervised Classification (SSC) aims to improve model performance by utilizing abundant unlabeled data in scenarios where labeled samples are limited. Previous approaches mainly focus on exploiting temporal dependencies within the time domain for SSC. However, these temporal dependencies are susceptible to sampling noise and may not effectively capture the global periodicity of features across categories. To this end, we propose a time series SSC framework called CompleMatch, leveraging the complementary information from both temporal and frequency representations for unlabeled data learning. CompleMatch simultaneously trains two deep neural networks based on time-domain and frequency-domain views, with pseudo-labels generated via label propagation in the representation space guiding the training of the opposing view's classifier. In this co-training paradigm, we incorporate a constraint term to harness the complementary nature of temporal-frequency representations, thereby enhancing the model's robustness under limited labeled data. In addition, we design a temporal-frequency contrastive learning module that integrates supervised and self-supervised signals to enhance pseudo-label quality by learning more discriminative representations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CompleMatch surpasses state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, analyses of model behavior (i.e., ablation studies and visualization) underscore the effectiveness of our proposed approach.

title: Impact of the FCS-MPC Switching Reduction Weighting Coefficient on Losses and THD for a Three-Phase Inverter
authors: Bruno Kretzer Barotto, João Pedro Brunoni, Rodolfo César Costa Flesch
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The use of the traditional implementation of finite control set model predictive control (FCS-MPC) in power converters often results in high switching frequencies, leading to increased losses and reduced efficiency. Unlike conventional modulation techniques, such as pulse width modulation, the switching behavior of FCS-MPC is highly variable, complicating loss estimation. This study proposes a method that uses losses, estimated through simulation, to tune the weighting factor of a switching reduction term in the cost function to obtain a response with reduced losses and acceptable total harmonic distortion (THD). The proposed approach considers both conduction and switching losses and takes into account the predicted temperature of the power switch while estimating the losses. This approach improves efficiency by directly addressing the challenge of nontrivial switching patterns, offering a more effective solution for FCS-MPC implementation in two-level three-phase inverters. Simulation results in a 22 kW inverter model show that it is possible to reduce the switching losses by more than 30% while still keeping the THD below 5%.

title: Electrically Controlled Reflectance Modulation Utilizing ENZ Materials Near 1550Nm Wavelength
authors: Shakti Pada Mahato, Vipul Rastogi
abstract: Recently, transparent conducting oxides (TCOs) have gained considerable attention as active materials for light modulation. We report a grating-assisted TCO-based light-modulating device, where the reflectance can be modulated by depleting or injecting carriers within the TCO thin film. The design consists of silver (Ag) grating placed on indium doped-cadmium-oxide (ICO) integrated on an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{HfO}_{2}$</tex>-coated Ag substrate. By harnessing the electro-tunable epsilon-near-zero effect of ICO, we achieve a large modulation depth of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 35 ~\text{dB}$</tex> at 1550 nm wavelength.

title: Interval Type-2 Fuzzy Covariance Control for Ship Fin Stabilizer Systems Under Stochastic Disturbances
authors: Yann-Horng Lin, Wen-Jer Chang, Cheung-Chieh Ku
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: This research investigates an Interval Type-2 (IT-2) fuzzy covariance control method for nonlinear ship rolling motion using fin stabilizers. To enhance practical applicability, uncertainties and stochastic disturbances are also considered. Based on the IT-2 Takagi-Sugeno Fuzzy Model (T-SFM), the nonlinear rolling motion under uncertainties can be captured in a more complete manner. Corresponding to the T-SFM, an Interval Type-2 (IT-2) fuzzy controller is developed to drive the fin stabilizers for the control of ship rolling motion. Then, the closed-loop T-SFM is reformulated into a reduced fuzzy rule form. Moreover, the covariance matrices and corresponding variance constraints are further constructed from an energy-based perspective for each subsystem of the closed-loop T-SFM. By integrating the IT-2 fuzzy control method, covariance control theory, and Lyapunov theory, stability criteria are established through the use of an upper bound matrix, which also allows the stability conditions to be transformed into Linear Matrix Inequalities (LMIs). Finally, the simulation results of the nonlinear ship rolling motion control using fin stabilizers are presented to verify the performance of the IT-2 fuzzy covariance control under uncertainties and stochastic disturbances.

title:
Design and Modeling of CsGe(I
                    <sub>1-x</sub>
                    Br
                    <sub>x</sub>
                    )3-Based Wide-Bandgap Perovskite Absorber for High-Performance Tandem Solar Cells
authors: Hayat Arbouz
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study investigates the simulation and optimization of a single-junction solar cell featuring an inorganic, lead-free absorber material, $\operatorname{CsGe}\left(\mathrm{I}_{1-\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{Br}_{\mathrm{x}}\right)$ 3, whose bandgap energy can be tuned by varying the bromine content. The primary goal is to determine the optimal absorber composition that maximizes photovoltaic performance. To this end, a baseline device structure was designed, and a tailored simulation model was developed to assess the photovoltaic parameters as a function of the bromine ratio, x. The second part of the study focuses on device design optimization. Through contour plot analysis of the photovoltaic parameters under simultaneous variation of the absorber and electron transport layer (ETL) thicknesses, the regions of optimal performance were identified for the baseline structure as well as for alternative ETL materials. Moreover, alternative hole transport layer (HTL) materials were also investigated. The results revealed an optimal bromine content of $\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0 . 3 3}$, corresponding to a bandgap energy of 1.83 eV, and an optimized device structure achieving a power conversion efficiency of $23 \%$. This optimized absorber was subsequently integrated as the top subcell in a tandem solar cell configuration, achieving an efficiency close to $27 \%$. The overall aim of this work is to develop stable, non-toxic, and high-performance perovskite solar cells.

title: Image Enhancement Using CLAHE and CNN for Underwater Lighting Effects
authors: Syed Shahareyar, Amarjeet Kumar, Pooja Agrawal, Sashi Kanta Panigrahi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: This paper concentrates on image enhancement in underwater environments, which is important for tasks like surveillance, navigation, and exploration of marine wildlife. Underwater images usually suffer from light scattering, color distortion, and uneven illumination, which hinders visual assessment. Although several enhancement techniques have been developed, but there is still no comprehensive assessment done in various real-life lighting scenarios. This research work fills that gap by applying and evaluating a hybrid enhancement model to images taken from an aquarium with a bright lighting effect and an open well lit with natural sunlight, capturing low, bright, and mixed lighting conditions. The model includes the CLAHE method and the CNN-based model. The former is well known for enhancing the local contrast, while the latter is dedicated to improving the image clarity and detailing the various structures within the image. Evaluation of performance was carried out using peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR). Findings indicate that while boosting contrast, CLAHE's speed and efficiency outperform its complex degradation handling capabilities. The other method, which employs a CNN model, consistently offers better visuals in addition to higher PSNR under various brightness conditions.

title: Blockchain-Powered Social Media: A Model for Privacy, Transparency, and Freedom of Expression
authors: Prutha Pawade, Manikrao Dhore, Kshitij Kumre, Manish Zure, Sakshi Patil
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Centralized social media networks frequently deal with serious problems such content control, equitable monetization, and data privacy. We suggest Decentralized twitter, a blockchain-based social media platform that makes use of decentralized IPFS storage and Ethereum smart contracts, to overcome these drawbacks. In order to provide content creators with consistent and equitable income from future sales of their digital work, this study presents a novel NFT-based monetization strategy with a mathematically enforced royalty distribution mechanism inside smart contracts. The platform also facilitates micropayment integration, which makes it possible to precisely monetize one-on-one conversations and encourages user involvement through transactions that are cryptographically secured. When taken as a whole, these developments greatly improve economic justice, transparency, and privacy protection, highlighting how blockchain technology has the ability to completely transform social networking.

title: Affordable and Compact CNC Machine for Small-Scale Fabrication
authors: Atharva Kudale, Ganesh Lokhande, Swayam Tryambake, Deepali Yewle
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The automation sector has improved accuracy, speed, and scalability, fundamentally changing production processes. The automation of cutting, milling, and engraving processes has been made possible in large part by Computer Numerical Control (CNC) devices. However, because of their prohibitive cost, enormous size, and limited accessibility for small users like hobbyists, small businesses, and educational institutions, traditional CNC machines typically pose significant challenges. This paper introduces a solution in the form of an affordable-priced and portable CNC machine to overcome these challenges. The suggested CNC system combines cost-effectiveness with performance, with a minimalist approach that enables easy assembly and operation. With cost-effective materials such as stepper motors, the RAMPS 1.4 control board, and a light frame, the machine is optimized for economical production with performance standards intact. It is the perfect tool for small-scale manufacture, prototyping, and instructional applications because of its simplicity of use and tiny size. By successfully bridging the gap between individual makers' creative requirements and industrial-grade automation, the system allows users to access CNC technology without significant financial or space barriers. This innovation aims to democratize access to contemporary manufacturing technologies by offering a scalable solution that makes automated fabrication capabilities more accessible to a wider range of individuals. This will encourage creativity and innovation across a wide range of applications, from small scale manufacturing to hobbyist projects.

title: A Machine Learning Framework for Robust Human Activity Recognition
authors: Bhavya Patel, Vishal Lokwani, Aaryan Limbasiya, Debabrata Swain, Amol Bhilare, Makarand Upkare
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The growing global population of the elderly demands new ways of maintaining their security and well-being, particularly those who live on their own without constant supervision. This paper, introduces a new Human Activity Recognition (HAR) system which is specifically designed for elderly care without the requirement of any supervision. In our system we have used Support Vector Machines along with the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) for purpose of improving accuracy and efficiency. By examination of the data from wearable sensors and OpenPose, it helps detecting movements like standing, walking, squatting, and waving. The result shows an impressive accuracy of 98.82%—which outperforms many of the existing methods. This advancement could help in achieving a real difference in elderly care, which offers a practical and dependable way of monitoring daily activities and quickly determining any kind of unusual behaviour.

title: Leveraging Natural Language Processing for Real-Time and Accurate Speech-to-Sign Language Translation
authors: Pooja Bagane, Sonali Kothari, Aradhana Pratap, Amol Dhumane
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The field of speech recognition has been an active area of research for many decades. Recent years have seen the rise of Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques to build translation systems. This project focuses on developing Speechto-Indian-Sign-Language Translation system using NLP techniques. The simple easygui system shows a pop-up window to the user to select the language in which the user wants to speak: Hindi or English. It then uses a speech-to-text conversion library to convert the speech into text as input to the program. After that text is tokenized, lemmatized and stop word removed through various steps of NLP to ensure better accuracy of system etc. The extracted form is then used to find a folder with Indian Sign Language gestures in MP4 format. The program shows the gesture for each word in the text. When a word is not present in the folder you break it down into letters and represent them using Indian Sign Language alphabet. The objective of this system is to create an effective tool for the speech-impaired community to communicate with greater ease in such environments where speech is the only method of communication. The combination of NLP techniques with Indian Sign Language gestures improve both the accuracy and efficiency of the system. Through the easygui, the system interacts with the user through a friendly interface. Audio files are transcribed using the Google Speech-to-Text API and the text is then matched to the appropriate audio file. Finally, it looks for matching mp4 file of the transcribed text in a lo of mp4 files, and the rest of the image files for the words not in the ISL dataset. This work sheds light on the potential of speech recognition tasks, and also serves as a practical guide for the implementation of speech recognition technology across multiple fields.

title: Federated Contrastive Graph Transformer Framework for Scalable and Privacy-Preserving Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT Networks
authors: Sachin Shankarrao Ajmire, Aniket Sanjayrao Wankhade, Karuna Vivekanand Agarkar, Shailesh R Thakare
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: A key requirement resulting from the increased adoption of Industrial Internet-of-Things (IIOT) networks is the improvement of anomaly detection systems against cyber threats. The traditional centralized model suffers from several limitations such as scalability issues, high latency, privacy concerns, and low adaptability to evolving threats. It is hard to generalize the accurate anomaly detection in all the industry domains for which the existing deep learning has been produced because they have been designed or trained with respect to individual industries. Moreover, these algorithms are either time-consuming or consume higher latency to be used at the edge in real-time. To solve these challenges, this study proposes a Hybrid Federated Contrastive Graph Transformer Framework, which integrates multiple advanced deep learning and machine learning models designed for scalable, real-time, and privacy-preserving anomaly detection in IIoT environments. The Federated Contrastive Graph Transformer Network (Fed-CGTN) yields privacy-preserving anomaly detection due to federated learning, graph transformers, and contrastive learning, consuming 62% less bandwidth while maintaining 98.2% accuracy. To enable low-power real-time execution, the proposed framework incorporates Spiking Temporal Graph Neural Networks (S-TGNN) into the framework, which results in a 74 % reduction in energy consumption and latency of less than 5 ms. The domain-generalization of the DA-MMGAN improves cross-domain generalization through synthetic anomaly generation and increases the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{F 1}$</tex>-score by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 4. 3 \%}$</tex>. The Meta-Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Cyber Threat Detection (Meta-RL-ACTD) continuously updates threat-detection strategies to dynamically adapt to emerging threats. It achieved a 92.7 % detection probability for zero-day attacks with a 63 % reduction in retraining frequency sets. Finally, the Hierarchical Hybrid Deep Learning Model (HHDL) integrates CNN, LSTM, and the Autoencoder to complement each other into a comprehensive multi-layered threat classification. The integrated scheme provides scalability, energy-efficiency, privacy-preservation, cross-domain adaptiveness, and real-time adaptive cybersecurity in IIoT networks. The proposed framework will bring significant contributions to the enhancement of IIoT security by providing robust anomaly detection and more optimized computational and communication efficiency.

title: Reverse Convolutional Precoding of Polar Codes: Design, Analysis, and Decoding Algorithms
authors: Xinyi Gu, Mohammad Rowshan, Jinhong Yuan
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Convolutionally precoded polar codes known as polarization-adjusted convolutional (PAC) codes are a promising variant of polar codes for short block lengths. The precoding in PAC codes has demonstrated an effective reduction in the number of minimum weight codewords (a.k.a error coefficient) of polar codes. This reduction potentially improves the error correction performance significantly. From a codeword formation perspective, this reduction has limitations. Capitalizing on the understanding of the decomposition of minimum-weight codewords, this paper proposes a new coding scheme called reverse PAC (RPAC) codes that can effectively reduce minimum-weight codewords more than in PAC codes. Additionally, we propose a look-ahead list decoding for the RPAC codes, which maintains the same order of complexity as list decoding in PAC codes. Numerical results demonstrate that RPAC codes achieve significant improvements in block error rate over polar and PAC codes, especially in high-rate short-code scenarios where existing schemes are less effective.

title: Collaborative design for moving target detection in distributed radar networks
authors: Dingsen Zhou, Minglei Yang, Xuehao Wu, Maria Sabrina Greco, Fulvio Gini
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Distributed radar networks (DRNs) can improve target detection by fusing the spatially diverse echoes from multiple receiving stations. However, this potential is limited by the communication burden and the spatial correlation of echoes. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a flexible hierarchical collaborative scheme for moving target detection in DRNs. The proposed scheme supports operating in coherent, noncoherent, and hybrid modes, providing a configurable trade-off between detection performance and communication demand. In particular, the hybrid mode provides an intermediate collaboration strategy between coherent and noncoherent modes. The collaboration design problem is generally non-convex due to the orthogonality constraint. Therefore, a stacked-product Riemannian conjugate gradient algorithm is developed to configure the collaboration matrix, allowing efficient fusion of radar echoes. Additionally, a multi-constraint k-medoids clustering-based topology design is proposed to organize radar nodes into effective cooperative groups based on echo correlation and communication cost. Analytical detection thresholds are derived for each detection mode to ensure a prescribed false-alarm rate under correlated observations. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of all three detection modes, showing up to 55% lower communication overhead compared to the non-collaborative fusion.

title: Intensity Based Optical Interrogation Using Fused Fiber Demux as an Edge Filter by Reference FBG Method
authors: Naveenkumar Mahadevachar, Shivaleela Esamudra Sharanappa
abstract: A wavelength-to-intensity conversion, (W2IC), based optical interrogation using reference FBG technique, based on the key component fused fiber demux, as an edge filter, is proposed. Two distinct Bragg wavelength, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\lambda _\text{B}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, FBGs are selected as reference / sense FBGs, which are chosen to lie on the flat / +ve slope characteristics of the edge filter to provide reference / W2IC, signals respectively. Sense FBG wavelength at the lower end of the +ve slope of the edge filter, gives maximum range. Source power variation, if any, affects both the reflected signals equally and hence is nullified after processing. Sense FBG when strained, Bragg wavelength shifts, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\Delta \lambda _\text{B}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, and the reflected signal power varies after passing through the edge filter, whereas the reference FBG signal power remains constant. Hence, change in the sense FBG signal power, w.r.t the reference FBG signal power, is only due to the strain variation. Proposed technique has two advantages, (i) 3 dB higher signal power, as the reference signal is generated from the reference FBG, and (ii) reduced hardware required, as compared to that of the popularly used ratio-metric optical interrogator. An experiment is carried out using strain sense FBG, by applying weight upto 2000 grams and an average sensitivity or wavelength shift of 1.134 pm/gram is obtained.

title: Assist-as-Needed Framework for Robotic Rehabilitation: Adaptive Admittance Control with Passivity-Based Safety Features
authors: Leilaalsadat Pezeshki, Hamid Sadeghian, Xiao Chen, Mehdi Keshmiri, Sami Haddadin, Abolfazl Mohebbi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
abstract: This paper presents an adaptive admittance control scheme that integrates an adaptive neural network (NN) algorithm as a shared autonomy framework to achieve the Assist-as-needed (AAN) property in robotic rehabilitation. The proposed algorithm enables real-time adjustment of control parameters based on human performance, without requiring extensive offline training. An energy-based performance index dynamically balances tracking accuracy with minimal robotic intervention to encourage active human participation. Furthermore, a modified virtual energy tank approach is introduced to preserve system passivity, preventing unsafe behaviors. Experimental results underscore the algorithm’s adaptability, ensuring compliant behavior as evidenced by a notable 83% reduction in average stiffness, reflecting a corresponding decrease in robotic intervention, due to detection of active human participation. Moreover, the algorithm ensures safe interaction and effective task completion. These findings highlight the framework’s potential for improving robotic rehabilitation by intelligently adapting to user needs and providing safety-aware control.

title: Exponential Stability of the Linearized Viscous Saint-Venant Equations Using a Quadratic Lyapunov Function
authors: Amaury Hayat, Nathan Lichtlé
abstract: In this work, we investigate the exponential stability of the viscous Saint-Venant equations by adding to the standard hyperbolic Saint-Venant equations a viscosity term coming from the higher order approximation of the Saint-Venant equations from Navier-Stokes equations. The inclusion of viscosity transforms these equations into more complex second-order partial differential equations, accurately modeling the behavior of real-world fluids that inherently possess viscosity. We construct an explicit quadratic Lyapunov function and demonstrate that it must be diagonal in physical coordinates, revealing that certain quadratic Lyapunov functions effective in non-viscous cases become inadequate when viscosity is introduced. We find explicit sufficient conditions on the parameters of the boundary conditions such that for small viscosities a quadratic Lyapunov function exists. This result ensures the exponential stability of the linearized system around the steady-state solutions in the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$L^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> norm.

title: Blind JPEG Artifacts Removal via Inverse JPEG Compression
authors: Shuai Liu, Binqiang Liu, Qingyu Mao, Jiacong Chen, Fanyang Meng, Yonghong Tian, Yongsheng Liang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Quantization and chroma downsampling are two primary operations that introduce distortions in the JPEG compression. However, most existing blind methods treat artifacts removal as a direct mapping from compressed images to clean ones. They fail to explicitly model the underlying degradation process or design targeted compensation mechanisms. As a result, these methods can only partially remove compression artifacts and struggle to generalize to diverse or unseen degradation scenarios. In this work, we present a novel perspective that formulates artifacts removal as an approximate inversion of the lossy steps in JPEG. Based on this view, we propose an Inverse JPEG Compression Network (IJCN), which aims to progressively compensate for quantization errors and color distortions. Specifically, we first design a Learnable Offset Guidance Module (LOGM) to approximate inverse quantization by modeling both intra-block and inter-block coefficient correlations for predicting rounding offsets. In addition, we propose a Quantization Table Guidance Module (QTGM) that leverages the quantization tables to guide the reconstruction network in mitigating color distortions. By modeling compensation mechanisms under the guidance of quantization tables, IJCN effectively eliminates artifacts across varying compression levels. Extensive experiments demonstrate that IJCN outperforms existing methods in both quantitative metrics and visual quality.
