title: KEYS: Keyframe Extraction and Yielding Summaries
authors: Diwash Poudel, Nitin Agarwal
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Efficient keyframe extraction is critical for effective video summarization and retrieval, yet capturing the complete richness of video content remains challenging. In this work, we present keyframe extraction and yeilding summaries (KEYS), a novel tri-modal framework that effectively integrates perceptual cues from color features in the CIELAB space, deep structural embeddings derived from ResNet-50, and semantic context from frame-level captions generated by Llama-3.2-11B-Vision-Instruct. By fusing these diverse modalities using principal component analysis, KEYS constructs robust multi-modal embeddings that enable adaptive segmentation of video content via HDBSCAN clustering. A subsequent refinement stage incorporating quality assessment and duplicate filtering ensures that the final keyframe set is both concise and semantically rich. Comprehensive evaluations on benchmark datasets TVSum20 and SumMe demonstrate that KEYS achieves state-of-the-art performance, substantially outperforming traditional unimodal and previous multi-modal methods. These results underscore KEYS's ability to capture nuanced visual and semantic information, thereby setting a new benchmark for video content understanding in large-scale retrieval scenarios.

title: Computational Creation of the Line of Operating Modes of Turbocharger of Modern Marine Diesel Engines
authors: Hristo Hristov, Hristo Milushev, Milen Bonev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The paper reveals a mathematical description of the processes in a turbocharger with a constant pressure turbine of a marine diesel engine. Turbocharger is investigated when changing the mode factors. The calculation method is indicated, i.e. the smallest deviations method. Standard assumptions are used to maintain the level of accuracy and to simplify the mathematical model.

title: Innovative Solution for Restoring Longitudinal Connectivity at Small Dams in the Context of Ecological Flow Implementation
authors: Cornel Ilinca, Madalina Ene, Valentin Minghiraș, Bogdan Ilinca
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This study presents an innovative technical solution for restoring longitudinal connectivity at small dams, funded by a National Research Grant (GnaC ARUST 2024-UTCB-21). The work addresses a critical gap in hydrotechnical design by proposing a hybrid fish passage that can operate under a variable ecological flow regime, as mandated by H.G.148/2020. This solution integrates a bypass system to guide fish around the dam, thereby ensuring the mobility and upstream migration of ichthyofauna. The design's primary objective is to maintain current velocities compatible with target species (trout, grayling, chub, etc.) across high, medium, and low hydrological regimes. This ensures the passage remains functional despite fluctuating reservoir levels, offering a comprehensive and efficient solution for modern ecological flow management. The research study resulted in the development of a hybrid fish passage structure, which ensures optimal parameters for longitudinal connectivity by integrating sequentially, a technical fish pass, a fish bypass tunnel, and an open fish bypass channel. The technical fish pass is equipped with side valves that can be individually opened to allow water inflow at various reservoir levels, a feature that directly addresses a major limitation of traditional fish passes.

title: Research on a Device for Rehabilitation of Knee and Hip Joints
authors: Marin Zhilevski, Mikho Mikhov, Georgi Pashkulski
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This article presents a passive rehabilitation device designed for knee and hip joint therapy. The system features a stepper motor-driven mechanical structure that allows precise and repeatable joint movement through a multi-link mechanism. A structured rehabilitation protocol, developed in collaboration with clinical specialists, guides the therapeutic process through four progressive phases. Computer modeling and simulation using the AnyBody Modeling System and MATLAB/Simulink software package validate the functional characteristics of the device, ensuring safety, accuracy, and adaptability to individual rehabilitation needs. The presented device successfully integrates mechanical precision, reliable control, and clinical adaptability to support postoperative recovery. The results confirm the potential of the developed system for clinical application in postoperative rehabilitation scenarios.

title: Modeling of Transparent Mesh Technology — Wideband Dispersion Model from Scattering Matrix
authors: Amira Merainani, Yann Mahe, Mohammed El Gibari, Tchanguiz Razban
abstract: In recent years, transparent technology has seen a significant advancement in hardware devices, accordingly, researchers are becoming increasingly interested in transparent and conductive materials, one key strategy in transparent technology is the use of mesh metallization, which balances transparency and high-frequency performance. This study proposes a new mathematical model that aims to accurately represent how the meshed microstrip line behaves at frequencies up to 40 GHz and model the dispersive behavior of the transmission line using analytical calculations. This work focuses on determining the equivalent line parameters, such as propagation constants, attenuation constants, and propagation mode dispersion, which are crucial for characterizing line performance across various operational frequencies. This involves extracting the measured scattering parameters of the transmission line and converting them to an equivalent Chain Matrix. This transformation process is based on specific equations that relate the elements of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S$</tex>-parameter matrix to those of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A B C D$</tex> matrix.

title: CMFS-UNet: A Mamba-UNet Model for Flood Mapping in Bitemporal and Dual-Polariziation SAR Imagery
authors: Yuxin Wei, Bin Liu
abstract: Efficient and accurate mapping of flooded areas is of great significance for emergency response and flood risk assessment. Satellite-based synthetic aperture radar (SAR) provides a data source for flood mapping with all-weather and day-and-night capabilities, as well as high spatial resolution and relatively high temporal resolution. This study addresses the challenges in accurate flood mapping by considering both local and global information, as well as maintaining low computational complexity in flood analysis from SAR imagery. To achieve these goals, we propose a deep learning model named CMFS-UNet, a CNN-based encoder-decoder architecture for extracting local image features, along with a Mamba-based encoder for integrating global information for flood mapping in dual-polarization Sentinel-1 SAR imagery. This model introduces two improvements: (1) a Vision Mamba module is integrated into the third layer of the encoder in a lightweight UNet with three skip connections, specifically designed to extract global features; and (2) residual connections are added to all convolutional layers to further enhance detail extraction, improve feature interaction, and facilitate the fusion of global and local information. The proposed CMFS-UNet is applied to a nationwide dataset of bitemporal and dual-polarization SAR imagery collected from 2015 to 2024 in Bangladesh. Experimental results indicate that the CMFS-UNet outperforms the existing and competitive models, including UNet, ResUNet, and TransUNet. Specifically, CMFS-UNet achieves the highest mIoU(79.41%), Accuracy (92.07%), and F1 score (81.23%) in different testing datasets, demonstrating its superior capability for feature extraction and information fusion while maintaining lower computational complexity, as evidenced by the 49.19 billion floating point operations (49.19 GFLOPs) required for a single batch of images during inference with one forward propagation. The proposed model thus provides an efficient and effective solution for flood detection using SAR imagery.

title: From Still Faces to Embodied Evaluation: a Multimodal Study of Behavioral, EEG, and Autonomic Stress Markers in Static vs. Dynamic Interview Contexts
authors: Michela Balconi, Katia Rovelli
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study examined how sensorimotor simulation modulates stress responses during digitally simulated job interviews. Participants were randomly assigned to either a dynamic version of the Realistic Evaluation and Appraisal of Cognitive sTress (REACT-D), featuring a realistic video-based evaluating committee, or a static version (REACT-S) with noninteractive facial images. During the interview preparation phase, behavioral performance (Stress regulation and Stress resistance scores), response times, EEG activity, and autonomic indices were recorded. The REACT-S group showed higher stress regulation scores, likely due to the reduced temporal and sensory complexity of the static condition. EEG analyses revealed decreased lowfrequency (delta, theta, alpha) activity and increased gamma power in the REACT-D group, indicating greater cognitive and attentional demands. Additionally, skin conductance response (SCR) was significantly higher in the REACT-D group, reflecting increased emotional engagement. These findings suggest that the degree of sensorimotor realism in digital social evaluation contexts differentially influences cognitive load, autonomic arousal, and regulatory efficiency.

title: Method of Moments-Based Scattering From Rough Surfaces Using High-Performance Parallel Implementations for Heterogeneous Computing Architectures
authors: P. Imperatore, F. Gregoretti, N. Pinel, M. Nisar, C. Bourlier, D. Romano, A. Iodice
abstract: Accurately predicting electromagnetic scattering from extensive ground profiles plays a crucial role in remote sensing applications; however, the associated computational cost of the inherent numerical techniques may become prohibitive. For computing the scattering from one-dimensional random rough surfaces, we developed distinct parallel implementations of the MoM-based solver targeted to different heterogeneous architectures, including (shared-memory) multicore CPUs and manycore GPUs, and (distributed memory) multinode architectures. For solving dense linear systems of equations in parallel with LU factorization on diverse heterogeneous architectures, we adopt state-of-the-art mathematical libraries developed in academia for numerical computation (such as PLASMA, MAGMA, and ScaLAPACK). The three selected libraries can somehow be considered parallel counterparts of the popular Linear Algebra PACKage (LAPACK) library. Representative case studies are explored, and inherent numerical results obtained by using the implemented solvers for diverse computing architectures are illustrated. The parallel performances achievable with the developed prototype solutions are also experimentally assessed and comparatively discussed, thus demonstrating inherent speedup and scalability. Therefore, the developed parallel prototypes enable the efficient use of the available degrees of parallelism to achieve faster solutions, explore scattering phenomena at higher resolutions, or simulate scattering from electrically large surfaces with greater fidelity. This investigation paves the way for the efficient computation of scattering from complex and layered structures in large-scale supercomputer simulations.

title: Targeting 100 Gbps Inter-Satellite Links: Mm-wave vs Free Space Optics
authors: X. Artiga
abstract: The objective of this work is to identify and compare available technologies meeting inter-satellite (ISL) link requirements of future low-Eart orbit (LEO) constellations. It first derives ISL requirements in terms of capacity and beam management, showing that 100 Gbps should be targeted. Then it analyzes available technologies, namely free space optics (FSO) and mm-wave at E- or D-band; and finally it compares them by means of link budget calculations and ISL data rate predictions.

title: Autonomous Amphibious Robot Attitude Detection Using Particle Filter
authors: Padmapriya Muthiah, Sri Suvetha Meenaa Subramanian, Shazmin Shajudeen, Jheel Shah, Senthil Pon Vignesh Subramanian, Jalaluddin Mohd Ansari Shajahan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel attitude estimation and detection algorithm for an Autonomous Amphibious Exploration Robot which operates both on land and in water. To achieve prior attitude estimation, the proposed system utilizes Particle Filtering (PF) instead of simple Kalman Filter (KF) or Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) or Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF). The fused data has been acquired from three major sensors accelerometer, magnetometer, and gyroscope. This collected data is often prone to errors due to rugged and marshy land terrain and complex underwater conditions. Unfortunately, this harsh environment is a non-linear system for the amphibious robot and may cause eccentric data deviations due to various natural factors in the operating environment and other data deviations due to the robot’s circuit interferences, and mechanical vibrations within the robot itself. Hence, for detection and compensation Gaussian based linear system filtering algorithm such as KF or EKF or UKF is not effective. Moreover, to validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm a simulation experiment is conducted on test bench in both stable and active state, and attitude detection is performed.

title: Machine learning model for prediction on skull’s landmarks.
authors: Ahmed Yousry, Nermeen Kashef, Ashraf Elsayed
publish: 2025 IEEE Global Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things (GCAIoT)
abstract: The Skull shape is a key step in many applications such as skull recognition, surgical planning, archaeology, education research. The main problem is locating the landmarks in their accurate place then finding the measurements in skull to recognize gender, predict population type, and predict landmarks placement. Most current research use 2D Computed Tomography (CT) image to locate landmarks in their place and that lead to less accuracy to calculate the cranial measurements. The aim of this research is to build an electronic medical assistance for calculating the cranial measurements based on accurate 3D coordinates that relies on meshgrid model which converts 2D skull’s medical image into 3D version. Based on the calculated measurements, traditional classifiers such as Random Forest classifier, logistic regression, Multi-layer Perceptron (MLP) and Support Vector Machines (SVM) to model for automatically predict gender and population type from the skull’s medical image. Furthermore, the suggested model can be used to detect accurate landmarks for new images to enhance the recognition accuracy. In comparing to a state-of-the-art works for gender recognition, the suggested model achieving 99.62 % accuracy in its prediction in comparison to highest previous work which achieved 96 %.

title: Assessment of Scalability and Resilience in Networks Based on the SCION Architecture
authors: Pavel Dzhunev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The SCION (Scalability, Control, and Isolation On Next-generation networks) architecture emerges as a promising alternative to the traditional Internet, offering significantly enhanced scalability and fault tolerance. This study analyzes SCION's mechanisms for hierarchical domain partitioning, controlled path selection, and cryptographic security, with the aim of critically evaluating its effectiveness compared to classical TCP/IP and BGP-based architectures. Through theoretical analysis and simulation modeling, this research demonstrates that SCION substantially enhances resilience by employing built-in path diversity and eliminating single points of failure. Furthermore, the architecture exhibits linear scalability of the control plane, surpassing the capabilities of BGP. The results support the hypothesis that SCION provides a viable foundation for next-generation Internet infrastructure, particularly in the context of increasing demands for security and reliability.

title: Multi RVM-Fuzzy Based Anticipatory System for Supporting Sustainable Nuclear Microreactor Powered Maritime Ports
authors: Miltiadis Alamaniotis
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: This paper envisions the maritime ports of the future, where the deployment of nuclear microreactors is technically feasible under strict regulatory frameworks. However, ensuring energy efficiency and financial sustainability requires not only regulatory compliance but also the optimal operation of these microreactors. In this context, artificial intelligence (AI) is expected to play a pivotal role by providing the tools necessary for managing reactor operation within smart maritime port environments. To this end, the paper proposes an intelligent system based on an anticipatory architecture designed to support optimal decision-making and efficient operation of a nuclear microreactor deployed at a maritime port. The system integrates learning Gaussian processes for predictive modeling and fuzzy logic inference for decision-making. Evaluation results on a set of simulated scenarios demonstrate the potential of microreactors to serve as integral components of the port's energy infrastructure. Furthermore, comparisons with a constant power output approach highlights the superior performance of the proposed intelligent system.

title: Enhancing Cyber Threat Intelligence Using Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)
authors: Sajjad Shaik, B P Vishwaksena Reddy, Valluri Keerthi Ram, K Ajay Nageswara Rao, Gokavarapu Abhay, M Prajjwal, B. Venkatesh
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: In the evolving landscape of cybersecurity, organizations often rely on large volumes of unstructured threat reports and forums to track emerging risks. However, the manual process of interpreting these texts is both time-consuming and error prone. This research introduces a practical framework that applies Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) to automatically identify hidden topics and patterns within cyber threat intelligence (CTI) datasets. The proposed system allows analysts to upload raw textual reports, which are preprocessed, tokenized, and analyzed in real-time. Visualization tools such as WordClouds and interactive topic maps are employed to present threat clusters in an intuitive format. The results demonstrate that LDA can effectively extract coherent topics related to common attack vectors, malware behavior, and infrastructure vulnerabilities. This approach enhances situational awareness, reduces dependency on manual tagging, and lays the groundwork for automated threat triage systems.

title: Cognitive Effort and User Experience in Real-Life Assembly Tasks: a Comparison of Human Alone, Human-Human, and Human-Robot Interactions
authors: Flavia Ciminaghi, Roberta A. Allegretta, Michela Balconi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The present study investigated the impact of collaborative robots (cobots) on perceived mental workload, user experience, and emotional responses during a realistic industrial assembly task. Forty young adults completed the task in three conditions: working alone (Human Alone, HA), collaborating with a human co-worker (Human-Human, HH), and collaborating with a cobot (Human-Robot, HR). Subjective measures were collected using the NASA-TLX, the User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ), and the Self-Assessment Manikin (SAM). Results showed that both collaborative conditions (HH and HR) significantly reduced perceived workload compared to the HA condition, with the cobot particularly effective in lowering mental demand and effort. The HR condition also led to higher ratings of attractiveness, stimulation, and originality, along with greater emotional engagement. These effects remained significant when controlling for prior familiarity with cobots, suggesting that cobots can offer both functional and experiential advantages in collaborative work. The findings highlight the potential of cobots to enhance not only performance but also engagement and emotional experience in human-robot interactions.

title: Intelligent Hybrid Wireless Communication for Management of Cattle Breeding System via FSO/RF
authors: Tsvetan Valkovski, Ivaylo Nachev, Iliyan Damyanov, Durhan Saliev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This article presents a designed model of a hybrid optical wireless and radio communication system for managing livestock farming systems. The possibilities for reliability of the communication link in the designed system, possibilities for adding new functionalities and flexibility of the proposed solutions are considered. Such a type of system is applicable for building both communication links between individual units in such a system, and for building a complex communication system including live monitoring, data storage in a data center, data processing, analysis, and results output. The future development of such a system is the integration of artificial intelligence and adaptive deep neural networks for processing results and predicting events. This would be of enormous benefit to the users of the system, as well as to the quality of livestock farming.

title: Analyzing Skin Cancer Datasets for Early Detection Using Deep Learning
authors: Amruta Thorat, Chaya R. Jadhav
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The current research explores the use of DL models, such as CNNs and transfer learning, to improve skin cancer detection on datasets such as HAM10000, ISIC, and Malignant and benign skin cancer images. Image preprocessing, data augmentation, and advanced architectures (e.g., VGG16, InceptionV3, Xception) all showed high accuracy, with Xception obtaining 90.91 % validation accuracy on the ISIC 2020 dataset. DL approaches outperformed traditional ML models in collecting complicated patterns and improving diagnostic precision. Future work will address difficulties such as dataset imbalance and clinical validation, with the goal of creating scalable, cost- effective AI tools for early diagnosis and better patient outcomes.

title: Edge-Based Audio Emotion Detection Using STM32 and Nanoedge AI
authors: Nutan V. Bansode, Nurish Shaikh, Janhavi Kawadkar, Sunil Tade, Sonali Sawant, Prachi R. Rajarapollu, Nagesh A. Patil
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: This paper introduces STM32Emotion, a real-time audio-based emotion detection system developed on the STM32 microcontroller platform using NanoEdge AI Studio. The system classifies four core emotions such as happiness, sadness, anger, and neutrality by processing speech input captured through a MEMS microphone. Initial model outputs on raw data showed limited accuracy, which was significantly improved through audio preprocessing techniques such as normalization and filtering. The optimized model was deployed on the STM32, achieving low-latency inference with minimal resource usage. This work demonstrates the feasibility of deploying affective computing solutions on cost-effective embedded hardware for applications in IoT, smart wearable's, and human-computer interaction

title: TransBioRetro: A Transformer-Based Self Correcting Beam Search Framework for Bio Retrosynthesis Prediction
authors: Suyash Utekar, Pranav Pillai, Aditya Randive, Varsha Patil
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: By utilizing enzyme-mediated modifications, bio retrosynthesis offers a reasonable, maintainable, and organically primarily based method of creating target particles as an optional to routine natural blend. This technique features a parcel of guarantee for utilize in regions like prescription drugs, strong point chemical compounds, and biofuels. In any case, problems like response versatility, vague product-precursor intuitive, and a want of excessive best biochemical response records confine its greater great appropriateness. A transformer-based totally retrosynthesis show, contrastive learning, recursive multi-step questioning, and a modern self-corrected bar appearance device are all mixed in our crossover profound studying gadget to triumph over these downsides. The strong scope of enzymatic and ordinary object modifications is made plausible via the coaching of the model on a cautiously chosen dataset that consolidates each biosynthetic and herbal responses from KEGG, MetaCyc, MetaNetX, and USPTO-NPL assets. A contrastive goal primarily based on the NT-Xent misfortune boosts the version's ability to distinguish authentic precursor-product combinations from chemically implausible ones. while the recursive multi-step retrosynthesis method breaks down target atoms into acknowledged bio-constructing portions, the self-correcting bar appearance powerfully re-ranks candidates primarily based on learnt trade embeddings amid deduction. The invalid Grins charge, top-N exactness, and BLEU score are applied to very well compare the version's execution, and all of them illustrate apparent alternatives over fashionable techniques. via bridging the hollow among AI-pushed questioning and usual retrosynthetic cause, this research progresses robotized bioretrosynthesis' versatility and steadfastness.

title: Inspection of steel elements using electromagnetic induction: A finite elements study
authors: Miguel Angel García
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study presents a finite element method (FEM) analysis aimed at detecting inhomogeneities in steel components using electromagnetic induction techniques. The results obtained are consistent with previous experimental studies and analytical models, while also providing significant complementary insights. Notably, the application of FEM enables detailed mapping of the electromagnetic field distributions involved in the induction process, even in complex geometries, an advantage not afforded by conventional analytical models. The findings demonstrate the method’s capability to detect stress levels well below the material’s elastic limit, as well as the presence of microcracks. This early detection capability is crucial for preventing mechanical failure in the analyzed components.

title: Empowering Student Skill Development in Robotics Through Autonomous Research Engagement
authors: Christopher R. Hudson, Jessie E. Cossitt, Daniel W. Carruth
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Robotics, automation, and artificial intelligence are rapidly transforming the modern workforce, drawing increasing interest from students across disciplines. To prepare students for this evolving landscape, Mississippi State University has adopted a research-driven, project-based learning model that goes beyond traditional classroom instruction. This approach emphasizes active engagement through hands-on projects that cultivate industry-relevant technical skills. By introducing students to core Robot Operating System (ROS) libraries, the industry standard for developing autonomous systems, we provide them with the foundational tools needed to tackle real-world challenges. This paper presents key outcomes from two representative projects: a classroom interface initiative where student teams develop deployable control systems for autonomous platforms and a RC car-based project where students implement robust localization algorithms using LiDAR sensor data. These projects not only reinforce theoretical knowledge but also bridge the gap between academic learning and industrial practice, equipping students with the tools to thrive in a technology-driven future.

title: Design of a SECaaS Service in a Private Cloud
authors: Pavel Segeč, Jana Uramová, Peter Tanuška
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Cloud computing offers flexibility but raises critical security challenges. This paper presents a methodology for implementing Security as a Service (SECaaS) in a private OpenStack cloud. Combining theoretical analysis with a proof-of-concept deployment, the study demonstrates benefits, risks, and applicability of SECaaS for academic and research environments.

title: Optimizing Photovoltaic Performance: A Comparative Analysis of XGBoost and Gradient Boosting for MPPT
authors: Rida Amine, Nouredine El Barbri, Hatim Ameziane
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: This work compares Gradient Boosting Regression (GBR) and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) for MPPT in PV systems. Both models were implemented and trained with three years of temperature and irradiance data available at NASA to predict the optimal maximum power point voltage (Vmp). The models developed were put to the test in MATLAB/Simulink. Experimental results showed that GBR achieved a power conversion efficiency of 95.7% under AM 1.5 irradiance (1000 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>), which was much higher than XGBoost of 73.5%.In addition, the accuracy of GBR was better than that of XGBoost (MAE = 0.18888) and presented higher robustness and more rapid convergence speed in the rapid fluctuation of irradiance. These results demonstrate the performance of GBR in real-time MPPT and the benefits of using ensemble learning strategies in intelligent solar energy harvesting.

authors: N/A

title: Intelligent Fault Diagnosis Method for Rotating Machines Using Multi-Kernel Size 1D-DCNN with Convolutional Block Attention Module
authors: Temesgen Tadesse Feisa, Hailu Shimels Gebremedhen, Fasikaw Kibrete, Dereje Engida Woldemichael, Getachew Getu Enyew, Samuel Gizachew Alamirew
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: Recently, deep learning methods have achieved great success in the intelligent fault diagnosis of rotating machinery. Of these, one-dimensional deep convolutional neural networks (1D-DCNNs) often perform very well in analyzing vibration signals, especially when there is abundant data and balanced health conditions. However, in practical applications, there is limited data, making 1D-DCNN models either too deep, leading to overfitting, or too shallow to extract meaningful features. Additionally, fixed-size filters cannot allow the model to capture adaptively diverse and critical patterns. Furthermore, most of them have some flaws in mining rich multi-scale features and are prone to being affected by noise and redundancy. To this end, a novel multi-kernel size 1D-DCNN combined with a Convolutional Block Attention Module, called MKS-1D-DCNN-CBAM, for fault diagnosis in rotating machines is developed. The highlights of the contributions of this framework include: (1) MKS convolution blocks-adopt a broad range of temporal scales, featuring concurrently both small and large kernel sizes to enlarge the effective receptive field; (2) CBAM is conducted after each block to highlight the most informative features; and (3) integrated batch normalization and dropout for each block to improve training stability and convergence, and mitigate overfitting. The experimental verification using the Case Western Reserve University motor dataset proved that the presented framework performed better than the existing techniques. The respective diagnostic accuracies of 100%, 99.92%, 100%, and 100% have been achieved under various loads (0-3hp), respectively. These results reflect the reliability and robustness of the model, hence showing significant progress in this domain.

title: Mapping Underground Moisture: Insights from Drone-Borne SAR System in UAE
authors: L. P. Oliveira, Jarrah Hammadi, T. Prabowo, L. S. Bins, Gian C. Oré, J. R. Moreira Neto, M. Almansoori, F. Vega
abstract: This paper explores the application of three-band Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) systems for mapping and measuring underground gravimetric soil moisture. Conducted in Remah, UAE, the research employed drone-borne SAR with P, L, and C bands to generate underground soil moisture maps. The experiment involved two stages of irrigation with controlled water volumes, enabling the detection of subsurface moisture distribution changes at depths up to 4 meters. The results confirmed that SAR technology can accurately detect and quantify soil moisture variations in both surface and subsurface layers. This marks the first successful measurement of underground gravimetric soil moisture using SAR. The study emphasizes the potential of SAR systems for applications such as water resource management, underground leakage detection, and real-time soil monitoring.

title: Reuniting Data, Processes, and Forms: Petriflow Object-Centric Processes in the Age of AI
authors: Gabriel Juhás, Milan Mladoniczky, Juraj Mažári, Tomáš Kováčik, Luboš Petrovič, Jakub Kovář
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: For decades, enterprise information systems have been designed around separation into layers - data models are defined independently of business processes, and user interfaces are treated as an afterthought. Yet in business reality, these dimensions are inseparable: a business object is not a static collection of attributes, but an evolving entity whose identity, behavior, and representation form one holistic whole. This gap between how business understands reality and how IT models it has created what may be called the Great Divide of digital design. This paper explores Object-Centric Processes (OCP) as a paradigm that reunites data, processes, and forms into a single coherent model of business reality. By treating objects as both carriers of information and drivers of behavior, OCP provides a natural bridge between conceptual understanding and executable system design. We illustrate this approach through the Petriflow language, which captures the state, lifecycle, and interactions of business objects in an integrated, model-driven way.

title: Thermal Imaging as a Tool in Technical Education and Applied Engineering
authors: Ružena Králiková, Ervin Lumnitzer, Valéria Eiben, Elena Lukáč-Jurgovská
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Modern technical education demands progressive methodologies that empower students not only to grasp theoretical concepts but also to apply them in practical contexts. Among the effective instruments, supporting this shift is the thermographic infrared (IR) camera, which enables real-time visualization of thermal phenomena. Its integration into the teaching of mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, and materials science transforms traditional instruction into a more interactive, demonstrative, and engaging experience. This paper explores the technological capabilities, core functions, and diverse applications of thermography across multiple disciplines. Special emphasis is placed on its educational potential — highlighting how thermal imaging can enrich the learning process, foster deeper understanding, and inspire innovation in the technical field.

title: Experience with the Emerging TSN Technology and Its Implementation in Education
authors: Peter Drahoš, Igor Bélai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Time-Sensitive Networking (TSN) represents a cutting-edge and rapidly advancing approach to communication networks, enabling precise synchronization, ultra-low latency, and high data throughput. This contribution offers a concise, yet comprehensive overview of TSN principles, the relevant standards, and the range of available hardware and software platforms for both TSN device development and educational purposes. To support research and training activities, the authors have designed and assembled a dedicated TSN workstation using commercially available components. The workstation facilitates experimental validation of TSN features under real-world conditions. The paper details the architecture of the workstation, outlines the configuration process for individual components, and discusses the key findings obtained from experimental evaluations.

title: Design and Conceptual Framework of ARGOS: An AI-Assisted System for Managing Georeferenced Environmental Surveys using UAS
authors: Gala Avvisati, Enrica Marotta, Gabriele Rossi, Orazio Colucci, Filippo Marotta, Francesco Maria La Marca, Romano Antonio Pescione, Giovanni Torre
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper introduces the conceptual design of ARGOS (Advanced Retrieval of Georeferenced Observational Surveys), an AI-assisted framework for managing, analysing, and querying environmental data acquired by Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS). ARGOS is being developed to address the current lack of integrated systems capable of indexing, interpreting, and retrieving large volumes of heterogeneous, georeferenced drone imagery in a traceable and intelligent manner. Building on a robust scientific and technical foundation, the proposed architecture includes a modular Data Management System (DMS), a metadata tagging and classification protocol, and a multi-agent AI validation layer interacting with non-proprietary large language models (LLMs). The system design prioritizes explainability, interoperability, and long-term scalability. Although still in the early development phase, ARGOS is structured to support future applications such as anomaly detection and environmental change tracking by combining structured data organization through its internal DMS, intelligent metadata tagging, explainable AI-based querying via external LLMs, and real-time multi-agent consistency checks. These components are designed to operate across diverse spatial and temporal datasets, enabling advanced analysis and transparent knowledge extraction in geophysical and environmental monitoring contexts.

title: Multi-Slots Loaded Planar Antenna for Wideband Millimeter-Wave Applications
authors: Saad Hassan Kiani, Umair Rafique, Hisham Khalil, Shobit Agarwal, Syed Muzahir Abbas
abstract: This paper presents the design of a planar monopole antenna for millimeter-wave (mm-wave) wireless communication applications. The designed antenna consists of a modified patch radiator and a partial ground plane with a square notch. The modification in the patch radiator is done by etching multiple slots that tend to generate higher-order resonant modes, ultimately enhancing the bandwidth and gain of the antenna. The partial ground plane with a notch is used to achieve maximum impedance matching in the frequency band of interest. It is noted from the simulation results that the proposed planar antenna is able to resonate well from 25.37 to 29.91 GHz, while the gain of the antenna varies in the range of 2.7-4.6 dBi. On the basis of the results, it is worth mentioning that the proposed antenna is a suitable candidate for mm -wave wireless communication applications.

title: Design and performance evaluation of a high-gain seven-level inverter with low spike current
authors: Ravi Anand, Rajib Kumar Mandal, S P Daniel Chowdhury
abstract: The escalating integration of renewable energy systems has amplified the demand for advanced multilevel inverter (MLI) topologies capable of delivering enhanced performance with reduced electromagnetic interference and power losses. Conventional two-level and three-level inverters often suffer from inherent limitations such as high output current ripple, elevated voltage stress across semiconductor devices, and significant switching losses. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel seven-level switched-capacitor (SC) MLI topology, comprising eight power switches, two self-balancing switched capacitors, two inductors strategically placed to mitigate inrush and charging current spikes, and three unidirectional diodes facilitating triple voltage boosting capability without the need for magnetic elements or complex auxiliary balancing circuits. The proposed topology eliminates the requirement for isolated DC sources or bidirectional switches, thereby simplifying the control and enhancing modularity. The operational principle, switching strategy, and voltage boosting mechanism are analytically described. Simulation studies are conducted in MAT-LAB/Simulink environments to evaluate the inverter’s steady-state and dynamic performance under varying load conditions. The simulation results demonstrate its suitability for medium-power renewable energy applications such as photovoltaic and wind energy conversion systems.

title: Performance Improvement of Long Reach Optical Access Systems Using Hybrid Optical Amplifiers
authors: Shreyas Srinivas Rangan, Jurgis Porins, Toms Salgals
abstract: Long Reach Optical Access Networks (LROANs) are emerging as a promising solution to meet the growing demand for high-capacity, cost-effective, and energy-efficient broadband services. However, the extension of optical reach beyond conventional limits introduces challenges such as signal attenuation, nonlinear impairments, and amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) noise. To overcome these challenges, this paper explores an advanced approach that enhances the performance of LROANs by utilizing Hybrid Optical Amplifiers (HOAs), which combine the benefits of different amplification technologies to optimize signal quality over extended distances. Among the commonly used optical amplifiers, the Erbium-Doped Fiber Amplifier (EDFA) stands out for its high gain and low noise figure (NF); however, its operational bandwidth is restricted (e.g., C/L-band), limiting its applicability in wavelength-diverse systems. Raman Fiber Amplifiers (RFAs) offer a broader amplification spectrum, making them an attractive solution for enhancing signal quality and extending transmission reach across a broader range of wavelengths - a compelling solution for long-haul optical networks. The proposed HOA solution leverages the complementary gain characteristics of both EDFA and RFA to achieve superior performance across a wide range of wavelengths. An experimental model of HOA is tested in different conditions using a 4-channel non-return-to-zero (NRZ) modulated wavelength division multiplexing (WDM) transmission system where bit-errorrate (BER) quality below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \times 10^{-9}$</tex> is used as a threshold. A comprehensive performance evaluation is conducted through numerical mathematical simulations analyzing key parameters such as signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), bit error rate (BER), and optical power budget. The results demonstrate that the hybrid HOA amplification scheme enhances transmission reach and improves overall system reliability compared to single-amplifier configurations. This work highlights the potential of hybrid amplification techniques in optimizing next-generation optical access networks, ensuring efficient and scalable broadband connectivity.

title: Analysis of tree sway response to wind conditions using low-cost sensor system
authors: Peter Kolok, Ján Šumský, Miroslav Chochul, Maxime Hell
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This work presents the development of a low-cost embedded system for acquiring and visualizing environmental and motion data at a local scale. The setup collects multi-axis measurements in real time and stores them for subsequent analysis. A visualization tool was implemented to render the sensor’s orientation and movements in three dimensions, allowing intuitive observation of dynamic behavior. The proposed approach demonstrates how affordable embedded platforms and open-source software can be combined to create a portable and flexible monitoring solution. The system highlights the potential of low-cost sensing for applications such as educational tools, structural monitoring, and lightweight data acquisition.

title: CulturalWaveNet: A Multi-Dimensional Media Risk Propagation and Prediction Model for Cultural Changes in Global Audiences
authors: Linman Deng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Society, Information Science and Risk Management (ICDIR)
abstract: With the accelerated advancement of global digitalization, risk prediction in cross-cultural media communication has become a critical technical challenge for maintaining international harmony and social stability. This paper proposes Cultural-WaveNet, a multi-dimensional media risk propagation prediction model that integrates deep learning and graph neural networks, specifically designed for modeling and analyzing cultural changes in global audiences. The model innovatively constructs a four-dimensional feature fusion architecture, including semantic understanding, sentiment analysis, propagation dynamics, and cultural adaptability features, and models complex associative relationships among cultural groups through heterogeneous graph neural networks. The model employs a multi-scale time-aware attention mechanism to achieve precise prediction of media risks across different time spans. Experimental results on three large-scale cross-cultural datasets show that CulturalWaveNet achieves a prediction accuracy of 87.243%, representing a 15.726% improvement over the optimal baseline method, with an F1 score of 0.854 and an AUC value of 0.923. Ablation experiments confirm the effectiveness of each component, particularly the cultural feature dimension contributes 6.789% to performance improvement. This research provides a new theoretical framework and technical pathway for cross-cultural media risk management.

title: Research on the construction of evaluation model of digital village construction development under data mining technology
authors: Li Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Society, Information Science and Risk Management (ICDIR)
abstract: In order to improve the evaluation accuracy of the development level of digital village construction, a composite evaluation system integrating multi-core support vector model and convolutional neural network is constructed, and 9,822 pieces of rural development data of the past five years from 31 provincial-level administrative districts across the country are modeled and analyzed, covering 12 types of indexes, such as agricultural e-commerce activeness, broadband access rate, and online governmental services. The study screens seven key feature variables based on PCA, introduces a dynamic gating mechanism to regulate the time-series fluctuations, and adopts five-fold cross-validation to assess the model performance. The results show that under the combination of RBF and linear kernel, the RMSE is as low as 3.43 and the MAPE is 7.12%, and the dynamic RMSE fluctuation is reduced to ±0.21 when the gating threshold is increased to 0.7, and the error variance is controlled at 0.074, which demonstrates strong fitting stability and the ability of adapting to non-stationary data.

title: C6-DataLog: An ESP32-C6 Data Logger for IoT Research
authors: Tomáš Bača, Andrej Tupý, Jan Šumský, Lukáš Čechovič
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Recent years have seen a rapid expansion of Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices. Everyday objects can now sense, communicate, and actuate within their environments. In our department’s research, focused on energy management and wireless communication, we repeatedly faced a practical gap during design, characterization, and field trials, researchers need a flexible way to read a wide assortment of sensors (with mixed bus interfaces) and store the data locally or send it to other devices for analysis. To address this, we developed a low-power ESP32-C6–based data logger that integrates wireless communication over WiFi and Bluetooth, MicroSD storage, ADC inputs, digital inputs, I2C and UART with low-power modes. We describe the hardware architecture, implemented features, and possible extensions of this device.

title: The Impact of Increasing Renewable Penetration on Dutch Electricity Imbalance Markets
authors: M. Fevzi Ustundag, Johan Morren, Wouter Van Den Akker, Anne van der Molen, Shima Mousavi Gargari
abstract: The rapid integration of variable renewable energy (VRE) poses a challenge to grid balancing. This study analyzes the impact of substantial VRE growth on the Dutch electricity imbalance market. The results show significant upward trends in absolute imbalance volumes, which are strongly correlated with VRE expansion. Hourly imbalance patterns intensified, particularly during VRE-driven midday peaks. While total monthly activated automatic frequency restoration reserve energy trends were weak, transmission system operator interventions became significantly more frequent, with reduced system stability and increased intra-imbalance settlement period volatility. Economically, dispatch price volatility increased significantly and asymmetrically: upward volatility rose dramatically, correlating almost perfectly with annual VRE growth, while downward volatility increased moderately. The results confirm that VRE expansion heightens the operational and economic burden on the imbalance market, increasing deviation magnitudes, intervention frequency, and price volatility. This underscores the critical need for enhanced forecasting, diverse system flexibility and generation mix, adaptive market mechanisms, and more dynamic operational strategies to manage high-VRE systems effectively.

title: Assessing the trustworthiness of LLMs in Slovak in terms of truthfulness and robustness
authors: Miroslava Matejová, Ján Paralič, Ulada Dalidovich
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are becoming increasingly popular and are used in many areas. The aim of this study is to evaluate the level of trustworthiness of these models when used in the Slovak language. An analysis of existing works helped to find the most appropriate approach to trustworthiness testing. The selection of trustworthiness criteria was based on the results of a survey focused on the attitudes of Slovak-speaking users. For testing, an auxiliary application was created to process datasets, interact with LLMs, and evaluate responses. The testing results were analyzed and dependencies between model parameters and their trustworthiness were identified.

title: Electric Field Analysis in XLPE Underground Cables using Finite Element Method
authors: Antonios K. Sartzetakis, Vassiliki T. Kontargyri, Eleni P. Nicolopoulou, Christos A. Christodoulou, Alexis Polycarpou
abstract: High voltage cables used for the transmission of electrical energy must be designed based on specific criteria to ensure their reliability for uninterrupted power delivery and to extend their service life. In the present study, the operation of underground cables embedded in rocky soil is simulated. These cables are arranged in different topologies and are subjected to specific voltage levels. The aim of this work is to analyse and simulate the electric potential and the electric field within the insulation in order to investigate the stress levels experienced by the insulating layers. Additionally, the study explores the impact of the presence of combined defects in the cable on the distortion of the electric field and electric potential within the insulating layers, with particular focus on the XLPE insulation. The results of each case study were obtained using the Finite Element Method (FEM) through the FEMM software, by applying the electrostatic analysis equation.

title: Recent Progresses of Mid-Infrared Solid-State Lasers Directly-Pumped by LDs
authors: Jiawei Guo, Xinyang Wu, Jia Cheng, Xinyu Wang, Juhong Han, He Cai, Dongdong Wang, Jiao Yang, Di Song, Jiaqi Wang, Shuyan Song, You Wang
abstract: LD directly-pumped solid-state lasers offer some obvious advantages, including simple operation, compact size, and streamlined structure. These characteristics are particularly beneficial for the applications of a solid-state laser in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \sim 5 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> wavelength region. However, when compared to conventional near-infrared LD-pumped solid-state lasers, LD directly-pumped mid-infrared (MIR) solid-state lasers exhibit a much larger quantum defect, resulting in terrible heat generation. Consequently, the outputted laser power is constrained by thermal effects during the high-power pumping and they are susceptible to thermal damage of the laser crystal. To address these challenges, some important improvements are presented in this paper from following two aspects: 1) Expeimental evaluation has been undertaken by using the short crystal length and the high pump pulse width of tranditional Ho:BYF media; 2) Verification results of destructive experiments have been obtained by utilizing the new-developed Ho:BYLF crystals as an alternative to the trandional Ho:BYF crystals. It has been demonstrated that the single-pulse energy as high as 48.8 mJ has been achieved for Ho:BYF crystals with the length reduced to 2 mm under the conditions of the repetition rate of 2 Hz and the pulse width of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$600 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex>, respectively. It has been believed that our result should be the highest output energy of mid-infrared solid-state lasers directly-pumped by LDs in the world until now. Additionally, our experiments also confirmed that Ho:BYLF crystals exhibit the superior resistance to thermal damage by comparing to Ho:BYF crystals while maintaining similar laser output performance and spectral characteristics. These findings should provide some valuable insights for further increasing the output power of LD directly-pumped mid-infrared solid-state lasers.

title: Design and Validation of Battery Management Subsystems for High-Performance EV Batteries: A Tesla Model S Case Study
authors: Omar Altahawi, Mohamed Darwish
abstract: This article presents the creation of a simulation environment for a Battery Management System (BMS) using SIMULINK. The environment is then paired with a Tesla Model S battery, and the BMS is simulated under different conditions to test the BMS algorithms. The simulation covers core BMS functions such as State of Charge (SOC), charging control, thermal management, State of Health (SOH), and Controller Area Network (CAN) communication, while prioritising battery safety and minimising user risk. The system was tested under various conditions, and the results confirmed the ability of the system to respond as expected, meeting the design objectives.

title: Application of Innovations and Innovative Technologies in the Educational Process - Microlearning
authors: Marcel Behun, Annamaria Behunova, Lucia Ševčíková, Filip Glova, Matus Pohorenec, Vladislav Vavrak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: The presented manuscript deals with the implementation of innovations and innovative technologies through microlearning in the educational process. This research aimed to explore the potential of using this method as an effective tool for enhancing education. The manuscript analyses the theoretical foundations of microlearning, its advantages and challenges, and suggests a specific application in a subject focused on the logistics of service processes within an enterprise. The comparison is based on a comparison of traditional educational methods and microlearning, while monitoring the effectiveness of learning and the practical application of acquired knowledge. Based on the analysis, the main benefits were identified - flexibility of learning, rapid acquisition of practical skills, and a high level of student involvement. At the same time, the research highlights limitations such as the risk of superficial learning and the necessity for regular content updates. The research results can serve as a basis for the introduction of modern educational approaches in secondary schools and universities.

title: Whisper Finetuning on Nepali Language
authors: Sanjay Rijal, Shital Adhikari, Manish Dahal, Manish Awale, Vaghawan Ojha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Despite advancements in ASR models, developing robust models for underrepresented languages like Nepali remains a challenge. Our work focuses on making a comprehensive dataset and finetuning OpenAI’s Whisper models to improve transcription accuracy on the Nepali language, which can be scaled to other low-resourced languages as well. We leverage publicly available and self-recorded datasets with diverse accents, dialects, and speaking styles, enriched through augmentation. Fine-tuning Whisper models on our dataset reduces WER across all model sizes, thanks to variations in the speaker’s age, gender, sentiment, acoustic environment, dialect, and denser audio segments (15-30 seconds) compatible with Whisper’s input. Our approach outperforms Whisper’s baseline models trained on Fleur’s dataset, with our custom dataset being closer to real-world audio recordings. This highlights the importance of dataset quality, variation, and augmentation for ASR in underrepresented languages.

title: Real-Time Radio Refractivity Estimation Using the Differentiable Split-Step Fourier Parabolic Equation
authors: M. S. Lytaev
abstract: A functional minimization problem with respect to the refractive index is posed. The functional to be minimized compares the solution to the forward problem with measured electromagnetic field data at the receivers. The forward problem is solved using the split-step Fourier method for the parabolic wave equation. This method is represented as a computational graph. By applying the automatic differentiation method to the computational graph, the gradient of the objective functional with respect to the refractive index can be efficiently computed. This gradient is used to find the optimal solution. The refractive index is represented as a multilayer perceptron. The proposed method is implemented in Python 3 using the JAX automatic differentiation framework. Unlike the variational adjoint approach, proposed method computes the gradient directly from the numerical scheme code, eliminating the need for a separate solution of the adjoint equation. Numerical experiments were conducted for typical refractive index profiles and irregular terrain. It was shown that the proposed method can be used for real-time tracking of variations in the tropospheric refractive index.

title: A Three-Level Abstraction Approach to Data Structures Education : From Library Principles to Undergraduate Curriculum Design
authors: Michal Varga, Michal Mrena, Miroslav Kvassay
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper presents a new approach to teaching data structures. It uses a three-level design that gradually guides students from memory management (type encoding and low-level memory operations) through memory arrangements (sequential, hierarchical, and networked, without considering data types) to abstract data types (arrays, lists, priority queues, and tables). A course structured in this way allows knowledge to be built up progressively in logically complete units. In addition, the three-level design of the data structures library supports the correct use of object-oriented programming and its advanced techniques (such as working with templates or multiple inheritance). Since courses on data structures are typically subsequent to courses focused on programming, using the proposed design shows good practice of how techniques learned before can be properly adapted when designing robust libraries.

title: Design of a Gain-Enhanced AMC-Backed Coplanar Waveguide Microstrip Antenna Array for X-Band Applications
authors: Lakshman Pappula, Venkata Kishore Kothapudi, T. P. S. Kumar Kusumanchi, Srinu Budumuru
abstract: This research article presents the design, optimization, and performance evaluation of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \times 3$</tex> Artificial Magnetic Conductor (AMC)-backed Co-planar Waveguide (CPW) microstrip antenna array, with the primary objective of achieving substantial gain improvements tailored for X-band applications. The antenna architecture comprises three square-shaped patches with I-slots, designed in a series-fed grouping alongside discrete grounding and a CPW feedline. Each unit cell of the AMC contains three anchor-shaped arms strategically designed to enhance radiation characteristics with high gain. The reported array dimensions are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 ~\text{mm} \times 80 ~\text{mm} \times 3.82 ~\text{mm}$</tex>, with electrical measurements of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.5 \lambda \times 2 \lambda \times 0.1 \lambda$</tex>. At 8.27 GHz, the antenna array produced observed gain values of 11.7 dB. The front-to-back ratio (FTBR) evaluation showed values of 14.5. The antenna integrated with an AMC structure demonstrates the effectiveness at X-band application with enhanced gain.

title: Green Entrepreneurship in Agriculture: Leveraging Energy Efficiency for Competitive Advantage
authors: Tsanka Zlateva-Petkova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The transition towards sustainable agriculture necessitates innovative entrepreneurial approaches that prioritize energy efficiency and environmental responsibility. This paper explores the role of green entrepreneurship in enhancing the competitive advantage of agricultural enterprises through the adoption of energy-efficient technologies and business models. Drawing upon recent literature and best practices, the study highlights how renewable energy integration, digitalization, and strategic resource management contribute not only to cost reduction but also to value creation and market differentiation. The analysis emphasizes that combining engineering solutions with entrepreneurial thinking fosters resilience, compliance with ESG criteria, and long-term growth in the agri-food sector. Key recommendations are offered for policymakers and practitioners seeking to promote green innovation and sustainable energy transformation in agricultural systems.

title: Low-Profile Ultra-Wideband Tightly Coupled Dipole Array Antenna Based on Artificial Magnetic Conductor
authors: Xiao Gao, Quanyuan Feng, Yan Wen, Yurong Sun, Haoxuan Sheng
abstract: In this paper, a low-profile, ultra-wideband tightly coupled dipole antenna array (TCDA) is presented, which utilizes an artificial magnetic conductor (AMC) with a magnetic medium. Unlike conventional TCDAs, the AMC structure is positioned beneath the dipole antennas, replacing the traditional ground plane. This novel configuration enables the proposed array to maintain ultra-wideband characteristics and excellent radiation performance, while achieving a low-profile. The array consists of tightly coupled dipoles and Marchand baluns, which serves as an impedance transformer. This balun effectively transforms the impedance from 100Ω to 50Ω over a broad frequency range, with the impedance transformation line folded within the balun to minimize the height of the array. This design enables the feeding network to operate efficiently across a wide bandwidth with high conversion efficiency. The antenna array is capable of wide-angle scanning, with a frequency range from 1.38 GHz to 3.97 GHz, and supports <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 60^{\circ}$</tex> scanning in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E$</tex>-plane and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 45^{\circ}$</tex> scanning in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$H$</tex>-plane. Experimental results demonstrate that the array achieves stable performance with a Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR) of less than 3 across the entire operational frequency band. Additionally, the array exhibits good directionality and low back lobes in both the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E$</tex>-plane and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$H$</tex>-plane scans, maintaining a stable beam pattern throughout. The excellent low-profile performance of the designed antenna makes it particularly well-suited for conformal integration, which is ideal for applications on airborne and missile platforms, where space constraints are critical. The proposed TCDA antenna combines compactness with wideband and high-efficiency characteristics, offering a promising solution for modern communication systems.

title: Perturbation-based Deep Learning Reveals Dynamic Spatiotemporal Shifts in Pediatric Brain Development from CT Imaging
authors: Fubuki Sawa, Naoya Takashima, Saya Ando, Naomi Yagi, Kumiko Ando, Reiichi Ishikura, Syoji Kobashi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Understanding pediatric brain maturation is essential for detecting neurodevelopmental disorders. However, quantitative spatiotemporal analysis remains limited in clinical practice, particularly using computed tomography (CT). This study proposes a perturbation-based deep learning framework that estimates brain age from pediatric CT scans while revealing region-wise contributions across developmental stages. A 3D ResNet architecture is trained on pediatric CT images to perform age regression and to enable region-wise interpretability through perturbation analysis. Anatomically guided perturbation analysis is conducted, consisting of lobe-wise masking to evaluate major regions. The proposed method was validated using head CT data from 201 pediatric patients aged 0 to 47 months with five-fold cross-validation stratified by age. The model achieved high accuracy with an RMSE of 5.205 months, an MAE of 4.007 months, and a Pearson correlation coefficient (r) of 0.925. The analysis reveals a dynamic posterior to anterior shift, with occipital lobe dominance in early infancy, emerging parietal lobe contributions in mid-infancy, and increasing frontal and temporal lobe importance in later stages. To our knowledge, this is the first CT-based study to investigate perturbation-driven region-wise interpretability in pediatric brain age estimation. The proposed framework offers a clinically meaningful approach for early developmental assessment.
