title: On the Performance of Large Intelligence Surfaces with LDPC Codes
authors: M. Marques da Silva, G. Pembele, R. Dinis, A. Correia
abstract: This study explores the integration of Low-Density Parity-Check (LDPC) coding with Large Intelligent Surface (LIS) systems in conjunction with Single Carrier with Frequency Domain Equalization (SC-FDE). LIS systems represent a revolutionary advancement in wireless communication, leveraging densely packed antenna arrays for enhanced signal processing and beamforming capabilities. The research evaluates the performance of four receiver configurations: Maximum Ratio Combining (MRC), Equal Gain Combining (EGC), Zero Forcing (ZF), and Minimum Mean Squared Error (MMSE). By incorporating LDPC codes, substantial improvements in error correction and system reliability are achieved. Specifically, simulation results indicate a performance gain of approximately 3 dB for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 25$</tex> LIS system and 2 dB for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 225$</tex> LIS system when compared to uncoded systems.

title: Data-Driven Multi-Spectral Imaging Techniques for Quality Assessment in Fruits and Vegetables
authors: Sushant Bhat, Varsha Patil, Arundhati Das
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Accurate quality assessment of fruits and vegetables is critical for reducing food waste and ensuring consumer satisfaction. Traditional methods are often subjective and destructive. This paper details a non-destructive system integrating multi-spectral imaging (MSI) via the AS7265 sensor with an ESP32 microcontroller and edge machine learning (Edge AI) using the Edge Impulse platform for real-time quality evaluation. We present a comprehensive offline data preprocessing pipeline implemented in Python, featuring Savitzky-Golay filtering for noise reduction, per-sample min-max normalization to handle intensity variations, and the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) to address significant class imbalance. Manual feature engineering was employed to create additional discriminative features from the 18-channel spectral data. A neural network classifier, trained on the combined 22 features from the balanced dataset, was optimized and deployed as an INT8 quantized TensorFlow Lite for Microcontrollers model onto the ESP32. The system achieves an on-device validation accuracy of 93.7% for a 16 -class fruit and vegetable quality problem. We describe the hardware, the advanced software preprocessing, the on-device feature calculation, and the model development workflow, demonstrating a viable and effective solution for accessible, data-driven quality control in the agricultural sector.

title: Real Time Sensing Methodology for Soil Using IoT
authors: Jayashri Sachin Zambre, Sanjay Badhe, Maheshwari Biradar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Soil is a major component of land which is useful for production of crop in the field of agriculture. This proposed work focus on developing a prototype model for measurement of several soil nutrients, temperature, moisture, pH, Electrical Conductivity(EC). There are various approaches to build this system. First, the data is measured by a 5-pin NPK sensor connected to an ATmega328-based Arduino Uno board, and all the values are displayed on a four-line(RG2004A) LCD display. Second alternative way is Interfaced the Resistive/Capacitive Soil Moisture sensor and Temperature sensor(waterproof) with Long Range(LoRa) TTGO(Inbuilt ESP 32-DOWDQ6) transmitter and measure the soil moisture and temperature at field side and at other end LoRa receiver(at user side) with OLED display is connected to monitor the soil parameter from long distance approximately 10 to 15 Km using Lora TTGO without an Internet to test the suitability of soil for farming as well for building construction. For further recommendation of this system is predicting a suitable crop for the farmer.

title: Enhancing Home Appliance Control with Bluetooth, ESP32, and Relay Integration
authors: Aarti Pawar, Suvarna Kadam, Rashmi Patil, Devang Rajesh Edle, Gaurav Dwivedi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Issues in controlling and securing home appliances include security vulnerabilities, privacy risks from data collection, interoperability challenges, remote access threats, and potential vendor lock-in. The proposed system is a Bluetooth-based ESP32 and relay system to enhance the control and privacy of home appliances. The system enables users to control their appliances via Bluetooth, eliminating the need for physical interaction with manual switches. The fan is controlled, providing an additional layer of customization to create an ideal room environment. The system allows users to manage multiple devices within a room, providing comprehensive appliance accessibility. The ESP32 microcontroller's Bluetooth module is the input channel, receiving user commands via Bluetooth. These inputs are then processed to determine which appliance to activate or deactivate. The processing phase involves code analysis and interpretation, triggering the GPIO pins to generate signals. Bluetooth technology reduces vulnerability to cyberattacks and ensures privacy and security. The energyefficient system allows users to power off appliances and optimize energy use remotely.

title: A 1.21-V 0.33-ppm/°C Bandgap Voltage Reference with a Multiple-Segment Curvature Compensation Function
authors: Yulin Li, Quanyuan Feng, Yan Wen
abstract: In this article, we present an accurate current-type band gap reference circuit that contains two high-gain operational amplifiers to generate proportional absolute temperature (PTAT) and complementary absolute temperature (CTAT) current sources. Compared to general bandgap reference sources, this BGR adopts a multi-current injection curvature compensation method based on different temperature thresholds, which enables the internal circuit to perform multi-band curvature compensation for both high and low temperature stages, and can more accurately realise the temperature compensation for different temperature segments, and greatly reduce the nonlinear dependence of the bipolar transistor base-emitter voltage on the temperature caused by the Error. The bandgap reference is designed using SMIC 180 nm CMOS process technology, and the circuit is built and simulated in cadence software. The simulation results show that when the power supply voltage is 3.3 V, the proposed BGR achieves the temperature coefficient of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.33 \text{ppm} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> at a typical TT process corner over a wide temperature range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to 150° C; the output voltage is 1.21 V; the power supply rejection ratio can reach 75 dB\DC at 27° C at different process corners; the voltage accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sigma / \mu$</tex>) obtained by Monte Carlo simulation is 0.4 %.

title: Standardized Logging Approach for Software Code-bases Using Natural Language Processing
authors: Brian Kipchumba Tum, Eunice Njeri Mwangi, Annette Waithira Irungu, Isaac Nyabisa Oteyo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: Software development efforts are shifting from localized to global collaboration ventures. This shift introduces linguistic disparity challenges, such as software developers using the same natural language differently. More concretely, in software development, linguistic disparity is experienced in how software developers describe anticipated error messages (in log statements) within code bases. This disparity negatively impacts software debugging activities. To address this challenge, in this paper, we propose a standardized logging approach using a natural language processing model. The model uses a large corpus of well-structured log entries to suggest semantically similar log entries during log instrumentation. Our approach ensures that software debugging is done in a uniform and standardized natural language, which streamlines collaboration in software development teams. To validate our approach, we trained our model using LogHub<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> log files. The validation shows promising results when tested using log statements in the English language.

title: A Full-Waveform Electric Field Detector for Lightning Localization Based on Electromagnetic Time Reversal Method
authors: Kang Hui, Yanzhao Xie, Zhaoyang Wang, Wenda Jia
abstract: The accuracy of lightning localization based on the electromagnetic time reversal (EMTR) method relies on comprehensive full-waveform information and precise time synchronization. This article presents a novel electric field (E-field) detector for lightning detection and localization applications. The proposed detector integrates a circular flat plate antenna with field programable gate array based digital signal processing circuitry, featuring a 100 MS/s sampling rate and 10 ms acquisition window to capture transient E-field waveforms. And its 3-dB bandwidth ranges from 100 Hz to 25 MHz. The acquired data can be stored in the local flash memory, which has a capacity of 16 GB and is capable of recording over 1000 waveforms. Furthermore, the fourth-generation mobile communication technology (4G) is utilized to transmit data, including timestamps and location information provided by the global positioning system, to a remote server via the TCP protocol. The test results indicate that the time synchronization error between different detectors is less than 50 ns. In this article, we build test platforms to verify its time-domain and frequency-domain performance. An illustrative example demonstrating the application of the detector is presented. The E-field data measured by the detector are processed using an EMTR algorithm for lightning location. Comparative analysis with the positioning results from the advanced direction time lightning detection system validates the effectiveness of the detector.

title: GATformer-Transformer Based Progressive Triplet Network for Hyperspectral Target Detection
authors: Songqi Li, Xudong Sun, Lingyu Kong, Jiahua Zhang, Xiaodi Shang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Deep learning (DL) has achieved significant progress in hyperspectral target detection (HTD), yet several challenges remain. The limited prior information in HTD hinders effective network training, while the high dimensionality of hyperspectral image and the complex relationships between bands impose greater demands on the model's ability to capture spectral features and variations. To address these issues, this paper proposes a GATformer-Transformer based progressive triplet network (GTPTN) for HTD. First, a clustering-driven linear mixing sample construction strategy is proposed to generate high-quality background and target samples for model training. Subsequently, the spectra are segmented to construct an enhanced chain spectral graph (ECSG), and we introduce a local-global progressive learning network to thoroughly explore representative spectral information of targets. In addition, a novel strong separation-aggregation (SSA) loss is designed by combining batch hard positive mining (BHPM) loss with binary cross-entropy (BCE) loss, further enhance the network's target recognition ability. Finally, experiments on four public HTD datasets demonstrate that GTPTN achieves excellent detection accuracy and strong stability. Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of each proposed module.

title: Hybrid Cloud-Integrated and GAN-Based Deep Learning Framework for Prediction of Environmental Time Series
authors: Archana Rout, Biswa Ranjan Senapati, Debahuti Mishra
abstract: Weather predictions empower authorities to proactively manage critical sectors like water resources, agriculture, and emergency services. By anticipating weather patterns, they can deploy early warning systems, formulate comprehensive response plans, and implement preventative measures, minimizing potential disruptions and protecting public safety. These points primarily motivate us to predict environmental parameters, recognizing their growing susceptibility to unsustainable development and environmental pollution, exacerbating natural calamities. Based on historical data, this study predicts six essential environmental parameters: temperature, precipitation, cloud cover, wind speed, wind direction, and dew point for Jaipur and Kanpur, India. Cloud-based services enable scalability and computational efficiency in organising and transmitting environmental data, offering practical support for the implementation pipeline. Vanilla GANs are implemented to address data gaps by generating missing values within these parameters. The present work focuses on predicting six significant environmental parameters by utilising ARIMA, SARIMA, SES, DES, and TES models. The comparative analysis demonstrates the superior performance of the SARIMA model overall for most parameters, as measured by the nMAE and nMSE. For a single parameter, the nMAE and nMSE were (0.16, 0.04) before data generation and (0.10, 0.03) after data generation for a single city, respectively, in forecasting all specified environmental parameters.

title: Active-passive coupling analysis and optimal design of internal and external hybrid coils in MSC
authors: Yi Liu, Xueping Xu, Chunbo Han
abstract: To enhance the performance of ultra-weak magnetic measurement equipment, an optimal design method for the internal and external hybrid coil (IEHC) by the improved target field method (TFM) is proposed. Firstly, an analytical model of the active-passive coupling between the magnetically shielded cylinder (MSC) and the magnetic field (MF) distribution of the IEHC is developed. Then, the established analytical model is combined with TFM to devise the coils inside and outside the MSC. Moreover, the design parameters are optimal with the differential squirrel search algorithm (DSSA). Simulations demonstrate that in large target regions, the maximum MF deviation of IEHC decreases from 38.89% (DC-IEHC) to 21.09%, representing a 45.77% improvement. In small target regions, the deviation drops from 38.89% to 3.56%, a reduction of 90.85%. Experimental validation confirms the effectiveness of the method, providing theoretical support for optimizing active magnetic compensation coils in ultra-weak magnetic measurement systems.

title: ProactiveVA: Proactive Visual Analytics with LLM-Based UI Agent
authors: Yuheng Zhao, Xueli Shu, Liwen Fan, Lin Gao, Yu Zhang, Siming Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Visual analytics (VA) is typically applied to complex data, thus requiring complex tools. While visual analytics empowers analysts in data analysis, analysts may get lost in the complexity occasionally. This highlights the need for intelligent assistance mechanisms. However, even the latest LLM-assisted VA systems only provide help when explicitly requested by the user, making them insufficiently intelligent to offer suggestions when analysts need them the most. We propose a ProactiveVA framework in which LLM-powered UI agent monitors user interactions and delivers context-aware assistance proactively. To design effective proactive assistance, we first conducted a formative study analyzing help-seeking behaviors in user interaction logs, identifying when users need proactive help, what assistance they require, and how the agent should intervene. Based on this analysis, we distilled key design requirements in terms of intent recognition, solution generation, interpretability and controllability. Guided by these requirements, we develop a three-stage UI agent pipeline including perception, reasoning, and acting. The agent autonomously perceives users' needs from VA interaction logs, providing tailored suggestions and intuitive guidance through interactive exploration of the system. We implemented the framework in two representative types of VA systems, demonstrating its generalizability, and evaluated the effectiveness through an algorithm evaluation, case and expert study and a user study. We also discuss current design trade-offs of proactive VA and areas for further exploration.

title: Towards Deeper Emotional Reflection: Crafting Affective Image Filters With Generative Priors
authors: Peixuan Zhang, Shuchen Weng, Jiajun Tang, Si Li, Boxin Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Social media platforms enable users to express emotions by posting text with accompanying images. In this paper, we propose the Affective Image Filter (AIF) task, which aims to reflect visually-abstract emotions from text into visually-concrete images, thereby creating emotionally compelling results. We first introduce the AIF dataset and the formulation of the AIF models. Then, we present AIF-B as an initial attempt based on a multi-modal transformer architecture. After that, we propose AIF-D as an extension of AIF-B towards deeper emotional reflection, effectively leveraging generative priors from pre-trained large-scale diffusion models. Quantitative and qualitative experiments demonstrate that AIF models achieve superior performance for both content consistency and emotional fidelity compared to state-of-the-art methods. Extensive user study experiments demonstrate that AIF models are significantly more effective at evoking specific emotions. Based on the presented results, we comprehensively discuss the value and potential of AIF models.

title: Task-Aware Effective Connectivity Modeling for Cognitive Function Prediction
authors: Wantong Zou, Yu Li, Xiang Hu, Xun Chen, Aiping Liu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Effective connectivity (EC) derived from resting-state Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (rs fMRI) has emerged as a critical tool for deepening our understanding of brain function in both health and dis ease. However, most studies estimate EC on an individual basis, treating it as a hidden parameter within the model and requiring retraining the model for each subject. They often overlook the valuable population-level information and limit their generalizability. Additionally, EC is typically obtained independently of downstream tasks, reducing its capacity to effectively capture task-specific variations. To address these limitations, we propose a flexible Task-Aware Effective Connectivity (TAEC) model, designed to construct individualized, task-aware, and nonlinear causal brain networks without requiring subject-specific retraining. In this framework, a Causal Discovery Module (CDM) is introduced to capture the implicit neural representation of the EC by a spatial-temporal attention mechanism, producing the estimation of an individual EC. Subsequently, we propose a Task-Aware Graph Neural Network (GNN) Predictor, which incorporates a task-aware penalty to enable end-to-end prediction, enhancing task performance and the identification of task-dependent EC patterns. Extensive experiments on twelve cognitive tasks from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance, validating its effectiveness in task-aware effective connectivity modeling. Furthermore, the framework discovers discriminative and task-specific EC patterns, which offer additional in-sights into cognitive functions.

title: Generalizable Deep Learning Models Reveal Distinct Epileptogenic Regions from 3D Brain MRI Scans
authors: Kumar Paritosh, Shubhangi K Gawali, Veeky Baths, Neena Goveas
abstract: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) plays a crucial role in detecting structural and functional abnormalities in the brains of epilepsy patients. Automating this process using advanced AI/ML techniques can reduce the burden on experts, be a training resource, and make diagnosis accessible and affordable to a larger population. However, models developed using imaging data have not achieved acceptable accuracy levels. One reason for this is the limited number of data points available and artifacts in the data capture mechanism of the available datasets. There is a need to develop a generalized model that can take as input diverse images with multiple conditions, which predicts epilepsy and identifies the impacted brain regions. In this work, we present the design of deep-learning models capable of predicting epilepsy using 3D brain Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans. Five deep learning models were developed to classify 3D MRI scans to identify specific brain regions involved in Hippocampal Sclerosis, Dysembryoplastic Neuroepithelial Tumors, Cavernomas, Focal Cortical Dysplasia, and other epileptic-related conditions. We find that our trained models predict epilepsy with over 91% accuracy on FLAIR images and nearly 100% accuracy on T1-weighted (T1-w) images. Our results show that deep learning architectures in 3D are highly effective in detecting epilepsy and identifying relevant pathological regions. These findings highlight not only the diagnostic accuracy of the models but also their potential utility in aiding clinical decision-making.

title: Extended node-specific distributed generalized sidelobe canceler for outdoor wireless acoustic sensor networks
authors: Shiqin Li, Jing Hu, Zhao Zhao, Zhiyong Xu
abstract: In distributed sound source enhancement (SSE) tasks using microphone array nodes, state-of-the-art node-specific distributed generalized sidelobe canceler (NS-DGSC) algorithm has achieved remarkable performance for simultaneously enhancing multiple desired sources. However, its assumption of an equal number of nodes and sources usually does not hold in outdoor applications. This letter proposes an extended NS-DGSC (ENS-DGSC) algorithm to tackle this issue. A correlation check module is introduced to handle scenarios where nodes outnumber or match sources. Furthermore, a temporal alignment module using two different strategies is designed to address time delays among nodes. Evaluations reveal that the proposed ENS-DGSC not only retains advantages of the NS-DGSC, but also provides superior enhancement performance with more nodes than sources.

title: Dynamic Bronchial Environment Reconstruction for Robotic Lung Invasive Surgery
authors: Shumei Yu, Tingyu Yu, Peng Li, Peng Yang, Qixia Wang, Rongchuan Sun, Yu Chen, Lining Sun, Yunhui Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping) has a wide application prospect in navigation of autonomous endoscopic minimally invasive surgery. However, traditional methods like ORB-SLAM2 often struggle in dynamic environments and exhibit significant modeling inaccuracies, particularly in bronchial scenes where respiratory motion induces continuous deformation of the airway structure. To address this challenge, we propose a novel monocular SLAM-based framework for dynamic bronchial environment reconstruction tailored to robotic lung invasive surgery. Firstly, a pseudo-static processing method that builds map sequences at identical respiratory phases across cycles was built. Furthermore, we present a voxel model optimization technique using curvature-consistent graph interpolation to refine the bronchial lumen surface, eliminating pores and redundancies in the voxel map. Experiments conducted on real patient demonstrate that our method has good accuracy and robustness. Compared to existing state-of-the-art methods, our framework achieves superior reconstruction completeness, showing strong potential for clinical use in robotic bronchoscopy.
