title: Demonstration of Low Power and Multifunctional Neurons With Only Two or Five Ferroelectric SBFETs
authors: Andreas Grenmyr, Jiayuan Zhang, Kenta Moto, Jingxuan Sun, Yu-Tzu Liao, Nazmus Sakib, Detlev Grützmacher, Joachim Knoch, Qing-Tai Zhao
abstract: This work demonstrates both artificial synapses and neurons based on a single type of ferroelectric Schottky barrier FET (Fe-SBFET). The Fe-SBFET features a 200-nm gate length, incorporating a ferroelectric Hf<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub>.<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</sub>Zr<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub>.<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> (HZO) gate dielectric and an ultrathin Si<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub> interfacial layer. A single Fe-SBFET exhibits robust synaptic characteristics with low energy consumption of 28 fJ/state. Utilizing only two Fe-SBFETs, we realize an integrate-and-fire (IF) neuron with an energy cost of 0.67 pJ/spike. Notably, a five-transistor Fe-SBFET neuron circuit replicates thalamic neuron behavior, exhibiting leaky integrate and fire or burst (LIFB) functionality at 5.6 kHz, with an energy consumption of just 2.6 pJ/spike.

title: Post fault transient stability enhancement of grid forming inverter with current saturation algorithm
authors: Keitaro Yanagihara, Goro Fujita
abstract: Recently, grid forming inverters receive growing interest as they contribute to the stability of grids. Due to their voltage source nature and limited overcurrent capability, they must be able to limit the overcurrent and successfully recover to the healthy mode while connecting to the grid. Current saturation algorithm is a promising approach; however, it has limited post fault stability. If it does not recover successfully, the inverter may oscillate or may not be able to recover the healthy mode control. This article proposes a simple supplementary control structure which avoids these modes. Simulation results are provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed control structure.

title: Comprehensive Technical Evaluation and Cost of Integrating Hybrid Renewable Energy System in Mining Operations
authors: E. Kalihonda, S. Chowdhury
abstract: This paper explores the potential of hybridizing conventional energy systems and storage to supply clean and reliable power to mining operations in a cost effective and sustainable manner. Four different hybrid renewable energy system (HRES) designs combining solar PV, wind turbines, battery storage and diesel generators and the grid have been analysed and compared in terms of system reliability, technical performance, and cost-effectiveness to determine the best option. The parameters used to evaluate them include net present cost, levelized cost of energy, excess electricity, unmet load, and emissions to determine the most viable solution. The most cost-effective and technically sound solution has been determined to be solar PV and battery grid-connected system which had the lowest net present cost.

title: The Information System Factory – Return to Simplicity
authors: Walter Koch, Ramiro Ortiz, Odo Benda, Amit Kumar Mishra
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper presents the concept of a tool (Information System Factory) which uses a Fourth Generation Language ($\mathbf{4 G L}$) environment for the production of Information Systems in an agile Software Development Style (RAD: Rapid Application Development). The production process follows the principle of a factory, which assembles the final product by reusing already developed components and adding new components either by in house development or by acquiring external components (Component Based Development). The final system follows a three layer architecture (MVC: Model View Control) separating Data Base (Model) Management, User Interaction (View), and Programming (Control). Modern Micro Computers can be used to execute this “4GL-RAD-Tool” locally on user’s premises or in the field (powered by a battery) without the need of accessing facilities in a global network (cloud). The power of a low cost, energy saving Single Board Computer (SBC) is enough e.g. for developing and running business information systems using this tool. SBCs are frequently used in embedded Systems, which interact with sensors and actuators to control physical processes. Since SBCs can be equipped with large storage devices, there is no need in many cases to use programs in the cloud for the further on processing of big data. A realization of this 4GL-RAD Tool is based on an INFORMIX-4GL compatible system, which is available as an open source productivity tool. The System provides a menu driven IDE, which supports a standard System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) as linear or iterative model. The different phases of the SDLC are delivering various artifacts like User Requirement Documents, Code, and Software User Manuals, which can be enhanced by using Artificial Intelligence (AI). Restricting the system development to classes like Business Administration, Cultural Heritage, IoT-Computing to name a few, can support the development process by introducing “domain ontologies” in the “DevOps"-Environment. The development of a Sensor Network provides a practical example in the field of Mechatronic Engineering.

title: A Multilayer Low-Pass Frequency Selective Surface with Wide Stopband
authors: Haonan Huang, Longjian Zhou, Qiang-Ming Cai, Xin Cao, Liping Wang, Meiying Li, Haoran Li, Yuyu Zhu, Jun Fan
abstract: This article presents a multilayer low-pass frequency selective surface (FSS) with wide stopband rejection property and low passband insertion loss. This kind of FSS can be used as antenna radome of UHF and VHF embedded antenna to reduce the radar cross section of the cavity. Firstly, some theoretical design methods of FSS are briefly reviewed. As the proposed FSS is presented by cascading three layers of periodic arrays, optimization by full wave software is time consuming. Thus, the equivalent circuit method is utilized to design a low-pass filter for U/V band (0.1 MHz 0.4 MHz). The optimized circuit is cascaded with three band stop filter, and a wide stopband that covers S, C and X band is realized. Then, three hexagonal rings with different size are utilized to realize the FSS unit cell. The structure parameters of the unit cell are optimized to achieve the corresponding values of capacitors and conductors. The simulation results show that the passband insertion loss is less than 0.5 dB, and the stopband suppression is more than 15 dB. The stopband bandwidth of 15 dB is 8.23 GHz, corresponding to a relative bandwidth of 96.1%. The polarization stability of the FSS is also studied, and the frequency response curves of TE and TM polarized waves are almost the same for normal incidence. In terms of angular stability, the transmission curve is basically stable in the range of −45 to 45 degrees.

title: Benchmarking Modern Deep Learning Architectures for Scalable and Accurate Plant Disease Detection
authors: Nitish Rupesh Sawant, Kashish Vinay Sagar, Aarya Deepak Jaiswal, Anuj Kumar, Bansidhar Joshi, Rahul Sharma
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The detection of plant diseases has become one of the most important tools at the modern edge of precision agriculture to maintain crop health, maximize yield, and ensure food security worldwide. Deep learning has given boost to the study of plant pathology through images to achieve the highest automation, scalability, and accuracy in disease diagnosis. The present work offers an overview of some of the state-of-the-art deep learning methods-DenseNet201, DenseNet169, DenseNet121, MobileNetV2, MobileNet, NasNetLarge, and EfficientNet-B0. These methods are used for the detection and classification of plant diseases based on visual symptoms on leaf images. In this paper, we study transfer learning and fine tuning to train and validate these models on plant disease datasets that belong to the public domain, suPlant Village. Based on classification accuracy, model generalization, training and inference times, memory consumption, and ease of deployment under resource constraints, the evaluation was carried out. emphasis was placed on DenseNet's densely connected pathways, MobileNet's deepwise separable convolution, and NASNet's optimized searching method. This study reveals that certain model architectures may indeed be more suitable for deployment according to different constraints and needs. Thus, the results contributed to developing intelligent, accessible, scalable plant disease solutions, along with a data-driven approach toward agriculture.

title: Integrating Weather Data to Improve House Price Prediction Accuracy of Machine Learning Models: Evidence and Implications
authors: Indranath Chatterjee, Swapnajit Chakraborti, Jayaraman V. K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: House price prediction has traditionally relied on textual features like the number of bedrooms, bathrooms, and square footage, but this approach often overlooks crucial qualitative aspects. Integrating house images allows models to evaluate visual appeal, architectural style, and property condition, including curb appeal, neighborhood aesthetics, and surrounding area demographics. Incorporating weather data enables analysis of both direct and indirect effects of weather on property values. The primary goal of including imagery data is to enhance prediction accuracy, while weather data serves to assess the impact of weather events on house prices. This research demonstrates that combining these diverse data sources, especially long-term weather data, enhances prediction accuracy. With different machine learning algorithms, this research has established that incorporation of weather data has led to increase the prediction power of house price models whether it is only textual or textual and imagery dataset. However, the improvement in prediction accuracy due to weather data varies depending on the region. These findings may be used for smart city initiatives, namely, urban planning, fair pricing and investment decisions.

title: Nutritionist GenAI Site: Personalised Dietary Recommendations
authors: Sunita Patil, Abhishek Dhande, Soham Dodake, Alok Bhoye, Sakshi Wadhe
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Nutritionist GenAI is a smart web-based application that uses deep learning and generative AI to deliver personalized nutritional feedback and analysis based on meal photos. Aiming to encourage healthier lifestyles and assist people with dietrelated conditions, the application analyzes user uploaded food pictures using a convolutional neural network (MobileNetV2) to correctly identify food and estimate caloric and nutritional values. The user interface provides a readable interface for input and output, while a powerful database stores user health profiles, dietary tendencies, nutrition facts, and interaction histories. GenAI is the central component that combines stored user information and real-time inputs to create individualized feedback, providing actionable information specific to an individual's needs. The system provides granular breakdowns of macronutrients and micronutrients, recommends changes, and monitors dietary habits over time. Its modular design provides unobstructed communication between modules, supporting scalability, smooth updates, and potential integration with other health systems in the future. In contrast to static calorie counter apps, Nutritionist GenAI learns through user engagement, sharpening its predictions and recommendations as it is used more. The adaptive learning cycle enables the system to provide expert-level advice at scale, turning nutritional management into a smart, responsive, and user-friendly experience. With cutting-edge AI and considerate design, the system fills the gap between nutrition science and daily wellness choices.

title: Defense-Focused Autonomous Unmanned Aerial Vehicle System Using Ensemble Model of ResNetV8 and ResDQN
authors: Pratik Dhage, Neel Shah, Shridhar Gore, Vyankatesh Jadhav, Anuradha Yenkikar, Nilesh Sable
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Navigation of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) is fraught with difficulties due to dynamic obstacles, narrow passages, and the presence or absence of GPS signals. To traverse such environments, one needs adaptable and intelligent control architecture that can make real-time decisions with some uncertainty involved. This paper proposes an all-encompassing AI control system that integrates ideas from Deep Learning and Deep Reinforcement Learning for autonomous navigation of UAVs. Key improvements include external 3D maps and customized drone assets integrated into the AirSim simulator thereby creating a very realistic testing environment. We included an enemy tracking module which allows visual prediction, enabling the drone to detect, track, and evade dynamic threats. Also, a voice command interface allows human operators to take real-time control, thus enhancing interoperability and flexibility in missions. The navigation strategy comprises a dual hybrid ensemble model that integrates ResNet8-based a path planning algorithm and DQN-based an obstacle avoidance algorithm. Furthermore, ResNet8 and CNN are integrated for preliminary object detection tasks, whereby CNN assigns a confidence score to the object detection, and if this confidence is high, then a request is made to ResDQN, without reconfirmation by ResNet8. Such integrated approaches have assured stable flight performance in complex environments while ensuring efficiency as well as high performance. Experimental results have illustrated the robustness and applicability of our system for navigating through tightly cluttered indoor environments containing static and dynamic hazards. This work, therefore, pushes intelligent UAV applications in time-sensitive missions such as search-and-rescue, surveillance, and reconnaissance.

title: AI-Based Real-Time Feedback System for Automated Assignment Evaluation and Personalized Quiz Generation in Computer Engineering Education
authors: Priya Surana, Sushma Vispute, Harsha Talele, Ashish Suryawanshi, Aditya Vedpathak, Irfan Tadvi, Atharva Toke
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: This article proposes a novel AI-based system that aims to offer real-time feedback and customized quizzes for computer engineering problems. The system focuses on one of the main issues of contemporary education: the time and effort required for manual grading. Through the utilization of Generative AI, our solution automatizes the process of feedback, resulting in a drastic reduction of the time spent by educators on manual grading. One of the main features of the system is its capability to process varied assignment types, both digital and hand-written submissions, with the inclusion of Optical Character Recognition (OCR). The system examines student responses by applying deep learning models to detect particular errors and knowledge gaps. It then uses Generative AI to create personalized quizzes automatically to reinforce principal concepts and enhance student comprehension. This method not only simplifies the grading process but also maximizes the learning process by giving students immediate, personalized feedback. Our testing of the system validates its effectiveness, with higher accuracy, faster operation rates, and higher user satisfaction.

title: Multimodal Disease Detection MedBot
authors: Aditya Dhir, Saksham Jain, Tanmay Sankuratri, Sumitra Motade
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Multimodal Disease Detection MedBot, investigates the use of artificial intelligence to enhance early diagnosis of retinal diseases. It combines two main components: an automated retinal image analysis module powered by a fine-tuned Vision Transformer (ViT) model and a health-oriented conversational chatbot utilizing a fine-tuned LLaMA 3.1 8B language model. Designed to improve accessibility to preliminary health screening, especially in remote or underserved areas, the system processes fundus images to detect conditions such as Diabetic Retinopathy. Images undergo preprocessing steps like contrast enhancement and resizing to optimize model accuracy. Concurrently, the chatbot provides real-time, context-sensitive responses to general health questions, leveraging a quantized LLaMA model fine-tuned on medical question-answer datasets. The user interface, built with Streamlit, enables smooth toggling between image diagnosis and chatbot interaction, while FastAPI manages backend communication and data processing. This integrated platform exemplifies the synergy of computer vision, natural language processing, and user-centered design to support early intervention and broaden access to medical expertise. Future enhancements include multilingual capabilities, electronic health record integration, and mobile deployment, positioning the MedBot as a scalable AI-driven telemedicine solution.

title: A Multi-Features-Based Model for Tropical Cyclone Intensity Estimation with Infrared Remote Sensing Observations
authors: Sheng Wang, Guihong Liu, Yang Yu, Wentao Ma, Xiaofeng Yang
abstract: In this study, a Tropical Cyclone (TC) Intensity Estimation (TIE) was proposed by comprehensively utilizing the multi-features of infrared (IR) remote sensing images, namely MFTIE model. The new model comprises of three modules: a CNN module based on Residual Blocks to extract the graphical features, an optimized multilayer perceptron (MLP) module with residual structure to process the statistical features, and a fully connected output module to give the final estimation of TC intensity. With the HURSAT-B1 dataset a root-mean-square error of 8.91 kt on test set. Besides, the MF-TIE model was compared with a model that uses only images as inputs, and the results showed that the test accuracy of the proposed model improved by 7.67 %. Furthermore, the comparisons with existing models confirm the performance superiority of the proposed model. The findings suggest that utilizing multi-source features of remote sensing data, such as the dynamic and radiative characteristics of IR images, has great potential in the field of remote sensing inversion.

title: AI-Driven Cloud Resource Optimization: An in-Depth Analysis
authors: Kapil Tajane, Prashant Ahire, Rahul Pitale
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Cloud computing enabled access to computing resources is disruptive in how we provide and manage computing resources, by making resources flexible, scalable and available on-demand utilizing a pay-as-you-go model. Finding the right resource and managing it efficiently still remains an ongoing challenge, due to the dynamic workloads that have fixed and flexible qualities, dynamic application requirements, and complex heterogeneous cloud environments. This study provides a comprehensive survey of the literature on artificial intelligence (AI) techniques that are used for optimizing resource allocation in cloud computing. This study presents a review and discussion of the use of AI-based methods, including reinforcement learning, predictive analytics, and hybrid optimization methods, across multiple cloud deployment scenarios. The study undertakes a systematic review of recently published papers - sorting and categorizing the AI resourcing allocation methods to describe the current state-of-the-art, describing and investigating the key performance indicators to identify research gaps and provide future research recommendations. This study concludes that AI-based resource allocation methods consider more variables than ad-hoc and heuristic models; and that the use of those variables allows the AI-based models to improve efficiency, cost savings, energy-efficiency and service performance - with reported improvements between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 - 6 0 \%}$</tex> across the research papers.

title: From Detection to Defense: A Review of Cyber Threat Intelligence Integration in Cloud Systems
authors: Meghana Sononi, Umesh Raut
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The exponential growth of cloud computing has introduced both unprecedented scalability and a broader attack surface, necessitating more intelligent and proactive cybersecurity strategies. This review explores the evolving landscape of Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) and its critical role in enhancing cloud security. Emphasizing the transition from passive threat detection to adaptive defense, the paper analyzes existing CTI frameworks, threat-sharing models, and integration approaches in cloud-based architectures. It highlights key technologies such as hypervisor-based monitoring, virtual machine introspection, and AI-powered data pipelines for real threat detection. By synthesizing findings from recent literature, the review identifies current gap such as lack of open-source CTI platforms and challenges in data privacy—and provides recommendations for building resilient, collaborative, and scalable cloud defense mechanisms. This comprehensive examination serves as a guide for researchers and security practitioners seeking to leverage CTI for robust cloud infrastructure protection. By synthesizing current research and practical implementations, this review provides actionable insights into how CTI can enhance cloud resilience, facilitate faster incident response, and strengthen the overall security posture of modern digital ecosystems.

title: Advancements in Sentiment Analysis of Code-Mixed Text: A Survey of Multilingual Models and Emerging Innovations
authors: Akshata Phadte, Manikrao Laxmanrao Dhore
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The rapid rise of multilingual communication, particularly on social media, has led to an increasing presence of code-mixed text, where words from multiple languages appear within a single sentence. Sentiment analysis of such text poses unique challenges due to language-switching, script variation, and data scarcity. This paper presents a systematic literature review of sentiment analysis techniques for code-mixed text following the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) guidelines. In addition to surveying state-of-the-art sentiment analysis models, this work introduces a simple yet effective Transformer-based sentiment classification model combined with basic tokenization techniques. By evaluating existing methodologies and proposing a streamlined yet powerful sentiment analysis approach, this paper aims to advance sentiment analysis in code-mixed languages and improve multilingual natural language processing (NLP) systems.

title: Skin Cancer Detection Using Deep Learning Models and Grad-CAM XAI
authors: Viraj Shewale, Bhavana Tiple
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Since skin cancer is one of the most prevalent and deadly types of the disease, millions of individuals worldwide are diagnosed with it each year as a result of excessive exposure to sunshine and UV radiation. The most prevalent kind of skin cancer observed is “Melanoma”. This study suggests a deep learning-based method for detecting skin cancer by improving data quality through the use of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and Data Augmentation. In this case, we are using DCGAN to create synthetic images, which increases model resilience, reduces overfitting, and is quick. The U-NET model, which guarantees the Rate of Interest of Lesion for localization, it then used to segment the pre-processed dataset. Using a Custom CNN and the Xception model, we conduct comparison analysis for classification in order to assess generalization and prediction accuracy. Furthermore, we use the XAI method known as Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) to improve model transparency and trustworthiness by offering visual interpretability. When applied to 5000 images from the ISIC 2020 dataset, the suggested methodology produced good results on classification models, such as Custom CNN and Xception, with an accuracy of 98.43%, demonstrating the model's efficiency.

title: Multilingual Signature Verification Using Deep Learning: A Three-Phase Modular Approach
authors: Rushabh Nitin Mistry, Nilkamal More, Suchitra Patil, Chirag Desai
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Signature verification is an important aspect of digital security in general and specifically in banking, legal, and administrative transactions, where fraud protection and identity authentication are paramount. Previous signature verification technologies have been trained mainly on English-language documents and thus function with reduced capability in multilingual noisy real-world settings such as in India. Such a language/context mismatch may result in strong operational issues, such as higher false rejection rates and lower overall verification accuracy. These are to be addressed with an effective, modular deep learning-based multilingual signature verification system consisting of three autonomous but interconnected phases: detection, cleaning, and matching. At the detection phase, YOLOv5 is utilized for efficiently localizing signature areas in documents with various scripts, supported by signature form-specific anchor tuning and aspect ratio optimization adaptations. The cleaning step employs unsupervised K-Means clustering to separate foreground signature ink from background noise such as stamps, printed lines, and seals to provide cleaner input for matching. Lastly, the matching step employs a Siamese network with a VGG16 backbone to learn discriminative feature embeddings and compare them by cosine similarity, trained on contrastive loss to enhance intra-class compactness and inter-class separability. Easily accessible experimental evaluation of real-world legal and financial documents shows the efficacy of the system with a mean Average Precision (mAP@0.5) of 92.7.

title: Topological Autoencoders++: Fast and Accurate Cycle-Aware Dimensionality Reduction
authors: Mattéo Clémot, Julie Digne, Julien Tierny
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: This paper presents a novel topology-aware dimensionality reduction approach aiming at accurately visualizing the cyclic patterns present in high dimensional data. To that end, we build on the Topological Autoencoders (TopoAE) [1] formulation. First, we provide a novel theoretical analysis of its associated loss and show that a zero loss indeed induces identical persistence pairs (in high and low dimensions) for the 0-dimensional persistent homology ($PH^{0}$) of the Rips filtration. We also provide a counter example showing that this property no longer holds for a naive extension of TopoAE to $PH^{d}$ for d $\geq$ 1. Based on this observation, we introduce a novel generalization of TopoAE to 1-dimensional persistent homology ($PH^{1}$), called TopoAE++, for the accurate generation of cycle-aware planar embeddings, addressing the above failure case. This generalization is based on the notion of cascade distortion, a new penalty term favoring an isometric embedding of the 2-chains filling persistent 1-cycles, hence resulting in more faithful geometrical reconstructions of the 1-cycles in the plane. We further introduce a novel, fast algorithm for the exact computation of PH for Rips filtrations in the plane, yielding improved runtimes over previously documented topology-aware methods. Our method also achieves a better balance between the topological accuracy, as measured by the Wasserstein distance, and the visual preservation of the cycles in low dimensions. Our C++ implementation is available at https://github.com/MClemot/TopologicalAutoencodersPlusPlus.

title: Valley Photonic Topological Insulator for Fluorescence Endoscopy
authors: Naved Sadat Yamin, Sajid Muhaimin Choudhury
abstract: Topological phases of light have transformed photonics, with valley photonic topological insulators (PTIs) emerging as a distinct subclass. Despite comprehensive study on PTIs, their utilization in fluorescence endoscopic imaging, especially within the near-infrared (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$890-1000 ~\text{nm}$</tex>) window, has yet to be investigated. Near-infrared light facilitates enhanced tissue penetration with reduced dispersion and absorption, hence facilitating the visualization of mucosal and submucosal features. This work examines the possibilities of valley photonic topological insulator waveguides in near-infrared fluorescence endoscopy, mainly how the optical image signals can be guided through the waveguide without distortion, with the objective of improving imaging resolution and diagnostic precision for minimally invasive medical procedures. For this, bandgap formation in the band diagram is demonstrated which is achieved through breaking inversion symmetry. Robustness of the valley PTI waveguide is tested against very sharp turns and defects. Finally, a practical method to incorporate the valley PTI waveguide for fluorescence endoscopy in the NIR-I region is discussed.

title: Magnon-Erbium-Ion Hybrids for Quantum Frequency Conversion
authors: Aliya Galimova, Hasan Pişkin, Faik Mikailzade, Rustem Khusnutdinov, Sergey A. Moiseev, Bulat Rameev
abstract: In this work, an approach based on the use of yttrium iron garnet (YIG) to increase the efficiency of quantum frequency conversion has been theoretically studied. YIG, which is a ferrimagnetic insulator transparent to both microwave and optical frequencies, has a very low damping parameter. Therefore, the coupling of YIG to microwave resonator modes is very strong. It has been demonstrated that it is possible to use the spin-wave oscillations of YIG to increase essentially the coupling of microwave photons to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Er}^{3+}$</tex> spin-flip transitions. The basic parameters of 2 -stage microwave-to-optic transduction in the proposed Erbium-YIG-based Hybrid Quantum System have been theoretically analyzed. The conditions needed for efficient coupling between magnetic resonance levels of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Er}^{3+}$</tex> ions and spin wave modes have been also considered.

title: Redefining Open-ended Assessment Authorship: Empirical Insights on Mind versus Machine Assessments in Computer Science
authors: Benson Kituku, Eric Araka, Elizaphan Maina
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: Manual preparation and design of high-quality and practical assessments can be challenging, time-consuming, labor-intensive, and require significant training alongside experience on the part of the educator. Currently, multiple-choice question (MCQ) automatic assessment methods are being employed to solve these challenges. However, MCQs are deficient in cultivating critical thinking, advanced cognitive skills and skills of analytical problem-solving as compared to open-ended questions, which are currently administered manually. Furthermore, there is insufficient empirical evidence to demonstrate the effectiveness of automatic question generation for open-ended assessments. Consequently, using a quasi-experimental approach, this research examined the latent potential of machine (ChatGPT-4) in supporting the design of open-ended assessments. The study designed both machine- and human-generated exams, assessed students, graded their responses, and compared the two sets of assessments and scores using external examiner reviews and statistical analysis in the computer science domain. The findings indicated equivalence between machine- and human-generated assessments, particularly when practical prompt engineering, moderation, and human oversight are applied to machine-generated assessments that align with course content and learning outcomes. Therefore, the study concluded that a hybrid approach, combining Generative artificial intelligence (Gen AI) and human expertise, offers a promising direction for developing credible and practical assessments.

title: Meteorological Station for Measuring the Evaporation Wave Duct
authors: A. M. Mikhailov, R. S. Yemelyanov, M. S. Mikhailov
abstract: This article discusses the creation of a station for measuring meteorological parameters of the troposphere, the creation of a system for analyzing data from sensors to obtain a refractive index profile. A system is also described for calculating the propagation of radio waves in a tropospheric waveduct, taking into account waves on the water surface and sea currents. The result of the work is a manufactured weather station for measuring tropospheric meteorological parameters at altitudes up to 30 meters from the sea surface in 0.5 meter increments. Creation of a system for collecting statistics and analyzing measured data. This system is planned to be used in Black Sea and northern seas.

title: Enhancing Drowsiness Detection: an Ensemble Machine Learning Approach to Eeg-Based Sleep Classification
authors: Shreya Neeraj Mandekar, Sneha Jagtap, Pranati Waghodekar, Anshul Patil, Deepali Javale
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Using EEG brainwave data, this study examines how well ensemble machine learning methods define sleep. Using a dataset of 3,735 EEG recordings, we evaluate bagging, boosting, and stacking techniques against conventional machine learning models. Our findings have implications for sleepiness detection systems in automotive and industrial safety applications since they show that ensemble approaches-in particular, Random Forest and XGBoost-perform better at differentiating between awake and sleep states.

title: Investigation of the Effect of a Complex-Shaped Dielectric Element on the Characteristics of a Bandpass Filter Based on an NRD Waveguide
authors: V. V. Krutskikh, A. N. Ushkov, D. S. Chukashov, A. Yu. Trofimov, M. S. Mikhailov, A. A. Komarov
abstract: The requirements for modern communication systems are actively growing, which requires a transition to higher frequency ranges and new device designs. So in the millimeter range, NRD waveguides and devices on them performed well. Since the task of primary signal processing is one of the fundamental ones, the study of the phenomena and characteristics of bandpass filters on the NRD waveguide is an urgent task. The present study analyzes the characteristics of a bandpass filter based on a square, rhombic, and complex-shaped element. Numerical modeling packages were used in the work, as well as field experiments were conducted. Based on them, the effects of the gap between the elements on the attenuation and departure of the central frequency were studied. Based on the data obtained in the work, recommendations were made on the design of bandpass filters for the elements studied in the work.

title: Development of a High-speed, Compact Magneto-optical Magnetic Field Detector
authors: E. Borchanu, M. Klein, A. Haj Yahya, N. Balal
abstract: This paper presents the development and experimental validation of a high-speed, compact magnetic field detector based on the magneto-optical Faraday effect in a Terbium Gallium Garnet (TGG) crystal, illuminated by a Helium-Neon (He-Ne) laser. By leveraging the optical polarization rotation induced by external magnetic fields, the proposed detector achieves higher measurement rates and improved sensitivity compared to conventional Hall effect-based gaussmeters [4]. Hall sensors often suffer from bandwidth limitations associated with intrinsic material properties and charge-carrier mobility, as well as a drop in sensitivity and an increase in noise during miniaturization. In contrast, the magneto-optical detector presented here provides accurate, high-speed magnetic field measurements in small volumes and is ideally suited for insertion into constrained spaces. We demonstrate measurement of dynamic magnetic fields generated by a solenoid energized through an RLC discharge circuit operating in an overdamped or critically damped regime. Our results show that this optical detection approach outperforms traditional methods in both temporal response and accuracy, thereby underscoring the advantages of magneto-optical sensing in a range of magnetic field measurement applications.

title: Hybrid Attention Driven CNN-Mamba Multimodal Fusion Network for Remote Sensing Image Semantic Segmentation
authors: Shu Tian, Minglei Li, Lin Cao, Lihong Kang, Jing Tian, Xiangwei Xing, Bo Shen, Kangning Du, Chong Fu, Ye Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: In recent years, the increase of multimodal image data has offered a broader prospect for multimodal semantic segmentation. However, the data heterogeneity between different modalities make it difficult to leverage complementary information and create semantic understanding deviations, which limits the fusion quality and segmentation accuracy. To overcome these challenges, we propose a hybrid attention driven CNN-Mamba multimodal fusion network (HACMNet) for semantic segmentation. It aims to fully exploit the strengths of optical images in texture and semantic representation, along with the complementary structural and elevation information from the digital surface model (DSM). This enables the effective extraction and combination of global and local complementary information to achieve higher accuracy and robustness in semantic segmentation. Specifically, we propose a progressive cross-modal feature interaction mechanism (PCMFI) in the encoder. It integrates the fine-grained textures and semantic information of optical images with the structural boundaries and spatial information of DSM, thereby facilitating more precise cross-modal feature interaction. Secondly, we design an adaptive dual-stream Mamba cross-modal fusion module (ADMCF), which leverages a learnable variable mechanism to deeply represent global semantic and spatial structural information. This enhances deep semantic feature interaction and improves the ability of model to distinguish complex land cover categories. Together, these modules progressively refine cross-modal cues and strengthen semantic interactions, enabling more coherent and discriminative multimodal fusion. Finally, we introduce a global-local feature decoder to effectively integrate the global and local information from the fused multimodal features. It preserves the structural integrity of target objects while enhancing edge detail representation, thus enhancing segmentation results. Through rigorous testing on standard datasets like ISPRS Vaihingen and Potsdam, the proposed HACMNet demonstrates advantages over prevailing methods in multimodal remote sensing analysis, particularly on challenging object classes.

title: ICECCME 2025 TOC
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)

title: Efficient Control and Data Processing of Drone-Borne SAR on Xilinx Kria K26 SOM
authors: E. E. S. Andrade, A. A. Santos, H. E. Hernandez-Figueroa
abstract: The use of Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) in Class 3 drones has gained significant interest for its ability to provide high-resolution images regardless of climate conditions or visibility. Integrating SAR control and data processing within the Xilinx Kria K26 System-On-Module (SOM) platform offers a compact, flexible, and efficient solution for embedded systems requiring highperformance processing and data storage. The K26 SOM demonstrates great potential for drone-borne SAR applications, thanks to its high processing power, low energy consumption, versatile I/O interface, and multiple storage options. However, its use in drone-based SAR systems remains under development and is primarily limited to specific niche applications. In this context, the K26 SOM efficiently handles SAR control and data processing tasks through its embedded Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA), multiple ARM core processors, and support for high-speed interfaces. It manages radar pulses, calibration, synchronization, and communication with other subsystems. Using its flexible I/O, the K26 SOM can configure radar components (antenna, modulator, amplifier), GPS (Global Positioning System), and IMU (Inertial Measurement Unit) via industry-standard protocols like Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI) and I2C. This paper presents a high-level implementation of the K26 SOM for drone-borne SAR applications, together with an analysis of expected SAR throughput and performance metrics.

title: Development of a Low-Cost System for Real-Time PV Curve Tracing and Health Diagnostics
authors: Saloua Yahyaoui, Abdelhak Aziz, Sanae Dahbi, Jalal Blaacha, Abdelhafid Messaoudi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: This article describes the development of a numerical real-time low-cost system for tracing the I-V and P-V characteristics of photovoltaic (PV) modules. It features a microcontroller, voltage and current sensors (LV25-P and LA55-P), and a Boost converter with PWM duty cycle control for dynamic load alteration. Compact and reliable design integration are achieved with the custom printed circuit board (PCB) design, which was developed in Altium Designer. Electrical data collection is done continuously and under varying duty cycles, enabling the full range capture of the PV module's electrical characteristics.Experimental validation was completed using a 180W PV panel in open sunlight. Implementation results verified the I-V and P-V curve tracing capabilities of the system, where a performance degradation of about 8.8% in maximum power point (MPP) was detected relative to simulation model predictions obtained using MATLAB Simulink. The results also capture a performance gap observation due to aging on PV module, which had been in operation for 30 years. These results emphasize the accuracy of the derived solution for real-time diagnostics, performance monitoring, aging analysis, and predictive maintenance, educational field testing, and maintenance forecasting.

title: Design and Simulation of PSO based Super-twisting SMC for High Speed Pick and Place Industrial SCARA Robot
authors: Mersha Kasaw Aderajew, Yayachew Mandefro Terlla, Emiyamrew Azmeraw Damtew, Habtamu Maru Yaried, Wondimu Bantihun Demlew
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: This paper presents the design and simulation of PSO based super-twisting sliding mode control (STSMC) for high speed pick and place industrial robot, which aims to derive the manipulator trajectories along the desired location, very precisely with a fast convergence. The complete dynamic model of a manipulator with DC motor actuators has been obtained by Euler-Lagrange technique. Several researchers have been proposed on a SCARA robot that utilizes sliding mode control techniques to address position control issues. However, it’s important to note that SMC can introduce a chattering effect when specific settings are chosen. In this work, STSMC techniques are used to reduce the chatter and particle swarm optimization (PSO) is employed to adjust the control settings. Dynamic performance and robustness characteristics of PSO-STSMC technique were compared with STSMC and PSO-SMC, to validate the effectiveness of suggested optimal controller. Decisively, this approach effectively mitigates chattering effects in control signal with a minimum tracking error (3.1 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−7</sup> rad for joint-1, 1.4 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−6</sup> rad for joint-2, 5.2 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−7</sup> rad for joint-3 and 4.4 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−7</sup> rad for joint-4). This study underscores the significance of PSO-STSMC in advancing robust trajectory tracking control.

title: A Novel RFID Bidirectional Displacement Detection Sensor with 2-Bit Reconfigurable Coding Units
authors: Zhuang Xu, Ya Ming Xie, Guo Chun Wan
abstract: The structural connection gaps in modern large-scale building facilities may experience minor displacements due to various vibrations, leading to structural damage. This paper proposes a novel 2-bit RFID bidirectional displacement detection sensor with reconfigurable coding capabilities, designed to measure small displacement changes within structures. The sensor substrate is made of FR-4 material, offering the advantage of low cost, making it suitable for extensive deployment in buildings. Compared to traditional unidirectional displacement monitoring systems, this sensor can detect displacement changes in both horizontal and vertical directions, providing better application capabilities. It operates at a frequency range of 500 MHz to 2.5 GHz, and the displacement values in both directions exhibit a good linear relationship with the resonant frequency. Additionally, the design of the 2 -bit reconfigurable coding unit facilitates sensor positioning and identification in multi-sensor deployment scenarios. Combining the displacement sensor with the coding unit offers an effective method for structural health monitoring of large buildings.

title: A Soil Science Rover: An Intelligent Agricultural Autonomous Ground Mobile Robot
authors: MD. Ragib Aunjum, Ali Ahsan, Zareef Jafar, KM Fahim Mahmud, Razin Bin Issa, MD. Mahbub Ali, S. M. Masrur Ahmed, Mohammad Zahirul Islam, Zaber Mohammad, Musa Al Johan, MD. Saiful Islam, MD. Golam Rabiul Alam, MD. Khalilur Rhaman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and computer vision in agricultural scenarios provides a significant advancement in crop monitoring, autonomous navigation, and disease detection. The following research proposed a system to improve agricultural automation incorporated with deep learning-based object detection models such as RCNN, ResNet50, and DenseNet121. Using computer vision models, this research aims to optimize the identification of potential obstacles and crops in farming environments. Moreover, this research justified the role of autonomous ground robots for navigation, path planning, and real-time decision making. The following study evaluates existing methodologies and presents an improved framework that combines deep learning architectures with robotic perception systems to enhance agricultural automation. Furthermore, a Soil Science Rover Test Module (SSRTM) has been proposed in this study, which is responsible for in-situ soil analysis focusing on moisture percentage, pH levels, and nutrient composition. Experimental results justified the effectiveness of the proposed systems in real-life scenarios. This research contributes to the growing field of AI-driven precision agriculture, which will eventually come up with intelligent and fully autonomous farming systems.

title: Fast Extraction of Chip Thermal Resistances for Advanced Packaging Design
authors: Boyuan Yu, Zhixiao Jiang, Zuochang Ye, Shunfeng Han, Bofu Li, Dejian Li, Wenjian Yu
abstract: Advanced packaging technology does not only improve product performance but also decreases costs. Therefore, it is one of the most promising directions of the development of integrated circuit and system. During the design and optimization of advanced packaging, it is necessary to repeatedly evaluate the heat dissipation capability of the chip packaging. For this purpose, the model with chip thermal resistances becomes an effective tool for the heat dissipation evaluation. In order to extract the thermal resistances accurately, the multi-physics simulation involving fluid is usually performed, but incurs large computational time. In this work, we propose a fast approach for extracting the junction-to-ambient thermal resistance in advanced packaging. It considers a simplified computational model with only solid components, where the effects of fluid are reflected by the convective boundary condition. To ensure good accuracy, the convective coefficient is set through a curve fitting approach based on the results from a couple of multi-physics simulations, for considering the influence of ambient temperature and chip power consumption. With this simplified model, the chip resistances can be fast extracted by a finite element method (FEM) based solver. Experiments with different packaging styles show that the proposed method is about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \times$</tex> faster than ANSYS Icepak, with little accuracy sacrifice. It is also demonstrated that the proposed method has good generality so as to accelerate the packaging design and optimization.

title: Feature Selection Based on Evidence Combination Rule for Label Distribution
authors: Rongrong Wang, Eric C.C. Tsang, Weihua Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: In label distribution learning, feature selection methods for dimensionality reduction play a crucial role. This paper proposes a label distribution feature selection algorithm based on Dempster-Shafer evidence theory. The method combines rough set approximation with evidential reasoning to enhance feature selection performance. Specifically, the direct correlation between features and labels is first quantified using an improved rough set positive region measure for dependency degree computation. Subsequently, a label correlation matrix is constructed to generate enhanced feature importance scores through a weighted fusion strategy. Building upon this foundation, an uncertainty parameter is introduced to transform the weighted scores into probabilistically interpretable basic probability assignments. An improved Dempster’s combination rule is designed to effectively aggregate cross-sample evidence. To quantify feature importance, belief and plausibility functions are further derived, ultimately forming a dual-dimensional evaluation metric that incorporates both credibility and likelihood measures. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms other comparative algorithms on five datasets, effectively capturing feature-label correlations and demonstrating strong applicability in complex label distribution scenarios.

title: Fluorescent Antennas/Concentrators in Optical Wireless Communications: A Review
authors: Cuiwei He, Ke Wang
abstract: This paper provides a brief review of recent advancements in fluorescent concentrators, also known as fluorescent antennas, for optical wireless communication (OWC). It highlights key parameters, such as the photoluminescence (PL) lifetime of the fluorophore and the concentration gain of the antenna, in the design of a fluorescent antenna. Additionally, it discusses advanced techniques, such as Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET), and their potential to significantly enhance antenna performance. Finally, the paper explores the opportunities and challenges associated with using fluorescent antennas for wavelength-division multiplexing (WDM) in OWC transmission.

title: Agricultural Plant Disease Detection using Machine Learning techniques
authors: Roxana Rusu-Both, Mihai-Sebastian Voina
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Early detection of plant diseases is crucial for reducing economic losses and ensuring global food security. Traditional visual inspections by farmers are subjective and time-consuming, prompting the need for automated solutions. This paper presents a machine learning-based system for identifying and classifying plant leaf diseases using convolutional neural networks (CNNs). We describe the preprocessing, augmentation, and segmentation techniques employed to enhance data quality and improve model performance. Our experiments, conducted on a dataset of 90,000 images across 38 classes, achieved a training accuracy and a validation accuracy above 98% The system also features an intuitive web interface for practical deployment, supporting real-time detection in agricultural fields.

title: Engineering Interoperability in IEC 61850-Based Substations: A Lab-Based Investigation of Top-Down and Bottom-Up Approaches
authors: Liam O Sullivan, Michael O Donovan
abstract: IEC 61850 has introduced a unified framework for substation automation by standardising communication protocols, data modelling, and engineering processes. However, the practical implementation of this approach continues to face interoperability challenges, particularly when integrating intelligent electronic devices (IEDs) from multiple vendors. This paper presents findings from a lab-based digital substation environment that included ABB and Siemens devices, highlighting issues such as schema mismatches, Substation Configuration Language (SCL) file incompatibilities, and vendor tool limitations. A hybrid engineering methodology is proposed as a practical solution, combining top-down configuration using a central Substation Configuration Description (SCD) file with refinement of device-specific Instantiated IED Description (IID) files. Continuous validation using tools like Wireshark, StationScout, and IEDScout proved essential in verifying communication quality and time synchronisation. The study also emphasises the importance of workforce readiness, recommending structured training programs such as the postgraduate offering at Munster Technological University (MTU) to address skills gaps in IEC 61850-based system design. The paper concludes that achieving true interoperability requires more than adherence to the IEC 61850 standard—it demands coordinated engineering strategies, rigorous testing practices, and investment in human capital.

title: Analysis of SSH Attack Frequency on Standard and Non-standard Ports in IPv4 and IPv6
authors: Dominik Hrinkino, Ladislav Huraj, Marek Šimon
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper focuses on analyzing attacks targeting SSH services that are exposed to the public internet. For this study, we used the Cowrie honeypot, which we deployed with various SSH port configurations to evaluate the impact of port selection on the frequency of attacks. The experiment lasted for one month, during which we monitored six devices running an active SSH honeypot. The first device operated on the standard TCP port 22, the second used the commonly known alternative TCP port 2222, which is often seen in practice, and the third device ran on a non-standard, unprivileged TCP port 65100. We also replicated this setup for IPv6 as well. This study aimed to investigate whether the number and nature of attacks on the SSH service vary depending on the selected port. In the final part of the paper, we present the results of our measurements and assess the effectiveness of the “security through obscurity” strategy, particularly the use of a non-standard port for a service that remains publicly accessible from the internet.

title: Bio-Inspired Fractal Antireflective Microwave Metasurface Structures
authors: Aneena Jaison, Natesan Yogesh
abstract: Biological systems have highly specialized periodic structures that support functions like enhanced photosynthesis, light trapping and antireflection functionalities. Conventional antireflective films often show a low transmission, which can be improved by incorporating bio-inspired periodic structures. Fractals, a self-similar geometry, are one of the most promising structural designs inspired by leaves of ferns. Due to its high branching and increase in surface area, fractal structure controls scattering of electromagnetic waves and minimizes losses. In this work, we realize a bio-inspired anti-reflective metasurface in microwave regime. The dielectric material glass is used as the fractal pattern on the top of the silicon substrate is designed. While the conventional antireflection films show transmission above 95%, the proposed design shows a maximum transmission and minimum reflection of about 99.9% and 0.1% respectively at 8.39 GHz for normal incident transverse electric (TE) and transverse magnetic (TM) polarizations. Thus, our proposed antireflective fractal metasurface is useful for concealment and energy storage applications at microwave frequencies.

title: Performance Evaluation of AODV, Monte Carlo and Deep Q-Learning Routing in Mobile Ad Hoc Networks
authors: Jozef Badár, Ján Papaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper presents a comparison of the AODV routing protocol with two reinforcement-learning approaches—Monte Carlo and Deep Q-Learning—in mobile ad hoc networks. The simulations were performed using the NS-3 simulator across various network configurations and node densities. Performance was evaluated in terms of packet delivery ratio, throughput, and average delay.The results showed that Deep Q-Learning achieved the best performance in most configurations and metrics, especially at higher node densities, compared with both the AODV protocol and the Monte Carlo method. While the magnitude of the differences varied across specific settings, the overall trend consistently favored Deep Q-Learning. These findings confirm the potential of AI techniques for adaptive routing in dynamic network environments.

title: Modular Enhancement of Oneformer via Cbam-Augmented Fastervit for Semantic Segmentation
authors: Meehir Mahendra Mhatre, Li Zhang, Stuart Rothnie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics (ICMLC)
abstract: Transformer-based segmentation models like OneFormer offer strong performance but remain computationally expensive for real-time and resource-limited settings. In this preliminary work, we propose a modular enhancement of OneFormer by integrating the efficient FasterViT backbone and lightweight CBAM (Convolutional Block Attention Modules). FasterViT introduces Hierarchical Attention for scalable, high-resolution processing, while CBAM enhances feature saliency through spatial and channel-wise attention strategies. We apply CBAM after the initial convolutional stage of the encoder and at the pixel decoder’s input projections without altering core architecture preserving pretraining compatibility. Evaluated on the Cityscapes dataset, our approach achieves a promising 77.18 % mean IoU across 19 classes despite limited training resources. These results indicate that hybrid transformers combined with modular attention can provide an effective path toward lightweight, scalable segmentation models.

title: An Integrated Photovoltaic Thermal Smart Energy Station
authors: Temitope Johnson, Tamer Kamel, David Jenkins, Gary Millar
abstract: Since their invention, photovoltaic (PV) cells have undergone significant technological advancements, emerging as one of the most accessible sources of clean energy with an effectively infinite fuel supply. However, PV technology continues to face a critical challenge; a decline in efficiency as operating temperatures rise above 25°C. This research aims to mitigate the impact of elevated temperatures on PV panels by investigating the phase change materials (PCMs) for temperature control of the PV panels and release their generated heat to PCMs as heat collection and temporary storage units. Consequently, the heat can be then transferred from the temporary storage point to a long-term heat storage in Zeolite materials through supply-air duct to enable forced convection heat transfer via moving air. Furthermore, this research also explores the maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms to harvest the maximum electrical power from the PV panels and then regulate this power to integrate with a DC microgrid of 48V by controlling power electronic converters at various environmental and operational conditions. The proposed demonstration offers a cheap and effective solution to regulate the PV’s temperature to achieve optimal performance and storing the excess heat for other domestic applications. It is also modular to accommodate different energy aspects as battery storage or fuel cells and allows for peer-to-peer selling of energies.

title: ADFL-DSV: An Adaptive Dynamic Federated Learning Aggregation Based on Shapley Value
authors: Jiawen Wu, Geming Xia, Hongwei Huang, Chaodong Yu, Yuze Zhang, Hongfeng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: The field of medical diagnostics is undergoing an AI-driven transformation from traditional centralized laboratory testing to instantaneous testing. Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a pivotal technique in medical image feature engineering. However, medical FL faces challenges such as vulnerability to data poisoning and inefficiency in handling dynamic class distribution changes in dynamic and noisy environments. To address these issues, we propose a dynamic FL framework called ADFL-DSV. The framework introduces a class-specific Shapley computation method for dynamically evaluating the contributions of clients during training. To enhance robustness in dynamic environments, we also develop an adaptive weighting mechanism inspired by dynamic Shapley values. Additionally, we accelerate the sampling process using client-importance sampling, optimizing the global update variance based on client weights and reducing communication costs. We validate our approach on several real datasets, outperforming benchmark approaches by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 \%}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 4 \%}$</tex> in terms of performance.

title: CANA: Enhancing Graph-Based Fraud Detection via Confidence-Aware Neighborhood Aggregation
authors: Zujia Wang, Jianqi Gao, Hang Yu, Zhengyang Liu, Junquan Gu, Xiangfeng Luo, Xue Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: In graph-based fraud detection, accurately distinguishing between normal and anomalous account nodes is crucial. Recent graph-based approaches have achieved remarkable progress, primarily by aggregating neighborhood information to learn node representations and enhance model discriminability. However, most existing methods employ a unified aggregation function to neighbors with different class labels, which weakens feature differences and allows anomalous node features to be obscured by normal ones, leading to representation contamination. Moreover, existing methods assign uniform confidence weights to all labeled nodes during training, without accounting for label quality differences caused by varying distances to the decision boundary, which weakens the robustness of model learning. To overcome these limitations, we propose a novel method named Confidence-Aware Neighborhood Aggregation (CANA). CANA introduces a category-aware aggregation mechanism that performs separate aggregation operations for normal, anomalous, and unlabeled neighbors, thereby mitigating the issue of representation contamination. In addition, CANA incorporates a confidence-aware node-reweighted learning objective function, which dynamically adjusts the confidence weights of the labeled nodes based on a confidence metric computed through controlled perturbations in neighbors and prediction accuracy, thus improving the model's ability to leverage high quality labeled nodes and improving its learning capability and classification performance. Specifically, the function includes two optional perturbation strategies, namely Homo-Hetero Neighbor Perturbation (HHNP) and Robust Neighbor Perturbation (RNP). Extensive evaluations of four public benchmark datasets underscore the superiority of CANA over current state-of-the-art methods.

title: Identification of Key Gene Modules and Hub Genes of Glioblastoma Using Machine-learning and WGCNA Algorithm
authors: Yiqin Wang, Xinquan Li, Yuqian Fu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Glioblastoma, the most aggressive form of primary brain tumors, presents significant challenges in treatment due to its poor prognosis and resistance to conventional therapies. This study employed an integrated approach combining machine learning techniques with Weighted Gene Correlation Network Analysis (WGCNA) to identify hub genes and explore key gene modules in glioblastoma. Analysis of the GEO dataset GSE147352 yielded 89 common differentially expressed genes (DEGs) across normal brain tissues, lower-grade gliomas, and glioblastomas. Through Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) and validation using multiple machine learning models including Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest, and Decision Tree, 11 key genes were identified with high classification accuracy (SVM accuracy: 0.9655). WGCNA analysis revealed the black module as crucial, containing five hub genes: HOTAIRM1, SERPINE1, CD44, HOXC4, and SPOCD1. Functional annotation of the 971 genes in the black module highlighted significant enrichment in cell adhesion, hypoxia response, and extracellular matrix-related processes. KEGG pathway analysis further revealed enrichment in adhesion, junction, and proteoglycan-related pathways. This study establishes a novel workflow combining machine learning and WGCNA for hub gene identification and provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying glioblastoma development, potentially contributing to future therapeutic strategies.

title: Based on Multimodal Radiradiomics PET/MR in Predicting the Staging of Cervical Cancer
authors: Guoxiu Lu, Chang Zhao, Yijia Zhao, Jiezi Xiang, Guoxu Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Objective: To explore and compare the predictive value of the classification model constructed based on PET/MR multimodal imaging radiomics technology for the imaging staging of cervical cancer. Methods: In this study, 135 cervical cancer patients undergoingPET/MRexamination in our hospital from January 2021 to January 2025 were retrospective analyzed and randomly divided into training set and test set according to the ratio of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6: 4$</tex>. And the clinical characteristics of these patients were collected. Based on PET, T1WI, CE-T1WI and DWI images, the optimal radiomics features were extracted and selected, including LR, RF, SGD and SVM. PET, T1WI CE-T1WI DWI and PET/MR fusion models, and added the clinical combination model to predict clinical stage. Draw the receiver working curve, evaluate the model performance by sensitivity, specificity and AUC; draw the DCA curve and calibration curve, evaluate the model strength and clinical relevance; and compare the model performance difference by Delong test. Results: A total of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 2}$</tex> patients were included in this study according to the Na discharge criteria. According to the 2018 FIGO stage criteria and pathological data, stage FIGO IA to IIA patients were included in the early group (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=14$</tex>) and stage FIGO IIB to IVB group <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{n}=28)$</tex>. The AUC values of the PET, T1WI CET1WI DWI, PET/MR, and clinical and PET/MR-clinical combination models in the training set were <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.949,0.930,0.941,0.941,0.961,0.983,0.933$</tex>, respectively, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.791,0.801,0.725,0.768,0.867,0.853,0.893$</tex> in the test set, respectively. In the training set and the AUC value of the PET/MR imaging-clinical combination model was higher than that of the other models, and the decision curve showed that the net clinical benefit of the combination model was high and stable.
