title: Efficient Lightweight Coordinated Sampling for Dynamic Flows: Theory and Implementation
authors: Mingming Chen, Thomas F. La Porta, Trent Jaeger, Srikanth V. Krishnamurthy
abstract: As cyber-attacks on networks become stealthier, monitoring techniques relying on low-rate packet sampling may prove insufficient to detect attacks. While various methods, such as truncating packets, flow-based sampling, and adaptive sampling rates, have been proposed to enhance detection rates and ease capability limitations, it remains challenging to perform sufficient sampling at line speed and high rates at a single sampling point due to limited CPU or bandwidth capacity and fluctuating network traffic. To address these challenges, we propose CoordSamp, a system that distributes the sampling workload across multiple sampling points and coordinates their actions to avoid duplicate sampling of the same packet. This design enables scalable, resource-aware monitoring—particularly suited for dynamic, agentless cloud-based environments—relying solely on network-level deployment that can be dynamically assigned and adjusted by the provider. We develop a coordinated sampling algorithm on multiple P4-programmable switches and show that the algorithm ensures coordination among multiple sampling points for each flow, preventing duplicate samples, with negligible network overhead and real-time configurability. At its core, CoordSamp separates offline placement—the budgeted selection of sampling points—from online allocation—the capacity-aware assignment of sampling tasks—allowing practical deployment in hybrid networks that combine programmable and legacy switches. We formulate sampling point placement as budgeted maximum multi-coverage problems, solving them optimally in pseudo-polynomial time. Our system far outperforms those based on greedy placement along many key dimensions.

title: Automated Placental ROI Selection for Quantitative Ultrasound Analysis Using Boundary-Aware Thresholding
authors: William Hempstead, Hamid Moradi, Atugonza Gamukama, Bashir Ssuna, Winfred Nakato Nansozi, Eunice Namwase, Nabafu Flavia, Aris T. Papageorghiou, Sam Ali, Robert N. Rohling, Farah Deeba
abstract: Quantitative ultrasound (QUS) analysis of placental tissue holds significant promise for evaluating pregnancy health and detecting placental pathologies. However, widespread clinical adoption of QUS is limited by the need for manual selection of a proper region of interest (ROI) for the calculation, which increases the analysis time and introduces operator variability. This study presents an automated ROI determination method that uses deep learning segmentation directly on minimally processed raw RF data (along with corresponding B-mode data for comparison) to replace manual ROI selection in placental QUS analysis while also taking advantage of the model’s internal confidence thresholds to reduce inclusion of non-placental tissue near ambiguous tissue boundaries. Using a diverse, multi-national data set of 1084 annotated ultrasound images, the proposed automated ROI model achieved a mean Dice similarity coefficient (DSC) above 0.8 for confidence thresholds between 50% to 75%. At thresholds above 75%, precision improved, but both DSC and recall performance declined, and the amount of placental tissue identified for an accurate QUS calculation fell below the minimum required ROI size. Bland-Altman analysis showed tight agreement between the QUS values derived from ground truth ROIs and automated ROIs up to a 75% confidence threshold, but reduced agreement at higher thresholds, consistent with inferior performance obtained for placental pixel area below the minimum. These findings demonstrate both the feasibility of automated ROI determination and the need for careful consideration of the confidence thresholds when assessing model performance.

title: Data-Driven Fault Detection via Invertible Neural Network for Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor Drive System
authors: Yunfei Ju, Shenquan Wang, Chao Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Reconstructing process variables from latent variables is a well-established approach for fault detection (FD). This method has been extensively applied in FD tasks for permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) drive systems. However, recent studies have primarily focused on application-oriented designs, often overlooking the intrinsic relationship between latent and process variables. To address this gap, this paper proposes an invertible neural network (INN)-based FD method specifically designed for PMSM drive systems. The distributional relationship between process variables and latent variables is rigorously established using an INN in conjunction with the change-of-variables formula. The main objectives of this work are threefold: 1) To propose a modeling approach for PMSM drive systems based on composite nonlinear mappings; 2) To develop an INN-based framework that facilitates bidirectional mapping between process variables and latent variables; 3) To integrate a residual generative module into the INN architecture to enable effective FD in PMSM drive systems. The proposed method is validated on a PMSM system, demonstrating its effectiveness in practical FD scenarios.

title: Reliability Analysis of Strain Gauge-Based Pressure Sensors Integrated in Stored Weapon Systems
authors: Praveen Tandon, Narendar Vadthiya
abstract: Many military weapon systems used for the battlefield are to be stored longer before they launch from aircraft, ships, or land. These weapon systems are subjected to extreme stresses from long-term exposure in harsh environments, which affects their total life cycle and reliability. A thorough reliability analysis of weapon-integrated pressure sensors exposed to environmental stresses during long-term storage and transportation, emphasizing performance drift and ageing, is presented in this article. Laboratory experiments were conducted under controlled conditions simulating climatic and dynamic stresses as per MIL-STD-810H. Furthermore, it has been demonstrated how to use interval-censored field failure data to estimate the life distribution of a population in service, where pressor sensors encounter varying stress levels over time, and to determine key reliability metrics, including failure rate, mean time to failure, and probability over a 10-year storage period. The study offers quantitative insights into stress-related deterioration, supporting the development of condition-based calibration strategies, predictive maintenance planning, and robust sensor designs suitable for extended military storage applications.

title: Wide-Temperature Digital Calibration Method for GaAs Hall Current Sensor with Integrated Current Conductor
authors: Zicai Yang, Tian Qiang, Pingping Yu, Mengye Cai, Yanfeng Jiang
abstract: Hall current sensors suffer from severe measurement inaccuracies over wide temperature range due to sensitivity drift, offset variation, and nonlinear errors. To address these issues, GaAs Hall current sensor with integrated current conductor incorporating a wide-temperature digital calibration method is proposed and verified in the paper. Firstly, a three-dimensional electro-magnetic-thermal coupled model of GaAs Hall element is established to accurately simulate temperature-dependent characteristics. Based on the modeling and experimental validation, an integrated current conductor packaging structure is optimized through structural simulation, eliminating bulky magnetic concentrators and ensuring stable flux concentration from -40 °C to 150 °C. Furthermore, a signal conditioning chip is developed with integrated digital calibration, including a rotating current module for offset suppression, a three-stage programmable amplifier for dynamic sensitivity adjustment, and a polynomial-based temperature compensation algorithm for correcting both sensitivity and static voltage drift. Experimental results confirm that the proposed calibration method effectively suppresses temperature-induced errors, maintaining the sensor error within ±0.3% of the full scale (±20 A) across -40 °C to 150 °C. Compared with conventional analog or narrow-range calibration methods, the proposed approach achieves higher accuracy, enhanced reliability, and extended applicability under extreme temperature conditions, making it suitable for high-precision current sensing in industrial and automotive applications.

title: Data-Driven Discrete-Time Linear Output Regulation With Unknown System Matrices
authors: Zitao Chen, Simone Baldi, Wenwu Yu
abstract: This article investigates a data-driven method to solve the discrete-time linear output regulation problem. Different from existing learning-based data-driven solutions, we adopt the Fundamental Lemma perspective, which reduces the level of excitation required on data. The solution in this work handles unknown system matrices: only knowledge of the exosystem matrix is required, an assumption standard in data-driven approaches. The data-driven output regulation problem is first transformed into a convex semi-definite program: then, necessary and sufficient analysis shows that the solvability of the output regulation problem and of the semi-definite program are equivalent. The proposed approach also allows to impose a performance index for the regulated error in terms of specified convergence rate, without additional requirements on data.

title: EIC Interaction Region Magnet Design Overview
authors: M. Anerella Anerella, V. Aleaga, Y. Bai, J. Becker, A. Ben Yahia, J. Cozzolino, A. Drees, R. Gupta, C. Hetzel, H. Hocker, P. Kovach, M. Kumar, F. Kurian, J. McNaughton, H. Oza, B. Parker, C. Runyan, J. Schmalzle, V. Teotia, W. Wahl, H. Witte
abstract: Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) was chosen to host the international Electron-Ion Collider (EIC), which will collide high energy and highly polarized hadron and electron beams with a center of mass energy up to 140 GeV. The Interaction Region (IR) requires several large aperture, relatively high field superconducting dipole and quadrupole magnets, some of which are very closely spaced. This paper describes the overall design philosophy of the fourteen one-of-a-kind, unique superconducting magnets in the IR on both sides of the EIC detector. A summary of the style chosen for each of the magnets with design rationalizations will be presented. The impact of the very tightly spaced, consistently off axis layout of forward side hadron magnets, from which difficulties result will be described. The many internal interfaces (vacuum, instrumentation, cryogenics, power supplies, detector, etc.) and associated issues thereof will be discussed. Installation issues and plans to date will be shown.

title: Optimal Transport Regularization for Simulation-Informed Room Impulse Response Estimation
authors: Anton Björkman, David Sundström, Andreas Jakobsson, Filip Elvander
abstract: Many audio applications, including echocancellation and active noise control, rely on the availability of accurately estimated room impulse responses (RIRs). For these applications, it is common that the source signal is short and primarily consists of speech or music, which may cause the estimation of the RIR to be poorly conditioned. Although priors on the amplitudes of the RIR could in principle be used to resolve the conditioning issue, there are situations where also the delay structure of the RIR is uncertain. In particular, we here consider when the prior is a simulated RIR obtained from a 3D-reconstruction of the room, from where uncertainties in the geometry, speed of sound, and the source and receiver positions all cause uncertainties in the delay structure of the simulated RIR. By considering such sources of error, we derive two robust regularizers for RIR estimation based on the concept of optimal transport. For each estimator, an efficient solver is proposed based on proximal splitting and Sinkhorn-type iterations. From numerical experiments on real data, we find that when only the uncertainty in the amplitude structure is considered in the regularizer, the simulated prior can in fact worsen the estimation as compared to the Tikhonov and Lasso estimators. Interestingly enough, when robustness for uncertainties in the delay structure is also introduced using the proposed regularizers, even the most naive room model, i.e., a shoe-box approximation, can significantly improve the estimate.

title: Equivariant Filter for Relative Attitude and Target Angular Velocity Estimation_supp1-3643413.pdf
authors: GIL SERRANO
abstract: Accurate estimation of the relative attitude and angular velocity between two rigid bodies is fundamental in aerospace applications such as spacecraft rendezvous and docking. In these scenarios, a chaser vehicle must determine the orientation and angular velocity of a target object using onboard sensors. This work addresses the challenge of designing an Equivariant Filter (EqF) that can reliably estimate both the relative attitude and the target angular velocity using noisy observations of two known, non-collinear vectors fixed in the target frame. To derive the EqF, a symmetry for the system is proposed and an equivariant lift onto the symmetry group is calculated. Observability and convergence properties are analyzed. Simulations demonstrate the filter's performance, with Monte Carlo runs yielding statistically significant results. The impact of low-rate measurements is also examined and a strategy to mitigate this effect is proposed. Experimental results, using fiducial markers and both conventional and event cameras for measurement acquisition, further validate the approach, confirming its effectiveness in a realistic setting.

title: A CNN for Ocean Parameter Retrieval Based on Space-Frequency Fusion
authors: Xuan Jin, Yawei Zhao, Jinsong Chong
abstract: With the rise of deep learning, an increasing number of deep learning methods have been applied to the field of Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) ocean parameters retrieval, yielding many promising results. Normalized radar cross section (NRCS) of SAR images and SAR image spectra respectively provide descriptions of sea states from the space and frequency domains, which are beneficial for constructing more accurate models for significant wave height (SWH) retrieval. To make the most of SAR data's space and frequency domain characteristics, this study develops a CNN-based approach for SWH retrieval, which fuses spatial and frequency information effectively. The model automatically extracts robust features from both the space and frequency domains through dual-branch convolutional layers. Shallow features from both the space and frequency domains are enhanced and fused by employing the feature cross fusion module (FCFM). Subsequently, the learnable weighted fusion module (LWFM) is applied to perform a weighted fusion of deep features from these domains, leading to the development of a high-precision SAR SWH retrieval model. Most models based on the GF-3 SAR data focus on wave mode, with limited utilization of other imaging modes. To develop a model applicable to various imaging modes, this study collects GF-3 SAR data from different imaging modes, such as SS, UFS, and FSII, and matches them with the fifthgeneration European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts reanalysis data (ERA5) to train and evaluate the model. The comparative analysis demonstrates that the proposed model performs well on the ERA5 test dataset, thereby certifying its effectiveness.

title: Precise Blood Cancer Detection Using GANs and Cross-Modality Data Integration for Optimal Diagnostics
authors: Gulbakshee J. Dharmale, Rakhi S. Pagar, Shradha A. Tawade, Shweta S. Devdas, Sphurti M. Deshmukh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Blood cancers are a group of complex disorders that impact the blood, bone marrow, and lymphatic system, including categories such as leukemia, lymphoma, and myeloma. This study focuses on developing an image-based classification system to identify different types and subtypes of blood cancers. It utilizes microscopic images of blood smears as the primary data source. To improve the resolution and overall quality of these medical images, an Enhanced Super-Resolution Generative Adversarial Network (ESRGAN) is applied before blood cancer prediction and analysis. The high-resolution images generated from ESRGAN are then fed into a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), which is trained to predict cancer categories based on image patterns. This approach aims to improve diagnostic accuracy and help healthcare professionals in making better decisions and evaluation.

title: Glaucoma Classification Using Machine Learning
authors: Ranjana Gore, Jayashree Prasad, Himani Dhakad, Shubham Patane, Saloni Deshmukh, Sucheta Kulkarni, Ashwini Gaikwad, Rohit Deshmukh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Glaucoma is an eye disease which may cause permanent blindness so its early diagnosis is critical to prevent vision loss. This study presents a machine learning-based approach for the detection of glaucoma using digital fundus images collected from H. V. Desai Hospital, Pune. The proposed methodology includes preprocessing, feature extraction, model building, then results and evaluation. The set of statistical features like mean, minimum, maximum, standard deviation, structural features like edge density, and texture-based features are extracted. These features are used to train and evaluate a Support Vector Machine classifier. The initial model using a radial basis kernel function achieved an accuracy of 50 %, which improved to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 2 \%}$</tex> using a sigmoid function. Further fine-tuning with feature enhancement and hyperparameter tuning led to a final classification accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{7 5 \%} \%$</tex>, demonstrating the model's effectiveness in detecting glaucoma from real-world fundus imagery.

title: A Novel Voice-Processing Method Leveraging Polyphonic Audio for Instrument Recognition Using Machine Learning
authors: Supriya Telsang, Tanishka Phad, Mohit Pingale, Prachi Singh, Aditya Pillay, Piyush Lohar, Mohit Pilgonde, Prakhar Raj
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: In this research, a novel polyphonic voice recognition system for instrument identification, pitch detection, and chord detection based on machine learning techniques is presented. The system utilizes python and its large set of data analytics libraries to provide efficient and realistic audio recognition. Some of the main techniques involve Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCC) for feature extraction and classification models like <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-nearest neighbors (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k-N N$</tex>) and hidden Markov models (hmm). MFCC s have been used to efficiently extract the spectral features of the audio signals, whereas K-NN classifiers (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k=3$</tex>) and hmm models (8 gaussian states) yield high instrument identification and sequential pattern audio analysis. The system also presents high accuracies of 58% using K-NN and 67% using hmm in classifying 8 instruments namely acoustic guitar, bass drum, cello, clarinet, double bass, flute, hi hat, saxophone, snare drum, violin. A stratified shuffle split strategy and a balanced dataset guarantee fair training and testing. The frontend, coded in html, CSS, and JavaScript, supports dynamic audio visualization and easy user interaction through web audio Api, whereas the backend, implemented with python and flask, processes real-time audio and machine learning operations. Iterative feedback-based updates enhance system flexibility even further, which makes it worthwhile for use in music education, production, transcription, and research applications. In spite of difficulties in overlapping sound separation and intricate polyphonic audio analysis, this research emphasizes the revolutionary potential of intelligent audio processing in developing music technology.

title: Dynamic Price Prediction of Pre-Owned Automobiles Using Machine Learning (ML)
authors: Nitish Yadav, Sanika R. Jagtap, Vikas Yadav, Aditya Darde, Uttara Varade, Sagar Shinde
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The growing demand for used cars has made it important to accurately estimate their resale value. Predicting the price of a pre-owned automobile is a challenging task, as it depends on multiple factors such as the car's age, model, fuel type, kilometres driven, transmission type, and more. Traditional methods often rely on manual inspection or basic pricing guides, which can lead to inconsistent and inaccurate results. In this study, we explore the use of machine learning algorithms to predict the price of second-hand cars by analysing historical data. Various regression-based models like Linear Regression, Rigde Regression, Lasso Regression, Elastic Net, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, LightGBM, XGBoost, Support Vector Regressor, K-Neighbors and MLP Regressor are tested and compared for accuracy and performance. The dataset is cleaned, pre- processed, and used to train and evaluate these models. Our results show that machine learning, especially Random Forest, can predict car prices with high accuracy. We also discuss feature importance to understand which attributes influence the price the most. Overall, the approach provides a fast, data- driven, and reliable way to estimate the value of used automobiles.

title: Edge-optimized Lightweight and Transformer backbones for Real-Time Road Damage Detection in IIoT Systems
authors: Hafiz Muhammad Sanaullah Badar, Israr Hussain, Ali Kashif Bashir, Nazik Alturki, Gaojuan Fan, Chongsheng Zhang
abstract: Accurate and efficient road damage detection is critical for maintaining urban infrastructure and ensuring public safety in Intelligent Internet of Things (IIoT) systems. There remains a significant challenge to achieving a balance between detection accuracy and real-time inference on resource-constrained edge devices despite advances in deep learning. This paper addresses this gap by enhancing the YOLOv9c object detection framework with two distinct backbone architectures: MobileNet V3-Small, which is a lightweight convolutional neural network optimized for edge deployment, and Swin Transformer, which is a hierarchical vision transformer that captures rich contextual features. We present a systematic, dual-backbone performance benchmark that quantifies the critical trade-off between computational efficiency and detection precision, which is essential for guiding IIoT deployment strategies. We conducted experiments on the Street View Road Damage Detection (SVRDD) dataset to evaluate detection accuracy, computational efficiency, and latency. The MobileNet backbone achieves the highest mean Average Precision (mAP@0.5) of 74.0% (a 1.5% gain over baseline) and recall of 68.8% (a 7.3% gain over baseline), demonstrating improved accuracy while maintaining a low inference time on a baseline GPU, indicating its suitability for deployment on IoT edge devices. Importantly, the MobileNet variant reduces the parameter count from 25.6 M to 2.54 M and the Giga Floating-point Operations Per Second (GFLOPs) from 102.3 to 0.49, making it more efficient for IIoT edge devices. Both backbones performed better than the YOLOv9c baseline model in terms of accuracy, thus providing scalable and practical solutions for real-time infrastructure monitoring. These findings contribute to the development of intelligent, efficient, and scalable object detection systems tailored for smart city and IIoT environments.

title: Adaptive Fuzzy-Convolution and TSK-Guided Attention for Interpretable EEG MI Decoding
authors: Yingjie Sun, Jian Yao, Tao Chen, Kaijian Xia, Yizhang Jiang, Pengjiang Qian
abstract: Brain-computer Interface (BCI) technology enables direct communication between the brain and external devices via non-invasive methods and holds significant potential in neu roengineering, rehabilitation, and human-computer interaction. However, decoding motor imagery (MI) from electroencephalo gram (EEG) signals remains challenging due to these signals' non-stationary characteristics and the limited interpretability of existing deep learning models. In this paper, we propose a novel Hierarchical Collaborative Fuzzy Network (HCFN) for interpretable EEG-based MI decoding. We introduce an Adaptive Fuzzy Temporal Convolutional Network (AFTCN) that employs dynamic fuzzy kernels within causal convolutions to extract robust temporal features from EEG signals. Additionally, we design a fuzzy attention-guided Takagi–Sugeno–Kang (TSK) architecture that achieves a tighter integration between feature extraction and fuzzy inference through a novel fuzzy feedback loop, thereby improving the discriminability of extracted features. Extensive experiments on the BCI Competition IV-2a, IV-2b and OpenBMI datasets, under both subject-dependent and cross subject evaluation paradigms, demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms state-of-the-art methods in classification ac curacy and Cohen's kappa. Furthermore, we provide multi-level interpretability analyses, from macro to micro perspectives, elucidating the model's decision-making processes and highlighting the advantages of our collaborative reasoning framework over conventional cascaded approaches. The code is available at https://github.com/Pitiless-Quinn/HCFN.

title: Towards Robust Assessment of Pathological Voices via Combined Low-Level Descriptors and Foundation Model Representations
authors: Whenty Ariyanti, Kuan-Yu Chen, Sabato Marco Siniscalchi, Hsin-Min Wang, Yu Tsao
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Perceptual voice quality assessment plays a vital role in diagnosing and monitoring voice disorders. Traditional methods, such as the Consensus Auditory-Perceptual Evaluation of Voice (CAPE-V) and the Grade, Roughness, Breathiness, Asthenia, and Strain (GRBAS) scales, rely on expert raters and are prone to inter-rater variability, emphasizing the need for objective solutions. This study introduces the Voice Quality Assessment Network (VOQANet), a deep learning framework that employs an attention mechanism and Speech Foundation Model (SFM) embeddings to extract high-level features. To further enhance performance, we propose VOQANet+, which integrates self-supervised SFM embeddings with low-level acoustic descriptors-namely jitter, shimmer, and harmonics-to-noise ratio (HNR). Unlike previous approaches that focus solely on vowel-based phonation (PVQD-A), our models are evaluated on both vowel-level and sentence-level speech (PVQD-S) to assess generalizability. Experimental results demonstrate that sentence-based inputs yield higher accuracy, particularly at the patient level. Overall, VOQANet consistently outperforms baseline models in terms of root mean squared error (RMSE) and Pearson correlation coefficient across CAPE-V and GRBAS dimensions, with VOQANet+ achieving even greater performance gains. Additionally, VOQANet+ maintains consistent performance under noisy conditions, suggesting enhanced robustness for real-world and telehealth applications. This work highlights the value of combining SFM embeddings with low-level features for accurate and robust pathological voice assessment.

title: Connecting the Impact of Silent Data Corruption with Different Training Characteristics: An Empirical Study
authors: Hengzhi Pei, Leonard Lausen, George Karypis
abstract: Despite the non-negligible occurrence of Silent Data Corruption (SDC) during large-scale training of Large Language Models (LLMs), SDC impact on training lacks systematic understanding. This article empirically analyzes the connections between different training characteristics and the impact of SDC on LLM training. Using deterministic training workloads on real-world SDC-affected hardware, we quantify SDC impact by measuring the difference from the baselines on healthy hardware and provide insights into training robustness against SDC by systematically controlled experiments. We find that SDC impact correlates strongly with training stability and loss landscape regions, with Not-a-Number (NaN) occurring during training larger models. We further study if setting elementwise gradient bounds can mitigate SDC impact considering that SDC can change gradients by large magnitudes. Our results show that a proper bound can reduce the relative performance gap caused by SDC but cannot avoid SDC-induced NaN and may compromise training performance on healthy hardware.

title: Physically Based Simulation of Electromigration-Induced Hillock and Void Evolution in Cu Interconnects with Grain Morphology Considerations
authors: Han Jiang, Shuibao Liang, Yaohua Xu, Saranarayanan Ramachandran
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Electromigration-induced hillocks and voids in Cu interconnects pose increasingly significant reliability challenges to microelectronic devices, as device scaling and current density continue to rise in advanced integrated circuits. These defects can cause critical short-circuit and open-circuit failures. However, the quantitative mechanisms governing these failure modes remain insufficiently understood, limiting the precise prediction of defect morphology and growth dynamics. In this work, we develop a physically based phase field model to investigate the formation and evolution of hillocks and voids in Cu interconnects under electric current stressing, incorporating the influence of grain morphology. Our results show that hillocks tend to form and grow on the anode side, with directional mass migration inducing voids on the cathode side, leading to increased electrical resistance and potential signal degradation. Interconnects with finer polycrystalline structures exhibit more rapid hillock and void growth, due to the increased number of grain boundaries that enhance atomic diffusion pathways. Hydrostatic stress not only flattens void morphology but also accelerates the growth of both hillocks and voids. The stress-driven diffusion flux flows into the hillock regions adjacent to the anode, promoting the formation of taller hillocks. The proposed model qualitatively reproduces key features observed in experimental studies, offering microstructure-aware insights into electromigration-induced failure mechanisms and providing a foundation for predictive reliability analysis and design optimization of Cu interconnects.

title: MDFANet: Multi-Dimensional Feature Alignment Network for Self-Supervised Pre-Training in Remote Sensing Change Detection
authors: Lu Wang, Chenyang Wang, Runzhou Li, Junbo Yu, Hang Sun, Wenbin Wang, Dong Ren
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Recently, self-supervised pretraining algorithms have been extensively investigated in the field of remote sensing, yielding significant performance improvements in change detection tasks. However, many existing algorithms inadequately exploit multi-level features, which impedes their ability to precisely extract salient change characteristics and accurately determine the structural integrity of changed targets. Moreover, most mainstream approaches tend to neglect the mining of shallow, frequency-domain details, thereby limiting the model's capacity to discern object boundaries. To address these challenges, we propose a novel multi-dimensional feature alignment self-supervised pretraining framework, termed MDFANet. Specifically, we introduce a Hierarchical Decoupling and Multi-dimensional Feature Alignment (HDMFA) mechanism that facilitates the precise capture of multiple change cues at different levels through decoupled modeling of deep and shallow features and the design of multi-dimensional alignment branches. Additionally, we develop a Shallow Frequency-domain Feature Alignment (SFFA) branch that emphasizes the high-frequency components in the input data, effectively compensating for the inadequate representation of edge features in the spatial domain and enhancing the model's ability to detect complex boundaries. Experimental results on LEVIR-CD, SYSU-CD and EGY-BCD datasets validate the superiority of MDFANet, which outperforms SSLCD, Cmid and other SOTA methods by 1.7–2.3% in F1 score.

title: Investigation of Brake Deceleration of Electric Bicycle
authors: Radostin Dimitrov Dimitrov, Radosław Stanislaw Wróbel, Velichka Rosenova Georgieva
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Over the past few years, the use of electric bikes has increased significantly. Accidents with this type of vehicle are constantly increasing, due to the continuous increase in their number. Electric bikes are generally treated as upgraded bikes for driving up to a certain speed (usually up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25 ~\text{km}/\mathrm{h}$</tex>) and do not need a license or registration as motorcycles if they meet bicycle standards. This article presents a study showing the possibilities for effective braking of the described vehicles. The maximum braking delay, average braking delay, braking distance and other specific parameters in an emergency braking situation are examined.

title: Electrodynamic Study of High-Selective Three-Dimensional Bragg Resonators for Spatially-Extended Free-Electron Masers
authors: E. D. Egorova, N. Yu. Peskov, A. S. Sergeev, D. I. Sobolev, A. A. Vikharev
abstract: Electrodynamic study of a novel scheme of the so-called “three-dimensional” (3D) Bragg structures of planar geometry is performed. The unique advantage of such structures is the use of three-dimensional scattering of partial wave-fluxes that allows for mode selection over all three spatial coordinates. Structures of this type open up the possibility of increasing the oversize parameter of the interaction space of free-electron mases (FEMs) and, thus, obtaining super-power narrow-band radiation based on intense spatially-extended relativistic electron beams (REB) of a sheet configuration. High selective properties of 3D Bragg structures in the ranges up to 0.6 THz were demonstrated under conditions of significant oversize at length (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$l_{z}$</tex>) and width (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$l_{x}$</tex>) of system from several tens to hundreds of wavelengths of radiation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$l_{z, x} \sim 50-100 \lambda$</tex>, and gap between the plates of resonator <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$l_{y} \sim 10-20 \lambda$</tex>. This work is devoted to study the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S$</tex>-parameters (reflection, transmission and transverse scattering coefficients) of spatially extended 3D Bragg structures both within the framework of the coupled wave approach (quasi-optical approximation) and CST simulations, and development of the experimental facility to measure electrodynamic characteristics of proposed resonator in “cold” tests. The 3D Bragg structures are planned to be used as electrodynamic system for sub- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{THz} / \text{THz}$</tex> band FEL which is being developed in collaboration between Gaponov-Grekhov IAP RAS and Budker INP RAS.

title: Hybrid CNN-ViT model for non-invasive biomass estimation in microalgae cultures using RGB images
authors: J.C. Martinez-Morgan, H.R. Hernandez-de Leon, J.A. Fragoso-Mandujano, H. Rodriguez-Rangel, L.E. Amabilis-Sosa, M.C. Salgado-Gutíerrez
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study proposes a CNN-ViT model for noninvasive biomass estimation in microalgae cultures. The system eliminates the need for traditional intrusive methods by estimating the amount of biomass produced in microalgal cultures using RGB images taken under controlled lighting conditions. Convolutional neural networks (CNN) and their feature extraction capabilities are integrated with the spatial attention of vision transformers (ViT). To present and validate the proposed model, which demonstrated excellent performance ($R^{2}=0.9626$, MAE $=0.1206 \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{L}$), a structured dataset consisting of image samples taken during growth, related to experimentally measured microalgal biomass values, was used. These findings demonstrate that real-time biomass monitoring is feasible using RGB-based computer vision.

title: Benefits of Automation in Manufacturing: Analysis of MES in Production Planning and Daily Management
authors: Johanna Perkola, Jyri Vilko, Alisa Misukka
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This research examines the complexities inherent in production planning and day-to-day operational control, and explores how these challenges can be mitigated through the implementation of a Manufacturing Execution System (MES). The proposed approach aims to complement the existing ERP system while reducing dependence on paper-based processes and Excel spreadsheets on the production floor. The research focuses exclusively on resolving identified challenges using MES, excluding alternative software solutions. Ten thematic categories of challenges were identified: detailed planning, change management, deviation handling, information flow, quality gate implementation, production reporting, traceability, transparency, pending tasks, and non-value-adding work. Primary data collection was conducted through semi-structured and unstructured interviews. Findings indicate that most challenges can be fully or partially mitigated through MES implementation, while detailed planning would require an Advanced Planning and Scheduling (APS) system. These results provide practical insights for manufacturing firms seeking to diagnose operational inefficiencies and evaluate MES as a potential solution.

title: Power Management in an Energy-Harvesting IoT Star Network with Wireless Power Transmission
authors: Antonio Caruso, Stefano Chessa, Soledad Escolar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: The proliferation of the Internet of Things (IoT) has ledto the widespread deployment of sensor nodes characterized by constrained energy availability, often powered by limitedcapacity storage components such as batteries or super-capacitors. To sustain uninterrupted operation and enable periodic energy replenishment, energy harvesting (EH) techniques have emerged as a viable solution. This paper investigates an advanced architecture for a star-topology IoT network, wherein the central coordinator node is equipped with a solar-based energy harvesting system. The energy accrued is utilized not only to maintain the coordinator’s operational integrity but also to facilitate Wireless Power Transmission (WPT) to neighboring peripheral nodes. This work introduces a novel task scheduling algorithm that optimizes application-level utility while satisfying the energy neutrality constraint of the overall platform. Simulation outcomes validate the effectiveness and viability of integrating EH and WPT mechanisms to ensure sustainable and efficient power delivery within IoT ecosystems.

title: Solid-State Modular High-Voltage DC Power Supply With Pulse Capability for High-Power RF Amplifier
authors: Rinki Upadhyay, Manmath Kumar Badapanda, Akhilesh Tripathi, Rajeev Tyagi, Sachin Rathi, Ramesh Kumar
abstract: A multisecondary transformer-based solid-state modular crowbarless high-voltage dc power supply with pulse capability is employed for biasing 1 MW, 352 MHz klystron amplifier. The primary windings of four numbers of multisecondary transformers are suitably phase shifted to realize 24-pulsed input system at 11 kV. Attempt has been made to equalize the mutual coupling between primary and secondary windings of these multisecondary transformers to enable cancellation of lower order harmonics. Low-ripple high-voltage dc output is achieved by phase staggering the outputs of 144 numbers of ac–dc converter-based power modules employed in this power supply. This power supply employs only feed forward control for its dc and pulse mode of operation. The design challenges associated with power module and their mitigation strategies for meeting the needs of continuous wave (CW) and pulse mode of operations are presented in this article. Availability analysis of this modular power supply incorporating active redundant power modules is also presented in this article. Wire burn test is carried out on the power supply to ensure that output stored energy is below 10 J. This power supply achieves output voltage stability <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\le$</tex-math> </inline-formula>0.5%, output ripple <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\le$</tex-math> </inline-formula>0.5%, current THD <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\le$</tex-math> </inline-formula>0.5%, input power factor (IPF) <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\ge 0.97$</tex-math> </inline-formula> at 87 kV, 18.7 A dc operating point. In pulse mode, rise time <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\le$</tex-math> </inline-formula>100 us and fall time <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\le$</tex-math> </inline-formula>100 us are achieved at 100 kV, 22 A operating point at pulsewidth of 2 ms and repetition rate of 40 Hz.

title: Attitudes and Experiences of Primary and Secondary School Teachers and Students of Teacher Training Programmes with Generative Artificial Intelligence in Education
authors: M. Hanzl, M. Dosedla, P. Novotná, T. Harsányi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: The article deals with the attitudes and experiences of primary and secondary school teachers, as well as students of teacher training programmes, with generative artificial intelligence (GAI) in the educational process. The theoretical part provides an overview of the opportunities, benefits, technological underpinnings, and challenges associated with the implementation of GAI in education, including ethical and regulatory aspects. The empirical section is based on quantitative research, carried out through the administration of an online questionnaire (N = 111), which examined the factors influencing the use of GAI, perceptions of its advantages and risks, and the differences across different groups of respondents. Conducted statistical analyses (Mann-Whitney U-test, χ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> test, Spearman’s correlation) confirmed four key hypotheses: more frequent use of GAI correlates with perceived benefits, while emphasis on potential risks reduces its use; younger and less experienced teachers use GAI more frequently; attitudes towards ethical considerations differ significantly between pre-service teachers (students) and in-service teachers; and greater institutional support predicts more frequent use of GAI. The study highlights generational differences, the importance of ethical dilemmas, and the necessity of targeted institutional support in integrating GAI into educational practice.

title: A Curvature-Compensated Based on Subthreshold MOSFETs Low-Power Bandgap Reference
authors: Yuhang Xia, Quanyuan Feng, Yan Wen
abstract: In this paper, we present a bandgap circuit capable of generating two reference voltages, 1 V and 0.75 V. The proposed BGR is implemented in a 180 nm BCD technology, operates with a supply voltage of 1.8 V, consuming <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.16 \mu\ \mathrm{W}$</tex> at room temperature. In the bandgap circuit proposed, we utilized the exponential behavior of subthreshold CMOS transistors to compensate the BJT base-emitter voltage high-order temperature dependence. By taking advantages of the characteristics of the current-mode bandgap reference circuit, which enable us to generating two reference voltages easily. The simulation verification in Cadence software shows that under a 1.8 V power supply voltage, the generated reference voltage VREF1 is 1 V at room temperature, and the temperature coefficient without trimming as low as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.27 \text{ppm} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> over a temperature range of 120° C because of the proposed curvature-compensation technique based on subthreshold CMOS transistors. The average value of VREF1 is 1.002 V and the average temperature coefficient is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12.58 \text{ppm} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> which could be improved by trimming resistor ratios. The generated reference voltage VREF2 is 0.75 V at room temperature, and the average value of VREF2 is 0.7498 V. Without any filter capacitor, the PSRR of the output voltage VREF1 is 67.7 dB at low frequencies. When the power supply voltage is between 1.8-2.8 V, the bandgap reference source provides two stable voltages, 1 V and 0.75 V.

title: Unleashing Student Motivation: The Role of Artificial Intelligence and Social Media Integration through the Lens of Self-Determination Theory
authors: Monica Dewi, Nofriska Krissanya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This study explores the influence of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and social media integration on student motivation through the lens of Self-Determination Theory (SDT), which emphasizes autonomy, competence, and relatedness as key motivational constructs. Utilizing a quantitative explanatory approach, data were collected from 100 Generation Z university students who actively use AI-based educational tools and social media for academic purposes. Structural Equation Modeling with Partial Least Squares (SEM-PLS) was employed to test the proposed relationships among AI integration, social media use, SDT dimensions, and student motivation. The results reveal that both AI and social media significantly contribute to student motivation, with SDT acting as a key mediating construct. AI enhances personalization and autonomy, while social media promotes collaboration and relatedness. The findings underscore the strategic potential of technology in fostering intrinsic motivation and improving educational engagement. This study contributes to the growing body of literature advocating for the pedagogical alignment of technology and psychological motivation theories in higher education.

title: Indirect Field Oriented Control With and Without Power Loops for Wind Conversion Systems Based DFIG
authors: Aziz Chahbi, Mourad Yessef, Amine Amharech, Hatim Ameziane
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: This work provides a comprehensive comparative analysis of indirect vector control or Indirect Field Oriented Control (IFOC) for Wind Energy Conversion System (WECS) based on Doubly Fed Induction Generator (DFIG). IFOC without power loops (IFOC-WPL) and IFOC using power loops (IFOC-UPL) have been both systematically investigated, simulated and evaluated under three different scenarios of DFIG parameters. Precise numerical simulations have been established using Matlab/Simulink to evaluate the performance of each control strategy under realistic operating conditions. In a first scenario, reduced magnetizing inductance (L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf>) and increased rotor resistance (R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r</inf>) have been implemented to evaluate the system under temperature variations and flux saturation impacts. The second scenario, simulate and evaluate the system performance only under flux saturation by reduced L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf>. While, the system performance under nominal conditions of temperature and flux has been tested in the third scenario. Indices performance such as Integral Time Absolute Error (ITAE) and Integral Absolute Error (IAE) were both used to examine the performance of each control strategy including steady state error, transient response, and robustness against parameter changes. The findings confirm that IFOC-UPL outperforms IFOC-WPL by delivering several performance improvement in term of robustness, overall system stability and accuracy enen under the most challenging conditions.

title: Research on a 3D Fiber Bragg Grating Accelerometer with Miniature and Integrated Structure Based on Composite Circular Hinge
authors: Lina Yue, Jinding Guo, Qiuming Nan, Ai Zhou, Juntao Wang, Sheng Li
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) vibration measurement is crucial for analyzing the dynamic property of complex structures. To address the issue of large volume and mass in existing FBG accelerometers, a 3D FBG accelerometer based on composite circular hinge is proposed using fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensing technology. The integrated design and 3D printing solution result in the miniaturization of the overall structure, measuring <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25 ~\text{mm} \times 24 ~\text{mm} \times 8 ~\text{mm}$</tex>, with a weight reduction to 18.1 g. This research establishes the dynamic model of the sensor using the virtual displacement and d'Alembert principle. Furthermore, the structural stiffness of the two types of circular hinges are derived by the Castigliano's second theorem. Sensitivity and inherent frequency of the integrated accelerometer are conducted using finite element simulation and vibration experiment. The time-domain and amplitude-frequency curves indicate that the first order inherent frequency of the FBG accelerometer is approximately 500 Hz, with sensitivities of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$35 \text{pm} / \mathrm{g}, 70 \text{pm} / \mathrm{g}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$58 \text{pm} / \mathrm{g}$</tex> in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X, Y$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Z$</tex> directions, respectively. Theoretical, simulation, and experimental results show a high degree of consistency. Meanwhile, the stereoscopic layout concept of four FBG enables the self-temperature compensation function of the sensor, with excellent lateral anti-interference performance, making it effectively applicable for structural vibration monitoring.

title: Park@FIIT: A LoRa-Based Parking System
authors: S. Sventek, L. Zemko, J. Dubec, P. Čičák, K. Jelemenská
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: We present Park@FIIT, a minimal LoRaWAN-based smart-parking prototype built from commodity parts (ESP32 + JSN-SR04T ultrasonic sensor end nodes, a Raspberry Pi + iC880A-SPI gateway, ChirpStack network server) and a lightweight web UI. In a campus deployment, one gateway covered the FIIT parking lot. End-node sensing achieved ±3 cm accuracy over 15 cm to 270 cm. We observed an implementation pitfall: with the LMIC-node stack, deep-sleep timing breaks increased average draw to about 70 mA (≈ 43 h on 3000 mA h) despite a low deep-sleep current, motivating either a different stack or solar assistance. A simple 2-minute edge debounce suppressed transient occupancy flaps and reduced uplinks. We discuss architecture, coverage, and power lessons for student prototypes.

title: Text to Image Synthesis Using StackGAN
authors: Purva Sandeep Warade, Swati V. Shinde, Bal Virdee, Ashish Khanna
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Text-to-image synthesis is a difficult task. It involves the translation of descriptive text to visual content, which maps language and image representations. Among several approaches, StackGAN was one of the most notable frameworks because of the pioneer two-stage architecture. The first stage generated low-resolution images based on the global structure. Then, the first stage results were utilized and refined in the second stage into high-resolution, realistic images with improved details. This paper reports the performance of StackGAN on a subset of the Flickr dataset where embeddings of textual descriptions are obtained from the USE. Experimental results will show that the model produces semantically coherent images, which are also visually coherent. A study focuses on the prospect of StackGAN in creative content generation and discusses challenges such as maintaining diversity and mitigating artifacts.

title: Neuroclear: a Novel Explainable Ai Framework for Sustainable Water Quality Intelligence and Adaptive Management
authors: Sonali B. Gavali, Anjali S. More, Sarika T. Deokate
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Ensuring sustainable water quality management in the face of climate change, urbanization, and industrialization demands systems that are both intelligent and transparent. This study introduces a novel Explainable AI (XAI) driven framework specifically designed for real-time water quality monitoring and management. The proposed system integrates IoT-based data collection, hybrid cloud-edge preprocessing, interpretable machine learning, and ethical oversight to ensure transparency, trust, and actionable insights. Unlike conventional black-box models, our architecture embeds XAI modules across the entire pipeline from inference to optimization to provide stakeholders with interpretable predictions, anomaly alerts, and resource recommendations. A key innovation lies in the incorporation of fairness aware decision support and ethical transparency checks, ensuring equitable outcomes in diverse water ecosystems. This paper not only surveys existing efforts from 2018-2025 but also positions the proposed system as a robust, scalable solution that overcomes limitations in model generalizability and interpretability. Future directions include fusing participatory sensing with edge-based XAI inference to accelerate citizendriven, sustainable water governance.

title: Wind Turbine Power Converter Architectures and Faults: Proposal of a Hardware-Independent Detection Approach
authors: Belouak Houda, Amine Amharech, Hatim Ameziane
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical Systems &amp; Automation (ICESA)
abstract: Wind energy is rapidly becoming one of the pillars of clean energy production. In 2023, wind power contributed to almost 8% of the global electricity generation. However, the harsh and variable environments to which wind turbines are exposed make them prone to electrical, mechanical, structural, and control system faults. This reliability issue is one of the main challenges of wind energy production. From an electrical perspective, components such as generators, power converters, transformers, and switchgear are the leading contributors to turbine unavailability and costly maintenance. Among these, power converters represent a significant portion of electrical downtime, making them a critical focus for improving system reliability. This article reviews wind turbine converter architectures and examines two representative faults to highlight the dependency of fault detection methods on different architectures. Building on this foundation, we introduce a new architecture-independent fault detection and classification concept. This paper is designed to facilitate future research and practical applications.

title: On the Digital Signal Processing for Optical Aperture Synthesis with Photonic Integrated Circuits
authors: Thushara Gunaratne, Zoran Ljusic, Brent Carlson, Glen Herriot, Alexis Hill, Ross Cheriton
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Precision Clock Synchronization for Measurement, Control, and Communication (ISPCS)
abstract: Accurate time recovery and clock synchronization are crucial for achieving high-contrast astronomical images using the recently proposed "Optical Aperture Synthesis" (OAS) method, which utilizes photonic integrated circuits (Photo-IC) to align the phases of photons captured by multiple optical sub-apertures/telescopes. In this method, the modulated optical signal from an artificial laser guide star serves as the global phase reference for each sub-aperture/telescope. After this optical signal is converted to an electrical signal and sampled, a digital signal processing (DSP) system processes the modulated signal to suppress excess jitter and accurately measures the phase offset caused by various factors such as atmospheric fluctuations and instrumentation non-idealities. Control signals derived using these phase estimates are fed back to the Photo-IC to correct for the phase variations for all sub-apertures/telescopes. Although numerical simulations showed that the proposed DSP system is possibly accurate enough to recover the phase variations, early measurements showed that temperature variations are detrimental to the stability of the analog signal chain.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Inverter Power Losses for BLDC Drive under Different PWM Techniques
authors: Dimitar Tsvetanov, Hristo Milushev, Nikolay Djagarov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper presents an experimental evaluation of inverter power losses in a brushless DC (BLDC) motor drive under different pulse-width modulation (PWM) techniques. The study employs the Texas Instruments BOOSTXL-DRV8305 inverter platform to investigate the impact of various PWM strategies-including sinusoidal PWM, space vector PWM, and third-harmonic injection-on conduction and switching losses. Experimental measurements were performed across a range of operating conditions to quantify inverter efficiency and power dissipation characteristics. The results indicate that the choice of PWM method has a significant influence on both switching dynamics and overall power loss, with certain techniques offering a favourable trade-off between efficiency and implementation complexity. These findings provide valuable insight into the selection of PWM control strategies for enhancing the performance and efficiency of BLDC motor drives.

title: Interface for Displaying and Analyzing Machine Learning Data
authors: Georgi Enchev, Dimitar Tsvetanov, Nikolay Djagarov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This article presents the structure, capabilities, and benefits of the ML Dashboard platform-an interactive web-based tool designed for analyzing, comparing, and visualizing the performance of machine learning classifiers. The system integrates experimental data stored in a database and enables users to explore various metrics through dynamic filters and interactive visualizations. Designed to support rapid evaluation of different model configurations and hyperparameters, the platform provides researchers and engineers with an efficient environment for interpreting classification results. The ML Dashboard stands out for its real-time filtering, export capabilities, and wide variety of visual tools that simplify model assessment and decisionmaking.

title: Multimodal Triplet Embeddings for Detection of Domain Name Abuse*
authors: Evrard Cabrel Nguemeyou Tchouangang, Idrissa Sarr, Bassirou Kasse
publish: 2025 IEEE Global Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things (GCAIoT)
abstract: This paper addresses the detection of phishing attacks in the context of less-automated TLDs (LaTLDs). With the rise of connected devices and social networks, these underdocumented environments are becoming increasingly vulnerable. Existing solutions, often developed for TLDs with large data volumes and mostly unimodal in nature, show limitations when applied to local specificities and attacks that combine multiple modalities.To tackle this challenge, we propose a multimodal approach combining visual analysis (screenshots) and structural analysis (HTML). The method relies on two triplet-based networks trained on augmented data simulating phishing attacks (HTML reformulations generated by language models and visual transformations through noise injection). The distances extracted from each modality are then fused into a supervised classifier.Despite the constraints associated with the limited dataset size and the complexity of multimodality, our approach achieves an F1-score of 0.9948 in the best configuration. These results confirm its effectiveness, outperforming unimodal approaches, and pave the way for integration into national registry governance processes.

title: Multi-Modal Vision and Language Models for Real-Time Emergency Response
authors: Adil Zhiyenbayev, Rakhat Abdrakhmanov, Huseyin Atakan Varol, Adnan Yazici
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Recent advancements in ambient assisted living (AAL) technologies leverage machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) for improved emergency response and preventive care. This research introduces a multi-modal system with an advanced vision-language model (VLM) to enhance detection capabilities in AAL settings. Using DL, the system interprets scenes to generate captions, answer visual questions, and facilitate commonsense reasoning. An interactive chatbot with a large language model (LLM) and text-to-speech and speech-to-text capabilities enables real-time assessments of abnormal behavior. The system uses prompt engineering to refine anomaly detection without extensive retraining. It autonomously dispatches ambulances and generates alerts. Qualitative analysis confirms high usability among study participants, while quantitative assessments show a detection accuracy of 93.44 %, a recall rate of 95 %, and a specificity rate of 88.88 %. User interactions further enhance accuracy to 100%. This multi-modal system improves emergency recognition and response, providing caregivers with actionable insights in real time.

title: AI-Driven Fiscal Risk Modeling for OECD Economies: Ethical Implications and Policy Considerations in Government Decision-Making.
authors: Mai Magdy, Safwat Hamad, Noha Elfiky
publish: 2025 IEEE Global Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things (GCAIoT)
abstract: This paper presents an AI-powered framework for evaluating public sector debt and its macroeconomic implications across 37 OECD countries. Using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), K-means clustering, and ARIMAX forecasting, we identify seven significant predictors of public debt including inflation, unemployment, GDP per capita, and labor force participation. A debt risk scoring model ranks countries based on fiscal vulnerability to provide insight into long-term economic resilience. The framework integrates macro-fiscal data through 2024-2025 from OECD and IMF reports. Beyond analytics, the study addresses ethical and governance concerns in the use of AI for fiscal decision-making. Transparency, accountability, and fairness are examined alongside potential biases that may disadvantage developing economies. Recommendations are made for implementing explainable AI (XAI), regulatory compliance, and alignment with global AI governance frameworks.

title: Identification of Ambient Sounds Based on Characteristic Parameters and Numerical Processing
authors: Constantin Daniel OANCEA, Raluca-Alexandra OANĂ
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: To associate a signal with its source, it is proposed to develop an application that proposes a series of signal processing. The basic idea is that having a database with different signals, they are compared with an unknown signal, and based on the closest possible approximation of the results, it can be decided to whom the unknown signal belongs. To achieve the comparison between signals, this article proposes the use of known mathematical processing operations to obtain the results. Both simpler and more complex signal processing methods are reviewed and their relevance is analyzed. For the portability of the application, a specialized programming environment for mathematical calculations is used, but which is available on different platforms (such as Scilab or Octave).

title: Sustainable Energy Management in Agricultural Engineering: ESG Trends and Entrepreneurial Practices
authors: Tsanka Zlateva-Petkova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper examines how sustainable energy practices are being incorporated into agricultural engineering, particularly through the application of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) principles and entrepreneurial thinking. The central idea is straightforward: when innovative technologies in agriculture are guided by ESG standards and supported by entrepreneurial drive, they can lead to farming systems that are greener, more competitive, and more resilient. We review current trends, common challenges, and effective strategies for integrating these elements in practice. Our methodology involves a broad review of recent literature and real-world examples at the intersection of technology and business. The motivation behind this research stems from the urgent need for agriculture to become more energy-efficient and climate-resilient. Our contribution lies in synthesizing insights from engineering, sustainability, and entrepreneurship to propose a practical framework for implementing sustainable energy solutions in agriculture. These findings can benefit researchers, policymakers, and practitioners looking for realistic strategies toward a more sustainable agricultural future.

title: Understanding Consumer Perspectives on AI-Driven Sustainability in Italy: Influencing Factors and Policy Implications
authors: Andrea Cibrario, Sevinj Iskandarova
publish: 2025 IEEE Global Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things (GCAIoT)
abstract: This study evaluates Italy’s AI strategy for promoting sustainable development within a broader European context. While Italy’s initiatives show promise, their success relies on sustained political commitment, effective data governance, and collaboration between public and private sectors. The role of consumer trust in AI and public awareness is also examined, revealing a largely optimistic outlook among Italian citizens regarding the potential benefits of AI, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability. Yet, significant gaps in knowledge and awareness persist, necessitating targeted educational initiatives and transparent communication to foster informed perspectives. In analyzing 184 adults across Milan and Turin, consumer perceptions towards AI-enabled sustainability solutions revealed a generally positive yet varied impact on sustainable behaviors, as well as mixed assessments of government policies related to AI and sustainability. The study findings suggest a call for collaborative efforts among regulators, researchers, and industry leaders to prioritize sustainable practices in AI development, emphasizing the critical balance between AI’s ecological impacts and its potential to drive sustainable progress.

title: Application of Mass-Spectrometric-based Proteomics in Origin Traceability of Sea Cucumber
authors: Zhenxing Wu, Zhiteng Liu, Yong Wang, Hongwei Zhang, Guo Cheng, Xin Ni
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Sea cucumber has high nutritional value and economic value. Food fraud and authenticity issues hinder the healthy and sustainable development of sea cucumber industry. It is of great significance to achieve origin traceability of sea cucumber. This paper reviews the action mechanism of mass-spectrometric-based proteomics technology in the application of sea cucumber origin traceability, also expounds the challenges and prospects of mass-spectrometric-based proteomics technology.

title: Forecast of SARIMA and ARIMA Models: An Application for Temperature Prediction
authors: Raluca-Alexandra Oană
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The variation and the constant evolution of the weather represents a demanding task for researchers around the world. These big fluctuations in weather systems require advanced prediction algorithms. This paper is made around the use case of the Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (SARIMA) and the Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA). The past few decades, especially since the computational power started to rise exponentially the development of advanced algorithms used for predictions in all types of environments has been a hot topic. When it comes to weather forecasting, being able to process huge amounts of data represents a big advantage in the accuracy of the predictions. The dataset used for this research covers the minimum, maximum and mean temperature recorded in Bucharest, Romania from 1979 to 2024. Using 46 years of historical data, ARIMA and SARIMA models were trained to predict the current year's temperatures. Their performance was evaluated using standard forecasting metrics, including Mean Absolute Error, Root Mean Squared Error, Coefficient of Determination and Akaike Information Criterion.

title: A Novel Miniature Circular Eye-Inspired UHF RFID Tag Antenna Design
authors: Zakaria Errachidi, Jamal Zbitou, Mohammed El Gibari, Mohammad Mashagbeh, Noha Chahboun
abstract: This paper introduces a novel miniature structure of Tag UHF RFID antenna, specifically designed for use on metallic objects within the European frequency bandwidth of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$865-868 \text{MHz}$</tex>. The proposed Tag antenna is a circular structure Eye-inspired designed to match the configuration of a folded dipole antenna. It incorporates a default T-Match network, which ensures flexible conjugate input impedance matching between the antenna and the chip. The RFID chip used is an Alien H4 having an input impedance around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Z_{c}=23.27-\mathrm{j} 203.35 \Omega$</tex> at 868 MHz, this chip used due to its reading sensitivity of −20.5 dBm. The final proposed antenna is mounted on a substrate Rogers RO 4350 B having a thickness of 1.524 mm, with a dielectric constant <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varepsilon_{r}=3.66$</tex> and a loss tangent <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\tan \delta=0.0037$</tex>.

title: MedREX: A Dual-Biaffine Attention and Feature-Enhanced Joint Model for Chinese Medical Entity-Relation Extraction
authors: Wenhao Ding, Xudong Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Relation extraction in specialised domains like medicine is challenging due to semantic complexity and class imbalance. MedREX, a novel joint entity-RE model, addresses these issues using Erlangshen-MegatronBert-1.3B as its encoder for rich contextual representations, enhanced by an additional Transformer encoder layer for long-range dependency modelling. Its dual-biaffine attention-based decoder factorises extraction into three subtasks: entity mention identification, subject-object alignment for relation classification, and tail alignment for relational structure completion. Focal Loss and adversarial training (Fast Gradient Method) mitigate class imbalance and improve robustness. Experiments on the CMeIE-V2 dataset show MedREX outperforms baselines, with improved F1 score, precision, and recall, confirming its effectiveness.

title: Research on Diabetes Prediction Based on Multi-Model Comparison and SHAP Interpretability Analysis
authors: Zihan Wang, Wentao Tang, Yibo Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedical Technology (ICBBT)
abstract: Diabetes, as a global chronic metabolic disease, holds significant importance for early prediction in reducing the risk of complications and improving patients' quality of life. In this study, based on the Pima Indians Diabetes Database, we employed preprocessing methods including data cleaning, handling of missing and abnormal values, feature engineering, and standardization to construct four machine learning models—LightGBM, RandomForest, KNN, and Naive Bayes—for predicting the onset of diabetes. Model hyperparameters were tuned using 10-fold cross-validation and grid search, and comprehensive evaluations of each model's Accuracy, ROC AUC, Sensitivity, Specificity, and PR AUC were conducted on an independent test set. The experimental results indicate that RandomForest and LightGBM perform exceptionally well across multiple evaluation metrics, exhibiting high predictive accuracy and stability. Furthermore, by applying the SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) method for interpretability analysis on the optimal model, we revealed the significant contributions of features such as Glucose, BMI, and Age to the model's decision-making process, with Pregnancies showing a particularly significant positive impact on predicting diabetes risk. This study not only provides an efficient machine learning method for early diabetes screening but also enhances the model's transparency and credibility in clinical applications through interpretability analysis.

title: Integrating Movement into Educational Settings through Active Workstations and Their Impact on Physical Activity and Academic Performance
authors: Veronika Sedláková, Norbert Ferenčík, Tomáš Balint, Radovan Hudák, Dmytro Malakhov, Teodor Tóth
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: Sedentary behavior in schools and universities contributes to negative health outcomes, creating demand for classroom-based physical activity interventions. Active workstations—including cycling, standing, and treadmill desks—enable movement during academic tasks. This review summarizes studies from 2015–2025 examining their effects on health and learning. Evidence shows that active workstations increase energy expenditure by 15–36% without impairing academic performance; cycling desks yield the largest benefits. Some studies also report gains in attention, concentration, and student engagement, with particular advantages for learners with ADHD or autism spectrum disorders. Effective use depends on appropriate equipment, teacher training, and integration into curricula. Neurophysiological evidence indicates that light activity may enhance cognition through improved arousal and cerebral blood flow. Overall, active workstations offer a feasible way to reduce sedentary time in education while supporting academic outcomes.

title: A Comprehensive Literature Review on On-Load Tap Changers in Autotransformers: Control, Optimization, Fault Diagnosis, and Predictive Modelling
authors: Pfunzo Nevhutalu, Bongumsa Mendu, Bessie Baakanyang Monchusi, Sumbwanyambe Mbuyu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: An on-load tap changer (OLTC) controls an electrical transformer’s turns ratio and, consequently, its voltage ratio so that the voltage supplied is constant. This work’s objective is to conduct thorough literature research based on the design and analysis of the autotransformer’s onload tap changer using voltage regulation. A thorough search for relevant papers is conducted using the Scopus database. The search is refined to focus only on the article titles, abstracts, and keywords, while excluding publications written in Chinese and Korean. The study employs machine learning techniques, particularly recurrent neural networks and fuzzy logic controllers, to predict and optimize OLTC operations in dynamic grid conditions, particularly with renewable energy sources. Studies also point to the growing use of vibro-acoustic signal analysis, deep learning models, and frequency domain techniques to diagnose early-stage mechanical faults in OLTC systems. This research contributes to improving operational efficiency and voltage regulation in power systems by optimizing and analyzing the design of on-load tap changers in autotransformers.
