title: Performance of Polar Code on Symmetric AlphaStable Impulsive Noise Channels
authors: Ana-Maria Grigoras Oanca, Mihaela Andrei, Daniela Tarniceriu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Polar codes have come to the forefront of research in communication channel coding, being a performant scheme used in the fifth $(5 \mathrm{G})$ and sixth generations $(6 \mathrm{G})$ with good results in data transmission reliability. Along with their study, special types of decoders were developed. The original one, proposed by the polar code inventor, was called the Successive Cancellation (SC). Over the years, several polar code decoders have been created and tested. In this paper, we investigate the performance of two types: SC and Belief Propagation (BP) under $\alpha$-stable impulsive noise, a non-Gaussian model that is often present in power line communications or in wireless environments with heavy-tailed interference. Simulation results provide a comparative analysis of the bit error rate (BER) performance as a function of signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), highlighting the degradation caused by varying levels of impulsiveness. There is no significant difference between the decoders considered. SC brings a gain of about 0.1 dB at $S N R=3$, when $\alpha=2$. If the noise is strongly impulsive, $\alpha=1.5$, the BER has a high value for both SC and BP. Additionally, probability density function (PDF) plots and power spectral density (PSD) representations of the noise are included to illustrate its statistical and spectral characteristics for different values of the model parameters. For $\alpha=2$, the distribution approaches a Gaussian one. It is symmetric when $\beta=0$; otherwise, it is skewed to the left (for $\boldsymbol{\beta}=-1$) or to the right (for $\boldsymbol{\beta}=1$). In the presence of SaS noise, even with a flat PSD, the absolute power level is significantly higher than that of AWGN. All the simulations were done in MATLAB and compared with the Gaussian channel case.

title: Highway Traffic Flow Monitoring Based on Spatio-Temporal Vibration Distribution of Ultra-Weak Fiber Bragg Grating Arrays
authors: Linxiao Guo, Jingwei Sun, Miao Ma, Qiuming Nan, Fang Liu
abstract: Real-time highway traffic flow monitoring is essential in constructing traffic management and transportation systems. However, it is still a significant challenge due to the large and increasing traffic flow, complex traffic scenarios and unique geographical environment. This article proposes a novel method for highway traffic flow monitoring based on the spatio-temporal vibration distribution of ultra-weak fiber Bragg grating (UWFBG) arrays. The continuous short-term energy characteristics of each UWFBG sensor are extracted by analyzing the collected vehicle vibration data, and the dynamic spatio-temporal vibration energy distribution of pavement is obtained. Then, vehicle trajectories are retrieved, and the corresponding traffic flow parameters are calculated to achieve long-term stable traffic flow monitoring. Unlike traditional traffic flow detection, which is limited to localized areas or affected by geographic and weather conditions, the experimental results show that the vehicle detection results are highly consistent with the actual situation, demonstrating the method's effectiveness for real-time lane-level traffic flow monitoring in high-volume and complex environment, which provides the sensing foundation for full-time, full-domain, and all-weather traffic flow monitoring of intelligent transportation system.

title: Increasing the Detail of the Point Spread Function Due to Apodization with a Phase Ring Grating to Improve the Efficiency of Detecting Wavefront Aberrations
authors: P. A. Khorin, D. P. Serafimovich
abstract: We propose to introduce additional phase apodization into the optical system for special transformation of the focal intensity. In particular, we consider apodization in the form of a phase ring grating to increase the detail of the point spread function (PSF), as well as to introduce more significant visual features for different types of aberrations. Note, the ring grating leads to the formation of a conical wave front in the paraxial region and annular intensity in the focal plane. It is known that the conical wave front is associated with Bessel beams, which, due to their special structure, are very sensitive to various wave front distortions. Thus, introducing a conical wave front will lead to a certain pre-distortion, which will increase the detailing of the PSF due to the annular structure of the beam. This should increase the efficiency of detecting/recognizing aberrations using various methods, including artificial intelligence tools.

title: LexiGuard: A Multilingual Transformer-Based Approach to Detecting Sexist and Toxic Language
authors: Zuzana Sokolová, Matúš Pleva, Eva Kupcová, Miroslav Sokol, Magdaléna Majerčáková
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: This paper presents LexiGuard, a multilingual transformer-based system designed for the detection of sexist and toxic language in Slovak and English online communication. A balanced and custom-annotated corpus, the LexiGuard-dataset, was created to capture expressions of misogyny, misandry, and neutrality across three levels of toxicity (low, medium, high). The dataset combines synthetic and real-world social media comments and represents a novel resource for offensive language research in the Slovak context. The proposed model, built on the XLM-RoBERTa architecture and optimized through a multitask learning approach, simultaneously classifies the type of expression and its toxicity level. Experimental evaluation achieved 89% accuracy for expression type and 85% for toxicity classification, confirming the model’s robustness in identifying both subtle and explicit manifestations of sexist discourse. A prototype web application demonstrates the system’s applicability, enabling real-time analysis and user interaction. The results highlight LexiGuard’s potential for practical deployment in online content moderation, while also emphasizing the importance of ethical considerations and future extensions toward broader context-aware hate speech detection.

title: Teachers’ Awareness of Online Threats and Interest in Education
authors: Jana Uramová, Matej Režný, Ondrej Škvarek
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging eLearning Technologies and Applications (ICETA)
abstract: The study addresses the level of cybersecurity awareness among primary and secondary school teachers and their preparedness to respond to the challenges of the digital environment. The research was conducted through a questionnaire survey involving teachers from various regions of Slovakia and supplemented with qualitative reflections from respondents. The analysis revealed that most educators possess only basic knowledge, and systematic training in this area remains insufficiently widespread. Respondents expressed strong interest in practice-oriented training, particularly in relation to the prevention of cyberbullying and the protection of personal data. The findings highlight the need for developing methodological support and implementing regular training programs that reflect the specificities of the school environment and foster the digital literacy of both teachers and students.

title: Analysis with regard to Research Building Convertion into Prosumer
authors: Mihaela Crețu, Levente Czumbil, Dorin Dacian Leț, Andreea Mihaela Leț, Andrei Ceclan, Alexis Polycarpou, Dan Doru Micu
abstract: This paper analyzes the transformation of an energy-efficient research facility at Valahia University of Târgoviște into a renewable energy prosumer. Two upgrade scenarios are evaluated using simulation tools: (1) expanding photovoltaic (PV) capacity, and (2) combining PV expansion with additional battery storage. Scenario 1 increases the building’s self-sufficiency from 52.4% to 75.9%, but excess energy is mostly exported due to limited storage. Scenario 2 achieves a 94.9% self-sufficiency rate by integrating a 270 kWh LFP (LiFePO4) battery system, minimizing grid dependence. The results demonstrate the benefits of combining local RES production with storage to support energy independence and decarbonization in urban infrastructure.

title: Ultra-Wideband Three-Dimensional Frequency Selective Surface with Large Angle Stability
authors: Zhaoran Chen, Junjie Hu, Xiayuan Yao
abstract: In this paper, a novel ultra-wideband three-dimensional Frequency Selective Surface (3-D FSS) with considerable angle stability is proposed. This FSS comprises two orthogonal metallic elliptical rings submerged in multi-layer dielectric slabs. The stopband of the 3-D FSS is located at DC-5 GHz, while the passband is from 7 GHz to 13 GHz for both TE and TM polarizations. The angle stability of the structure reaches 70°, and the insertion losses of the passband are no more than 0.6 dB, regardless of the varying angles. The transition zone is sharp, and the reflection band rejections are superior to 10 dB below 5 GHz. The orthogonal metallic elliptical rings build the main frame of the filtering characteristics to maintain the bandwidth and the angle stability. Seven layers of dielectric slabs improve the matching between the metallic structures and the free space to alleviate the burrs and the ripples in the passband.

title: Evaluation of Fish Migratory Conditions at Water Intakes of Small Hydropower Plants
authors: Rareş-Andrei Chihaia, Radu-Costinel Manarca, Măriuţa Popanton, Gabriela Cîrciumaru, Lucia-Andreea El-Leathey, Dumitru Vâju
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper is focused on evaluating fish migratory conditions at Tyrolean intakes of small hydropower plants by determining the flow conditions for a given facility in operation. By numerical calculation, the mean velocity was obtained in certain places of the intake and then compared with the swim ability of certain fish species that can be found in the considered river section. Special attention was paid to ensuring upstream migration in rivers, also known as potamodromous migration, which involves fish traveling from lower rivers to higher reaches, often for spawning or feeding. Migration represents a crucial process for maintaining fish populations and supporting healthy ecosystems. Obstacles like dams or intakes can impact migration, reducing the fish populations. Thus, special care and thorough research are required to ensure proper living conditions for aquatic fauna. This paper also summarizes different studies and results obtained so far for maintaining adequate migratory conditions at mountain river water intakes.

title: Social Media and Mental Health: Detecting Depression from Tweets Using Machine Learning
authors: Veeramma Yatnalli, Saroja S Bhusare, Tarun G V, Tushar M S, Vijay M, Sumukh A
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: Nowadays, the world faces significant challenges in addressing depression, especially among teenagers. Feelings of worthlessness or guilt, fixation on past failures, and self-blame are common symptoms. Frequent or recurring thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, attempts, or suicide itself can indicate depression, affecting 121 million people worldwide. In today’s social media-dominated world, individuals spend considerable time on platforms like Twitter, primarily communicating via text. This architecture integrates NLP models to gather data efficiently, assisting psychologists in better understanding and treating various mental illnesses. In this work, dataset is obtained from Twitter streaming, and the focus is on classifying tweets containing keywords such as Depression, Anxiety, Sadness, Suicide, death, Stress etc. Models are developed to understand and extract information from English text data, utilizing a suitable deployment architecture to effectively handle data from the Twitter API. This paper focuses on analyzing tweets associated with depression, employing various Machine Learning algorithms for classification such as Support Vector Machine, Logistic Regression, Random Forest, K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN), and Naive Bayes. Through these classifiers, the objective is to identify patterns and gain insights into depression trends by analyzing a mix of tweets. The classifier models demonstrate higher accuracy and better performance metrics for class 0, with precision and recall values generally exceeding 80%. The reliable, balanced dataset achieves the highest accuracy of 85.6% with Random Forest.

title: Novel Blockchain-based, Decentralized, Offline Locking System
authors: Robert Manthey, Richard Vogel, Matthias Baumgart, Marc Ritter, Matthias Vodel
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Facilities with a larger number of buildings and rooms as well as users with different, possibly frequently changing access permissions are a challenging task. Infrastructure for additions, changes and removals must be provided, maintained and secured. Depending on the type of locking device and manufacturer, this can require considerable resources and trust. On the other hand, almost everyone today has a smartphone and, at least for some time, an internet connection to receive information and carry them even to locks at places without infrastructure. Combined with blockchain-technology to protect the information against unauthorized changes, every user can transport permissions to the locks. This realize resource-efficient operability and offline environments as well as timely and uncomplicated manageability of the proposed locking system.

title: Surge Arrester Failure Prediction and Protection in Power Systems: A Review of Simulation, Diagnostics, and Machine Learning Approaches
authors: Siphe Tsutsu, Bongumsa Mendu, Bassie Baakanyang Monchusi, Sumbwanyambe Mbuyu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Surge arresters are safety devices used to protect power system equipment such as switch gears, transmission network grids, and communication systems. They deliver a path to ground in the event of an overvoltage or overcurrent surge. The objective of this work is to execute a review that is dependent on surge arrester failure prediction using machine learning models on event datasets. SCOPUS database keywords used are Surge Arrester or Lightning Arrester, Failure or Fault Diagnosis, or Machine Learning, and Event Data are applied to create pertinent information based on the specified area of vigilance. According to the Scopus database’s inclusion criteria, articles, titles, abstracts, and technical terms with results that are appropriate are the main focus; whilst authors, book chapters, conference reviews, and language (Chinese, French, German, etc.) are excluded. Methods like ATP-EMP prototype, frequency response analysis, and impulse voltage testing are critically applied to understand failure mechanisms under different environmental and functional conditions. This study confirms that electrical equipment is highly significant and needs to be protected against voltage surges to prevent downtime and increase power system reliability, which will be beneficial to power system network grid stakeholders.

title: EvoCAD: Evolutionary CAD Code Generation with Vision Language Models
authors: Tobias Preintner, Weixuan Yuan, Adrian König, Thomas Bäck, Elena Raponi, Niki Van Stein
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Combining large language models with evolutionary computation algorithms represents a promising research direction leveraging the remarkable generative and in-context learning capabilities of LLMs with the strengths of evolutionary algorithms. In this work, we present EvoCAD, a method for generating computer-aided design (CAD) objects through their symbolic representations using vision language models and evolutionary optimization. Our method samples multiple CAD objects, which are then optimized using an evolutionary approach with vision language and reasoning language models. We assess our method using GPT-4V and GPT-4o, evaluating it on the CAD-Prompt benchmark dataset and comparing it to prior methods. Additionally, we introduce two new metrics based on topological properties defined by the Euler characteristic, which capture a form of semantic similarity between 3D objects. Our results demonstrate that EvoCAD outperforms previous approaches on multiple metrics, particularly in generating topologically correct objects, which can be efficiently evaluated using our two novel metrics that complement existing spatial metrics.

title: Energy-Efficient Task Scheduling in Data Centers Using Adaptive Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Dinuț Ionuț-Cosmin, Bogdan Alexandrescu, Rodica-Claudia Constantinescu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: Efficiently managing energy consumption while maintaining low service latency is a critical challenge for modern data centers. This paper presents a novel approach using a Deep Reinforcement Learning (RL) agent, trained with Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), to schedule incoming tasks across multiple servers dynamically. We demonstrate through simulation in a dynamic environment with fluctuating workloads that the proposed RL agent outperforms standard heuristic policies, such as Round-Robin and Least-Loaded, achieving a superior balance between minimizing power consumption and reducing Service Level Agreement (SLA) violations. The results indicate that adaptive RL-based policies are a highly effective and viable solution for intelligent resource management in real-world data center operations.

title: Implementation of RISC-V Processor along with Radix-2 Booth Multiplier Using Verilog
authors: Karthik E, Karamdeep Singh
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: This paper presents the integration of a Radix-2 Booth multiplier within a RISC-V soft-core processor architecture, implemented in Verilog. Unlike traditional approaches that treat the multiplier as an isolated module, our design embeds the Booth multiplier directly into the execution stage of the pipeline, optimizing signed multiplications with reduced cycle latency. We introduce a control-path optimization technique for conditional activation of the multiplier unit, minimizing dynamic power consumption. Verified on FPGA, our implementation demonstrates superior performance compared to multiple open-source RISC-V variants, achieving a delay of 5.95 ns, power consumption of 0.103 µW, and area efficiency with 1123 LUTs and 426 registers. This study highlights the advantages of a tightly coupled Booth multiplier in lightweight, pipelined RISC-V architectures, enhancing performance for edge computing and embedded applications.

title: Producer/Consumer Problems
authors: Sharmi Dev Gupta, Helmut Simonis, Luis Quesada, Barry O'Sullivan
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Interactive constraint systems often suffer from infeasibility (no solution) due to conflicting user constraints. A common approach to recover feasibility is to eliminate the constraints that cause the conflicts in the system. This approach allows the system to provide an explanation as: “if the user is willing to drop some of their constraints, there exists a solution”. However, this form of explanation might not be very informative. A counter-factual explanation is a type of explanation that can provide a basis for the user to recover feasibility by helping them understand what changes can be applied to their existing constraints rather than removing them. We propose an efficient approach NoPropCounter-factualXplain to find counter-factual explanations for infeasible problems. We also propose a version of this algorithm which takes into account preferences called PrefnoPropCounter-factualXplain. We showcase it's usability in real world scenario using the producer/consumer constraint which is useful in problems which involve resource allocation.

title: System Verilog-Based Design and Verification of an Optimized AXI4 Interface for Low-Power FPGA Applications
authors: Swaroop S Harithsa, Vaishnavi Sankar
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: The proposed work demonstrates the implementation and verification of a power-efficient, high-throughput Advanced eXtensible Interface 4 (AXI4) for FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Array) based system on chip designs. Both the AXI Master and Slave modules have been implemented in Verilog and System Verilog with support for burst mode and aggressive transactions. These modules also incorporate power-saving strategies, such as clock gating and adaptive clocking. Compared to standard AXI IP cores, the design delivers approximately 21% lower total power consumption and 32% lower average latency, highlighting its optimization efficiency. The design is rigorously verified using a constrained-random testbench, achieving over 98% functional and 100% assertion coverage. Standard tools such as Questa Sim and EDA Playground are used for simulation and waveform analysis, which validate low-latency, pipelined data handling and verify protocol compliance. The design is validated using randomized constrained testing in System Verilog and synthesized in Xilinx, making it suitable for high-performance embedded systems, including AI, DSP, and real-time computing domains.

title: Transient Power Angle Stability Control for Grid-Forming MMC-HVDC Receiving-End Converter Station Based on MPC
authors: Chenzhi Fang, Yongfeng Ren, Rong Zhu, Bin He, Ruijie Xu, Chengzhang Sun
abstract: To address the issues of power angle instability and oscillations in grid-forming Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC) stations caused by AC grid voltage sags in flexible HVDC transmission systems, this paper proposes a transient power angle stability control strategy based on Model Predictive Control (MPC). Firstly, a grid-forming MMC station model is established. The relationship between active power, output voltage, and power angle stability is analyzed using the Virtual Synchronous Generator (VSG) power angle characteristic. Secondly, building upon conventional droop control, an MPC algorithm is introduced. The algorithm dynamically optimizes the active power command in real time based on power angle deviation and active power deviation. This indirectly achieves adaptive adjustment of the droop coefficients. By compensating for the active power deficit in the system, it effectively suppresses power angle oscillations. Furthermore, it ensures rapid system recovery to stable operation after grid fault clearance. Finally, a corresponding simulation model is developed on the MATLAB/Simulink platform. Time-domain simulations verify the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed control strategy.

title: Unmasking Influence: The Power of Artificial Entities in Shaping Public Opinion on Social Networks
authors: Hani Rabiee, Behrouz Tork Ladani, Ebrahim Sahafizadeh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: With the rise of social networks, powerful actors have increasingly attempted to manipulate public opinion in their favor using various methods, including the deployment of artificial accounts such as bots and trolls. The influence of these artificial entities poses substantial risks to fundamental freedoms, including thought, expression, and decision-making, while also creating significant social, political, cultural, and economic challenges for society. To mitigate this influence, it is essential to identify and analyze the factors that contribute to the effectiveness of artificial entities. Despite significant advancements in recent years in the detection, modeling, and analyzing of the effects of artificial entities, less attention has been paid to the accurate identification of the factors influencing their role in the formation of public opinion. This gap persists, particularly in the context of simultaneously considering both consensus-building and polarization-inducing stimuli. In this study, we try modeling artificial entities in social networks and conduct a series of experiments under various conditions to examine the factors that influence their success. To this end, we also introduce new criteria for assessing the formation of public opinion and the effectiveness of artificial entities, addressing the current lack of suitable metrics in this domain. The study demonstrates that attachment strategy, intelligence level, and lifespan of artificial entities play critical roles in shaping public opinions. We show that even a small presence of artificial entities can lead to consensus, underscoring the importance of their characteristics in shaping public discourse. By understanding the factors that influence the success of artificial entities in manipulating public opinion, policymakers, social network platforms, governing organizations, and individuals can effectively counteract their influences.

title: OTDR Aided Assessment of Fiber-Induced WDM Spectrum Unflatness
authors: Adriana Lipovac, Vlatko Lipovac, Mirza Hamza, Miralem Mehić
abstract: The imperatively excellent performance of wavelength-division multiplexing (WDM) transmission over a fiber optic link, demands flat, i.e. not wavelength-selective transfer function. This implies that, mostly during installation and commissioning of a WDM-aimed fiber link, it is of interest to measure its frequency response, by complex stimulus-response tests using a tunable laser source coupled with an optical spectrum analyzer. On the contrary, a simple and practically costless alternative that we propose here, is testing in time domain by means of the ubiquitous optical time-domain reflectometer (OTDR), considering its distinctly reflective trace pattern as approximation of the fiber channel two-way power-delay profile, whose rms delay spread is the straightforward indicator of the fiber attenuation vs. wavelength characteristics’ unflatness qualifying the fiber as either appropriate for WDM transport, or requiring piecewise “flattening” of the transfer function by applying coherent optical orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (CO-OFDM). Specifically, the proposed OTDR – aided WDM suitability fiber test model applied on the exemplar traces, showed significant peak-to-peak DWDM spectrum unflatness, i.e. the pronounced frequency selectivity strongly indicating the need for introducing CO-OFDM on top of WDM. This was found to be monotonically tracked by the WDM transmission performance – the bit-error rate (BER) values in particular, measured with and without the CO-OFDM applied.

title: A Survey of Accessible Explainable Artificial Intelligence Research
authors: Chukwunonso Henry Nwokoye, Maria J. P. Peixoto, Akriti Pandey, Lauren Pardy, Mahadeo Sukhai, Peter R. Lewis
publish: IEEE Transactions on Technology and Society
abstract: The increasing integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into everyday life makes it essential to explain AI-based decision-making in a way that is understandable to all users, including those with disabilities. Accessible explanations are crucial, as accessibility in technology promotes digital inclusion and allows everyone, regardless of their physical, sensory, or cognitive abilities, to use these technologies effectively. This paper presents a systematic literature review of the research on the accessibility of explainable artificial intelligence (XAI), specifically considering individuals with sight loss. Our methodology includes searching several academic databases with search terms to capture intersections between XAI and accessibility. The results of this survey highlight the lack of research on accessible XAI (AXAI) and stress the importance of including the disability community in XAI development to promote digital inclusion and accessibility and remove barriers. Most XAI techniques rely on visual explanations, such as heatmaps or graphs, which are inaccessible to individuals who are blind or have low vision. Therefore, it is necessary to develop explanation methods through non-visual modalities, such as auditory and tactile feedback; visual modalities accessible to persons with low vision; and personalized solutions that meet the needs of individuals, including those with multiple disabilities. We further emphasize the importance of integrating universal design principles into AI development practices to ensure that AI technologies are usable for everyone. We conclude the paper by discussing what constitutes a good explanation and desiderata for AXAI implementations.

title: Enhancement of Synchronization Accuracy of OFDM-FSO via Triple Autocorrelation Algorithm
authors: Tingwei Wu, Tingting Yuan, Song Song, Lun Zhao, Wenhui Zhu, Weiyu Zhou, Lei Guo
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) synchronization preamble structure and combine it with the triple autocorrelation algorithm to improve the poor accuracy of traditional synchronization algorithms in free space optical (FSO) systems. Our proposed synchronization sequence, optimally designed by building upon the Schmidl-Cox, Minn, and Park algorithms, employs triple autocorrelation operations and reuses two training sequences. This approach effectively enhances synchronization accuracy without extending the total sequence length. Simulation results from a 40-Gb/s FSO communication system show that the proposed algorithm reduces timing synchronization error by 10%-25% under poor channel conditions, demonstrating its superior anti-interference capabilities and robustness.

title: 2HD: Hybrid Dynamic Utility-Driven Dependency-Aware Task Scheduling in Heterogeneous Datacenters
authors: Roxana-Gabriela Stan, Florin Pop
abstract: Most dependency-aware task scheduling algorithms are formulated with an optimization objective of minimizing makespan. In this paper, we directed our research towards algorithms which optimize for early availability of partial output data in heterogeneous computing environments. We proposed a dependency-aware task scheduling model for heterogeneous datacenters, we built the task scheduling algorithms to be able to adapt to the dynamically changing conditions of a realistic heterogeneous system (varying DAG structures, dynamic arrival of task sub-graphs, task-related computing requirements, resource constraints such as limited battery or limited memory for edge resources). We defined the relevant performance metrics, and we continued our efforts to build the 2HD performance evaluation framework that is publicly available for task scheduling experimentation with support for comprehensive parametrization. In this paper, we proposed heuristic-based (2HD and Rand-2HD) and learning-based (QL-2HD) utility-driven DAG task scheduling algorithms to effectively address our research objective. QL-2HD is a Q-learning enhanced variant of 2HD, designed to learn the DAG structure and the properties of a dynamic heterogeneous computing environment. 2HD provides a gain of 47.62% in utility at a cost of 2.13% makespan loss, and QL-2HD provides a gain of 52.11% in utility at a cost of 4.92% makespan loss, when compared to HEFT and other state-of-the-art algorithms on real-world benchmarks (specifically on the Epigenomics and Montage workflows). By performing experiments on a wide range of graphs of various sizes (up to 8000 tasks), we observed that for larger DAG sizes, we get higher utility gains (up to 82.02% for 2HD and up to 87.72% for QL-2HD) at even lower makespan costs. To illustrate the practical benefit of the utility metric, we outlined the actual difference between makespan and the utility-based time at which 50% of the output data is generated by the system, clearly highlighting the efficiency of the 2HD and QL-2HD utility-driven task scheduling algorithms for earlier partial data readiness. Finally, we highlighted multiple use cases in the edge–cloud continuum that would benefit from the improvements provided by the 2HD and QL-2HD utility-driven algorithms, and suggested future work directions.

title: Unleashing the Potential of Industrial IoT and Industry 5.0
authors: Poonam Maurya, Abhishek Hazra, Alakesh Kalita
abstract: The transition to Industry 5.0 emphasizes the need and importance of human–machine collaboration, driving the demand for intelligent Internet of Things (IoT) and communication protocols. This paper examines the essential prerequisites for Industry 5.0, evaluates the existing constraints of IoT communication protocols, and highlights the requirements for industrial convergence. Specifically, the article focuses on and discusses the role of IoT protocols and standards in realizing the key objectives of Industry 5.0 over Industry 4.0. In addition, it outlines a human-centric Industry 5.0 reference architecture designed to support managers and decision-makers through real-time data visibility, predictive maintenance insights, and resource optimization. To this end, we introduce an edge-enabled Industry 5.0 reference architecture and use cases, particularly emphasizing the enhancement of human–machine interaction. This paper also examines the 6TiSCH (IPv6 over the Time-Slotted Channel Hopping mode of IEEE 802.15.4e) wireless network protocol, focusing on its performance evaluation, prospective advantages, and upcoming advancements. Finally, several open research challenges and managerial implications are discussed to achieve Industry 5.0 resolution.

title: Investigating the Effectiveness of Haptic Resistive Force Feedback to Improve Tremors in Parkinson's Disease: A Training Impact Study
authors: Nafees Mahmood, Meldin Bektic, Chen Li, Angela Ridgel, Kwangtaek Kim
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: The goal of this study was to investigate the effectiveness of haptic resistive force feedback in improving the upper limb tremors in Parkinson's Disease (PD) during a button push task. We developed a haptic-mixed reality (HMR) button push simulation system that provides virtual button touch feedback synchronized with mixed reality 3D buttons and various levels of kinesthetic resistance force against hand movements. Two user studies were conducted: one to ensure the system's usability with 25 healthy individuals, and another to measure tremor improvement over a five-day training program with seven individuals diagnosed with idiopathic PD. PD participants were randomly assigned to either a haptic resistive force group or a no haptic resistance group. The results demonstrated that the system provided excellent usability for both healthy and PD participants. Additionally, PD participants in the haptic resistance group showed improvements in tremor and upper bradykinesia levels compared to the no haptic resistance group.

title: An Area-Efficient Noise-Shaping SAR ADC With Parallel-Delayed Sampling
authors: Zhengtao Zhu, Wenjie Wang, Fan Luo, Longbin Zhu, Zhijun Zhou, Keping Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: This brief presents an area-efficient noise-shaping (NS) successive approximation register (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC) employing a parallel-delayed sampling (PDS) technique. PDS samples the residual voltages from multiple ADC conversion cycles to increase the NS effect, without the need for large integration capacitors of the typical cascaded passive integrators. A preamplifier is placed between the sampling capacitors and the integrator to avoid signal attenuation, while further reducing the area of the integrator. PDS and preamplifier introduce two left-half-plane poles to the noise transfer function (NTF) to boost the NS effect, while reducing the impact of the parasitic capacitance to essentially enhance the robustness. A prototype 9-bit NS-SAR ADC is designed in a 130-nm CMOS process. At an oversampling ratio (OSR) of 16, the proposed PDS NS-SAR ADC achieves 80.93-dB peak signal to noise and distortion ratio (SNDR) and provides 4.2 NS/area efficiency factor. It consumes a power of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$23.46~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>W over a bandwidth of 19.53 kHz, achieving a Schreier figure of merit (FoM<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}_{\mathrm {S}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of 170.13 dB.

title: Early Wildfire Detection and Identification in High Depth-of-Field Scenarios Using LWIR Thermal Imaging from Ground-Based Systems
authors: Antonio Galván-Hernández, Víctor Araña-Pulido, Francisco Cabrera-Almeida, Pedro Quintana-Morales
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: This paper presents a novel hybrid framework that integrates spatial and temporal processing techniques for detecting and identifying incipient fires. By combining thermal imaging with a core detector, based on an object detection model, and a secondary detector, leveraging temporal features, the framework significantly enhances the detection of thermal anomalies and the identification of fires using raw Long-Wave Infrared (LWIR) thermal imaging. The framework was tested with different core detectors, trained using the Thermal Anomaly (TA) dataset, on the Fire’s Latent Activity Monitoring and Evaluation through Thermography (FLAME-T) dataset, achieving improvements in mean Average Precision (mAP) and F1 scores of up to 35.9% and 20.9%, respectively, with the addition of the secondary detector. Although these improvements introduced higher processing times, the framework demonstrated its capability to maintain high detection accuracy even on a resource-constrained platform like the Raspberry Pi 5. The proposed novel identification algorithm achieves high classification accuracy for early fires at a significant depth of field, with accuracies of up to 0.913 and identification times of approximately 2 ms, making it suitable for edge applications. The code and data needed to replicate this work are available at: https://github.com/AntonioIDeTIC/IFTH.

title: An Updated Assessment of Reinforcement Learning for Macro Placement
authors: Chung-Kuan Cheng, Andrew B. Kahng, Sayak Kundu, Yucheng Wang, Zhiang Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: We provide an improved assessment of Google Brain’s deep reinforcement learning approach to macro placement [29] and its updated Circuit Training (CT) implementation in GitHub [53]. A stronger simulated annealing (SA) baseline leverages the “go-with-the-winners” metaheuristic [3] and a multi-threading implementation. We develop and release new public benchmarks in sub-10nm technology: LEF/DEF for Google’s 7nm TSMC Ariane protobuf and scaled variants, as well as testcases implemented in the open-source ASAP7 7nm research enablement. We evaluate from-scratch training and fine-tuning results for the latest “AlphaChip” release of Circuit Training, alongside multiple alternative macro placers. We also study the recently-published pre-training guidance in [53]. A commercial place-and-route tool is used to provide “true reward” post-route power, performance and area metrics. All data, evaluation flows and related scripts are publicly available in the MacroPlacement GitHub repository [63]. Our study affords insights into reproducibility and reporting in the research literature, and points out still-missing confirmations (e.g., of CT’s scalability and pre-training methodology) that remain open questions for the research community.

title: Global Trends in Digital Taxation Research: A Bibliometric Study
authors: Hera Khairunnisa, Nayla Nandhita Nuril Hadi, Ayatulloh Michael Musyaffi, Hafifah Nasution, Diah Armeliza
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Taxation is an important aspect of a country’s economy. It often represents the largest component of a nation’s revenue. In the context of research, taxation is frequently studied due to the many existing issues and the potential benefits that tax research can offer. The objectives of this study are (1) to identify research trends in taxation, particularly in tax digitalization, and (2) to explore the potential of taxation research for future studies. The current problem is that taxation is often seen as a specific topic with research applications that are limited and highly dependent on the context of each country. However, tax policies in one country can be adopted by others, especially in terms of using technology to enhance tax revenue and oversight. The benefits of this research are: (1) to describe the trends in tax digitalization research, and (2) to provide insights into potential future research, particularly in tax digitalization. The method used in this research is a quantitative description with bibliometric analysis through VOSViewer with the keyword “Digital Taxation System”. The results of bibliometric analysis with the keyword Digital Taxation Sytem show that there are 8 clusters with 73 items with VOSViewer depth analysis showing a less intense green color which indicates that the topic has not been widely researched and discussed. Hence, there is a great opportunity to research the topic of digital taxation systems in the field of taxation. Considering Indonesia’s ongoing implementation of the Core Tax Administration System (CTAS), significant avenues for future research emerge.
