title: Developing Wolaita Coffee Bean Quality Grading Model Using Deep Learning
authors: Bekele Balta Albako, Temesgen Tadesse Tilahun, Habtamu Fanta Alambo, Eyob Solomon Chinasho
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: Ethiopia produces a wide range of coffee beans. Coffee is the nation’s primary export, a key source of foreign currency, and a vital income source for farmers. However, the approach to classifying the quality of Wolaita coffee beans is an expert observation with the naked eye. This approach is unfeasible due to subjective decisions, proneness to error due to fatigue, excessive processing time, and a smaller number of experts. Therefore, it is critical to automatically classify the quality classification of the Wolaita coffee bean through a model. Thus, this research tackles the challenges of manually classifying the quality of Wolaita coffee beans by developing an effective model. To do so, the 3133 image dataset was collected from the Ethiopian Commodity Exchange (ECX) Wolaita branch, annotated with domain experts, and preprocessed to make the dataset smooth and clean. In an attempt, the study explored custom Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), VGG19, and ResNet50 algorithms. All of the work was done using Python and the supporting libraries. Consequently, an experiment result shows that the VGG19 pre-trained model achieves an accuracy of 99.2% to classify the quality of the Wolaita coffee bean into six grades: G1, G2, G3, G4, G5, and UG (ungraded). Therefore, VGG19 was taken as an effective and robust performance for the quality grading of Wolaita coffee beans. Furthermore, automatically classifying the diverse range of agricultural scenarios and refinement of the model can be a future research direction.

title: Study of Artificial Magnetic Conductor Unit Cell Designs to Enhance Bowtie Antenna Performance
authors: Safia Chenaoui, Lila Mouffok, Sami Hebib
abstract: In this paper, multiple geometries of Artificial Magnetic Conductor (AMC) unit cells are investigated as reflectors to enhance the performance of a wideband bowtie antenna. The proposed AMC reflector consists of an array of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \times 8$</tex> unit cells positioned with a 2 mm air gap from the bowtie antenna. Initially, the bowtie antenna was loaded with a standard square patch AMC reflector, which exhibited a significant dip in gain due to strong surface currents on the AMC surface. To address this issue, the design methodology focused on progressively reducing the surface area of the standard square patch AMC unit cell by modifying its edges, thereby decreasing the surface current distribution. This approach resulted in a wide cross shaped AMC design. To further minimize the current distribution, the surface area of the cross shaped AMC design was further reduced, leading to a thinner cross shaped unit cell. However, the AMC became out of phase. Finally, two conducting T-strips were added to the thin cross shaped AMC design, ultimately developing a modified cross shaped AMC design. The results indicate that the bowtie antenna with the modified cross-shaped AMC reflector demonstrates optimal performance; it exhibits a low profile of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.084 \lambda_{L}$</tex> (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda_{L}$</tex> is the wavelength at the lowest frequency) and a stable gain with 0.85 dB variation over a wide usable bandwidth of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \%(3.9-6.5 \text{GHz})$</tex>. The designed prototype has been manufactured and tested, demonstrating good agreement between the simulated and measured results.

title: Helical Motion of a Particle in a Multilayer Cylindrical Waveguide
authors: M. I. Ivanyan, B. Grigoryan, A. Grigoryan, L. Aslyan, V. Avagyan, H. Babujyan, S. Arutunian, K. Floettmann, F. Lemery
abstract: An algorithm for calculating the radiation field of a charged point particle performing a helical motion in an infinite cylindrical waveguide with a multilayer side wall is found. The number of layers and their filling is arbitrary. The axis of the helical is aligned with the axis of the waveguide, so that the geometry of the problem has cylindrical symmetry. Explicit expressions for modal frequency distributions and equations for resonant frequencies for single-layer and double-layer waveguides are given. Examples of graphical constructions of modal frequency distributions of modes for single-layer (resistive), double-layer (metal-dielectric) and triple-layer (metal-dielectric with internal NEG coating) waveguides are presented.

title: Large Language Model (LLM) based Question and Answering System (QAS): A systematic literature review
authors: Yibrah Gebrewahd Gebretsadkan, Bantamlak Dejene Tegegne, Dereje Senay Merawi, Million Meshesha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: This paper presents systematic literature review on LLM based (QAS). The review showed that the factoid type QAS are the most studied problem. Unlike the traditional QAS, the LLM based QAS are general purpose and have the capability of fine-tuned to specific purpose QAS using different techniques. Currently the LLM based pre-trained models are used to develop different QAS. T5, XLM-R, BERT, and SQuaD are the common models used to develop QAS. There are gaps related to those models, including training time, dataset preparation, computational costs, hallucination, biasness, shortage of high-quality datasets are common issues in the existing LLM based QAS. In general the current state of the art of QAS is the application of LLM which has the capability of supporting multimodality depending on the models used and the techniques applied. The Agentic AI is considered as an example of LLM used in QAS. This Agentic AI has the capability of accepting users query, understanding the users query, selecting an AI agent from a list of AI agents that will be responsible for providing answers to the users query, finally the selected AI agents will act based on the query to provide answer for users query. Using such kind of Agentic AI models for QAS will minimize searching time and optimizes QAS efficiency and effectiveness. Future researchers are expected to develop more effective and efficient QAS, in terms of the quality of answers.

title: Research on Road Safety-Based Wide-Angle RCS Enhancement Flexible Surface
authors: Jia-Hao Wang, Jin Wang, Longjian Zhou, Zongwei Zhan, Qiang-Ming Cai, Xin Cao, Yuyu Zhu
abstract: With the rapid development of intelligent driving technology, intelligent perception system plays a more and more important role in enhancing road safety. Millimeter-wave radar serves as a vital component of intelligent perception systems. However, due to the very small radar cross-section (RCS) of pedestrians, it is challenging for millimeter-wave radar to effectively detect pedestrians in complex urban road environments, where the RCS of vehicles is much greater than that of pedestrians. To address this problem, RCS enhancement surfaces are proposed. However, RCS enhancement surfaces are mainly metasurfaces, which can only enhance the RCS in a specific direction, thus cannot operate effectively when the pedestrians are in different gestures on the road. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a wearable wide-angle RCS enhancement flexible surface that can significantly improve the RCS of pedestrians, thereby providing a more reliable guarantee for road safety. This wide-angle RCS enhancement flexible surface is mainly composed of a flexible material surface, a metallic spherical reflector, and a Luneburg lens array. Simulation results show that, when compared with large metal plate, monostatic RCS enhancement in wideangle range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-65^{\circ}$</tex> to 65° can be achieved in frequency range from 77 GHz to 81 GHz. At the same time, the RCS enhancement flexible surface also has the advantages of lightweight and softness.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Prediction of Ship Maneuvering Dynamics Using Gaussian Process Regression
authors: Ashwini G. Mhatre, Reena Gunjan, Archeesha Kumar Sharma, Selva Balan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The accurate prediction of ship movement is important for optimization of port operations, minimizing delays and enhancing safety. This paper is regarding a novel data oriented machine learning framework to predict ship dynamics using the characteristics of ship, berthing locations and meteorological data. The ship displacements and rotations are predicted by regression based models and further feature engineering is applied to improve accuracy. The model works efficiently in real-world scenarios and is depicted by performance measures such as MSE, RMSE and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The results show that the predictions based on Machine Learning based tools enhance mooring strategies, berth allocation, ship scheduling so that maritime maneuvers are expedited and safe.

title: Dual Layer Spiral Planar Shaped Metamaterial Structure for Circular Polarization
authors: Huma, Farman Ali Mangi, Fatima Ghulam Kakepoto, Umair Rafique, Syed Muzahir Abbas
abstract: A dual layer spiral planar metamaterial structure for circular polarization based on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> array is presented. The design features spiral patterns on the top and bottom layers, twisted at specific angles relative to each other in the XOY plane. This novel structure effectively converts an incident linear-to-circularly polarized wave. Specifically, the impinging wave is transmitted into a right-handed circularly polarized (RHCP) wave from 14.42 GHz-to-16.12 GHz. The large axial ratio bandwidth and improvement of transmission loss for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{xx}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{xy}$</tex>, within a 10% threshold, confirms the achievement of circular polarization. The results demonstrate that the design exhibits excellent performance, such as, transmission efficiency, AR bandwidth and pure circularly polarized wave. This structure shows great potential for applications in designing optical devices and polarization control systems.

title: Handling of Addition and Subtraction Singularities in Surface Triangular
authors: Jia-Ming Yang, Jin Wang, Qiang-Ming Cai, Xin Cao, Longjian Zhou, Haoran Li, Yuyu Zhu, Jun Fan
abstract: In the field of computational electromagnetics (CEM), curved triangle mesh partitioning technology has received widespread attention for its ability to accurately fit the shape of the target surface, and is used to solve complex electromagnetic scattering problems. However, when using methods such as the method of moments for numerical calculations, the coincidence or near coincidence of the source triangle and the field triangle may lead to singularity problems in the integration, seriously affecting the accuracy and efficiency of the calculation. This article proposes an effective method for handling the singularity of surface triangle addition and subtraction. By introducing specific geometric transformations and singular term addition and subtraction techniques, this method successfully solves the singularity problem in surface triangle mesh generation. The experimental results show that this method can significantly improve computational accuracy, reduce computation time, and provide a new and effective means for electromagnetic scattering analysis of complex targets in CEM.

title: TinyML for Acoustic Anomaly Detection in IoT Sensor Networks
authors: Amar Almaini, Jakob Folz, Ghadeer Ashour
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: Tiny Machine Learning enables real-time, energyefficient data processing directly on microcontrollers, making it ideal for Internet of Things sensor networks. This paper presents a compact TinyML pipeline for detecting anomalies in environmental sound within IoT sensor networks. Acoustic monitoring in IoT systems can enhance safety and context awareness, yet cloud-based processing introduces challenges related to latency, power usage, and privacy. Our pipeline addresses these issues by extracting Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficients from sound signals and training a lightweight neural network classifier optimized for deployment on edge devices. The model was trained and evaluated using the UrbanSound8K dataset, achieving a test accuracy of 91% and balanced F1-scores of 0.91 across both normal and anomalous sound classes. These results demonstrate the feasibility and reliability of embedded acoustic anomaly detection for scalable and responsive IoT deployments.

title: An Electromagnetic Compatibility Evaluation Method with AHP-Entropy Weight Fuzzy Comprehensive
authors: Bin Xie, Jiasheng Chen, Yujie Song, Hao-Ran Jiang, Qiang-Ming Cai, Xin Cao, Longjian Zhou, Haoran Li, Zhen-Yong Du, Yixiang Li, Yuyu Zhu, Feng Guo, Jun Fan
abstract: This paper mainly proposes an improved evaluation design method for electromagnetic compatibility systems. In this method, the weight of each evaluation index is first calculated using the analytic hierarchy process (AHP) to reflect its relative importance in the overall assessment. The entropy weight method further quantifies the objective weight of the indices to reduce the impact of subjective judgment. The fuzzy comprehensive evaluation method deals with the uncertainty and fuzziness of the evaluation objects through fuzzy mathematics, transforming qualitative evaluations into quantitative values. By using the fuzzy comprehensive evaluation method, combined with the weights determined by AHP and the entropy weight method, a comprehensive assessment of the electromagnetic compatibility performance of complex electromagnetic propulsion systems is conducted. The improved AHP-entropy weight fuzzy comprehensive evaluation algorithm combines the systematic nature of AHP, the objectivity of the entropy weight method, and the ability of the fuzzy comprehensive evaluation method to handle uncertainty, which can effectively reduce errors caused by subjective and objective factors, providing a new perspective and tool for electromagnetic compatibility assessment. This paper mainly focuses on evaluating a complex electromagnetic system using three EMC design schemes. The improved AHP-entropy weight fuzzy comprehensive evaluation algorithm is used to evaluate and compare the electromagnetic compatibility of these three schemes, ultimately calculating the best electromagnetic compatibility performance, and the calculation results verify the effectiveness of the method.

title: A Novel RFID Temperature Sensor Integrated with Reconfigurable Encoding Structure
authors: Ya Ming Xie, Guo Chun Wan, Mei Song Tong
abstract: Ambient temperature has a significant impact on the health of metallic structures in buildings. This paper proposes an RFID temperature sensor integrated with an encoding structure for Structural Health Monitoring (SHM). By connecting the encoding structure to the transmission line using a varactor diode, the resonant frequency of the encoding structure can be altered by varying the capacitance across the varactor diode, thereby enabling reconfigurable encoding. Simulation results from High Frequency Structural Simulator (HFSS) software reveal a strong linear correlation between the shift in the resonance frequency of the sensor and the temperature parameter, which can be effectively utilized to monitor the ambient temperature of metallic structures. Furthermore, the implementation of five encoding values on a single structure enhances the information capacity of the encoding.

title: Mitigating climate change impact on renewable energy: role of energy efficiency and diversification in sustainability
authors: Alma Ademovic Tahirovic, Hossein Ameli, Goran Strbac
abstract: Environmental pressures have long driven the shift toward non-fossil fuel alternatives in energy systems. However, the impact of climate change on reliability of renewable sources has received limited attention. Brazil’s energy system, dominated by hydropower (71%), faces increasing strain from prolonged dry conditions and growing peak demand. Only half of this hydro capacity is reservoir-type dispatchable, increasing reliability concerns. While expansions in wind, solar, and natural gas have been pursued, they introduce volatility and logistical complexity, with imposed constraints of domestic reserves and imports. Biomass emerges as a flexible and viable alternative, particularly in decentralized applications. It offers emission reductions and cost savings when derived from locally sourced agricultural residues, in form of biogas and biomethane energy streams. This paper applies the extended Combined Gas and Electricity Network model to assess infrastructure interdependencies and diversification strategies under Brazil’s energy transition. Results show that small-scale biomass, paired with energy efficiency and demand management, enhances resilience. Energy efficiency, despite higher upfront costs, provides long-term savings and emission reductions. The findings highlight the need for diversified, low-emission strategies with energy conservation as the foundation of sustainable development.

title: Novel Principle of Reactive to True Power Conversion for AI, Data Centers, and BTC Mining
authors: Miguel Lopes, Nuno Neto, Tyler Thurmond, László Juhász
abstract: The exponential rise of AI, data centers, and other non-linear loads is burdening the global electrical grid, requiring the delivery of record levels of electricity. Such power converter-based loads inject reactance (e.i. harmonics, stray currents, and distorted power) across the AC distribution system, resulting in equipment breakdown, expensive downtime, and reduced energy efficiency. The paper presents a novel passive-parallel method for converting reactive and distorted power into true power, utilizing a proprietary magnetic field-based technique that deviates from the conventional passive-active harmonic filter. Real world case studies validate the method’s ability to improve overall power quality, power utilization efficiency (PUE), and other electrical parameters by double digits.

title: An Analog Front-End Circuit with Walk Error Compensation for 4D LiDAR Imaging Sensors
authors: Jianping Guo, Xiaoyang Zeng, Wenhong Li, Mingyu Wang
abstract: This paper presents an Analog Front-End (AFE) circuit designed for Linear-Mode Avalanche Photodiode (LM-APD) Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) sensors. This AFE circuit introduces two advancements to the LiDAR receiver: (I) simultaneous acquisition of Time-of-Flight (ToF) and light intensity information, enabling 4D (x, y, range, intensity) imaging when implemented with an array; and (II) significant reduction in walk error, which directly impacts ranging precision. A compensation method utilizing echo light intensity is also proposed. It achieves a walk error below 259 ps within the photocurrent range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mu ~\mathrm{A}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$96 \mu ~\mathrm{A}$</tex>, reducing the walk error by an order of magnitude compared to the uncompensated case. The AFE circuit was designed using 110 nm CMOS process, with 1.75 mW power consumption. The feasibility of the 4D imaging system and walk error compensation method was verified by simulations.

title: Understanding Inter-Microgrid Operation for Power Sharing in a Multi-Microgrid System
authors: Jyoti Ranjan Baral, Malabika Basu, Michael Conlon
abstract: This paper investigates mutual power sharing between neighbouring microgrids (MGs) to enhance system reliability and resilience. A droop-based supervisory control strategy is implemented to achieve proportional power sharing among inverters within and between MGs. A coupling and decoupling strategy is formulated to regulate the interconnection of two microgrids, facilitating seamless transitions while maintaining frequency deviations within 0.2 Hz during coupling and voltage variations below 60V. Simulation results in MATLAB/Simulink indicate that the proposed approach fosters effective power sharing while maintaining voltage and frequency within acceptable limits across diverse load conditions, achieving nearly equal power distribution between the two microgrids and ensuring stable operation during coupling and decoupling events. This validates the practicality of applying traditional islanded microgrid control methods to multi-microgrid (MMG) systems for enhanced power management.

title: ScholarMatch: AI-Powered Hybrid Platform with Real Time Data Integration
authors: Rajesh Phursule, Shreya Lokare, Shraddha Gavkare, Vasudha Shivane
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: In today's rapidly evolving educational landscape, identifying and securing appropriate scholarship opportunities has become an increasingly challenging task due to the vast and fragmented availability of information. This research addresses this gap by developing a personalized scholarship recommendation system that integrates state-of-the-art web scraping, machine learning, and advanced natural language processing (NLP) techniques. Our approach systematically aggregates up-to-date scholarship data from diverse online sources, ensuring a comprehensive and reliable dataset for subsequent analysis. Machine learning algorithms dynamically match student profiles with relevant scholarship opportunities, while NLP methods extract and structure complex eligibility criteria from unstructured text, thereby enhancing the overall precision of recommendations. Preliminary evaluations reveal that our hybrid system significantly improves recommendation accuracy and efficiency, outperforming traditional search methods in terms of precision and recall. These results indicate that leveraging LLM capabilities is a superior choice for delivering scalable, intelligent, and personalized scholarship recommendations. Ultimately, our system streamlines the scholarship search process and empowers students to make informed decisions regarding their educational funding, thereby enhancing access to educational opportunities and supporting academic success. The system's practical application in realtime scholarship recommendation settings was demonstrated by its preliminary evaluation, which revealed an 80 % recommendation accuracy, 78 % precision, 82 % recall, and an average response time of 1.5 seconds.

title: New Bessel-Bessel-Gaussian Beams with High Rotation Speed
authors: A. A. Kovalev, E. G. Abramochkin, E. S. Kozlova, V. V. Kotlyar
abstract: This paper introduces a novel family of Bessel-Bessel-Gaussian (BBG) beams, characterized by a complex amplitude formed as the product of a Gaussian function and two Bessel functions with distinct arguments. Through theoretical analysis and numerical simulations, we demonstrate that these beams exhibit anomalously high rotational speed, with their intensity patterns rotating by nearly 45 degrees over propagation distances much shorter than the Rayleigh length. Furthermore, we show that the topological charge (TC) of the BBG beams can be dynamically controlled by tuning a single parameter, enabling precise adjustment of the beam's phase structure. These unique properties highlight the potential of BBG beams in applications such as optical microscopy, where rapid intensity rotation enhances longitudinal resolution, and in optical trapping, where tunable vorticity and intensity profiles enable non-destructive manipulation of particles.

title: AI-Powered Legal Document Analyzer Using Mistral- 7B and Gradio Interface
authors: Samiksha Waman, Prof. Rohini Pise
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: As legal documents grow in complexity and in length, there comes an ever-increasing demand for an intelligent tool capable of helping legal professionals to efficiently review and analyze such content. This hereby-proclaimed Legal Document Analyzer sets itself apart by engineering an AI mechanism that combines the prowess of the Mistral-7B large language model with a sleek Gradio interface for ease of use. Uploading of PDF files is supported, making such tasks that used to be done by hand-aided contractors' review, legal research, risk assessment, or compliance-a piece of cake. In this manner, under the IoT conception of operation, mid-range hardware such as graphic cards on laptops can be used to retain the power necessary in running the model-4-bit quantization is implemented from the Bits And Bytes library-for the best trade-off between performance and computational efficiency. Our study concludes that this tool provides accurate, fast, and easy-to-use support for legal professionals, students, and researchers towards the educational realm and the more preliminary stages of an enterprise.

title: Enhancing IoT Device Security Using Zeroknowledge Proofs: A Privacy-Preserving Authentication Approach
authors: Rupali C. Kothawade, Aditya Mourya, Vinayak Musale, Saloni Kumbhar, Amruta Amune, Madhuri Rao
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: The exponential growth of IoT devices has created unprecedented security challenges, particularly in device authentication where traditional methods expose sensitive credentials and lack scalability. This paper presents a comprehensive authentication framework integrating ZeroKnowledge Proofs (ZKPs) with Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) to achieve privacy preserving device authentication. Our framework employs zk- SNARKs for efficient proof generation and verification while leveraging PUF-derived hardware-rooted identities for unclonable device fingerprints. Experimental evaluation demonstrates 20 % energy reduction compared to RSA-2048, 19ms verification time, and 100% success rate across varying environmental conditions. The framework supports over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> devices per verifier node while maintaining strong security against replay attacks, device impersonation, and physical tampering.

title: Secure and Efficient Bus Ticketing System
authors: Madhavi Repe, Nilakshee Rajule, Komal Vibhute, Janhvi Dhummansure, Aashna Tahilramani
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: This research work presents a novel, secure, and efficient RFID-enabled bus ticketing system using ESP32 microcontrollers, RFID technology, and GPS. The proposed system streamlines the ticketing process by enabling contactless fare collection without physical tickets through RFID-enabled cards. These cards are scanned at boarding to ensure fast and accurate ticket validation. The integration of GPS allows real-time bus location tracking, improving route monitoring and providing passengers with live updates. The system also includes encrypted communication to secure transaction data and permits real-time observation of passenger numbers, fare collection, and bus locations. Experimental results show a significant improvement, with a 35 % increase in operational efficiency and a 25 % reduction in human error compared to traditional methods, saves environment through contactless ticketing enhancing the overall passenger experience. The proposed RFID system achieves ∼92% accuracy, surpassing traditional methods at ∼85%. The proposed system is able to identify the traffic areas 99 % and helps in immediate action to increase the bus frequency in such areas.

title: Enhanced Melanoma Skin Cancer Detection Through Ensemble of Thepade's SBTC and GLCM Features Using Machine Learning
authors: Minal Shahakar, Panakaj Kaname, Rohan Patil, Om Mahajan, Deep Navle
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Melanoma, a type of skin cancer, often develops due to sun exposure and genetic factors. Its increasing prevalence, especially among young people, highlights the urgent need for better detection and treatment methods. Early detection of melanoma is crucial because it can quickly extend to different body parts if not caught and treated promptly. Melanoma spreads rapidly and becomes very dangerous if not addressed early. Detecting melanoma early greatly increases the chances of successful treatment, but if it's found late, it can become uncontrollable and impossible to cure. Identifying melanoma visually can be challenging. Melanoma can also appear in different shapes and forms, making it harder to recognize. Various techniques are available for detecting melanoma. This paper uses the HAM-10000 Dataset and proposes a method to improve melanoma detection using machine learning classifiers. We combine Thepade's SBTC and GLCM for feature extraction. Experimental results show that the optimized results came from the fusion of multilayer perceptron and random forest algorithm, achieving an accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 8. 4 6 \%$</tex>.

title: AI-Driven Optical Intelligence for Modern Warfare Command and Control
authors: Rahul Chougule, Varad Patil, Amey Rane, Monika Mangla, Pravin Hole, Monali Sankhe
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: Modern warfare is increasingly driven by real-time intelligence, precision strikes, and rapid decision-making, where traditional surveillance models often fail to provide the necessary balance between resolution, coverage, and computational efficiency. In the era of electronic warfare, where cyber and signal-based attacks can disrupt conventional systems, AI-driven drone surveillance offers a resilient and adaptive solution for real-time reconnaissance and threat detection. Our proposed AI-driven drone surveillance framework overcomes these limitations by integrating advanced optical intelligence with dynamic GIS plotting, enabling adaptive altitude adjustments based on mission-critical parameters. This ensures optimal spatial accuracy, stealth, and real-time data processing, making it superior to existing models that struggle with efficiency and precision. Leveraging deep learning-based object detection, photogrammetric calculations, and geospatial analytics, our approach accurately translates pixel coordinates into real-world locations using camera intrinsic and extrinsic parameters. Homography and triangulation refine object localization, while distortion corrections minimize errors in measurement. Finally, real-time GIS mapping continuously updates drone telemetry, enhancing situational awareness, target tracking, and strategic planning. This integration marks a significant advancement in ISR capabilities, ensuring faster threat detection, improved battlefield intelligence, and higher mission success rates.

title: Automated PCB Defect Detection and Quality Assurance System Using Image Processing
authors: Sumedh S. Deshmukh, Yogesh S. Nirve, Sharad A. Tichkule, Rohan G. Pawar, Archana Dongardive, Kiran Patil
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Control and Automation (ICCCBEA)
abstract: This project, “Automated PCB Defect Detection and Quality Assurance System using Image Processing,” is an AI-based solution that detects defects in Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs) at high speed and precision. The system is industrial in nature, where users can <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\log$</tex> in and upload images of PCBs for checking. The system starts with checking if the uploaded image is of a PCB or not using the YOLO (You Only Look Once) algorithm, which supports real-time object detection. The image is then transformed to grayscale, which simplifies and speeds up processing. Template matching is then implemented to match the reference defect-free image with the input image to determine areas of mismatch. To prevent unwanted data and false positives, heuristic filtering is implemented. YOLO Class Map Check is then employed to label and classify certain defect types, i.e., missing holes, spurious copper, open circuits, and shorts, on the output image directly. One of the most important features of the system is its AI advisory module, which gives insight into potential reasons for each defect and recommends the necessary corrective measures, helping quality control engineers in decision-making. The analytics dashboard provides real-time metrics on total scans, OK and defective PCBs, and a detailed defect report table exportable as PDF for audits and records. This project is significant since it automates a historically manual, timeconsuming, and error-prone inspection process. The system proved highly accurate and efficient during testing and showed great promise for real-time use in PCB production lines. Through minimizing human error and maximizing throughput, the solution plays an important role in smart manufacturing and product reliability improvement.

title: A Hybrid LBM-FVM Solver for Simulating Multiphase Multi-Component Fluids
authors: Lin Ding, Xiaopei Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Multiphase and multi-component fluid flows are highly intricate, exhibiting dynamic behaviors that challenge conventional simulation methods, especially across a wide range of operating conditions. Adding fluid-solid interactions further escalates this complexity, requiring simulations that are both physically accurate and computationally more tractable. Existing methods often fall short in aspects of either accuracy, efficiency, or stability, and sometimes may also consume excessive memory, rendering them unsuitable for many practical applications. In this paper, we introduce a novel, more practical solution combining a collision-enhanced lattice Boltzmann method with a finite-volume approach. This hybrid solver is designed to effectively simulate multiphase, multi-component flows via the phase-field modeling with a novel wetting boundary treatment in the finite-volume framework, while significantly reducing memory consumption. It enables simulations of multiple fluid phases under varied conditions, capturing rich interfacial behaviors. Additionally, it incorporates an immersed-boundary method to efficiently handle complex fluid-solid interactions. Validation tests confirm that our method produces physically consistent results and demonstrates accuracy across multiple evaluations. We provide comprehensive simulation results, along with comparisons of memory consumption and efficiency, highlighting the practical utility and superiority of our solver over conventional methods.

title: Hybrid Magnetic Systems for Quantum Frequency Conversion
authors: Maksut Maksutoğlu, Erdem Demirci, Eren Doğan, Sinan Kazan, Ibrahim S. Ünver, Farkhad Zaynullin, Talha Bozkurt, Hacer Ipek, N. Güneş Sarıbaş, Hasan Pişkin, Fikret Yıldız, Georgy Mozzhukhin, Bulat Rameev
abstract: Microwave-to-optical quantum transduction is a critically important task in the field of quantum information and communication technologies. Hybrid Quantum Systems (HQS), consisting of different interacting subsystems, are believed to be a physical base for the realization of quantum frequency conversion. HQSs based on magnetically ordered materials look like a very prospective solution due to the strong coupling between MW photons and magnetic oscillations. Another approach is based on rare-earth (RE) ions doped in crystals, which potentially provides an efficient way for magneto-optical quantum coherence transfer. In this work, we review approaches for quantum transduction based on both classes of materials (magnon- and RE-based). We analyze their specific features and compare the strong and weak sides of each material class. The possibility interfacing or combining these two approaches in a single device is also considered as well as the technical challenges of the practical realization of such a hybrid system.

title: High-Performance UVB and Far-UVC LEDs on Sapphire Aiming for Inactivation of Viruses and Bacteria
authors: M. Ajmal Khan, Mitsuhiro Muta, Hiromitsu Sakai, Yukio Kashima, Hiroyuki Yaguchi, Yasushi Iwaisako, Hideki Hirayama
abstract: AlGaN-based far-ultraviolet C light-emitting diodes (far-UVC LEDs) and ultravioletB (UVB) LEDs have a wide range of applications to kill viruses and bacteria, and a large market is expected. However, the efficiency of far-UVC LEDs is still much lower than that of blue LEDs due to the quite low light-extraction efficiency (LEE) and hole injection efficiency. We investigated the influence of Al-compositionally graded Mg-doped multi-quantum-barrier electron-blocking-layer (Al graded p-MQB EBL) and Al-compositionally graded Mg-doped p-AlGaN hole injection layer (HIL) on the carrier injection toward the active region of UVB LED. The external quantum efficiency (EQE) of the world record 10 % and light output power of 42 mW on bare-wafer under continuouswave operation at room temperature in the absence of standard package, flip-chip, and resin-like lenses are achieved. These improvements are attributed to the use of transparent Al -graded Mg doped p-AlGaN HIL and p-MQB EBL structure for hole transport toward the multi-quantum wells via intra-band tunneling mechanisms. Using Al-graded p-MQB EBL coupled with softly polarized p-AlGaN HIL and the highly reflective 0.4 nm -thick Ni and 200 nm -thick Al p-electrode in the UVB LED were combined effect on EQE. In the case of AlGaN-based far-UVC emission, the influence of the n -AlGaN buffer layer's growth temperature on its relaxation and electrical properties in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$228{-}$</tex> 230 nm far-UVC LED is also investigated. Quite a low contact resistivity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho_{c}$</tex>) of 0.05Ω - <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{cm}^{2}$</tex> on the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{n}-\text{AlGaN}$</tex> contact layer was also achieved. The low relaxation ratio is critical for the suppression of transverse magnetic (TM)-mode as well as for promoting transverse electric (TE)-mode emission (along the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$c$</tex>-axis). Finally, the power and EQE were significantly improved to a record value of 2.2 mW and 0.42 % under pulse operation and 1.4 mW and 0.41 % under CW operation on wafer at RT. This is the highest value of EQE in far-UVC LED grown on c-Sapphire.

title: Image Captioning in Amharic Language using Deep Convolutional Neural Networks with LSTM
authors: Samuel Ashagrre Guigsa, Tesfahun Nurrie Mengestie, Mikru Lake Melie, Yohannes Sefane Molla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for Development for Africa (ICT4DA)
abstract: Image captioning has become one of the important areas of research that automatically produces comprehensible natural language descriptions of visual content, especially static images, by integrating computer vision and NLP components. The discipline has seen considerable works done through deep learning architectures, recurrent neural networks and, more recently, vision-language pre-training paradigms. Image captioning is one of the challenging applications of machine learning, especially when describing images in low-resource languages. In this paper, a multilayer CNN-LSTM network is designed for recognizing objects in an image and providing Amharic captions of the same. For the experiment, we have created a manually annotated Amharic version of the Flickr8k dataset. Based on the proposed methodology for a caption generation task, we develop a pre-trained deep learning model combining visual feature extraction and sequence generation. To find out the best model, we did experiments with several model variations by tuning key parameters such as embedding size, epoch, Dropout for encoder and decoder, and dense layer. Performance of the presented system is evaluated using BLEU. Our best model uses an LSTM with embedding size of 256, Dropout for encoder and decoder of 0.4, and deterministic generation, that achieves a BLEU-1 score of 0.529174 and a BLEU-2 value of 0.335369, showing LSTMs can perform quite well for automatic image annotation.

title: Hybrid Knowledge Distillation for Generalizable Lightweight Models in Medical Image Recognition
authors: Yu-Ting Lai, Cheng-Yan Huang, Tsung-Hsuan Lee, Ting-Yu Lin, Nai-Zhen Lin, Chiao-Wen Kao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Fuzzy Theory and Its Applications (iFUZZY)
abstract: This study addresses the challenge of deploying accurate yet computationally efficient models for medical image recognition. We propose a hybrid knowledge distillation (KD) strategy that integrates both response-based and feature-based approaches. The method strengthens a lightweight student network by enabling it to learn from a deeper teacher model, with joint optimization guided by a dual-loss function (cross-entropy and temperature-scaled KL divergence) and a feature alignment module. This approach ensures the student model not only learns the final prediction logic but also captures critical mid-level representations and focuses on key anatomical regions, thereby achieving high accuracy and generalization while maintaining a low computational footprint. The proposed method was systematically validated across homogeneous and heterogeneous network architectures, utilizing ResNet families as exemplars. Initial evaluations on CIFAR-10 confirmed the synergistic benefits of our hybrid approach compared to single-modality KD. Subsequently, the strategy was applied to the OCT2017 ophthalmic dataset, where it achieved a remarkable 98.76% accuracy and high recall, demonstrating its strong potential for practical applications such as pre-clinical screening and edge device deployment. This work provides a robust framework for developing generalizable lightweight models for medical imaging. Future research will explore the application of this method to larger-scale and more diverse medical imaging modalities, and further validate its efficacy in actual clinical workflows and segmentation tasks.

title: Physical Health Improvement in First Year Undergraduate Students Under Mentoring Scheme
authors: Nehal K. Dave, Hiren R. Kavathiya
abstract: For first-year undergraduate students, making the move from high school to college entails major changes in their academic, social, and personal lives. The preservation of physical health frequently takes a backseat among these modifications. Many academic institutions have implemented mentorship programs designed to help students completely in order to solve this issue. This study examines whether mentorship programs may improve the physical health of first-year college students. This study uses a mixed-methods approach to evaluate the association between mentorship programs and improvements in physical health by combining quantitative surveys and qualitative interviews. Through the use of a questionnaire, information was gathered to assess changes in physical health-related behaviors including exercise frequency and nutritional preferences. Results show that mentorship programs have a beneficial impact on first-year undergraduate students' physical health. Data from the survey show that participants' participation with healthy lifestyle choices has significantly improved, including their frequency of exercise and dietary habits. Mentorship may improve one's quality of life while also helping first-year undergraduate students succeed by boosting their physical wellness.

title: Counterfactual Explanations for k-Means and Gaussian Clustering
authors: Georgios Vardakas, Antonia Karra, Evaggelia Pitoura, Aristidis Likas
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Counterfactuals have been recognized as an effective approach to explain classifier decisions. In this work, we focus on the use of counterfactuals to explain clustering solutions. First, we present a general definition for counterfactuals for model-based clustering that includes plausibility and feasibility constraints. Then we consider the counterfactual generation problem for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-means and Gaussian clustering assuming Euclidean distance. Our approach takes as input the factual, the target cluster, a binary mask indicating actionable or immutable features and a plausibility factor specifying how far from the cluster boundary the counterfactual should be placed. In the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-means clustering case, analytical mathematical formulas are presented for computing the optimal solution, while in the Gaussian clustering case (assuming full, diagonal, or spherical covariances) our method requires the numerical solution of a nonlinear equation with a single parameter only. We demonstrate the advantages of our approach through illustrative examples and quantitative experimental comparisons.

title: Joint Learning for Efficient German Argument Mining
authors: Lorenz Wendlinger, Ramona Kühn, Jelena Mitrović, Michael Granitzer
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: We propose a lightweight and adaptable model tailored to German argument mining in two dissimilar domains. It offers improvements over the state-of-the-art, as well as over recent LLM approaches. Specifically, we achieve an 11.5 % absolute improvement across all classes of the SPWSLE dataset as well as 3.5% absolute detection performance boost across all datasets of the CIMT collection. We show that for both tasks, the hitherto disjoint steps of argument detection followed by argument classification can be merged with no loss in quality, resulting in a greater than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 x$</tex> training and inference speed-up. For the naive baseline, this joint scheme also significantly improves results. For CIMT we propose realistic evaluation that incorporates actual detection results instead of simulating perfect detection. We also investigate the transferability between and to new datasets and find it to be higher than in previous work and in certain cases even better than within the dataset. A super model trained on all other datasets adapts to unseen data without re-training or performance loss.

title: Gaussian Mixture Model-Driven Scenario Analysis and Human-Centered Performance Assessment for Autonomous Photovoltaic-Battery Electric Vehicles Charging Stations
authors: Fadila Barkat, Josep M. Guerrero, Ioan Viorel Banu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: The rise of electric vehicles (EVs) and renewable integration such as photovoltaic (PV) sources has made autonomous PV-powered battery EVs (BEVs) charging stations (PVCSs) an essential solution for sustainable electrified transportation. This work presents an original study of such PVCSs, leveraging Gaussian mixture model (GMM) scenario creation, human-in-the-loop analytics, and state-of-the-art Matlab modeling. The originality consists in combining realistic behavioral scenario generation, robust state-of-charge (SOC) and load supervision, and a suite of new visual figures for transparent, user-centric academic evaluation. The “human-in-the-loop” approach, which involves incorporating real-world user behaviors and unpredictability into the computer simulation, is a significant aspect of this research. By capturing daily/behavioral dynamics, renewable energy sources fluctuation, and storage effects across five analytics figures, it has been demonstrated how smart controls and data-driven insights can enhance self-sufficiency and robustness. Results highlight the design trade-offs, detect potential vulnerabilities, and demonstrate the viability of off-grid PVCSs even under human behavioral uncertainty.

title: FiLSTM: Fuzzy Rule Induction for LSTM Model: The Case of Predictive Maintenance
authors: Abdelouadoud Kerarmi, Assia Kamal-Idrissi, Loubna Benabbou, Amal El Fallah Seghrouchni
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Predictive Maintenance (PdM) is crucial in manufacturing, enabling early detection of equipment failures and optimized maintenance to improve reliability and reduce costs. Yet, extracting accurate and explainable predictions from complex time-series data remains challenging. Deep learning models such as Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks offer strong predictive power but act as ‘black boxes,’ while fuzzy systems provide interpretability but lack robustness in dynamic industrial settings. To address these limitations, recent studies have integrated fuzzy inference with LSTMs. In this paper, we propose FiLSTM (Fuzzy Rule Induction for LSTM), a hybrid model that leverages Decision Trees to generate fuzzy rules and membership functions directly from data. This approach enhances both interpretability and prediction, achieving higher accuracy, faster computation, and lower execution time compared to FLSTM. FiLSTM advances PdM systems toward real-time, scalable, and transparent industrial applications.

title: Extending the Capabilities of MATLAB and Signal Processing Toolbox for Generating Digital Signals
authors: Adriana Borodzhieva
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Energy Efficiency and Agricultural Engineering (EE&amp;AE)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive approach to extending the capabilities of MATLAB and Signal Processing Toolbox for the advanced generation of digital signals. By integrating custom scripts and dynamic visualization techniques, we demonstrate how MATLAB can evolve into a more versatile platform for signal design, transformation, and analysis. The proposed methodologies support a wide spectrum of applications, ranging from communications and biomedical signal processing to audio engineering and real-time systems. Practical examples and benchmarks illustrate improvements in flexibility, performance, and usability. These enhancements pave the way for more intuitive workflows and deeper insights into digital signal behavior, making MATLAB a more powerful environment for both academic research and industrial development.

title: Design of a Mechanical-Thermal Cam Device for Rolled Fondant Softening by Numerical Simulation
authors: Esteban Rodríguez, George Pauccar, José Carrizales, Julio Ronceros, Luis Sampen, Ayrton Nieves
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering (ICECCME)
abstract: This paper presents the design and validation of a novel mechanical-thermal system for automated softening of rolled fondant in confectionery. Manual softening suffers from ergonomic risks, inconsistent pressure application, and long processing times. The proposed device integrates stainless-steel heated rollers (internal temperature $40{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$) with a progressive compression mechanism driven by four rotating symmetric cams. Thermal and structural performance were evaluated via finite-element simulation in ANSYS fluent and ANSYS Mechanical. A theoretical heat-transfer model predicted a power requirement of 66.23 W to maintain a roller surface temperature of $35{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, closely matching the simulation result of 65.26 W (1.5% deviation). Theoretical analysis revealed a contact pressure of 0.21 MPa (0.1% of stainless-steel yield strength), while the simulation resulted 0.247 MPa, and a maximum stress of 1.5 MPa under cyclic loading with peak deformations below $10^{-8} \mathrm{~m}$. An experimental assessment of an operating torque of $\mathbf{5. 7 4 ~ N m}$ (safety factor 1.5), informing motor and transmission sizing. These findings validate the system’s ability to deliver uniform, repeatable fondant softening while improving ergonomics, confirming effectiveness of the integrated thermal-mechanical design.

title: Adaptive Quadruped Spider Bot: Enhancing Environmental Perception and Mobility for Complex Terrain Navigation
authors: Pavithra S, Thriam Bakesvar B, Sanjaykrishnaa R S, Sena Abhishek S, Gopiyanantham M
publish: 2025 First International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Communication Systems (CICCS)
abstract: This paper introduces a new quadruped spider bot that is installed with a mini remote Bluetooth camera that helps in increase perception of the environment and movement through rough terrains. While the wheeled rover usually fails to move around obstacles or on a rough surface, the quadruped spider bot is adaptive in its limb structure to be stable and mobile in the obstacle course. The incorporation of a high-resolution Bluetooth camera enables live space and physical barrier surveillance, offering extremely valuable, real time visual feedback into the navigation plan. This capability can overcome the drawback of wheeled robots, in which robots face problems of terrain along with assessment of environment. The mobility of the spider bot is enhanced by its sense system, allowing it to maneuver in rough terrains, and thus more appropriate for rescue, exploration activities or for the physical inspection of remote areas. In the light of the above-discussed findings, this study fills the existing research gap in environmental perception as well as adaptive navigation to enhance advanced characteristics of robotic systems for multifaceted and complex applications. This paper describes the design, construction, and improvement analysis of the quadruped spider bot, it shows that the quadruped spider bot has better mobility and perceptual ability than wheeled robots.

title: Investigating Dynamic Example Selection for ICL-Based Text-to-SPARQL Generation
authors: Carlos Eduardo A. Ferreira, Basil Ell, Martin Giese, Joel L. Carbonera
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Knowledge Graph Question Answering (KGQA) aims to generate factual answers to natural language (NL) questions by querying structured data in knowledge graphs (KGs). This study investigates the use of in-context learning (ICL) for text-to-SPARQL generation, focusing on how the number, similarity, and diversity of prompt examples can affect an LLM' performance when applied to the text-to-SPARQL task. We conducted experiments using the LC-QuAD 1.0 benchmark and a 70B-parameter instruction-tuned LLM, exploring multiple dynamic example selection strategies based on BERT embeddings. We evaluated performance based on the retrieved answers and the structural similarity of the queries. We found that adding similar examples to the prompt enhanced performance; however, the gains became minimal beyond approximately ten examples. Contrary to our initial hypothesis, diversity did not yield the expected improvements. We also conducted an error analysis and further experiments, revealing a recurring issue: even when gold URIs are provided, the models often generate fake URIs, and additional problems persist.

title: Iteration, Mother of Transferability: A Study of Black-Box Iterative Adversarial Attacks Across CNNs and Vision Transformers
authors: Michail Alexiou, Sachin Sharma, Matthew Mickelson, Sukarno J. Mertoguno
publish: 2025 IEEE 37th International Conference on Tools with Artificial Intelligence (ICTAI)
abstract: Deep learning models have become central to many computer vision tasks, yet their vulnerability to adversarial attacks-particularly in black-box settings-remains a significant concern. Iterative attacks such as I-FGSM and PGD are commonly used to strengthen perturbations, but their ability to transfer across different architectures remains underexplored. In this paper, we present a systematic evaluation of adversarial transferability across both closely related architectures–Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Dilated CNN–and fundamentally different ones-CNN and Vision Transformer (ViT)-using both high-resolution (ANIMAL5) and low-resolution (FMNIST) datasets. To capture the impact of attack configuration, we vary the perturbation size <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\epsilon)$</tex>, step size (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex>) and number of iterations. Our results show that iterative attacks tend to overfit to the source model and that their transferability decreases as the number of steps increases. This effect is further amplified when architectural differences such as dilation or attention mechanisms are present. Higher <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\epsilon$</tex> values partially compensate for this drop in transferability, providing marginal improvement across settings. In addition, we show that increasing input resolution reduces transferability for CNN and Dilated CNN-based targets, whereas ViTs maintain strong transferability even from low-resolution inputs when global structure is preserved. These findings indicate that architectural generalization, rather than iterative strength alone, is a key driver of adversarial transferability.
